site_title: Australia's biggest department store chain Myer slashes sales target
summary: Myer Holdings Ltd, Australia's biggest department store chain, slashes its sales growth target to 10% over three years due to intense competition and lacklustre consumer spending. The company reported a 2.8% decline in total sales for the 13 weeks to October 28, with online sales jumping 68% but remaining a small fraction of overall revenue. Major shareholder Solomon Lew has pressed the company for board seats, sparking speculation of a potential takeover, which has sent the company's share price sharply lower.

site_title: China's 1st offshore nuclear reactor to be finished soon
summary: China is set to complete its first offshore nuclear reactor soon, bolstering Beijing's maritime ambitions and raising concerns about the potential militarization of disputed island territories in the South China Sea. The reactor, being developed by China Shipbuilding Industry Corporation and other state-owned companies, will provide reliable electricity to oil and gas rigs and remote islands. The project aims to support China's goal of becoming a "strong maritime power" by 2020, but experts warn that the technology could raise safety and security questions.

site_title: Looking ahead to 2018
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face a mixed bag in 2018, with a steady economy but challenges from uncertainty, e-commerce, and potential Chinese demand drops. To stay ahead, businesses must adopt a sound strategy to build capability, go digital, and expand overseas. Forward-looking SMEs are preparing for 2018 by expanding globally, investing in digitalization, and adapting to changing market conditions. Experts emphasize the need for agility and boldness to navigate the rapidly changing business landscape.

site_title: IMDA to seek proposals for parcel locker network in Punggol, Bukit Panjang
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) plans to deploy a parcel locker network in Punggol and Bukit Panjang by the end of 2018, with a pilot launch in the second half of the year. The network will be interoperable and provide secured access to the lockers. The pilot will last for six to 12 months. This is part of the government's Industry Digital Plan for the logistics sector, aimed at supporting economic restructuring.

site_title: Shell opens new lubricants facility in Tuas, its third largest globally
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has opened its third-largest lubricants facility globally, located in Tuas, Singapore. The 430 million-litre facility replaces Shell's 240,000-tonne facility in Woodlands, increasing production capacity. The new facility is part of the Lube Park joint venture with Sinopec and Total, which also includes pipelines, a tank farm, and import-export jetty. This expansion supports Shell's global lubricants production and reinforces its presence in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.17 points to 1,748.09 on Wednesday, driven by a higher volume of 97.06 million lots worth RM31.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 113 to 58.

site_title: New Zealand unemployment rate hits nearly nine-year low in Q3
summary: New Zealand's unemployment rate dropped to 4.6% in Q3, its lowest in nearly nine years, surpassing analysts' expectations. The rate rebounded from a 0.1% fall in the second quarter, with jobs growth rising 2.2%. Despite the strong figures, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand is unlikely to alter its decision to keep interest rates at a record low due to inflation concerns. The central bank will meet on November 9 to set rates, with economists predicting no change.

site_title: Australia shares finish near 6-month high; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares closed near a six-month high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.49% to 5,937.80. The energy and materials sectors drove gains, boosted by rising oil prices and iron ore futures. BHP Billiton and Westpac Banking Corp led the gains. In contrast, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index fell 1.1% to 8,053.81, with Myer Holdings Ltd and a2 Milk Company Ltd contributing to the decline.

site_title: Europe: Shares cling to 5-month high with October gains
summary: European stocks closed at a five-month high on October 31, ending the month with a 1.8% gain, the second consecutive monthly increase. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% as euro zone data showed faster-than-expected growth and unemployment fell to nearly nine years low. Heavyweight oil major BP's shares jumped 3% after beating expectations and announcing a share buy-back program. The energy sector, which has struggled this year, may see a re-rating due to its high dividend yield.

site_title: South Korea will not develop nuclear weapons: president
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-In has declared that the country will not develop nuclear weapons, despite North Korea's nuclear threat. In a parliament address, Moon stated that a nuclear North Korea cannot be accepted and Seoul will not develop or own nuclear arms. This stance aligns with the 1992 joint declaration to denuclearize the Korean peninsula. The decision is seen as a commitment to the joint declaration and a rejection of the idea of a "balance of terror" on the peninsula.

site_title: Property data
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several property-related news stories were reported. Specialist centre Royal Healthcare plans to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. A NUS researcher's startup aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants of Hao Mart's Taste Orchard lament poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and cuts 42 staff, putting the building up for sale. Meanwhile, businesses like Munchi Pancakes and Sam Goi are modernizing traditional snacks and making mandatory offers. Chinatown Business Association seeks compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee.

site_title: Japan killing spree 'lasted 2 months'
summary: A Japanese man, Takahiro Shiraishi, has confessed to killing 9 people over a 2-month period after contacting them via Twitter. He hacked off their flesh and disposed of the bodies in a suburban Tokyo house, using cat litter to cover up the evidence. Authorities were led to Shiraishi after investigating the disappearance of a 23-year-old woman who had tweeted about seeking help with a suicide plan. Shiraishi, 27, has been charged with improper disposal of one body, but police are searching for evidence he killed all 9 victims.

site_title: The fat years for US airlines come to an end as costs increase
summary: US airlines face higher costs in 2018 due to labour contracts, airport renovations, technology spending, and fleet upgrades. Despite robust travel demand, fuel costs remain stable, and nonfuel expenses are the main concern. The industry's four largest players are operating under new contracts with pilots and flight attendants, leading to higher expenses. This has resulted in disappointing growth expectations for investors, with stock prices declining. Airlines are closely managing capacity growth and expressing optimism about fare hikes, but the Standard & Poor's Airlines Index has declined by almost 9% since October.

site_title: New Zealand's foreign home ownership ban won't cause price collapse: trade minister
summary: New Zealand's Trade Minister David Parker stated that the proposed ban on foreigners buying existing homes will not lead to a house price collapse. The ban is part of the country's efforts to align with the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal, which removes New Zealand's ability to bar overseas investment in its residential property market. The new law is set to be passed in early 2018, ahead of the trade deal, and aims to bring the country in line with Australia.

site_title: Macau casinos post 22% growth in October
summary: Macau casinos posted a 22% increase in October, marking the 15th consecutive month of growth. The territory's monthly gambling revenue reached 26.6 billion patacas (S$4.5 billion), surpassing analysts' expectations and the highest revenue figure since 2014. The growth was fueled by a national holiday week, boosting demand for casino gambling.

images.alt_text: Government data on Wednesday showed monthly gambling revenue was 26.6 billion patacas (S$4.5 billion).

site_title: Tencent unit raises US$1.1b after pricing Hong Kong IPO at top end
summary: China Literature, the country's No.1 online publisher, priced its Hong Kong IPO at the top end of its indicative range, raising US$1.1 billion. The IPO, majority owned by Tencent Holdings Ltd, priced at HK$55, surpassing the target. The company, which owns a 62% stake, aims to raise HK$8.33 billion, with existing shareholders and private equity firm Carlyle Group LP also participating in the offering.

site_title: Smile Inc leans on overseas expansion and innovation amid challenging market
summary: Smile Inc, a dental chain in Singapore, is navigating challenges in the market by expanding overseas and innovating. Despite high rental costs, a shortage of skilled manpower, and competition, the company has successfully opened its first overseas branch in Hong Kong. CEO Grace Chong-Tan attributes the group's success to its focus on innovation, low costs, and high-quality care. However, Singapore's overly stringent regulations and restrictions on foreign manpower hinder the growth of the healthcare industry. Smile Inc is adapting by training staff to multi-task and implementing an inventory system to optimize costs. Despite these challenges, the company remains confident in its prospects and continues to innovate and expand.

images.alt_text: "The group's success in promoting a lifestyle focus for dentistry also changed the public's perception of the sector; instead of being only about fillings, drilling and extractions, consumers started to associate a visit to the dentist with enhancing their own self-esteem and confidence through an improved smile." - Mrs Chong-Tan, CEO and co-founder, Smile Inc

site_title: Logistics sector's digital plan to bring industry leaders together to collaborate
summary: Singapore's industry groups will unveil industry digital plans (IDPs) to help SMEs build digital capabilities. The logistics sector's IDP will bring industry leaders together to collaborate on projects, with partnerships established with VCargo Cloud and three major logistics players. The goal is to adopt impactful, inter-operable tech solutions and coordinate delivery trips using complex algorithms. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of multi-stakeholder collaborations to benefit companies and uplift the entire sector. The initiative is part of the SME Go Digital Programme, tailored to each sector's objectives.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, following overnight gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index rose 1.74 points to 3,375.82, driven by US data and ahead of a US tax cut proposal. The rally extends a 5-day streak, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: US pursues direct diplomacy with North Korea despite Trump rejection
summary: The US is secretly pursuing direct diplomacy with North Korea despite President Donald Trump's public dismissal of talks as a waste of time. Using the "New York channel," US negotiator Joseph Yun has been in contact with North Korean diplomats, discussing issues beyond prisoner releases. Yun's mandate has been expanded to include stopping nuclear tests and missiles, amid fears of military conflict following Trump's bellicose insults with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Diplomatic efforts aim to prevent war and achieve a settlement, but Trump's threats have complicated negotiations.

site_title: Sembawang site for sale by public tender under GLS Confirmed List
summary: The government of Singapore has launched public tenders for two land parcels under the GLS programme. A site at Chong Kuo Road in Sembawang is under the Confirmed List, with a tender closing on January 30, 2018. A site at Fourth Avenue is under the Reserve List, with a trigger for tender expected after a developer offered a minimum price of S$448.8 million. Consultants expect the sites to attract significant bids, with prices ranging from S$38.7-42 million to S$567 million.

images.alt_text: The government has launched a site at Chong Kuo Road for sale under the Confirmed List of the second-half 2017 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme.
Another site at Cuscaden Road is also for application under the Reserve List.

site_title: Oil up near 2-year highs, analysts see more US crude exports
summary: Oil prices rose to near two-year highs, with Brent crude settling at $61.37 and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $54.38. Analysts attribute the increase to bullish sentiment, which may encourage US producers to export more oil, potentially disrupting global markets. The monthly gain exceeds 5%, with Brent up 37% from its 2017 lows.

site_title: UK opposition look to force government into publishing Brexit dossiers
summary: Britain's opposition Labour party plans to force the government to publish its assessment of Brexit's economic impact on 58 sectors. The government has refused, citing a need for a "safe space" to make Brexit policy in private. Labour lawmakers argue the documents should be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and used to shape the public debate on a good EU departure deal. The move could lead to a parliamentary vote, with some within Prime Minister Theresa May's party also calling for transparency.

site_title: Brokers' take: OCBC cuts Starhill Global Reit to 'hold' on Singapore office weakness
summary: OCBC Investment Research has downgraded Starhill Global Reit to a "hold" due to weak Singapore office occupancy, which fell 11.2 percentage points to 83.5% in the latest quarter. The broker cut its target price to 77 Singapore cents from 82 cents. Net property income slipped 3.5% year-on-year to S$41.4 million, with downtime expected due to fit-out periods for new tenants. OCBC also reduced its distribution per unit forecast for FY2018 and FY2019.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with gains, tracking overnight US market record highs. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.34% to 28,342.51, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight increases. The gains come as investors brush off new US President Trump's threats, focusing on ongoing US-EU trade talks and other market developments.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a global equity index target of 1,150 by mid-2026. In Thailand, Prime Minister Thaksin is confident his daughter will be cleared of suspension in an ethics case. ASEAN has deemed Myanmar's election a non-priority, with Malaysia in agreement. The UK economy has shrunk for the second month, and South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. Additionally, Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, and Rubio will meet China's Wang at Asean talks.

site_title: Capital World obtains HK$50m share financing with controlling shareholders' shares
summary: Capital World Limited secured a HK$50 million share financing from Great View Finance Limited, with a 10% interest rate and repayment within 12 months. The financing is secured against 166.5 million shares held by three controlling shareholders, representing 13.1% of the company's issued shares. The funds will be used to further strengthen the group's foothold in Malaysia through property development projects.

site_title: 'We must do better,' social media giants tell US Congress
summary: US social media giants Facebook, Google, and Twitter testified before Congress, stating they are committed to cracking down on fake news operations, including those conducted by Russia to meddle in the 2016 US presidential election. New data reveals millions of Americans were exposed to fake news, with Twitter finding nearly 37,000 automated "bot" accounts generating 1.4 million tweets seen by 288 million people. The companies acknowledged the need to improve their efforts to prevent disinformation and propaganda, with Facebook's general counsel saying, "We are deeply concerned about all of these threats."

site_title: Suspect kills eight in New York truck 'act of terror'
summary: A pickup truck driver killed eight people and injured 11 others in a terror attack in New York City on Halloween. The suspect, identified as 29-year-old Sayfullo Saipov, was shot by an officer and taken into custody after mowing down cyclists and pedestrians and striking a school bus. The attack, which occurred just blocks from the 9/11 Memorial, was deemed a "cowardly act of terror" by officials, with Saipov shouting "Allahu akbar" before being apprehended.

images.alt_text: Eight people were killed and numerous others injured in New York on Tuesday when a suspect plowed into cyclists and pedestrians in Lower Manhattan, and rammed another vehicle on Halloween, police said.

site_title: MAS slaps prohibition orders against Kelvin Ang and Lee Chee Waiy in 1MDB case
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders (POs) against six individuals involved in the 1MDB case, including Kelvin Ang and Lee Chee Waiy, effective from October 30, 2017. The six-year POs prohibit them from providing capital market and financial advisory services, and taking part in the management of firms in Singapore. Ang was convicted of bribing Lee with S$3,000 to expedite a valuation report on PetroSaudi Oil Services Limited. Yeo Jiawei, who was convicted of money laundering and other charges, faces a lifetime ban from providing financial advisory services.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said it has issued prohibition orders (POs) against former remisier of Maybank Kim Eng Securities, Ang Wee Keng Kelvin, and former NRA Capital research head Lee Chee Waiy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher tracking gains in US
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on November 1, 2017, tracking US gains, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.57% and the Topix index up 0.54%. A weaker yen supported the market, and Sony was set to rally after forecasting record annual profits.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at record high on US data, tax cut hopes
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq closing at a fresh record, driven by strong US data and hopes for a US tax cut proposal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also advanced, while key gainers included Apple and Tesla Motors. Consumer confidence hit a 17-year high, and single-family home sales spiked in September. Analysts await a Federal Reserve policy announcement, which may influence interest rates in December.

site_title: Sembmarine back in the black with Q3 net profit of S$2.72m
summary: SEMBCORP Marine has returned to profitability in the third quarter with a net gain of S$2.72 million, reversing a loss of S$21.79 million in the same period last year. This marks a significant turnaround despite the challenging operating environment in the offshore and marine sector. Earnings per share also improved to 0.13 Singapore cents from a loss of 1.04 Singapore cents. The company's reversal of losses is a positive sign for investors.

site_title: Dymon Asia emerges as new substantial shareholder of IFS Capital, SMRT ceases to be one
summary: Dymon Asia Capital Ltd has become a substantial shareholder of IFS Capital Limited, acquiring 25.77 million shares representing 6.86% of IFS Capital's issued shares. This move comes after SMRT ceased to be a substantial shareholder after selling the same amount of shares. Dymon Asia's involvement is through its controlled entity, Diamond GP Holdings.

site_title: Federal Reserve begins two-day meeting as Yellen era appears set to close
summary: The Federal Reserve began a two-day meeting on Tuesday, with policymakers unlikely to raise interest rates due to poor inflation numbers despite robust economic growth. The meeting comes as President Donald Trump is set to announce his nominee for Fed chair, with current Governor Jerome Powell likely to be the choice. Powell's cautious approach to rate hikes and deregulation agenda may appeal to Trump, who has expressed admiration for Powell despite criticism of Yellen's economic stewardship. Markets expect a decision on the next rate hike, with some predicting a wait until January due to weak inflation data.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve began a two-day monetary policy meeting on Tuesday, largely overshadowed by this week's expected White House decision to replace central bank chief Janet Yellen.

site_title: US sports memorabilia scores big hit for collectors
summary: US sports memorabilia is experiencing a significant surge in popularity among collectors, with many, such as Corey Shanus, amassing valuable historical gems over the past 50 years. Shanus, who began collecting Topps trading cards in 1963, is now sitting on a "goldmine" as the value of his collection increases. The growing demand for sports memorabilia is driven by collectors seeking unique and authentic items, with prices for rare items reaching record highs. This trend is expected to continue, making it an exciting time for sports enthusiasts and collectors alike.

site_title: Netflix cancels flagship series House of Cards
summary: Netflix cancels House of Cards, ending its flagship series after six seasons, amid allegations of sexual misconduct against star Kevin Spacey. Spacey faces claims from actor Anthony Rapp that he made a sexual advance at a party 31 years ago. Despite initial reports suggesting the series' cancellation was unrelated to the allegations, Netflix ultimately decided to end the show. Filming for the final season was underway in Maryland before the news was announced.

site_title: The fashionista who can
summary: Pek Lay Peng, a 32-year-old mother of one, is a successful businesswoman who owns multi-label store SocietyA and executive director of Shingda Group of Companies. She switched from a male-dominated construction industry to retail after observing a gap in the market for quality apparel by Asian designers. SocietyA focuses on Asian designers and has 30 brands under its belt. Pek credits her construction industry background for teaching her the importance of professionalism and reliability, which she applies to her retail business. Despite declining retail sales in Singapore, Pek believes the future of retail will consist of both online and offline strategies. Her goal is to house 50 brands in SocietyA and expand to Asia and the US.

site_title: Empowering China's new miracle workers
summary: China's future success hinges on the leadership of its next generation of technocrats, who will drive economic reform and transformation. The current generation, highly educated and experienced, will step down in 2018, and a new generation is prepared to carry forward China's progress. However, they will face significant uncertainty, including a shift in China's dominant policy framework under President Xi Jinping. The new leaders must balance the Communist Party's muscular approach with economic growth, and their success will determine China's trajectory over the next five years.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Micro-Mechanics (Holdings) Ltd and Raffles Medical Group are recommended to "buy" with target prices raised to S$2.50 and S$1.26, respectively. Analysts expect the companies' revenue growth to be sustained due to the semiconductor sales cycle's current momentum. This is attributed to the industry's synchronized growth in global economies and a relatively short cycle duration. The recommendations are based on the assumption that the current cycle will continue, unlike previous cycles that lasted 20-26 months.

site_title: Michelin expands restaurant guides as part of Asian growth push
summary: Michelin is introducing its restaurant guide for Bangkok in December as part of its effort to boost its brand image in Asia, where it faces competition from lower-cost Chinese tyremakers. This move comes after the company's acquisition of a 40% stake in the US-based Robert Parker wine guide, which hosts tasting events in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Macau. Michelin aims to leverage its luxury reputation to increase its appeal in the region.

images.alt_text: "The guide is an extraordinary tool for our brand. It's in our DNA - as much as tyres are." - Claire Dorland Clauzel, the Michelin executive vice president who oversees the guides

site_title: SGX to reduce unusual activity queries by half
summary: SGX, Singapore's stock exchange, will reduce unusual activity queries by half starting November 1. The new system aims to issue fewer, higher-quality queries instead of high-volume ones, which can have a chilling effect on share prices. The system will be calibrated to allow prices and volumes to increase before a query is issued. This change follows successful initiatives to detect and stop market misconduct, including a trade surveillance handbook and targeted "trade with caution" alerts.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CACHE Logistics Trust has resolved a dispute with Schenker Singapore, agreeing to a fresh lease and a lump-sum payment of S$8.2 million. Former President Tony Tan Keng Yam has accepted a role as the first chief patron for the Securities Investors Association (SIAS). Samurai 2K Aerosol expects higher revenue and profit in the first half of 2018 due to stronger demand for its aerosol paint products.

site_title: Gold falls ahead of US data-heavy week, Fed chair decision
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $1,270.40 an ounce ahead of US data-heavy week, including payrolls data and Federal Reserve meetings, which may lead to a stronger US dollar and reduced demand for the metal. The Fed is set to announce its decision on the next chair on Thursday, with speculation favoring Jerome Powell, seen as more dovish. Rising equity markets also reduced gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset, with precious metals trading mixed.

site_title: Surviving the brave new world of retail
summary: Retail in Singapore is not dying, but transforming due to tough times such as high rents, manpower shortages, and increased competition from e-commerce giants like Amazon. Despite these challenges, industry watchers believe that the sector is adapting and evolving. While some retailers struggle with low footfall and vacant units, others are innovating and rebranding to stay relevant. The transformation of retail in Singapore is a positive development, driven by the industry's resilience and ability to adapt to changing consumer habits and market conditions.

site_title: IBM builds a partner ecosystem that delivers winning solutions
summary: IBM is reimagining its partnership model to support core and new-age partners in the cloud and cognitive era. The company is providing cognitive solutions on its IBM Cloud platform to help partners develop deep expertise and speed up their time to market with new innovations. This move aims to help partners stay ahead of the competition and leverage the potential of cognitive systems, which can ingest and understand all forms of data at an unprecedented rate.

images.alt_text: The first-ever Watson Build, held earlier this year, is a challenge designed to help partners conceptualise, propose, develop and launch new cognitive business solutions. More than 1,300 Business Partners attended 36 workshops around the world.

site_title: Time off for good behaviour: Japan firm rewards non-smokers
summary: A Tokyo-based online commerce consulting firm, Piala, has launched a program rewarding non-smoking employees with six additional days of paid leave to compensate for time lost by smoking colleagues. The initiative aims to reduce smoking in the workplace and promote a healthier environment. Since its start in September, four smokers have quit, and the company hopes to encourage more employees to adopt smoke-free habits. Japan's lax smoke-free policies and social pressure to quit contribute to the program's goal of reducing smoking in the workplace.

site_title: Building a Lifestyle Empire
summary: EpiCentre Holdings, a Singaporean company, has successfully diversified its business to build a lifestyle brand. Under new CEO Kenneth Lim, the company shifted its focus from reselling Apple products to a more customer-centric approach, introducing a range of products and services. This strategy, "Living Out Loud", led to a significant turnaround, with the company netting a profit of S$507,000 in the financial year ended June 30, 2017, up from losses of S$5.8 million the previous year.

site_title: Republicans face rift within their party
summary: The Republican Party is facing a rift within its ranks as disagreements between the White House and Congress threaten to derail the planned tax overhaul. The issue stems from a tension between cutting taxes and balancing the federal budget, with deficit hawks opposing the proposed tax cuts. President Donald Trump's Trumpist agenda challenges traditional Republican principles, including opposition to internationalist foreign policy and free trade. This has led to opposition from some Republican lawmakers, including Senator John McCain, and has raised concerns about Trump's ability to get legislation passed in Congress.

site_title: MAS grant, new insurance consortium to propel Singapore as insurance hub
summary: Singapore aims to establish itself as a major insurance hub with the launch of a new insurance consortium and a MAS grant scheme. The grant will fund 100% of upfront costs for catastrophe bonds, covering all forms of risks beyond natural catastrophes. A Singapore-based infrastructure consortium, backed by China Re Singapore, will provide insurance coverage and risk management services for the One Belt One Road (OBOR) projects in the Asia-Pacific region. The government hopes to close the protection gap in the region and promote technology-driven innovation in the insurance market.

site_title: Razer to raise up to HK$4.3b in HKSE listing
summary: Razer, a Singaporean gaming company, plans to raise up to HK$4.3 billion in its proposed listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKSE) mainboard. The company will offer 1.063 billion shares at between HK$2.93 and HK$4 apiece. Proceeds will be used to develop new verticals, finance acquisitions, expand research and development capabilities, and run sales and marketing initiatives. The deal is expected to start on November 1 and close on November 6.

site_title: Hot stock: Artivision shares surge on news of potential reverse takeover
summary: Artivision Technologies Limited shares surged 11.8% to 1.9 Singapore cents on Wednesday after signing a conditional heads of agreement to acquire Mobile Credit Payment (MC Payment) Pte Ltd. for at least S$80 million, with the potential for an additional S$64 million. This deal may lead to a reverse takeover of the group.

site_title: South Korean stocks rise 1%, won up
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1% on November 1, 2017, with the Kospi index reaching an all-time high intraday level of 2,551.33. The won strengthened against the US dollar, trading at 1,116.5 per dollar. The index was lifted by gains in tech companies like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The Kospi is up 24.52% this year and 6.97% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Japanese restaurant group RE&S to list on Catalist
summary: Japanese restaurant group RE&S Holdings plans to list on Catalist, a Singapore stock exchange, with an initial public offering (IPO) by the end of 2017. The company aims to raise capital for new outlets, refurbishment, and expansion through acquisitions and joint ventures. Revenue has increased by 4.8% in the last two years, and net profit nearly doubled to S$5.7 million in FY17. Temasek's unit Heliconia Capital Management will be a cornerstone investor.

site_title: French PM booted from rightwing party
summary: French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe has been expelled from the right-wing Republicans party after joining President Emmanuel Macron's centrist government. The party confirmed the expulsion of Philippe, as well as two other government ministers and two MPs who supported Macron. The move comes after Macron's En Marche party won a commanding majority in parliamentary polls. The Republicans party holds 100 seats, while En Marche and its allies hold 313. The expulsion is seen as a blow to the mainstream right-wing party.

site_title: China Airbnb rival Xiaozhu gets Jack Ma backing, claims "Unicorn" status
summary: China's short-term rental firm Xiaozhu.com has raised $120 million in a funding round led by Jack Ma's Yunfeng Capital, valuing the company at over $1 billion, making it a "unicorn startup." The funding boost will help Xiaozhu compete with local rival Tujia.com and US giant Airbnb, as China's growing middle class drives a boom in domestic tourism.

site_title: Changi Airport traffic grows nearly 6% in first three quarters
summary: Changi Airport's passenger traffic grew 5.9% to 46 million for the first three quarters of 2017, driven by strong growth in India and China. Airfreight throughput increased 8.1% to 1.56 million tonnes. The airport's new Terminal 4 was launched on November 1, 2017. Passenger traffic to and from India expanded 18% and China 11%, while aircraft movements rose 3.4% to 277,370 landings and takeoffs.

site_title: The disrupters could get disrupted
summary: The article discusses the growing regulatory pressure on the four mega-cap tech companies, known as FANG stocks (Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, and Google), which have dominated the US stock market in recent years. The companies are facing challenges in digital advertising, free content, unused cash, data privacy, and a potential "duty-of-care" requirement. These pressures could lead to a leveling of the playing field and potentially disrupt the FANGs' dominance. Regulators in Europe are already cracking down on data privacy, and the US government may impose similar requirements, which could impact the companies' profitability and growth.

site_title: More pharma companies added in US price-fixing probe
summary: Prosecutors have added 12 more companies and two executives to a US price-fixing probe into generic drug manufacturers. The investigation, supported by 45 US states, alleges a conspiracy by Mylan, Teva, and others to set prices to boost profits. The expanded complaint names 18 generic drug manufacturers and two executives, including Mylan president Rajiv Malik and Emcure Pharmaceuticals' CEO Satish Mehta. The probe, initially filed in December, accuses companies of fixing drug prices, dividing markets, and harming consumers.

site_title: Tax rollout delayed to Thursday as US Congress braces for overhaul
summary: US Republicans have delayed unveiling the tax overhaul bill until Thursday, citing a need for additional time to study the measure. The $1.5 trillion plan, backed by President Donald Trump, includes tax cuts for most income groups and the elimination of loopholes and deductions. The delay raises uncertainty about the bill's fate, as it risks running afoul of fiscal conservatives and Senate moderates concerned with tax breaks for the wealthy.

site_title: StanChart Singapore on the hunt for new CEO
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore is searching for a new CEO after Judy Hsu was promoted to a regional role, leading Asean and South Asia by Q4 2018. Current regional CEO Anna Marrs will transfer her responsibilities to Hsu in two stages, with Hsu taking on additional roles for Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam. Hsu's appointment comes after a risk-averse culture was addressed, and the bank secured significant investments in its Singapore operations. The search for a new Singapore CEO marks a change for the bank, which derives a significant portion of its income from emerging markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher; Sony up 11% on record profit outlook
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.86% on Wednesday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a weaker yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index reached 22,420.08. Sony surged 11% after forecasting record annual profits. The broader Topix index also rose 1.17%. The gains follow the US stock market's recent records, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: China now in a position to offer roadmaps to the world
summary: China is now openly sharing its development model with the world, shifting from a low-profile approach under previous leaders. At the 19th Communist Party Congress, General Secretary Xi Jinping emphasized China's achievements, including its rapid economic growth from extreme poverty to the second-largest economy. China is now positioning itself as a model for other developing countries, and Xi Jinping is open to sharing its development strategies. This marks a significant change in China's approach, as it seeks to promote itself as a global leader and provide a roadmap for other nations.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on materials; NZ falls about 1%
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday, driven by gains in materials stocks, including a 1.1% rise for BHP Billiton and a 0.9% gain for Rio Tinto. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.9% due to declines in consumer staples. The Australian mining index saw its biggest intraday percentage gain in over two weeks. National Australia Bank and Westpac are set to announce their results, contributing to positive sentiment.

site_title: Singapore condemns New York City terror attack
summary: Singapore strongly condemns the terrorist attack in New York City, expressing heartfelt condolences to the victims' families and wishing the injured a swift recovery. There are no reported Singaporeans directly affected or injured, but the Singapore Consulate in New York has reached out to e-registered Singaporeans for assistance. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs advises Singaporeans in New York to exercise vigilance and follow local authorities' instructions.

site_title: Staying strong
summary: Singapore's retail sector faces challenges, with store closures and vacant lots on the rise. To adapt, retailers must focus on experiential retail, offering memorable experiences that engage customers' senses and emotions. Strategies include investing in creative business models, such as coworking spaces and events, and prioritizing great service and customer experience. Retailers should also optimize their real estate portfolios and supply chains to remain competitive in a booming e-commerce era. By doing so, they can thrive in the new retail landscape and establish a stronger presence.

site_title: China consumer stocks soar 65% as defensive ploys pay
summary: China's consumer staples stocks have surged 65% this year, outperforming the broader market, as investors seek defensive assets amid the country's deleveraging campaign. Indexes of companies such as Kweichow Moutai Co and Yonghui Superstores Co have jumped 13% in the past month, driven by earnings optimism and a pick-up in inflation. Investors are rotating to consumer sectors, including technology and healthcare, as a result, with some selling stocks in other sectors to invest in consumer staples.

site_title: Coach joins Glencore in applying to delist from Hong Kong bourse
summary: Coach Inc has applied to delist from the Hong Kong stock exchange, citing weak demand for its shares. This follows Glencore's plan to withdraw its listing from the city, also citing weak demand. The departures come as the Hong Kong stock exchange struggles to attract international companies. Coach, now known as Tapestry Inc, did not specify a timeline for its exit, while Glencore's withdrawal is expected to become effective January 31, 2018. This marks another blow to the financial hub, which has seen several high-profile listings leave in recent years.

site_title: 4,200 passengers breeze through Terminal 4 on its first day
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 officially opened after five years of construction. On its first day, 19 flights carried approximately 4,200 passengers. The terminal's opening marks a significant expansion for the airport, which is expected to enhance passenger experience and efficiency.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary: Newly registered companies were listed in the SME Magazine, featuring companies with issued capital between $200,000 and $5 million. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare is set to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after Sojitz took control. Researchers at NUS are working on a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC aims to provide $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and putting the building up for sale.

site_title: September bank lending up 6.2% amid improved business sentiment
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in September rose 6.2% to S$641 billion, stronger than the 5.1% year-on-year growth in August. This comes as the economy powered into its strongest 3-year GDP growth for the third quarter of 2017. However, manufacturing loans surged 11% in September, reversing from contraction, while service sector confidence improved for the third consecutive quarter. Economists expect growth to moderate due to a slowdown in manufacturing, but business loan growth remains strong.

site_title: China's CDH, SenseTime raising about 3b yuan for AI fund: sources
summary: China's CDH Investments and Hong Kong-based startup SenseTime Group are raising about 3 billion yuan (S$616 million) for an AI fund, co-managed by the two companies. The fund aims to invest in growth-stage AI startups worldwide, amid Beijing's drive to be a leader in AI technology. This move comes as AI becomes increasingly important in various sectors, including healthcare, financial services, and autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Sony revives robot pet dog
summary: Sony has revived its robot pet dog, "aibo", after a decade-long hiatus. The new model, launched in Japan, features artificial intelligence, internet connectivity, and a range of sensors and cameras. It can be controlled remotely via smartphone and displays emotions through eye movements. The device is priced at 198,000 yen (S$2,300), a significant increase from its initial price of 250,000 yen in 1999. The new aibo marks a return to the digital pet market, which was discontinued by Sony in 2006 due to business restructuring.

site_title: Oil treads US$60 line to lift O&M stocks
summary: Oil prices have hovered above the US$60 a barrel mark for a third day, driven by falling inventories and optimism about sustained output cuts. The Singapore Exchange's oil and gas stocks have extended their rally to nearly a 2-year high, with analysts predicting a potential price pullback due to overbuying and the threat of shale producers flooding the market. Brent crude prices are seen vulnerable to profit taking, with some analysts forecasting a decline to US$45-55 a barrel.

site_title: The 'inconvenient truth' about artificial intelligence
summary: Artificial intelligence is transforming the world with the potential to improve efficiency, healthcare, and access to knowledge, but also raises concerns about social inequity, loss of humanity, and employment. Experts predict exponential change in technology, with some forecasting human-level intelligence by 2029 and the Singularity by 2047. As AI becomes more integrated into daily life, issues such as data analysis, privacy, and cybersecurity will need to be addressed. To mitigate these risks, clear frameworks and standards for AI use are necessary, and investors must adapt to the rapidly evolving competitive landscape.

site_title: Foreign buyers inch back into Vancouver housing market
summary: Foreign buyers are slowly re-entering the Vancouver housing market, accounting for 5% of home purchases in September, up from 0.9% in August 2016. The 15% foreign buyer tax, implemented in response to offshore money inflating the market, has led to a decline in detached home sales but a rebound in condo sales, with prices increasing 21.7% in the past year. Finance Minister Carole James is reviewing the tax's impact on housing affordability, with all options on the table to address concerns about foreign speculation in the market.

site_title: BOJ keeps policy steady but board newcomer signals desire for easing
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its policy settings steady on Tuesday, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda citing no immediate need to exit its ultra-easy monetary policy despite inflation remaining below the 2% target. However, a new board member expressed a desire for clearer commitment to ramping up stimulus if necessary, potentially complicating future efforts to dial back the massive monetary support. This move may signal a shift in the BOJ's approach to its stimulus policies.

site_title: The ad is watching you
summary: TheSeafoodCompany, a seafood distributor, reduced marketing costs by adopting Intelli-Signage, a digital platform. The company previously relied on manual uploads by its marketing staff to share advertising collateral. With Intelli-Signage, the company no longer needs to dedicate staff to uploading and observing advertising, resulting in cost savings.

site_title: Plan to name German train after Anne Frank condemned
summary: Germany's national rail provider, Deutsche Bahn, plans to name a train after Jewish diarist Anne Frank, sparking controversy. The Anne Frank Foundation said the name "caused new pain" to those who experienced deportations during World War II. Despite the backlash, Deutsche Bahn claimed the move was to "keep the name of Anne Frank alive" and apologized for any hurt feelings. The decision was made after a jury of historians chose Anne Frank from a shortlist of 25 names, out of 19,000 proposals.

site_title: GP Batteries' public float drops below 10%, slated to suspend trading of shares
summary: GP Batteries International Limited's public free float has dropped below 10%, prompting the Singapore Exchange to suspend trading of its shares on November 17. The company, which produces and distributes primary and rechargeable batteries, had launched a voluntary conditional cash offer in September to privatize and delist the subsidiary. As of Tuesday, 9.63% of shares were held by the public, with the remaining 90.37% owned by the offeror and its concert parties. This move aims to provide more flexibility in managing GP Batteries' business.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Manulife US Reit, Citic Envirotech, ComfortDelgro, Cache Logistics Trust
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Investors are watching for corporate news and potential positive cues from US stocks. Manulife US Reit completed the acquisition of a New Jersey office property for $315.1 million. Citic Envirotech secured its largest project in China worth $945.5 million for wastewater treatment and land remediation. ComfortDelgro acquired a Perth-based taxi management company for $5.5 million. Cache Logistics Trust resolved a dispute with Schenker Singapore over a Singapore property, agreeing to a 46-month lease. These developments follow a positive rally in Singapore stocks and US markets, with investors awaiting GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Two office buildings in city get into en bloc mode
summary: Two office buildings in Singapore, Shenton House and Golden Wall Centre, have begun their en bloc sale processes. Shenton House, a 174-unit development, has formed a collective sales committee and hopes to appoint a marketing agent by the end of the week. Golden Wall Centre, a 158-unit office-cum-retail building, also set up its collective sales committee after a previous attempt in 2016 failed to garner an 80-per-cent consensus. Neither property has set a reserve or asking price, but Shenton House's 2012 attempt had an indicative price tag of S$530 million.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to boost dividends after record Q3 profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported record third-quarter profit, driven by the global boom in memory chips, and promised to return $26 billion to shareholders over the next three years. The company plans to double dividends to 9.6 trillion won (S$11.68 billion) next year and maintain the level until 2020. This move aims to respond to investor pressure and catch up with more generous peers.

site_title: Japanese brewers pursue growth overseas
summary: Japanese brewers Kirin Holdings, Sapporo Holdings, and Asahi Group are pursuing growth overseas due to a stagnant domestic market. Despite a 4.2% decline in beer sales in Japan, the companies are focusing on international expansion. Kirin acquired a 24% stake in Brooklyn Brewery, while Sapporo bought Anchor Steam Brewery. Asahi plans to generate 30% of its sales from overseas, nearly double its 2016 figure. These moves are expected to boost earnings, with shares of the companies trading near all-time highs.

site_title: Pacific Star, Damac Int'l to develop luxury properties in South-east Asia
summary: Pacific Star Development and Damac International have formed a strategic partnership to develop luxury properties in South-east Asia over the next five years. The joint venture will focus on key cities in Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Singapore, with a primary emphasis on residential, hospitality, and retail projects. Both developers will collaborate on identifying prime locations and shareholdings will be determined on a case-by-case basis. The partnership aims to capitalize on South-east Asia's rising urbanization and favorable demographics.

site_title: OCBC bares all in book to commemorate 85-year history
summary: OCBC Bank has released a new book, "Wind behind the Sails: The story of the people and ethos of OCBC," to commemorate its 85-year history. The book provides a behind-the-scenes look at the bank's milestones and mishaps, including its winding up of an Australian venture and the acquisition of Keppel TatLee Bank. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised the book for its honest appraisal of OCBC's successes and failures. The bank's commitment to steady and sustainable growth, customer relationships, and staff well-being has earned it a solid reputation.

site_title: Singapore comes in third in Asia for sustainable transport: report
summary: Singapore ranks third in Asia for sustainable transport, according to the 2017 Sustainable Cities Mobility Index, with a perfect score for encouraging electric vehicle use and a high score for public transport efficiency. However, the city-state's bicycle infrastructure is considered poor. Singapore's strong scores in social and economic pillars, along with its environmental performance, make it one of the safest cities to drive or be a pedestrian. Despite this, the city-state still has room for improvement in addressing urban pollution and emissions.

site_title: Big Four China banks post double-digit gains in loan income
summary: China's four largest banks posted double-digit increases in loan income in the third quarter, with average net interest income gains of 15%. Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, Bank of China, and Agricultural Bank of China reported improvements in interest margins and asset quality, while China Construction Bank Corp reported a 10% rise in net interest income. However, Bank of China's shares slumped 3% due to a jump in impairment losses, while ICBC and CCB dropped 1.7% and 0.8%, respectively.

site_title: A heart for his work
summary: Dr. Julian Tan, an interventional cardiologist, runs a private practice in Mount Elizabeth Medical Centre, likening his trade to plumbing. He performs minimally-invasive procedures like coronary angioplasty to treat clogged arteries. Dr. Tan brings extensive experience from high-volume centers in Singapore and Australia, and his clinic offers comprehensive, affordable, and personable heart healthcare. He emphasizes the importance of lifestyle changes and controlling risk factors after procedures, and notes that newer developments in angioplasty include the "transradial approach" and bioresorbable stents. Despite the challenges, Dr. Tan remains passionate about his work, saying he enjoys helping patients and looks forward to performing angioplasty procedures daily.

site_title: US consumer confidence hits 17-year high in October
summary: US consumer confidence reached a 17-year high in October, rising to 125.9 from the upwardly-revised 120.6 in September, according to a Conference Board survey. The index beat expectations, driven by a favorable job market and improved business conditions. The present condition index increased to 151.1 and the expectations index jumped six points to 109.1, with consumers expressing more confidence in the short-term outlook. This marks the fourth consecutive month of increases, suggesting the economy will continue to expand at a solid pace for the remainder of the year.

site_title: Towards a strong finish
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are adapting to challenges such as e-commerce and changing consumer patterns. To cope, many are using augmented reality, omni-channel approaches, and customer service chatbots. Key SMEs share their forward-looking strategies for 2018, including Smile Inc, EpiCentre, and Julian Tan Heart Specialist Clinic. The article also discusses the importance of customer experience and provides guidelines for brick-and-mortar retailers to futureproof their businesses.

site_title: More buzz in big-ticket industrial property deals
summary: Credit Suisse is selling its Singapore industrial property at 1 Serangoon North Avenue 6 to US-based Iron Mountain for S$80.5 million. StarHub has entered a put and call option deal to buy 13 Tai Seng Drive for nearly S$30.9 million. Investment sales of industrial properties in Singapore have increased year-to-date, with vacant possession being a key factor. This trend is attributed to companies opting to own their premises instead of renting, with some planning to convert properties into data centers.

site_title: New Zealand dollar jumps on upbeat job data; Australian dollar treads water
summary: The New Zealand dollar surged 1% to its highest level in over a week after the country's jobless rate fell to a near nine-year low, with jobs growing 2.2% in the third quarter. The employment rate also reached a record high, while the labour cost index increased 1.9% annually. Strong labour market data boosted the kiwi currency, despite analysts cautioning that policy implications are uncertain, with the Reserve Bank of New Zealand considering adding full employment to its mandate.

site_title: Sinopec mulls over two US oil projects ahead of Trump's visit: sources
summary: China's state oil major Sinopec is evaluating two US oil projects ahead of US President Donald Trump's visit to Beijing. The projects could boost Gulf Coast crude oil exports and expand storage facilities in the Caribbean. Sinopec is considering partnering US firms Freepoint Commodities and ArcLight Capital Partners to build a pipeline and VLCC terminal. The investments could reduce China's trade deficit with the US and allow Beijing to tap growing US crude supplies, as China seeks to diversify its import sources.

site_title: Owners of 11 Balmoral Road asking for S$75m
summary: A collective sale of 11 Balmoral Road in Singapore's prime district 10 has been launched with owners asking for S$75 million, translating to an estimated land rate of S$1,761 per sq ft per plot ratio. The site, comprising 17 units in two four-storey apartment blocks, has been approved by owners and can be redeveloped to accommodate an exclusive medium-rise high-end residential project. The vacant possession period is expected to be completed quickly, allowing the successful purchaser to plan and build the new project.

site_title: Elvis Presley's Graceland to borrow US$88m to expand
summary: Graceland, Elvis Presley's iconic 120-acre estate, plans to borrow $88 million from the municipal market to expand, with the aim of transforming it from a tourist attraction to a vacation destination. This is the King's third trip to the municipal market, with previous deals in 2015 and 2016. The project, which includes an archive studio, hotel, museum, and retail facilities, is expected to attract more visitors, with an average of 540,000 annual visitors over the last 12 years. Revenue generated will be crucial for repaying obligations, dependent on continued tourist interest in Elvis's life and legacy.

site_title: Oil and gas speculation continues
summary: Crude oil prices surged to a two-year high, pushing speculative activity in the oil and gas exploration and support services space on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed almost unchanged, despite gains in manufacturing stocks. Top percentage gainers included Mirach Energy, Vallianz Holdings, and Pacific Radiance. Electronics and semiconductor-linked manufacturing stocks also continued their rally, driven by strong export growth in Taiwan.

site_title: Asean must tackle underlying issues fomenting anti-state rebellions
summary: The Philippines' battle against separatism and militancy in its southern provinces is ongoing, following the seven-month Marawi uprising. The conflict, sparked by a failed intelligence operation, resulted in 920 militants, 165 troops and police, and at least 45 civilians killed, with over 300,000 displaced. Experts warn that extremist-inspired violence is likely to spread to other South-east Asian countries, including Thailand and Myanmar, highlighting the need for Asean states to address underlying issues and share intelligence to prevent future conflicts.

site_title: ANA raises profit outlook as Japan's stronger economy boosts demand
summary: ANA Holdings Inc raised its full-year operating profit forecast to 160 billion yen (S$1.9 billion) due to Japan's stronger economy boosting travel demand. The airline cited improved domestic employment, the Japanese income environment, and government policies as contributing factors. ANA's operating profit for the three months ending September 30 was 89.6 billion yen, exceeding an average analyst estimate of 82.6 billion yen. This follows Japan Airlines' also raising its full-year profit outlook on Tuesday.

site_title: Trump's trip to Asia a diplomatic balancing act
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to embark on a 12-day trip to Asia, visiting Japan, South Korea, China, Vietnam, and the Philippines. The trip aims to outline his vision for the region, differing from his predecessor Barack Obama's "pivot" strategy. Trump seeks to dispel perceptions of a lack of interest in Asia, but faces a diplomatic balancing act, particularly with North Korea, China, and South Korea. The US president will focus on tightening sanctions on North Korea while also engaging in regional dialogue, including counter-terrorism and trade issues. The trip's success will depend on Trump's ability to align positions with key allies and adversaries, including China, which has significant reservations about the US approach.

site_title: Connecting with a click
summary: Zilingo, a Singapore-based fashion e-commerce platform, aggregates sellers from Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia, and Hong Kong, offering a seamless shopping experience for consumers. Founded by Ankiti Bose, the platform aims to make fashion accessible to millions of consumers across South-east Asia. Zilingo provides services such as logistics, payments, and inventory management to support small sellers, and has over 5,000 sellers on board. The company is poised for growth, with plans to prioritize sustainability and unit economics, and is leveraging technology to enhance the shopping experience. Bose foresees changes in the industry driven by technology, including AI and machine learning, and aims to become a household name and the go-to fashion marketplace.

site_title: US dollar heads for best month since February
summary: The US dollar is on track for its best month since February, recovering from an 11-day low against the yen after news of a Trump aide's charges. The dollar has gained 1.5% against a basket of major currencies, boosted by speculation of a hawkish Fed direction and weakness in the euro. Analysts attribute dollar strength to a low interest rate cycle and lack of inflation, with the euro expected to have its worst month since February.

site_title: Toyota wins over US car buyers with new Camry and more RAV4s
summary: Toyota takes 15% market share in the US, its highest since 2009, with its RAV4 outselling the Camry mid-size sedan. The company is projected to top retail sales leader General Motors Co with its retail sales up 3% for the year. Toyota's US fleet sales are down 11% but its total sales are now expected to top initial forecasts of 2.44 million. The company's momentum is expected to continue, with deliveries likely rising 4% in October, surpassing Volkswagen's and Audi's 10% gains.

site_title: Singapore Mediation Act in force from Nov 1
summary: Singapore's Mediation Act and its subsidiary legislation will be in force from November 1, 2017, covering international commercial mediation and strengthening enforcement of mediated settlements. The Act follows consultations with stakeholders since the passing of the Mediation Bill in January 2017.

site_title: SGX set to harvest seeds sown in new businesses, IPO pipeline as markets recover
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is poised to benefit from its efforts to attract new businesses and listings as markets recover from a decline. Despite low liquidity and concerns about an asset bubble, SGX reported a 9.2% increase in net profit for its fiscal first quarter, driven by a positive outlook for the US economy and Singapore's improving economy. The exchange expects to attract more listings and improve liquidity, but faces uncertainty from unpredictable US policy and global economic trends. SGX's diversified business and focus on fixed income and commodities may provide resilience in a potentially volatile market.

site_title: Oct market value surges past trillion-dollar mark
summary: The Singapore stock market surged past the trillion-dollar mark in October, with the Straits Times Index rising 3.8% to S$597.8 billion. The market capitalisation jumped 3.6% to S$1.014 trillion, snapping two consecutive months of falls. Wall Street's record highs and encouraging macro numbers contributed to the rally, with Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, leading the gains. The construction sector saw the largest percentage increase, followed by manufacturing and multi-industries.

site_title: US facing 'mad dash' to adjust to new financial regulations MiFID
summary: The US is facing a "mad dash" to adjust to new financial regulations, MiFID II, which will take effect on January 3. The sweeping EU regulations will impact investment research, transaction booking, and customer data collection, requiring firms to prove they're getting the best deals for customers. Many US firms, particularly small ones, are struggling to prepare, with some even unaware of the regulations' impact. The Securities and Exchange Commission has given a 30-month reprieve, but many firms, including Bank of America, are taking proactive steps to become MiFID-compliant.

site_title: Spreading it out
summary: Luxury watch brands are spreading out their 2017 releases beyond traditional industry mega exhibitions like BaselWorld and SIHH. Instead of cramming all major new launches into a short period, brands like Richemont and Swatch are releasing new models every two to three months. This includes notable releases such as Breitling's Bentley GT Dark Sapphire Edition, IWC's Aquatimer Perpetual Calendar Digital Date-Month Edition 50 Years Aquatimer, and Omega's Seamaster Qua Terra Worldtimer Master Chronometer.

site_title: Heineken to double beer production in Ivory Coast to meet greater thirst
summary: Heineken plans to double its beer production in Ivory Coast by next year, aiming to compete with Castel, the market leader. The company will invest 20 billion CFA francs ($48.19 million) to increase production to 160 million litres annually, surpassing half of Ivory Coast's 270-million litre consumption. This move follows a decade-long political crisis and increasing beer consumption in the country. Heineken's investment will be part of a total 100 billion CFA francs spent on the Brassivoire brewery, which opened last year.

site_title: Bitcoin surges as world's biggest exchange announces futures
summary: CME Group, the world's biggest exchange operator, plans to introduce bitcoin futures by the end of the year, pending regulatory approval. The move is expected to help professional traders and investors access the cryptocurrency, alleviating liquidity concerns. This decision comes after a surprise reversal from previous statements, with CME CEO Terry Duffy expressing interest in the crypto market. The introduction of bitcoin futures could pave the way for exchange-traded funds and provide a robust derivatives market for market makers to hedge their positions.

site_title: Drones, clones and chocolate help buoy United Malacca Bhd
summary: Malaysia-based palm oil company United Malacca Bhd is diversifying its operations to overcome challenges from labor shortages and price volatility. The company is using drones, clones, and other crops to boost yields and oil extraction rates. United Malacca plans to plant 6,000 hectares of clones and hybrids over the next three years, aiming to increase yields to 19 tonnes per hectare by 2025. The company also plans to diversify into crops like cocoa, coffee, and stevia to mitigate risks and capture rising demand.

site_title: Artivision in proposed reverse takeover with MC Payment
summary: Artivision Technologies Limited has proposed a reverse takeover with MC Payment, with a total consideration of at least S$80 million. Ching Chiat Kwong, controlling shareholder and CEO of Oxley Holdings Limited, will acquire MC Payment's shares and bonds, resulting in a 25.18% stake in Artivision. The deal aims to consolidate the Singapore fintech industry and expand into cashless payments in South-east Asia.

site_title: Samsung unveils new management to quell leadership crisis
summary: Samsung Electronics has appointed three new executives to stabilize its top management amid a leadership crisis. Kim Kinam, HS Kim, and DJ Koh will lead the company's components, consumer electronics, and mobile-device divisions, respectively. The appointments come after the company's crown prince, Lee Jae-yong, was sentenced to prison on bribery charges and the family's patriarch, Lee Kun-hee, remains in a coma. The new executives are expected to serve as co-chief executives once they join the board, which requires shareholder approval. Despite the challenges, Samsung reported a record-high profit for the second quarter in a row.

site_title: Tencent's red-hot e-book IPO sets stage for music arm's debut
summary: China Literature Ltd, Tencent's online reading unit, raised $1.1 billion in its Hong Kong IPO, pricing 151 million shares at HK$55 apiece. The company, which operates the QQ Reading app, has 9.6 million works and 6.4 million writers. Tencent's music unit is seeking a similar IPO, which could raise at least $1 billion. Retail investors showed enthusiasm, placing orders for over 600 times the stock initially available. The IPO is the fifth-largest in Hong Kong this year, and shares of Tencent rose 1.5% on the news.

site_title: Towards a better customer experience
summary: A family-owned SME, Chee Fatt Co Pte Ltd, aims to deepen brand advocacy and customer loyalty through a customer-centric approach. The company believes that understanding customers' needs will result in closer working relationships. According to KPMG's Top of Mind survey, 34% of respondents aim to attract new customers by creating personalized customer experiences. SMEs can implement customer experience solutions more easily and faster than larger companies, thanks to advanced technology and affordable prices. To achieve customer centricity, companies must shift their focus from selling products to solving customer problems and infuse customer-centricity into their entire operation.

site_title: AirAsia-Sats' new JV a fitting marriage
summary: AirAsia has formed a joint venture (JV) with Singapore-based ground-handler Sats, with Sats gaining access to Malaysia's market through AirAsia's ground-handling operations at 15 airports. The JV, which Sats will hold 50% of, will provide ground-handling services to third-party airlines, expanding Sats' network in Thailand and the Philippines. In exchange, AirAsia will acquire a 50% stake in Sats Ground Services Singapore and receive $119.3 million in cash, with AirAsia owning 51% of the JV's Malaysian subsidiary and 40% of the Singapore subsidiary.

site_title: Mastercard's profit rises on higher consumer spending
summary: Mastercard reported a 11% increase in gross dollar volume to $1.35 trillion in the third quarter, driven by higher consumer spending globally and maintaining market share. Net income rose 20% to $1.43 billion, beating analyst expectations, and shares rose 1.4% to $151. The company's cross-border volumes increased 15.1% on a local currency basis, with net revenue rising 18% to $3.40 billion. Mastercard's rival Visa also posted a rise in quarterly profit, fueled by higher spending.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore business expectations strengthened in the next six months, with services and manufacturing sectors showing signs of further growth. The Singapore Exchange plans to cut unusual trading activity queries by half. The government is considering a wider carbon market and launching sites for sale. Changi Airport's Terminal 4 opened for business, marking a milestone in aviation history. Singapore shares closed 0.06% lower, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: S'pore mulls prepaid carbon credits to link up with systems elsewhere
summary: Singapore is considering a prepaid carbon credits system to link its carbon tax framework with external carbon markets. Under a draft bill, liable facilities will buy and surrender carbon credits corresponding to their greenhouse gas emissions. This mechanism aims to facilitate integration with global carbon markets and promote a more efficient carbon pricing system. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to prepare for the integration of its carbon tax framework with external carbon markets.

site_title: Ryanair holds profit forecast despite flights chaos
summary: Ryanair has maintained its full-year profit forecast despite cancelling thousands of flights due to a pilots shortage. The airline reported a 11% increase in net profit to €1.3 billion in the first half of the year, driven by a 11% rise in passenger numbers to 72.1 million. Ryanair still expects annual profit after tax of €1.4-1.45 billion, despite taking a hit of €25 million in compensation costs due to flight cancellations.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust amicably resolves dispute with Schenker S'pore
summary: Cache Logistics Trust has resolved a dispute with Schenker Singapore Pte Ltd over a property lease in Singapore. The dispute centered on whether Schenker had a valid option to renew its anchor lease agreement. The parties reached an amicable resolution, marking the end of a legal proceeding initiated by Schenker last year.

site_title: US:Wall St opens higher on strong earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by strong earnings reports from companies such as Kellogg and Mastercard. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 26.64 points, the S&P 500 gained 2.9 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 17.59 points, all up 0.11% or less. The gains followed upbeat earnings reports, helping to extend the stocks rally despite US trade uncertainty and tariff threats.

site_title: The emissions debate gets nasty at IMO meet
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) met to discuss reducing greenhouse gas emissions from international shipping, but progress was hindered by environmental campaign groups and the shipping industry. Despite the IMO's efforts to shape a draft initial strategy, the group agreed to prioritize short-term measures, with candidate measures to be finalized by 2018-2023 and 2023-2030. Environmental groups, such as the Clean Shipping Coalition, criticized the lack of urgency in the proposed strategy, citing a need for immediate action to reduce emissions and meet the 2020 global 0.5% sulphur cap. The IMO and shipping industry associations expressed optimism about the progress made, but the debate highlights the challenges in implementing effective measures to combat global warming through maritime regulations.

site_title: Pfizer beats profit estimates, raises 2017 earnings forecast
summary: Pfizer Inc. reported a quarterly profit that beat market estimates, driven by higher-than-expected sales of its pneumonia vaccine Prevnar. The company raised its full-year earnings forecast and tightened its revenue forecast. Prevnar sales accounted for 11.5% of Pfizer's total revenue, while breast cancer treatment Ibrance saw a 60% surge in sales. Net income more than doubled to $2.84 billion, or 47 cents per share, beating analysts' average estimate.

site_title: Fengshui, the contemporary way
summary: Desmond Jason Academy, a Singapore-based fengshui consulting firm, modernizes the ancient Chinese practice by applying contemporary approaches to classic texts. Masters Desmond Ng and Jason Chan, who have read widely across various fields, provide holistic advice on sustainability, prosperity, and wellness. The duo has clients from diverse cultures and regions, leveraging their bilingualism to adapt to local cultures. They utilize innovative marketing and operations, including social media and 3D printing, to deliver consultations and presentations. As the global economy consolidates, Desmond Jason Academy advises clients to assess their "ba zi" for guidance on navigating challenging times.

site_title: Belgium to treat Catalan ex-leader 'like any other European'
summary: Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel stated that deposed Catalan separatist leader Carles Puigdemont will be treated "like any other European citizen" after arriving in Brussels. Puigdemont plans to stay in Brussels for "safety purposes and freedom," despite not seeking asylum. Michel emphasized that his government did not invite the Catalan leader and that he has the same rights and responsibilities as any European citizen. The Belgian leader reiterated his call for "political dialogue in Spain to resolve the crisis within the framework of the national and international order."

site_title: Forex gains and tax credit pull SembMarine back into the black
summary: SembCorp Marine reported a net profit of S$2.7 million in its third quarter, reversing a net loss of S$21.8 million in the previous year. Revenue dropped 64.3% to S$316.9 million due to lower rig building revenue and fewer projects. A foreign exchange gain of S$31.3 million helped offset losses. The group expects a recovery in the drilling segment due to stabilisation of day rates and increased secondary rig sales.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange Fund assets reach HK$3.9t end-Sept
summary: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund assets reached HK$3.9 trillion at the end of September, down HK$9.9 billion from the previous month. Foreign currency assets increased by HK$8.5 billion, while Hong Kong dollar assets decreased by HK$18.4 billion due to sales and withdrawals. The decline was partly offset by mark-to-market losses on foreign currency portfolios.

site_title: US labour costs increase 0.7 per cent in third quarter
summary: US labour costs increased 0.7% in the third quarter, the largest year-on-year rise in 2-1/2 years, lifting the year-on-year rate to 2.5%. Wage growth remained modest, with economists forecasting a 3% increase needed to push inflation closer to the 2% target. This increase is a welcome sign for the Federal Reserve, which may consider a policy change to address inflation concerns. The Employment Cost Index, a measure of labour costs, rose 0.7% after a 0.5% gain in the second quarter.

site_title: Citic Envirotech secures 4.6b yuan China project
summary: CITIC Envirotech secured its largest project, worth 4.6 billion yuan, in Lanzhou City, China, involving wastewater treatment and land remediation. The wastewater treatment project will upgrade an existing plant to 400,000 cu m/day using CEL's proprietary Membrane Bioreactor technology, while the land remediation project will clean up 124,000 sq m of land. The project will be completed within two years, funded by internal resources and bank financing, with no impact on the company's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: Happiness for sale
summary: Benny Low, founder of Weekends, a lifestyle gift and stationery store, aims to sell happiness through quirky and inspirational lifestyle items. His store, Weekends, and Simply Toys' distributor, share that buying happiness is possible. Weekends' exterior is designed to catch customers' attention, while the store's interior features fun and light-hearted items. The founders believe their stores can provide a happy experience for customers, resonating with the concept of the weekend.

site_title: Japanese restaurant group RE&S to list on Catalist
summary: Japanese restaurant group RE&S Holdings has filed a preliminary prospectus to list on Catalist, aiming to raise capital for new outlets and business expansion. The company, which owns 20 restaurant brands, reported rising revenue and net profit in the past two years. Proceeds from the listing will be used to open new outlets, refurbish existing ones, and invest in acquisitions and joint ventures. RE&S expects to recommend and distribute dividends of at least 35% of net profits, despite not having a fixed dividend policy.

site_title: Samurai 2K Aerosol issues profit guidance
summary: SAMURAI 2K Aerosol expects to report higher revenue and profit for the first half of 2018 due to increased demand for its aerosol paint products. The company attributes the improvement to enhanced marketing initiatives, which have built strong end-user engagement and educated consumers about the aesthetic benefits of its products. The results are expected to be stronger in the Indonesian market compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Doing the right thing as an employer
summary: Employers in Singapore must handle employment law issues carefully to avoid severe consequences. The law requires employers to pay employees till the last day of service, even if the employee is terminated without notice. Employers must also ensure their employment agreements clearly outline the terms and conditions for termination, avoiding overly broad or vague clauses. Misinterpretation of these clauses can lead to costly lawsuits, investigations, and reputational damage. Employers must carefully define what constitutes "serious misconduct" and "material terms" to avoid potential issues.
