site_title: Oil and gas, manufacturing stocks notch dramatic rises in Singapore
summary: Singapore's oil and gas stocks surged, with Brent crude reaching a two-year high, while the Straits Times Index (STI) remained flat. Mirach Energy rose 23%, Vallianz Holdings rose 21%, and Pacific Radiance rose 12%. In non-oil and gas news, manufacturing stocks climbed, with Venture Corp adding 3.1% and Taiwan's economy growing 3.1% year-on-year. The new iPhone X's availability is expected to boost the economy in the near term.

site_title: HK to host 2022 Gay Games as LGBT acceptance grows in parts of Asia
summary: Hong Kong has been awarded to host the 2022 Gay Games, beating bids from the US and Mexico, amid growing momentum for the gay rights movement in Asia. The event, expected to attract over 15,000 participants, will provide a HK$1-billion economic boost and promote LGBT+ equality. This marks a significant step forward for Hong Kong, which has a history of autonomy and freedoms not seen on the mainland. The games are part of a global movement, with the next event set to take place in Paris in 2018.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.43 points to 1,747.92. Trading volume reached 3.1 billion lots worth RM2.8 billion, with 458 gainers outnumbering 449 losers.

site_title: Japanese restaurant group RE&S lodges preliminary prospectus for Catalist listing
summary: Japanese restaurant group RE&S Holdings has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a Catalist listing to raise capital for new outlets. Proceeds will be used for business expansion, new outlet establishment, and general working capital. The IPO is expected to be backed by Heliconia Capital Management, a unit of Temasek Holdings. RE&S, owner of popular Japanese restaurants like Ichiban Boshi, reported a net profit of S$5.7 million in FY2017, with plans to distribute at least 35% of its net profits as dividends. The company's controlling ownership resides with executive directors Hiroshi Tatara and Yek Hong Liat.

site_title: Dubai's Emirates Reit plans debut sukuk of at least US$300m this year: source
summary: Dubai-based Emirates Reit plans to issue a debut sukuk of at least $300 million by the end of 2017, replacing all of its outstanding debt. The sukuk, denominated in US dollars, will be managed by Equitativa and could potentially replace up to $300 million of debt. The move comes as the Gulf Cooperation Council sees record debt sales, with dollar-denominated bond issuance reaching $79.2 billion this year. Emirates Reit has a portfolio of $772 million and a loan-to-value ratio of 36.8%, allowing for issuance larger than the planned amount.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are strengthening their collaboration in green and transition finance. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks are experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release. Companies such as Grab and OCBC have seen leadership changes, with Grab downgraded to 'hold' and OCBC CEO Helen Wong retiring with Tan Teck Long taking over. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event, while Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: ComfortDelGro subsidiary acquires assets of Perth-based taxi management company
summary: ComfortDelGro's subsidiary, Swan Taxis, has acquired Metro WA Taxi Management's business assets in Perth for A$5.3 million. Metro Taxi, the largest taxi management company in Perth, owns 170 taxis and provides taxi plate management, fleet maintenance, and leasing services. The acquisition expands Swan's services into fleet management and retains Metro Taxi's trade name for the cabs.

site_title: Pacific Star unit partners Mid-East property group to develop luxury properties in region
summary: Pacific Star Development and DAMAC International partner to develop luxury properties in Southeast Asia over the next five years. The partnership will focus on Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Singapore, with an emphasis on high-end residential, hospitality, and retail projects in key gateway cities. The two developers will collaborate on identifying prime locations and developing new projects. This partnership aims to capitalize on the growing demand for luxury properties in the region.

site_title: Former president Tony Tan takes on role as chief patron of SIAS
summary: Former Singapore President Tony Tan Keng Yam has accepted the role of chief patron for the Securities Investors Association (SIAS), a shareholder advocacy group. This title is reserved for individuals who have made significant contributions to the nation's betterment. Tan stepped down as president in August 2017, following a six-year term. The appointment marks a return to the public sphere for Tan, who is now set to contribute to the country's financial sector.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's stock markets remained steady at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.2% to 7,499.52 points. The Paris CAC 40 and Madrid's IBEX 35 were virtually flat. This stability follows recent US trade tensions, with investors focusing on the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.06 per cent down on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.06% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index dropping 1.89 points to 3,374.08. The most actively traded counter was Lion Gold, with 2.14 billion shares worth S$1.43 billion changing hands. Gainers narrowly outnumbered losers 231 to 216. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: NTU, SMI launch S$15m maritime research centre to cut ship emissions
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and the Singapore Maritime Institute (SMI) launched a S$15 million research centre to develop innovative and sustainable solutions for Singapore's maritime industry. The Maritime Energy and Sustainable Development (MESD) centre of excellence will focus on energy management, emissions management, and sustainable maritime operations to reduce harmful ship emissions and comply with international maritime regulations. The centre is expected to be operational by the end of this year, with the goal of contributing to a more sustainable maritime industry.

site_title: StanChart Singapore CEO Judy Hsu promoted to regional role
summary: Standard Chartered announced that Judy Hsu, its Singapore CEO, will take over responsibility for the Asean and South Asia region by the fourth quarter of 2018. Current regional CEO Anna Marrs will step down, but retain her position as CEO of commercial banking and private banking. Hsu will join the management team, with the bank expected to fill the Singapore CEO position separately.

site_title: Airbus Q3 earnings down 4%
summary: Airbus reported a 4% decline in third-quarter earnings to 697 million euros, lower than the expected 5.6% drop. Revenues rose 2% to 14.244 billion euros. The company attributed the decline to delays in aircraft deliveries and inventory build-up. Airbus reaffirmed its forecasts despite ongoing corruption problems and a sweeping internal investigation. The company also disclosed inaccuracies in past US declarations related to commissions in airplane sales.

site_title: Indian billionaire fund says bank boost to help clear loans
summary: Indian billionaire fund Kotak Investment Advisors says the government's pledge of 2.11 trillion rupees (S$44.3 billion) of capital for state banks could help distressed funds buy loans, accelerating loan resolution and market clearing prices. This could aid banks plagued by high stressed-asset ratios to start lending again, potentially kick-starting economic growth. The fund's managing director, S. Sriniwasan, notes that the capital injection will enable banks to take necessary 'haircuts' on nonperforming assets, making it easier for funds to deploy money.

site_title: South Korea: Signs of thaw in Seoul-China row spurs stocks to record high, won firms
summary: South Korea's stocks reached a record high for the third consecutive session after Seoul and Beijing agreed to work on strained relations. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.9% at 2,523.43 points, driven by Samsung Electronics' share price rise of nearly 2%. Foreign investors bought 412.5 billion won worth of shares, lifting the won to a nine-week high against the dollar.

site_title: BP beats Q3 expectations, announces share buyback programme
summary: BP has reported a third-quarter earnings of $1.87 billion, exceeding analysts' forecasts of $1.58 billion. The company will also resume a share buyback program to dilute the impact of its scrip dividend program. This move comes after a profit of $933 million in the same quarter last year and $684 million in the second quarter of 2017. The decision to restart the share buyback program was made by BP's chief financial officer, Brian Gilvary, citing the company's confidence in its financial outlook.

site_title: Razer to raise up to HK$4b in proposed HKSE listing
summary: Razer, a Singapore-founded gaming company, plans to raise up to HK$4.3 billion (S$749.7 million) through a proposed listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKSE) main board. The company will offer 1.063 billion shares at a price range of HK$2.93 to HK$4. The Hong Kong public offering is expected to start on November 1 and close on November 6.

site_title: Nissan's Oct passenger car sales in Japan likely halved amid scandal
summary: Nissan's Oct passenger car sales in Japan are likely to have halved due to improper final inspection procedures discovered at its domestic plants. The company has recalled 1.2 million vehicles, including all passenger cars produced for sale in Japan over the past three years. Nissan has completed measures to bring final inspection procedures in line with transport ministry requirements, with all plants expected to be compliant by the end of the week. The company will only allow certified inspectors in the final inspection area and conduct regular checks to ensure proper inspections.

site_title: New Zealand bans foreign home buyers after price surge
summary: New Zealand has banned foreign home buyers from purchasing existing homes, effective early next year, in an effort to make property more affordable for its citizens. The ban aims to curb price surges, particularly in Auckland, where average house prices have reached over NZ$1 million. The move follows a growing trend of nations restricting foreign property sales, but its effectiveness remains uncertain.

site_title: SGX to cut down on unusual trading activity queries by half
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to reduce the number of unusual trading activity queries by half, starting November 1, to eliminate "noise" in the market. The new system will allow prices to increase before a query is issued, and the regulatory regime's robustness has been tested to ensure that material cases will still be queried. This move follows two recent initiatives to detect and stop market misconduct, which have cut down on alerts by half. Insider trading is also being addressed with a new initiative to be announced later.

site_title: Aussie shares end lower but see best month of 2017; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Tuesday, falling 0.17% to 5,909.00, despite gaining 4% in October, its best month in 2017. Materials stocks declined due to a slowdown in China's manufacturing sector, while financials stocks also dipped. Consumer staples and energy stocks were stronger, with New Zealand shares reaching a record high, rising 0.03% to 8,146.34.

site_title: Residential GLS site at Fourth Avenue under reserve list triggered for sale
summary: A residential site in Singapore's Bukit Timah area, under the Reserve List of the government land sale (GLS) programme, has been triggered for sale. The 1.9-hectare site, with a maximum permissible gross floor area of 33,358 sq m, is next to the Sixth Avenue MRT Station and well-connected via major roads. A developer has lodged an application to bid at a minimum price of S$448.8 million, and the tender will be launched in about four weeks. The site is nestled in a mature private residential estate and is close to several good schools.

site_title: Singapore business expectations up for next six months; services show signs of strengthening
summary: Singapore's services sector showed significant improvement in business optimism, with a net weighted balance of 9% expecting improved conditions, up from 5% a quarter ago. The manufacturing sector also turned more positive, with a 5% net weighted balance. The majority of firms expect similar business conditions, but industries such as food and beverage, retail trade, and accommodation industries foresee a pickup in business conditions due to year-end festivities.

site_title: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 opens for business
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 (T4) opened for business on October 31, 2017, marking a milestone in Singapore's aviation history. The terminal operated smoothly, with passengers using self-check-in facilities for the first flight out to Hong Kong. Cathay Pacific operated the first arriving and departing flights, with CX659 arriving at 5:40am and CX650 departing at 6:50am. The successful opening of T4 is a significant development for Singapore's aviation industry.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat, Softbank down on merger reports
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index unchanged at 22,011.61, and the Topix index down 0.28% at 1,765.96. SoftBank dropped following reports of a collapsed telecoms mega-merger. Japan's central bank cut its annual inflation forecast but maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy.

site_title: MPA partners Shell in clean fuels tech, automation and port digitalisation
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has partnered with Shell to develop innovative solutions for clean fuel technologies, automation, and digitalisation in the maritime industry. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) aims to reduce emissions and enhance safety, efficiency, and security of maritime communication. Key areas of focus include electronic data exchanges, automation, intelligent systems, and cleaner energy. The partnership will support research and development, test-bedding of projects, and digitalisation efforts in Singapore's ports, driving the digital transformation of the maritime industry.

site_title: French economy grew 0.5% in Q3, previous quarter revised up
summary: The French economy grew 0.5% in the third quarter, matching a Reuters poll, driven by consumer spending and robust investment. This resulted in a 2.2% annual GDP growth rate, the fastest since 2011. The revised growth for 2017 stands at 1.7%, thanks to upward revisions in previous quarters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip, risk appetites cut by China data
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday, curbing investors' risk appetites due to a stronger-than-expected cooling in China's factory activity in October. The Hang Seng index dipped to 28,245.54, while Shanghai stocks ended slightly higher. China's manufacturing sector growth slowed more than expected, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) showing a decline. Despite this, Hong Kong shares rose 2.5% for the month, while Shanghai stocks gained 5.5%.

site_title: Google ditches autopilot driving feature after test user napped behind wheel
summary: Google's self-driving car unit, Waymo, has halted development of features requiring driver intervention in emergency situations due to user distractions. Tests showed users napping, applying makeup, and using phones while driving at 56 mph. This decision comes after five years of envisioning autonomous highway driving technology. The shift is aimed at reducing reliance on drivers and minimizing the risk of accidents.

site_title: Asian imports of Iranian oil hit highest in six months
summary: Asian imports of Iranian oil reached their highest level in six months in September, driven by increased purchases in China and South Korea. The imports rose 5.1% from last year, with China, India, South Korea, and Japan importing 1.9 million barrels per day. However, purchases are expected to fall in coming weeks as shipments drop below 1.5 million barrels per day for October. Chinese imports rose 60% from last year, while South Korea's imports reached a five-month high, but Japan's imports declined by 30% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened lower on Tuesday, following a retreat in New York, amid economic news including major earnings reports and a Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.36%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices lost 0.28% and 0.16% respectively.

site_title: Sony forecasts record annual profits on smartphone parts business
summary: Sony forecasts record annual profits, driven by its PlayStation games division and a booming smartphone parts business. The electronics giant expects to book a net profit of 380 billion yen (S$5.6 billion) for the fiscal year to March 2018, surpassing a decade-old record. Operating profit is forecast to be the highest-ever 630 billion yen, beating a record set two decades ago. Sales expanded 22% in the latest quarter, with net profit more than 27 times bigger than the year-before level.

site_title: Asia: Markets track US retreat
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, following a US retreat, as investors await major earnings reports and a Federal Reserve policy meeting. Hong Kong fell 0.2%, Tokyo dropped 0.4%, and Shanghai dipped 0.3%. However, Seoul gained 0.4% as Samsung Electronics reported a record profit, despite its de facto leader's imprisonment and the recall of its Galaxy Note 7 device. Chinese manufacturing growth slowed in October due to weak demand and public holidays. Investors await US news, including a possible replacement of the Federal Reserve chief and the release of the October jobs report.

site_title: Singapore ramps up R&D for smarter, greener maritime future
summary: Singapore has launched three initiatives to build a smarter and greener maritime future, including a new research centre focused on sustainable energy and maritime solutions. The Maritime Energy and Sustainable Development centre (MESD) will be established with a $15 million investment from Nanyang Technology University (NTU) and $10 million from Singapore Maritime Institute (SMI). The centre will focus on energy management, emissions management, and sustainable maritime operations. Additionally, NTU has signed agreements with Jurong Port and MPA to pursue research and innovation in clean fuel technology, remote or autonomous technology, and digitalisation.

site_title: South Korea, China to hold talks: Seoul
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In will hold talks with Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the APEC summit in Vietnam, aiming to restore bilateral cooperation and exchanges. The talks come after China imposed economic measures on South Korea in response to the deployment of the US THAAD missile defense system. China views the system as a threat to its military capabilities, while South Korea and the US say it's necessary to defend against North Korea's missile threats. The talks are seen as a step towards normalizing relations between the two countries.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Hay Kian issues 'buy' on GL
summary: UOB Hay Kian has issued a "buy" call on GL Ltd, citing a weakened sterling, high performance in the UK hotel market, and potential asset disposal of GL's casino and Hawaii properties. The broker sets a target price of S$1.185, representing a 30.9% increase from its current valuation. GL's established status in the London hotel market and diverse portfolio near tourist hotspots are seen as positives, while risks include intensifying competition and geopolitical risks.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.25% at 3,367.42, following a correction on US stocks and negative earnings reports from corporates. The Straits Times Index fell 8.55 points, with 94.9 million shares traded. Losers outpaced gainers 86 to 46.

site_title: JGBs steady as market ponders BOJ member's easing signal
summary: Japanese government bonds remained steady on Tuesday as investors considered a Bank of Japan policymaker's suggestion to guide 15-year bond yields lower. The 10-year JGB yield was flat at 0.065%, while the 30-year and 40-year yields decreased by half a basis point to 0.865% and 1.065%, respectively. The market's reaction was muted, with the 10-year JGB futures contract ending up 0.03 points at 150.47. The steady yields suggest a cautious approach to monetary policy, with investors waiting for further guidance from the BOJ.

site_title: 9 bodies, 2 severed heads, found in Tokyo flat: reports
summary: Japanese police have found nine bodies, including two with severed heads, in a Tokyo flat. The bodies were discovered in a cool box and large boxes in the apartment, and authorities have arrested 27-year-old Takahiro Shiraishi. Shiraishi told police he killed the victims and chopped up their bodies to hide evidence. The victims were eight women and one man, with a 23-year-old woman who had been missing since September 21 being connected to Shiraishi through a website. CCTV footage shows Shiraishi and the missing woman walking together last Monday.

site_title: Off-grid power provider SolarHome bags first debt funding
summary: Singapore-based off-grid power solutions startup SolarHome secured its first debt funding through crowdfunding platform Kiva, with support from Impact Investment Exchange and USAID. The two-year, zero-coupon non-convertible instruments were raised in seven days, with funding to be used to support the growth of its installed system base in Myanmar. This milestone follows an oversubscribed pre-Series A equity funding round of US$625,000 led by Uberis Capital, and marks a major step for the company as it aims to expand to other developing nations.

site_title: Asia racks up US$67.8b in debt issuance for Q3; up 18.2%
summary: Asia's total debt issuance for Q3 2017 reached US$67.8 billion, a 18.2% year-over-year increase, according to the Asia Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association. This represents a 14.6% drop from Q2 and a 10.1% increase from Q3 2016. The rise in debt issuance is attributed to robust appetite in China, particularly for bonds issued by Chinese groups in Hong Kong, as they expand their offshore business and diversify overseas.

site_title: DBS rolls out programme to re-skill 1,500 workers over next 18 months
summary: DBS Bank has launched a Professional Conversion Programme (DBS PCP) to re-skill 1,500 employees over the next 18 months. The programme aims to enhance the skills of employees in various departments, such as back-end operations and client-facing roles. This move is seen as a first for a Singapore bank, with the goal of deepening employees' skillsets and competitiveness. Eight job roles have been identified for re-skilling, allowing employees to transition into new or enhanced roles within the bank.

site_title: BOJ keeps policy steady; newcomer signals desire for future easing
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, with interest rates unchanged at 0.1% and a 10-year government bond yield target of zero%. New board member Goushi Kataoka dissented, arguing the BOJ should buy government bonds to keep 15-year JGB yields below 0.2%. Kataoka's dissent was not enough to change the policy, which was decided by an 8-1 vote. The BOJ also slightly cut its inflation forecast for the current fiscal year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.24 points to 1,748.11. Volume was 221.42 million lots worth RM68.4 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 134 to 89.

site_title: BRC Asia suspended as takeover bid ends with offeror holding 95.8% stake
summary: BRC Asia, a steel prefabrication firm, has been suspended after a takeover bid by Esteel Enterprise ended with the offeror controlling 95.83% of the company's issued share capital. Esteel's 92.5 Singapore cents per share offer closed on Monday, leaving BRC Asia with a public float of just 4.17%, below the 10% minimum for trading on the Singapore Exchange. Esteel had stated it would keep BRC Asia listed, but retained the right to revisit this plan if the public float falls below 10%.

site_title: Singapore September bank lending up 1%
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in September rose 1% from August to S$640.7 billion, driven by higher disbursements to financial institutions. This represents a 6.2% increase from the same period last year. Loans in Asian currency units (ACU) also rose to S$570.4 billion, up from S$569.1 billion in August.

site_title: JTC launches industrial site at Jalan Lam Huat for sale under confirmed list of iGLS
summary: JTC has launched an industrial site at Jalan Lam Huat, zoned for Business-2 development, as part of its Industrial Government Land Sales (iGLS) programme. The 0.77-hectare site has a 20-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 2.5. Industrialists can apply for the site before Dec 26, 11am. This is the fifth out of eight Confirmed List sites for the second half of 2017, aiming to offer more choices for industrial development.

site_title: Australian dollar slips on China PMI; NZ$ set for worst month since January 2016
summary: The Australian dollar slipped 0.1% to US$0.7678, edging closer to its 4-month trough, after China's official manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 51.6 in October, down from 52.4. The Aussie is poised for its third straight month of losses in October, but some analysts see its woes coming to an end. The New Zealand dollar also fell 0.36% to US$0.6850, on track for its worst monthly showing since January 2016.

site_title: 3 land parcels for food fish farming at Lim Chu Kang up for sale by public tender
summary: The Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority of Singapore has launched three land parcels for food fish farming at Lim Chu Kang for public tender. The parcels, each with a 20-year lease, range from 15,575 to 23,961 square meters and have fixed sale prices of S$378,000 and S$587,000. The tender will close on January 9, 2018, following the release of 12 land parcels for vegetable farming in August. This is part of a larger plan to tender out 36 new plots of farmland in Lim Chu Kang and Sungei Tengah.

site_title: China factory PMI falls from five-year high on pollution cleanup
summary: China's official factory gauge fell to 51.6 in October, the lowest since May 2012, due to a pollution cleanup campaign. New orders and prices declined, with the non-manufacturing PMI at 54.3. Despite this, the economy is expected to grow for the first full year at 6.5% or above, with growth momentum expected to continue. Tighter environmental supervision is believed to have impacted the PMI, but the manufacturing sector's overall contribution to GDP growth has been declining.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Roxy-Pacific, Tianjin Zhong Xin, KTL Global
summary: Investors are reacting to negative earnings reports from Singapore, following a retreat on Wall Street. Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported an 81.5% decline in Q3 net profit to S$1.5 million, while Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group saw an 8% decline in net profit to S$17.1 million. KTL Global has lifted a trading halt after its CEO was requested to assist in an investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: Disappearing bank jobs won't be coming back: Nordea CEO
summary: Nordea Bank AB has announced a 6,000 job cut, nearly 10% of its workforce, as part of a radical overhaul in the banking industry. CEO Casper von Koskull views this as a necessary step towards becoming more efficient and digitally advanced. The European Banking Federation estimates a 14% reduction in finance industry personnel since 2008, with banks now employing 2.8 million people. Von Koskull believes only lean, efficient banks will thrive in the future, and that Nordea is pioneering this transformation.

site_title: Hot stock: Oil & gas explorers ride crude surge
summary: Oil and gas explorers on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a surge in stock prices as crude oil prices rose above $60 a barrel for the second day. Mirach Energy's shares jumped 32% after trading at S$0.099, while Interra Resources and Rex International also rose. The next OPEC meeting is set for November 30, where officials will present their oil outlook and push for production cuts to be extended until the end of 2018, potentially benefiting oil and gas explorers.

site_title: Facebook's testimony says Russia posts reached 126m users
summary: Facebook's general counsel, Colin Stretch, is set to testify before a Congressional panel, stating that 29 million US voters were served content from Russian-backed accounts, which reached 126 million users' news feeds over two years. This represents about 40% of the US population. Facebook portrays itself as shocked by the Russian use of its platform for political means and is taking steps to prevent future misuse, including requiring more documentation from political advertisers.

site_title: Brent oil holds above US$60 on expected output cut extension
summary: Brent oil prices held above $60 a barrel, near a 7-year high, due to expectations of OPEC-led production cuts being extended beyond March 2018. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Russia, and nine other producers agreed to cut 1.8 million barrels per day from January 2016. Saudi Arabia and Russia have voiced support for a further extension, which has rallied Brent crude futures. However, rising Iraqi exports and US production have put a lid on prices, preventing a further rise.

site_title: Gold rises ahead of bumper week for central bank news
summary: Gold rose 0.3% to $1,275.76 an ounce ahead of central bank meetings, including the US Federal Reserve policy meeting and the Bank of Japan and Bank of England meetings. The metal is sensitive to rising rates and a stronger US dollar. Speculators cut bullish COMEX gold bets, and US President Donald Trump's expected announcement of the next Federal Reserve chair, with Jerome Powell considered a moderate, is also influencing prices.

site_title: Blazing new trails in the tech world
summary: The article highlights the winners of the SiTF Awards, which recognize innovative infocomm products and solutions. DC Frontiers won for Artificial Intelligence/ Big Data, while igloohome won for Internet of Things. The companies shared their groundbreaking solutions and cutting-edge technologies behind their products. The article also mentions unrelated news, including China's efforts to aid employment amid trade tensions, US weekly jobless claims falling, and Ambani's Reliance Jio delaying its India IPO.

site_title: URA launches Chong Kuo Road site for sale, releases reserve site at Cuscaden Road for application
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a 99-year leasehold site at Chong Kuo Road for sale under the Confirmed List, with a maximum building height of five storeys and a permissible gross floor area of 5,997 sq m. A second site at Cuscaden Road is available for application under the Reserve List, with a maximum building height of 100 metres and a permissible gross floor area of 16,024 sq m. Together, these sites can potentially yield about 250 residential units. The tender for Chong Kuo Road site will close on Jan 30.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks hit record high as Seoul, Beijing seek to mend relations, won jumps
summary: South Korean stocks reached a record high on October 31, 2017, after Seoul and Beijing agreed to normalize relations strained by a year-long standoff over a US anti-missile system. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.5% to 2,514.96 points, with shares of Hyundai Motor and Hyundai Mobis gaining 2% and 5.7%, respectively. Lotte Tour Development surged 18% and Lotte Shopping Co Ltd jumped 5.7% in early trade. The agreement boosted sentiment and helped drive the South Korean won to an eight-week high against the dollar.

site_title: Amazon teaches Alexa to speak Hinglish. Apple's Siri is next
summary: Amazon is teaching its Alexa virtual assistant to speak Hinglish, a blend of Hindi and English, as it ships Echo speakers in India. The local makeover began about a year after introducing the product in foreign markets like the UK and Germany. This Hinglish-speaking Alexa uses an Indian accent and is a result of collaboration between linguists, speech scientists, developers, and engineers.

site_title: Shinvest trims FY18 loss to S$182,000 on back of lower costs and expenses
summary: Shinvest Holding, a precision manufacturing company, reported a narrowed full-year loss of S$182,000 in FY18, down from a year-ago loss of S$1.5 million. The company reduced costs and expenses by 90% to S$115,000, while revenue decreased 0.4% to S$53.3 million. Despite this, the net asset value per share rose to 90.2 Singapore cents.

site_title: Alliance Mineral makes further amendments to recent deal with Burwill
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets Ltd has amended its deal with Burwill Commodity, a Hong Kong-listed company, to supply lithium concentrate from its Bald Hill Project in Western Australia. The new terms include a payment of A$5 million by Burwill as subscription consideration for the fourth tranche of subscription shares by November 7. Alliance Mineral will also waive its right to retain A$4.375 million paid as the second prepayment for lithium concentrate if it receives the A$5 million by the deadline. The amended agreement also includes loan payments and revised delivery terms.

site_title: Ex-national player meets Navratilova in Pro-Am event
summary: SINGAPORE: Former Singapore national tennis player Sherman Lim, 42, had a rare opportunity to play tennis with tennis legend Martina Navratilova at the BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals Singapore presented by SC Global. Navratilova, a 61-year-old former world No 1 player, was one of nine legend ambassadors at the tournament. Lim praised Navratilova for her passion and generosity, saying she is "genuine and wonderful" and continues to inspire the next generation of tennis players. The encounter was part of the Pro-Am event at the Singapore Sports Hub.

site_title: Collective sale tender for 11 Balmoral Road launched with S$75m asking price
summary: A collective sale tender for 11 Balmoral Road, a 17-unit freehold development in Singapore's prime district 10, has been launched with an asking price of S$75 million. Owners are seeking an estimated land rate of S$1,761 per sq ft per plot ratio. The site is zoned "residential" with a gross plot ratio of 1.6, allowing for a medium-rise high-end project of up to 12 storeys. The site is located near the Newton MRT Interchange and renowned schools, making it an attractive option for developers.

site_title: Draft of Singapore's carbon pricing bill released for public consultation
summary: Singapore's government has released a draft of its carbon pricing bill for public consultation, outlining a framework for a carbon tax on large greenhouse gas emitters. The bill sets measurement, reporting, and verification requirements and gives the National Environment Agency powers to make regulations. This marks the second round of public consultation on the carbon tax, which aims to reduce the country's carbon footprint and meet international climate goals. The bill is expected to be finalized later this year.

site_title: Singapore mulls wider carbon market in crafting carbon tax law
summary: Singapore is considering a wider carbon market as part of its carbon tax law, which aims to reduce carbon intensity by 36% by 2030. The tax will apply to large emitters, mainly from the petroleum refining, chemicals, and semiconductor sectors, and will be linked to a credits-based mechanism. Facilities will buy and surrender carbon credits corresponding to their emissions, with the government setting a fixed price for credits. The tax is expected to be between S$10-20 per tonne of greenhouse gas emissions, with a consultation period for the draft bill running until December 8.

site_title: Europe: Shares tick higher as earnings roll in, Spain rebounds
summary: Spanish equities rebounded on Monday, driven by weekend demonstrations for a unified Spain and a poll lead for parties opposed to Catalan independence. The IBEX benchmark rose 2.4% led by Caixabank and Banco de Sabadell. European tech stocks also gained, with European iPhone suppliers STMicro, Dialog Semi, and AMS rising 2.3%, 5.6%, and 4.8% respectively. However, some UK housebuilders and HSBC shares fell, and Glencore's shares rose after a trading update. Investors are optimistic about the resolution of the Catalan crisis, but expect volatility in the weeks to come.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower, SoftBank down
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on October 31, 2017, following a decline in New York markets. SoftBank dropped sharply after reports of a telecoms mega-merger call-off. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.53% to 21,894.27, while the Topix index decreased 0.43% to 1,763.18.

site_title: SpaceX launches Korean satellite, sticks rocket landing
summary: SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying a South Korean communications satellite, Koreasat-5A, to boost broadband coverage in southeast Asia and the Middle East. The rocket, the 19th to land in two years, stuck its first stage on an ocean platform, marking a significant milestone in SpaceX's reusable rocket technology. The launch was the 16th for SpaceX this year, with the goal of saving money and reducing the cost of space travel.

site_title: Nintendo lifts profit outlook on strong Switch console sales
summary: Nintendo has raised its full-year operating profit forecast to 120 billion yen (S$1.44 billion) due to strong demand for its Switch console, which has nearly doubled its stock price to nine-year highs. The company forecast 14 million Switch sales for the year, up from 10 million units, and expects supply shortages to ease. Nintendo is trying to diversify its business by moving into new areas such as smartphone gaming and theme parks, amid stiff competition from the Xbox One X console released by Microsoft.

site_title: Sand is precious resource for Singapore that's harder to buy
summary: Singapore, a small island nation, is struggling to secure a steady supply of sand, a precious resource essential for its physical expansion. The country has expanded its land by 24% since 1960 by importing sand to fill its coastline. This expansion has enabled the creation of key assets, such as the shipping port and airport, which are now situated on land that didn't previously exist. The scarcity of sand poses challenges for Singapore's development and growth, highlighting the importance of this often-overlooked resource.

site_title: Netflix cancels flagship series 'House of Cards'
summary: Netflix has canceled its flagship series "House of Cards" after the sixth and final season, citing a decision made before the allegations of sexual misconduct against star Kevin Spacey surfaced. The move comes after actor Anthony Rapp accused Spacey of making a sexual advance towards him in 1986. Despite the allegations, a source claims the decision to end the series was unrelated to the allegations, which were made public after Spacey apologized on Twitter and came out as gay.

site_title: Najib's Budget crafted with eye on swing voters: analysts
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's pre-election Budget aimed to boost disposable incomes of potential swing voters, particularly the lower and middle classes, through tax cuts, bonuses, and increased maternity leave. Analysts expect Umno and the Barisan Nasional coalition to win the upcoming elections, but rising living costs threaten to chip away at their support. Najib's budget also targeted Generation Y and women, while maintaining discipline to reduce the fiscal deficit.

site_title: Samsung Electronics posts record Q3 profits of 11.2t won
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a record Q3 profit of 11.2 trillion won ($10.0 billion) in the July-September period, a 148% increase from the same period last year. Despite facing challenges such as the jailing of its de facto leader and a recall of its flagship device, the company attributed its profitability to past decisions and investments. This comes after CEO Kwon Oh Hyun's resignation, citing an "unprecedented crisis" facing the company.

site_title: Jigsaw carves up Clooney's Suburbicon at US box office
summary: George Clooney's film "Suburbicon" opened at the US box office, earning a poor wide-release total for Paramount Pictures, marking its worst opening in the company's history. Meanwhile, Steven Spielberg's production company released a military drama that was largely ignored.

site_title: Putin assassination plot suspect wounded, wife killed in Ukraine
summary: A Chechen volunteer soldier, Adam Osmayev, was wounded and his wife, Amina Okuyeva, killed in a car strafing near Kiev, Ukraine, in a suspected assassination attempt targeting Russian President Vladimir Putin. Osmayev was accused of plotting to kill Putin in 2012 and had previously survived an assassination attempt. The attack occurred just weeks after Ukraine opened a terror probe into a bombing that wounded a nationalist Ukrainian lawmaker.

site_title: Euro-area economic confidence in Oct surges to highest in 17 years
summary: The euro-area economic confidence index surged to 114 in October, its highest in almost 17 years, driven by improved growth prospects, declining unemployment, and rising consumer spending. This marks the fifth consecutive monthly increase, with the manufacturing sector experiencing a turnaround. The European Commission expects the bloc's economy to expand for an 18th quarter, while Germany's largest economy is headed for its fastest annual expansion since 2011. However, the European Central Bank remains cautious, citing a need for a "prudent" approach to exiting quantitative easing to maintain the recovery.

site_title: China's richest property tycoons just got richer
summary: China's richest property developers have seen their collective net worth increase by $44.3 billion since the start of the year, with investors betting on consolidation in the industry. The largest companies, such as China Evergrande and Sunac, are expected to continue to dominate the market, while smaller businesses are expected to lose market share. The rally has added billions to the fortunes of top developers, including chairman Kwok Ying Shing of Kaisa Group Holdings, who now has a net worth of $948 million.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs on Monday, closing down 0.4% on the Dow Jones industrial Average and 0.3% on the S&P 500. Investors were cautious due to upcoming economic news, including the October US jobs report and a potential threat to tax cuts from the Russia investigation. Tech stocks, including Apple, jumped after bullish commentary, while others, such as Merck and Sprint, declined following disappointing earnings and merger news.

site_title: Who needs a runway? Indian budget airline wants to land on water and in fields
summary: SpiceJet Ltd, an Indian budget airline, is exploring options to land on water and in fields, targeting the billion Indians who've never flown before due to affordability or geographical constraints. The airline's stock has seen a 899% increase in three years. By doing so, SpiceJet aims to expand its market share in the third-largest aviation market. This innovative approach could potentially increase air travel accessibility for a large segment of the Indian population.

site_title: High Court grants Nam Cheong permission for debt restructuring, extends moratorium
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted Nam Cheong permission to proceed with debt restructuring under a scheme of arrangement (SA), extending a six-month moratorium on certain legal proceedings. The company can now call a meeting with creditors within three months to approve its SA, which allows it to swap debts and outstanding notes for equity. The moratorium does not prevent the DBS Trustee from taking steps to enforce its rights to release monies held in interest service reserve accounts.

site_title: Singapore rates stirring from slumber to track rising US rates
summary: Singapore's interest rates are rising, tracking the US, with the three-month swap offer rate (SOR) staying above 1% for the longest stretch this year, hitting a year high of 1.06973%. Experts expect further rate hikes, with DBS Bank's Eugene Leow predicting the SOR to reach 1.40% by year-end and 2.15% by 2018, as the US Fed hikes rates and the Singapore dollar weakens.

images.alt_text: Singapore interest rates seem to be finally on an upward march, tracking higher US rates.

site_title: Singapore designers to get retail and incubation showcase at Orchard Road
summary: Singapore is set to launch Design Orchard, a 2.5-storey retail and incubation space at Orchard Road, promoting homegrown design talent and fostering local brands. The project, a joint development by the Singapore Tourism Board, JTC Corporation, and Spring Singapore, aims to showcase 60 local brands with original designs and unique stories. The retail showcase will feature a "garden-style" space with fashion and lifestyle products, while the incubation space will offer support programs, networking opportunities, and collaboration services.

images.alt_text: Industry Minister S Iswaran at the groundbreaking ceremony of design incubator Orchard Green, at the junction of Cairnhill and Orchard roads, on Monday.

site_title: STI falls but manufacturing stocks rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 10.47 points to 3,375.97 points, but manufacturing stocks rallied hard, with companies like Frencken Group, Hi-P International, and Venture Corp rising to recent highs. Electronics and semiconductor-related stocks are expected to continue rallying ahead of Q3 results, driven by strong growth in the industry. Some stocks, such as SembMarine and OCBC, also rose on positive earnings reports.

site_title: Azerbaijan opens new link in Asia-Europe railway
summary: Azerbaijan has opened a new railway link between Asia and Europe, cutting transport times for goods. The railway connects the Caspian Sea port of Alat to the Black Sea port of Poti in Georgia. The opening was marked by a ceremony attended by Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and Georgian Prime Minister Giorgi Margvelashvili. The new railway is expected to improve trade and economic ties between the region and Europe.

site_title: GSK grows business footprint from Singapore with Asia HQ
summary: British pharmaceutical giant GSK has officially opened its Asia headquarters, GSK Asia House, in Singapore, serving as the commercial hub for more than half of its global healthcare operations. The 14,330 sq m facility, home to over 800 employees, will support global commercial activities alongside GSK's US hub. The move aims to create a more agile and sustainable business in Asia, with a focus on developing leadership talent and driving growth in key markets such as China, India, and South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Ms Walmsley (from far right), Mr Tharman and Singapore EDB managing director Chng Kai Fong, at a briefing during the opening of GSK Asia House, a facility that includes a learning and development centre that aims to nurture a pipeline of leadership talent from Asia who can be considered for global roles.

site_title: Spanish bourse soars as govt seeks charges against ex-Catalan leaders
summary: Spanish prosecutors are seeking charges against Catalonia's ex-leaders, including Carles Puigdemont, for rebellion and sedition after they declared independence from Spain. The move comes as the Madrid stock market soared, with shares rising 1.3% and the euro regaining its value. Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy invoked emergency constitutional powers, dissolving the Catalan Parliament and scheduling new elections. The possibility of charges has sparked a dispute among lawyers, with some arguing that no crime of rebellion has been committed. If found guilty, those charged could face up to 30 years in prison.

images.alt_text: Attorney-General José Manuel Maza stopped short of ordering the separatist leaders' arrest.

site_title: Scandal-hit Kobe Steel seeks 50b yen in loans; pulls profit forecast
summary: Kobe Steel, Japan's third-largest steelmaker, is seeking 50 billion yen in loans from banks amid a scandal over falsified product specifications, which has led to the revocation of the government-sanctioned seal of quality on some products. The company has pulled its forecast for a first annual profit in three years and expects a 10 billion yen reduction in recurring profit due to the misconduct. Bigger rival Nippon Steel has offered support, but Kobe Steel has declined.

images.alt_text: Kobe Steel is losing customers and said on Friday it had its government- sanctioned seal of quality revoked on some of its products.

site_title: Not just fun and games for Clown Blox
summary: Four Temasek Polytechnic students created Clown Blox, an award-winning augmented reality game, as a school project. The game combines programming and game design, where players destroy clowns using powerful bombs in an AR tower. The team won the Best Innovative ICM Student Project (Tertiary) at this year's SiTF Awards. The game utilizes mobile phones' cameras to detect AR image markers and project the game. The team aimed to implement AR technology in a game and learn physics application, with their tools also available for developers to track usage data and improve products.

images.alt_text: Clown Blox is an augmented reality (AR) game, where a player moves around an AR tower to destroy the clowns and their defences using powerful bombs.

site_title: The vanguard of innovation
summary: The Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation (SiTF) held its 2017 awards ceremony, recognizing local companies and individuals that have developed innovative solutions through the use of technology. Over 200 submissions were received, with 61 finalists selected. Winners included DC Frontiers for its real-time surveillance system, CashShield for its online fraud management solution, and FoodZaps for its innovative point of sales provider. The awards also recognized innovative student projects and companies that have adopted technology to innovate their businesses. The SiTF Awards will be merged with the National Infocomm Awards next year to create a single highest accolade for technology innovation in Singapore.

images.alt_text: SiTF award recipients, together with SiTF councillors, and guest-of-honour Dr Yaacob Ibrahim, Minister for Communications and Information.

site_title: Toyota eyes airless tyres in bid to build lighter electric vehicles
summary: Toyota is exploring airless tyres for electric vehicles, aiming to reduce weight and boost performance. The technology, featuring individual motors in each wheel, is currently in development and could shave 30% from tyre weight by 2025. Sumitomo Rubber Industries is leading the project, with a goal of commercializing the product by 2020. While airless tyres have been tested on a hydrogen-powered concept car, they still need to overcome challenges such as rolling resistance and safety concerns before being ready for mass production.

site_title: SiTF changes with the times
summary: The Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation (SiTF) is rebranding to SGTECH to stay relevant in a rapidly changing tech landscape. The new brand will reflect the increasing digitization of companies in Singapore and aim to represent all businesses that use technology. The organization's chairman, Saw Ken Wye, stated that technology now serves non-IT companies, and the federation will focus on expanding its membership, providing industry insights, and advocating for its members. The new brand will take effect in January 2018.

images.alt_text: Mr Saw says SGTECH will expand its membership base to include companies that leverage technology as a driver of their business.

site_title: Global economy health at stake as China tries to hold sneeze
summary: China's massive credit buildup poses a significant threat to its economy, with total borrowing expected to reach 320% of the economy's size by 2021. Outgoing People's Bank of China governor Zhou Xiaochuan warned of a potential "Minsky Moment" due to the risk of a debt binge. To curb speculation in property prices, regulators are implementing measures to make it harder for investors to buy real estate with borrowed money, but the challenge remains in aligning borrowing costs with borrowers' ability to repay.

images.alt_text: The latest data show that in some areas, prices are still surging in many Chinese cities despite a raft of measures to make it harder for investors to buy real estate with borrowed money.

site_title: Evolving the blueprint for financial services
summary: Singapore's government is guiding the restructuring of its economy through a sectoral approach, focusing on the financial services industry. The Industry Transformation Map outlines a strategy to position Singapore as a leading global financial centre in Asia. Key thrusts include becoming a global FX pricing and liquidity centre, cementing its position as a leading Asian hub for fund management and domiciliation, and supporting entrepreneurship and enterprise. The regulator aims to spur innovation, promote an innovation ecosystem, and facilitate the development of infrastructure. To address talent and skills, MAS is expanding and deepening the talent pool through its SkillsFuture programme, enabling Singaporeans to compete for and take on regional and global leadership roles.

images.alt_text: To develop deep capabilities, we need to anchor the best international capabilities in Singapore, and grow our own timber over time.

site_title: Not all Fed chair candidates are good central bankers
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is set to announce its choice for Federal Reserve Board chair by November 2, subject to Senate approval. The White House is considering five candidates, but not all would be a good choice. Notably, Janet Yellen, the current chair, is a potential candidate, despite being a Democrat originally appointed by Barack Obama, as her predecessors were re-appointed by a president of the opposite party, reflecting the value of continuity in central banking.

site_title: Apple suppliers rally on signs of strong demand for iPhone X
summary: Apple suppliers rally after delivery times for the iPhone X stretched to as long as six weeks in the US, underscoring strong demand for the marquee smartphone. Shares in Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, TSMC, and other suppliers rose as much as 3.6% and 2.5% respectively, following Apple's announcement that it began taking orders for the iPhone X. The company reported "off the charts" demand, with the phone selling out quickly in Asia and the UK, and customers facing wait times of up to six weeks.

images.alt_text: The iPhone X's Nov 3 debut will be about six weeks after the arrival of the iPhone 8 (above), which is a less sophisticated device. Apple has struggled to manufacture aspects of the X's new features.

site_title: Cutting-edge tech helps Sarine add sparkle to diamond grading
summary: Sarine Technologies, an Israeli diamond specialist technology firm, is developing cutting-edge tech to automate diamond grading. The company's research and partnerships with the Israel Diamond Institute aim to create more reliable and coherent diamond reports, potentially rivaling the Gemological Institute of America (GIA). Sarine's products, such as its Galaxy and Sarine Loupe systems, use 3D scanning and imaging to detect internal features of diamonds, enabling more accurate assessment and polishing. Despite a 70% slump in its share price, Sarine plans to push forward with its technology, supported by the launch of a new Diamond Tech Innovation Center.

images.alt_text: Sarine's research and links with the Israel Diamond Institute's technological centre have already resulted in products that help diamond manufacturers, dealers and jewellers assess the quality of their diamonds.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific builds up Singapore landbank
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has built up a Singapore residential landbank with potential for over 400 freehold private homes in seven projects. The group has acquired sites worth S$36.3 million and is developing a 48-unit project in Jalan Eunos. Revenue fell 33.7% to S$60.3 million in the third quarter, with property development revenue shrinking 39% due to lower recognition from completed projects. The group's gross profit margin rose to 29% in Q3 FY2017, driven by higher margins from property development.

site_title: Have a one-stop shop; ditch the one-size-fits-all approach
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry plans to merge IE Singapore and SPRING Singapore, expected to benefit small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The merger aims to provide more targeted support and streamlined schemes to address SME challenges, including complex issues like manpower constraints and rising costs. The new agency will offer a more holistic policy framework, address the "one-size-fits-all" approach, and simplify the application process for government grants. The merger is expected to enhance the growth of Singaporean enterprises and promote local businesses.

site_title: Butter melts away from French shelves as global demand soars
summary: France is experiencing a butter shortage due to soaring global demand and falling supplies, which has boosted butter prices. The shortage is attributed to the end of milk-production quotas in 2015 and a drastic drop in prices, prompting production cuts by spring this year. French dairy companies are selling abroad to countries like Germany where retailers are willing to pay higher prices, leaving the French short of a key ingredient for sauces and tarts. Industry projections suggest that butter prices may head down slightly as milk production picks up, but the shortage has made it to the French parliament.

images.alt_text: Global butter prices have almost tripled to 7,000 euros (S$11,106) a tonne, and with French supermarkets unwilling to pay more for the dairy product, producers are taking their wares across the border.

site_title: The case for self-sustaining rural areas
summary: India's rapidly growing cities are facing severe challenges due to overcrowding, inadequate infrastructure, and unsustainable development. The country's urban population is projected to reach 1.1 billion by 2050, putting pressure on civic infrastructure, pollution, and social unrest. To mitigate this, India needs to focus on developing self-sustaining rural areas, which can provide a decent standard of living and reduce rural-urban migration. Initiatives like model villages with access to basic amenities, employment opportunities, and sustainable livelihoods can be a game-changer in addressing the country's urban challenges.

site_title: Self-driving startups racing down a narrowing road
summary: Self-driving startups, including Nullmax co-founders Lei Xu and Justin Song, are racing to develop autonomous vehicle technology. Over 240 startups worldwide, including 75 in Silicon Valley, are working on software, hardware, and systems for future self-driving cars. This surge in interest and investment is driven by the growing demand for autonomous vehicles. As the industry continues to evolve, these startups aim to design and implement the technology that will revolutionize the automotive industry.

site_title: Japan's Sept retail sales show strength in consumer spending
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 2.2% in September, the fastest pace in three months, driven by strong consumer spending due to a tight labor market. This follows a revised 1.8% annual increase in August. The sales growth indicates that consumer spending remains robust, despite global economic uncertainties.

site_title: Pearlbank to launch at S$728m; How Sun Park going for S$78m
summary: Pearlbank Apartments in Outram has launched a public tender with a reserve price of S$728 million, while How Sun Park's 20 Bartley townhouses are up for sale at a minimum price of S$78 million. Both developments are the fourth and third collective sale attempts, respectively. Owners of Pearlbank Apartments can expect a minimum gross profit of S$1.8 million to S$4.9 million, while How Sun Park's owners can get at least S$3.9 million per unit.

site_title: NY demand lifts Millennium & Copthorne's 9-mth RevPAR
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels reported a 9-month revenue per available room (RevPAR) increase of 11.5% to £82.41 million, driven by strong growth in New York. Excluding deals and currency movements, like-for-like RevPAR rose 1.4%. The company's nine-month pretax profit grew 16% to £118 million, with revenue increasing 13% to £748 million. The board recommended a £1.8 billion buyout offer from City Developments, despite minority shareholders criticizing the offer as undervaluing the company's property holdings.

site_title: Re-train, not retrench, when jobs are at risk, financial sector told
summary: Singapore's financial sector aims to create 3,000 net jobs annually, with 1,000 in fintech, while maintaining 4.3% annual growth, driven by productivity (over half of growth). The sector's ITM emphasizes retraining and redeployment over retrenchment. To address talent and skills, the government will strengthen HR practices, build a local pipeline of specialized talent, and reskill professionals into growth areas through conversion programs.

site_title: DP World is Gulf's new shining star in bond market
summary: DP World Ltd, a Dubai-owned ports operator, has emerged as the Gulf's top performer in the bond market, with its debt due in 2037 yielding a 21% return this year. The state-controlled company's improved finances and credit-rating upgrade have driven this success. DP World's bond performance is the best among US dollar-denominated bonds of $1 billion or more in the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC).

site_title: 44 years on, BNP Paribas continues to embrace tennis
summary: BNP Paribas, a French multinational bank, has been a long-time supporter of tennis, having sponsored over 500 tournaments worldwide since 1973. The bank's partnership with the WTA Finals Singapore has exceeded expectations, with the CEO stating that the event has been a positive experience for the bank and stakeholders. The bank's values of fairness, agility, and performance align with those of tennis, and they have organized various sustainability initiatives, including a forum and a fan village with eco-friendly activities. BNP Paribas plans to celebrate 50 years in Singapore next year.

images.alt_text: Mr Veyres presenting the WTA Finals runner-up trophy to American Venus Williams on Sunday. The American lost in straight sets to Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark at the Singapore Indoor Stadium.

site_title: Ping An's tech dreams long way to being realised
summary: Ping An Insurance, a Chinese conglomerate, delivered a 45% increase in third-quarter profit driven by online users and artificial intelligence initiatives. The company aims to rebrand itself as a tech company, with over 2,000 patent applications and a $2 billion technology research investment. However, it remains mainly an insurance provider, with fintech accounting for just 1% of its divisions' profit. Government scrutiny and short interest in its Hong Kong stock may pose challenges, but Ping An trades at 2.5 times book value, higher than peers, making it seem like a bargain in comparison to its rival Zhong An, which reported a net loss.

site_title: Jakarta open to lifting ban against JPMorgan, says finance minister
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati has indicated the country may lift a ban on JPMorgan Chase & Co, a year after it was imposed due to negative comments about the stock market. The ban was imposed after JPMorgan downgraded Indonesia's equities by two notches following Donald Trump's election victory. The government stopped doing business with the bank as an underwriter of its bonds, but may reconsider if it's necessary for a good relationship.

site_title: China carmaker BYD sees 2017 profit down as much as 20%
summary: China's BYD Co Ltd, backed by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, reported a potential 15-20% decline in annual profit due to increased competition in hybrid and electric car markets. The company forecasts a net profit range of 4.04-4.29 billion yuan, down from 5 billion yuan in 2016. BYD's shares fell 5% in morning trading after reporting a 23.8% decline in January-September net profit. The company's sales of new-energy vehicles are expected to continue growing, with 398,000 units sold in the first nine months of the year, up 37.7% from 2016.

site_title: High Court grants six-month moratorium on legal proceedings against Nam Cheong
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted a six-month moratorium on legal proceedings against Nam Cheong, a listed holding company, allowing it to proceed with debt restructuring under a scheme of arrangement (SA). The moratorium prevents the appointment of a receiver or manager over the company's property or undertakings. However, DBS Trustee can still take steps to enforce its rights to release monies held in interest service reserve accounts to repay note holders. This decision comes after Nam Cheong entered a voluntary trading suspension on July 21.

site_title: S Korea's Lotte Corp soars in debut on hopes for better governance, returns
summary: Lotte Corp, South Korea's No 5 conglomerate, made its debut with shares soaring 45% above their issue price on Monday, driven by hopes for better corporate governance and shareholder returns. The holding company was created to simplify the group's complex ownership structure, with chairman Shin Dong Bin seeking to enhance control. Despite concerns over political tensions between Seoul and Beijing, combined valuations for the group's main listed firms were 17% above comparable entities in late September.

site_title: Ascendas Reit posts 1.1% jump in Q2 DPU
summary: Ascendas Reit posted a 1.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.059 Singapore cents for Q2, driven by higher net property income of 5.3% to S$160.5 million. This growth was attributed to contributions from newly acquired properties and a positive rental reversion of 3.1%. The Reit's portfolio occupancy reached 92% and comprises 101 properties in Singapore and 30 in Australia.

site_title: US dollar consolidates gains as outlook brightens
summary: The US dollar consolidated its gains on Monday after posting its biggest weekly rise this year, but fell after investors took profits ahead of data showing the world's biggest economy's growth momentum. The dollar index dipped 0.3% to 94.69, while the euro climbed 0.20% to $1.1630. Despite strong US data and expectations of a rate hike, some investors are cautious about the dollar's outlook due to concerns about a global growth pick-up. Net short bets on the US dollar fell to $8 billion, the smallest in nearly three months.

site_title: Didi Chuxing 'in talks with taxi operator Daiichi Koutsu for Japan rollout'
summary: China's Didi Chuxing is in talks with Japanese taxi operator Daiichi Koutsu Sangyo Co to provide ride-hailing services for Chinese tourists visiting Japan. The service, expected to launch in spring, will allow mainland visitors to use Didi's app to summon and pay for Daiichi Koutsu's taxis. The partnership aims to cater to the growing number of Chinese tourists visiting Japan, with an estimated 3.5 million expected to visit the country in 2018.

site_title: Consumer spending sees growth at fastest clip since 2009
summary: US consumer spending recorded its largest increase in over eight years in September, rising 1.0% due to purchases of motor vehicles as households in Texas and Florida replaced flood-damaged cars. Underlying inflation remained muted, with the personal consumption expenditures price index excluding food and energy edging up 0.1%. This growth was offset by slower consumer spending in the third quarter, growing at a 3.0% annualized rate. The moderation in consumption is likely to intensify the inflation debate among Fed officials ahead of a policy meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday.

site_title: Singtel offers an effortless shopping journey for customers
summary: Singtel has introduced digital innovations to enhance the shopping experience for its customers. The telco now offers real-time assistance through chat options, including AI-powered ChatBot and live agents, as well as e-appointments and digital micro-signages at its retail stores. These initiatives have resulted in strong online sales conversion, increased productivity, and improved customer experience scores. Singtel was also awarded the SiTF Award for Best Innovative Infocomm Product (Private Sector) for its efforts in creating a seamless and effortless sales journey through digital innovation.

site_title: The Pines will not return to Stevens Road site; members to move to Laguna golf club and resort
summary: The Pines golf club in Singapore will no longer use its Stevens Road site, as the club management was unable to secure a lease due to redevelopment plans. Members will instead use facilities at the Laguna National Golf & Country Club and its upcoming Dusit Thani Laguna Singapore resort. The club is extending its 30-year membership by 8 years to 2040 as a show of appreciation. About 1,300 members will be affected, with waived transfer and administration fees for those transferring within two years of the resort's opening in 2018.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages maintain their stance on several Singapore Reits and Sheng Siong Group, with upgrades and downgrades. UOB Kay Hian maintains "hold" on CDL Hospitality Trust, raising its target to S$1.70, while maintaining "hold" on Suntec and Frasers Hospitality Trust. OCBC Investment Research upgrades Sheng Siong Group to "buy" with a higher target price of S$1.04, citing improved consumer sentiment. Viva Industrial Trust is also upgraded to "buy" with a higher target price of S$1.02, citing improving occupancy rates and positive rental reversions.

site_title: Ascott beefs up Singapore presence with two new contracts
summary: Ascott Limited, the serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has signed two new contracts to manage properties in Singapore's CBD and Ophir-Rochor Corridor, adding over 600 units to its portfolio under the Citadines brand.

images.alt_text: Citadines Rochor Singapore is part of an upcoming integrated development that will also have a retail podium.

site_title: Next China sell-off seen in corporate bonds on leverage focus
summary: Chinese investors in corporate bonds may face a debt sell-off as the Communist Party Congress concludes, with aggressive deleveraging policies and accelerating inflation casting a shadow over the bond market. 10-year sovereign yields have reached their highest in three years, and corporate debt is at risk of rising significantly in the coming year. Authorities are rolling out measures targeting higher-risk investments, and a default could trigger a sell-off. The yield on three-year AAA notes has risen eight basis points to 4.90%, with the spread between corporate and government debt reaching 117 basis points.

site_title: HSBC's Asia push pays off; closes chapter on Gulliver's travails
summary: HSBC's Asia push has paid off, with the bank reporting a 3rd consecutive quarter of revenue growth driven by its Asian operations. The lender's US$100 billion bet on Asia has yielded Q3 adjusted revenue of US$13 billion, beating analyst estimates. HSBC added $1.1 billion in loans in Guangdong, China, and paid out an extra $300 million in performance-related pay due to the strategy's progress. CEO Stuart Gulliver's tenure, which includes a focus on Asia, is coming to an end with the appointment of John Flint.

site_title: NZ's PM finalising details of foreign home ownership ban
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is finalizing details of a ban on foreign buyers purchasing established homes before a key trade deal meeting next week. The ban aims to address the country's housing crisis, with prices increasing over 50% in the last decade. Ardern plans to seek renegotiation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership to allow for the ban, which is at odds with the existing agreement. Foreign investors can still buy new homes, and the government will need to enforce the ban to make it effective.

site_title: Novartis to buy pharmaceutical group AAA for US$3.9b
summary: Novartis has agreed to purchase French-based Advanced Accelerator Applications (AAA) for US$3.9 billion. The deal gives Novartis a platform in radiopharmaceuticals and access to a new therapy for certain types of cancer, including those that killed Apple co-founder Steve Jobs. The acquisition is in line with Novartis CEO Joe Jimenez's strategy of pursuing smaller deals. AAA's flagship product, Lutathera, won EU backing for treating rare cancers and can both diagnose and deliver treatment. The deal will reap AAA founder Stefano Buono over US$420 million.

site_title: Ex-campaign chairman for Trump and protege face 12 charges
summary: Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and his business partner Rick Gates have been charged with 12 counts, including conspiracy, money laundering, and false statements, in a Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into possible coordination between the Trump campaign and Russia. The indictment marks the first criminal allegations in Mueller's probe, which has also examined Manafort's work as a political consultant in Ukraine and possible violations of the Foreign Agents Registration Act. Manafort joined the Trump campaign in March 2016 and served as chairman until August 2016.

site_title: China's top lenders' Q3 profits grow, bad loans ease
summary: China's top four state-owned banks reported higher quarterly profits and slower growth in bad loans, driven by a resilient economy and tightened regulation on the shadow banking sector. Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) posted a 3.3% rise in net profit, while Agricultural Bank of China (AgBank), China Construction Bank (CCB), and Bank of Communications (BoCom) also reported faster quarterly profit growth. Non-performing loan ratios declined at CCB, ICBC, BoCom, and AgBank, but rose at Bank of China Ltd.

site_title: SATS, AirAsia tie up for bigger bite of Asia-Pac boom
summary: SATS, Asia's largest ground handler, and AirAsia, the region's largest budget carrier, have formed a tie-up to tap the ground-handling services market in the Asia-Pacific region. The two firms will own stakes in each other's ground-handling units, giving them access to each other's turf. SATS will acquire an 11.4% stake in AirAsia's Ground Team Red Holdings, while AirAsia will sell a 38.6% stake to SATS for $119.3 million. The partnership aims to expand ground-handling services in Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly lower ahead of Apple results, jobs data
summary: US stocks fell on Monday ahead of Apple's earnings report and the October US jobs report, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% and the S&P 500 down 0.2%. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.1%. The market is expected to pull back after a record-breaking month, with analysts citing the ongoing Russia probe and Catalonia-Spain debate as concerns. The Federal Reserve's two-day meeting, concluding with a monetary policy announcement, is also a key focus.

site_title: Ageing private home owners want ability to cash out on houses
summary: Singapore's ageing population presents opportunities for private developers to build senior homes, despite challenges. One in four Singaporeans will be 65 or older by 2030, and there's a shortage of private housing for seniors. Private home owners face limited options to cash out on their housing assets, with reverse mortgages not being successful. Social stigma and insufficient supply of nursing homes also deter development. A more viable business opportunity for developers is providing co-living spaces for retiring singles, which can be more affordable and offer social support.

site_title: In Singapore's push to be a global financial hub, job skills must keep up
summary: Singapore aims to be a leading global financial center in Asia, connecting global markets and supporting Asia's development, with a focus on wealth management, fund management, and forex. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has released an industry transformation map outlining growth strategies, skill-upgrading programs, and innovation agendas. The plan aims to achieve 4.3% real value-added growth and 2.4% productivity growth annually, creating 3,000 net jobs in financial services and 1,000 in the fintech sector. The MAS is working to reskill and redeploy professionals, and collaborate with industry associations to ensure the workforce is equipped to meet the future demands of the financial sector.

site_title: Debt and taxes - and politics at its most cynical
summary: The US tax reform proposal, led by the Trump administration, aims to cut the top corporate tax rate from 35% to 20%. However, historical evidence on the relationship between tax rates and economic growth is inconclusive, with studies showing mixed results. Some studies suggest lower taxes stimulate entrepreneurship and business investment, while others find little connection between tax rates and overall economic growth. Critics argue that tax cuts are not a guarantee of economic growth and that the benefits may be swamped by other factors. The proposal's proponents, including Kevin Hassett, predict wage gains of $3,000 to $7,000 for households with median income, but economists remain skeptical, citing a lack of consensus on the role of tax rates in explaining economic growth.

site_title: Raffles Medical pins hope on new hospitals in China for growth
summary: Raffles Medical Group, a Singapore-based private healthcare provider, is diversifying its business by opening new hospitals in China, aiming to drive growth. The group's chairman, Loo Choon Yong, expects the new hospitals to have a significant impact on earnings. Despite flat revenue in the third quarter, the group reported a 1% year-on-year increase in net profit and a 3.1% increase in revenue from the hospital services division. The group plans to expand its network in Singapore and other regional cities, and is confident that a strong regional economy will attract more foreign patients to Singapore for medical treatment.
