site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q3 net profit down 81.5% to S$1.5m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 81.5% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profit to S$1.5 million, with revenue falling 33.7% to S$60.3 million. The property and hotels group attributed the decline to lower revenue recognition from completed projects in Singapore and a lack of revenue recognition from projects in Australia due to accounting differences. Earnings per share eased to 0.13 Singapore cents, while net asset value per share edged up to 42.23 Singapore cents. Roxy-Pacific shares ended down 0.9% at S$0.58.

site_title: A-Reit manager stresses team's bench strength after CEO's exit
summary: Ascendas Reit's CEO Chia Nam Toon resigned, effective November 19, with a replacement to be selected through a review process. The Reit's manager, Manohar Khiatani, emphasized the team's "bench strength" and assured continuity despite the change. The Reit reported a good Q2 performance, with a 5.3% net property income increase and a 92% portfolio occupancy. Distributions rose to 4.059 Singapore cents per unit, and the Reit is expanding its Australian portfolio.

site_title: Rent eating up a record share of Americans' disposable income
summary: US disposable income is being increasingly consumed by rent, with 3.81% of Americans' income going towards rent in the third quarter, the highest share in nearly six decades. The price index for rental housing rose 3.7% in the year through September, contributing to the inflation in the US economy. Despite a 2.9% year-over-year increase in nominal disposable personal income, it has grown at a slower rate than rental inflation for the 22nd consecutive month.

site_title: Manafort charged with conspiracy against US, money-laundering
summary: Paul Manafort, former Trump campaign chairman, was charged with conspiracy against the US and money laundering, the first close aide to face charges in the Mueller probe. Manafort and business partner Rick Gates allegedly hid millions earned from Ukrainian politician Viktor Yanukovych and his pro-Moscow party. The 12 charges mark the first time a former Trump aide has been charged in the federal probe into possible collusion with Russia.

site_title: The fat years for US-based airlines come to an end as costs increase
summary: US-based airlines face increasing costs, threatening profits in 2018. Higher bills are due to labour contracts, airport renovations, technology spending, and fleet upgrades. Despite robust travel demand, expenses are creeping into 2018, potentially spoiling fare increases planned for the holidays.

site_title: US consumer spending posts largest gain since 2009
summary: US consumer spending increased by 1.0% in September, the largest gain since 2009, driven by households in Texas and Florida replacing flood-damaged motor vehicles. Underlying inflation remained muted, with the core PCE price index edging up 0.1%. The growth rate slowed to a 2.4% annualized pace in the third quarter, offset by a rise in inventory investment and a drop in imports. The economy grew at a 3.0% rate in the third quarter.

site_title: SEA's IPO noteworthy on many fronts
summary: SEA Ltd, a Singapore-based internet company, debuted a US$884 million initial public offering (IPO) on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), becoming the first Singapore-based tech unicorn to go public in the US. Founded in 2009, SEA was valued at US$3.75 billion in 2016 and its market cap is now about US$4.58 billion, making it the largest IPO by a South-east Asian tech company. SEA's diversification into e-commerce and digital payments has contributed to its growth, solidifying its position as a major player in the tech industry.

site_title: Trendlines co-CEOs take 20% pay cut as part of plan to cut cost
summary: Trendlines Group co-CEOs David Todd Dollinger and Stephen Louis Rhodes have agreed to take a 20% pay cut as part of a plan to reduce operating expenses by $1.3 million by the end of 2018. The plan also includes reducing salaries of senior management and certain employees. The move aims to reduce costs, increase efficiency, and enhance shareholder value. Implementation has commenced and is expected to be fully implemented during FY2018.

site_title: SATS, AirAsia ink ground-handling pact
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground-handling firm, has inked a strategic pact with Malaysia's low-cost carrier AirAsia to grow ground handling across the Asean region. Under the agreement, SATS will acquire a 50% stake in AirAsia's ground-handling unit in exchange for a 50% stake in its Singapore operation and $119.3 million in cash. The partnership aims to expand into Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand, with both companies to hold stakes in each other's subsidiaries in Malaysia and Singapore.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's financial sector aims to create 3,000 net jobs annually, surpassing national economic growth. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) unveiled strategies to boost the city-state's status as a top global financial centre in Asia. Meanwhile, developers are shifting towards leasehold assets in en bloc sales, and completed condo prices rose 0.1% in September. The Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF debuted with an initial AUM of S$100m, while a subsidiary of OUE Lippo Healthcare faces a lawsuit claiming a majority stake.

site_title: Kevin Spacey apologizes, comes out as gay after 'sexual advance' claim
summary: Actor Kevin Spacey apologized to Anthony Rapp for a 1986 incident in which Rapp, then 14, claimed Spacey made a sexual advance on him. Spacey, 58, said he didn't remember the encounter but acknowledged it was "deeply inappropriate." He came out as gay, stating he had romantic encounters with men throughout his life and chose to live as a gay man. Spacey's apology followed Rapp's accusation, which sparked a wider examination of abuses by powerful men in the entertainment industry, including Harvey Weinstein.

site_title: Singapore interest rates on upward march tracking higher US rates
summary: Singapore interest rates have started to rise, tracking higher US rates. The three-month SOR reached a year-high of 1.06973% in mid-October, its longest five-day run above 1% this year. Experts expect the rate to continue to rise, with DBS Bank's Eugene Leow predicting a 1.40% rate by year-end and 2.15% by end-2018. The Singapore dollar's weakness and domestic liquidity management also contribute to the upward pressure on interest rates.

site_title: Tianjin Zhong Xin Q3 net profit down 8%
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group reported a 8% decline in third-quarter net profit to 83.3 million yuan, down from the previous year. Revenue also fell 14% to 1.31 billion yuan. The company attributed the decline to challenging economic conditions and took measures to strengthen operations, including boosting marketing and R&D activities. It aims to improve its operations and gear the company towards greater scientific progress and development.

site_title: AA Reit receives TOP for purpose-built greenfield development in Marsiling
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) has received a temporary occupation permit (TOP) for its first greenfield development, a five-storey industrial facility at 51 Marsiling Road. The S$43 million project will be leased to manufacturer Beyonics International Pte Ltd for 10 years, with estimated property income of S$3.5 million in the first year. The facility's completion marks the Reit's strong development capabilities, building on its successful redevelopment track record.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end flat ahead of Japan, US central bank decisions
summary: Tokyo stocks ended flat on Monday, following recent gains, ahead of key Japanese and US central bank announcements. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.01% to 22,011.67, while the Topix index fell 0.01% to 1,770.84. The move comes as investors await decisions from the Bank of Japan and the US Federal Reserve, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall, hurt by the mainland's stock slide
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.4% on Monday, hurt by a slump in mainland stocks triggered by liquidity concerns. The Hang Seng index dropped to 28,336.19, while the China Enterprises Index fell 0.7% to 11,563.38 points. The decline was attributed to increased cross-border flows making Hong Kong markets more vulnerable to China market swings. Shanghai's benchmark index posted its biggest one-day slide in 11 weeks, with Chinese bond yields surging.

site_title: HPH Trust Q3 net profit falls 37%
summary: HUCHISON Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported a 37.1% drop in net profit to HK$270.4 million for the three months to September, primarily due to a share of Huizhou International Container Terminals result. Revenue slipped 1.3% to HK$3.2 billion, with combined container throughput increasing 12.8% compared to the same period in 2016. The port operator posted lower earnings per unit, and its counter fell 1.7% to close at 59.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% down on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.3% on Monday, closing at 3,375.97 points, after a 5-day rally. The index saw 1.88 billion shares traded for S$1.22 billion. Trendlines rose, while KOP and Rowsley were among the most actively traded counters. The decline comes ahead of upcoming GDP data, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Thai finance ministry raises 2017 GDP growth outlook to 3.8%
summary: Thailand's finance ministry raised its 2017 GDP growth outlook to 3.8% from 3.6%, citing stronger exports and tourism. Exports are expected to increase 8.5% this year, while the government predicts 5.7% growth in 2018, mainly driven by government spending. The strong baht has not deterred export competitiveness, but the government is concerned about potential trade and economic growth in 2018 if the currency continues to climb.

site_title: Wall Street 2017 profits set to surpass last year's - report
summary: Wall Street profits are expected to surpass last year's, with the securities industry reporting $12.3 billion in profits for the first half of 2017, a 33% increase from the same period in 2016. Bonuses are also expected to be higher, with a 4% increase in compensation set aside for the industry. The securities industry has maintained its critical role in New York City's economy, accounting for 20.1% of all private sector wages paid in the city.

site_title: Family pumps fresh blood into home-grown eyewear brand O+
summary: Entrepreneur David Hwang has successfully launched his family's home-grown eyewear brand O+ in Singapore, filling a gap in the market for premium quality but affordable optical frames. The family business, which includes Hwang's wife and two sons, has gained traction with locals and Caucasians alike, with 30% of customers being Caucasian. The brand's flagship store, located at the OUE Downtown Gallery, offers high-quality frames made from materials such as Italian acetate and German hinges, at affordable prices. The business aims to expand overseas in the next year or two, with the Singapore brand being a key differentiator.

site_title: Europe: Shares open sideways as earning roll in, Spain rebounds
summary: Spanish equities rose 1.4% on Monday, driven by weekend demonstrations for a unified Spain and a poll showing a lead for parties opposed to Catalan independence. European shares traded sideways, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index down 0.1%. Spain's IBEX benchmark led the gains, driven by Caixabank and Banco de Sabadell shares, which rose 4.2% and 3.6% respectively.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at fresh high on foreign demand boost; won strengthens
summary: South Korean stocks reached a fresh record high on Monday, driven by foreign demand and a strengthening won. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.2% at 2,501.93 points. Foreign investors added 253.1 billion won to their portfolios, while domestic institutions sold 522 billion won. The won strengthened against the US dollar, closing at 1,124.6 to the dollar. Shares of Lotte Corp, a new holding company for South Korea's No 5 conglomerate, rose 10% on its first day of trading.

site_title: S Korea set for record coal imports on nuclear outages as winter looms
summary: South Korea is expected to set a record for coal imports in October, driven by nuclear reactor outages and the start of peak demand season over winter. The country's coal imports in September reached 11.3 million tonnes, with October imports forecast to reach 12 million tonnes. This growth is attributed to the commissioning of five new coal-fired power stations and increased demand for power due to lower nuclear generation. The utility is planning to buy 16-17 million tonnes of coal, 5-6 million tonnes more than usual, to meet the higher demand.

site_title: HSBC's Asia push bearing fruit for Gulliver before hand-off
summary: HSBC Holdings reported its third consecutive increase in quarterly revenue, driven by Asia's $13 billion adjusted revenue, the highest gain among the bank's five regions. The bank added $1.1 billion of loans in Guangdong, China, where it has targeted expansion. This growth is attributed to HSBC's strategy, which has paid out $300 million in performance-related pay due to its progress. The results come ahead of CEO Stuart Gulliver's handover to John Flint, with Finance Director Iain Mackay stating that the strategy is "progressing well and ahead of our expectations."

site_title: Singapore ranks 8th on global sustainable transport survey
summary: Singapore ranks 8th globally in sustainable transport, according to a study by Arcadis. The city-state excelled in the "people" pillar with a perfect 100% score, thanks to its digital technology and low traffic fatalities. However, it struggled in the "planet" pillar, with poor bicycle infrastructure. Singapore scored 65% in the "profit" pillar, reflecting its sustainable financials. The city-state's focus on electric vehicles and digitalization earned praise, with its 15-year plan to reduce petrol-fuelled car reliance also commended. Overall, Singapore ranked as one of the world's most sustainable cities.

site_title: Nomura Q2 net profit falls 15% on bond trading drop
summary: Nomura Holdings reported a 15% drop in Q2 net profit to 51.9 billion yen (S$623.58 million), primarily due to a decline in fixed income trading in its wholesale division. This fell short of an average estimate of 60.5 billion yen. The drop was attributed to a decrease in bond trading, affecting the company's overall performance.

site_title: Takeover target M&C Hotels reports higher rooms revenue
summary: M&C Hotels reported higher nine-month rooms revenue, with revenue per available room (RevPAR) rising 11.5% to £82.41 million, boosted by strong growth in New York. Excluding deals and closures, RevPAR increased 1.4%. The company's board has agreed to back a formal bid of 552.5 pence per share from shareholder City Developments, despite criticism from several shareholders.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the MAS and PBOC set to deepen collaboration in green and transition finance. CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold', citing slowing earnings growth in H2. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring, with Tan Teck Long named her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to $3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a Mumbai launch event, and Citigroup set a mid-2026 target for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: September sees marginal rise in completed condo prices in Singapore: SRPI
summary: Singapore's completed private apartment and condominium unit prices rose 0.1% in September, mainly driven by a 0.9% increase in small units. This follows a revised 0.9% increase in August. Prices in the central region rose 0.4%, while the non-central region saw a 0.2% dip. The increase excludes shoebox units. The data is based on the Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) series compiled by the National University of Singapore.

site_title: Indonesia may lift curbs on JPMorgan's government business
summary: Indonesia may lift its ban on JPMorgan Chase & Co, a year after the US investment bank was shunned over negative comments about the stock market. The ban was imposed by President Joko Widodo's government after JPMorgan downgraded Indonesia's equities by two notches following Donald Trump's election victory. Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said that any future business cooperation will be based on "trust and respect," and that the government is open to reinstating JPMorgan as an underwriter of its rupiah and dollar bonds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.22 points to 1,748.35 on Monday, driven by a gain of 518 to 402 gainers-to-losers ratio. The shares closed higher with a volume of 2.877 billion lots worth RM2.153 billion.

site_title: Glencore raises full-year marketing guidance again
summary: Glencore increased its full-year marketing guidance for earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) to between US$2.6 billion and US$2.8 billion, reflecting the company's recovery from the commodity crash. The company lowered its zinc output guidance to 1.1 million tonnes, citing operational difficulties and end-of-mine-life declines. Despite this, CEO Ivan Glasenberg stated that he would only raise zinc output if confident it wouldn't drag the market lower, indicating a cautious approach to production increases.

site_title: Manufacturing stocks rally 2% to 9% despite STI fall
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector, particularly electronics and semiconductor-related stocks, are rallying despite a decline in the Straits Times Index (STI). Companies such as Frencken Group, Hi-P International, and Micro-Mechanics reported strong earnings, with Micro-Mechanics' net profit increasing 53% year-over-year. The sector's growth is driven by a 33% increase in Singapore's manufacturing output in September, with the industry expected to continue growing due to increasing demand for electronic components.

site_title: Billionaires keep bubbling up as China property market soars
summary: China's property market has seen a surge in wealth creation among billionaires, with the collective net worth of seven real estate tycoons rising by $44.3 billion since the start of the year. Investors are betting on the largest companies to consolidate their dominance, with some stocks rising 500% or more. Key players, including Hui Ka Yan and Sun Hongbin, have added billions to their fortunes, with Hui now just $5.2 billion behind Asia's richest person, Jack Ma. Regulators are moving to tame the market, but investors remain optimistic about the industry's fundamentals.

site_title: Financial firms must do more to retrain, match workers when disruption hits: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasized the need for financial firms to retrain and match workers when disruption hits, rather than laying them off. To address this, the Monetary Authority of Singapore plans to create 3,000 net jobs in financial services and 1,000 financial technology jobs annually through Professional Conversion Programmes. The government aims to expand career advisory and job-matching services and anchor international capabilities to develop deep capabilities in the industry.

site_title: Emas Offshore updates financial information
summary: Emas Offshore Ltd has updated its financial information, restating non-preferential unsecured creditor liabilities at US$910 million, with a decrease in bank loans and payables to US$49.3 million. The company's subsidiary, Emas Offshore Private Ltd, now has total liabilities of US$528 million, with a net liability position of US$508.7 million. The changes reflect a shift in "contingent claims" from US$75 million to US$220 million.

site_title: Kobe Steel to withdraw its full-year earnings forecast: Nikkei
summary: Kobe Steel Ltd has withdrawn its full-year earnings forecast due to the impact of its data falsification scandal. The company will not pay a dividend for the six months through September and will announce first-half earnings results later. This decision comes after Kobe Steel struggles to quantify the scandal's effects, which could lead to significant financial losses.

site_title: Asian stocks mixed as Chinese shares, bonds tumble
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Monday, with Chinese shares and bonds tumbling due to a bond slump. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.2% as investors await an announcement on the next Federal Reserve chair. US President Donald Trump is expected to reveal his choice by Friday, with Governor Jerome Powell favored to take the role. Earnings reports from companies such as Exxon and Chevron also weighed on markets.

site_title: Australia shares near 6-month peak; New Zealand ends at record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.27% to near six-month peaks, tracking a strong lead from Wall Street and rising oil prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,919.1, while New Zealand's benchmark index reached a record high of 8,143.98. Energy stocks, led by Santos and Beach Energy, gained 1.4%, and financials, including Westpac, rose 0.3%. The gains followed a strong lead from US tech stocks and expectations of an extended Opec production cut.

site_title: 'Pineapple Pen' star to serenade Trump on Japan visit
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to be serenaded with the viral hit song "PPAP" by Japanese singer Pikotaro during his upcoming visit to Japan. The 45-second song, about a "pen-pineapple-apple-pen," has become a favorite of Trump's grandchildren, including Ivanka Trump's daughter Arabella Kushner. Trump will also play a round of golf with Japanese pro Hideki Matsuyama during his visit, marking the start of his Asian tour.

site_title: Gold edges down on caution ahead of key cenbank meetings
summary: Gold prices edged down 0.1% to $1,271.50 per ounce as investors remained cautious ahead of key central bank meetings and the naming of the next US Federal Reserve chair. The market awaits cues from the Federal Open Market Committee, central banks of England and Japan, and US President Donald Trump's announcement of the next Federal Reserve head, with Jerome Powell being favored as the candidate. Higher interest rates are expected to boost the dollar and pressure gold prices.

site_title: German September retail sales rise, supporting consumption-led growth
summary: German retail sales rose 0.5% in September, beating expectations, and jumped 4.1% year-over-year. This growth is attributed to consumption-led growth, with record-high employment, job security, and rising wages. The data supports the outlook for the economy, with leading institutes increasing growth forecasts to 1.9% and 2% for this year and next, respectively.

site_title: Dealmakers still like UK best despite Brexit: EY poll
summary: Global dealmakers still favor the UK as the top investment destination in Europe, according to Ernst & Young's Global Capital Confidence Barometer report. The UK ranked third globally, behind the US and China, with business executives citing "doing deals" as a key part of British companies' DNA. Despite Brexit, the UK's attractiveness to investors remains unchanged.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics posts 53% jump in Q1 profit
summary: Micro-Mechanics Ltd posted a 53% increase in Q1 net profit to S$5.2 million, driven by 32.5% revenue growth to S$17.7 million and improved gross profit margin to 60.9%. The company attributes the growth to strong demand from customers in major semiconductor markets. CEO Chris Borch expects prolonged growth in the industry, focusing on customer value and long-term sustainability.

site_title: Nintendo lifts annual profit outlook on strong Switch console sales
summary: Nintendo raised its annual operating profit forecast to 120 billion yen (S$1.44180 billion) due to strong demand for its Switch console, which nearly doubled its stock price to nine-year highs since its March launch. The company forecast 14 million Switch sales for the year, up from 10 million units, and expects supply shortages to ease. Nintendo aims to reduce its reliance on the console business and diversify into new areas, such as smartphone gaming and theme parks, as it faces increasing competition from Microsoft's Xbox One X console.

site_title: Singapore financial sector aims to create 3,000 net jobs per year, beat national economic growth
summary: Singapore's financial sector aims to create 3,000 net jobs annually and outpace the overall economy's growth of 2-3% per year, with a productivity rate of 2.4%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has unveiled strategies to raise the Republic's status as a top global financial centre in Asia, focusing on developing into a leading international wealth management hub, building a talent pool, and creating common utilities for financial institutions. The sector also aims to create 1,000 net jobs in the fintech sector annually.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.6% on Monday, driven by strong US growth data and ahead of key earnings reports. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,609.78, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes dipped 0.09% and 0.10% respectively. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a rise in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US.

site_title: Asia pivot helps HSBC post jump in Q3 pretax profit
summary: HSBC Holdings PLC reported a five-fold rise in its pretax profit for the third quarter, reaching US$4.6 billion, driven by its expansion in Asia and lower comparative base in the year-ago quarter. The bank's Asia region reported a 10% increase in pretax profit to US$4 billion, with a focus on China's Pearl River Delta region. HSBC's newly arrived chairman has promoted an insider to drive revenue growth, and the bank's common equity tier 1 ratio is expected to increase in the medium term.

site_title: Room to grow senior housing projects in Singapore but challenges remain: study
summary: A study by Edmund Tie & Company suggests that Singapore's ageing population presents opportunities for private senior housing projects, but challenges remain. With one in eight Singaporeans being senior citizens, the need for elderly-friendly features and lifestyle solutions has grown. However, homeowners with private properties have limited options for monetizing their assets, and social stigma may deter buyers from such projects. Insufficient nursing home supply and high land costs are also cited as challenges, making such projects inaccessible to middle and lower-income individuals. Conducting financial planning ahead of retirement is crucial for maintaining quality of life.

site_title: North Korea's Kim tours cosmetics plant with wife, sister
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visited the Pyongyang Cosmetics Factory with his wife Ri Sol Ju and sister Kim Yo Jong, a "field guidance trip" amid the country's nuclear standoff with the US. The visit showcased "world-level" cosmetics and highlighted the Kim family's emphasis on women's beauty. This is not the first time the powerful women have accompanied Kim to official events, breaking a tradition of their absence from public appearances. The visit comes amid high tensions on the peninsula, with North Korea conducting its sixth nuclear test in September and trading threats with US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Japan bank Mizuho eyes cutting workforce by one-third: reports
summary: Japan's Mizuho Financial Group is considering cutting its global workforce by about one-third, or around 19,000 jobs, by March 2027. The bank aims to replace clerical jobs with artificial intelligence and technology. This move follows similar job cuts by rivals Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui. Mizuho's net profit fell 11% in April-June, and the bank is looking to close up to 30 branches in Japan. The decision is part of Japan's lenders' efforts to adapt to a negative interest rate policy and boost lending and inflation.

site_title: Ezion dangles further protections as it courts bondholders' support for refinancing
summary: Ezion Holdings, an oil and gas contractor, is seeking bondholders' support for a refinancing plan. The proposed plan includes sweetened terms, such as conversion options and bonus warrants, to swap out liabilities for equity. If conditions are not met by March 31, 2018, the refinancing terms will revert to original terms. Bondholders will vote on the plan on November 20, with the option to redeem securities within 30 days of approval.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.35% to 22,084.47, driven by gains in US and European stocks. The Topix index also increased, inching up 1.22 points to 1,772.27. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: How Sun Park to be launched for collective sale with S$78m reserve price
summary: Sun Park, a 20-townhouse development in the Bartley area, will be launched for collective sale on Nov 28 with a reserve price of S$78 million. The site, zoned for residential use, has a land area of 54,942.7 sq ft and a potential GFA of 76,919.8 sq ft. Owners of 19 units (95% approval rate) have consented to the sale, with each unit expected to fetch at least S$3.9 million. The site's value is seen as high due to its proximity to the Bidadari township and Bartley MRT station.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened 2.27 points higher, up 0.07% at 3,388.71, driven by a strong run-up on Wall Street last Friday on tech giants' earnings. Gainers outpaced losers 120 to 46, with 74.1 million shares traded for S$106.1 million.

site_title: Asia: Markets muted ahead of earnings reports, Fed decision
summary: Asian markets were flat on Monday as investors awaited key earnings reports and the US Federal Reserve decision. Hong Kong and Tokyo initially rose, but later declined, while the Shanghai exchange fell sharply. The US market had closed with gains on Friday on strong tech earnings and economic growth figures.

site_title: Flood of Chinese capital seen shaking up aviation finance
summary: Chinese capital is flooding the global aircraft leasing market, now accounting for 28% of the $261 billion deployed by leasing firms worldwide. This influx of over $70 billion from Chinese banks and investors is helping airlines expand their fleets, but curbs returns for traditional players. Experts warn that new investors' willingness to accept lower returns and their long-term commitment pose a threat to rivals. Chinese capital is expected to account for over a third of the industry within five years.

site_title: PSL chairman quits due to 'other work commitments'
summary: PSL Holdings' chairman, Sucipto, resigned due to "other work commitments," effective immediately. Non-executive director Ng Yoke Chan has been appointed as chairwoman, replacing Sucipto. This change comes after PSL Holdings had several key changes to its board and senior management in recent months, including the appointment of new CEO Tan Cheang Shiong and independent director Kevin Wong Wei Boon.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare subsidiary faces suit by individual claiming majority stake
summary: A lawsuit has been filed against OUE Lippo Healthcare's subsidiaries, Shanghai Yilin Medical Management Consulting Co and Wuxi Yilin Health Management Co, by individual David Lin Kao Kun, claiming a majority stake in Shanghai Yilin. Lin alleges he held a 71% stake in Shanghai Yilin on trust from June 2014, and is seeking a court order determining his ownership. OUE Lippo Healthcare believes its subsidiaries have a strong defence against the claim and will vigorously defend the suit.

site_title: Pearlbank Apartments' owners cross 80% mark, asking for S$728m in collective sale
summary: Pearlbank Apartments' owners have reached the required consensus for a collective sale, aiming to sell the iconic building for S$728 million. This translates to a land cost of S$1,505 per square foot per plot ratio. The sale will be launched in two weeks, with the appointed solicitors conducting legal verification. The building, with 280 apartments and eight commercial units, has a 99-year leasehold tenure and sits on a 7,653 sq m land area. Owners will receive minimum prices of S$1.8 million to S$4.9 million for residential units and S$1.2 million to S$6.9 million for commercial units.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks climb to all-time high; won strenthens
summary: South Korean shares reached an all-time high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) climbing 0.2% to 2,502.01 points. The gains were driven by positive sentiment in the tech sector, particularly from Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, which rose 1.8% and 2.9% respectively. Domestic institutions trimmed gains, but foreign investors purchased KOSPI shares worth 75.3 billion won. The South Korean won strengthened against the US dollar, and December futures on three-year treasury bonds gained 0.07 points.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.54 points to 1748.67. The market saw 102.3 million lots traded worth RM30.6 million, with 148 gainers and 46 losers.

site_title: Oil markets firm on expected extension of production cuts
summary: Oil markets remained firm on Monday, with Brent crude opening above US$60 per barrel, driven by expectations that an Opec-led production cut agreement would be extended. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has agreed to cut 1.8 million barrels per day to eliminate a supply glut. Hedge funds increased their bullish wagers on US crude futures, and Opec's next meeting on November 30 will determine the fate of the production cuts. This is the highest level for Brent crude since July 2015, with prices up 36% since 2017 lows.

site_title: British PM May calls for action after lawmaker sex toys allegations
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has called for tougher rules governing MPs' conduct after a government minister, Mark Garnier, was accused of asking his secretary to buy sex toys. May expressed concern in a letter to the House of Commons speaker, stating current disciplinary procedures lack "the required teeth." The Cabinet Office will investigate Garnier's behavior, and May has urged the speaker to overhaul the disciplinary procedure to make it contractually binding for lawmakers.

site_title: Truffle season shocks chefs as prices double to US$3,200 a pound
summary: Truffle season is experiencing a bumper year, but prices have doubled to US$3,200 a pound, making it one of the most expensive ingredients in fine dining. The shortage is due to a hot summer followed by a dry autumn, resulting in a significantly smaller harvest. Restaurants may respond by serving simpler dishes or reducing truffle portions to offset the high prices, with some chefs considering alternative sources like Croatia for their truffles.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q3 profit gains 1% as expat plan renewals slip, hospital loads improve
summary: RAFFLES Medical Group's Q3 net profit grew 1% to S$16.4 million, driven by higher local patient loads at hospitals. Revenue increased 0.3% to S$119.6 million, with hospital services contributing 3.1% growth. However, healthcare services revenue slipped 4.2% due to lower expatriate plan renewals. The company expects to remain profitable in 2017, with new clinic openings in Changi Airport and hospital capacity expansion planned for 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Hot stock: Asti up 5.3% on extension of exclusivity period to China Fortune-Tech Capital
summary: Asti Holdings Limited, a semiconductor equipment manufacturer, saw its stock rise 5.3% after extending the exclusivity period for a potential divestment of the STI Group to China Fortune-Tech Capital Co Ltd from Oct 28 to Dec 15, 2017. The stock price rose to S$0.08 at 10am on Monday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Raffles Medical, OUE Lippo Healthcare, Healthway Medical, CSC, Pan Hong
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence arm, The Ascott Limited, signed new contracts to manage two properties in Singapore, increasing its portfolio to over 900 units. Raffles Medical Group reported a 1% growth in net profit to S$16.4 million for the third quarter, driven by higher local patient loads. Revenue increased marginally, while hospital services' contribution rose 3.1% and healthcare services revenue slipped 4.2%.

site_title: Qatar emir accuses blockade countries of wanting 'regime change'
summary: Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani has accused Saudi Arabia and its Arab allies of seeking to topple his government with a nearly five-month-old embargo, labeling it a "regime change." The Gulf crisis began in June, with Saudi Arabia and its allies imposing economic sanctions and closing borders, accusing Qatar of supporting terrorism and Iran. Qatar denies the charges, citing its desire for independence, freedom of speech, and a vision for the region that contradicts its allies.

site_title: Storm kills at least six in Europe, freighter runs aground
summary: Strong winds in northern and central Europe killed at least six people, with four victims in Poland and the Czech Republic killed by falling trees. The storm also knocked out power to thousands and suspended rail traffic in Germany. A freighter, the "Glory Amsterdam", ran aground on a German island, with authorities monitoring for oil leaks. The storm caused widespread damage and flooding, particularly in Hamburg, with thousands of travelers stranded due to rail disruptions.

site_title: Combine Will inks investment pact for new plant in China's Guangxi
summary: Combine Will International Holdings Limited has signed a 200 million yuan (S$41.1 million) investment agreement with the Cangwu County Government in China's Guangxi province to construct a new 59,000 sq m production facility. The facility will manufacture toys, plastic gifts, and computer accessories. As part of the agreement, Combine Will will enjoy rental concessions and special subsidies, and will sell its existing Dongguan production plants to Veken Group Co Ltd for 160 million yuan.

site_title: Saudi Airlines to operate first Baghdad flight in 27 years
summary: Saudi Arabian Airlines will launch its first flight to Baghdad in 27 years, resuming flights between the two countries after an interruption since 1990. The move follows growing ties between Saudi Arabia and Iraq, with the two countries holding their first joint coordination council meeting earlier this month. The airline's return to Baghdad aims to capitalize on economic benefits and counter Iranian influence in Iraq, as both countries face a protracted oil slump. Private carrier flynas also plans to expand its routes to major Iraqi cities.

site_title: Trump tax overhaul under intensifying fire as Congress readies bill
summary: President Trump's tax overhaul plan faces growing opposition from interest groups as Republicans prepare to unveil a sweeping bill. The National Association of Home Builders opposes a change to home mortgage deductions, while Republican leaders try to address concerns over individual retirement savings and state and local tax payments. The plan aims to deliver up to $6 trillion in tax cuts, but analysts say it may be delayed until next year due to challenges from rank-and-file House Republicans and opposition from high-tax states.

site_title: The bull charges on
summary: Market experts weigh in on the rationality and sustainability of current market "exuberance," citing varying perspectives. Vipin Kalra, CEO of BankBazaar International, believes the current positive sentiment is rational, driven by financial systems' resilience and rising investments. In contrast, John Bittleston, founder of Terrific Mentors International, sees it as euphoria gone mad, ignoring heavy debt and exacerbating income disparities. Others, such as Kristy Castleton, founder of Rebel & Soul, caution that emotions often trump rational analysis. Many experts agree that markets can splurge on enthusiasm but emphasize the importance of sustainable growth, structural reforms, and prudent policy decisions.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton claims his place among the greats with fourth title win
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured his fourth Formula One world title, joining an exclusive club of four-time champions alongside Sebastian Vettel and Alain Prost. The 32-year-old British driver, who grew up in a disadvantaged background, surpassed five other racing legends with his achievement. Hamilton's ninth-place finish in the Mexican Grand Prix marked a remarkable milestone in his career, solidifying his position as one of the sport's greatest drivers.

site_title: Bringing cheer to children in the rural community
summary: CapitaLand Hope Foundation employees joined a volunteer expedition to Inner Mongolia, where they created colourful wall murals with over 300 students at the CapitaLand Xingfuzhilu Hope School. The artwork was part of a biannual volunteer event from September 17-19, showcasing the collaboration between the foundation and local students and staff.

site_title: London house-buyers benefit from Brexit impact on prices
summary: London house prices are growing more slowly than in any other region in the UK, a first in 10 years, due to the Brexit impact. The capital's housing sector has seen a decline in investment from abroad, with foreign investors examining the 0.6% year-on-year drop in average property prices. Experts attribute this to the uncertainty surrounding Brexit, as well as Chinese capital controls and British legislation making buy-to-let investments more expensive.

site_title: Saudis to allow women into sports stadiums from 2018
summary: Saudi Arabia will allow women to attend sports events at three stadiums starting early 2018, marking a significant step in the country's reform drive. This move follows the Crown Prince's Vision 2030 plan, which aims to boost female employment and relax strict norms. The announcement comes after a test run last month, where hundreds of women attended a sports stadium in Riyadh. The move is seen as a step towards greater female participation in public life, following the recent decision to allow women to drive in June 2018.

site_title: Greek government in spat with Spain's ambassador over Catalonia
summary: Greece called on Spain's ambassador to rescind comments suggesting Athens wasn't supportive of Spanish unity amid a Catalan independence drive. The Greek Foreign Ministry stated it was surprised by the ambassador's remarks, criticizing the Greek government's stance. EU leaders generally back Madrid, but Greece's left-wing government has not. The ambassador claimed Greece's president didn't speak for the government, and the ministry accused him of insulting Greece's constitution and interfering in domestic politics. Tensions arise as Greece and Spain disagree over the Catalan crisis, a sensitive issue in the European Union.

site_title: Saudi Aramco IPO: final destination, size still unclear
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil giant Aramco is expected to go public in 2018, but the final details of the initial public offering (IPO) remain unclear. The IPO, intended to seed a $2 trillion sovereign wealth fund, is a key part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's reform program. Despite assurances from officials, the possibility of forgoing an international listing and opting for a domestic sale in Riyadh has been raised, potentially complicating the timeline.

site_title: Ascott bags contracts to manage two properties in CBD, Ophir-Rochor Corridor
summary: Ascott Limited, the serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has secured contracts to manage two properties in Singapore: Citadines Raffles Place and Citadines Rochor Singapore. The properties, offering over 600 units, will operate under the Citadines brand and are set to open in 2020 and 2021. This move significantly increases Citadines' portfolio in Singapore, making it the country's leading serviced residence brand with over 900 units. The new properties cater to the growing demand for accommodation in emerging commercial hubs beyond the CBD.

site_title: 'Icarus' market tipped to fly higher on big tech's earnings
summary: The US stock market is expected to continue its upward trend, dubbed the "Icarus" market, driven by strong earnings reports from big tech companies and a solid jobs report. More than half of S&P 500 companies have reported Q3 earnings, with most exceeding targets. Shares of Amazon, Google, and Apple have hit record highs, with Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos surpassing Bill Gates as the world's richest man. Analysts predict continued growth for these companies, driven by their experimental operations and adaptability.

site_title: Indian diamond dealers on industry's watch list
summary: India's diamond industry is on the watch list due to a significant debt burden of around $10 billion, accounting for most of the global diamond debt of $12-14 billion. Indian diamond dealers and manufacturers are facing financial checks from Israel and Belgium, and some have been restricted from buying and selling diamonds due to non-performing loans. The industry's debt levels have resulted in a financial squeeze on manufacturers and dealers, with some firms asking for debt forgiveness or extended repayment terms.

site_title: Apple's face recognition in iPhone X raises security concerns
summary: Apple's iPhone X, released on November 3, 2017, features facial recognition technology, known as FaceID, allowing users to unlock their device with a facial scan. While Apple claims its technology is secure and cannot be tricked by a photo or hacker, privacy activists express concerns over the potential for misuse by law enforcement, marketers, and others. The widespread adoption of facial recognition technology could "normalise" it and lead to broader surveillance, according to Jay Stanley, a policy analyst with the American Civil Liberties Union.

site_title: #Metoo campaign moves to French streets
summary: Protesters in France held rallies in several cities to support the #MeToo campaign against sexual harassment and assault, inspired by the US movement. The rallies, organized by freelance journalist Carol Galand, aimed to raise awareness and ensure the campaign goes beyond social media. French feminists believe the movement could mark a turning point in attitudes towards sexual predation in the country. Prominent figures, including Roman Polanski, have been targeted with new abuse claims, with protests planned outside a Paris-based film archive where Polanski is scheduled to attend.

site_title: France weighs nuclear reactor closures
summary: France plans to close nuclear reactors to reduce atomic energy's share in power generation to 50% by 2025. Environment Minister Nicolas Hulot will detail the number of reactors to close in a 2018 plan, considering the need to avoid electricity shortages. The nuclear sector supports around 220,000 jobs, making closures a sensitive topic. France aims to meet the target through a "green deal" on energy transition, which will be presented in the first half of 2018.

site_title: BT League thrives on unpredictability factor
summary: The Business Times Corporate Golf League, a unique format tournament, maintained suspense until the final round in September. The league, which began in July, saw teams like Team Boustead and Tat Hong-The Crane Boomers switch leads frequently due to the adopted formula of discarding low scores and counting the final round. In the end, Team Boustead edged out Tat Hong on countback with a total of 542 points, winning the event for the second time in 2015. The tournament promises to be bigger and better next year due to continued sponsor support.

site_title: FJB sews up new look for profitability
summary: FJB, a luxury retailer in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, is revamping its business to achieve profitability. After years of struggling with losses, the company has introduced new business strategies, including smaller store premises and a focus on high-street brands. FJB has narrowed its losses to S$942,000 in the first quarter of 2017, with its ongoing business showing growth. The company will also launch an online platform and is exploring opportunities with big online groups. FJB's CEO Nash Benjamin is confident that the business is turning around, with a focus on improving the Singapore market and containing costs.

site_title: ST Index firmer; HNA Group takes a stake in Sapphire Corp
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.6% over five trading sessions from Oct 20 to Oct 26, bringing its dividend-inclusive return for 2017 to 20%. Notable company moves include HNA Group acquiring a 27.97% stake in Sapphire Corporation, Nordic Group's executive chairman Chang Yeh Hong acquiring 3,312,500 shares, and Valuetronics Holdings' HSHK Asian Small Caps fund acquiring 192,400 shares. Other transactions include share buybacks by Singapore Post and Keong Hong Holdings.

site_title: iFast Corporation posts 21.5% rise in Q3 net profit
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 21.5% increase in Q3 net profit to S$2.32 million, driven by a 24.9% rise in revenue to S$26.23 million. However, the China operation posted a loss of S$1.03 million, a 3.7% reduction from the previous year. The company's net revenue was 21.9% higher at S$13.02 million.

site_title: McDonald's sets new welfare standards for chickens
summary: McDonald's has set new welfare standards for chickens, requiring suppliers to follow guidelines for raising and slaughtering birds by 2024. The standards include providing birds with access to perches and measuring the amount and brightness of light in chicken houses. Animal welfare groups say the measures fall short of commitments made by other restaurants, such as Burger King and Subway. McDonald's pledged to conduct trials with suppliers to measure the well-being of different chicken breeds, and will not raise menu prices as a result of the new standards.

site_title: Tanglin Shopping Centre in third bid at collective sale
summary: The owners of Tanglin Shopping Centre, a 47-year-old building on Orchard Road, are making a third attempt at a collective sale. The building, comprising shops, eateries, and medical suites, has 170 strata-titled owners. A sale committee will be elected on Nov 3, and owners must sign a collective sale agreement with 80% of the property. The previous attempts in 2011 and 2014 fell through due to failed reserve prices. Maintenance costs are rising, and the building's age is cited as a reason for the latest attempt.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us bankruptcy hangs over toymakers as holidays approach
summary: Toys 'R' Us' bankruptcy has cast a shadow on toymakers, particularly during the holiday season. Despite vowing to keep operating stores, the retailer's struggles have affected Hasbro and Mattel, with combined losses of almost $800 million in market value. Mattel reported a 22% decline in sales, with half attributed to reduced shipments to Toys 'R' Us, while Hasbro's sales forecast for the fourth quarter was significantly lower than analyst projections. The impact of Toys 'R' Us' bankruptcy is expected to be felt by smaller toy companies as well.

site_title: Kaspersky's sales hit by Russian hacking controversy, says CEO
summary: Kaspersky Lab's CEO Eugene Kaspersky said the company's US sales are expected to drop by a "single-digit" percentage due to the controversy surrounding his company's ties to the Russian government. Despite this, global revenue is expected to increase to around $700 million in 2017. Kaspersky denies any wrongdoing, stating that the company's interactions with law enforcement are limited to cyber crime investigations. The US government has ordered Kaspersky's products removed from government computers, citing national security concerns, and several retailers have also pulled the company's products from their shelves.

site_title: Leasehold favoured over freehold properties in current en bloc fever
summary: Developers in Singapore's en bloc market have shifted their preference from freehold to leasehold properties, with 92% of units sold in 2016 and 83% in 2017. This change is driven by the desire for larger leasehold sites to achieve greater economies of scale and revenue. Land-starved developers are opting for leasehold assets to maximize their returns in the current market. This trend is expected to continue as the en bloc cycle continues.

site_title: Wilton Resources secures US$13.5m project financing deal from a shareholder
summary: Wilton Resources Corporation, a Singapore-listed gold-mining group, secured a US$13.5 million project financing deal from Karl Hoffmann Mineral Pte Ltd, with US$5 million initially credited to the company. The funds will be used to build a 500-tonne per day flotation and carbon-in-leach mineral processing facility at the Ciemas gold project in West Java, Indonesia. The deal's completion is subject to the finalization of ancillary terms.

site_title: Facebook in a fix over a fix for fake content
summary: Facebook is grappling with the issue of fake content, particularly in the US, where efforts to block certain posts could inadvertently aid censors in oppressive regimes. The company has acknowledged that Russian organizations with ties to the Kremlin purchased $100,000 worth of ads related to the 2016 presidential election, but its hands-off approach has raised concerns among employees. The debate centers around whether Facebook should censor certain content, with some arguing that it should prioritize free speech and others worrying that its lack of action will lead to problems.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights reports on the tanker and dry bulk market. VLCC rates increased in nearly all loading areas, with the biggest gains in the Caribbean, where rates rose 8% to $4 million. Meanwhile, unrelated news includes Tesla's entry into the Indian market, FedEx partnering with a robot startup, and Japan's carmakers cutting export prices due to tariffs. The news also touches on EV battery makers facing pressure to cut emissions and Nissan's potential record-high coupon in a $4 billion bond sale.

site_title: US Fed to stand pat as inflation conundrum persists
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at a two-day meeting, defying expectations of a rate hike, as inflation remains below the central bank's target of 2%. The Fed's decision comes despite a strong US economy, which beat expectations with a 3% growth rate in the third quarter. The decision is also influenced by President Donald Trump's potential decision to replace Fed Chair Janet Yellen, whose term expires in February. The Fed's decision is seen as a surprise, with some critics arguing that the central bank's models are not supported by hard data.

site_title: Buyout firms crave Buffett-like long game that remains elusive
summary: Buyout firms in the private equity industry are struggling to adopt a long-term investment strategy similar to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, as seen in its landmark deals. These firms aim to raise long-duration funds to make megadeals, but investors are hesitant to take the long game. The buy-and-hold model remains elusive, and it will take time for investors and managers to warm up to this approach. Private equity firms are expected to need decades of patient capital to make large-scale investments.

site_title: Collaboration is key to growing SMEs: KPMG
summary: KPMG is shifting its focus from large, listed companies to nurturing small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) from their early stages. New head of enterprise Jonathan Ho aims to establish an ecosystem to promote collaboration among SMEs, larger corporations, and KPMG itself. This includes a formalized enterprise committee and partnerships to harness synergies among family businesses, startups, and high-growth companies. Ho emphasizes the importance of risk-taking and calculated risks to drive innovation and growth, and KPMG is committed to supporting SMEs in their pursuit of growth and success.

site_title: Norway's US$1 trillion fund adjusts to world of ultra-low rates, high liquidity
summary: Norway's Government Pension Fund Global, a $1 trillion sovereign wealth fund, is shifting its focus to equities due to ultra-low interest rates and high liquidity. The fund now views its bond portfolio as a hedge for its stock investments, with 60-70% of its assets allocated to equities. Despite a 3.2% return in the third quarter, the fund's CEO warns of caution due to market volatility. The fund plans to reduce its bond holdings and increase its stock holdings to 70% of its portfolio, targeting a balance between equities and fixed-income securities.

site_title: Rampant Wozniacki snaps Williams hoodoo in style
summary: Caroline Wozniacki has ended her seven-match losing streak against Venus Williams, winning 6-4, 6-4 in the title showdown in Singapore. This marks the Dane's first victory over Williams in their eighth meeting. Wozniacki's win comes after a determined effort to break the losing streak, as she faced Williams for the eighth time in the past 10 years.

site_title: On mission to reboot rubber industry
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation Ltd, a Singapore-listed company, aims to reboot the rubber industry. CEO Robert Meyer, who grew up with rubber factories, is leading the effort. He plans to bring a modern approach to the industry, which he describes as "the business that time forgot."

site_title: US healthcare industry shudders at sound of Amazon's footsteps
summary: Amazon's entry into the US pharmacy market is likely, with CVS Health's acquisition of Aetna partly a response to Amazon's presence. Amazon has received wholesale pharmacy licenses in at least a dozen states, but these licenses allow it to sell a variety of products, not just prescription drugs. Analysts predict Amazon may start by targeting cash-paying customers, potentially through a mail-order pharmacy, before expanding to insured patients and pharmacy-benefit managers.

site_title: Profit warnings: OUE Lippo Healthcare, Healthway Medical, CSC Holdings
summary: Three Singapore companies have issued profit warnings: OUE Lippo Healthcare, Healthway Medical, and CSC Holdings. OUE Lippo Healthcare blames operating costs, while Healthway Medical cites a "challenging operating environment and increase in finance costs." CSC Holdings does not specify the reason for its expected losses. These warnings come ahead of upcoming quarterly results, signaling potential financial difficulties for the firms.

site_title: Brexit hastens Pakistani Kashmir's economic break with Britain
summary: Brexit has exacerbated the economic struggles of Pakistan's Mirpur, a region that relies heavily on remittances from British emigrants. With the value of the pound decreasing, the cost of living has surged, and the number of remittances has fallen by nearly 10% since the Brexit referendum. The region's economy, already limited by lack of industry and jobs, is facing uncertain prospects, and the decline in remittances has raised concerns about the country's foreign exchange reserves.

site_title: Goshen gets CSR down to a fine art
summary: Goshen Art Gallery, founded by Jack Yu in 2015, has established itself as a champion of corporate social responsibility (CSR) through art-driven initiatives. The gallery donates art pieces to charity events, auctions them to raise funds, and donates a portion of its commission to charity. It also provides a platform for artists to showcase their work, offering exhibitions and expertise to help them grow. Plans include expanding its regional presence and collaborating with other artists to impact communities.

site_title: CVS' bid for Aetna is a US$66b bet on cutting drug costs
summary: CVS Health is proposing a $66 billion merger with health insurer Aetna, aiming to reduce US drug costs by cutting out middlemen. The deal would enable CVS to negotiate prices with pharmaceutical manufacturers and set customer out-of-pocket costs. The move is expected to pressure rival insurers, drugmakers, and pharmacies to consider mergers or changes to maintain profit margins. Industry analysts predict potential ripple effects, including increased consolidation and a counterweight to big pharma companies.

site_title: Tiger Woods pleads guilty to reckless driving
summary: Tiger Woods, 41, pleaded guilty to reckless driving in a Florida court, agreeing to one year of probation and a $250 fine after being found asleep in his car beside a road in Jupiter, Florida, in May 2017. Woods had five drugs in his system, including opioids and marijuana, at the time of his arrest. The plea deal allows him to avoid jail time unless he commits major violations of his probation. Woods will also complete "DUI school" and community service as part of the agreement.

site_title: easyJet clinches parts of Air Berlin ops for German expansion
summary: easyJet has agreed to buy parts of Air Berlin's operations at Berlin Tegel airport, acquiring 25 A320 aircraft, take-off and landing slots, and jobs for staff. The deal, worth 40 million euros, will make easyJet the leading carrier in the German capital, connecting passengers to destinations across Germany and Europe. This acquisition is seen as a strategic move to ease concerns about the impact of Lufthansa's takeover of Air Berlin's operations on the domestic German market.

site_title: New vessels join PIL fleet amid recovery in box ship industry
summary: Singapore-based Pacific International Lines (PIL) has received 12 new 11,800-TEU vessels from China, bolstering its shipping capacity to 500,000 TEU. The deliveries come as the box ship industry recovers from a multi-year trough, with Drewry Shipping Consultants projecting a US$1.5 billion operating profit for 2017. PIL's managing director, SS Teo, believes the new vessels will enable the company to have "more meaningful dialogues" with shipping alliances, and expand its presence in lucrative long-haul trades.

site_title: Market-moving news from multiple directions this week
summary: The Singapore bourse is set to enter a busy earnings season, with several key central bank meetings and macro data releases expected to influence market sentiment. The US economy's 3% Q3 GDP growth, beating projections, is expected to keep the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates. Earnings season will also see three-fourths of S&P 500 companies release results by the end of the week. Markets will be watching for potential leads from the US FOMC, Bank of England, and Bank of Japan meetings, as well as President Trump's tax bill.

site_title: WongP first Singapore law firm to embrace AI
summary: WongPartnership, a Singapore-based law firm, has become the first in its sector to adopt artificial intelligence (AI) technology to support its service offerings. The firm is partnering with Luminance, a London-based AI platform, to deploy its AI technology to enhance due diligence processes for merger and acquisitions (M&A) transactions. The aim is to optimize legal services for clients, not replace lawyers with robots, and to focus on key documents from the outset, improving efficiency and effectiveness. WongP is not the first law firm to adopt AI, but it is the first in Singapore to do so, giving it a first-mover advantage.

images.alt_text: Mr Ng says: "Our success as lawyers has been premised on doing things differently and challenging some of the norms of how law has been practised."

site_title: Portman says 'at end of day' Republican tax plan to cut deficit
summary: Senator Rob Portman says the Republican tax plan won't raise the US budget deficit over the long term, despite sharp reductions to corporate and individual tax rates. He believes the plan will boost the economy, leading to a 2.3% annual growth rate, which will lower the deficit. The plan is expected to include a $1.5 trillion in tax cuts, but wrangling over details continues ahead of the House's expected release of its version on Wednesday. Portman aims to change behavior through the tax plan, which will be delivered by year's end.

site_title: NY returns some neighbourhoods to nature to fend off storms
summary: New York state has spent $255 million to buy out 654 properties in flood-prone areas, including Staten Island, as part of a programme to convert vulnerable neighborhoods into uninhabited buffer zones to combat rising sea levels and more frequent storms. The programme has displaced long-time residents, with many opting to move to higher ground despite initial resistance. The state has set aside $83 more properties for buyouts, but will not use eminent domain to force out residents who declined offers.

images.alt_text: Frank Lettieri on the patch of grass where the house in which he and his wife lived used to be, before the land was acquired.

site_title: New career and training website launched for students and working adults
summary: Singapore has launched the MySkillsFuture website to help citizens plan their learning and training journey from childhood to adulthood. The website, launched by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, aims to help students and working adults make informed learning and career choices. The site offers games and resources for primary school pupils and provides job search and training course listings for adults. The Ministry of Education, Workforce Singapore, and SkillsFuture Singapore collaborated on the initiative, which also includes free 90-minute talks on skills upgrading and career planning at community centers.

site_title: Rouhani says Iran will keep producing missiles, state TV reports
summary: Iran President Hassan Rouhani stated that the country will continue to produce missiles for defense purposes, citing no international agreements are violated. The US House of Representatives voted for new sanctions against Iran's ballistic missile program, amid efforts to curb Tehran without undermining the 2015 nuclear agreement. Rouhani criticized US President Donald Trump's refusal to certify Iran's compliance with the accord, saying America should forget future talks and agreements. The International Atomic Energy Agency's director general reiterated that Iran is implementing its nuclear-related commitments, calling for full implementation to make the JCPOA sustainable.

site_title: United Airlines launches daily non-stop flight between Singapore and Los Angeles
summary: United Airlines launched a daily non-stop flight between Singapore and Los Angeles on October 29, 2017, saving passengers nearly two hours of journey time each way. The flight, UA38, departs Changi Airport at 11am and arrives at Los Angeles at 11:15am, while the return flight, UA37, departs Los Angeles at 9:25pm and arrives in Singapore at 6:20am two days later. This marks the return of a long-haul route for travelers after Singapore Airlines stopped operating it about a decade ago.

site_title: Kuroda looks favoured to get second term as Bank of Japan chief: Nikkei
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is favored to secure a second five-year term, with top advisers citing his "appreciation for the present system". The decision comes after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling bloc won a landslide election, maintaining its economic agenda focusing on loose fiscal and monetary policies. The government will propose a list of candidates for governor and deputy governors in January, with Kuroda's age, 73, not seen as a problem. The Bank of Japan has not commented on the matter.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda looks favoured to get a second five-year term when his current one ends in April, the Nikkei business paper reported on Saturday.

site_title: Cambodia deports 61 Chinese telecom extortion scam suspects
summary: Cambodia deported 61 Chinese nationals suspected of extortion, including 13 women, who were detained in raids on October 17 and 21. The suspects were wanted in China for extorting money from people over the internet and by phone, with billions of dollars in losses reported. Chinese police arrived to pick up the suspects, who were not among those arrested in Taiwan. The deportation has raised concerns from Taiwan, which has accused Cambodia of acting at the behest of Beijing.

site_title: A true gentleman with a big heart
summary: There is no article content provided to summarize. The given text appears to be a collection of news article titles and publication dates, but no article is actually provided for summarization.

site_title: Tanglin Shopping Centre making third collective sale attempt
summary: The Tanglin Shopping Centre, a 47-year-old Orchard Road landmark, is set to attempt its third collective sale after two previous attempts in 2011 and 2014. The sale requires 80% of owners to sign the collective sale agreement, with a target reserve price of S$1 billion. The building, comprising shops, eateries, and offices, has been plagued by rising maintenance costs and a desire to rejuvenate the property. The sale committee will be formed and a marketing agent and lawyers will be appointed for the latest attempt.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit five-month high; Spain hurt by Catalonia vote
summary: European shares reached a five-month high on Friday, driven by gains in the broader market, despite Spain's IBEX index falling 1.5% due to Catalonia's declaration of independence. The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 0.6%, while Germany's DAX index reached a record high. Tech stocks also gained, led by Alphabet, Microsoft, and Amazon.com. Despite a cautious outlook from UBS, European equities are expected to benefit from continued financial conditions and strong GDP growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: First charges filed in special US probe on Russia meddling: report
summary: A Washington grand jury has approved the first charges in the Mueller probe on Russia meddling, marking a major step forward in the investigation into potential links between President Donald Trump's campaign and Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential vote. The charges, details of which remain unclear, could lead to possible criminal indictments. A federal judge has ordered the charges to stay sealed, and those charged could be taken into custody as early as Monday. The probe is also examining Trump's firing of James Comey, his son's meeting with a Kremlin-linked lawyer, and foreign lobbying by campaign chairman Paul Manafort.

site_title: Work and play
summary: adidas Consortium has collaborated with Singapore-based retailer Limited Edt to release a luxury Superstar shoe, paying homage to Limited Edt's Vault store. The shoe features burgundy burnished leather and batik-inspired embroidery. Available at Limited Edt Vault and limitededt.com for S$219, the collaboration offers a dressy yet playful take on the iconic Superstar design.

site_title: United launches longest flight to or from US, from LA to Singapore
summary: United Airlines launched the longest non-stop flight to or from the US, a 14,000km journey from Los Angeles to Singapore, on October 27, 2017. The 18-hour flight departs Los Angeles at 9:25 pm and lands in Singapore at 6:20 am the next day. This daily service is the longest non-stop flight from the US to anywhere in the world, connecting two major markets.

images.alt_text: United Airlines on Friday was set to launch the longest non-stop flight to or from the United States, a 14,000km journey connecting Los Angeles and Singapore.

site_title: S&P 500 in blow-off phase seeking new high
summary: The S&P 500 index is in a "blow-off phase" seeking new highs, according to a study that divides market cycles into three phases: early stages of a bull market, a blow-off phase, and a bearish quarter. The current bull market, which began in 2009, is nearing its end, with the previous blow-off phase lasting six quarters. A bearish quarter is required to confirm the market top, and the current phase may be nearing its end, with the S&P 500 index expected to close below 2521 points in Q4 2017 to signal exhaustion.

site_title: Tencent-backed Sogou aims for up to US$585m in US IPO
summary: Sogou Inc, backed by Tencent Holdings, aims to raise up to $585 million in its US IPO by selling 45 million American depositary shares at $11 to $13 each. The funds will be used for research and development and sales marketing. Sogou is the default search engine in Tencent's Mobile QQ browser and qq.com, and is exploring collaboration opportunities with the Chinese tech giant.

site_title: Trump to announce new Federal Reserve chair 'next week'
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to announce his choice for the next Federal Reserve chair next week. Trump mentioned that his pick will do a "fantastic job" and hinted at having someone "very specific" in mind. Current Fed Chair Janet Yellen, who has kept interest rates low, is reportedly in the running. The announcement could have significant implications for Trump's economic agenda, which has seen a surge in the stock market.

site_title: Falcon Energy's full-year net loss widens to US$121.2m from US$5m
summary: Falcon Energy Group, a Singapore-listed offshore oil and gas contractor, reported a widened net loss of US$121.18 million for the year ended June 30, 2017, compared to a net loss of US$4.96 million in the previous year. Revenue slumped 56% to US$106.82 million due to lower works volume and charter rates. The company attributed the loss to a US$133.15 million jump in allowance for impairment of assets, mainly due to the prolonged depressed oil and gas industry.

site_title: Gold rises on safe-haven appeal after Catalonia declares independence
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,270.36 an ounce after Catalonia declared independence from Spain, seeking a safe-haven asset amid geopolitical uncertainty. Despite this, analysts expect gold's gains to be short-lived due to the strong US dollar. The dollar index remains near a three-month high, limiting gold's gains. Other metals, such as silver, platinum, and palladium, also fell, tracking gold's decline.

site_title: Controversy-battered Uber hires top legal officer
summary: Uber hires Tony West, a former federal prosecutor and senior Department of Justice official, as its new top legal officer, starting next month. West's experience is seen as well-equipped to handle investigations into Uber's past practices. This move comes amid controversy in the workplace and on the streets. CEO Dara Khosrowshahi believes West's expertise will help Uber navigate investigations and past practices.

site_title: Falcon Energy's full-year loss widens to US$121.2m
summary: Falcon Energy Group, a Singapore-listed offshore oil and gas contractor, reported a widening net loss of US$121.18 million for the year ended June 30, 2017, compared to a net loss of US$4.96 million in the previous year. Revenue declined 56% to US$106.82 million due to lower volume of works and charter rates. The group's average gross profit margin contracted to 11.7% from 20.5% in FY2016, and it made a US$133.15 million jump in allowance for impairment of assets. Shareholders will not receive a dividend for FY2017.

site_title: The time is now
summary: Bell & Ross has released the BR-X1 Skeleton Tourbillon Sapphire, a limited-edition watch featuring a transparent case made from five sapphire blocks. The watch showcases a flying tourbillon that appears to float, and only eight pieces have been produced. The unique design allows wearers to admire the movement, making it a rare and beautiful timepiece.

site_title: Don't hold your breath for quantum computers - they can't do everything
summary: Quantum computers, expected to achieve quantum supremacy by year-end, may not live up to expectations, says Simon Benjamin, a professor of quantum technologies. Despite Google's claims of quantum supremacy, quantum computers perform worse than conventional supercomputers for many tasks and are error-prone due to fragile qubits. Currently, quantum computers are only good for solving optimisation problems, and it may take another decade for error-corrected or error-free quantum computing to become possible, potentially leading to a backlash if investors lose money.

images.alt_text: A computer chip unveiled by D-Wave Systems Inc, the only company to sell a commercial quantum computer.

site_title: Q3 office rents back in growth mode, reversing long downtrend
summary: Singapore's office market has reversed its long downtrend, with Q3 rents rising 2.4% and occupied office space increasing by 10,000 sq m. Consultants attribute the recovery to improved business sentiment and tenants' preference for new developments. Despite a 13.3% office vacancy rate, the market is showing signs of improvement, with higher rental expectations from landlords and increased leasing commitments. Rents are expected to rise further in 2018, with a potential increase of 3-5%.

site_title: Hundreds of thousands march for unified Spain, poll shows depths of division
summary: Hundreds of thousands of supporters of a unified Spain gathered in Barcelona on Sunday, showing force against Catalan independence. A poll shows a small lead for anti-independence parties, with 43.4% support compared to 42.5% for pro-independence parties. Spain's central government called a regional election to try to resolve the country's worst crisis in four decades, following the assembly's unilateral declaration of independence. European countries and the US have rejected the Catalan declaration of independence, and tensions remain high as Madrid enforces direct rule.

site_title: Catalan rebels defiant as pro-unity supporters gather
summary: Catalan rebels have defied Spanish authorities after the region's government was dissolved and its leaders were ousted. Despite Madrid's direct control, rebel leaders claim the Catalan Republic has been born and will continue to work on its independence roadmap. Thousands of pro-unity supporters gathered in Barcelona, while the region's economy faces uncertainty. The situation remains unpredictable, with potential for civil unrest and arrests in the coming days.

images.alt_text: A demonstrator holds a placard bearing a crossed-out portrait of Catalan regional leader Carles Puigdemont, who was officially ousted by Madrid, which reads "dictators out" as others wave Spanish and Catalan flags during a pro-unity demonstration in Barcelona on Sunday.

site_title: Edible art
summary: NestBloom, an edible flower dessert, is now available in Singapore. The blooms, priced from S$21, "blossom" into a creamy bird's nest dessert when added to hot water. Available from October 27 to November 9 at 13 Bussorah Street, they come in three flavors: original almond cream, almond cream with matcha, and rose.

site_title: Oil up 2%, Brent hits US$60/barrel on support for extending curbs
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Friday, with Brent crude reaching US$60.44 a barrel, as Saudi Arabia and Russia expressed support for extending a deal to cut supplies for nine months.
