The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) secretary general announced the backing ahead of the group's next policy meeting on Nov 30. The deal, currently set to expire in March 2018, aims to stabilize the market and boost prices. The increase in oil prices is attributed to the dollar's retreat from three-month peaks and the rising oil benchmark.

site_title: US drops robotics trade secrets case against Chinese-Canadian man
summary: US federal prosecutors dropped charges against Dong Liu, a Chinese-Canadian man accused of trespassing at Medrobotics Corp's headquarters to steal trade secrets. Liu's lawyer argued that prosecutors lacked evidence of computer system access. Liu suffered a brain injury in 2012 and had been struggling to accept his diminished abilities. The case was dismissed without explanation, but Liu's lawyer claimed his client's mental state may have contributed to the lack of evidence.

site_title: Job market turning a corner as retrenchments fall, vacancies rise
summary: Singapore's labour market is showing signs of improvement, with retrenchments down to 7,640 in the first half of the year and job vacancies rising for the first time since 2014. The economic recovery is gathering pace, with forecasts predicting 2-3% growth this year and moderation in 2018. The job creation rate, excluding the construction and transport equipment industries, was comparable to the same period last year. However, the marine and offshore engineering cluster and construction sector have been hard-hit, with employment declines of 8,000 and 23,100 workers, respectively.

site_title: Spain on a knife's edge as Madrid seizes control of rebel Catalonia
summary: Spain's Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy dissolved the Catalan government and parliament after regional lawmakers voted to declare a Catalan "republic". Rajoy fired pro-independence leader Carles Puigdemont and his ministers, as well as the regional police director and envoys to Madrid and Brussels. The move came after a standoff with Catalonia, which had been seeking greater autonomy. December 21 elections will be held to replace the rebel government, marking the first curtailment of regional autonomy since Franco's dictatorship.

site_title: Tried & tested
summary: Heineken, a Dutch brewery, attributes its special taste to A-Yeast discovered by its founders in the 19th Century. The company's beer remains a popular choice for golfers on hot days. Meanwhile, in international news, the ASEAN region has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, with Malaysia expressing this stance. China is urging Southeast Asian countries to support openness amid US tariffs, while Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 end at records after strong tech earnings
summary: US stocks reached fresh records on Friday, driven by strong earnings from tech giants like Amazon, Intel, and Microsoft, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 2.2% to a record 6,701.26. Amazon surged 13.2% after reporting a 34% jump in revenues, while Apple gained 3.6% after reporting strong consumer interest in its new iPhone. The S&P 500 rose 0.8% to a record 2,581.07, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.1% to 23,434.19, despite some losses from companies like Expedia and Merck.

site_title: GLP's independent adviser finds privatisation bid 'fair and reasonable'
summary: Global Logistic Properties' (GLP) independent directors have accepted a proposed privatisation bid deemed 'fair and reasonable' by independent adviser Evercore Asia. The S$3.38 per share offer is considered a premium over historical prices and a sum-of-the-parts valuation of the business. The bid is being offered by Nesta Investment Holdings, a vehicle owned by major investors, with Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC agreeing to support the bid with its 36.84% stake in GLP. A scheme of arrangement meeting will take place on November 30, requiring a majority of shareholders to approve the proposal.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sheng Siong's margins and sales grew stronger year-over-year despite Amazon Prime's launch, with three new stores set to open in Q4. Samudera Shipping's Q3 net profit rose 14% year-over-year, driven by increased container volumes and freight rates. Genting Singapore is expected to maintain market share and keep VIP discounts, supporting its adjusted Ebitda estimate of S$285.1 million.

site_title: Hamptons mansions pile up as buyers fight over smaller homes
summary: Buyers in the Hamptons are prioritizing smaller, more affordable homes, leading to bidding wars on condos under $3.3 million, with 10% of deals exceeding the asking price. The non-luxury market saw a 10% decline in listings, while sales of homes priced between $500,000 and $999,000 jumped 22%. Meanwhile, inventory in the luxury market increased 22%, with buyers showing less interest in acquiring high-end homes.

site_title: US economy sees 3% growth, shrugging off hurricanes
summary: The US economy expanded at a 3% clip in the third quarter, exceeding forecasts and shrugging off the impacts of back-to-back hurricanes. This marks the second time since President Trump's inauguration that the economy has reached this growth target. Strong consumer spending and business investment drove the growth, while sagging home building and falling state and local government spending were partly offsetting factors. The result is seen as a boost to the White House's economic agenda and may strengthen the hand of monetary policymakers at the Federal Reserve, who are expected to raise interest rates despite flagging inflation.

site_title: Australia appoints acting PM while he travels amid citizenship crisis
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull appointed Foreign Minister Julie Bishop as acting prime minister while he travels abroad due to a citizenship crisis. The crisis resulted from the High Court ruling that Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce and four other lawmakers were ineligible to remain in parliament due to holding dual citizenship. With his government in a precarious position, Turnbull must win the support of independent lawmakers to keep his minority government afloat. Bishop, the second-highest ranking Liberal Party member, will act as prime minister until Turnbull's departure on Monday.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull appointed Foreign Minister Julie Bishop as acting prime minister on Saturday while he travels abroad after a citizenship crisis ousted his deputy and cost his government its parliamentary majority.

site_title: Brexit keeps UK debt outlook 'negative': Fitch, S&P
summary: Ratings agencies Fitch and S&P have reaffirmed the UK's 'AA' high-grade rating on sovereign debt, citing concerns over the Brexit process. The agencies express worry due to the recent Brexit talks deadlock and the UK's economic contraction for the second month in a row, which is a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer's government. The UK's debt outlook remains negative due to the uncertainty surrounding its future trade relations with the EU.

site_title: Banyan Tree to continue links with BT Golf League
summary: The Banyan Tree Group has reaffirmed its commitment to The Business Times Corporate Golf League, supporting the event as a main sponsor and participating social team. The company aims to build awareness about Laguna Golf Bintan and its new accommodation, Cassia Bintan, which opened recently. Banyan Tree believes that the BT League creates opportunities for corporate networking, attracting about 400 players throughout its six legs. The company has introduced a limited-time annual membership "top offer" to make golf more accessible to golfers in Singapore.

site_title: Analysts cautiously hopeful retail slump over after Q3 data
summary: Singapore's retail slump may be nearing its end, with moderation in rent decline and increase in demand for retail space. Analysts cite new F&B entrants and uptick in rents as reasons for optimism. Demand for islandwide retail space expanded by 15,000 sq m in Q3, reversing previous quarters' contractions. While full-year rental decline is expected to be lower than 2016's 8.3%, consultants still expect the retail market to remain subdued due to challenges such as high operating costs and e-commerce threats.

site_title: Wealth through health
summary: Singapore entrepreneurs are turning to niche wellness services to earn healthy revenue. Elvina Cheong, founder of Freedom Yoga, has opened two yoga studios, cultivating a community culture among members. Jaslyn Koh, founder of Broccoli & Dumbbells, connects busy professionals and travelers over healthy pursuits, offering a website and wellbeing experiences. Wendee Lee, co-founder of Biconi, has created a range of skin and hair-care products using natural ingredients like noni and coconut oil. Dawn Sim, founder of Trium Fitness, has built a yoga studio with a focus on community and charity work, offering classes and initiatives to benefit others.

site_title: Yoma Strategic's Q2 profit down on absence of fair value gain
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-based conglomerate, reported a 56.8% decline in Q2 net profit to S$3.7 million, due to the absence of a fair value gain on investment properties. Revenue rose 32.9% to S$33.1 million, driven by growth in automotive, heavy equipment, and consumer businesses. The company expects positive momentum in non-real estate businesses, including the opening of more KFC restaurants and peak demand for New Holland tractors.

site_title: Novel gifts for the festive season
summary: Cult Status is dedicating two columns to unique gift ideas, focusing on beauty and novelty gifts this month and fashion, accessories, and home decor in November. The article aims to provide novel and unusual gift suggestions to help with Christmas shopping.

site_title: Local duo to play in golf World Finals in Mexico
summary: A local duo, Nina Um and Shirley Lee, will represent Singapore in the Audi Quattro Cup World Finals in Mexico from Dec 1 to 5. They topped the Singapore Qualifiers with 46 Stableford points, beating 144 other golfers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KLW Holdings expects to report a net loss for its second fiscal quarter due to declining revenue and profit margins. Viva Industrial Trust reported a 18.3% increase in net property income and a 16.8% increase in gross revenue for the third quarter. In other news, MAS and PBOC are deepening collaboration on green and transition finance, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, companies like Grab, OCBC, and Citigroup have made announcements regarding earnings growth, leadership changes, and market targets.

site_title: China's cryptocurrency barons seek new life in Japan, HK
summary: China's largest cryptocurrency operators, such as OKCoin and Binance.com, are seeking new opportunities in Japan, Hong Kong, and Singapore due to Beijing's crackdown on trading and coin offerings. At least 19 companies are applying for a license to operate in Japan, which has emerged as a safe haven for many operators. These companies hope to attract investors and hedge risks by operating in friendlier jurisdictions.

site_title: How to engage a fanatic
summary: A writer reflects on his experiences with fanatics from different backgrounds, concluding that engaging with them is futile if approached with anger or disdain. Instead, he suggests using love, compassion, and genuine listening to address the emotional root of their fanaticism. By doing so, one can teach the world about civility, replace dark passions with better ones, and potentially learn from the fanatic themselves. The writer argues that civility is essential for living together and that even those who detest the fanatics' words can show ultimate care for their destiny and soul.

site_title: Creative space
summary: Two new creative spaces, MOX 451 Joo Chiat Road and 16 Shaw Road, have opened in Singapore, offering facilities for creatives and designers. MOX, a 40,000 sq ft space, features workshops, co-working space, and retail areas with experiential retailing, while 16 Shaw Road, a former workers' dormitory, has been converted into a creative hub with 60 tenants, offering 24-hour concierge services, storage space, and more. Both spaces aim to promote entrepreneurship and collaboration among creatives, with plans for expansion to other locations.

site_title: Playing for time
summary: Hermes is hosting a 10-day exhibition at its Takashimaya boutique and atrium in Singapore, showcasing the brand's classic watches with a playful focus on the concept of time. The exhibition, "Time, a Hermes object," features iconic timepieces such as the Cape Cod Shadow, Slim d'Hermes Grrrrr, and Slim d'Hermes L'heure impatiente, which are designed to evoke emotions and create spaces for spontaneity. The event aims to communicate Hermes' philosophy of having fun with time and not taking itself too seriously, with interactive and entertaining displays.

site_title: Savills Investment sees HK property as among riskiest
summary: Savills Investment Management has identified Hong Kong as one of the riskiest property markets due to its high prices and low affordability. Despite a nine-year bull run, home prices have soared 11% since 2017, making it the least affordable city to buy a home, according to the UBS Global Real Estate Bubble Index. Savills Investment is avoiding Hong Kong in favor of Japan and Australia, instead scouting for offices in Singapore, where leasing is picking up and the market seems to be bottoming out.

site_title: Singapore's GDP growth strengthening and spreading to more sectors
summary: Singapore's GDP growth is strengthening, with two consecutive quarters of accelerated growth driven by sustained global electronics demand. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) notes that growth is broadening beyond trade-related industries, with economic expansion expected to remain steady in the coming year. While pockets of weakness remain, the central bank is optimistic about the country's economic recovery.

site_title: The perfect base for golfing jaunts
summary: A property in Seminyak, Bali, offers a central location for golfing excursions to nearby courses, including the New Kuta Golf Club and Handara Golf Resort. The property is within walking distance to restaurants, beach clubs, and bars in Seminyak and Petitenget. Guests of Kemala Villa Bali receive a 25% discount at these golf courses.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality's earnings rise on better overall performance
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) reported a 10% year-on-year increase in full-year distributable income to S$93.5 million, driven by better performance in Australia, the UK, Malaysia, and Germany. The addition of Novotel Melbourne on Collins and refurbishment works on Novotel Rockford Darling Harbour contributed to the growth. However, the Singapore portfolio underperformed, with a 3.5% decline in distribution per stapled security. The trust's net property income rose 15.3% to S$120.2 million, while revenue increased 28.4% to S$158.7 million.

site_title: Tarot is trending, and Dior predicted it months ago
summary: Tarot cards have experienced a surge in popularity, with sales increasing 263% for the Motherpeace Tarot Deck after Christian Dior featured it in a fashion line. This trend follows the success of other decks, such as the Wild Unknown Tarot, which has been selling out due to its unique imagery and appeal to modern audiences. Tarot readers attribute the trend to the deck's connection to feminist spirituality and the current social climate, as well as its use in modern boutiques and online platforms like Instagram.

site_title: Welcome to the era of Xi Jinping
summary: Xi Jinping solidified his leadership at the 19th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, with his name and ideology enshrined in the party constitution. The event reaffirmed his "near-absolute" power and cemented his status as China's founding father, Mao Zedong. Xi's signature "One Belt One Road" initiative is now part of the party constitution, and he is poised to remain in power for a long time, with no clear successor in sight. This has significant implications for China's global influence and could have far-reaching consequences for the world's economy and politics.

site_title: Going for the ace
summary: The WTA Tour has seen a significant change in the way tennis is played, watched, and reported due to the increasing use of data and analytics. The Women's Tennis Association (WTA) has adopted technology to provide coaches with real-time insights, enabling faster and smarter decision-making. The WTA has also introduced innovative technologies, such as SAP Tennis Analytics for Coaches and Telstra's NetCam, which provides a panoramic view of the court during competition. These advancements aim to give athletes and coaches a competitive edge, and the WTA is working to protect data from hacking and illicit transfers.

site_title: 9,300 new homes to result from slew of en bloc sales, warns URA
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) predicts 9,300 new private housing units will be added to the existing supply pipeline from en bloc sales by 2021, bringing the total to about 16,700 units. Analysts remain optimistic, citing a lag in supply and expected demand from overseas talents to offset the increased supply. The new units will replenish supply to meet demand, with the current unsold units standing at 2,223, half of the 4,698 units in Q3 2016.

site_title: Make a connection
summary: A play titled "Sanctuary" explores how human interaction has changed with technology. The story, a collaboration between Singapore's The Necessary Stage and Japan's Hanchu-Yuei, examines data, communication, social media, AI, and surveillance through the eyes of a dying woman trying to stay connected with her children digitally. The play premieres at the Necessary Stage Black Box from November 1-4 and 8-11, offering a unique blend of intellectual and aesthetic engagement.

site_title: All the presidents men... And women
summary: The article "All the Presidents Men... And Women" appears to be about a golf tournament, but the provided content is unrelated to the article title. However, the article content seems to be a collection of news summaries from various sources.

site_title: Innovator-mentor
summary: Taizo Son, a serial entrepreneur, shares his early introduction to the Internet and meeting Yahoo!'s Jerry Yang in the early 1990s. Yang predicted that human knowledge and intelligence would be uploaded to the Internet, but without a search engine, correct information couldn't be accessed. Son, an innovator-mentor, now focuses on funding startups and mentoring innovators, aiming to transform education.

site_title: Big boost for junior golf, elite squad
summary: The article discusses a recent junior golf contest where 14 young golfers, including 9-year-old Brayden Lee, competed against each other. The event aimed to promote junior golf and provide a platform for young golfers to develop their skills. The contest highlighted the importance of junior golf and the need to support young golfers in developing their talents.

site_title: Retirement - it's about the kind of life you want to lead
summary: A holistic retirement planning model prioritizes the retiree's purpose to mitigate negative emotions and encourage a healthy lifestyle. Based on a 2010 survey, individuals go through six stages: Imagination, Hesitation, Anticipation, Realisation, Reorientation, and Reconciliation. A purposeful retirement model involves integrating financial decisions with life's purpose, using low-cost investment strategies, and managing assets to mitigate risks. By focusing on the kind of life one wants to live, retirees can make informed financial decisions, live a meaningful life, and achieve peace with themselves.

site_title: Private home prices 'on firm ground' after index shows uptick
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.7% quarter-over-quarter in Q3, beating the 0.5% flash estimate, according to analysts. The increase is attributed to en bloc fever and developers running short of new units or delaying new launches. The uptick in prices is also seen as a reflection of firmer prices in the last 2.5 weeks of September. The Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf.

site_title: Indofood Agri Q3 profit drops 37% on fertilisers and forex shifts
summary: Indofood Agri Resources reported a 37% drop in Q3 profit to 100.5 billion rupiah, despite a 5% increase in revenue to 3.72 trillion rupiah. The decline was attributed to higher fertiliser application, operating expenses, and foreign currency fluctuations. Gross profit slumped 11% to 748.2 trillion rupiah, and selling and distribution expenses rose 35%. The company expects agricultural commodity prices to remain volatile, driven by global developments and regulatory changes.

site_title: Boys to men
summary: In 1952, Singapore scouts, facing funding issues, organized "Job Week" by working odd jobs to raise money for a Sydney trip. Inspired by Britain's "Bob-A-Job" Week, scouts took on tasks like gardening, babysitting, and cleaning. By 1957, nearly 6,000 scouts participated, raising S$10,000 for a new headquarters. This annual event, now an annual tradition, allowed scouts to experience the value of hard work and community service.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q3 DPU dips on enlarged unit base
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 2.1% decline in Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.483 Singapore cents, due to a larger unit base. However, gross revenue and net property income rose 10.6% and 11.6% year-over-year, driven by rental contributions from Sydney and Suntec Singapore. The Reit's Singapore office portfolio had an overall committed occupancy of 99% and secured approximately 150,000 square feet of new leases.

site_title: HDB resale flat transactions drop 3.2% in Q3
summary: HDB resale flat transactions dropped 3.2% in Q3, reaching 5,808 cases, the lowest since 2012. Resale prices fell 0.7% compared to the previous quarter, continuing the gradual decline since 2013. The number of approved subletting applications decreased by 2.1% to 10,698 cases. HDB plans to release 4,800 Build-to-Order flats in November, bringing the total BTO supply to approximately 17,500 units.

site_title: Court rules Australian DPM ineligible for Parliament; govt loses majority
summary: The Australian High Court ruled Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce ineligible to remain in parliament, stripping the government of its one-seat majority. This decision led to a by-election. The ruling was accepted by Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, despite it not being the desired outcome. The Australian dollar fell due to the unexpected decision.

site_title: UBS posts 14% jump in Q3 profit, keeps cautious outlook for rest of 2017
summary: UBS, the world's largest private bank, reported a 14% year-on-year jump in Q3 profit to 946 million Swiss francs ($1.3 billion). Despite this increase, the bank maintained a cautious outlook for the rest of 2017 due to uncertainty over monetary policy and geopolitical tensions. The bank cited risks to client sentiment, including high asset prices and seasonality factors. Group pre-tax income rose 39% to 1.2 billion francs.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq up on strong tech earnings, GDP data
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened higher on Friday, driven by strong earnings from technology giants and a better-than-expected quarterly GDP growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was little changed, weighed down by Chevron. The S&P 500 gained 8.13 points, or 0.31%, to 2,568.53, while the Nasdaq Composite added 75.03 points, or 1.14%, to 6,631.80.

site_title: ECB weighs options for ending QE programme with short taper in 2018
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) policymakers discussed options for ending its quantitative easing (QE) program, with a possible short taper in 2018 if inflation improves. The ECB extended its bond-buying program for another nine months, cutting monthly purchases to 30 billion euros, and pledged to extend the program if needed. A "large majority" of policymakers backed the decision, with some scenarios including a 12-month taper or a three-month taper in monthly steps. The ECB's goal is to maintain a stable economic environment, and policymakers emphasized that a sudden stop to QE is not feasible.

site_title: How one hedge fund ignored the China bears and made a clean profit
summary: A Hong Kong-based hedge fund, Parantoux Capital, made a clean profit in 2017 by betting against short-sellers. The fund, managed by Gloria Lu, went long on shares of AAC Technologies Holdings Inc and Chinese property developers China Evergrande Group and Sunac China Holdings Ltd, which soared after short-seller reports were discredited. Parantoux's fund outperformed global peers, climbing 24% in 2017, and is one of the five best-performing Asia-based hedge funds. Lu attributes the fund's success to taking the opposite view of bears who bet on a hard landing for Asia's economy.

site_title: Many ETFs languish thanks to restrictive regulation
summary: Virtu Financial Inc is pushing for a change in US rule 5250, which restricts traders from getting paid by public companies for buying and selling their stocks. The rule affects 24% of US ETFs that saw less than $100,000 traded daily on average in the past year. Virtu's acquisition of KCG Holdings Inc has given it the leverage to advocate for the rule change, which could breathe life into small ETFs and boost industry growth.

site_title: OCBC draws analyst upgrades but many are cautious on price
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 12% increase in net profit to S$1.06 billion for its third quarter, driven by strong loans growth. Analysts upgraded the bank's rating, with CIMB Research turning "buy" and Phillip Securities Research increasing its target price to S$13.48. However, many brokers maintained "hold" ratings, citing valuation concerns. Analysts praised OCBC's holistic franchise in banking, insurance, and wealth management, but noted that the biggest challenge for Singapore banks is competition in the payments space. The bank's stock rose 2% to S$11.80 after the earnings announcement.

site_title: The road to the future: talking cars and more at Tokyo show
summary: The Tokyo Motor Show showcased concept cars from Japanese carmakers, including Toyota's AI-sensing car, Honda's electric coupe, and Lexus's autonomous luxury vehicle. Toyota unveiled its Concept i, which features an AI "agent" nicknamed Yui that assesses a person's mood and understands their preferences, aiming to make people "fall in love" with cars again. Other notable concepts include Honda's Sports EV Concept, Lexus's LS+ Concept, and Nissan's IMx, which combines electrification, autonomous drive, and crossovers. The event highlights the industry's efforts to navigate disruption from ride-hailing services and upstart carmakers, with a focus on creating emotionally engaging cars for the future.

site_title: Exxon's 3rd-qtr profit beats expectations despite Harvey dent
summary: ExxonMobil posted a higher-than-expected quarterly profit despite Hurricane Harvey's impact on US operations. The company's third-quarter net income jumped to $3.97 billion, or 93 cents per share, as higher crude and natural gas prices offset earnings losses from the storm. Exxon's refining business remained strong, with production increasing 2% to 3.9 million barrels of oil equivalent per day. CEO Darren Woods attributed the earnings growth to solid business performance and higher commodity prices.

site_title: CDLHT's DPS down 3% in Q3 due to effect of rights issue
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 3% decrease in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for the third quarter due to the effect of a rights issue in August. Despite this, the trust saw a 15.9% increase in net property income (NPI) to S$40.4 million, driven by inorganic contributions from new acquisitions in Manchester and Munich, as well as strong performance from the New Zealand Hotel. The total distribution to stapled securityholders rose 13.3% to S$27.4 million, while gross revenue increased by 20.7% to S$54.8 million.

site_title: Labour market improves further in Q3, job cuts down slightly: MOM
summary: Singapore's labour market showed further signs of recovery in Q3, with a lower overall unemployment rate of 2.1% in September. The jobless rate for residents decreased to 3.1% from 3.2% in March, while retrenchments remained at 3,600. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) warned that the unemployment rate for residents may be difficult to reduce further due to ongoing economic restructuring. Despite this, total employment fell by 2,500, with the services sector adding workers.

site_title: Merck tops profit estimates on Keytruda sales
summary: Merck & Co reported a quarterly profit that beat analysts' estimates, driven by sales of its immuno-oncology drug Keytruda, which reached US$1.05 billion in the third quarter. The company's shares rose 1.8% to US$63.10, and it narrowed its full-year adjusted earnings per share forecast to US$3.91-US$3.97. Net loss was US$56 million, or 2 US cents per share, compared to a year-ago profit of US $2.18 billion.

site_title: Andy Goh
summary: Singapore-based architecture firm ONG&ONG has been successfully expanding its presence in emerging markets such as Cambodia and Myanmar. CEO Andy Goh, 42, has led the firm's efforts, working on over 20 projects in the region since 2011. ONG&ONG's success can be attributed to its ability to craft unique design solutions that meet local needs, as well as its strong reputation in the region. Goh emphasizes the importance of understanding market trends and balancing visionary design with practicality. The firm's Singaporean brand and regional offices have also contributed to its success, allowing it to build trust and relationships with clients.

site_title: Catalan parliament declares independence from Spain
summary: Catalonia's regional parliament declared independence from Spain on October 27, 2017, with 70 votes in favor and 10 against. The move is likely to be declared illegal by Spain's constitutional court. The vote came after lawmakers from the Socialist Party, People's Party, and Ciudadanos left the chamber in protest.

site_title: Najib tables 'mother of all budgets'
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak presented a budget of RM280.25 billion, the largest yet, with 84% allocated to operating expenditure. Development expenditure remained unchanged at RM45.4 billion. The budget aims to appeal to rural voters, civil servants, and East Malaysians, but critics say it lacks major fiscal and revenue reforms. Key benefits include a 2% tax cut for wage earners, free income tax for 261,000, and improved benefits for civil servants and retirees. The government projects a 3% fiscal deficit this year and aims to reduce it to 2.8% in 2018.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.33 points to 1,746.13 on Friday, closing higher. Volume reached 2.8 billion lots worth RM2.7 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 511 to 344.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Analysts have raised target prices for SGX earnings, citing a defensive play benefiting from market volatility. Meanwhile, Chinese banks struggle due to Beijing's consumer lending push. MUFG targets US securitization business and plans to boost headcount. The PBOC adviser recommends a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs. Tesla plans to expand robotaxi services in California and Arizona. FedEx partners with QuikBot for robot deliveries in commercial areas. In corporate news, Sam Goi makes a mandatory offer for PSC shares at S$0.40. Asian stocks rally despite Trump's new threats.

site_title: Flamenco fever
summary: Flamenco artist Rocio Molina is reinventing the centuries-old dance form with her theatrical storytelling and technical skills. Her performance "Bosque Ardora" (Forest Worship) makes its Singapore debut, blending traditional flamenco with contemporary dance elements. The show has received standing ovations in Seville, and fans include ballet legend Mikhail Baryshnikov. "Bosque Ardora" will play at the Esplanade Theatre on October 28.

site_title: STI up 0.9% on Friday, ends week on fresh two-year high
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% on Friday, ending the week at a fresh two-year high of 3,386.44, driven by gains in US technology stocks and upbeat earnings. The week's trading saw the index advance 45 points or 1.4% on a week-on-week basis, breaking the 3,350 resistance mark. Strong exports data from Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand, along with a broad-based recovery in domestic demand, contributed to the market's buoyancy.

site_title: ECB should shift focus away from monthly asset buys: Policymakers
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) should shift its focus away from monthly asset buys as eurozone growth accelerates, two policymakers said. The ECB has already purchased over two trillion euros of bonds and plans to maintain a large balance sheet and low rates to provide stimulus. However, French Central Bank chief Francois Villeroy de Galhau and Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann argue that new bond buys are less relevant as the main impact of the purchase program is in the total volume of bonds already on the books.

site_title: Keppel units sell Cebu building for 794m pesos
summary: Keppel Corporation's subsidiaries have sold their 100% stake in Kepwealth Property Phils, Inc. for 794 million pesos (S$21 million) to Euro Capital Land, Inc. The divestment aims to recycle capital for other opportunities.

site_title: Gayatri to hold golf event on Nov 10
summary: Gayatri Restaurant, a key sponsor of The Business Times Corporate Golf League, is organizing its own golf tournament, Gayatri's Fish Head Master, on November 10 at Raffles Country Club. The event, priced at S$888 per flight, will feature local professionals and corporate teams. Registration closes on November 1. The tournament aims to build new relationships and sell the event to golf enthusiasts and corporations, with support from Singapore Press Holdings.

site_title: A (smart) house for all seasons
summary: A modern, eco-friendly house in Latvia's countryside, Villa A, showcases a unique blend of technology and nature. The smart home features a keyless entry system, voice-activated appliances, and remote-controlled lawnmowers, while also emphasizing the beauty of the surrounding forest. Designed to be a seamless extension of the outdoors, the house boasts floor-to-ceiling sliding glass walls and an open-plan living area. Completed in 2016, Villa A won an international Architecture Prize and serves as a testament to its owner's love of simplicity and technology.

site_title: Indonesia questions fireworks factory owner after deadly blaze
summary: Indonesian police began questioning the owner of a fireworks factory that exploded and caught fire, killing 47 workers and injuring dozens, with many suffering severe burns. The blaze occurred at the PT Panca Buana Cahaya Sukses factory in Tangerang, near Jakarta, and officials are investigating the cause. The factory's owner and seven witnesses have been brought in for questioning, amid concerns over workplace safety standards in Indonesia, where enforcement is often lax.

site_title: The eclectic chef
summary: Chef Rafael Osterling, a 47-year-old Peruvian chef, runs several restaurants in Lima, including his eponymous flagship restaurant ranked 30th in Latin America's 50 Best Restaurants list. His cooking style is eclectic and passionate, reflecting Peruvian cuisine's fusion of different cultures. Osterling emphasizes the importance of cooking with passion and love, being hungry to learn, and maintaining a positive attitude in the kitchen. He is proud of Peruvian cuisine's unique blend of cultures and ingredients, particularly the potato, which is used in classic dishes like causa.

site_title: Ahead of Trump trip, China urges US not to allow Taiwan president in
summary: China has urged the US not to allow Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-Wen to transit through US territory on her way to Pacific island allies, citing concerns over the "one China" policy and potential signals to Taiwan independence forces. The visit comes ahead of US President Donald Trump's trip to China, which has been strained over the issue. China considers Taiwan a wayward province and has never renounced the use of force to bring it under control. The US has helped arrange the stopovers, but China hopes the US will not allow Tsai to transit and will take actions to protect China-US relations and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

site_title: Swiber applies for time extension to release financial statements and convene AGM
summary: Swiber Holdings, a financially distressed oil and gas firm, has applied to the Singapore Exchange for an extension of time to release its overdue financial statements and convene an annual general meeting (AGM) due to cash flow issues. The judicial management period has been extended till October 2018, allowing more time for review. The firm's judicial managers must send creditors a statement of proposals by March 31, 2018, and convene a creditors' meeting. The extension will enable the firm to report its financial statements and convene the AGM after the judicial management period.

site_title: The hopeful romantic
summary: Fashion designer Erdem Moralioglu has collaborated with H&M on an inclusive Fall/Winter 2017 collection, marking a milestone in his mission to create beautiful clothes for every type of woman at every price point. The collection, which includes women's and men's wear, features traditional English nostalgia and Islamic references from the Ottoman dynasty, while showcasing a mix of formal and casual selections. Erdem emphasizes the importance of quality and detail, using organic cotton and traditional materials such as Harris Tweed. The collection, priced from $45 to $449, will be available on November 2.

site_title: WeWork said in talks to buy £600m Blackstone UK Project
summary: WeWork is in talks to buy £600m Blackstone UK Project, a 12-building campus in London's financial district, Devonshire Square. The campus has over 57,600 square meters of offices and will be managed by WeWork after the deal is completed. This would be WeWork's second major property purchase, following the $850m buy of the Lord & Taylor building in Manhattan. WeWork currently operates 16 locations in London and plans to open eight more.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.9% higher, led by rally in US stocks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 30.19 points to 3,386.44 on Friday, driven by gains in US stocks overnight. The rally was fueled by 1.8 billion shares worth S$1.3 billion, with 236 counters up and 202 counters down. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains for the index, ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: US economy keeps robust 3% growth in 3rd quarter
summary: The US economy maintained a robust 3% growth in the third quarter, exceeding analyst estimates of 2.4% and handily beating President Trump's target. The growth was fueled by strong consumer spending and business investment, despite disruptions from hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria. Officials noted the preliminary estimate may be revised as more data becomes available. The outcome is likely to fuel arguments among lawmakers over sweeping tax cuts, which could be financed by an expanding economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher
summary: Hong Kong shares ended higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.84% to 28,438.85, boosted by a stronger US dollar and hopes for tax cuts. The Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.27%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.34%. The gains come despite US President Donald Trump's recent threats, with traders opting to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Australia's NAB reaches agreement with regulator over rate rigging
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has reached a $50 million agreement with the Australian Securities & Investment Commission (ASIC) to settle allegations of manipulating the bank bill swap rate (BBSW) between 2010 and 2012. The BBSW is the primary interest rate benchmark used in Australian markets to price home loans and other financial products. NAB is the third major lender to reach an agreement with ASIC over the issue. The settlement marks the end of a lawsuit filed by ASIC last year.

site_title: Melbourne property, better overall performance lift Frasers Hospitality's Q4 distributable income, DPS
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 8.5% year-on-year increase in distributable income for Q4, driven by the addition of Novotel Melbourne on Collins and improved performance from Australia, UK, Malaysia, and Germany portfolios. Net property income rose 9.8% and revenue climbed 24.2%. The company's distributable income for FY2017 rose 10% to S$93.5 million, but DPS decreased 3.5% to 5.0458 cents. The trust's debt remained stable at S$810.9 million, with gearing at 32.1%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy is on a path to recovery, with growth rates accelerating over two straight quarters due to sustained global electronics demand. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) also noted the labor market is turning a corner, with a gradual recovery expected. Meanwhile, Sheng Siong Group's pre-tax margin hit a record high of 9%, and Citi Private Bank appointed Steven Lo as its new Asia head. Triyards Holdings received demand letters from two lenders totaling US$9.1 million, and the global economy faces challenges, with China's GDP growth set to slow and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Europe: Equities extend gains at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Friday, extending the previous day's gains, as the European Central Bank announced plans to taper its monetary stimulus program. The ECB will reduce bond purchases to 30 billion euros per month from January, maintaining the same level of stimulus. The move was seen as dovish and good news for the stock markets in the eurozone. Asian markets also rose, driven by investor optimism over President Trump's tax cuts and a stronger US dollar.

site_title: Triyards receives two demand letters for US$9.1 million
summary: Triyards Holdings, a yard-operating unit of offshore marine firm Ezra Holdings, has received two demand letters from lenders for a total of US$9.1 million. The company is in discussions with lenders to secure support for 180 days to develop a viable restructuring plan. Triyards has also faced claims from suppliers, with one subsidiary receiving a statutory demand from two suppliers for US$2.9 million. The company has suspended trading of its shares since September, following its parent Ezra Holdings' bankruptcy filing in March.

site_title: Quick takes: Office property on firm recovery, while retail slump still moderating
summary: Rentals of office space rose 2.4% in Q3 2017, reversing a 1.1% decline in the previous quarter, as business sentiment improved and demand for office space increased. Retail rents, however, continued to slump, falling 0.2% in Q3. Experts attribute office rent recovery to improved demand and economic recovery, while retail slump is expected to moderate as the market finds its footing.

site_title: Noble Group subsidiary invests in Malawi rare earth elements explorer
summary: Noble Group's subsidiary Talaxis Ltd has acquired 14.5% equity stake in rare earth elements explorer Mkango Resources Ltd for £500,000 (S$896,000). Mkango focuses on mineral exploration in Malawi, a move to tap into the country's potential rare earth elements reserves. The deal follows a 23% surge in Mkango's London trading price to four pence per share.

site_title: UK blames N Korea for cyberattack that crippled hospitals
summary: The UK government has blamed North Korea for a cyberattack that affected a third of English hospitals in 2017, causing significant disruptions. The attack, which was a ransomware attack, could have been prevented with basic IT security. The government is "as sure as possible" that North Korea was involved, according to junior minister Ben Wallace. The attack resulted in significant disruptions to healthcare services, highlighting the vulnerability of hospitals to cyber threats.

site_title: Spain set to impose direct rule in Catalonia as crisis spirals
summary: Spain's government is set to impose direct rule over Catalonia, a move that blocks the region's push for independence. The upper house of parliament approved the law, allowing the central government to take over the autonomous region. Separatist leaders are considering a unilateral declaration of independence, and supporters gathered in the streets. This move marks Spain's worst political crisis in four decades, with the upper house vote taking the country to a new level of confrontation.

site_title: OCBC draws analyst upgrades but many are cautious on price
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 12% increase in net profit to S$1.06 billion for its third quarter, driven by strong loans growth and momentum across its banking, insurance, and wealth management businesses. Analysts upgraded the bank, with CIMB Research turning positive and Phillip Securities Research upgrading it to "buy", but many maintained "hold" ratings due to valuation concerns. The bank's target price rose marginally to S$11.70, with analysts citing a holistic franchise and strong loan growth as positives, but also noting challenges from non-bank competitors in the payments space.

site_title: SIAEC, JV partners to sell aircraft component repair company for US$60 million
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has agreed to sell its stake in Asian Compressor Technology Services Company (ACTS) to MB Aerospace Newton Abbot for US$60 million. SIAEC will gain approximately S$14.3 million from the sale, which represents its actual share of US$14.7 million. ACTS, a joint venture between SIAEC, Pratt & Whitney, and China Airlines, provides repair and overhaul services for certain aircraft engines. The sale is expected to be completed by the end of the financial year ending March 31, 2018.

site_title: Australian govt in crisis as deputy PM ejected in citizenship ruling
summary: Australia's government is in crisis after Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce was declared ineligible to sit in parliament due to his New Zealand citizenship at the time of election. Joyce renounced his citizenship, but the ruling forces him to re-contest his seat in a special election. The government now faces weeks of uncertainty, potentially delaying company tax cuts and undermining Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's leadership. Three independent lawmakers have pledged to support Turnbull, but the opposition will continue to attack the government's eligibility.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise on Japan earnings, US tax cut hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.24% on Friday, driven by Japanese earnings season and hopes for US President Donald Trump's tax cut plans. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 22,008.45 and the Topix index at 1,771.05. The yen weakened against the US dollar, contributing to the market's positive momentum.

site_title: Baidu shares plunge over poor revenue outlook
summary: Baidu shares plummeted 15% in after-hours trading on Friday due to a poor revenue outlook. The decline is attributed to self-imposed content restrictions on its iQiyi streaming unit, limiting the screening of popular TV shows during the Communist Party congress. The restrictions, imposed to give President Xi Jinping a second term, resulted in a projected decline in revenue for the final quarter. This move is seen as a strategic decision by Baidu to align with the Chinese government's agenda.

site_title: Know Your Customer compliance costs continue to grow at financial firms: surveys
summary: Financial firms worldwide face growing Know Your Customer (KYC) compliance costs and headcounts, with average spend increasing to $150 million in 2017 from $142 million in 2016. The number of KYC compliance professionals has risen to 307 from 68 in 2016. Despite higher staffing, many firms struggle with resource constraints. This burden affects firms with $10 billion or more in revenue, with scarce resources cited as the biggest challenge in conducting KYC and customer due diligence processes.

site_title: Uber appoints banking exec as first UK chairman
summary: Uber appoints Laurel Powers-Freeling, a banking executive, as its first UK chairman, effective November 1. This comes as the company battles to retain its operating licence in London after it was stripped of its licence due to concerns over reporting serious criminal offences and background checks on drivers. Powers-Freeling, previously chief executive of M&S Money and senior adviser at the Bank of England, aims to help Uber manage and implement change, while Uber faces further challenges with the decision on its Brighton licence renewal due on November 4.

site_title: Japan's Sharp swings to first-half profit on screen sales
summary: Japan's Sharp reported a net profit of 34.7 billion yen (S$415.79 million) for the April-September period, reversing a 45.4 billion yen net loss a year ago. Sales jumped 21% to 1.12 trillion yen, driven by strong LCD screen sales and cost cuts under Taiwanese owner Hon Hai. Sharp upgraded its full-year outlook to 69 billion yen, up from a previous forecast of 59 billion yen, citing brisk sales of small- and mid-sized LCD panels and TVs.

site_title: Hong Kong property seen among riskiest at Savills Investment
summary: Savills Investment Management has identified Hong Kong as one of the riskiest property markets due to high prices and low affordability. Despite a 9-year bull run, Hong Kong's home prices have soared 11% since 2017, making it difficult to justify further increases. The company is instead focusing on Japan and Australia, citing their tight supply and stable annuity income. Savills has also sold out of a Hong Kong residential development joint venture due to cost overruns and planning delays, yielding an internal rate-of-return of just 7%.

site_title: Boom for Japan's largest steel mill on China clean air push
summary: China's push for cleaner air has boosted global steelmakers, particularly Japan's Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp, which saw a nine-fold surge in first-half profit. The company's net income climbed to 99.15 billion yen, surpassing its forecast of 85 billion yen. China's production cuts and resilient domestic demand have reduced steel exports to the lowest in four years, benefiting Japanese steelmakers. Meanwhile, Kobe Steel, Japan's third-largest producer, is facing a scandal after admitting to faking data on metal products, which may impact its earnings.

site_title: Xi discarded straw polls in picking China leaders: Xinhua
summary: President Xi Jinping has ditched traditional straw polls to select China's top leaders, opting for direct consultations with dozens of Communist Party officials instead. A task force led by Xi assessed potential candidates in 2016, with Xi personally speaking with 57 leaders between April and June 2017. The new system emphasizes "person-to-person dialogue" and "field research," aiming to reduce corruption and favoritism. Former leaders who took advantage of the straw-poll system, including Zhou Yongkang and Ling Jihua, are being held accountable.

site_title: Job market may have reached turning point, but recovery will be gradual: MAS
summary: Singapore's labour market is showing signs of turning the corner, with retrenchments down and more companies hiring, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The recovery is expected to be gradual, with the unemployment rate remaining close to its current level. Economic growth is forecast to be 2-3% this year, with growth broadening out to more industries. Job vacancies have increased, with overall retrenchments moderating to 7,640 in the first half of 2017. However, the poorest-performing sectors, including marine and offshore engineering, have been hard-hit.

site_title: Air Berlin set for final farewell as carve-up talks continue
summary: Air Berlin, a German airline, is set to hold its final farewell flight after filing for administration in August. The company has agreed to sell most of its assets to Lufthansa, easyJet, and Condor, with around 8,000 staff and thousands of customers affected. Founded nearly 40 years ago, Air Berlin struggled with debt and was kept afloat by Etihad, but the Abu Dhabi-based carrier withdrew its support in August. The airline's last flight, AB6210, is scheduled to land in Berlin on Friday night, marking the end of a nearly four-decade-long flying career.

site_title: RBS signals resilience with stronger capital in third quarter
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland Group reported stronger-than-expected capital ratios in the third quarter, with common equity Tier 1 reaching 15.5% compared to the estimated 15.3% average. CEO Ross McEwan said the bank remains on track to hit financial targets, but still faces legacy misconduct charges and needs to settle with the US Department of Justice. RBS plans to pay dividends once uncertainty over legacy issues is resolved and aims to be profitable in 2018.

site_title: Australia shares turn red as court ruling triggers political uncertainty
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Friday, shedding earlier gains, after a court ruling removed Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce from parliament due to dual citizenship, forcing a by-election and potentially destabilizing Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's government. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 13.097 points to 5,903.2, with financial stocks led by "Big Four" banks dropping 0.8%. The market is concerned about the prospect of Labor forming government and implementing policies that could negatively impact the housing market and financials.

site_title: Volkswagen lifts profit target as cost cuts pay off, shares at eight-month high
summary: Volkswagen lifted its profit target for the year after cost cuts at its core autos division helped it outperform third-quarter earnings forecasts. Shares rose 1.9% to an eight-month high, driven by strong demand from China, the US, and South America. The company's core brand saw a significant improvement in margins, with quarterly deliveries rising 7.3%. However, premium brands Audi and Porsche posted flat and lower profit. Volkswagen expects the group operating margin to moderately exceed 6-7% and is focusing on electrification and digital mobility services to reposition itself following the diesel emissions scandal.

site_title: BA owner IAG beats profit expectations in third quarter
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways, reported a 20.7% increase in third-quarter operating profit to 1.46 billion euros, beating analyst expectations. The airline group attributed the improvement to strong passenger unit revenue growth in Spain and Latin America. IAG expects a full-year operating profit of 3 billion euros before exceptional items. The company's robust performance comes despite disruptions from severe weather and terrorism, and follows the insolvency of several airlines this year.

site_title: South Korea Oct consumer sentiment improves as exports surge
summary: South Korea's October consumer sentiment index rose to 109.2, a five-month high, due to a surge in exports supporting the country's economic recovery. This marks a reversal from a five-month low in September, with more consumers now optimistic about economic conditions. The increase suggests a wider economic recovery, although the article does not provide further details.

site_title: Citi Private Banking appoints Steven Lo as successor to retiring Asia head
summary: Citi Private Banking appoints Steven Lo as its new Asia head, succeeding Bassam Salem's retirement in February 2018. Lo, based in Hong Kong, has 26 years of experience in private banking, covering clients in North America, Asia, and other regions. He previously held roles as Global Market Manager in Thailand and Hong Kong, and will report jointly to Citi's Global Head and CEO of Citi Asia Pacific. Lo will assume his new responsibilities on February 1, 2018, with a seamless transition planned over the next few months.

site_title: ECB is said to see option for ending QE with short taper in 2018
summary: European Central Bank policymakers implicitly assume their bond-buying program will be tapered to a halt by the end of 2018 if inflation improves, according to officials. The program, which has been extended, will cut monthly bond buying in half to 30 billion euros starting in September. A "large majority" of governors backed the decision to include a pledge to extend the program if needed, with a 12-month tapering scenario being considered a realistic option.

site_title: Brexit batters Ford Europe as tumult sidelines UK car buyers
summary: Ford Motor reported a surprise loss of $86 million in Europe during the September quarter, attributed to Brexit's impact on the UK market. British buyers are pulling back, with industrywide car sales sliding for six consecutive months. The company estimates Brexit costs around $1.08 billion annually and is seeking clarity on EU talks by year-end. Ford is pushing for a two-year transition period to maintain current trading conditions. The automaker operates two engine plants and one transmission factory in the UK, where Brexit is affecting its most profitable market.

site_title: Gaming firm Razer to launch up to US$550m HK IPO on Monday: IFR
summary: Razer Inc, a gaming hardware maker backed by Intel and Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, plans to launch a US$550 million Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) on Monday, according to IFR. The company will offer shares in an indicative range of HK$2.93 to HK$4.00 each.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit new highs on signs of thawing China ties
summary: South Korean shares hit a new all-time high as signs of thawing China ties boosted market sentiment. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed up 0.6% at 2,496.63 points, driven by a Chinese tour company's consideration to resume sales of individual tours to South Korea. This move lifted Hotel Lotte shares by 30%. The benchmark index marked its sixth positive week, while the South Korean won slumped against the US dollar due to the European Central Bank's dovish stance.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse cuts profit target; CEO Kengeter quitting
summary: Deutsche Boerse CEO Carsten Kengeter is resigning amid growing shareholder pressure following an insider-trading probe. The company also cut its full-year earnings targets due to uncertainty from the probe. Kengeter will step down on December 31, allowing the company to focus on clients and growth. The board accepted his resignation, citing the need to avoid further burdens from the investigation. The company's shares rose 0.6% after the announcement, despite the negative impact on earnings forecasts.

site_title: Asian markets rise as US dollar gains
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, driven by a stronger US dollar and investor optimism over President Donald Trump's tax cuts. The US dollar surged, boosting Eurozone stocks and the yen's weakness against the US dollar, making Japanese exporters more competitive. Tokyo rose 0.9%, while Hong Kong and Seoul gained 1% and 0.5% respectively. The European Central Bank announced it would cut back its monetary stimulus program, further fueling the gains.

site_title: Fed candidate Taylor calls for reforms that echo Trump agenda
summary: Federal Reserve candidate John Taylor called for reforms to encourage investment and hiring, echoing President Donald Trump's agenda. Taylor, a Stanford professor, suggested faster US economic growth is possible with policies that focus on incentives, tax rates, and regulation. His remarks were seen as favorable to the White House, with Trump expected to announce his Fed nominee soon. Taylor's economic growth projections, which compare to pre-financial crisis rates, could lead to a potential overhaul of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act.

site_title: En bloc sale sites could add about 9,300 homes to supply: URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has estimated that the redevelopment of en bloc sale sites could add approximately 9,300 new private housing units to Singapore's supply pipeline by 2018. This figure is based on the land areas of the en bloc sale sites and allowable plot ratios under Master Plan 2014. The number of units proposed by developers will be subject to detailed evaluation to determine feasibility.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.20 points to 1741.34. Gainers outnumbered losers 153 to 59, and volume reached 128.1 million lots worth RM36.2 million.

site_title: Nissan said to have conducted unauthorised checks since '79
summary: Nissan has been conducting unauthorized vehicle inspections since at least 1979, according to a person familiar with the situation. The company has commissioned an external investigation team to investigate the issue and suggest measures to prevent recurrence. The inspection scandal, which led to a recall of 1.2 million vehicles and a temporary shutdown of production, has widened after Subaru was found to have allowed uncertified workers to inspect vehicles. Nissan's CEO, Hiroto Saikawa, has promised to investigate the matter and reconfigure the inspection process to add additional final inspectors.

site_title: China's Sept industrial profits surge most in nearly six years
summary: China's industrial profits surged 27.7% in September, the largest increase in nearly six years, driven by a government crackdown on air pollution and rising prices of finished goods like steel and copper. This sustained growth gives policymakers more room to restructure state-owned enterprises, which dominate the industrial landscape and account for a significant portion of corporate debt. The strong earnings growth will help China's policymakers address the country's corporate debt issues.

site_title: Singapore economy on path to recovery, steady growth in 2018: MAS
summary: Singapore's economy is on a path to recovery, with steady growth expected in 2018, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Growth rates accelerated over two straight quarters, driven by sustained global electronics demand. Official forecasts predict 2-3% economic growth this year, with the upper half of this range expected. The MAS noted a broadening of the recovery across industries, with trade-related sectors leading the way, and some segments, such as finance and retail, expected to benefit from the improving business climate.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOB Kay Hian upgrades ST Engineering to 'buy' with S$3.80 target
summary: UOB Kay Hian has upgraded ST Engineering to a "buy" rating with a target price of S$3.80, expecting a 50% increase in third-quarter net profit. Analyst K Ajith cites potential positives, including enhanced capabilities and US defence ship repair work, despite known negatives being reflected in the stock price. The upgrade follows a decline in the stock price after the company's second-quarter results and guidance on second-half profit.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on signs of thawing China ties
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.6% on Friday, driven by signs of easing tensions with China, which had banned unofficial tours to the country. Hotel Lotte shares surged 30% after Chinese tour company Ctrip considered resuming sales. Cosmetic companies, which rely heavily on China, also gained. Analysts expect the Kospi index to extend gains or pare losses after third-quarter earnings are released later in the day. The South Korean won slumped against the US dollar following the European Central Bank's dovish policy move.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI gains 0.31% to 3,366.63
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.31% to 3,366.63 on Friday, driven by gains in United Overseas Bank and OCBC Bank. The STI has notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, US stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The global market outlook remains positive, with investors brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Harvey Weinstein sues for emails he says may exonerate him
summary: Harvey Weinstein sued the Weinstein Co, the film studio he co-founded, to force it to turn over personnel records and emails that may exonerate him from allegations of sexual harassment and rape. Weinstein, 65, claims his email account contains information that could help the company defend against claims filed against it. He also seeks to investigate whether his younger brother, Robert, was wrongfully accused of misconduct. Weinstein holds the largest individual stake in the studio and stands to lose interest if the company pays out unjustified settlements or sells itself for less due to unsubstantiated allegations.

site_title: China's focus on quality of growth to be positive for its ratings: Moody's
summary: China is shifting its focus from rapid GDP growth to high-quality, long-term growth, which is expected to boost productivity and reduce financial vulnerability, according to Moody's Investors Service. The country aims to double its per capita income by 2020, but will prioritize quality over pace. This change in focus is expected to lead to more policy space for economic reform and rebalancing, with Moody's citing a stronger policy focus on financial regulation and greater coordination of monetary policy as credit-positive for China's banking sector.

site_title: Singaporeans ready to work for longer as 70 becomes the new 60
summary: Singaporeans are more likely to work past traditional retirement ages, with 70 becoming the new 60, according to a survey by the Singapore Management University's Centre for Research on the Economics of Ageing. Men aged 55-59 expect to work full-time past 65 and 70, while women anticipate working past 62, 65, and 70. The findings could ease pressure on policymakers to financially support a rapidly-aging population. The survey, which has an active sample of 12,000 Singaporeans, shows that those with lower education and wealth are more likely to expect to work longer.

site_title: Japan inflation ticks up in September but way off BOJ target
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 0.7% in September, the ninth consecutive month, but remained below the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target. Excluding volatile food and energy prices, inflation edged up 0.2%. The weak inflation is in contrast to other major economies, which are tightening monetary policies. Japan's economy has shown signs of improvement, with a 0.6% expansion in the April-June period, but wage hikes have been slow and efforts to lift inflation have been unsuccessful. Experts expect inflation to remain low, with some predicting a 0.5% rate in coming months.

site_title: Office rents rise 2.4% in Q3 on higher space absorption
summary: Office rents in Singapore rose 2.4% in Q3 2017, driven by a 10,000 sq m increase in occupied space, while prices rose 0.4%. The total office space supply increased by 91,000 sq m, resulting in a 13.3% vacancy rate, up from 12.4% in the previous quarter.

site_title: Indofood Agri Q3 profit drops 37% on fertilisers and forex
summary: Indofood Agri Resources reported a 37% drop in Q3 profit to 100.5 billion rupiah (S$10 million), due to higher fertiliser application and operating expenses. Revenue rose 5% to 3.72 trillion rupiah, driven by recovered palm oil output. The group's net profit per share fell to 72 rupiah, down from 114 rupiah a year ago. Higher costs, including fertiliser application, outweighed revenue growth, resulting in the decline in profit.

site_title: China's yuan weakens on US dollar strength, set for 2nd weekly loss
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar on Friday, marking its second straight weekly loss, after the People's Bank of China lowered its official midpoint by the most in five weeks. The US dollar rose, while the euro fell to three-month lows. The global dollar index increased to 94.774, with the onshore yuan opening at 6.6555 per US dollar and weakening to 6.6645 per US dollar. The yuan's recent trade was driven by market forces, with the central bank having "basically exited" from its regular yuan intervention.

site_title: HDB resale flat transactions fell 3.2% in Q3
summary: HDB resale flat transactions fell 3.2% in Q3, with 5,808 cases, down from 6,001 in the second quarter. Resale prices dropped 0.7% and have been on a gradual decline since 2013. The number of approved subletting cases fell 2.1%. HDB will offer 4,800 Build-to-Order flats in November, bringing the total BTO supply to 17,500 units.

site_title: Cloud computing drives massive growth for big US tech firms
summary: Big US tech firms, including Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet's Google, and Intel, are seeing massive growth in the cloud computing market. The shift away from company-owned data centers to the cloud is driving strong quarterly earnings for these companies, with Microsoft's Azure business nearly doubling in year-over-year growth. Cloud computing market estimates indicate a 43% increase to $14.4 billion in the third quarter of 2017, with Amazon holding 31.8% of the market share. Analysts predict continued growth, but also note that competition may slow down the market in the future.

site_title: Q3 private home prices rise 0.7%; beats flash estimate, confirms first gain in 4 years
summary: Singapore's Benchmark private residential property price index rose 0.7% in Q3 2017, beating the flash estimate of 0.5% and marking the first gain in 4 years. This comes after 15 consecutive quarterly declines since the peak in Q3 2013. The index showed a 0.1% decrease in Q2 2017.

images.alt_text: The rise in the index for Q3 2017 comes after 15 consecutive quarterly declines since the peak in Q3 2013.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as US tax-cut hopes rise
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, October 27, 2017, driven by hopes for US President Donald Trump's tax cut. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.59% and the Topix index rose 0.44% as the yen fell against the US dollar. This upward trend was attributed to exporters and banks, suggesting a positive outlook for the market despite ongoing US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Viva Q3 DPS grows 5% as portfolio occupancy improves to 90.9%
summary: Viva Industrial Trust reported a 5% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.900 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by 18.3% growth in net property income to S$20.6 million. Gross revenue rose 16.8% to S$28.3 million, with portfolio occupancy reaching 90.9% as of end-September, up from 88.6% last year.

site_title: Malaysia budget-day guide: It's all about the upcoming election
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is set to unveil his budget on Friday, focusing on economic growth and rising oil prices to boost tax revenue and cash handouts. The budget deficit is expected to be slightly lower than this year's 3% of GDP. Analysts predict a populist tone, addressing issues such as the cost of living and affordable housing. The election, which must be held by August next year, is expected to be a key factor in Najib's budget announcement, with investors closely watching for clues on the election timing.

site_title: UBS Q3 net profit jumps 14%, keeps cautious outlook
summary: UBS, the world's largest private bank, reported a 14% year-on-year jump in third-quarter net profit to 946 million Swiss francs. Despite a cautious outlook due to political and monetary policy uncertainty, the bank's adjusted pre-tax operating profit rose 9% in its Wealth Management division. UBS also reported a 39% increase in group pre-tax income and a 13.7% common equity tier one capital ratio. The bank aims to achieve its 2.1 billion franc cost-cutting target by end-2017.

site_title: Australian, NZ dollars set for second losing week as politics rules
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are set for their second losing week due to the country's government losing its one-seat majority in the lower house. The Australian dollar fell to a 3-1/2 month trough of US$0.7623 after Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce was ruled ineligible to remain in parliament. The New Zealand dollar also sank to a new five-month trough of US$0.6818 after the left-leaning Labour Party won control of government. Investors expect the Australian government to regain its majority if Joyce wins a by-election, but currently see limited impact on the currency.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Sheng Siong, CDL Hospitality Trusts, Indofood, Yoma
summary: Singapore Exchange CEO is still in the running to list Aramco shares, a potential world's biggest IPO. Sheng Siong Group reported a 25.3% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$19.6 million. CDL Hospitality Trusts saw a 3% dip in distribution per stapled security. Indofood Agri Resources posted a 36.8% fall in net profit to S$10 million. Yoma Strategic Holdings' net profit fell 56.8% to S$3.7 million, driven by higher minority interests and foreign currency fluctuations.

site_title: New Saudi mega-city will be listed publicly, crown prince says
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to list its $500 billion mega-city, NEOM, on financial markets alongside oil giant Aramco, aiming to diversify the economy and create jobs. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman envisions NEOM as the world's first capitalist city, offering a liberal lifestyle and attracting investments in renewable energy, biotechnology, and entertainment. The city, located near the Red Sea and Suez Canal, will be owned by Saudi Arabia's sovereign Public Investment Fund until its listing, with a planned valuation of over $2 trillion. The listing is part of the crown prince's ambitious Vision 2030 plan to overhaul the economy.

site_title: China cuts minimum purchase price for wheat for first time in over a decade
summary: China, the world's top wheat producer, has cut its minimum purchase price for wheat to 2,300 yuan (S$474) per tonne for 2018, the first such move in over a decade. The price reduction is aimed at reducing state stockpiles and aligning domestic prices with international market prices. The move could ease tensions with the US over Beijing's subsidies, which Washington claims break international trade rules. The cut is not expected to immediately impact the market, with most winter wheat already planted, and is seen as a step towards bringing domestic prices more in line with the international market.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q3 DPU slips 2.1% on enlarged unit base, but property income improves
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 2.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q3 2017, despite a larger unit base, due to the conversion of S$166.5 million in debt into equity. Net property income rose 11.6% to S$63.9 million, driven by contributions from 177 Pacific Highway and Suntec Singapore. The decline in DPU was primarily attributed to the enlarged unit base, rather than a decrease in property income.

site_title: Rare China soverign bond sees robust global demand, tight pricing
summary: China issued $21 billion in global sovereign bonds, priced at 15-25 basis points over US Treasuries, drawing orders 10 times the offer size. The five-year bond priced at 15bps, while the 10-year bond priced at 25bps. The bonds, unrated, attracted strong demand despite S&P and Moody's downgrading China's credit rating this year. The unsatiable demand spilled over into the credit default swaps market, with the five-year CDS for China dropping to 45.5bps from 49bps.

site_title: CDLHT's Q3 DPS dips 3% on rights issue, but property income grows
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 3% dip in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.29 Singapore cents in Q3 2017, despite a 12.3% increase in net property income (NPI) to S$40.4 million, driven by strong performance from The Lowry Hotel and Pullman Hotel Munich. The rights issue completed in August negatively impacted DPS. Excluding the rights issue, NPI would have increased 12.3% from the year-ago quarter.

site_title: Yoma Q2 profit drops 56.8% on higher minority interests, lower fair-value gains
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings' Q2 profit dropped 56.8% to S$3.7 million, primarily due to higher minority interests and lower fair-value gains. Revenue rose 32.9% to S$33.1 million, driven by sales of New Holland tractors and KFC restaurants. However, other income declined 53.5% and non-controlling interests increased, reducing the amount attributable to shareholders. The company expects rental demand for serviced apartments to remain healthy and delivery of tractors to contribute S$4 million in revenue in the third quarter.

site_title: KLW warns of Q2 net loss as sales, margins shrank in door business
summary: KLW Holdings, a Singapore-based door maker, expects to report a net loss for its second fiscal quarter ended September 30 due to declining revenue and profit margins in its core business. The company is finalizing its results, with a financial performance announcement expected on or before November 14. KLW's shares closed flat at 0.8 Singapore cents on Thursday, and the company's core business has seen a significant decline.

site_title: Broker's Take: DBS sees no Amazon Prime pain on Sheng Siong
summary: DBS Group Research maintains its buy rating on Sheng Siong Group, citing a record high pre-tax margin of 9% driven by strong gross margins and modest operating expense growth. Despite the opening of Amazon Prime, Sheng Siong's margins and sales parameters grew stronger year-over-year. The research firm trimmed its target price to S$1.19 from S$1.20, but remains optimistic on the stock.

site_title: Flash: URA private home price index up 0.7 % q-o-q in Q3, rental index flat
summary: Singapore's URA private home price index rose 0.7% quarter-over-quarter in Q3, while the rental index remained flat. Condo launches in Q3 will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates increased after five consecutive weeks of declines. Manhattan rents reached a record, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at a post-bankruptcy location.

site_title: Retail slump continues in Q3 as rents ease 0.2%, prices slip 0.9%
summary: Retail space rentals in Singapore declined 0.2% in Q3 2017, compared to a 1.2% drop in the previous quarter. Occupied retail space increased by 15,000 sqm, while the total supply rose by 22,000 sqm. Vacancy rates rose to 8.2% from 8.1%. Retail space prices dropped 0.9%, contrasting the 3.2% decline in the previous quarter. The pipeline supply of retail space stood at 556,000 sqm, up from 576,000 sqm in the previous quarter.

site_title: Singapore exchange chief bullish on bourse's Aramco IPO chances
summary: Singapore Exchange CEO Loh Boon Chye expressed confidence in his bourse's chances of hosting Aramco's upcoming IPO, stating they "stand as good a chance as any others."
