At least six exchanges, including Singapore, are vying for the listing, with Saudi Arabia aiming for exclusive rights. The IPO, valued at up to $2 trillion, is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's economic plan to diversify the kingdom's economy. Singapore's exchange has received interest from companies due to its rules allowing dual-class shares for secondary listings.

site_title: Mattel plunges after slump deepens, leaving new CEO scrambling
summary: Mattel Inc. plummeted 28% after reporting a sharp 13% sales decline, with North America being the hardest hit, falling 22% due to the Toys "R" Us bankruptcy. The company's new CEO, Margo Georgiadis, vowed to increase cost-cutting measures threefold, suspend dividends, and invest in digital content and learning products. The company's net loss was $1.75 per share, and revenue fell to $1.56 billion. Georgiadis aims to simplify the business, reduce expenses by $650 million, and reach mid- to high-single-digit sales growth.

site_title: Gold touches nearly three-week low as ECB plan lifts dollar
summary: Gold fell to a nearly three-week low on Thursday, touching $1,266.27 an ounce, after the European Central Bank extended its bond-buying program and cut back on purchases, lifting the dollar and making dollar-priced gold more expensive for non-US investors. The decision also boosted stocks and other assets, while speculation of a potential policy hawk at the US Federal Reserve further pressured gold prices.

site_title: GLP's independent adviser finds privatisation bid 'fair and reasonable'
summary: Global Logistic Properties' (GLP) independent adviser has deemed the proposed privatisation 'fair and reasonable', recommending a scheme of arrangement meeting on November 30. Evercore Asia, appointed after a review, concluded the S$3.38 per share offer is a premium over historical prices and a sum-of-the-parts valuation. GLP's independent directors accept the recommendation, urging shareholders to approve the scheme. The privatisation bid is backed by Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, which holds a 36.84% stake in GLP.

site_title: Hong Kong's iconic trading floor is the latest to close for good
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd (HKEX) is closing its iconic trading floor, 31 years after it opened, amid the rise of electronic trading. The last remaining trading floor in Hong Kong, the space will be replaced with a conference center and history section after a renovation. The closure marks the end of an era for the industry, with floor transactions comprising just 0.2% of total turnover in 2014. The shift away from humans may accelerate, with HKEX considering reducing the city's stamp duty to attract more algorithmic and high-frequency traders.

site_title: Boeing's cash surges as 737 Max fuels record jet deliveries
summary: Boeing reported record-breaking jet deliveries in the third quarter, with 202 jetliners shipped, fueled by the successful 737 Max production. The company's cash flow surged to $3 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. Boeing's commercial aircraft division saw a decline in sales, while the new Boeing Global Services division reported a 2% increase in sales. The company's shares have skyrocketed 71% this year, making Boeing a Wall Street darling.

site_title: US dollar stands tall as ECB sends euro to 3-month lows
summary: The European Central Bank extended its bond buying program by nine months to September 2018 and reduced the chances of a 2018 interest rate hike, sending the euro to three-month lows. The US dollar, meanwhile, stood tall, gaining 0.2% against a basket of major rivals and on track for a weekly gain of 1.1%. The ECB's decision also pushed potential rate hikes to 2019, according to analysts. The US dollar's gains were also fueled by the US House of Representatives' vote to clear a path for a Republican tax bill.

site_title: Euro plunges as ECB decides to extend bond buying
summary: The euro plummeted to its worst day against the US dollar in 16 months after the European Central Bank extended its bond purchases for nine months to September 2018, reducing the likelihood of interest rate hikes next year. The ECB also announced it will start paring monthly purchases by half to 30 billion euros starting in January. The decision was seen as dovish, causing the euro to fall 1.4% against the US dollar. The euro was also down 1.2% against the Japanese yen.

site_title: Amazon shares soar as earnings top expectations
summary: Amazon reported strong third-quarter earnings, with profit of $256 million and revenue jumping 34% to $43.7 billion. The company's digital assistant Alexa saw significant growth, and Whole Foods, acquired this year, provided $1.3 billion in revenue. Amazon shares rose nearly 8% to $1,050 in after-hours trade, driven by the strong results. The company expects revenue growth of 28-38% in the fourth quarter. Analysts praise Amazon's expansion into new sectors and markets, calling it "stellar" and "in very good shape."

site_title: Trump delays release of some 'sensitive' Kennedy assassination files
summary: US President Donald Trump has approved the release of thousands of records about the JFK assassination, but delayed the publication of some "sensitive" files at the request of the CIA, FBI, and other agencies. The National Archives will release 2,800 records, but some documents related to national security or informants' identities will remain classified for six months. Scholars believe the released documents will not contain bombshell revelations, as the Warren Commission previously concluded Lee Harvey Oswald acted alone in the assassination.

site_title: If you're as hungry as a wolf...
summary: Wolfgang's Steakhouse, a new restaurant in Singapore, is drawing crowds with its carnivorous offerings. Located at Robertson Quay, the restaurant is open daily from 11:30am to 11:30pm. The article does not provide further details on the menu or reviews.

site_title: Oil little changed as Saudi comments offset US output, exports
summary: Oil prices remained little changed on Thursday, with Brent futures up 13 cents to $58.57 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 15 cents to $52.33 a barrel. Saudi Arabia's comments on ending a global supply glut and ongoing Middle East tensions supported prices, while rising US crude inventories and exports offset gains. Global demand continues to rise, with Southeast Asia's net crude oil imports expected to more than double by 2040.

site_title: Europe: ECB, Spain boost Stoxx as earnings trigger sharp moves
summary: European shares rose 1.1% on Thursday, boosted by the European Central Bank's decision to keep stimulus taps open and hopes of a breakthrough in the Catalan crisis. The Stoxx 600 benchmark index reached a four-week high, with Germany's DAX touching an all-time closing high. Individual stocks were also affected, with Nokia falling 17.5% and Barclays losing 7.4%. Despite some losses, the overall market was lifted by strong economic growth and earnings expectations.

site_title: Cisco, Google join hands in cloud computing
summary: Cisco and Google have joined forces to help companies manage software and technology services that run in their own data centres or external cloud services. The partnership aims to close security gaps and provide a hybrid cloud solution, allowing companies to deploy computing resources more quickly and flexibly. The collaboration follows growing pressure on big tech companies from cloud computing, with Google seeking to catch up to market leader Amazon and Cisco facing stiff competition from cloud services.

site_title: Another star showing by electronics likely to upgrade Q3 GDP growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed strong growth in September, with a 14.6% increase in factory production compared to the same period last year. The electronics cluster drove this growth, with a 33.2% expansion, and is now expected to upgrade the country's Q3 GDP growth forecast to between 4.7% and 5.1%. This is likely to lead to a potential full-year GDP growth of 3% or higher, surpassing the government's 2-3% forecast range.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly rise as tax cut gains in Congress
summary: US stocks rose 0.3% to 23,400.86, driven by solid earnings and congressional progress on President Trump's tax cut. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 0.1% each, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.1%. Health and pharma shares declined, with companies like Celgene and Cardinal Health plummeting after Trump's opioid crackdown warnings. The House approved a budget resolution for a $1.5 trillion tax cut, paving the way for tax reform.

site_title: MBS Q3 results lifted by VIP segment
summary: Marina Bay Sands' parent company, Las Vegas Sands, reported a 13% year-on-year increase in ebitda to US$442 million in Q3 2017, driven by higher contributions from the VIP segment and cost control. Revenue rose 4.1% to US$793 million, with casino revenue up 6.3% and hotel occupancy down 1.7 percentage points. The company's net income increased 13% to US$685 million. Las Vegas Sands plans to invest US$1.1 billion in Macau renovations to ride the gaming recovery.

site_title: China will not set target to double GDP from 2021
summary: China's top leaders have pledged to focus on better quality economic growth in the long term, rather than setting a target to double GDP from 2021. Vice Minister Yang Weimin stated that the government will emphasize quality over expansion, allowing policymakers to pursue structural reforms. This shift marks a departure from past practice and could give Beijing more room to address debt and growth concerns. China is on track to meet its 2020 GDP doubling goal, but faces environmental and debt constraints.

site_title: Nordea Bank to cut more than 6,000 jobs amid backlash over moving its HQ
summary: Nordea Bank AB will cut at least 6,000 jobs, including 2,000 consultants, amid struggles to stay competitive in the Nordic region. The bank will incur a transformation cost of up to 150 million euros and report these costs as running expenses over the next four years. The cuts reflect the shift towards digital services, a trend seen across the banking industry. The bank's headquarters is set to move from Stockholm to Helsinki, sparking a backlash from Swedish clients.

site_title: Amazon's latest way into your life is through the front door
summary: Amazon has launched a new service called Amazon Key, allowing customers to grant permission for couriers to unlock their doors and deliver packages inside when no one is home. The service requires a smart lock and security camera, and is available to Prime members starting November 8. Amazon aims to address the issue of package theft, which is estimated to be substantial, and provide customers with an added layer of security and assurance. However, concerns have been raised about the trust and security implications of allowing strangers into homes.

site_title: Importance of, well, being in BT Weekend
summary: A health-conscious trend is emerging, with wellness businesses becoming sustainable ventures. Meanwhile, co-working spaces are being offered in buildings to attract creative professionals. Grief is explored in a magazine article, suggesting that embracing it can lead to better living and working. The Tokyo Motor Show showcases cars with artificial intelligence designed to form emotional bonds with drivers. Other lifestyle topics include mod-Indian cuisine, zero-waste living, and financial literacy for women. These stories highlight various aspects of personal and professional development, highlighting the importance of embracing change and innovation.

site_title: China begins sale of first sovereign dollar bond since 2004
summary: China has begun marketing its first sovereign dollar bonds since 2004, offering $1 billion of five-year and 10-year notes at a spread of 30-40 basis points over Treasuries and a premium of 40-50 basis points respectively. The sale comes after the twice-a-decade Communist Party congress where President Xi Jinping cemented his status as China's strongest leader. The issuance aims to establish a benchmark for pricing foreign currency bonds from China, despite S&P Global Ratings and Moody's Investors Service cutting China's sovereign rating due to soaring debt and increased economic risks.

site_title: PSA to cut about 400 jobs at Vauxhall's Ellesmere Port
summary: PSA to cut approximately 400 jobs at Vauxhall's Ellesmere Port in Britain by the end of the year to improve the facility's competitiveness. The job cuts, which account for about a quarter of the facility's staff, will be carried out through a voluntary redundancy plan. The move aims to address the facility's high manufacturing costs, which are significantly higher than those of benchmark plants in France. The decision comes as PSA seeks to protect its future and considers future investments once Britain's future trading relationship with the EU is clarified.

site_title: What emboldened GuocoLand in Beach Rd bid
summary: GuocoLand won a Beach Road commercial site with a bid of S$1.622 billion, setting a new benchmark price of S$1,706.30 per square foot per plot ratio. This surpasses IOI Properties' S$1,689 psf ppr paid for a Central Boulevard site last year. Analysts see this as bullish, given the similar tender conditions and the site's 99-year leasehold tenure. The winning bid has set a new benchmark price for Government Land Sale sites in Singapore.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported Q1 FY18 net profit of S$91 million, a 9% year-over-year increase. Revenue rose 7% and operating expenses increased 5%. The trust Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported decent Q4 FY17 results, with gross revenue and net property income growing 8.1% and 10% year-over-year, respectively. The trust's full-year performance is expected to deliver another record distribution per unit, with a distribution yield of 5.5%.

site_title: US cannot disengage itself from Asia: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the US cannot disengage from Asia, citing the region's need for peace and stability. He emphasized America's role in the global balance of power and the importance of accommodating China's growing influence in a stable manner. Lee's comments come as the US navigates its strategic landscape, and the implications of its actions will affect the international order.

site_title: Big tech's rivals seize chance to even the score
summary: US lawmakers are pushing for regulations on big tech companies, following Russia's alleged use of Google, Facebook, and Twitter in the 2016 presidential election. Rivals such as Yelp, media organizations, and companies like Disney, Oracle, and 21st Century Fox are filing complaints and endorsing legislation to hold the tech giants accountable. However, the companies are deploying large lobbying armies and increasing spending to influence lawmakers, making it a daunting task for critics. For the first time in years, criticism of Silicon Valley is gaining a receptive audience.

site_title: Scientists score breakthrough in fixing genetic defects, mutations
summary: Scientists have developed programmable molecular machines that can repair genetic defects and mutations, offering a breakthrough in fixing debilitating diseases such as genetic blindness, sickle-cell anaemia, and cystic fibrosis. The new technologies expand the reach and precision of gene-editing, providing a path to treating thousands of genetic disorders.

site_title: Microsoft tops forecasts with 16% profit growth
summary: Microsoft delivered stronger-than-expected earnings for its first fiscal quarter, with a 16% profit growth to $6.6 billion. Revenue rose 12% to $24.5 billion, driven by gains in cloud computing and enterprise services. The company's cloud technologies operations now accounts for $20 billion annually, and 96% of Fortune 500 companies have at least one of its cloud offerings. Microsoft's shares jumped 3.2% after-hours, with the company's "productivity and business process" unit seeing sharp growth of 28% and its "intelligent cloud" unit experiencing a 14% increase in revenues.

site_title: French ingredient maker Roquette opens R&D hub, Asia HQ in S'pore
summary: French plant-based ingredients maker Roquette has opened a regional headquarters and research centre in Singapore, aiming to boost its Asian growth. The 1,100 sqm innovation centre at Biopolis will facilitate partnerships with customers, universities, and research institutions, such as A*star and the National University of Singapore. This move marks Roquette's increased focus on the Asian market, following the opening of its Asia HQ in Singapore.

site_title: US jobless claims rise modestly as labour market tightens
summary: US jobless claims rose 10,000 to 233,000 in the week ended Oct 21, slightly above forecast, but still within the tight labor market. The four-week moving average fell 9,000 to 239,500, suggesting a sharp rebound in job growth in October. The labor market continues to show signs of improvement, with the number of people receiving benefits declining to 1.90 million, the lowest level since December 1973. The widening goods trade deficit and declining retail inventories also raised concerns about the economy's growth, but the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in December due to the strong labor market.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q3 profit rises 25% to S$19.6m
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 25.3% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$19.6 million, driven by revenue growth of 4.2% to S$210.9 million. The supermarket chain attributed the increase to new stores and comparable same-store sales. However, revenue at the Woodlands store declined, and the group expects competition to remain keen in the industry. The company is also expanding into new markets, including China, and expects to begin operations at a new outlet in Kunming before the end of FY2017.

site_title: Asia billionaire pool surpasses US; region's income gap not expected to widen
summary: Asia has surpassed the US in the number of billionaires, with a 23% increase in Asia's billionaire population to 637 in 2016, compared to a 5% rise in the US to 563. Despite this, the US still holds the largest amount of billionaire wealth. The region's income gap is not expected to widen due to the trickle-down effect of wealth, with all segments growing at the same rate. Asia's wealth is expected to surpass the US in the next four years, driven by technological innovation and financial services.

site_title: STI up 0.4% ahead of ECB policy meeting
summary: The Singapore stock market rose 0.4% to 3,356.25, driven by a strong Q3 earnings report from OCBC and expectations of clarity on the European Central Bank's (ECB) tapering plan. The Straits Times Index gained 12.37 points, with 1.8 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion traded. Despite regional peers showing mixed results, Singapore's factory production for September beat expectations, leading economists to revise their GDP growth forecast upwards.

site_title: Going after dealers and abusers dooms war against drugs to failure
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte and Indonesian President Joko Widodo have authorized shoot-on-sight policies against alleged drug dealers, with over 10,000 individuals killed. This approach is widely criticized, as it fails to address the root causes of drug addiction and instead fuels a cycle of violence. Experts argue that a more effective strategy is to engage people with ideals and purpose, reducing the appeal of drugs. The policies have garnered public sympathy for dealers and users, and critics warn that they will do little to curb drug trade.

site_title: When the Poop! hits the fan
summary: The Finger Players' revival of "Poop!" tackles death, suicide, and illness with quirky humor and gentle grace. The black light theatre piece features fluorescent costumes, puppetry, and a floating head, but also explores the emotional toll on family members. After a family man's suicide, his wife, mother, and young daughter struggle with grief, each handling it differently. The play shines a light on the complexities of grief and the importance of human connection in coping with loss.

site_title: Here's why you should book your hotel before confirming your flight
summary: Hopper, an airfare-tracking app, has launched a new feature to track hotel prices and forecast potential rate changes. The app claims to save users an average of US$270 per week-long trip or up to US$720 over eight nights. This feature, initially available in New York City, aims to help users book hotels before flights, potentially leading to deeper savings. Expansion plans are set for early 2018, with the app using regression data to inform its predictions.

site_title: Indian bank rescue may lure foreign equity investors
summary: India's US$32 billion rescue plan for state-owned banks may boost foreign equity investors' confidence, potentially reversing recent net sales of US$1 billion of Indian stocks. The plan, coupled with a US$106 billion road spending program, aims to spur borrowing and kickstart growth. Overseas investors bought a net 36 billion rupees of shares on Wednesday, the biggest single-day inflow since June 13. Analysts predict a 5 percentage point improvement in gross domestic product and bullish equities. However, some concerns remain about the rescue's effectiveness and repayment mechanism.

site_title: Crystal Tower up for en bloc sale at S$138m
summary: Crystal Tower, a 28-unit freehold residential site in Singapore's District 10, is up for en bloc sale at S$138 million. The site can be redeveloped into an upscale boutique project with 130 units, given its prime location near the Orchard Road shopping belt and lifestyle destinations. Consultants estimate the breakeven price at S$1,900 to S$2,050 psf, with a tender closing on November 28.

site_title: Walking on sunshine not easy, energy sector learns
summary: The Singapore International Energy Week (SIEW) highlighted the growing importance of grid management and energy storage as the world shifts towards renewable energy sources. Renewable energy's intermittent nature remains a challenge, and mastering its management is crucial for widespread adoption. Key takeaways from the event include the need for better grid management and energy storage solutions to ensure a stable energy supply. This underscores the sector's focus on overcoming the challenges of integrating renewable energy into the grid.

site_title: Important for Singapore to sustain good ties with US: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of maintaining good ties with the US during his six-day official visit. He stated that US companies and investments in Singapore generate tens of thousands of jobs and that the US understands its crucial role in Asia's economy, security, and other areas. Lee highlighted the strong US-Singapore economic ties, noting that Singapore Airlines' deal with Boeing will sustain over 70,000 US jobs, and encouraged the US to remain engaged in the region.

site_title: Euro falls as ECB curbs bond-buying
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced it will extend its bond purchases at a reduced rate, cutting asset purchases to 30 billion euros from 60 billion euros starting January, while also extending the scheme by nine months to September. The euro fell 0.6% to US$1.1740, while the dollar rose 0.4% against a basket of currencies. The move is seen as a gradual approach to monetary policy, with ECB chief Mario Draghi stressing that short-term rates will not rise before purchases are stopped.

site_title: Draghi calls for caution as flagship stimulus heads to exit
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi has warned that the bank will remain cautious as it exits its signature stimulus measure, which began six years ago to prevent the euro area from breaking up and staving off deflation. The ECB plans to dial down bond buying from January, marking a new phase in its efforts to balance growth and inflation. Draghi emphasized the need for caution as the eurozone navigates this transition, which comes after unprecedented actions to stabilize the region's economy. The move is seen as a significant shift in the bank's policy stance.

site_title: Green shoots for rent at some industrial segments
summary: Singapore's industrial rents continued to decline, falling 1.1% in Q3, marking the 10th consecutive quarter of decline. However, new demand for industrial space rebounded by 51.5% from the same period last year, driven by strong manufacturing and trade activities. Key sectors such as single-user and multi-user factory spaces saw increased take-up, while business parks bucked the trend with a 0.3% rent increase. Consultants predict that rentals will remain under downward pressure for the rest of 2017, with a full-year decline expected to be less than 4%.

site_title: Crimean winemakers' dream sours after Russian annexation
summary: Crimean winemakers are struggling to establish a center for boutique vineyards after Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014. The region's wine industry was previously ignored, but pioneers like Pavel Shvets aim to create a distinctive appellation. However, Western sanctions and Russia's limited wine consumption hinder progress. Shvets believes Sevastopol has time and terroir to develop, but the lack of mainstream Russian bank support and high interest rates pose significant challenges. Currently, there are fewer than 30 boutique wineries in the region, and most are still experimenting with grape varieties.

site_title: A hero who is out of this world
summary: Thor: Ragnarok, the third installment in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, offers decent entertainment with a fresh comic tone. The film, directed by Taika Waititi, features plenty of action and wisecracks, with Chris Hemsworth reprising his role as Thor. The star-studded cast, including Tom Hiddleston, Cate Blanchett, and Jeff Goldblum, delivers solid performances. The movie follows Thor's battle against his demonic arch enemy Sutrur, and his sister Hela's return to wreak havoc on Asgard. The film's lighthearted and humorous tone sets it apart from previous Thor movies, making it an enjoyable watch.

site_title: Multitasking is a myth - it makes people more inefficient
summary: Multitasking is a myth, making people more inefficient, according to research. Constant busyness leads to mental exhaustion, hindering creativity and innovation. The brain doesn't process tasks simultaneously, but rather sequentially, wasting time. Productivity is not linear, and fatigue sets in with longer hours. Companies can improve focus and productivity by reducing distractions, such as email and meeting time, and implementing policies that promote employee well-being. Leading by example and taking concrete actions is key to creating an environment that fosters greater focus and sustained productivity.

site_title: Killing Nafta will hurt US business and farm interests
summary: The US trade deficit with Canada and Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) is being misperceived as a major issue, despite being only 4% of total Nafta trade. The agreement has actually been beneficial to the US, with increased consumer choice, competition, and jobs created in all three countries. However, the Trump administration is pushing for changes to the agreement, with some business and farm interests opposing a US withdrawal from Nafta, which could disrupt supply chains and harm US exports to Canada and Mexico.

site_title: OCBC's Q3 profit up 12%, outlook positive in line with region's trends
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 12% increase in Q3 profit to S$1.06 billion, driven by sustained growth in its banking, wealth management, and insurance businesses. The bank's total non-performing loan ratio remained stable at 1.3%, while net interest income grew 12% to S$1.38 billion. CEO Samuel Tsien attributed the positive outlook to higher growth in regional countries, including China and ASEAN nations, which will lead to increased loan demand in Singapore. The bank's loan growth is expected to reach 7-8% for FY17-18.

site_title: Scandal-hit Japan carmakers eye return to 'golden age'
summary: Japan's carmakers, including Toyota, Nissan, and Suzuki, are seeking a comeback after years of scandals, foreign competition, and lagging technology. Despite quality issues, including recalls and safety disasters, analysts say they have the technological prowess to succeed in the electric segment. The industry faces a shrinking domestic market and stiff competition globally, but some analysts believe they can adapt and innovate to regain their reputation for quality.

site_title: Neo Group, Select Group among winners of S'pore Quality Award
summary: Neo Group and Select Group, two Singaporean companies, were among six winners of the Singapore Quality Award (SQA) for their organisational capabilities. Neo Group introduced automation initiatives to address manpower challenges, reducing late deliveries by half, while Select Group emphasized staff development through Workforce Skills Qualification (WSQ) modules. The award recognizes organisations that demonstrate outstanding management capabilities and deliver superior performance. This marks the first time both companies have received the award, alongside utility services provider SP Services and others.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands revamps Macau casino
summary: Las Vegas Sands plans to spend $1.1 billion on new projects in Macau, including renovating and rebranding Sands Cotai Central as The Londoner Macao by 2020. The move aims to boost appeal and diversify away from gambling, which accounts for 80% of Macau's government revenues. The company will also renovate existing properties, including the Venetian and Plaza Macau. The renovation comes as operators compete to finish planned resorts before licenses expire in 2020, following pressure from authorities to diversify the industry.

site_title: Terrorism, cyber-attacks top global risks for Singapore businesses
summary: Singapore business leaders ranked terrorism and cyber-attacks as the top global risks that keep them up at night, alongside Germany and the US. The country's low unemployment rate and historical experience with infectious diseases, such as Sars and Zika, also influenced their risk assessments. The survey highlights the vulnerabilities of Singapore, which is an oasis of stability in the region, and the growing threat of cyber-crime and terrorism in the Asia-Pacific. The Singapore government's initiatives to combat these threats, such as the Cyber Security Agency, are seen as crucial in managing these risks.

site_title: EU launches probe into UK tax scheme for multinationals
summary: The European Commission has launched a probe into the UK's tax scheme for multinationals, investigating whether exemptions allow for a breach of EU state aid rules. The probe centers around an exception to the UK's "controlled foreign companies" rule, which allows interest received by a parent company's offshore subsidiary from another foreign subsidiary to be exempt from British taxation. The EU's competition chief, Margrethe Vestager, will investigate the scheme, which is seen as part of the bloc's efforts to crack down on member states giving big international firms unfair tax breaks.

site_title: US goods-trade gap widens to 4-month high
summary: The US merchandise-trade deficit widened to a four-month high in September, reaching $64.1 billion, as imports rose for the first time since April. Wholesale inventories increased 0.3% and retail stockpiles fell 1% month-on-month. Exports rose 0.7%, with industrial supplies and capital goods seeing significant gains, while auto exports and imports declined. The trade data will be used to refine estimates for third-quarter economic growth, with analysts expecting the US economy to continue benefiting from strong overseas markets and a weak dollar.

site_title: Singapore mulls putting ICOs in regulatory sandbox
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is considering a regulatory sandbox for initial coin offerings (ICOs), potentially becoming one of the world's first regulators to do so. MAS Chief Fintech Officer Sopnendu Mohanty expressed interest in testing ICOs in a sandbox environment to assess their suitability for regulation. The move comes ahead of the Singapore Fintech Festival, amid the growing popularity of ICOs, which have raised nearly $800 million in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: How dealers woo buyers of Supercars
summary: A luxury car dealer, Brett David, has made $2 million in sales from Instagram posts, sparking nearly $1 billion in Lamborghini car sales since 2007. David credits Instagram for keeping the romance alive with long-time clients, including Kris Singh, who initially reached out to him for a Lamborghini Reventon and later bought a Pagani and multiple other high-end cars. The platform's influence is evident in David's business, with many sales inspired by Instagram posts. David's success highlights the significant role social media plays in the luxury car sales industry.

site_title: New Toyota Century is Japan's challenge to Rolls-Royce, Bentley
summary: Toyota has unveiled the new Century, Japan's most exclusive car, challenging Rolls-Royce and Bentley as a luxury vehicle. The third-generation Century features all-new bodywork while maintaining its traditional design, stately formal, and conservative look. The new car boasts a hybrid V8 engine and new safety technology, including a large display and LCD panels, while retaining traditional materials and design elements. The Century has been exempt from national restrictions and is only available by invitation, with the emperor of Japan being a notable chauffeured occupant.

site_title: Screen gems not to be missed at SGIFF
summary: The Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) featured a diverse lineup of films, including "Angels Wear White," "The Song of the Scorpions," and "Oh! Lucy." The festival also showcased documentaries such as "Never-Ending Man: Hayao Miyazaki" and "I Want to Go Home." Other notable films included "Dragonfly Eyes," "Shuttle Life," and "Mayhem." SGIFF highlighted the work of local and international filmmakers, covering topics such as social issues, satire, and mortality.

site_title: Australia cements grip in lithium market amid rising demand
summary: Australia is cementing its grip in the global lithium market, with almost 60% of planned supply from large projects over the next five years set to come from the country. The region, including mines in Western Australia, is expected to become the world's largest production center by the early to mid-2020s. Rising demand for lithium-ion batteries from electric vehicle manufacturers is driving price gains, with Australia accounting for 37% of production in 2027, according to forecasts.

site_title: US House passes budget plan, paving way for tax cut legislation
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a budget plan, paving the way for potential tax cut legislation, with a 216-212 vote. The plan, which includes slashing corporate and individual tax rates, will make it easier for the Senate to pass tax legislation with a simple majority. The bill's passage was marred by opposition from Democrats, who call the plan a giveaway to the rich and corporations, and some Republicans who expressed concerns about the impact on middle-class voters in high-tax states. The tax plan is expected to cut taxes by up to $6 trillion over the next decade.

site_title: Luxury stores' exit mauls Hong Kong malls
summary: Luxury stores are exiting Hong Kong malls, reflecting a shift in shopping habits among the city's wealthiest residents. Average spending per overnight visitor dropped 8.8% last year, with luxury goods being the hardest hit. Chinese shoppers are increasingly buying luxury brands online or at home, and are more price-sensitive when shopping abroad. Mall owners are broadening their tenant mix to cater to changing spending habits, but may struggle to capture growth. Luxury brands are reducing store sizes, but remain committed to the market, with some even investing in renovations.

site_title: Singapore reinvents itself as Asia's fintech hub
summary: Singapore is reinventing itself as Asia's fintech hub, leveraging its well-developed infrastructure and supportive regulatory environment to create a controlled, yet thriving, financial technology ecosystem. The country's fintech landscape enjoys strong support from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, which has fostered a conducive environment for innovation and growth. With a strong fintech ecosystem and a huge Asean migrant population, Singapore is transforming into a regional remittance hub, facilitating the intra-bloc redistribution of wealth and contributing to the economic development of its regional neighbors.

site_title: Heavyweight accelerator may help Singapore fintech punch above its weight
summary: Plug and Play, the world's largest startup accelerator, plans to open an accelerator program in Singapore by March 2018 to tap the city-state's fintech market. The program aims to work with five banks and five insurance companies, and potentially collaborate with Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore. This move follows Plug and Play's expansion to Abu Dhabi, where it launched a fintech acceleration program. The goal is to help fintech players develop proven technologies that can be expanded into the Middle East region, similar to how Singapore has become a hub for Southeast Asia.

site_title: Voices of asia and beyond
summary: The 28th edition of the Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) will feature "strong women voices" in a lineup of 112 films from 42 countries, including 18 world and six Asian premieres. The festival will highlight female protagonists and filmmakers, with a focus on co-productions and new talent. Notable films include "Angels Wear White," "Marlina the Murderer in Four Acts," and "Oh Lucy!," which will be screened alongside a late-night section and tributes to Asian cinema veterans Koji Yakusho and Garin Nugroho.

site_title: Twitter bans ads from two Russian media outlets
summary: Twitter has banned advertisements from Russian media outlets RT and Sputnik due to allegations by US intelligence agencies that they interfered with the 2016 US election. The social network stated that election-meddling is not welcome on its platform. This decision comes after similar actions by Facebook and Google. RT denied involvement in any illegal activity, while a representative for Sputnik was unavailable for comment. Twitter has previously suspended about 200 Russian-linked accounts for propaganda efforts related to the US presidential race.

site_title: 2017 looks set to be best year for Canada builders
summary: Canada's builders are on pace to start work on over 215,000 new homes in 2017, the most since 2007, as the country experiences a rebound in the construction industry. Despite initial predictions of a decline in housing starts, the industry's strength is broad-based across provinces, with notable rebounds in the Prairies and Quebec. Economists now forecast the sector will contribute positively to growth in 2017, but predict it will become a drag on the economy by 2019.

site_title: Yang Kee Logistics to buy NZ peer Fliway for S$52.1m
summary: Yang Kee Logistics has agreed to purchase New Zealand-listed logistics firm Fliway Group for S$52.1 million. The acquisition, conditional on shareholder and court approval, aims to boost the combined group's revenue by S$81.9 million. With the deal, Yang Kee will expand its presence in Oceania and Asia, with a projected revenue of over S$400 million and a headcount of over 1,050 employees across 12 countries. The acquisition is part of Yang Kee's vision to strengthen its global presence and leverage synergies between Fliway and its existing Australian logistics firm Axima.

site_title: Bombardier to lay off 280 UK staff as part of global cuts
summary: Bombardier Inc will lay off 280 UK staff as part of a global restructuring, following a trade dispute with Boeing Co and a potential 300% duty on its CSeries jet. The layoffs are part of a larger 7,500 job cuts worldwide. The move comes after Airbus agreed to buy a majority stake in the CSeries, potentially easing trade tensions. The Belfast plant, where 4,200 workers were affected, is expected to remain operational.

site_title: UOB in exclusive talks for possible sale of Hengfeng Bank stake
summary: UOB Bank is in exclusive talks to sell its stake in Hengfeng Bank Co Ltd, China, to Shandong Lucion Investment Holdings Group Co. The talks follow China's GDP growth slowdown, putting pressure on policymakers. UOB's decision comes as Chinese banks face challenges from Beijing's consumer lending push. The sale is part of a broader effort to restructure state-owned assets in China. No terms of the deal have been disclosed, and the talks are still in the early stages.

site_title: Unusual up 10% before announcing Disney on Ice agreement with Feld Entertainment
summary: Unusual Entertainment, a subsidiary of Unusual Limited, has signed letters of intent with Feld Entertainment Inc. and Barnum & Bailey International to jointly present 48 Disney On Ice shows in South Korea and Taiwan. The proposed shows will run from October 2018 to August 2019, with 12 shows in Seoul, 24 in Seoul and Busan, and 12 in Taipei.

site_title: UK government faces legal challenge to its alliance with N Irish party
summary: A legal challenge was launched in a London court against the UK government's alliance with the Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) in June, following the Conservatives' loss of majority in a snap election. The challenge, brought by a Northern Irish citizen, argues that the £1 billion pledge to Northern Ireland in exchange for DUP support was corrupt and an offence under the Bribery Act 2010. Government lawyers rejected the claims, arguing that the deal was authorized by parliament and did not violate the 1998 Good Friday peace agreement.

site_title: Why oil-rich Gulf Arab countries turn to renewables
summary: Oil-rich Gulf Arab countries are shifting to renewable energy sources, driven by the increasing affordability of solar and wind power. Despite having significant oil reserves, the region aims to diversify its energy mix to reduce reliance on fossil fuels and curb carbon emissions. The six member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council plan to invest heavily in solar and wind power, with Saudi Arabia aiming to generate 10% of its power from renewables by 2023 and the UAE aiming for 44% by 2050. This shift is also driven by the risk of oil price falls, which could lead to reduced earnings for producers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: UOB Bank is in exclusive talks to sell its stake in Hengfeng Bank Co Ltd to Shandong Lucion Investment Holdings Group Co, with Lucion being a wholly owned entity by Shandong Provincial State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission and Shandong Provincial Council for Social Security.

site_title: Epicentre signs MOU with F&B operator Coterie Dining Concepts
summary: EPICENTRE Holdings has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Coterie Dining Concepts and its shareholders to collaborate, invest in, or acquire businesses linked to Coterie. This could involve new dining and entertainment concepts, launching new outlets, or expanding existing businesses. The parties will negotiate exclusively for six months. Coterie is behind themed-bar Sum Yi Tai and Szechuan yakitori bar Chikin.

site_title: Hilton revenue jumps 26.1%
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings reported a 26.1% increase in quarterly revenue to $2.35 billion, driven by higher room bookings at higher prices. Net income attributable to Hilton stockholders rose to $179 million, or 55 US cents per share, in the third quarter ended September 30. This marks a decrease from the year-ago quarter's net income of $187 million, or 57 US cents per share.

site_title: Barclays sets bold profit targets even as weak Q3 saps share price
summary: Barclays set a bold new timeline for achieving profitability targets, despite a weak third-quarter performance in investment banking. The bank aims to achieve an overall return on equity above 9% in 2019 and above 10% by 2020, with a new target cost-to-income ratio of 60% or less by 2019. Shares fell 7% to 183p, making it the biggest faller in the FTSE index, following a 14% decline since February's full-year results. Barclays' chief executive Jes Staley signaled confidence in the bank's ability to increase returns.

site_title: Bayer books bumper Q3 as Monsanto merger waits in wings
summary: Bayer reported a significant increase in Q3 net profit, reaching 3.9 billion euros, more than triple the 1.2 billion euros from the same period last year. The result included a one-off gain of 2.8 billion euros from the spin-off of Covestro's polymers division. However, the company is still awaiting approval for its mega-merger with Monsanto.

site_title: Japan business lobby throws weight behind PM Abe's wage hike plan
summary: Japan's largest business lobby, Keidanren, backs Prime Minister Abe's plan to raise wages by 3% next year, which could boost household spending and drive up consumer prices. This move is seen as a step towards the Bank of Japan's inflation target. The business lobby, led by chairman Sadayuki Sakakibara, acknowledges that society demands higher wages and is willing to take aggressive action to achieve this.

site_title: Singapore must be at forefront of the blockchain technology race
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has emphasized the importance of blockchain technology in driving innovation and customer service in the financial sector. MAS Managing Director Ravi Menon stated that distributed ledger technology (DLT) has the potential to transform industries and economic activities. The government is investing in blockchain applications, with initiatives such as Project Ubin and partnerships with fintech startups. Singapore aims to be a global center for blockchain development and testing, competing with other countries like China, Australia, and India in the technology race.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q3 net profit down 9% to S$5.9m
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 9% decrease in Q3 net profit to S$5.9 million, down from S$6.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 12% to S$101 million, driven by its property and industrial services segments. The company's stake in printed circuit board manufacturer GulTech contributed S$4.5 million to its profits, a 2% increase from the previous year.

site_title: Singapore vegetable farms form trade body
summary: Nine Singapore vegetable farms have formed the Singapore Agro-Food Enterprises Federation (Safef) to address industry challenges and improve standards. The organization, led by emeritus president George Huang, aims to set standards, raise productivity, and promote local produce over the next three years. Safef will work with government agencies and collaborate with related industries to implement initiatives and suggestions. The founding members include major vegetable farms and companies, aiming to enhance the industry's competitiveness and growth.

site_title: Slows asset purchases as Draghi heads for stimulus exit
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced plans to reduce monthly bond purchases to 30 billion euros, starting in January and continuing for nine months, in a step towards ending its stimulus program. This move aims to revive euro-area inflation, which was 1.5% in the previous month. The decision marks a significant milestone for ECB President Mario Draghi's tenure, as the bank prepares to exit its asset-purchase program that has spent over 2 trillion euros. The move is seen as cautious, with the ECB leaving room for further extensions if needed.

site_title: China's new Silk Road runs straight through junk territory
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative, a $1.2 trillion infrastructure project, traverses territory with junk-rated sovereign debt in 27 of the 68 nations listed as partners. The project aims to boost economic growth and middle-class expansion in developing countries by 2050. Despite financial risks, China has already spent over $500 billion and lent billions through institutions like the Silk Road Fund. The initiative is seen as a geopolitical project to cement China's trade and political role over the US, rather than an economic one.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong shares ended lower on Thursday, following a retreat on Wall Street due to uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's tax reform plans. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.36%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices rose 0.26% and 0.25%, respectively.

site_title: MAS names new chief cybersecurity officer
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has appointed Tan Yeow Seng as its new chief cybersecurity officer (CCSO), effective December 1, 2017. The CCSO will help strengthen the MAS's cyber resiliency and the financial sector's. Tan will hold the position concurrently with his role as executive director of the technology risk and payments department. MAS Managing Director Ravi Menon praised outgoing Assistant Managing Director Wong Nai Seng for his 22 years of service, as the organization undergoes three senior management changes.

site_title: Crystal Tower in Bukit Timah up for en bloc sale for S$138m
summary: Crystal Tower, a 28-unit freehold residential site in Bukit Timah, has been put up for collective sale by tender with a price tag of S$138 million. The site, built in the 1970s, has a land area of 60,482 sq ft and is zoned for residential use with a gross plot ratio of 1.6. The sale price reflects a land rate of S$1,406 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: Apple, Volkswagen, BMW warn EU over patent fees guidelines
summary: Apple, Volkswagen, BMW, and Daimler have warned EU regulators that adopting patent fee guidelines favoring Qualcomm and Ericsson could harm consumers and hinder innovation. The companies, through the Fair Standards Alliance, expressed concerns in a letter to EU officials, citing trillions of dollars in sales at stake. The EU executive is considering whether a carmaker should pay a different rate for crucial patents than a fridge maker, or a flat, fixed rate. The companies urge caution to avoid hurting consumers and hindering innovation.

site_title: Japfa Q3 net profit down 94%
summary: Japfa Ltd, a Singapore-listed Indonesian agri-food firm, reported a 94% drop in net profit to US$3 million for its third quarter ended Sept 30, 2017, from US$48 million a year ago. Revenue rose 3% to US$814 million from US$788 million a year ago. The decline in net profit was attributed to lower sales in the Indonesian market.

site_title: UK retail sales slide in October at fastest rate since 2009
summary: British retail sales plummeted in October at the fastest pace since 2009, with a CBI survey showing a monthly retail sales balance of -36, the lowest level since March 2009. This marks a sharp slowdown from September's two-year high of +42. The reading was far below forecast, with economists expecting a modest slowdown. The decline is a fresh blow to the UK economy, which has already shrunk for the second month.

site_title: Singapore not rushing to regulate cryptocurrencies: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reaffirmed its stance of not rushing to regulate cryptocurrencies, citing no basis for regulation. MAS managing director Ravi Menon stated that the central bank will focus on assessing the risks posed by cryptocurrencies and will only proceed with regulation if necessary. This approach is seen as positive by industry players, who believe it could lead to Singapore becoming the region's cryptocurrency hub. In contrast, China and South Korea have imposed bans on ICOs, with Singapore's cautious approach allowing it to potentially benefit from the growth of the cryptocurrency sector.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P open higher as earnings gather pace
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a busy day of corporate earnings releases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 113.42 points, or 0.49%, to 23,442.88, while the S&P 500 gained 6.78 points, or 0.26%, to 2,563.93. The Nasdaq Composite added 3.53 points, or 0.05%, to 6,567.42. Investors assessed the results, despite ongoing trade uncertainty and tariff threats.

site_title: Fundraising activity on Catalist rises to S$3.8b in past five years
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a significant rise in fundraising activity on its Catalist platform over the past five years, with a total of S$3.8 billion raised by Catalist companies from 2013 to 2017. This represents a 120% increase from the 2008-2012 period. The Catalist has become one of the most liquid growth boards in the world, with a 129% five-year weighted average turnover velocity. Two new initiatives were launched to deepen the ecosystem and raise the Catalist's profile, including the Association of Catalist Companies and ShareInvestor's new portal, Investor-One.

site_title: American Airlines leads US carriers in racial bias complaints
summary: American Airlines has led US carriers in racial bias complaints, with 29 complaints filed in the last 20 months, according to the US Department of Transportation. The NAACP has issued a travel advisory for the airline, citing incidents of racial insensitivity and possible bias. American Airlines has invited NAACP representatives to discuss concerns and has stated it will not tolerate discrimination. The airline's CEO, Doug Parker, has signed a pledge to support diversity and has extended an invitation to Tamika Mallory, a high-profile critic, to meet with the airline's team.

site_title: China Life Insurance Q3 profit surges on investment gains
summary: China Life Insurance Co Ltd, the country's second-largest insurer, reported a 365.5% surge in third-quarter net profit to 14.6 billion yuan, driven by a 98% rise in 9-month net profit to 26.8 billion yuan. Investment income increased due to a rising stock market and healthy premiums, with 9-month premium income rising 20% to 450 billion yuan. The insurer's profit gains were underpinned by China's blue-chip index reaching a fresh 28-month high.

site_title: New Zealand's new leader Ardern promises government for all
summary: Jacinda Ardern was sworn in as New Zealand's Prime Minister, promising a government for all despite her Labour Party falling short of a majority in the general election. She formed a three-way coalition with the New Zealand First party and the Greens, vowing to act on urgent measures such as banning non-residents from buying existing houses and addressing housing affordability, healthcare, and environmental issues. Ardern emphasized that her government would represent all New Zealanders, regardless of who voted for them, and would outline its immediate agenda next week.

images.alt_text: Jacinda Ardern was officially sworn in as New Zealand prime minister on Thursday, pledging to lead a government for all despite her Labour Party falling well short of a majority in last month's general election.

site_title: Kobe Steel loses industrial standards certification for copper products
summary: Kobe Steel has lost its Japanese Industrial Standards (JIS) certification for copper products due to data falsification at its Hatano plant near Tokyo. The move could harm the company's business, which has already been impacted by customers switching to competitors. Kobe Steel chairman Hiroya Kawasaki will hold a news conference to provide details on the scandal. The certification revocation affects the company's ability to sell products with the JIS label, potentially leading to lost sales and supply chain disruptions for global manufacturers, including carmakers, aircraft companies, and others.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands rakes in 13% higher Q3 profit on VIP volume growth
summary: Marina Bay Sands reported a 13% increase in Q3 profit to US$442 million, driven by strong casino revenue and increased VIP volumes. Net revenue rose 4.1% to US$793 million, with casino revenue growing 6.3% and rolling chip volumes increasing 30.1%. The company attributed its success to innovative programming, mass gaming play, and non-gaming revenues. Chairman and CEO Sheldon Adelson praised Marina Bay Sands as a "reference site" for integrated-resort businesses.

images.alt_text: Net revenue, defined as sales less promotional allowances, rose 4.1 per cent to US$793 million on the back of a US$37 million, or 6.3 per cent, increase in casino revenue.

site_title: Keeping the business within the family bumps up returns: Credit Suisse
summary: A new report by Credit Suisse found that family-owned companies globally outperformed broader equity markets, with Singapore family-run businesses achieving the greatest relative returns of 7% since 2006. The report, which studied over 1,000 family-owned companies, found that younger family-owned companies (those run by the first or second generation) tend to perform better, generating share price returns of around 9% per annum, compared to 6.5% for companies in the third generation or beyond. This suggests that family involvement in the business is a key factor in success.

site_title: SAP finds indications of misconduct in S Africa on Gupta links
summary: SAP has found indications of misconduct in its South African business related to Gupta family connections. An internal probe uncovered instances of misconduct in managing Gupta-related third parties, prompting disciplinary procedures against three employees. SAP denies finding evidence of payments to government officials or employees of state-owned companies, but acknowledges the seriousness of the allegations and its commitment to transparency and ethics.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,356.25, with 1.8 billion shares traded worth S$1.1 billion. This marks the second consecutive day of gains, with losers narrowly outpacing gainers. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty, with investors staying positive.

site_title: Civmec commences ASX dual listing plans
summary: Civmec, an Australia-based construction and engineering services provider, has appointed PwC Australia to evaluate options for a dual listing on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX). The company, which is already listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), plans to maximize existing shareholder value and broaden its shareholder base. Civmec's CEO, Patrick Tallon, views a dual listing as a complementary option to its existing growth prospects in Australia. A report from PwC Australia is expected to be provided to the board in the second quarter of 2018.

site_title: Indonesia fireworks factory fire leaves 47 dead, dozens injured
summary: A fire at a fireworks factory in Tangerang, Indonesia, killed at least 47 people and injured dozens, police said. The blaze, which broke out at an industrial complex, triggered explosions and sent plumes of black smoke into the air. The victims had been burned beyond recognition, and authorities were working to recover their bodies. The factory, which had only been operating for six weeks, was part of a complex bordering a residential area.

images.alt_text: Nearly two dozen people have been killed and dozens injured in a blaze that tore through a fireworks factory outside the Indonesian capital, police said Thursday, triggering explosions and sending plumes of black smoke into the air.

site_title: Eurozone corporate lending growth inches up
summary: Eurozone corporate lending grew 2.5% in September, the highest level since the global financial crisis, but remained below pre-crisis levels due to banks' reluctance to lend. Household lending was steady at 2.7%. The European Central Bank's M3 money supply measure grew 5.1% in September, beating expectations. The ECB is expected to announce a cut in asset purchases from next year, marking a significant step in weaning the eurozone off stimulus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.25 points to 1,736.80. The market saw 2.5 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion, with 420 gainers outnumbering 383 losers.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady at 4-week low; Nokia plunges after results
summary: European shares remained steady near 4-week lows on Thursday, weighed down by mixed earnings updates and uncertainty over the Catalonia crisis. Nokia plummeted 14% after weaker-than-expected earnings, while banks such as Barclays and Deutsche Bank also fell. However, gains from companies like MTU Aero Engines and Neste offset losses. The European Central Bank's policy decision later in the day is expected to cut back on bond-buying stimulus, marking its biggest step yet in unwinding loose monetary policy.

site_title: Tax refund, higher revenue lift Sheng Siong's Q3 earnings
summary: Sheng Siong Group posted higher third-quarter earnings, driven by a 25.3% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$19.6 million, and a S$2.2 million tax refund. Revenue grew 4.2% to S$210.9 million, led by new stores and comparable same-store sales. However, the group faces competition from large online retailers and potential disruptions in the supply chain. Despite this, Sheng Siong remains optimistic about its prospects, with plans to open new stores in Singapore and China.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong Group on Thursday posted higher third-quarter earnings, lifted by a rise in revenue and a refund of previous years' taxes amounting to S$2.2 million.

site_title: Deutsche Bank beats forecasts as Q3 profit more than doubles
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a third-quarter net profit of 647 million euros (S$1 billion), more than doubling its 2016 figure of 153% increase. The bank continues to battle restructuring and Europe-wide headwinds. This marks a significant turnaround from previous quarters. The bank's strong performance is seen as a positive sign for the European banking sector.

site_title: Barclays talks tough on targets as weak quarter saps shares
summary: Barclays set a new, ambitious target for achieving profitability, aiming for an overall return on equity above 9% in 2019 and 10% by 2020. Despite a weak third-quarter performance, the bank's return on equity excluding costs from the disposal of its Africa unit is 7.1%. Shares fell 7% following the results, the largest drop in the FTSE index. Barclays' chief executive Jes Staley signaled confidence in the bank's ability to increase returns, citing cost-cutting measures and a new target cost-to-income ratio of 60% or less by 2019.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on corporate results
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, driven by robust Japanese corporate earnings. The Nikkei 225 and Topix indexes rose 0.15% and 0.14% respectively, with Line surging 17% on better-than-expected profit. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data and a positive day in Europe and the US, where mining and healthcare shares lifted shares. Despite US-EU trade tensions, investors remained positive, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Hyundai Motor posts smaller profit drop, but sees tough US market
summary: Hyundai Motor reported a smaller-than-expected quarterly profit drop, with a net profit of 852 billion won (S$1.03 billion) for the third quarter, down from 1.06 trillion won a year ago. The company attributed the decline to weak demand and rising competition in the US market, particularly due to China's backlash over Seoul's deployment of an anti-missile system. Hyundai plans to introduce more SUVs in the US and China, but analysts predict the company will miss its global sales target for a third straight year in 2017.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor posted a smaller-than-expected drop in quarterly profit, but cautioned of continued weak demand and rising competition in the United States, indicating the South Korean firm was still far from being out of the woods.

site_title: Yang Kee Logistics to buy New Zealand peer Fliway for S$52.1m
summary: Yang Kee Logistics has agreed to purchase New Zealand-listed logistics firm Fliway Group for S$52.1 million. The deal, conditional on shareholder and court approval, aims to boost combined revenue by S$81.9 million and expand the group's presence in Oceania. Yang Kee, which has previously acquired Australia's Axima, expects to have over 1,050 employees and an expected revenue of over S$400 million after the acquisition. The deal is part of Yang Kee's global growth strategy, supported by IE Singapore and Spring Singapore.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge down; won at 8-week high as strong GDP fuels rake hike talk
summary: South Korea's won reached an eight-week high against the US dollar, closing at 1,124.6 to the dollar, as traders anticipate a potential interest rate hike following robust third-quarter economic growth. The country's GDP rose 1.4% in the quarter, beating forecasts, and shares edged down 0.5% on the KOSPI index. Investors took profits after the benchmark index hit record highs for four consecutive sessions, with foreign investors selling a net 35.2 billion won worth of KOSPI shares.

site_title: China Zhongwang buys Australian aluminium superyacht builder
summary: China Zhongwang Holdings has acquired a controlling stake in Australian superyacht builder Silver Yachts, expanding its aluminium deep-processing strategy to the marine sector. The deal aims to utilize aluminium in the marine industry, following the acquisition of a German aluminium extrusion firm. Chairman Liu Zhongtian's investment firm, Zhongwang USA, is also in talks to buy US aluminium products maker Aleris Corp, despite opposition from US senators.

site_title: EU to start Brexit Plan B in case of December flop: sources
summary: The European Union has agreed to start internal preparations for a "Plan B" in case Brexit negotiations with the UK fail to reach a breakthrough by December, according to EU sources. This comes as the UK's trade goals are deemed unrealistic and the EU seeks to agree on a "sufficient progress" on the main issues of the UK's departure. Preparations will begin for both a positive and negative outcome, with the EU aiming to have plans in place for negotiations to begin immediately in December if agreement is reached on separation issues.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's electronics output continued its double-digit expansion in September, pushing overall factory production higher. Industrial space prices and rentals moderated in the third quarter, while occupancy rates remained stable. Singapore Airlines debuted its new A380 superjumbos on the Singapore-Sydney route, and the Monetary Authority of Singapore appointed a new chief cybersecurity officer. Yang Kee Logistics acquired New Zealand's Fliway Group for S$52.1 million, and Keppel sold its stake in a China waterfront development for S$597.4 million. Singapore shares rose 0.4% to close at 3,356.25.

images.alt_text: The Economic Development Board on Thursday reported that Singapore's manufacturing output increased 14.6 per cent year on year in September.

site_title: Australia shares rise as financials rebound, New Zealand slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,916.3, driven by gains in healthcare stocks, including Cochlear, which surged 2.2%. Banks rebounded after initial declines, with ANZ ending 1.2% higher. New Zealand's benchmark fell 0.4% due to material stocks, led by Fletcher Building. Weaker-than-expected inflation data and improved interest margins contributed to the Australian market's rebound.

site_title: Toyota makes a case for hydrogen fuel-cell car
summary: Toyota is pushing for hydrogen fuel-cell cars to complement electric battery vehicles in a future dominated by electric vehicles. Despite initial excitement, Toyota's Mirai has sold only 4,300 units, compared to four million Prius hybrids. Toyota chairman Takeshi Uchiyamada believes both technologies will be needed to replace petrol cars, citing advantages of hydrogen cars, such as rapid refueling and longer driving ranges. Toyota is investing in rapid charging technology and plans to expand its network of refuelling stations in Japan and China, aiming to raise the Mirai's driving range to 500 km.

site_title: Kobe Steel finds four more cases of suspected faked data
summary: Kobe Steel has found four more cases of suspected falsified data, expanding a scandal that has cut the company's market value by over a third since its disclosure in October. The affected products were produced by Shinko Engineering, a machinery manufacturing unit, and include metals and machinery departments. The company has set up an independent review committee to address the issues and will submit its findings by year-end. Despite no reports of safety issues, the scandal has affected over 500 customers, including Toyota Motor and Boeing, and has led to a 1.5% drop in Kobe Steel's shares.

site_title: ShareInvestor unveils news portal catered for Catalist-listed firms
summary: ShareInvestor has launched a news portal catering to Catalist-listed firms, providing a one-stop platform for investors to access exclusive content, including interviews with CEOs, aggregated news from Singapore Press Holdings, and educational articles. The mobile-friendly website aims to address the lack of news coverage on the secondary board, offering a platform for companies to share their stories and connect with investors.

site_title: Australia: Shares slump after ANZ misses; NZ at near 1-week low
summary: Australian shares plummeted 0.3% on Thursday, led by a drop in ANZ Banking Group Ltd's annual net profit, which fell short of estimates. The bank's shares slipped 2.4%, the biggest daily percentage drop in nearly 11 weeks. Other "Big Four" banks also fell, with the financial index posting its biggest daily drop in over three weeks. The Australian dollar sank to its lowest since mid-July, and miners such as BHP Billiton and Fortescue Metals Group Ltd fell due to soft iron ore prices.

site_title: ANZ Bank annual net profit jumps 12%
summary: ANZ Bank reported a 12% jump in annual net profit to A$6.41 billion, driven by the benefits of a restructure. Cash profit, excluding volatile items, rose 18% to A$6.94 billion, in line with expectations. The result marked the lender's second consecutive year of profit growth.

site_title: Singapore's electronics output continues stellar run in September
summary: Singapore's electronics sector continued its strong growth in September, with factory production increasing 14.6% year-over-year, beating economists' expectations. The electronics cluster drove the growth, expanding 33.2% with semiconductors and computer peripherals segments posting significant gains. Excluding the biomedical sector, manufacturing output grew 16.1% year-over-year, and economists expect the gross domestic product (GDP) for Q3 to be revised upwards. This stronger-than-expected showing suggests a more robust economy than initially thought.

images.alt_text: The Economic Development Board on Thursday reported that Singapore's manufacturing output increased 14.6 per cent year on year in September.

site_title: May heads for Brussels after Brexit talks deadlock
summary: Theresa May travels to Brussels on Monday for talks with EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker after Brexit talks deadlock, with no clear path forward for negotiations on future trade ties. The talks come as EU officials and leaders express concern that the process may collapse, with the UK's refusal to detail its financial offer and other issues holding up progress. The EU has agreed to allow Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier to explore a possible post-Brexit transition period, but Germany and France have resisted, insisting further progress is needed.

site_title: Fundraising activity on Catalist rises to S$3.8b over past 5 years
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a significant rise in fundraising activity on its Catalist platform over the past 5 years, with S$3.8 billion raised from 2013 to 2017, compared to S$2 billion from 2008 to 2012. Catalist companies have seen a 120% increase in funds raised at listing and triple the amount through secondary fundraising. The platform has grown to become one of the most liquid growth boards in the world, with 197 firms and a combined market capitalisation of S$12 billion.

images.alt_text: Fundraising activity on the Catalist has risen significantly for the five-year period from 2013 and has helped speed up the growth of companies.

site_title: Mattis says US 'not rushing to war' with North Korea
summary: US Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis stated that Washington is seeking a "peaceful resolution" with North Korea amid heightened tensions over Pyongyang's nuclear threats. Mattis said the US is not "rushing to war" and is looking for a diplomatic solution, but acknowledged that military options are available. Mattis and his counterparts agreed that North Korea's nuclear program poses an "unprecedented and grave threat" and vowed to step up diplomatic pressure. Mattis' visit to the divided peninsula comes ahead of a visit by US President Donald Trump next month, amid concerns of a potential conflict.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.15 points to 1,740.20. The market saw a significant increase in volume, with 68.58 million lots traded worth RM14.7 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 55.

site_title: Asia: Markets muted after Wall Street retreat
summary: Asian markets were muted on Thursday, following a retreat on Wall Street due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's tax cut plans. Tokyo edged up slightly, while Shanghai rose 0.2% after China's President Xi Jinping was re-elected. Hong Kong slipped 0.2%, and Seoul, Sydney, and Singapore were flat. Investors remained bullish on Tokyo, despite a 16-day run of gains ending, as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to press on with his economic agenda.

site_title: Citi Private Bank's Asia-Pac CEO to retire in Feb 2018
summary: Citi Private Bank's Asia-Pacific CEO, Bassam Salem, will retire in February 2018 after six years at the helm. Salem, with 30 years of experience in private banking and asset management, led the bank's activities across Asia. His tenure was marked by numerous trade awards, but the bank credits his ability to build a strong team as his most notable achievement. Salem will be replaced in February 2018, with no further details on the successor.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars at multi-month lows; BoC further dampens mood
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars hit multi-month lows due to slower-than-expected inflation data and a dovish turn by the Bank of Canada. The Australian dollar steadied at US$0.7710, while the New Zealand dollar fell 0.3% to US$0.6873. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates low, and investors await the European Central Bank's meeting and RBA Deputy Governor Guy Debelle's speech for further guidance.

site_title: Young Muslims to drive US$300b boom in Islamic travel: study
summary: Young Muslims worldwide are expected to boost the Islamic travel sector to US$300 billion by 2026, with spending on travel projected to almost double to US$100 billion by 2025. This growth is driven by young Muslims aged 20-36 who take multiple trips, increasing their overall expenditure. The sector's growth comes as countries like Saudi Arabia, Malaysia, and Turkey capitalize on the market, with Indonesia, Egypt, and Kazakhstan also contributing to the expansion.

site_title: Trump calls Yellen 'impressive' as replacement choice looms
summary: President Donald Trump praised Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen as "very impressive" and a potential candidate to succeed her, despite betting markets expecting him to pass her over. Yellen has performed well during her term, with low unemployment and inflation, but Republican lawmakers want her to raise interest rates and reduce regulations. Trump's decision would mark the first time a president has not retained the incumbent Fed chair since Jimmy Carter in 1978. Trump has narrowed his choice to two or three people, but has not disclosed their names.

site_title: Catalan brinkmanship sets stage for Spain to seize control
summary: Spain is on the brink of a constitutional crisis as Catalan separatists, led by President Carles Puigdemont, face a make-or-break decision on declaring independence. The Spanish government, led by Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, has proposed implementing Article 155, a draconian constitutional tool that would oust Puigdemont and his administration from office. The Catalan leader is set to address the regional parliament on Thursday, with many speculating he will unilaterally declare independence, potentially leading to a parallel administration and escalating tensions. The outcome is uncertain, with some fearing a "crash" and deepening economic and social divisions.

site_title: Billionaires' fortunes rise to US$6t with Asia leading way
summary: The world's billionaires saw a 17% increase in wealth to $6 trillion in 2016, with Asia leading the way, surpassing the US for the first time. China drove this growth, and American billionaires still control the most wealth at $2.8 trillion.

site_title: China will not set target to double GDP from 2021: party official
summary: China will no longer set a target to double its GDP from 2021, according to a senior Communist Party official. The government aims to focus on high-quality growth rather than solely pursuing economic expansion. China's GDP growth is on track to meet its 2020 goals, which include doubling GDP and per capita income from 2010 levels. This shift in focus emphasizes the importance of economic quality over quantity.

site_title: ESR-Reit to sell S$150m of 4.6% perpetual securities
summary: ESR-Reit plans to sell S$150 million of 4.6% perpetual securities to refinance debt and fund investments. The securities will be sold at par, with a potential call at five years and a reset distribution rate after the call date. Moody's has affirmed ESR's investment-grade rating but downgraded its outlook to negative due to expected debt burden from the acquisition of Tuas South Lane.

site_title: Price, rentals of Singapore industrial space continue to moderate in Q3
summary: Singapore's industrial space prices and rentals continued to moderate in Q3 2017, with a 0.9% drop in price and 1.1% drop in rentals from the previous quarter. Occupancy rates fell by 0.1 percentage point to 88.6%. About 931,000 sq m of industrial space is expected to come onstream in Q4, leading to further price and rental softening. With 2.3 million sq m of new supply expected by end-2018, prices and rentals are likely to continue to decline.

site_title: SIA's refreshed superjumbos to take flight on Singapore-Sydney route
