site_title: China Jinmao says executive assisting Hong Kong anti-graft body with probe
summary: China Jinmao Holdings Group Ltd's chief financial officer, Jiang Nan, is assisting Hong Kong's anti-graft body, the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC), with a bribery investigation. The ICAC searched the company's office and Jiang is providing documents and records. China Jinmao claims it will not be affected by the probe, which is unrelated to the company itself. The ICAC has declined to comment on the individual case.

site_title: Trump may be Yellen's unlikely advocate at White House: sources
summary: President Donald Trump may be considering Janet Yellen for a second term as Federal Reserve chair, despite initial reservations from his advisors. In an Oval Office interview, Yellen impressed Trump with her arguments that the economy is doing well and Fed policies have been supportive of growth. Trump has said he'll decide by November 3 who to nominate, and sources suggest he considers her a finalist for the job. The decision could be a surprise to conservatives in his own party, and maintaining confidence in the central bank is critical for continued economic growth and job creation.

site_title: Japan advisers propose delaying primary surplus target to after FY2020
summary: Japan's influential advisory panel proposes delaying the primary budget surplus target to after fiscal 2020/21, and reducing fiscal stimulus spending. The panel also recommends changes to the tax code to encourage capital expenditure and higher wages. This proposal aligns with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's thinking, and is likely to become official government policy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.30% on Wednesday, following a record close on Wall Street, as bargain hunters moved in after two days of losses. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,238.85, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices dipped 0.10% and 0.07% respectively.

site_title: China's JD.com eyes Mid-East entry, Saudi government partnership
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce firm, is eyeing a partnership with the Saudi government as part of its entry into the Middle East. President Winston Cheng described Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 as an "incredible opportunity" to boost private-sector growth. The move comes as Amazon and Alibaba's cloud-computing subsidiary Aliyun have already established a presence in the region. JD.com plans to move quickly and establish a partnership, with the Saudi government's Public Investment Fund hosting a major business conference in Riyadh, highlighting growing tech interest in the Middle East.

site_title: Finnair's profits rise on strong Asian demand
summary: Finnair reported a 80% increase in third-quarter core operating profit to 119 million euros, driven by strong demand on its Asian routes and the deployment of newer aircraft. The airline plans to acquire 19 new Airbus A350 planes, with 11 already delivered. Despite this, shares remain up 3% due to concerns over the fourth quarter. Finnair maintains its full-year profit forecast range of 135-155 million euros, which is ahead of expectations. Analysts expect the airline's profits to improve further in 2018 and 2019, justifying its current valuation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.57 points to 1,736.71. The market saw a significant volume of 98.34 million lots worth RM27.6 million, with gainer-to-loser ratios at 116-63.

site_title: Xi promotes no clear China heirs, opening door to stay in power
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has announced a new leadership lineup with no clear potential heirs, breaking with a quarter-century-old succession system. The five new members, all over 60, will join Xi and Premier Li Keqiang on the Politburo Standing Committee, raising the chances of Xi staying in power beyond 2022. The move, coupled with revisions to the party charter, elevates Xi's status and allows him to influence China's economy for decades to come. This departure from the traditional two-term succession system signals a shift towards a personality-driven model, with Xi likely to maintain his authority indefinitely.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping unveiled a new leadership line-up that included no clear potential heirs, breaking with a quarter-century-old succession system and raising the chances that he might seek to stay in office beyond 2022.

site_title: Singapore won't regulate cryptocurrencies, remains alert to risk: Menon
summary: Singapore's central bank will not regulate cryptocurrencies like bitcoin, but will monitor potential risks such as money laundering. Managing director Ravi Menon stated that the focus is on assessing risks and deciding if regulatory action is needed. Singapore already requires virtual-currency intermediaries to combat money laundering and terrorism financing, and ICOs with security-like features will be covered by the country's Securities and Futures Act. The approach will be case-by-case, with some digital tokens allowed to operate outside of regulation.

images.alt_text: Singapore doesn't plan to regulate cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin, but will remain alert to money laundering and other potential risks stemming from their use, the head of the country's central bank said.

site_title: Canadian pension fund Omers opening Singapore office
summary: Canadian pension fund Omers is opening an office in Singapore in January 2018. The office, located at One Raffles Quay, will help identify promising investment opportunities in emerging markets. Omers' Chief Investment Officer, Michael Rolland, will lead the development of the company's presence in Singapore. This move is part of Omers' strategy to diversify its global investment holdings.

site_title: Cerberus shows interest in troubled Alitalia: report
summary: US private equity group Cerberus Capital Management has approached Alitalia with an offer to allow the carrier to remain independent, provided it undergoes comprehensive restructuring. Cerberus is willing to invest between 100 million euros and 400 million euros to gain control of the airline, with plans to ask the Italian government to retain a stake and share profits with trade unions. This offer comes after Alitalia's staff rejected a plan to cut jobs and salaries, and follows a formal sale process involving seven bidders, including Lufthansa and easyJet.

images.alt_text: Cerberus told Alitalia that it was still interested in buying the airline if it could be comprehensively restructured, the FT said, citing sources.

site_title: SGX queries Hong Leong Asia's recent 16.8% share price climb
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Hong Leong Asia's 16.8% share price climb, citing "unusual price movements" between October 2 and 24. The SGX has requested the company to disclose any previously unannounced information. CIMB's recent "add" recommendation for China Yuchai International, a subsidiary of Hong Leong Asia, may be a contributing factor to the stock's price surge, with CIMB citing the company's robust financial position and potential benefits from China's industrial development initiatives. The company must respond to the SGX's query.

site_title: OCBC, DBS, UOB's Q3 results will be scrutinised to see if their 2017 strong rally continues
summary: Singapore's three major banks, OCBC, DBS, and UOB, will report their third-quarter results, with analysts scrutinizing their net interest margins, wealth management income, and potential bad debts. The banks have seen a strong rally in 2017, with OCBC and DBS up 30% and UOB up 20%, outperforming the benchmark Straits Times Index. Analysts expect the banks to continue their growth, with DBS and UOB projecting net earnings of S$1.189 billion and S$788 million respectively. The focus will be on the banks' ability to sustain their momentum, particularly in the property market.

site_title: Singapore partners Hong Kong to boost fintech development
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong have signed a new agreement to boost fintech development, strengthening cooperation and innovation between the two financial centers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will collaborate on trade finance cross-border infrastructure and other fintech initiatives, sharing expertise and information. The partnership aims to enhance the trade finance corridor between the two markets, with a strategic project on distributed ledger technology set to be launched. This comes ahead of Singapore's Fintech Festival in November.

images.alt_text: Mr Shu-pui Li, HKMA's executive director (left) and Mr Roy Teo, head of the Financial Centre Development Department of MAS (right) exchange the Co-operation Agreement, signed between heads of the two organisations, at the HKMA Fintech Day today

site_title: Japan's Jera to buy LNG from Malaysia
summary: Japan's Jera Co, the world's largest LNG buyer, has signed a Heads of Agreement to purchase up to 2.5 million tonnes of liquefied natural gas per annum from Malaysia LNG Sdn Bhd for three years starting from April 2018. The deal, valued at approximately $12 billion, is in line with Japan's Fair Trade Commission guidance and will be delivered ex-ship and free-on-board. This purchase will further solidify Jera's position as the world's largest LNG buyer.

site_title: Australian Q3 inflation surprisingly soft, rate hike more distant
summary: Australian consumer prices rose 1.8% for the year to September, below market forecasts of 2.0%, and core inflation averaged 1.85%, undershooting the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band for the seventh straight quarter. This suggests the RBA is unlikely to raise interest rates soon, with interest rate futures now pushing out the likely timing of a rate hike to November next year.

site_title: Asia: Shares edge up, Nikkei aims for 17th straight gain
summary: Asian shares edged higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei index on track for its 17th straight gain, driven by hopes of continued stimulus from Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's coalition following his election victory. US Treasury yields rose, lifting the dollar, amid reports that Republican senators favor John Taylor as the next Federal Reserve chief, potentially leading to faster interest rate increases. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.2% and China's CSI300 index gained 0.3%.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 0.2 point to 3,334.47. About 74.9 million shares worth S$86.2 million changed hands, with gains outnumbering losses 87 to 52. The Dow Jones surged to a record, while Tokyo stocks opened higher, extending their longest winning streak.

site_title: Japan eyes bigger tax breaks for firms that hike wages: sources
summary: Japan's government is considering expanding tax incentives for companies to raise wages, aiming to spur economic activity and inflation. The current incentives are set to expire at the end of March 2018, but the government wants to continue and expand them. The goal is to encourage companies to increase wages by 3% through annual negotiations with unions. Despite a tight job market, companies are hesitant to raise wages due to concerns about passing on costs to customers accustomed to falling prices.

site_title: Global Infrastructure acquires Equis in US$5b cash deal
summary: Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP) acquired independent power producer Equis Energy for US$5 billion in cash, including assumed liabilities of US$1.3 billion, in a deal expected to close in first-quarter 2018. Equis Energy, which owns 11,135 MW of installed capacity across the Asia-Pacific region, will continue to expand competitively under GIP's management. The acquisition positions GIP as a dominant renewable energy developer in key OECD markets of Australia and Japan, according to GIP and Equis Energy.

site_title: Bitcoin retreats as another cryptocurrency offshoot appears
summary: Bitcoin's value dropped 3.3% to $5,413 after a new cryptocurrency, bitcoin gold, was created through a "hard fork" from the original blockchain. Bitcoin gold allows for easier mining with standard gaming graphics cards, making it accessible to a wider audience. The new cryptocurrency's market capitalization stands at $1.6 billion, making it the world's eighth-largest cryptocurrency. The creation of bitcoin gold has sparked debate over an upgrade to bitcoin's protocol, with some factions wanting to increase the blocksize to speed up transactions.

site_title: Outlook 2018: What's Your Plan?
summary: A half-day seminar, "Outlook 2018: What's Your Plan?", was held on November 21, 2017, in Singapore, addressing the uncertain business year ahead. Experts discussed geopolitics, economic climate, and evolving consumer expectations, including the impact of the Trump administration's approach to global affairs, China's increasing influence, and the instability in the Korean Peninsula. The panel also explored the impact of digitization on consumers, the global investment outlook, and the potential risks and opportunities for businesses in 2018.

site_title: Pavilion Gas and Shell Trading now able to bring in LNG cargoes with award of licence
summary: Pavilion Gas and Shell Trading have received licences from the Energy Market Authority to import liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargoes into Singapore. The award marks the end of the first exclusive franchise awarded to BG, now Shell, and allows for greater competition among gas suppliers. The government has lifted the moratorium on piped natural gas imports, and spot LNG imports will be allowed from the first quarter of next year, subject to a 10% market-wide cap. This move aims to increase dynamism in Singapore's gas market.

site_title: UK economy picks up speed in Q3, puts BOE rate hike firmly on track
summary: The UK economy showed unexpected growth in Q3, with quarterly GDP rising 0.4% compared to 0.3% in the previous quarter. This growth is attributed to the services industry and a rebound in car production, despite manufacturing struggles. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates to 0.50% in November due to concerns over inflation, despite a slightly stronger-than-expected growth rate. The news is a boost to finance minister Philip Hammond ahead of his budget, but the economy's performance remains a concern due to its poor productivity performance.

site_title: Singapore passport 'most powerful' in the world: Passport Index
summary: Singapore's passport has been ranked as the most powerful in the world, with a visa-free score of 159, according to the Passport Index. This marks the first time an Asian country has held the top spot. The US passport has fallen to 154, tied with Malaysia, following changes in visa policies. The ranking is attributed to Singapore's inclusive diplomatic relations and effective foreign policy, with managing director Philippe May stating it's a testament to the country's diplomatic efforts.

site_title: Twitter increases ad transparency to foil politics meddling
summary: Twitter has taken steps to increase ad transparency amid concerns over Russian meddling in the 2016 US election. The platform will launch an online center with details about advertisers and their messages, and adopt stricter ad policies with a visual indicator for electioneering ads. The moves follow US lawmakers' introduction of the Honest Ads Act, which aims to require disclosure of online political ad sources. Twitter's changes are seen as a "good first step" by lawmakers, but the issue remains a national security concern.

site_title: Mystery ancient stone structures found in Saudi desert
summary: Nearly 400 ancient stone structures, known as "gates," have been discovered in the Saudi Arabian desert using Google Earth by Australian researcher David Kennedy. The structures, believed to have been built between 2,000 to 9,000 years ago, are thought to be man-made but their purpose and function remain a mystery. Kennedy, a University of Western Australia academic, was baffled by the remote site, which was spotted on satellite images despite his decades-long work in the region, and is set to be published in a paper next month.

images.alt_text: Nearly 400 mysterious ancient stone structures have been identified in the Saudi Arabian desert by an Australian researcher using Google Earth.

site_title: Ferry sector confronts new sulphur rules
summary: The ferry sector is grappling with the upcoming 0.5% sulphur in fuel limit, set to come into effect in 2020, amid increasing environmental regulations. This poses significant challenges for global ferry operators, particularly those operating on short routes within territorial waters or exclusive economic zones. Alternative fuels are being explored as a solution, but the industry is still uncertain about how to adapt to the new regulations.

site_title: Australia: Shares ride higher on miners; NZ subdued as Fletcher weighs
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,909.6, driven by gains in miners BHP Billiton and South32 Ltd, which touched one-week highs. Brent oil rose 1% and aluminum prices closed up 0.8%. The "Big Four" banks rose, but later retreated to trade flat. New Zealand's benchmark index was little changed, with Fletcher Building Ltd plummeting 5.9% after reporting a loss. Prime Minister-designate Jacinda Ardern announced plans to review and reform the Central Bank Act to include employment as a target.

site_title: US dollar firm on report of support for Taylor as Fed chief
summary: The US dollar remained stable against a basket of currencies, despite concerns over the passage of a tax-cut plan. John Taylor's reported support from Republican Senators for Federal Reserve chief offset news that might hinder the tax bill. The New Zealand dollar declined to a five-month low due to the incoming Labour-led government's plan to review and reform the Central Bank Act. The dollar's stability is attributed to Taylor's hawkish stance on interest rates, favoring a rule-based approach.

site_title: Offshore legal firm hacked, braces for media leaks
summary: A Bermuda-based offshore firm, Appleby, has been hit by a data breach, potentially exposing financial details of wealthy individuals. The firm, which has offices in Bermuda and the Cayman Islands, has investigated allegations of wrongdoing and denies any wrongdoing. The leak follows a similar data breach last year, and Appleby is bracing for publication of its documents in the coming days by a global consortium of media organizations, including The Telegraph. The leak is expected to impact some of Britain's wealthiest people, who had sought to protect their reputations.

site_title: Broker's take: Phillip Capital upgrades UOB to 'neutral'
summary: Broker Phillip Capital has upgraded United Overseas Bank (UOB) to 'neutral' with a target price of S$23.46, citing improving economy and oil and gas sector signs. The broker expects UOB's credit costs to improve and higher return on equity, but notes that it may lag behind peers DBS and OCBC due to lower wealth management exposure. Market sentiment is expected to be strong in 2018, benefiting DBS and OCBC. UOB is trading at S$24.37, while DBS and OCBC are at S$21.97 and S$11.47 respectively.

site_title: Brokers' take: Cache Logistics' improved gearing soothes concerns
summary: Cache Logistics Trust's improved gearing has alleviated concerns among brokers, with CIMB upgrading its call from "hold" to "reduce" and OCBC maintaining a "hold" call. The company's third-quarter results are in line with expectations, and a potential resolution to its 51 Alps Avenue dispute could boost the stock. Cache's gearing has decreased to 35.7% after a recent rights issue, providing balance sheet comfort. Analysts expect warehouse rents to stabilize by mid-2018, offering growth potential for the company.

site_title: Oil up 1% on Saudi comments, forecast of US inventory drop
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Tuesday after Saudi Arabia's energy minister stated the country is determined to end a supply glut, while US crude inventories are forecasted to drop, supporting prices. Brent crude settled up 96 cents to $58.33 a barrel, and US crude rose 57 cents to $52.47 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has cut oil output by 1.8 million barrels per day since January, with the pact set to run to March 2018.

site_title: First Sponsor posts 13.9% surge in Q3 profit
summary: First Sponsor, a Singapore-based developer, reported a 13.9% surge in Q3 profit to S$22.02 million, driven by robust sales from projects in China and higher contributions from its property financing business. Revenue fell 21.4% to S$64.82 million due to lower property sales and rental income, but was partially offset by an increase in property financing revenue to S$11.3 million.

site_title: Singapore needs to be on guard for inflation pickup: Menon
summary: Singapore's central bank chief, Ravi Menon, warned that the country needs to be vigilant for a potential pickup in inflation due to strengthening economic growth. Menon stated that while inflation remains below historical average, the central bank must be proactive in controlling price pressures. He emphasized that as long as inflation remains benign, the current policy stance has been appropriate, citing the bank's track record of keeping inflation under control.

images.alt_text: Mr Menon, 53, has been head of the central bank since 2011, when core inflation averaged 2.2 per cent.

site_title: Who wants to host Amazon's second HQ?
summary: Amazon has received 238 pitches from cities across North America vying for its second headquarters, with a $5 billion investment and 50,000 well-paid jobs on the line. The US company is seeking a location that can accommodate its growth and provide a high quality of life for employees. The winner will be announced in the coming months, with no specific timeline provided.

site_title: OCBC plans research push into rival market Hong Kong
summary: Singapore's OCBC plans to expand its research coverage to Hong Kong, adding 60 Hong Kong-listed stocks by year-end, supplementing the existing coverage of 75 firms tracked by its private banking unit. This move aims to capitalize on the growing importance of Hong Kong as a financial hub. OCBC's head of research, Carmen Lee, expects 14 to 20 new stocks to be added by the end of the year. The expansion is seen as a strategic move to tap into the rival market and stay competitive.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Q4 DPU up 5.5%
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 5.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, driven by higher rental income and improved occupancy at Northpoint City. Full-year DPU reached 11.9 cents, the highest since FCT's listing in 2006. Net property income rose 10% to S$34.6 million, while distributable income increased 6.1% to S$27.5 million.

site_title: Two Republican US senators blast Trump as party feud deepens
summary: Two Republican US senators, Jeff Flake and Bob Corker, publicly criticized President Donald Trump, accusing him of debasing US politics and the country's standing abroad. Flake described Trump's behavior as "reckless, outrageous and undignified," while Corker expressed concerns about Trump's influence on foreign policy. The criticism further strained relationships between Trump and fellow Republicans, potentially hindering their legislative agenda. The incident marks a significant escalation of tensions within the Republican Party.

site_title: IMF chief warns of 'dark future' over climate change
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned of a "dark future" for the world if it fails to address climate change and inequality. At a major economic conference in Riyadh, she urged critical decisions on climate change to prevent severe consequences. If the world fails to act, it will be "toasted, roasted, and grilled" in 50 years, Lagarde said. The warning comes as the world grapples with economic and environmental challenges, with Lagarde emphasizing the need for collective action to mitigate the effects of climate change and inequality.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial sets placement at price talk's S$1.90 rich end, upsizes to S$155.7m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust has priced an upsized S$155.7 million placement of units at S$1.90 apiece, covering the rich end of the initial price talk. The issue price represents a 3.2% discount to the counters volume-weighted average price of S$1.9623. The deal received 3.3 times interest from bookrunner and underwriter DBS Bank, exceeding the planned issue of at least S$125 million units.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Industrial, FCT, Ezion, Aspial
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust priced an upsized S$155.7 million placement at S$1.90 apiece to cover rich end of price talk. Frasers Centrepoint Trust posted a 5.5% rise in distribution per unit for the fourth quarter, driven by higher rental income and improved occupancy. Ezion Holdings is cautiously optimistic about refinancing plans, citing recovery in its core liftboat business. Aspial Corporation canceled S$6.5 million worth of notes due 2019 after repurchasing them in the open market.

site_title: US Midwest oil refiners boost output, cut region's dependence on Gulf Coast
summary: US Midwest oil refineries have increased output, reducing their dependence on Gulf Coast fuel. Since the early 2000s, crude flows from the Gulf Coast have been cut in half, as Canadian and North Dakota oil has boosted refining activity in the region. Midwest refiners have invested billions on new units to process sludgy Canadian crude, now capable of producing petrol and diesel. This shift has helped the region break its historic dependence on Gulf Coast fuel, with Midwest refiners now well-positioned to supply their region and parts of southern Canada.

site_title: Gold prices dip on nerves before Fed chair decision
summary: Gold prices declined on Tuesday due to investor optimism in the US stock market and a calmer geopolitical environment, reducing demand for safe-haven assets. The uncertainty surrounding the next head of the US Federal Reserve also contributed to the dip. Market strategist Phillip Streible stated that gold futures may remain weak until the release of US GDP figures on Friday.

site_title: Malaysian bonds at crossroads as Najib prepares election budget
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is expected to present an election budget that could boost the country's bonds, driven by higher revenue from a consumption tax and a recovery in crude prices. A nascent recovery in bond inflows is set to depend on whether Najib can shrink the fiscal deficit while appealing to voters. Analysts from Investec Asset Management and Aviva Investors see the ringgit as an attractive asset, citing a narrowing deficit target and a potential expansionary budget. However, Aberdeen Standard Investments remains cautious due to rising US interest rates and the Federal Reserve's balance sheet unwind.

site_title: Airlines get ready for new US security rules from Thursday
summary: New security rules for US-bound flights take effect on Thursday, requiring airlines to implement stricter passenger screening measures. The rules, designed to avoid expanding an in-cabin laptop ban, will affect 325,000 passengers on 2,000 flights daily. Airlines must comply with the measures, including increased screening and short security interviews, by Thursday. The rules follow a June announcement by the US government to boost security measures in response to unspecified threats, with some airlines saying the changes may cause disruptions.

site_title: World travel body expects S'pore tourism revenue to hit US$18b by 2027
summary: Singapore's tourism revenue is expected to reach US$18.1 billion by 2027, growing at an average rate of 3% per year from 2017 to 2027, according to the World Travel & Tourism Council. The sector directly employed 164,000 people in 2016, contributing 9.9% to Singapore's GDP. The government is urged to create unique experiences to increase spending, with the private sector also playing a role in boosting the sector. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to drive tourism growth, with cities like Shanghai and Beijing leading the way.

site_title: China to unveil new leadership after Xi stamps authority on country
summary: China is set to unveil its new ruling council on Wednesday, with President Xi Jinping likely to emerge with a second five-year term as the party's general secretary. The new Politburo Standing Committee members will have significantly less influence than their predecessors, with Xi's name now enshrined in the Communist Party's constitution, cementing his status as the country's locus of power. The selection process, which was highly choreographed, has raised questions about the future of the collective model of leadership promoted by Deng Xiaoping, and analysts expect Xi to prioritize his own agenda.

site_title: It makes sense for South-east Asia to go for clean energy
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has highlighted the potential for South-east Asia to transition to clean energy, citing the region's rapid economic growth and increasing energy demand. Primary energy demand in Asean countries grew 60% between 2000 and 2015, with the region's economy projected to triple by 2040. To meet this growth while ensuring access to electricity for 64 million people, nearly $3 trillion will be invested in power generation by 2040. The IEA emphasizes the importance of making informed choices to shape South-east Asia's energy future and achieve a cleaner, more sustainable energy mix.

site_title: US: Dow ends at fresh record as markets await ECB
summary: US stocks jumped to a record high, driven by strong earnings from Caterpillar and 3M, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.7% to its sixth record in seven sessions. The move comes ahead of a key European Central Bank meeting, where a reduction in financial stimulus support is expected. Meanwhile, European equities edged higher, and Asian markets continued their advance, with Tokyo's Nikkei reaching a 16th straight gain.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mixed; Apple supplier AMS soars
summary: European stocks closed mixed on Tuesday, with the pan-European STOXX 600 down 0.4% despite gains from Apple suppliers AMS and other companies exposed to the iPhone X introduction. AMS jumped 22% after reporting third-quarter sales above expectations, while Dialog Semiconductor and STMicroelectronics also gained. Euro zone banks rose 1.3% as Commerzbank reported hiring Goldman Sachs and Rothschild to defend against takeover bids. The European Central Bank meeting later this week is expected to highlight a potential inclination towards lower interest rates, supporting equities.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, extending winning streak
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, extending their winning streak, with the Nikkei 225 rising 0.37% and the Topix index gaining 0.34%. This marks the longest winning streak in nearly 70 years as Japan begins its corporate earnings season. The benchmark index closed at 21,885.95 and 1,762.91, respectively.

site_title: Build your future with new skills
summary: ESSEC Business School emphasizes the importance of entrepreneurial spirit and developing key skills such as creativity, innovation, and leadership for MBA students. Associate Professor Kevyn Yong advises considering career trajectory and desired skills over prestige and field of study. Employers now expect more than just a degree, seeking entrepreneurial skill sets like teamwork, digital impact, and problem-solving. ESSEC Business School's programs focus on developing these skills through project work and collaboration with industry partners.

site_title: Private equity investing no longer just for the rich
summary: Private equity investing is becoming more accessible to the general public, thanks to new regulations and alternative financing options. The Jumpstart Our Business Startups (JOBS) Act of 2012 allowed private companies to raise capital in exchange for equity, and online investment platforms combined with traditional private equity funds have bridged the gap for businesses to reach bankability. Alternative financing options include crowdfunding, marketplaces, and private exchanges, which provide a transparent and open process for entrepreneurs to raise funds and investors to access a diverse range of investment opportunities.

site_title: Energy security concerns rising for South-east Asia: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that South-east Asia's energy security concerns will rise as the region's oil production falls and energy imports increase. The region's oil demand is expected to expand from 4.7 million barrels per day to 6.6 million by 2040, driven by rising demand for mobility. Energy demand is also expected to grow by almost two-thirds, with coal accounting for 40% of the growth. The IEA urges South-east Asian countries to reform electricity subsidies to prevent wasteful consumption and incentivize investments in efficiency.

site_title: US to resume refugee admissions; 11 countries blocked
summary: The US will resume accepting refugees after a 120-day ban, but arrivals from 11 "high-risk" countries, primarily with Muslim majorities, will still be blocked. The ban, initially implemented by President Donald Trump, allowed officials to review security procedures and set tougher screening procedures. Applicants will face "enhanced" vetting, including more in-depth checks of their social media presence and connections. The review aims to improve security procedures, with enhanced vetting procedures in place for all applicants.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages predict strong performance for First Reit and Bumitama Agri, with First Reit's acquisition of hospitals and Bumitama Agri's estate in Indonesia expected to be accretive to their dividends. Credit Suisse Research also sees the Singapore offshore and marine sector recovering, with Keppel and Sembcorp Marine poised for growth due to a growing tender pipeline.

site_title: IE S'pore, IFC to help S'pore firms break into Africa, Asia markets
summary: Singapore's International Enterprise (IE) and the World Bank's International Finance Corporation (IFC) have signed an agreement to help Singapore firms break into emerging markets in Africa and Asia. The partnership aims to drive growth in these markets and enhance economic integration. IFC's development finance strategy will be supported by IE's network of overseas centres and market insights, enabling Singapore companies to access financing and expertise. This move follows IFC's recent investments in Singapore-based firms in Africa and Asia, and is part of IE's efforts to help Singapore firms capture overseas projects.

site_title: Ezion cautiously optimistic about debt refinancing plan
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based liftboat operator, is cautiously optimistic about securing noteholders' approval for its refinancing plan. The company has seen a recovery in its core liftboat business, with daily charter rates increasing by 50% and new contracts fetching rates of up to US$45,000. Despite a decline in revenue due to reduced charter rates, the group still generates positive cash flow from operations. The proposed refinancing aims to reduce debt levels and interest payments, with lenders agreeing to reduce interest costs by US$30 million per year.

site_title: Foreigners ready for MSCI's Saudi upgrade: HSBC
summary: Foreign investors, led by HSBC, are preparing for a significant stock purchase in Saudi Arabia as the country's upgrade to emerging-market status is likely, according to MSCI's classification. The upgrade could prompt US$9 billion in inflows from passive investors, a win for the Saudi bourse. Total foreign ownership is currently below 5%, but the market is on the path of fulfilling all requirements, according to HSBC's CEO. An upgrade is expected to bring more institutional money to the exchange.

site_title: Far East Orchard unit to manage 3 new Sentosa hotels
summary: Far East Orchard's indirect subsidiary, Far East Hospitality Management, will operate and manage three new hotels in Sentosa, including Village Hotel Sentosa and The Outpost Sentosa, with a total of 839 rooms. The hotels are targeted to open in mid-2019. The management agreement was entered into with Fontaine Investment Pte Ltd, a 70-30 joint venture between Far East Organization Centre and DBS Trustee. The deal is expected to have minimal impact on Far East Orchard's financials.

site_title: HK plan for new listing board for tech startups runs into uncertainty
summary: Hong Kong's plan to create a new listing board for tech startups has been met with uncertainty, with regulators urged to prioritize investor safeguards. The proposed board, unveiled in June, aims to attract companies with unique share structures and non-profitable firms. Critics worry about corporate governance, prompting Financial Secretary Paul Chan to request regulators to reassess safeguards. HKEX CEO Charles Li said the consultation has reached a consensus on direction, with further work on proposals and a second consultation underway. The proposal's future remains uncertain.

site_title: Managing your network through the cloud with Cisco Intersight
summary: Cisco introduces Intersight, a cloud-based systems management platform, to simplify enterprise networking infrastructure management. The platform reduces the need for administrators to constantly monitor software and hardware, providing automation, simplicity, and operational efficiency. With features such as cloud-hosted systems management, analytics, and machine learning, Intersight helps organizations manage distributed computing environments and provides actionable intelligence. Cisco plans to offer Intersight as a public or private cloud service, aiming to relieve the burden of maintaining systems management software and hardware, and to provide a more unified approach to managing complex networks.

site_title: BOJ sits tight amid record Japan stock rally
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has significantly reduced its buying of Japanese equity ETFs in October, amidst a record 15-day winning streak for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average. The central bank, which had been increasing its purchases as part of unprecedented stimulus, has cut its buying to 18 billion yen, down from an average of 505 billion yen in 2017. Analysts say the BOJ's reduced purchases do not necessarily indicate a change in market conditions, with many predicting the rally will continue due to strong corporate earnings and foreign investor returns.

site_title: Six clean-energy investments to trigger S$500m in business spending
summary: Singapore has secured six clean-energy investments worth S$500 million, creating 400 professional-level jobs, over the next five years. The investments include solar, micro-grids, energy storage, and digital technologies from companies like Envision Energy, GCL New Energy, and Hover Energy. A new offshore power grid system on Pulau Semakau has also attracted three new investors, further solidifying Singapore's role as a hub for clean-energy innovation in Asia.

site_title: Shifting career gears
summary: A prospective postgraduate student, Miss Malathy Kamalakaran, spent six months researching and chose a master's degree in Human Resource Management at University College Dublin (UCD) via Kaplan Singapore. The program offered a triple-crown international accreditation and was ranked within the top one percent of higher education institutions worldwide. Miss Malathy emphasized the importance of considering factors such as value, relevancy, and schedules when choosing a program, and that a specialized degree can provide an edge in employability.

site_title: SIA finalises US$13.8b order for Boeing planes; inks deal with GE Aviation
summary: Singapore Airlines has finalized a US$13.8 billion order for 39 Boeing aircraft, consisting of 20 777-9s and 19 787-10s, to be delivered from 2020/21 and 2021/22 financial years. The deal also includes six options for each aircraft type, potentially increasing the total order to 51 aircraft. The order is aimed at modernizing SIA's fleet and expanding its network, with the airline's CEO stating that the new aircraft will enable continued operation of a modern and fuel-efficient fleet.

site_title: Mobility-as-a-Service is next disruptive wave in smart mobility
summary: Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) is poised to disrupt the smart mobility landscape with its integration of various mobility modes and providers on a single digital platform. This concept addresses the demand-supply gap in transport, fueled by rapid urbanization and increasing travel journeys. MaaS has the potential to reduce congestion, increase convenience, and foster sustainable transportation options. By creating a level playing field for all players, MaaS can drive economic growth, encourage entrepreneurship, and expand to cities worldwide, including Jakarta and Bangkok. Governments can foster a conducive environment by lifting barriers, regulating payments, and promoting public-private partnerships.

site_title: Ascott Reit's DPU falls in Q3
summary: Ascott Residence Trust's (Ascott Reit) distribution per unit (DPU) for Q3 fell 28% year-over-year to 1.69 Singapore cents due to an enlarged unit base from a rights issue. Revenue rose 2% to S$126.9 million, driven by acquisitions in Germany and New York, while gross profit increased 3% to S$58.75 million. The company maintained its focus on the extended stay segment, which provides stable income, and plans to diversify its portfolio through further acquisitions.

site_title: Bitcoin pioneer says new coin to work on multiple blockchains
summary: Jeff Garzik, a key developer of Bitcoin's underlying software, has created a new digital currency called Metronome that can jump between multiple blockchains, providing users with a more stable and secure way to transfer coins. The new currency will be issued on Ethereum and can be transferred to other blockchains, including Bitcoin, without the need for online exchanges. This move aims to address the limitations of Bitcoin's blockchain and the volatility of other cryptocurrencies, potentially increasing the value and longevity of Metronome.

site_title: A stock market panic like 1987 could happen again
summary: A 30-year-old stock market panic, like the 1987 crash, could happen again due to a powerful feedback loop of human emotions and viral contagion. Research by the Nobel laureate found that investors' responses to the 1987 market collapse were driven by psychological factors, not market fundamentals. The survey revealed that rumors, narratives, and fear played a significant role in the panic, with widespread selling and a shift in mass psychology. Although regulations have been put in place to prevent another severe market collapse, the risk remains, and the situation has become worse with the ease of viral rumor transmission enabled by technology.

site_title: STI down 0.5% following pullback in US
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,334.67, down 0.5% with 1.7 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion traded. US stocks declined overnight, with the S&P 500 down 0.4%, affecting Asian markets. Banking stocks led the decline, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB falling. Despite this, some Asian bourses, such as China's Shanghai Composite and South Korea's Kospi, gained modestly. The US Federal Reserve chair appointment is expected to influence markets, while China's Communist Party Congress concluded with President Xi Jinping's second term.

site_title: Proposed RTO unlikely to be silver bullet for Dragon Group
summary: Dragon Group International is acquiring Coeur Gold Armenia for S$500 million in shares and cash through a reverse takeover. Coeur Gold holds exploration rights to mine for gold, silver, antimony, and copper in the Azatek and Sofi Bina Mineral Deposits. This is the third attempt by Coeur Gold to list on the Singapore Exchange, following previous attempts in 2013 and 2014. Despite the deal, little information is known about Coeur Gold's operations, and investors may be skeptical about the company's prospects.

site_title: 'Many Singapore firms fare poorly' in climate disclosure
summary: Singapore firms have struggled with climate disclosure, with 15 out of 29 companies failing to meet the standard. Only City Developments, Singapore Telecommunications, and Olam International secured a grade of B or above. However, globally, companies are stepping up their climate efforts, with 89% of respondents setting emissions reduction targets in 2017, and a significant increase in long-term targets aligned with climate science. This trend is attributed to the Paris Agreement and the growing recognition of the importance of climate action for corporate growth.

site_title: Construction sector unveils plan to modernise
summary: Singapore's construction industry has unveiled a plan to modernize by 2025, aiming to double the pool of professionals in digital technology, pre-fabrication, and green-building capabilities from 32,000 to 80,000. The Industry Transformation Map (ITM) will focus on increasing the use of digital technology, pre-fabrication, and green buildings, with a goal of 80% of large consultants and 60% of large builders using Building Information Modelling (BIM) by 2025. The BCA has also set targets for increasing adoption of pre-fabrication and making prices more competitive.

images.alt_text: The construction industry aims to more than double the pool of professionals in digital technology, pre-fabrication and green-building capabilities from the current 32,000 to 80,000 by 2025.

site_title: Cairnhill Mansions, adjacent site up for sale in separate tenders
summary: Cairnhill Mansions, a 61-unit condo in Singapore's prime district 9, has been launched for collective sale with a guide price of S$362 million. An adjacent freehold site, also launched for collective sale, has a guide price of S$115 million. The combined land area of both sites can accommodate up to 308 units with an average size of 70 sqm. Developers have shown keen interest, with local and foreign developers already in the running, and experts predict more prime freehold plots will come onto the market as values increase.

site_title: Brics want to build - not replace - financial structure
summary: Brics nations, comprising Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, aim to build new elements within the existing global financial framework, rather than replacing it. At the recent Brics summit, leaders emphasized the need for improved global economic governance and cooperation with institutions like the IMF, WTO, and G-20. They called for a review of IMF quotas and stressed the importance of closer cooperation between the IMF and the Brics' contingent reserve arrangement. The Brics leaders also prioritize promoting their figures to senior posts at these institutions and supporting greater financial regulatory reforms.

site_title: Trump accepts invitation to visit Singapore in 2018
summary: US President Donald Trump accepted an invitation to visit Singapore in 2018, reaffirming the "robust and enduring partnership" between the two countries over the last 51 years. Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong invited Trump to visit and expressed confidence in the strong economic and security ties between their nations, including substantial trade and investment. Trump accepted the invitation, stating that the US-Singapore relationship has made both peoples prosperous and secure.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in the White House Oval Office on Monday (Washington time). Mr Lee said he and Mr Trump discussed what more could be done to take the deep bilateral ties further.

site_title: The future is retro for ThinkPad 25
summary: Lenovo unveiled the 25th model of its iconic ThinkPad line, marking a quarter-century of the laptop's existence. The ThinkPad Anniversary Edition 25 is a limited edition with retro features, including a bright red TrackPoint nub and backlit keyboard. The device pays homage to the original aesthetics while maintaining powerful performance. ThinkPad laptops have a long legacy, revered by tech enthusiasts and collectors, and have been used in space. Lenovo chose to go retro to honor the brand's loyal fans and nostalgia.

site_title: Raffles looks to suite life as part of revamp
summary: The Raffles Hotel Singapore, a 130-year-old national monument, is undergoing a major restoration and revamp. The hotel will introduce 12 new suite categories, including Residence, Promenade, and Studio suites, when it reopens in the second half of 2018. The total number of suites will increase from 103 to 115. The hotel's Grand Ballroom will be renovated to seat up to 300 people, and new dining concepts, including the Writers Bar, will be added. The shopping arcade will also be revamped with a new Raffles Gift Shop and history gallery.

images.alt_text: Restoration of the 130-year-old property, which began in February this year, is currently in Phase 2. Phase 3 will begin in December, where the hotel will be fully closed until its official opening in 2018.

site_title: Game makers use artificial intelligence to profile players and keep them hooked
summary: Game developers are using artificial intelligence to create personalized profiles of players, predicting how long they'll play, what levels they'll achieve, and how much they'll spend. Silicon Studio Corp's software, called Yokozuna Data, uses deep-learning algorithms to mold player behavior and keep them hooked. The technology has already been adopted by three Japanese publishers and a South Korean developer, with plans to collaborate with European publishers. This approach aims to balance drawing in casual players and encouraging big spenders, a crucial aspect of the free-to-play model in the gaming industry.

site_title: Keppel Logistics' new brand taps e-commerce market
summary: Keppel Logistics has launched a new brand, UrbanFox, to tap into the growing e-commerce and urban logistics markets in the region. The integrated brand offers a full suite of services, including e-commerce channel management and last-mile fulfilment, and is integrated with online marketplaces such as Lazada and Shopee. Global brands like Kao and Mondelez are already on board, and the company plans to invest S$20 million in automation and software upgrades over the next two years. The move is expected to help businesses store, sell, and send products more effectively, with the potential to boost economic growth through the transportation and storage sector.

images.alt_text: UrbanFox, Keppel Logistics' new omnichannel logistics and channel management brand, leverages technology and automation.

site_title: Online retailers bring jobs and new life back to rust-belt communities
summary: Online retailers, including Zulily, Amazon, and Walmart, are creating jobs and revitalizing rust-belt communities by locating warehouses near highways and rail lines. Since 2010, warehouses have added hundreds of thousands of jobs, with many in rural areas, at a rate four times faster than overall job growth. Companies like Amazon and Walmart are drawn to these areas due to cheap land and labor, and the resulting growth has made these communities thriving hubs for global trade.

images.alt_text: Warehouses - such as Walmart's fulfilment centre in Bethlehem (above) - have produced hundreds of thousands of jobs since the recovery began in 2010, adding workers at four times the rate of overall job growth.
Ms Gaugler fulfilling orders at the Zulily warehouse where she earns US$13.50 an hour working 10-hour shifts four days a week.

site_title: Changi Airport's T4 carries out rehearsal as it prepares for Oct 31 launch
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 (T4) conducted a full-dress rehearsal for its Oct 31 launch, involving 1,500 staff, tenants, and airlines. The rehearsal included systems checks, fire evacuation exercises, and asset transfers. The two-storey terminal has completed necessary inspections and audits. Nine airlines, including Cathay Pacific, AirAsia, and Vietnam Airlines, will move into T4 over a one-week period, with 3,000 staff working from the terminal. The rehearsal is part of T4's preparations for its launch.

site_title: When words of comfort reopen old wounds
summary: US Chief of Staff John Kelly and Rep. Frederica Wilson are at odds over a condolence call made by President Donald Trump to a grieving war widow. Kelly called Wilson an "empty barrel" after she claimed to have heard the call, which Trump denied. Wilson's defenders argue Kelly's attack was racist, but Kelly's critics say he was defending Trump. The controversy has sparked a heated debate in Washington, with some accusing Trump and his aides of bigotry and racism. The incident has dominated the news cycle, with the widow of Sgt. La David Johnson confirming Wilson's account, and Trump defending his call.

images.alt_text: Frederica Wilson, a Florida Democrat, at the burial of US Army Sergeant La David Johnson in Hollywood, Florida last weekend.

site_title: India embarks on U$32.4b recapitalisation to boost economy
summary: India's Cabinet approved a $32.43 billion recapitalization plan for state banks over two years to boost the economy, following a three-year low growth rate. This move aims to tackle the economic drag and create jobs for the million new workers entering the workforce each month. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to boost growth have been hindered by this issue.

site_title: Revolutionary but not disruptive
summary: Cisco's cloud-based systems management platform, Intersight, aims to deliver major benefits to users without being too difficult to use. The platform combines the simplicity of the cloud with actionable intelligence derived from analytics and machine learning, relieving users of the burden of maintaining systems management software and hardware. Intersight will provide customers with reduced manual effort, better insights to improve performance, reduce outages, and lower the overall cost of management. The platform is designed to be straightforward and will continually improve, add features and functionality, with a focus on security and iron-clad security protocols.

site_title: Fewer affordable housing units for lower-income US families
summary: The number of affordable housing units for very low-income US families decreased by over 60% between 2010 and 2016, according to a report by Freddie Mac. At first financing, 11% of nearly 100,000 rental units were deemed affordable, but by second financing, just 4% were categorized as affordable due to increased rents. The report highlights the "rapidly diminishing supply of affordable housing" and suggests that without government subsidies, affordable housing without rent control is becoming extinct.

images.alt_text: Freddie Mac says the number of apartments deemed affordable for very low-income families across the US fell by more than 60 per cent between 2010 and 2016.

site_title: Emerging market debt in sweet spot: Blackrock
summary: BlackRock's managing director Ernesto Bettoni says emerging market debt is in a "sweet spot" due to synchronised global growth, low volatility, and US dollar weakness. Returns are expected to be moderate, around 5-6%, but not double-digit. The World Bank predicts emerging markets will expand 4.1% this year. Blackrock has seen inflows into actively managed emerging debt, with $5.9 billion in net inflows from January to September, exceeding full-year 2016 and 2015 net inflows. The firm takes a thematic approach to alpha, focusing on growth cycles and commodity prices, and aims to provide a positive and smoother ride under different environments.

images.alt_text: "In our opinion, EM debt is not just about getting the largest return all the time by keeping a high beta and taking lots of risk. It is about being consistent." - Blackrock's MD and product strategist for EM debt.

site_title: Central bank review sends Kiwi to 5-month low
summary: The New Zealand dollar fell to a five-month low after the incoming Labour government outlined its policies, seen as unfriendly to foreign investment. The government aims to reduce immigration, raise the minimum wage, and ban foreigners from buying local homes. This move was viewed negatively by investors, leading to a decline in the Kiwi currency.

site_title: Pimco sees China refraining from broad-based deleveraging
summary: Pimco predicts China's deleveraging campaign will create pockets of pain in markets over the next year without significantly curtailing borrowing. Chinese companies will be able to refinance most of their borrowings as authorities refrain from broad-based deleveraging. The debt stock is expected to remain high, contributing to its expansion faster than nominal GDP. Pimco is overweight on state-owned enterprises with good credit ratings and underweight on provincial state-run firms, investment-grade property developers, and financial companies.

site_title: Netflix sells US$1.6b of junk bonds to fund more shows
summary: Netflix Inc sold US$1.6 billion of junk-rated bonds to fund new hit series, its largest-ever US dollar-denominated sale. The 10.5-year notes yield 4.875%, slightly below initial talks of 4.75-5%. This financing will help the streaming giant develop and produce new shows like Stranger Things.

site_title: Aramco IPO on track for 2018, Saudi Arabia reassures investors
summary: Saudi Arabia reassured investors that it's on track to sell a stake in oil giant Aramco in 2018, with the kingdom planning to sell a 5% stake in Saudi Arabian Oil Co. Aramco CEO Amin Nasser stated that "things are on track for 2018," but the decision on the international IPO is in the hands of the government. The sale could value Aramco at up to $2 trillion, with estimates suggesting it could raise $100 billion. A conference in Riyadh gathered global finance leaders, including HSBC CEO Stuart Gulliver and IMF chief Christine Lagarde, to discuss the IPO.

images.alt_text: From left: Mr Al-Rumayyan, Ms Lagarde, and Mr Nasser at the Future Investment Initiative conference in Riyadh on Oct 24.

site_title: People-friendly budget expected from Najib ahead of election
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is expected to unveil a people-friendly budget ahead of the country's election, which must be held within 10 months. The budget aims to address rising costs of living and will likely include handouts for civil servants, middle-income earners, and affordable housing initiatives. Najib faces a challenge from former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who has accused him of wrongdoing in a 1MDB scandal. Economists expect the new budget's fiscal deficit target to be slightly below 3% and hope it will boost spending without disappointing foreign investors.

site_title: VW, Daimler offices searched in EU probe into illegal collusion
summary: EU investigators searched the offices of Daimler and Volkswagen as part of an inquiry into allegations of illegal collusion among Germany's three major vehicle manufacturers. Regulators are examining whether the companies worked together to fix vehicle equipment prices, including emissions controls. The searches are a preliminary step in the investigation, which comes as the companies face backlash over their efforts to evade diesel emissions rules. Possible collusion is being looked into, with discussions between manufacturers potentially being illegal if they agreed to limit competition.

site_title: Japan's carmakers set to show future of motoring
summary: Japan's top automakers, including Nissan, Toyota, and Honda, will showcase their futuristic technologies at the Tokyo Motor Show. Despite recent scandals, the industry aims to demonstrate its commitment to electric and autonomous vehicles. Nissan will unveil its latest electric model, while Toyota will introduce a hydrogen fuel cell concept with improved driving range. Honda will debut its Sports EV Concept and a new Segway-like device. Analysts see these innovations as a sign that Japanese automakers remain trend-setters in automotive technology, but face increased competition from China in the electric vehicle market.

images.alt_text: Some analysts see the carmakers' innovations as confirmation that Japanese automakers are still trend-setters when it comes to automotive technology.

site_title: Fast food outlets are California's ally in climate change fight
summary: California fast food restaurants are using diesel brewed from fats and oils to fuel their vehicles, supporting the state's fight against climate change. The practice, which began seven years ago, has been adopted by cities and companies across the state. This alternative fuel source is being used in various vehicles, including fire engines and delivery vehicles. The move is seen as a significant contribution to California's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change.

site_title: Delphi buys self-driving car startup NuTonomy for US$450m
summary: Delphi Automotive agreed to acquire self-driving startup NuTonomy for US$450 million, expanding its team of engineers and scientists to develop autonomous driving software. The acquisition will speed up Delphi's plans to supply automakers with autonomous vehicle systems. The deal includes operations in Boston, Pittsburgh, Singapore, and other locations, and is expected to close later this year.

site_title: Lenovo 'torture chamber' that whips its ThinkPads into shape
summary: Lenovo's ThinkPad, a durable laptop line, has undergone rigorous testing at the Yamato Lab in Yokohama, Japan, for 25 years. Described as a "torture chamber," the lab pushes the laptops to their limits to ensure they meet the company's high standards. Lenovo's innovative approach to product development involves a customer-centric strategy, incorporating feedback from top customers and analysts, as well as embracing a culture of entrepreneurship that allows for the introduction of new products and services.

images.alt_text: And as Lenovo continually innovates and evolves its PC (personal computer) offerings, it is also "attacking growth segments" such as gaming, detachables, workstations, augmented reality, virtual reality, augmented intelligence and smart devices.

site_title: 'I'm now the most humorous person in the world': Letterman on Mark Twain prize
summary: David Letterman, a renowned late-night host, received the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Letterman's 33-year career was marked by his unique blend of humor, wit, and irreverence. Tributes from comedians Jimmy Kimmel, Norm Macdonald, and John Mulaney praised his influence on American comedy. Letterman, who stepped down from late-night television in 2015, has continued to use his platform for social causes, including climate change awareness and advocating for Donald Trump's removal from office. He is now "the most humorous person in the world," according to himself, after accepting the prestigious award.

site_title: Thai retailers banking on consumer spending as mourning period ends
summary: Thai retailers are optimistic about consumer spending rebounding once the year-long mourning period for King Bhumibol Adulyadej ends on October 29. Household consumption accounts for half of Thailand's US$407 billion GDP, and subdued spending amid mourning has led to a preference for monochrome clothing. The success of this rebound will determine the strength of a Thai economic rebound.

site_title: Nokia to test Asia's first elderly-fall prediction system
summary: Nokia has partnered with St Luke's Eldercare in Singapore to trial Asia's first elderly-fall prediction system, a video analytics application that uses machine learning to predict falls among the elderly. The system analyzes walking speed, gait width, and step width to send alerts to caregivers when a risk of falling is detected. The trial, which will last 3-6 months, aims to provide personalized and predictive solutions to prevent falls and improve elderly care.

site_title: Risky business set to dominate high-yield bond market in 2018
summary: For 2018, the European high-yield bond market is expected to shift towards leveraged buyouts and lower-rated credits, driven by yield-hungry investors. This change is a departure from the year's initial trend of big but boring refinancings. The market's increased activity is partly due to the abundance of supply and ultra-low funding costs secured by borrowers in 2017. As a result, investors are seeking higher yields, leading to a greater share of bond sales by leveraged buyouts and lower-rated credits.

site_title: Toshiba boss apologises as shareholders blast US$18b sale of chip business
summary: Toshiba's president, Satoshi Tsunakawa, apologized sincerely to shareholders over the $18-billion sale of its prized memory chip business, citing concerns over the deal's impact on the company's survival. Shareholders expressed frustration, demanding answers about the pivotal deal. The sale is seen as crucial for Toshiba's survival, but the apology and uncertainty surrounding the deal highlight the challenges facing the Japanese electronics giant.

site_title: China enshrines 'Xi Jinping Thought', cementing his power ahead of 2nd term
summary: China's ruling Communist Party enshrined President Xi Jinping's 'Xi Jinping Thought' into its constitution, cementing his power ahead of a second term. The move includes his Belt and Road initiative, a key infrastructure project linking China with neighboring countries. Wang Qishan, a key Xi ally, was not named to the Politburo Standing Committee, sparking speculation about his future role. This development solidifies Xi's control over the party and sets the stage for his second five-year term, potentially extending his rule until 2027.

site_title: Investors find returns in industrial conglomerates with digital divisions
summary: Investors are finding returns in industrial conglomerates with digital divisions, such as Siemens and ABB, due to their growing software and systems capabilities. These companies are adding value to customers in traditionally commodity-driven sectors by improving product design, testing, and manufacturing efficiency. Digital divisions are outperforming legacy fossil fuel businesses and attracting investors seeking alternative technology plays. While growth opportunities are limited by legacy businesses, the trend towards separate reporting of digital earnings allows investors to see the value of these emerging businesses.

images.alt_text: ABB is winning investors' attention thanks to its robotics segment, although oil & gas, mining and other industries still account for more than 40 per cent of company revenues.

site_title: Malaysia asked Interpol to locate Jho Low, but case now closed, says DPM
summary: Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi stated that the country had asked Interpol to locate Jho Low, a Malaysian financier accused of misappropriating billions from a state fund, but now believes the case is closed. The US Justice Department has filed civil lawsuits seeking to seize assets allegedly bought with stolen funds, but no charges have been filed against Low. Zahid Hamidi expressed confidence that Interpol has acted professionally and that the police have no further information to pursue the case.

site_title: Halep, Wozniacki heat up centre court
summary: Simona Halep faces off against Caroline Wozniacki in a potential tennis classic at the Singapore Indoor Stadium. Halep, currently ranked No. 1 on the women's professional tennis tour, seeks her second consecutive match victory. This match follows her historic No. 1 ranking achieved just two weeks prior.

images.alt_text: Halep (left), who beat Garcia on Monday, will play against Wozniacki (right) on Wednesday evening. Wozniacki defeated Svitolina 6-2, 6-0.

site_title: US: Strong McDonald's, Caterpillar profits boost Dow
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average pushed back into record territory after strong earnings from companies like Caterpillar and McDonald's. Caterpillar surged 6.6% and McDonald's jumped 2.5% after reporting tripled and nearly 50% profit increases, respectively. The Dow rose 0.6% to 23,420.98, while the S&P 500 added 0.1% to 2,566.92, despite the Nasdaq Composite Index losing 0.1%.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 21% increase in net profit for the third quarter, reaching S$235.5 million, compared to the same period last year. For the nine months, the group's net profit was S$732.9 million, an 86% increase.

site_title: Hudson's Bay selling Lord & Taylor 5th Ave building for US$850m
summary: Canadian retailer Hudson's Bay Co sold its Lord & Taylor Fifth Avenue building to WeWork for US$850 million, with WeWork and Rhone Capital also investing US$500 million in the company. The flagship store will continue operations through the 2018 holiday season before being converted into WeWork's headquarters. The deal aims to reduce Hudson's Bay debt by C$1.6 billion and increase liquidity. This follows pressure from investors to explore options for its real estate assets, with real estate activist investor Jonathan Litt previously threatening to launch a proxy fight.

site_title: How money could unblock the Brexit talks
summary: The UK's Brexit negotiations have reached an impasse, and a compromise is needed to avoid a "clean break" with the EU. Prime Minister Theresa May's proposal to make annual budget contributions of 10 billion euros (S$16 billion) for a transition period of at least two years could unlock the talks. This would involve a mutually beneficial transition modelled on the EU's relationship with Norway, acknowledging the interdependence of finance and trade. The proposal could also create a "deep and special partnership" with Europe, but its success depends on May's true intentions and the EU's willingness to accept the offer.

site_title: Energy security concerns rising for South-east Asia: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that energy security concerns are rising in South-east Asia due to declining oil production and increasing energy imports. The region's countries are urged to reform electricity subsidies to prevent wasteful consumption and incentivize efficiency investments. This move aims to avoid a drain on fiscal resources and promote sustainable energy practices.

site_title: It makes sense for South-east Asia to go for clean energy
summary: South-east Asia's energy outlook is expected to grow significantly, with primary energy demand increasing by 60% between 2000 and 2015. To achieve this growth, nearly $3 trillion will need to be invested in power generation by 2040, with the choice of energy sources having a significant impact on the region's future. If decisions are made to pursue "climate-safe" pathways, South-east Asia can avoid 75% increase in energy-related CO2 emissions by 2040, but if business-as-usual policies are adopted, coal power plants will account for 40% of growth, leading to 75% increase in emissions.

site_title: Raqqa liberated, but Middle East remains a cauldron of chaos
summary: Syrian city of Raqqa, captured by ISIS in 2014, has been liberated by Syrian-Kurdish forces backed by the US. This marks a significant advance in the military campaign against ISIS, which has also retaken the Iraqi city of Mosul. While the momentum is now with the forces fighting ISIS, a coherent strategy to rebuild and stabilize Iraq and Syria is crucial to prevent growing ethnic and sectarian tensions that could lead to military conflicts between regional powers. The defeat of ISIS forces in Syria and Iraq is a major step towards vanquishing the group, but challenges remain.

site_title: S Korea to tighten mortgage curbs for multiple-home owners
summary: South Korea will impose stricter mortgage curbs for multiple-home owners starting in 2018, aiming to curb binge borrowing and prevent household debt from growing too rapidly. The new rules will require lenders to consider the principal balance of existing debt when assessing a borrower's credit worthiness for new loans. The move follows a 10.4% increase in household debt to 1.388 trillion won and comes amid concerns about the nation's economy being exposed to a crash. The government aims to prevent excessive debt expansion and restrain private consumption and economic growth.

site_title: MIT, Mapletree in JV to acquire 14 US data centres for US$750m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has partnered with Mapletree Investment to acquire 14 US data centres for US$750 million. The move aims to gain a foothold in the world's largest data centre market. The acquisition is funded through a combination of equity and debt financing, with MIT also proposing a private placement to raise up to S$125 million. The deal is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2017. This marks a significant expansion for MIT, which has reported a 6% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit for the second quarter.

site_title: Harry Potter still casting his spell over Bloomsbury revenues
summary: Bloomsbury's revenue rose 15% in the first half of 2017, driven by special editions of JK Rowling's Harry Potter And The Philosopher's Stone, which increased Harry Potter revenue by 40%. The company's children's trade division delivered an "outstanding" performance, with print revenue more than nine times e-book revenue. Bloomsbury reported revenue of £72.1 million and adjusted pretax profit of £2.5 million, up 74%. The company's second-half list, including new Harry Potter editions and cookery titles, is expected to drive further growth.

site_title: Ezra Holdings' deadline extension for restructuring plan approved
summary: Ezra Holdings, an offshore-services provider, has had its restructuring plan deadline extended to November 13, 2017, by the US Bankruptcy Court. The company will continue to pay vendors for ongoing operations until the plan is finalized. Salaries to employees and certain unsecured debts to critical vendors have been approved. Payments to secured bank creditors and other unsecured creditors have not been made. The company will not pay interest due on certain notes until the plan is finalized, and an informal meeting with noteholders will be held once the plan is near-finalized.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler's SUV shift fuels profit jump as sales decline
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) reported a 17% jump in third-quarter profit to 1.76 billion euros, driven by a shift to lucrative SUVs such as the Jeep Compass and Maserati Levante. Despite weaker sales and deliveries, the company's margins increased to 6.7% from 5.6% last year. CEO Sergio Marchionne is prioritizing profit over growth to prepare the company for his departure in April 2019 and to shore up the balance sheet.

site_title: India approves 2.11 trillion rupees state bank recapitalization plan
summary: India's government approved a 2.11 trillion rupees ($44.2 billion) state bank recapitalization plan over two years to clean banks' books and revive investment. The plan includes 1.35 trillion rupees from recapitalization bonds, 760 billion rupees from budgetary support and equity issuance. The move aims to address the stubborn bad debt problem and meet global Basel III banking rules, which require additional capital by March 2019.

site_title: GM's earnings beat, forecast lift shares; supply glut shrinks
summary: General Motors (GM) reported a stronger-than-expected pre-tax profit for the third quarter, beating forecasts. The company's shares rose to their highest levels since 2010 due to a reaffirmed full-year earnings outlook and a promise to slash stocks of unsold vehicles. GM expects US vehicle sales to remain stable at 17 million light vehicles in 2017 and 2018. The results were largely driven by a shrinking supply glut, which contributed to the company's improved financial performance.

site_title: Italy proposes phasing out coal power plants by 2025
summary: Italy plans to phase out coal power plants by 2025, according to a consultation document on a new energy strategy. The strategy aims to reach 27% of renewable energy consumption by 2030 and speed up the introduction of alternative fuel vehicles. The plan also includes increasing electric charging stations to 19,000 by 2020. Italy's largest utility, Enel, has committed to not investing in new coal-fired power plants. The government is expected to approve the strategy at the beginning of November.

site_title: Marco Polo seeks big haircut for S$50m notes
summary: Marco Polo Marine is seeking approval from noteholders to take a significant haircut and waive key obligations for a S$50 million series of 5.75% notes due 2016. The company proposes redeeming the bonds by January 2018 with a combined redemption amount of S$71,736, comprising S$35,868 in cash and 1.02 million shares priced at 3.5 cents per share. The move aims to address the company's financial struggles.

site_title: Saudi Arabia launches mega-zone on Red Sea
summary: Saudi Arabia launched an independent economic zone, NEOM, on the Red Sea, spanning 470 kilometers and valued at $500 billion. The zone will be self-regulated, separate from Saudi oversight, and will be open to local and international investors. The project is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its oil-dependent economy, following a significant decline in oil revenues since 2014. NEOM's CEO is Klaus Kleinfeld, and the zone is expected to be a secure area, overlooking the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aqaba.

site_title: Aspial Corporation cancels S$6.5m worth of repurchased notes
summary: Aspial Corporation has cancelled S$6.5 million worth of repurchased notes due 2019, reducing the aggregate outstanding principal amount to S$123.5 million. The notes, issued under a S$700 million multicurrency debt issuance programme, were repurchased in the open market. The cancellation follows the company's decision to repurchase the notes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 5.33 points to 1,736.14. The FTSE 100 index saw 2.486 billion lots traded worth RM2.128 billion, with 599 losers outnumbering 276 gainers.

site_title: New cyber attacks hit airport, metro in Ukraine
summary: Cyber attacks hit Ukraine's Odessa airport and the metro system in Kiev, with the state-run CERT warning transport networks to be on high alert. The attacks, which did not appear to be a mass attack, targeted the payment system of the Kiev metro and the IT system of Odessa international airport. The central bank said the banking system was working normally. Ukraine is trying to roll out a national strategy to keep state institutions and major companies safe, amid speculation that Russia is behind regular attacks on its computer systems.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse to review CEO's future after inquiry prolonged
summary: Deutsche Boerse's supervisory board will meet on Thursday to discuss the future of CEO Carsten Kengeter amid a prolonged insider trading inquiry.
