A court blocked a settlement deal, and Kengeter denies wrongdoing. The exchange operator's shares have lost nearly 2% due to the setback. Kengeter's contract expires at the end of March 2018, and the company has said it won't renew it until the case is settled. Further investigation could lead to a closure of proceedings or an indictment, with separate investigations by regulators set to start after the Frankfurt investigation is completed.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.5% to 3,334.67, with 1.7 billion shares traded for S$1.09 billion. The index had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Losers outpaced gainers, with 222 counters down and 202 up.

site_title: Singapore eDevelopment issues, transfers shares in US subsidiaries
summary: Singapore eDevelopment Ltd announced several transactions involving its subsidiaries, Global BioMedical Inc and Global BioLife Inc. The company will allot and issue 10 ordinary shares to an executive director, and transfer 100 shares to a US-based company. These transactions are expected to have minimal impact on the company's financials. Additionally, Global BioLife Inc has developed a low-calorie sugar, Laetose, which is being collaborated with a US candy manufacturer to develop, manufacture, and distribute.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks finish at new high on earnings hopes, offsets foreign selloff
summary: South Korean stocks closed at a record high of 2,490.49 points, driven by bullish expectations for September quarter earnings. However, foreign investors sold 101.4 billion won worth of shares, offsetting gains. The South Korean won edged up due to the US dollar's weakness.

site_title: Changi Airport's T4 all set for launch on Oct 31
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 (T4) is set to open on October 31. A full dress rehearsal was conducted involving 1,500 staff, tenants, and stakeholders to test systems, fire evacuation, and asset transfer. The terminal has completed necessary inspections and audits, including a safety declaration by the Singapore Civil Defence Force. Nine airlines will move into T4 over a one-week period, starting with Cathay Pacific's arrival flight on October 31. Staff have undergone trials, training sessions, and workshops since October 2016.

site_title: Euro zone inflation expectations hit 7-month high
summary: Investor expectations for long-term inflation in the euro zone rose to a 7-month high, reaching 1.6571% in the 5-year, 5-year breakeven forward rate, as stronger economic growth, a weakening single currency, and firmer oil prices contribute to the increase. This encouraging sign supports the European Central Bank's decision to trim its monthly bond purchases, pushing up bond yields and inflation expectations. The move is seen as a positive development for the ECB, which is preparing to step back from its extraordinary monetary stimulus.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei extends longest-ever winning streak
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index extended its longest-ever winning streak, rising 0.50% to 21,805.17, for its 16th consecutive day of gains. The broader Topix index also rose 0.67%. This milestone marks a nearly 70-year history for the Nikkei.

site_title: Far East Orchard unit to manage three new Sentosa hotels
summary: Far East Orchard's indirect subsidiary, Far East Hospitality Management, has entered into a binding term sheet to manage three new Sentosa hotels: Village Hotel Sentosa, The Outpost Sentosa, and a third property yet to be branded. The hotels, with 839 rooms, are targeted to open in mid-2019. As the operator, FEHMS will be responsible for the overall management of these properties.

site_title: Nippon Life plans to increase foreign bonds without FX hedge, to cut hedged investment
summary: Nippon Life Insurance Co plans to increase its holdings of foreign bonds without currency hedging, aiming to boost returns on foreign bond investments due to low domestic bond returns. The company expects to allocate a significant portion of its 800 billion yen fresh funds to unhedged foreign bonds, increasing investment in foreign stocks as well. The shift in strategy is driven by rising dollar hedging costs, with the cost expected to rise further due to US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Tesla to build wholly-owned Shanghai plant
summary: Tesla has reached an agreement with Shanghai authorities to build a wholly-owned manufacturing facility in China, the first foreign automaker to do so. The plant will be located in Shanghai's free-trade zone and could allow Tesla to lower the cost of its cars in China. The move comes as China's electric-vehicle market is expected to continue growing, with the government planning to require a certain percentage of electric vehicles in sales by 2019. No launch timeframe was given for the plant, which will still incur a 25% import tariff.

site_title: Ezion cautiously optimistic over its refinancing proposal
summary: Ezion Holdings, a liftboat operator, is cautiously optimistic about securing noteholders' approval for its refinancing plans. The company's core liftboat business is seeing a recovery, with a 50% increase in daily charter rates and a new contract secured at $45,000 per day. Despite a decline in revenue and positive cashflow, the company's debt level is unsustainable, and refinancing is necessary to put the group on a sustainable level. A town hall meeting with noteholders is scheduled for November 2, and RSM representatives will hold clinics to address questions.

site_title: Opec working on exit strategy alongside cuts extension
summary: Opec is working on an exit strategy to ensure a smooth transition once oil production cuts expire at the end of 2018. The plan, still in development, aims to reassure investors that the market won't flood with oil, similar to central banks' tapering strategies. Opec's internal forecasts indicate the fuel-stockpile surplus will be eliminated in the third quarter of 2018. The group is likely to endorse the plan at its meeting in Vienna on November 30, with the full strategy to be unveiled later in 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall amid signs of tighter liquidity
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.5% to 28,154.97, amid signs of tighter liquidity, attributed to potential US rate hikes by year-end. The Hang Seng index declined, with nearly all sectors falling, including consumer and industrial sectors. Hong Kong's interbank fixing rate spiked to its highest level in five months.

site_title: Euro zone business remained strong as prices rise sharply -PMI
summary: The euro zone's private sector growth slowed more sharply than predicted in October, but remained strong with a Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 55.9. Firms increased prices at the steepest rate in over six years, with Germany's private sector posting the highest increase in new orders in 6-1/2 years. The robust growth is expected to lead to fourth quarter economic growth of 0.6-0.7%, faster than the predicted 0.5%.

site_title: Canon boosts profit outlook on medical equipment sales
summary: Canon has raised its annual financial projections, citing strong sales of office equipment and booming demand for medical equipment. The company revised its net profit outlook to 245 billion yen, up from an earlier estimate of 220 billion yen. This comes as demand for cameras continues to decline, but medical equipment sales contribute to the company's growth. Canon attributes the growth to replacement demand for medical equipment in developed countries and increasing medical needs in emerging countries.

images.alt_text: Japan's Canon on Tuesday raised its annual financial projections, saying demand for its office and medical equipment offset sagging demand for digital cameras as consumers increasingly turn to picture-taking smartphones.

site_title: AIMS Property Securities Fund disposes of Blackwall Property Trust stake
summary: AIMS Property Securities Fund has disposed of its holdings in Blackwall Property Trust (BWR) due to national and global effects on the real-estate market that may lead to downward value in the short to medium future. The fund sold approximately 5.8 million units at A$1.30 each, citing that the funds are better utilized in other opportunities for a more profitable outcome for unitholders. The sale was made to maintain acceptable liquidity and influence over the strategy and direction of the unlisted investment.

site_title: Lum Chang bags S$85.7m construction contract from own JV
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' subsidiary, Lum Chang Building Contractors, has been awarded a contract valued at S$85.7 million for building works at 2 Serangoon Road in Singapore. The contract, expected to be completed in the second half of 2019, includes the demolition and reconstruction of the existing main block and major refurbishment of the adjoining annex block. The contract brings the total outstanding value of construction works yet to be reported as revenue to S$600 million. Lum Chang shares rose 5.2% following the announcement.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust's DPU down 12.8% in Q3
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a 12.8% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.54 cents for Q3, primarily due to its recent rights issue. The trust's distributable income fell 0.8% to S$16.45 million, mainly affected by lower income from operations. Gross revenue declined 2.2% to S$27.43 million, and net property income (NPI) dropped 3.3% to S$21.34 million. The decline was attributed to lower revenue and higher property-related expenses resulting from the conversion of properties to multi-tenancies.

site_title: Regulators back emissions fix for Volkswagen SUVs in US
summary: US and California regulators approved Volkswagen's proposed fix for emissions systems on 38,000 SUVs with diesel V-6 engines, allowing the automaker to avoid buying back the vehicles under a $1.2 billion court settlement. Repairs have been approved for 477,000 VW and Audi vehicles with 2.0-liter engines. The remaining 40,000 vehicles with 3.0-liter diesel V-6 engines will receive modifications, including software updates and hardware changes. The fixes bring emissions into compliance with US standards without negative impacts on vehicle reliability or durability.

site_title: Hengxin Technology to delist from its secondary listing on SGX
summary: Hengxin Technology, a Chinese manufacturer of radio frequency coaxial cables, plans to voluntarily delist from its secondary listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to thin trading volume and additional administrative costs. The company will retain its primary listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKSE), which is deemed sufficient for its future debt and equity fund-raising requirements. The proposed delisting is expected to take place on February 5, 2018, after which shares will only be traded on the HKSE. Shareholders' voting rights and entitlement to dividends will remain unaffected.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to build new mega city on country's North Coast
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced plans to build a new mega city on the Red Sea coast, aiming to prepare the kingdom for the post-oil era. This latest project follows his efforts to diversify the economy, including selling a stake in Saudi Aramco and lifting the ban on female drivers. The announcement was made during the Future Investment Initiative conference in Riyadh, which hosted over 3,000 attendees, including the International Monetary Fund's Christine Lagarde.

site_title: Keppel Logistics launches new brand to provide full suite of services
summary: Keppel Logistics launches UrbanFox, a new integrated logistics brand offering e-commerce channel management, warehousing, and last-mile fulfilment. The brand aims to tap into the growing e-commerce and urban logistics markets, with global brands Kao and Mondelez already on board. UrbanFox plans to invest S$20 million in automation and process optimisation over the next two years. The move is seen as a response to the projected 39% growth in e-commerce parcel and express delivery volumes by 2020, and aims to support Singapore's logistics industry transformation, which is expected to contribute S$8.3 billion to the economy and create 2,000 new jobs by 2020.

site_title: Nokia to trial Asia's first elderly fall prediction app in Singapore
summary: Nokia is trialing Asia's first elderly fall prediction app in Singapore, developed in partnership with St Luke's Eldercare. The app uses Nokia Bell Labs' video analytics technology to analyze walking speed and gait patterns to predict falls among the elderly. The solution, integrated into Nokia's Impact IoT Platform, aims to provide caregivers with real-time information to prevent falls. This is the first-of-its-kind application in Asia, leveraging proprietary video analytics to create an unobtrusive and continuous monitoring system.

site_title: Most Singapore firms fare poorly in climate disclosure; global traction picking up
summary: Singapore companies have underperformed in climate disclosure, with 15 out of 29 assessed by CDP scoring poorly, earning failing grades. Only City Developments, Singapore Telecommunications, and CapitaLand secured a B grade or higher. Globally, 89% of companies set emissions reduction targets in 2017, with 61% committing to science-based targets. CDP's report coincides with new Singapore Exchange regulations requiring listed companies to produce sustainability reports. This comes as businesses step up climate action, driven by the Paris Agreement, and integrate sustainability into their operations.

site_title: Saudi Aramco CEO says considering New York, London, Tokyo, Hong Kong for listing
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser mentioned considering listing on New York, London, Tokyo, and Hong Kong exchanges for the state oil giant. The company plans to list in 2018 and will review detailed information before making a decision. A 2019 listing is not currently under consideration, according to Nasser.

site_title: ST Engineering's electronics arm wins S$585m in contracts in Q3
summary: ST Engineering's electronics arm secured S$585 million in contracts in Q3 2017, primarily in rail electronics, intelligent transportation, satellite communications, and advanced electronics. Contracts include systems for Bangkok's MRT Blue Line and Wuhan Metro Line 11, as well as broadband network and satellite equipment for government and enterprise users worldwide. The wins were from local and overseas customers, with S$359 million coming from the public and private sectors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.26% at the open on Tuesday, following a retreat from record highs in New York. The Hang Seng Index slipped to 28,232.62, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The sell-off is part of a broader Asia-wide downturn, with the US and EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: NetLink Trust to enhance operational procedures following S$10,000 fine
summary: NetLink Trust has enhanced its operational procedures following a S$10,000 fine imposed by the Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) for a fibre service interruption incident in December 2016. The incident was caused by an unintended splicing of a new cable segment, and NetLink has vowed to review and enhance its capabilities to prevent recurrence. IMDA's investigation found NetLink in contravention of the Telecom Service Resiliency Code, leading to the financial penalty.

site_title: Novartis sees bright future for eye unit
summary: Novartis announced a strategic review of its eye care unit Alcon, which showed strong growth potential but a possible spin-off or listing is unlikely before 2019. The firm reported a 7% increase in net profit to $2.08 billion and a 2% increase in sales to $12.4 billion in the quarter. Despite a one percent decline in net profit over the first nine months, Novartis confirmed its annual outlook of $48.5 billion in sales and $12.9 billion in operating profits. The company will continue to review Alcon's future before making a decision.

site_title: Vopak launches concurrent bunkering services at its Singapore terminal
summary: Vopak has launched concurrent bunkering services at its Singapore Sebarok oil terminal, allowing tankers to refuel while simultaneously loading or discharging cargoes. This new service aims to improve port efficiency and reduce congestion in Singapore's busy waterways. The service eliminates the need for tankers to sail to designated anchorages for refueling, addressing safety concerns. Vopak collaborated with BW Pacific, Sinanju Marine Services, and Unicore Fuel to develop the service, which will be expanded to other terminals. This move is in line with Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority's directive to enhance port efficiency.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Cairnhill Mansions are up for sale at S$362 million and S$115 million respectively. The city-state's tourism industry has doubled in the past 10 years, supporting 164,000 jobs, according to the World Travel & Tourism Council. Singapore Airlines finalized a US$13.8 billion order for Boeing planes and AIMS Property Securities Fund disposed of its holdings in Blackwall Property Trust. The construction industry aims to train 80,000 personnel in new technologies by 2025. Meanwhile, Singapore shares closed 0.5% lower, and the UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: Bitcoin pioneer says new coin to work on multiple blockchains
summary: Bitcoin pioneer Jeff Garzik has created a new digital currency called Metronome, which can jump between different blockchains, including Ethereum, Ethereum Classic, Qtum, and the bitcoin blockchain. This mobility allows Metronome owners to move their holdings to other blockchains if one dies out due to developer infighting or decreased use, providing a potential solution to blockchain instability.

site_title: MIT posts 6% rise in Q2 DPU, acquires US data centres with sponsor for US$750m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has acquired a portfolio of 14 US data centres for US$750 million, gaining a strategic entry into the world's largest data centre market. The acquisition, funded through equity and debt financing, is part of MIT's expansion into data centres worldwide. The trust posted a 6% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q2, driven by revenue from a build-to-suit project and pre-termination compensation. MIT will hold 40% interest in the US data centres through a joint venture with its sponsor Mapletree Investments.

site_title: Ikea signs Uganda coffee deal; targets cocoa and nut farmers
summary: Ikea has signed a 3-5 year partnership with Kawacom Ltd in Uganda to source single-origin Arabica coffee. The deal, valued at an unspecified amount, will provide market access and training to local farmers. Ikea aims to enhance livelihoods, build sustainable crop production, and support communities in Africa and Asia. The partnership is part of Ikea's social entrepreneur initiative, which has already involved 19 smaller-scale suppliers in handicraft and services businesses. Ikea plans to sell the coffee in 30 markets starting this autumn, with an equivalent purchase in the next fiscal year.

site_title: World wine output set to fall to lowest since 1961: OIV
summary: Global wine production is expected to fall to its lowest level since 1961, with an estimated 246.7 million hectolitres in 2017, down 8% from last year. The decline reflects harsh weather in western Europe, particularly in Italy, France, and Spain, which are projected to see sharp drops in output. The European Union's wine grape harvest is expected to shrink to a 36-year low, with France's production projected to be its lowest in decades. The reduced global production may erode a surplus over demand, but the quality of wine in landmark regions, such as France, may mitigate the impact.

site_title: 'Up to London' how Brexit ends, says EU chief
summary: European Union President Donald Tusk stated that the outcome of Brexit negotiations is "up to London," leaving the UK's decision on its future relationship with the EU uncertain. The EU is open to a deal, but also prepared for "no deal" or "no Brexit." Tusk's comments come after EU leaders agreed to start preparations for post-Brexit trade and a transition deal. The slow progress in talks has raised concerns about the UK potentially leaving the EU without a deal in March 2019, which could lead to economic and legal chaos.

site_title: Cairnhill Mansions, adjacent site up for sale at S$362m and S$115m respectively
summary: Cairnhill Mansions in Singapore's prime district 9 is launched for collective sale through a public tender with a guide price of S$362 million. An adjacent freehold site of 19,800 sq ft is also launched separately with a guide price of S$115 million. The combined sites can accommodate up to 308 units with an average size of 70 sq m, totaling 233,223 sq ft of allowable gross floor area.

site_title: Hong Kong signals may drop plan for third board for new economy firms
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan has asked regulators to review plans for a new trading board for companies with dual-class share structures, potentially dropping the proposal. The review aims to protect investor interests. This move follows public consultation, which saw financial industry professionals divided over the matter. The decision comes as Hong Kong seeks to attract "new economy" firms, similar to Alibaba Group and Baidu Inc, which have chosen US listings due to less stringent rules.

site_title: New Zealand dollar recoils as Labour talks policies, Aussie steadies
summary: The New Zealand dollar dropped to US$0.6954 after the Labour Party, led by Prime Minister-elect Jacinda Ardern, outlined left-leaning policies, including a clamp-down on foreign buyers of local housing. The currency has sunk over three cents in three sessions since the election. Investors worry that these policies could threaten New Zealand's strong economic track record.

site_title: Europe: Shares swing sideways as Q3 earnings keep rolling in
summary: European shares traded sideways on Tuesday, with the pan-European STOXX 600 flat and London's FTSE 100 down 0.1%. Apple supplier AMS surged 15% after its earnings report, while peers Dialog Semiconductor and STMicroelectronics rose. Spain's Caixabank lifted the IBEX 30 with a 2.3% gain after posting a 53% jump in nine-month net profit. Conversely, mining company Boliden fell 9% after its trading update. Despite the mixed results, some stocks rose due to order bookings and profits above market forecasts, including Saab and other defense firms.

site_title: Singapore tourism doubled in 10 years, supports 164,000 jobs: WTTC
summary: Singapore's tourism has doubled in 10 years to $12.4 billion, supporting 164,000 jobs, according to the World Travel & Tourism Council (WTTC). Chinese cities are driving tourism growth at a 5.8% annual rate, with Chongqing leading at 14% growth. The WTTC notes that travel and tourism contribute $7.6 trillion to global GDP and 292 million jobs, or 10% of all jobs.

site_title: DP World Q3 gross container volumes rise 13.5%
summary: DP World reported a 13.5% increase in third-quarter gross container volumes to 18,282 TEUs, exceeding full-year market expectations. This growth was driven by terminals in the Americas and Australia, with 18.1% growth, and Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, with 14.3% growth. The UAE, part of the Europe, Middle East, and Africa region, saw a 5.3% increase in container volumes.

site_title: EDB bags six new investments in clean energy
summary: The Economic Development Board (EDB) in Singapore has secured six new clean energy investments worth S$500 million, creating 400 jobs over five years. The investments include a global digital research center by Envision Energy, energy storage capabilities by VDE Renewables and Narada, and micro-grid systems by REIDS, a partnership between Nanyang Technological University and several companies. These projects aim to develop innovative clean energy solutions for Southeast Asia and beyond.

site_title: IE Singapore, IFC to lend Singapore firms entering Asia and Africa a hand
summary: IE Singapore and the International Finance Corporation (IFC) have signed an agreement to support Singapore firms entering emerging markets in Asia and Africa. The World Bank forecasts 4.1% growth in emerging markets, driving demand for infrastructure. The two institutions will co-host market-focused workshops for Singapore companies to share insights on business opportunities, financing landscapes, and financing partners. This collaboration aims to help Singapore companies tap into the growing economies of Asia and Africa.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after record run of gains
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.20% lower on Tuesday, snapping its 15th consecutive gain and retreating from record levels on Wall Street. The broader Topix index also declined 0.05%. The losses came after a record-breaking run of gains, with the Nikkei reaching a 70-year high. The decline was attributed to a breather after the long winning streak and retreats from record levels.

site_title: Top Glove in talks to buy glove maker, but no final terms yet
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian-based rubber glove maker, is in talks to acquire a glove manufacturer but has not finalized terms. The company denied reports of acquiring Adventa Bhd or Supermax Corp Bhd. The planned acquisition's terms and conditions have not been released, leaving the deal's status uncertain.

site_title: Japan carmakers look to future at Tokyo Motor Show amid scandals
summary: Japan's major carmakers will showcase futuristic technologies at the Tokyo Motor Show, including hydrogen-fueled cars and electric vehicles with longer driving ranges. Amid scandals and regulatory scrutiny, Nissan is keeping its marquee product under wraps, while Toyota will unveil a fuel cell-driven concept and Honda will debut an AI-powered electric sportscar. Despite innovations, analysts warn that Japanese carmakers may face increased competition from China in the EV market, potentially putting them at risk of falling behind overseas rivals.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 1.54 points to 1,743.01. The index saw 126 gainers for every 96 losers, with a total trading volume of 113.43 million lots worth RM67.4 million.

site_title: Marco Polo seeks noteholders' nod on haircut, waivers for 5.75% bonds due 2016
summary: Marco Polo Marine is seeking noteholders' approval to reduce the value of its 5.75% bonds due 2016 by 29.2% and waive certain obligations. The company is proposing a redemption amount of S$71,736, which includes S$35,868 in cash and 20,868 shares priced at 3.5 Singapore cents each. A noteholders' meeting is scheduled for November 15 at Ocean Financial Centre.

site_title: South Korea to tighten mortgage rules for owners of multiple homes
summary: South Korea plans to tighten mortgage rules for multiple home owners starting in 2018, aiming to curb binge borrowing and prevent household debt from negatively impacting the economy. The new rules will require lenders to consider the borrower's existing debt when evaluating creditworthiness for new loans. This move follows a surge in household debt, which has reached 10.4% growth in the second quarter, with the total debt totaling 1.388 trillion won. The goal is to assess debt obligations from the first home to prevent excessive borrowing.

site_title: US SEC to require greater transparency around company audits
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) will require companies to disclose remarks and inquiries made by independent auditors during audits. This change aims to increase transparency, helping investors better understand potential risks and the interactions between auditors and companies. The new rule, effective immediately, was created by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board and approved by the SEC. It will require auditors to disclose discussions with companies and information on how they reached conclusions about individual companies. This move was urged by transparency advocates to improve investor understanding of audit processes.

site_title: Kobe Steel plant under inspection by Japan ministry
summary: Japan's transport ministry is inspecting Kobe Steel's Daian plant, which produces aluminium used in a passenger aircraft, amid a product data cheating scandal. The inspection began on Monday, with no concerns raised by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries about the safety of the aluminium parts supplied by Kobe Steel. The plant's aluminium is used in the aircraft being developed by Mitsubishi Heavy, which has stated there are no concerns over safety. The inspection is part of an ongoing investigation into Kobe Steel's data falsification.

site_title: Xi tightens grip on China as name added to Communist constitution
summary: Chinese leader Xi Jinping's name was added to the Communist Party's constitution at a defining congress, cementing his place as the most powerful leader in decades. This move elevates him alongside Chairman Mao, solidifying his position as paramount leader. Xi's name, along with his guiding philosophy, will be included in the document, making him the third Chinese leader to have his name in the constitution, after Mao and Deng Xiaoping.

images.alt_text: Chinese leader Xi Jinping's name was added to the Communist Party's constitution at a defining congress on Tuesday, elevating him alongside Chairman Mao to the pantheon of the country's founding giants.

site_title: Australian shares rise on materials, real estate stocks; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 5,898.9, driven by gains in materials stocks, including South32 Ltd and Newcrest Mining, which rose 1.9% and 1.2% respectively. Retail property developer Scentre Group also added 1.8% to the index. Financial stocks fell, while US stocks retreated from record positions. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1% to 8,135.27, with The a2 Milk Company Ltd reaching an all-time high.

site_title: Ezion to hold third informal meeting with securityholders on Nov 2
summary: Ezion Holdings will hold a third informal meeting with securityholders on November 2 to provide a summary of the consent solicitation exercise (CSE) and answer queries. The CSE, set for November 20, involves the restructuring of the company's debt. The meeting will be facilitated by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore). Shareholders and securityholders are advised to carefully read the announcement and consult with their stockbrokers, bank managers, or solicitors if they have any doubts.

site_title: Singapore Poly, Japan consultancy ICMG to promote food science and technology
summary: Singapore Polytechnic's Food Innovation and Resource Centre (FIRC) has signed a memorandum of understanding with Japanese consultancy ICMG to promote collaborations in food science and technology. The partnership aims to facilitate the exchange of technical expertise and knowledge between Singapore and Japanese companies. A Food Innovation Platform will be established to share ideas, create new business models, and enhance commercialization in the Singapore food industry. Nippon Closure Company Limited will house Japanese capping machines in the FIRC, offering a range of packaging choices for their products.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Marco Polo, Ascott Reit, Great Eastern
summary: Singapore Airlines finalized a $13.8 billion order for 39 Boeing aircraft, with options for up to 51 planes. Marco Polo Marine is seeking to waive obligations for $50 million in notes due 2016. Ascott Residence Trust's third-quarter DPU dropped 28% to 1.69 cents, while Great Eastern Holdings reported a 21% increase in net profit to $235.5 million.

site_title: Kim Jong Nam murder suspects visit airport crime scene
summary: Two women, Indonesian Siti Aisyah and Vietnamese Doan Thi Huong, visited the Kuala Lumpur International Airport's budget terminal where Kim Jong Nam, the North Korean leader's half-brother, was allegedly poisoned. The suspects, accompanied by police and court officials, were escorted to the airport to mark a significant step in the trial. The visit took place amid heavy police presence, with over 200 officers in attendance, wearing masks and armed with rifles. The move is seen as a crucial development in the case, allowing the women to see the crime scene and potentially aid in their defense.

images.alt_text: Two women on trial for murdering the North Korean leader's half-brother visited the Malaysian airport on Tuesday where they allegedly poisoned him, escorted by huge numbers of heavily armed police.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares eke out modest gains on resource stocks support
summary: Australian shares rose 0.06% on Tuesday, driven by gains in commodity prices and material stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index increased 3.638 points to 5,897.6, with mining giants BHP Billiton and South32 contributing to the gains. Gold stocks also rose, while bank stocks declined, led by Australia and New Zealand Banking. New Zealand's benchmark index was little changed, with consumer staples dominating gains and healthcare stocks losing traction.

site_title: Retailers hope US$188b engine of Thai economy will revive
summary: Retailers in Thailand are hopeful that a yearlong mourning period for King Bhumibol Adulyadej will end on October 29, leading to a revival in consumer spending worth about half of the country's US$407 billion GDP. Consumer spending has been subdued amid grief, with households preferring monochrome clothing. A five-day, US$90 million cremation ceremony is expected to conclude the mourning period, potentially boosting spending. However, elevated household debt and structural forces may limit the impact, with exports and tourism driving the current economic growth.

site_title: Lippo Malls Retail Trust in early talks on possible rights issue
summary: Lippo Malls Retail Trust (LMIRT) is in early talks with investment banks about a possible rights issue to fund acquisitions and reduce debt. The trust, which manages Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIR Trust), has confirmed discussions are underway but no deal is expected. LMIRT has also considered other means of equity fundraising, with no plans to raise capital this year. Unitholders and shareholders are advised to exercise caution when dealing in its units and securities.

site_title: Asia: Shares hover near recent highs; NZ dollar slips
summary: Asian shares near decade highs, with major currencies trading within narrow ranges. The New Zealand dollar fell after the incoming Labour government's left-leaning policies, seen as unfriendly to foreign investment and immigration, were announced. The kiwi currency shed early gains to trade at US$0.6953, down from a five-month trough of US$0.6932.

site_title: US dollar edges down as attention turns to Fed leadership
summary: The US dollar edged down on Tuesday as investors awaited news on the Federal Reserve leadership, with President Trump stating he's "very, very close" to deciding on a new head. The dollar index dropped 0.1% to 93.817, while the euro added 0.1% to US$1.1754. A more hawkish Fed candidate could boost the dollar, but investors are also watching US tax reform developments. The Japanese yen strengthened against the dollar after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's coalition secured a decisive victory in the general election.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.2% or 6.14 points to 3,343.66 at 9:03am on Tuesday, following US stocks' retreat from record highs due to a drop in technology shares and industrial heavyweights. About 33.2 million shares changed hands, with 64 gainers to 62 losers.

site_title: In record Japan stock rally, the BOJ is sitting on its hands
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has significantly reduced its buying of Japanese stocks in October, with a 15-day winning streak in the Nikkei 225 Stock Average. The BOJ's reduced purchases come as the market reaches a record high, with the Nikkei 225 closing at its highest since 1996. Analysts attribute the BOJ's reduced involvement to the market's strength, with some predicting further gains. The BOJ aims to buy 6 trillion yen in ETFs annually, but its reduced purchases suggest that the market may continue to rise without its support.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records; GE, tech shares fall
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average ending down 0.2% at 23,273.96. General Electric shares plummeted 6.4% amid a downgraded earnings report. The broader S&P 500 fell 0.4% and the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.6%. Skepticism over earnings justifying soaring stock values and uncertainty over tax cuts contributed to the market decline. Nearly 200 companies from the S&P 500 are scheduled to report results this week, including General Motors and Amazon.

site_title: Fox protected Bill O'Reilly from harassment claims: Megyn Kelly
summary: Megyn Kelly accuses Fox News of protecting Bill O'Reilly from harassment claims, citing an email she sent in 2016 about settlements between O'Reilly and several women. Kelly claims management was aware of the settlements, and Bill Shine allegedly promised to "take care of" O'Reilly. O'Reilly denies having any complaints filed against him, but Fox News has since taken steps to increase reporting channels for harassment or discrimination. The move comes after O'Reilly settled a $32 million sexual harassment claim with Fox legal analyst Lis Wiehl and was later fired.

site_title: Australia to train Philippines in urban warfare
summary: Australia will train Filipino soldiers in urban warfare to counter Islamic extremism after a five-month battle in the southern city of Marawi, which claimed over 1,100 lives. The training aims to enhance the Philippines' capabilities to combat the spread of the Islamic State group. This move follows Australia's ongoing military aid to the Philippines since September, including surveillance and information-gathering support. The declaration of victory in Marawi marks a significant milestone in the Philippines' efforts to combat extremism.

site_title: Airbus turmoil clouds bid to rescue Bombardier's CSeries jets
summary: Airbus has acquired Bombardier's CSeries jets for a dollar, but internal disarray at the European planemaker raises questions about its ability to implement the deal smoothly. The acquisition comes as Airbus faces falling sales and corruption investigations, with some employees shying away from selling in problematic countries. Airbus CEO Tom Enders has defended his decision to report flawed paperwork to UK authorities, but the company's sales operation remains demoralized and in disarray. The deal is expected to close next year, with Airbus facing a second challenge in marketing the CSeries alongside its A320 model.

site_title: Noble flags Q3 loss of over US$1b, selling oil unit to Vitol
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-listed commodities trading firm, has issued its third consecutive quarterly profit warning, citing massive potential net losses of $1.1 billion to $1.25 billion for the third quarter. The company is selling its oil-liquids business to Vitol Group for $582 million, which may cushion the blow. Analysts expect Noble to conduct a liability-management exercise, possibly in the form of a debt exchange/extension plan, and are closely watching the company's cash burn levels.

site_title: Australia publishes draft laws for relaxed fintech regulation
summary: The Australian government has published draft laws that would allow financial technology companies to operate without a full licence, aiming to encourage innovation while maintaining consumer protection. The draft laws would permit companies to test products in areas such as non-cash payments, crowdfunding, and financial advice, while still adhering to robust consumer protection requirements. The move is seen as part of Australia's efforts to develop Sydney as a technology hub and attract talent, similar to Silicon Valley.

site_title: Toshiba boss sorry as shareholders blast US$18b chip sale
summary: Toshiba's president, Satoshi Tsunakawa, apologized sincerely to shareholders over the $18 billion sale of its prized memory chip business, citing the deal as crucial for the company's survival. The sale, led by US investor Bain Capital, aims to plug massive losses at Toshiba's US nuclear division, Westinghouse Electric. Shareholders demand clear answers and expressed concerns about the company's governance, following a series of setbacks, including a 2015 accounting scandal and disastrous acquisition of Westinghouse. The sale is expected to be finalized by March 2018.

site_title: China's Xi sets eyes on more power as congress closes
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is set to consolidate power after the Communist Party congress, which will likely grant him a second five-year term as general secretary. He may also have his name enshrined in the party's constitution, a move that would cement his position as the country's paramount leader. The constitutional amendments could be unveiled on Tuesday, and Xi's allies may be named to the powerful Politburo Standing Committee, potentially paving the way for him to remain in power beyond 2022.

site_title: Brokers' take: OCBC upgrades First Reit to 'buy'
summary: OCBC has upgraded its rating for First Reit to 'buy' following a 0.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter. The target price was increased to S$1.44 from S$1.38. The Reit's DPU rose to 2.14 Singapore cents, up from 2.12 cents a year ago. OCBC's upgrade comes after First Reit's acquisition of Siloam Hospitals Buton and Lippo Plaza Buton for S$28.5 million in October.

site_title: Cashless payments will succeed only if customers find it easy to use
summary: Singapore's drive to become a cashless society is gaining momentum with the launch of NetsPay, the country's leading payment network. Despite being compared to China in terms of digital payments, Singapore has a long history of using cashless methods such as cheques, debit cards, and credit cards. The key to widespread adoption of mobile payments and digital wallets lies in providing a seamless customer experience, with factors such as speed, ease of use, and understanding user behavior playing a crucial role.

site_title: Shared academic, research and industry platform boosts Singapore's AI agenda
summary: Singapore has signed an agreement with NVIDIA to establish a shared AI platform, AI.Platform@NSCC, to boost the country's AI agenda. The platform will provide AI training, technical expertise, and computing services to researchers and developers, including those from academic, research, and industry stakeholders. This is part of AI Singapore's (AISG) national programme to drive AI adoption, research, and innovation in Singapore. The platform aims to bolster capabilities among stakeholders, including four local universities and research institutions, and is in line with the country's efforts to become a leader in AI.

site_title: Oil steady, supported by Iraq disruptions and drop in US rigs
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Monday, supported by disruptions in Iraq's oil exports and a drop in US drilling rates. Oil exports from southern Iraq fell by 110,000 barrels per day, while US drilling rates decreased by seven to 736 rigs. Analysts expect volatility to be tame and prices to remain within a $45-$55 a barrel range. US crude inventories are expected to fall for the fifth straight week, and market participants await data on the pace of rebalancing.

site_title: FJB's senior management takes 70% pay cut, seeks S$39m cash call
summary: FJ Benjamin, a Singapore luxury fashion retailer, has implemented a 70% pay cut for its senior management, including CEO Nash Benjamin and CFO Karen Chong, to speed up its recovery. The company is also raising up to S$39 million through a rights cum warrants issue, its first fund raiser since 2002. FJB aims to use the funds to pursue growth strategies, expand its store presence, and acquire new brands. Despite the pay cuts, the company's losses narrowed to S$942,000 in the first quarter, and it plans to focus on organic expansion and acquisitions to accelerate profitability.

site_title: One in two wealthy Asians has no retirement plan: survey
summary: A survey by Transamerica Life (Bermuda) Ltd and Asian Private Banker found that nearly half of wealthy and ultra-wealthy individuals in Asia lack a retirement plan, with 73% of those who have planned for retirement expressing uncertainty. High net worth individuals (HNWI) cite savings, investments, and provident funds as primary retirement sources, and life insurance is seen as a potential tool for financial security and legacy planning.

site_title: GM closes Holden factory as Australia's car industry runs out of road
summary: General Motors closed its Holden factory in Elizabeth, South Australia, marking the end of over a century of car manufacturing in the country. The factory's closure, following Toyota's shutdown in Victoria and Ford's closure of two sites last year, leaves hundreds of workers jobless and a significant economic gap. The loss of Holden's $1 billion-plus annual investment is expected to have a profound impact on the local economy, with an estimated 2,500 jobs lost in the region from suppliers.

site_title: Construction sector to train 80,000 people in new tech under industry roadmap
summary: Singapore's construction industry aims to train 80,000 personnel in new technologies such as pre-fabrication, digital, and green technologies by 2025. The Industry and Transformation Map (ITM) emphasizes the development of capabilities in cloud and digital technology, pre-fabrication, and green buildings. The goal is to improve the integrated digital delivery process, reducing delays and abortive works, and to encourage adoption of shared platforms and standards. By 2020, the ITM targets to increase adoption of Design for Manufacturing and Assembly (DfMA) to 40% and build 10 integrated construction and prefabrication hubs.

site_title: China vows no return for closed steelmakers
summary: China has vowed to prevent closed steel plants from returning to the market, following a campaign to reduce overcapacity and clean up the environment. The nation's lead economic planning body has stuck to its capacity-cuts mission, resulting in over 1.1 million workers being re-employed. Benchmark steel prices have advanced, with spot reinforcement bar reaching its highest level since 2011, and exports have declined, easing pressure on producers elsewhere. The move is part of China's supply-side reforms to address overcapacity in the domestic steel industry.

site_title: Border wall prototypes a first small step on Trump campaign promise
summary: President Donald Trump's campaign promise of a US-Mexico border wall has taken its first tangible step forward, with eight prototypes of a potential wall constructed near the Otay Mesa border crossing in San Diego. The prototypes, built over the last month, are 9m tall and feature different designs, including see-through models. While Congress has shown little interest in funding the estimated $21.6 billion wall, border patrol officials welcome the momentum and see potential for incorporating the prototypes into the existing fence.

site_title: Can property tax promote Industry 4.0?
summary: Singapore's tax policies may hinder the adoption of Industry 4.0, a revolutionary manufacturing approach. The government's current approach to property tax could discourage companies from investing in advanced manufacturing, potentially leading to job losses and revenue erosion. A proposed amendment to the Property Tax Act aimed to tax machinery used for environmental control, but this move was met with criticism, as it could stifle innovation. The government has since withdrawn the proposal, and experts recommend a broader interpretation of the current tax exemption to encourage advanced manufacturing and technological adoption.

site_title: Ascott Reit Q3 DPU falls 26% to S$0.0169/share on one-offs, rights issue
summary: Ascott Residence Trust's (Ascott Reit) Q3 DPU fell 26% to S$0.0169/share due to one-off items and a rights issue. The distribution slipped 6% to S$36.3 million and gross revenue grew 2% to S$126.9 million. Despite this, the company's gearing was at 31.9% and its effective borrowing rate remained stable at 2.4%. The group's DPU would have increased by 1% if adjusted for one-off gains and the rights issue.

site_title: China court uses social media to shame debtors
summary: A Chinese court in Wenzhou is using social media to shame debtors, releasing the names and photos of 20 defaulters owing a total of 10.7 million yuan. The court posts targeted advertisements on WeChat, notifying contacts about the debt. This move aims to curb household debt, which has doubled in less than a decade and reached 50% of China's GDP. The use of social media to shame debtors is part of efforts to crack down on those who fail to repay loans, amid concerns about rapidly rising debt levels.

site_title: First Reit DPU 0.9% higher for Q3, revenue up 3.3%
summary: First Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, posted a 0.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter, reaching 2.14 Singapore cents. The Reit's gross revenue rose 3.3% to S$27.8 million, driven by contributions from Siloam Hospitals Labuan Bajo and higher rental income. Property operating expenses increased 13.3% due to higher expenses for acquired properties. The Reit has ample headroom to make more acquisitions, with a low gearing ratio and a pipeline of potential hospital acquisitions.

site_title: SIA finalises US$13.8b order for Boeing planes, signs new deal with GE Aviation
summary: Singapore Airlines has finalized a US$13.8 billion order for 39 Boeing aircraft, including 20 777-9s and 19 787-10s, to support growth and fleet modernization over the next decade. The deal was signed at the White House on October 23, with US President Donald Trump and Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in attendance. The agreement also includes options for up to 51 aircraft and covers maintenance and repair services for GE Aviation's 45 GE9X engines.

site_title: COE supply to shrink in Nov-Jan; car and m-cycle growth 0% from Feb
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore announced that the certificate of entitlement (COE) supply will decrease by 5.3% for the November-to-January period, with a total of 25,913 COEs available. The vehicle growth rate for cars and motorcycles will be cut to zero% from February 2018, while the rate for commercial vehicles will remain at 0.25% until Q1 2021. The LTA attributes the reduction to competing needs for land and limited expansion of the road network.

site_title: Spot gold prices pare losses after hitting over two-week low
summary: Spot gold prices fell to a two-week low on Monday before recovering, closing at US$1,280.43 per ounce after technical buying offset pressure from a stronger dollar and rising equities. The US dollar had surged after the Senate approved a budget blueprint, but gold rebounded after hitting its lowest at US$1,271.86. Expectations of Japan's ultra-loose monetary policy also weighed on gold.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TEE International secures S$56.5 million in contracts from Singapore's Land Transport Authority to build noise barriers along rail viaducts. Wing Tai Holdings reports a 676.4% jump in first quarter net profit to S$8.2 million, while New Silkroutes Group announces pre-tax losses for its last three financial years. Soilbuild Construction Group expects to report a loss for the third quarter due to lower revenue and higher construction costs.

site_title: 'Last best chance' for Brexit talks to move
summary: The UK's Brexit talks have stalled with the European Council summit concluding without significant progress. The UK has a limited window to break the impasse before the next EU council meeting in December, with a March 2019 exit deadline looming. British Prime Minister Theresa May's attempts at progress are hindered by a lack of a clear UK government strategy for exiting the EU, leaving the country divided and potentially heading for a hard, disorderly Brexit.

images.alt_text: To many key allies such as Germany and France, Brexit is an act of vandalism to Europe. The fear of EU disintegration might have receded, in part because Britain has shown no clear strategy for its EU exit.

site_title: Trump may not visit Korea DMZ
summary: US President Donald Trump may not visit the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) between North and South Korea, breaking a tradition of previous US presidents. Instead, he will visit Camp Humphreys, a US military base in South Korea, due to security concerns. This decision comes as Trump prepares for a five-nation Asia visit in November, where he will focus on North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks slightly firmer on earnings expectations, investors wary
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.1% to a record high, buoyed by strong corporate earnings expectations, despite a weak Wall Street finish and concerns about US tech firms' sell-off. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) hovered around 2,491.93 points. Analysts attributed the slight increase to investors' optimism about earnings, but sentiment remained subdued. A large sell-off in the US tech sector overnight also affected Seoul stock markets.

site_title: Garuda aiming for US$75m profit in 2018 after cost cuts
summary: Garuda Indonesia, the flag carrier of Indonesia, aims to post a US$75 million profit in the second half of 2018 after a loss of US$284 million in the first half. The airline is boosting aircraft utilization, reducing expenses, and targeting global customers to achieve this goal. CEO Pahala Mansury stated that while the airline won't post a profit for the full year, it is taking steps to improve operations and reduce costs.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific buying freehold Dunearn Court for S$36.3m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings, a wholly-owned subsidiary, has signed a conditional deal to purchase the freehold Dunearn Court in Singapore for S$36.3 million. The price translates to S$1,371 per square foot per plot ratio, including an estimated development charge of S$550,000. The deal was brokered by Knight Frank.

images.alt_text: Roxy-Pacific plans to redevelop the freehold Dunearn Court site into a five-storey project with 35 units, likely to comprise two and three-bedders

site_title: Supreme Components believes in human touch
summary: Supreme Components International (SCI) has achieved success as a fast-franchised distributor of high-tech electronic and LED components, with over 2,000 global clients and seven offices in five countries. Founded in 2001 as an independent trading firm, SCI turned around under CEO and President Vick Aggarwala in 2005, focusing on customer service and adapting to changing market trends. SCI now boasts an annual revenue of close to $11 million and has been consistently profitable for 12 years, including six Enterprise 50 Awards. The company aims to continue its aggressive expansion into overseas markets and explore new business opportunities, such as the Internet of Things (IoT) sector.

site_title: O&M firm Gaylin sold shares at 50% discount for S$68m
summary: Gaylin Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine company, is placing a 75.64% stake in itself to a private equity fund at a 49% discount to its current stock price. The deal, valued at S$68 million, will be used for general working purposes and to strengthen its capital base. ShawKwei Asia Value Fund 2017, a private equity firm, is subscribing for new shares at S$0.05 apiece, acquiring more than 30% of Gaylin's voting rights. The deal comes as the company posts consecutive losses, but is seen as a positive sign for the O&M sector's consolidation.

site_title: New Zealand populist to become deputy prime minister, foreign minister: media
summary: New Zealand's populist leader Winston Peters will become deputy prime minister and foreign minister in a coalition government led by Prime Minister-elect Jacinda Ardern. Peters, leader of the New Zealand First party, has accepted the roles after Labour and New Zealand First formed an agreement following a closely fought election. This marks a shift towards "fortress New Zealand" policies, aligning with populist movements in Europe and the US. Peters, who previously served as foreign minister under Labour's Helen Clark, has worked under both Labour and National governments.

site_title: Not even a ghost of a chance hotel is haunted
summary: The Grand Hyatt Taipei responded to a Business Times Weekend article, stating that the hotel was misrepresented as being haunted. The article, which featured a guest's stay, was titled "A Taiwanese Ghost Story" and may have deterred Singaporean travelers. The hotel expressed concern that the article's misleading headline had negatively impacted their reputation among key markets. They invited readers to share their feedback on the article.

site_title: Wanted: Engineers with deep tech skills and soft skills
summary: A collaborative approach between government, urban planners, and engineers is needed to create resilient, sustainable, and future-ready cities. This requires "smart" engineers with both technical and soft skills, such as collaboration and persuasion. The article emphasizes the importance of unconventional smarts in designing smart cities and mitigating complex problems like poverty and climate change.

site_title: London curbs 'toxic' vehicles with new daily fee
summary: London has introduced a new daily fee, the T-Charge, for drivers of the most polluting diesel vehicles, effective Monday. The £10 charge targets vehicles registered before 2006 and is in addition to the city's existing congestion charge. The move aims to reduce air pollution in central London, where nearly eight million people live in areas with poor air quality, resulting in thousands of premature deaths. The T-Charge is a precursor to an Ultra Low Emission Zone in central London in 2019, and is being welcomed by organizations such as the British Heart Foundation and Greenpeace.

site_title: S'pore sees jump in venture capital fund-raising
summary: Singapore sees a surge in venture capital fund-raising, with three firms raising a combined $730 million this month. Investors are seeking opportunities beyond the US and China, attracted by the region's growing startup ecosystem and government incentives. The government has cut regulatory red tape and allocated public money for early investments, leading to higher-quality startups and increased funding. Singapore's venture investments totalled $725.3 million in the second quarter, boosted by Sea Ltd's $550 million funding round.

site_title: Crunching numbers
summary: San SeSan Global, a Singapore-based food marketer and importer, has achieved a turnover of S$12 million with its own snack and beverage brands. Established in 2003, the company now has 16 brands, including Tao Kae Noi and Want Want, and has expanded into manufacturing its own products. This growth marks a significant shift for the company, which was previously focused on importing and distributing other brands.

images.alt_text: Ms Lim has parlayed a S$30,000 acquisition in 2003 into a S$12 million global supplier of fast-moving goods in FY2016. San SeSan Global today is a food marketer, importer and distributor and is already expanding into East Asia.

site_title: Digital giants paying huge salaries for scarce AI talent
summary: Tech giants are increasingly competing for scarce AI talent, potentially rendering traditional startup recruitment advantages obsolete. Companies like Amazon Web Services, Oracle, and Grab are establishing AI-focused innovation hubs, while mining giant BHP joins this trend in Singapore. Meanwhile, digital giants are offering high salaries to attract AI experts, making it a highly competitive job market. This shift may lead to a more uniform approach to AI development across industries, with potential benefits for businesses and consumers alike.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q3 profit up 21%
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 21% increase in Q3 net profit to S$235.5 million, driven by higher operating and non-operating profit, as well as investments. Gross premiums rose 33% to S$3.1 billion, while insurance business profit increased 22%. The company's nine-month net profit reached S$732.9 million, up 86% from last year. Earnings per share rose to 50 Singapore cents, but no interim dividend was declared. The group's performance may be affected by global financial market volatility, with key indicators to watch including interest rates, equity prices, and foreign exchange rates.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern Holdings on Tuesday posted net profit of S$235.5 million for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2017, 21 per cent higher than last year's S$195 million.

site_title: En bloc contagion spreads to commercial, mixed-use properties
summary: Residential en bloc contagion has spread to commercial and mixed-use properties in Singapore, with the Goldhill Centre and Katong Shopping Centre owners forming collective sales committees. Marketing agent Cushman & Wakefield reports that these developments will target a reserve price in November. This spillover has revived interest in these projects, following a surge in residential en bloc sales. The developments' owners are now looking to capitalize on the trend, seeking to sell their properties through collective sales.

site_title: Japan casino plans off the table for gaming mogul Packer
summary: Australian billionaire James Packer has shelved plans for Crown to expand into Japan's lucrative gaming market, citing a lack of opportunity to win a licence. The company is now focusing on developing a flagship Sydney casino amid a Chinese crackdown on gambling. Packer expressed concerns that participating in a competitive bidding process for a licence in Japan would be "distracting" for management. Japan's casino industry is still awaiting a formal bill outlining its principles, but Crown has deemed the opportunity "off the table".

site_title: Indonesia govt's impasse over Freeport could spook foreign investors
summary: Indonesia's government is in an impasse with US mining giant Freeport McMoRan over the Grasberg copper-gold operation in Papua, risking a negative message to foreign investors. The Indonesian government has sent Luhut Pandjaitan, a former Suharto-era general, to negotiate with Freeport. This development could potentially threaten President Jokowi's re-election bid. The standoff may deter foreign investors from doing business in Indonesia, which could have significant economic implications.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hold firm as banks, Spanish shares fall
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Monday, despite Spanish shares falling 0.6% due to the ongoing Catalan crisis. Banks, including BBVA and Banco Santander, led the decline. Financial shares fell across Europe, with Deutsche Bank and Standard Chartered losing 1.2% and 0.6% respectively. Company results also impacted the market, with Securitas and Pendragon making notable gains and losses. The number of profit warnings issued by British companies rose to 75 in the third quarter, adding to economic pressure on retailers and support service companies.

site_title: ANZ Bank settles rate-rigging case with securities regulator
summary: ANZ Bank has settled a case with Australia's securities regulator over allegations of rate-rigging, agreeing to pay over A$50 million. The settlement resolves claims that ANZ traders manipulated the benchmark bank bill swap rate to benefit the bank's trading positions. The case, which also involves Westpac and National Australia Bank, is ongoing, with a court hearing set to reconvene to review the ANZ settlement and proceed with the cases against the other two banks.

site_title: Plan in NY to make timely rent payment count towards good credit scores
summary: New York City Comptroller Scott M. Stringer plans to announce a plan to encourage landlords to report rent payments to credit bureaus, which would boost tenants' credit scores and potentially lift them out of poverty. The proposal aims to address the issue of inequality faced by renters, who do not receive the same benefits as homeowners for paying rent on time. A pilot program by the NYC Housing Authority has seen limited participation, and advocates are pushing for widespread adoption to benefit low-income and minority renters.

site_title: Acquisitions, higher revenue boost MLT's Q2
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported higher revenue in its Q2, driven by increased revenue from its Hong Kong properties, completed acquisitions in Australia, Malaysia, and Vietnam, and a stronger Australian dollar. Net property income rose 2.5% to S$78.7 million, and the trust attributed this to acquisitions completed last year. MLT also launched an equity fundraising exercise to raise S$640 million to finance the purchase of a Hong Kong property and redeem perpetual securities.

site_title: SGX must shore up its promise of a stepping stone for tech start-ups
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced a tie-up with Nasdaq to allow concurrent or sequential listings on both exchanges. The move aims to attract more tech companies and start-ups, positioning SGX as a stepping stone or fast-track channel to Nasdaq. The agreement, which includes offering Nasdaq's International Designation programme, could capture some of the Nasdaq-bound companies before they reach their end goal. However, SGX must overcome deep-seated issues of liquidity, investor appetite, and issuer quality to draw positive impact from the partnership.

site_title: Newseum: More relevant, but can it survive?
summary: The Newseum, a museum dedicated to journalism, is facing financial challenges, having run up deficits. The institution, which showcases historic front pages of newspapers, including those from the 9/11 attacks, is struggling to stay afloat. Despite its mission to preserve journalism history, the museum's financial situation remains uncertain, raising concerns about its long-term survival.

images.alt_text: Scott Williams, the Newseum's chief operating officer, and Jan Neuharth, chief executive of the Freedom Forum. The museum has just begun an in-depth financial review. Initial findings are expected at the end of the year.

Scott Williams, the Newseum's chief operating officer, and Jan Neuharth, chief executive of the Freedom Forum. The museum has just begun an in-depth financial review. Initial findings are expected at the end of the year.

site_title: Xi Jinping pushes global role for China
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is pushing for a global role, visiting various countries and regions, including Fiji, Central Asia, and Tasmania, as well as sending warships to London. He aims to restore China to its rightful place as a global power, citing a vision of national rejuvenation. Despite his successes in expanding Chinese influence, Xi faces friction in different parts of the world, including Australia, Europe, and South Asia, and must navigate challenges in his second term, including strained ties with Japan and India, and the Korean Peninsula.

site_title: Tech chiefs off to Vegas - for bank conference
summary: Tech industry leaders are gathering in Las Vegas for the Money 20/20 conference, where they will discuss payments technologies and partnerships. The conference aims to address issues such as FinTech acquisitions, hacking problems, and the use of artificial intelligence. The event is expected to bring together over 11,000 people from 4,500 companies, including Barclays Plc's Jes Staley, who warned his competitors about the threat of technology companies encroaching on the payments business. The conference will unveil the latest advancements in payments technologies and partnerships.

site_title: ST Aerospace clinches Q3 deals worth over half a billion dollars
summary: ST Aerospace, the aerospace arm of ST Engineering, secured contracts worth S$530 million in Q3 2017 for services including heavy airframe maintenance, component repair, and cabin retrofit. Contracts include long-term agreements for MD-11, Boeing 777, and Boeing 757 A300 aircraft, as well as engine maintenance and landing gear overhaul for European and Asian airlines. The company also secured a cabin retrofit contract for two A320 aircraft and a pilot training agreement with Xiamen Airlines.

site_title: May's Brussels gains eclipsed by domestic challenge on Brexit
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit legislation faces a new roadblock as the Labour Party threatens to unite with Tory rebels, potentially undermining her negotiating strategy. Labour leader Keir Starmer has proposed changes to the legislation, including a veto over the divorce deal with the European Union, and has issued an ultimatum to May, threatening to risk defeat if her demands are not met. May's minority government is deeply divided over Brexit, with some lawmakers calling for a swift departure without a deal, while others fight to keep the closest possible links to Europe.

site_title: What does Abe victory mean for key industries
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's landslide victory for his ruling coalition means good news for industries such as nuclear power and defence, while posing challenges to retailers and others. The government's ultra-easy monetary policy has boosted Japanese stocks, and Abe's coalition retained its two-thirds majority in the lower house. A depreciating yen is expected to benefit companies like Fanuc Corp and Nintendo Co, while higher taxes may hurt retailers like Seven & i Holdings Co. The government's stimulus plans may continue, but the impact on stagnant wage growth and the labour market remains uncertain.

site_title: China's housing market shows signs of slowing
summary: China's housing market showed signs of slowing in September, with prices in the biggest markets slipping and gains in smaller cities easing. Average new home prices rose 0.2% month-on-month, the slowest rate in seven months. Despite a slowdown, prices still rose 6.3% year-on-year, fueled by a high base and increasing debt. Authorities are expected to introduce more curbs in lower-tier cities, which could further dampen demand. The country's leaders are seeking to shift from high-speed to high-quality growth, and a stable housing market is seen as a key priority.

site_title: Does Malaysia need a national airline?
summary: Malaysia's national airline, Malaysia Airlines (MAS), has struggled with persistent losses and mismanagement, despite billions of dollars in government investment. The airline has seen nine CEOs in less than 20 years and has a dismal financial record. In contrast, low-cost carrier AirAsia has grown larger and more profitable, performing the role of a national carrier. Many national airlines have failed or stagnated, and some countries, like the US, have no "national airline". It is unclear whether MAS should continue to receive public funding to support its operations, given its financial struggles.

site_title: Singapore beefs up muscle in solar and energy storage
summary: Singapore is enhancing its energy ambitions by developing solar forecasting capabilities, enhancing solar energy sales, and installing an energy storage testbed on the grid. Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean estimates that solar energy could reach up to 20% of Singapore's energy mix in 10-20 years. The Energy Market Authority has awarded a S$6.2 million research grant to develop solar forecasting capabilities, while two consortiums will receive grants to build utility-scale energy storage systems. These efforts aim to improve grid management and facilitate the deployment of renewable energy sources.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust reported stable Q3 '17 results with gross revenue falling 0.2% to S$169.4 million and net property income rising 1.6% to S$121.4 million. The company's NPI margin increased to 71.6%, and distribution per unit remained unchanged at 2.78 Singapore cents. Analysts lifted FY17 and FY18 DPU forecasts by 0.5% and 0.4%, respectively, due to lower finance costs and the repayment of borrowings.

site_title: New Wave shares soar on proposed offer from Fragrance CEO
summary: New Wave Holdings shares surged 56% on October 23, 2017, following a proposed offer by Fragrance Group CEO Koh Wee Meng. The stock, which resumed trading after a halt on October 20, closed at S$0.013, up 44% from its intra-day low. The offer represents a 44.4% premium over the company's closing price on October 19. Koh Wee Meng owns approximately 11.26% of the company's shares and plans to keep New Wave listed on the Catalist board of SGX if the offer is accepted.

site_title: Cisco 'nearing deal' to acquire BroadSoft for almost US$2b
summary: Cisco Systems Inc is nearing a deal to acquire US telecommunications software firm BroadSoft Inc for nearly US$2 billion. The deal would allow Cisco to diversify away from its stagnating switches and routers business by gaining a stronger foothold in unified communications software sales. This acquisition comes after Cisco's US$3.7 billion acquisition of AppDynamics Inc in March, and would be its second major deal this year. BroadSoft provides software and services for telecommunications companies to offer unified communications, and its shares closed at US$54.90 on Friday.

site_title: EU states fail to agree on reform of labour rules
summary: EU states failed to agree on reforming labour rules, a key EU agenda item, in a first round of talks. The rules, valued by poorer countries, allow citizens to work elsewhere in the EU for higher salaries than at home, but lower than local wages. French President Emmanuel Macron and wealthier countries back reform, while poorer countries, including Poland, seek to preserve current rules. Estonia will offer more compromise proposals later, and ministers will discuss transition time and remuneration rules in a further debate.

site_title: US$ hits three-month high versus yen on Abenomics triumph
summary: The US dollar reached a three-month high against the yen, trading at 114.10 yen, following Japan's ruling party's victory in the election, which is expected to continue "Abenomics", a loose monetary policy. This move is attributed to speculation that the next US Federal Reserve chair will take a more hawkish stance on monetary policy. The yen's depreciation against the dollar is seen as a result of the expected continuation of Abenomics, easing fears of economic disruption.

site_title: Ezion sweetens proposal for holders of its notes, perpetuals
summary: EZION Holdings has revised its proposal for holders of S$575 million of medium-term notes and perpetuals, offering two conversion options to shares, including a lower conversion price and improved terms for those opting to convert securities on or before 60 days after the issue of new convertible bonds. The revised proposal includes a 10% discount on conversion price for Series 3-7 noteholders and 50,000 warrants for every S$50,000 converted. The deal is considered a "fair, negotiated outcome" by the Informal Steering Committee, but OCBC credit analyst Nick Wong notes that the convertible bond option may be more meaningful for noteholders.

site_title: Volkswagen, Daimler say targeted by EU antitrust probe
summary: Volkswagen and Daimler, German car giants, are under investigation by EU antitrust regulators. Daimler said it's the subject of an "inspection" and has filed a leniency application. Volkswagen confirmed it's also a target of ongoing EU antitrust investigations. The probes are a new blow to the country's struggling auto industry.

site_title: 'Ace queen' Pliskova eager to seal her semi-final spot early
summary: Czech tennis star Karolina Pliskova won her first victory at the season-ending BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals presented by SC Global tournament, defeating Venus Williams in a straight sets match. Pliskova, ranked fourth, now has her sights on a semi-final spot, with two more matches to come. She will face Garbine Muguruza, the Wimbledon champion, in the next match, which could determine the two teams advancing to the semi-finals. Pliskova's strong serve and aggressive play made her a favorite to win, and she is now in a strong position to secure her semi-final spot.

images.alt_text: "The scoreline (6-2, 6-2) makes it look easier than it was. There are no easy matches in Singapore, so you have to be ready from the first point." - 4th-ranked Pliskova, after beating Venus Williams in the one-sided 72-minute match.

site_title: New agency to coordinate policies, research in energy
summary: The Singapore government has established a National Energy Transformation Office (Neto) to coordinate policies and research efforts across various agencies, focusing on industrial energy efficiency and clean energy. Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean announced the move, which will also hire 250 more power engineers in the public sector. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) will lead the effort, launching a regulatory sandbox for the power and gas sectors to test new products and services.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Teo said the public sector would need 250 more power engineers over the next five years.

site_title: STI advances in 7th straight session
summary: Singapore stocks advanced for a seventh consecutive session, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 9.07 points or 0.27% to 3,349.80. Strong local earnings and optimism over Japan's pro-business prime minister and US President Trump's tax cut plan drove the rally. Index heavyweight Keppel Corporation's shares gained 11 cents, while over 2 billion units worth S$1 billion were traded, with gainers beating losers 228 to 196.

site_title: Swedish FSA to go forward with plans for tougher mortgage rules
summary: Sweden's Financial Supervisory Authority plans to introduce tougher mortgage rules to cool its housing market. Despite recent signs of slowing borrowing and price growth, Director General Erik Thedeen believes more measures are needed. The housing market has seen a 40% price increase and a 20% rise in household debt over the past three years. The FSA aims to address these issues, with a proposal for tougher amortization requirements set to come into force next March. The goal is to reduce household debt and slow price growth.

site_title: Darco shares soar in early trade after raising S$19.6m from strategic HK investor
summary: Darco Water Technologies shares surged 16.8% to 66 Singapore cents after the company raised S$19.6m from a strategic Hong Kong investor in early trade on October 23, 2017.

site_title: S'pore imports of Swiss luxury watches spike 90% in Sept
summary: Singapore's imports of Swiss luxury watches surged 90% in September, making it the third-largest importer after Hong Kong and the US. Shipments jumped from S$130.41 million in September 2016 to S$130.41 million last month, with the value doubling due to the delivery of highly-priced watches.
