summary: Australia's employment has surged beyond expectations, with 2.7% growth in the year to August, despite a 5.6% unemployment rate. The key to this growth lies in the healthcare sector, which created 329,000 net jobs, with women making up a record 60% of the workforce. Tax breaks on childcare and the launch of a disability insurance scheme have driven this growth, particularly in roles dominated by women. While this is a positive sign for the economy, most other sectors have seen limited or no job growth, leaving slack in the labor market and restraining wage growth.

images.alt_text: The proportion of women in Australia's workforce has reached a record high of 60 per cent, which analysts say is a big positive for the economy. More than a third of the 329,000 net jobs created in Australia in the year to August were in healthcare, outstripping even the booming construction industry.

site_title: Gold, as an inflation hedge, should continue uptrend
summary: Gold prices are expected to continue their uptrend as the current rate hike cycle is similar to past cycles in 1972, 1976, and 2004, which led to gold rallies. The prolonged period of negative spread between the Fed Funds Rate (FFR) and the Taylor Rule has historically resulted in a sharp rise in gold prices, as seen in instances of 400%, 270%, and 140% gains. With the FFR currently near the zero bound and the Fed Funds Futures implying an 80% probability of a rate hike, gold is likely to benefit as an inflation hedge.

site_title: China's Communist Party says still talking to N Korean counterpart
summary: China's Communist Party continues to engage in talks and maintain contacts with North Korea, despite international pressure to rein in Pyongyang's nuclear and missile capabilities. The two countries have a traditional friendly cooperative relationship, and maintaining ties is seen as important for regional stability. China has imposed strict UN sanctions and will cut off oil shipments to North Korea, but exchanges between the two parties play a crucial role in developing overall China-North Korea relations. China's President Xi Jinping is set to meet with US President Donald Trump next month to discuss North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: The brave new world of asset management
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management's CEO Mike O'Brien states that the asset management industry has reached an inflection point due to ageing demographics and crimping profit margins. To retain market share, mid-sized players must prioritize building scale while offering tailored services. O'Brien notes that the "golden age of returns" is over, creating a premium for alpha. This shift emphasizes the importance of alpha-generating strategies in the industry's future.

site_title: Tech spends millions lobbying as Washington pressure rises
summary: Tech companies, including Amazon, Facebook, and Google, spent over $10 million on federal lobbying in the third quarter, with Amazon spending $3.41 million. This comes as Washington increases pressure on issues like child sex-trafficking, Russia's alleged election meddling, and online political advertising. The companies will testify before congressional committees and face scrutiny over their handling of Russian interference in the 2016 election. A bipartisan bill aiming to impose new disclosure requirements for online political ads has also been introduced.

site_title: Digitalisation and R&D key for Jurong Island's growth: EDB
summary: Singapore aims to transform its aging petrochemical sector on Jurong Island through digitalization and research and development (R&D). The government plans to have 20 facilities digitally-enabled by 2020, with a focus on improving productivity, health, and safety. R&D expenditure is expected to increase to S$137 million by 2025, with a goal of creating 1,400 new jobs and lifting the industry's value-add to S$12.7 billion. The government will also work with companies to upgrade assets and produce higher-value products, such as specialty chemicals, to remain competitive in the long term.

site_title: Unearthing story behind US capital's 'mystery tomb'
summary: A mysterious building on the National Mall in Washington D.C. has been puzzling locals and visitors alike since its construction in 1934. The American Pharmacists Association (APhA) headquarters, located at 2215 Constitution Avenue, is a Beaux-Arts building designed by John Russell Pope, but it was not intended as a tomb. Initially planned as the Abraham Lincoln birthplace memorial, the building was retooled for APhA after the project's costs became too high. The building has been the site of several misconceptions, including being called the "Tomb of the Unknown Pharmacist," but it remains a unique and inconspicuous presence on the Mall.

site_title: Europe: FTSE closes flat as sterling bounces back on Brexit hopes
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index closed flat on Friday, up 0.2% as sterling bounced back on hopes of a Brexit breakthrough. The pound strengthened to 89.295 pence per euro, leaving it up 0.8% on the day. Consumer heavyweights Unilever and Reckitt Benckiser weighed down the index, while miner Fresnillo was the top loser after a downgrade. Financials, led by Standard Chartered and RSA Insurance, boosted the index, and mid-caps closed up 0.1% after a record close on Wednesday.

site_title: Keppel Corp soars on signs of multi-business portfolio bearing fruit
summary: Keppel Corp's shares surged on Friday following its first quarterly revenue and operating profit increase since 2014. The company posted a 30% rise in net profit to S$291 million and a 75% rise in operating profit to S$324 million in the third quarter. Analysts attribute the better performance to diversification in the company's multi-business portfolio, with potential for growth in its property arm and new initiative, Keppel Urban Solutions.

site_title: Beauty in the ordinary
summary: Artist Michael Craig-Martin's latest exhibition, "All in All," at Gallery Hyundai in Seoul, features his signature stylized paintings of everyday objects. The 76-year-old artist, known for his graphic style, is inspired by the mundane and aims to encourage viewers to appreciate the present moment. Craig-Martin's work, which began in the 1970s, has taken on an archaeological dimension, documenting the evolution of objects and society. His art is a celebration of the little things, challenging the notion that meaning lies in grand or hidden messages.

site_title: New Zealand's incoming leader flags TPP problems
summary: New Zealand's incoming Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has expressed her intention to push for changes to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement, which is set to be finalized next month. Ardern supports the TPP and lifting exports, but insists on proceeding with the Labour Party's plan to stop foreign speculation in the housing market, which would breach the draft agreement. This move may cause a breach of the agreement, highlighting potential problems with New Zealand's participation.

site_title: High tea spa
summary: Mandarin Oriental Singapore has partnered with Aromatherapy Associates London to create a bespoke spa-inspired afternoon tea, featuring lavender-infused dishes such as poached shrimps and blackberry lavender tart. The De-Stress treatment, priced at S$380, includes a five-course spa-inspired afternoon tea until October 29. Reservations can be made by calling 6338 0066.

site_title: US step towards tax reform helps equities
summary: US lawmakers adopted a budget resolution, easing the path for tax reform measures, boosting global equities. The positive start in Europe was also attributed to EU leaders' support for British Prime Minister Theresa May in Brexit talks. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers, while Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: Startup regulator
summary: Richard Teng, CEO of Abu Dhabi Global Market's Financial Services Regulatory Authority, highlights the tax-free financial centre's success in attracting over 350 firms, including Aberdeen Asset Management and Societe Generale. ADGM aims to diversify the UAE's economy away from oil and has seen non-oil contributions increase. The centre is set to become the region's largest asset management hub within two years, with a fund returning 400% to investors. Teng emphasizes the importance of collaboration with Singapore, with ADGM and Singapore funds exploring fund passporting. He notes that fintech plays a key role in addressing the credit gap in the Middle East, where 85 million adults are unbanked.

site_title: Vintage time
summary: Longines is celebrating its 185th anniversary in Singapore with an exhibition at Marina Square Central Atrium. The event features a collection of vintage models, timing devices, and archival records showcasing the brand's history in time-keeping and watch-making. Recent novelties are also on display, offering a glimpse into the brand's rich heritage. The exhibition runs until October 22, allowing visitors to discover the story behind Longines' iconic winged hourglass logo.

site_title: Gillette weakens P&G report after Peltz row
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) reported a 1% increase in net sales to $16.65 billion in its first quarter, but missed analyst expectations due to a decline in its Gillette business. The company attributed the decline to higher shipping costs and commodity costs, particularly in Brazil where consumers were hit by an ongoing recession. Despite this, P&G maintained its full-year organic sales and adjusted profit forecast, and reported a 5% increase in net income to $2.85 billion. The company's shares fell 3.5% in afternoon trading.

site_title: Trump tax cut plan gains momentum after US budget vote
summary: President Donald Trump's tax reform plans gained momentum after US Senate approval of a budget measure, allowing Republicans to pursue a tax-cut package without Democratic support. However, the party remains divided on how to achieve the main item on its domestic agenda. Senator Rand Paul, a fiscal hawk, expressed support for massive tax cuts, but the party is under pressure to succeed after failing to scrap Obamacare. The tax plan promises up to $6 trillion in tax cuts but will bloat the federal deficit by $1.5 trillion over the next decade.

site_title: Airbus sees CSeries jets grabbing major global market share: CEO
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders expects to sell thousands of Bombardier's CSeries aircraft, capturing half the global market for smaller single-aisle commercial jets. Airbus will take a majority stake in the CSeries program for $1 billion, reducing costs and boosting sales. The move aims to create new jobs in Canada and the US, but faces a potential 300% duty on US sales due to a trade dispute with Boeing. Enders believes the deal should be supported by the US government, citing job creation, and suggests it could foster new partnerships.

site_title: Ballet hero
summary: Ballet dancer-choreographer Benjamin Millepied is set to bring four exquisite pieces to the Esplanade's da:ns festival in Singapore, including a tribute to Martha Graham and two works set to Philip Glass' music. Millepied, a principal dancer of the New York City Ballet and artistic director of the Paris Opera Ballet, founded the LA Dance Project, which is gaining recognition in the world of ballet and contemporary dance. The performances will take place on October 24 and 25 at 8pm, with tickets available from Sistic.

site_title: US: Wall Street hits record highs; tax plan hopes fuel optimism
summary: US stocks hit record highs, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite posting gains of 0.51% and 0.36% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.71% to an all-time closing high. The Senate's approval of a 2018 budget blueprint has lifted hopes for President Trump's tax-cut plan, fueling optimism among investors. The S&P 500 has posted a sixth week of gains, while small-cap companies are expected to benefit from tax reform.

site_title: UN draws flak after naming Mugabe goodwill ambassador
summary: The United Nations named Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe a "goodwill ambassador" for promoting health causes despite the country's dire health crisis under his rule. The appointment was met with criticism from international rights campaigners and opposition parties, who accused Mugabe of human rights abuses and economic ruin. The WHO cited Zimbabwe's national policy on non-communicable diseases as a reason for the appointment, but critics questioned the timing and implications of the move.

site_title: US existing home sales edge up in September
summary: US existing home sales rose 0.7% in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.39 million, exceeding analyst expectations. However, sales remained below the year-ago period, marking the first annual decline since July 2016. Limited housing supply and high prices continue to impede sales growth, with the median home price rising 4.2% to $245,100. Existing homes for sale increased 1.6% to 1.9 million, still 6.4% below the previous year.

site_title: Reworking of TPP to exclude US could see progress by Apec summit: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong hopes for progress on a new TPP framework excluding the US by the Apec summit in Vietnam in November. The US has pulled out of the trade pact, but Lee believes the remaining 11 members can still move forward. He also emphasizes the importance of maintaining ties with China, citing Singapore's role as Asean chairman in 2018 and coordinator for relations with China. Lee notes that while the US may not return to the table, trade links between the two countries will continue.

site_title: US deficit grows 13.6% in 2017, now 3.5% of GDP
summary: The US budget deficit increased 13.6% in 2017 to $666 billion, accounting for 3.5% of GDP. This marks the second consecutive year where spending outpaced tax receipts due to historically slow economic growth. The Treasury Department attributed the growth to a lack of economic growth.

site_title: Executive mentors wanted - only millennials need apply
summary: Young professionals, mostly millennials, are being given a new role: advising top executives at their companies. These "millennial mentors" are providing guidance on topics such as catering to new markets, developing new products, and understanding digital trends. Companies like Mastercard, Cisco Systems, and Mars Inc have implemented these mentoring programs, which are seen as a way for executives to stay relevant in a rapidly changing business environment. The programs offer a unique opportunity for executives to learn from younger employees and gain a fresh perspective on the industry.

images.alt_text: David Watson, left, a managing director at Deutsche Bank, and Fernando Hernandez, an engineer at the bank who has mentored him. Mr Watson credited Mr Hernandez with good tips for retaining young employees and with helping him spot trends in the financial tech industry.

site_title: Yellen defends legacy amid uncertainty over Fed leadership
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen defended the central bank's use of unconventional monetary policy tools, citing the US economy's strength since the Great Recession. Yellen emphasized the need for policy makers to confront future economic downturns with tools like quantitative easing. Her four-year term as chair is set to expire in February, and President Trump is considering her reappointment along with Jerome Powell and John Taylor. Yellen highlighted her achievements, including lower unemployment and bond purchases that spurred economic activity, amid uncertainty over Fed leadership.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen defended the central bank's use of unconventional and often unpopular monetary policy tools after the Great Recession, highlighting some of her achievements at the helm as President Donald Trump weighs her reappointment.

site_title: Apple hit with trademark lawsuit over iPhone X "animoji" feature
summary: A Japanese software company, Emonster kk, is suing Apple in a US court over the trademark for the term "animoji", alleging Apple stole the name for its iPhone X feature. Emonster holds the US trademark on the term and claims Apple's use of the word is a deliberate infringement. The company is seeking unspecified damages and a court order blocking Apple's use of the term while the lawsuit is pending. Apple had full knowledge of Emonster's "Animoji" app, which it launched in 2014.

site_title: The Pines club to relocate from Stevens Road
summary: Members of The Pines club in Singapore will be informed of the new address for their clubhouse, which has relocated from 30 Stevens Road, after repeated requests for information from members. The club's management initially told members to wait for an official letter, which was supposed to be sent in August 2017, but the development deadline passed a year ago. The new location will offer better facilities, according to the club's management, and members will be notified next week.

site_title: AccorHotels upbeat on 2017 profit target after Q3 sales
summary: AccorHotels, Europe's largest hotel group, reported strong third-quarter sales of 504 million euros, up 6.4% on a like-for-like basis. The company expects 2017 operating profit to be at the upper end of its forecast range of 460-480 million euros. Robust demand in most markets, including France, Britain, and Germany, drove the sales growth, while South America saw a 15.3% decline. AccorHotels is also exploring a deal to sell a stake in its property business to raise cash for growth.

site_title: Discussions still ongoing for potential share transaction in Tat Hong
summary: Tat Hong Holdings is still in discussions regarding a potential share transaction, with no certainty on the outcome. The company, which operates in the Asia-Pacific and Australia, had previously announced it was approached by certain parties about a potential deal. Shares closed unchanged at 45 Singapore cents after 1.85 million shares were traded. Tat Hong, celebrating its 60th anniversary, is the eighth largest crane and construction equipment operator in the world with 5,000 employees.

site_title: EU raids automaker BMW in post-Dieselgate cartel case
summary: EU antitrust regulators raided BMW's offices in Munich, Germany, as part of a post-Dieselgate cartel case. The inspection, which began on October 16, 2017, is related to concerns that several German car manufacturers, including BMW, Daimler, and Volkswagen, may have violated EU antitrust rules. The European Commission is investigating allegations of collusion on car development, construction, and logistics, including how to meet diesel emissions criteria. BMW denied any manipulation of diesel emissions, while Daimler cooperated with the commission and may receive leniency in the case.

site_title: Clans of Chinatown
summary: Singapore's Chinatown, the largest historic district in the city, was established by the first Chinese immigrants in the 1800s. Today, it features four sub-districts, numerous temples, clan associations, and historical buildings, showcasing the diverse origins of the Chinese immigrants. Notable landmarks include Fuk Tak Chi, Thian Hock Keng, and the Red Dot Design Museum, which were built in the 19th century. The area also preserves the legacy of the rickshaw industry and features the Ee Hoe Hean Club, one of the oldest millionaire clubs in Singapore.

site_title: CDL moves to quell disquiet among shareholders
summary: City Developments (CDL) is facing opposition from shareholders over its proposed £1.8 billion (S$3.2 billion) takeover offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C). Fund managers have criticized the offer, citing a 32.5% discount to M&C's 2013 valuation, and are calling for a valuation of the hotelier's property portfolio. CDL and M&C's independent directors argue that the offer is reasonable and that M&C's assets are valuable, despite the company's struggling operational performance. The proposal must secure more than 50% of valid acceptances, a potentially challenging task.

site_title: The Italian job
summary: Tod's has launched a new concept flagship boutique in Hong Kong, embodying the brand's refined and timeless DNA. The 255-square-meter two-storey boutique features exquisite craftsmanship, luxurious materials, and elegant designs. The Gommino shoe, a unisex fashion staple, and the Sella handbag, with its intricate ribbing and stitching, are showcased alongside other key products. The boutique was officially launched with an invitation-only cocktail party, attended by local celebrities, including Liu Shi Shi, brand ambassador.

site_title: Thailand rehearses lavish 3b baht funeral for late king
summary: Thailand rehearses a lavish 3 billion baht funeral for late King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died at 87. The five-day funeral, attended by over 250,000 mourners, will feature a mock-up of a golden urn, elaborate structures, and a public relations machine that helped revive the monarchy's prestige. The king's son, King Maha Vajiralongkorn, will formally ascend the throne after his father's funeral, which is set to take place on October 26. The event is expected to be a national holiday, with many businesses and businesses shutting down or closing early.

site_title: Taste of kiwi
summary: The North Island of New Zealand offers unique attractions beyond its southern counterpart, including a greater Maori presence and scenic spots for nature lovers. White Island, an active volcano off the coast, provides an adrenaline-pumping experience for visitors. The island's rugged landscape features bubbling pits, hot streams, and a lake of steaming acid. The North Island is also home to popular destinations like Rotorua and Taupo, offering trout-fishing, trekking, and geothermal activities. Accommodations like Solitaire Lodge and Huka Lodge provide luxurious experiences, making the North Island an ideal choice for those seeking a more exclusive and nature-focused adventure.

site_title: CCT reports rise in Q3 DPU but expects lower income from negative rental reversions
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 2.6% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter, driven by higher net property income. However, the company expects lower net property income in fiscal 2018 due to negative rental reversions, which are expected to decrease pressure on reversions in 2018 as market rents rise.

site_title: US:Dow opens at record highs on tax-cut optimism
summary: Wall Street opened at record highs on Friday, driven by optimism over the Trump administration's tax-cut plan. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 79.88 points to 23,242.92, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also hit new highs. The gains were attributed to growth expectations despite uncertainty over tariffs, which the US and EU are currently negotiating.

site_title: Big screen design
summary: The seventh edition of A Design Film Festival returns with 10 films showcasing various design disciplines, including architecture, fashion, and product design. The festival features films such as "Konstantin Grcic: Design is Work" and "You're Soaking in It," which explore the design process and its impact on consumers. The festival runs from October 21-22 and October 27-29 at Capitol Theatre, with tickets available for $15.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Holdings is expected to see accelerated loan growth of 2.5% quarter on quarter in Q3 17, driven by consolidation of ANZ's businesses. UOB Kay Hian set a target price of S$24.48. Singapore Medical Group is expected to benefit from the acquisition of its third pediatric clinic, with a target price of S$0.78. China Everbright Water Limited is favored due to its large project portfolio, with a target price of S$0.54.

site_title: Economists sound note of caution on flip side of the sharing economy
summary: Economists at the Singapore Economic Policy Forum 2017 expressed caution about the sharing economy, citing potential negative externalities such as increased transient people and shared facility overcrowding. However, they also highlighted the benefits of sharing platforms, enabling more effective use of resources and promoting productivity. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran emphasized the need for a policy response that seizes new opportunities and mitigates disruption, ensuring "inclusive economic growth that can benefit all."

images.alt_text: ''What happened is that data has narrowed the distance between the borrowers and lenders, giving enough information so that they can trust each other. So what causes this sharing economy to take off today, especially in sectors such as real estate and transport? It's under-utilisation.'' - Jimmy Koh, managing director, business insights and analytics, sector solutions group, UOB

site_title: In a good space
summary: Celebrated designer Anouska Hempel is bringing her first hotel project, The Duxton Club, to Singapore, set to open in early 2018. Designed by Hempel and boutique hotel developers Harpreet Bedi and Satinder Garcha, the hotel will feature a unique blend of Chinese and eclectic influences. Each room will be individually created with a distinct colour theme, including a Chinese bed that requires guests to sleep on their side. Hempel, known for her hands-on approach and "eclectic, capricious" design style, will also oversee the hotel's restaurant and visual branding, including the use of "wok sticks" as chopsticks.

site_title: How valuable is a 'unicorn'? Maybe not as much as you think
summary: The term "unicorn" refers to private companies valued at over $1 billion, but their valuations may be exaggerated or based on wishful thinking. Companies like Uber ($62.5 billion), Airbnb ($31 billion), and Pinterest ($12.3 billion) are often referred to as unicorns, but their true worth may be lower due to various factors such as high valuation multiples and limited financial transparency. This raises questions about the accuracy of these valuations and the true value of these companies.

site_title: A new VW Golf swings into Singapore
summary: Volkswagen has launched a facelifted Golf in Singapore with three models, featuring new infotainment systems and upgraded engines. The range-topping Golf R boasts 290 horsepower, while the Golf GTI now has 230 horsepower and features radar-based blind spot monitoring and a smartphone app-controlled infotainment system. Prices start at S$175,900 for the GTI.

images.alt_text: The new Golf's arrival comes at a crucial time for Volkswagen.

site_title: A smashing success
summary: The WTA Finals' Racquet Club in Singapore is set to host its fourth edition, with over 90% of the 9,350 VIP hospitality tickets sold. The event, featuring top players like Venus Williams and Simona Halep, boasts premium food and beverage options, as well as opportunities to meet players and legends. The tournament's corporate hospitality program has seen significant interest, with companies snapping up tickets to catch the action from October 22-29.

site_title: Cheery mood spurs STI's rally for 5th day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 5.82 points to 3,340.73, its fifth consecutive gain, driven by optimism in major economies and firm US and local earnings. The rally was fueled by Keppel Corporation's 28-cent rise to S$7.30 on a volume of 15.9 million, and DBS and OCBC's 4.6-point gains. The STI's total weekly gain was 21.62 points, or 0.65%.

site_title: The unlikely places in London to buy a £1 million penthouse
summary: London's eight-year housing boom has led to £1 million flats being offered in areas historically associated with heavy industry and subsidized worker's housing. Telford Homes Plc has sold three penthouses in Stratford for over £1 million, with over 780 similar listings on Zoopla. Unlikely places for these luxury flats include Stratford Central, Borough, Tottenham Road, Royal Arsenal Riverside, Miramar Lodge, and Royal Wharf, with prices ranging from £1.05 million to £1.38 million.

site_title: Fragrance CEO makes offer for New Wave
summary: Fragrance Group CEO Koh Wee Meng is making a voluntary conditional cash offer to acquire New Wave Holdings at S$0.013 per share, a premium of 44.4% over its closing price. Koh, who owns 11.26% of New Wave, aims to keep the company listed on the Catalist board of SGX. The offer aims to address low trading liquidity, allowing shareholders to liquidate at a premium. If successful, New Wave's existing activities will continue, and major changes to the business are not anticipated.

site_title: MAS rolls out simpler, quicker process for venture capital managers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced a simpler and quicker process for venture capital managers, reducing the need for directors and representatives with extensive experience. The new regime focuses on existing anti-money laundering and fit and proper safeguards, and will not apply capital requirements and business conduct rules. To qualify, VC managers must manage funds for accredited and institutional investors, and invest at least 80% of committed capital in start-up securities. The MAS aims to enhance the operating environment for VC managers to support start-up and growth stage businesses.

site_title: How Mercedes-Benz aims to become King of SUVs
summary: Mercedes-Benz is shifting its focus towards becoming the "King of SUVs" with a diverse lineup of models. The luxury brand now accounts for more than 14% of its sales with SUVs, surpassing traditional cars. Mercedes has introduced six SUV families, catering to various tastes and budgets, and has seen a record 78,000 SUV deliveries in September, accounting for 35% of worldwide sales. The brand's product strategy is paying off, with customers drawn to SUVs' style and comfort over off-roading capabilities.

site_title: A major bear market around the corner? Not quite yet
summary: A major bear market may not be imminent, despite concerns over the US bull market's age and global economic indicators. The current cycle is in the "sweet spot" phase, with global economic indicators strong and growth forecasts revised up. Share market valuations are mostly okay, and there is no over-investment globally. US inflation is expected to rise, but it's unlikely to trigger a sharp fall in markets. Unlike 1987, share markets have not broken down, and economic growth was barely impacted, suggesting a longer bull market ahead.

site_title: Mazda CX-9 review: Singapore's sexiest seven-seater
summary: The Mazda CX-9 is a seven-seat SUV that aims to compete with luxury European models like Audi and Volvo, priced at S$188,800 with Certificate of Entitlement. The vehicle boasts a charismatic design, ample space for occupants and cargo, and advanced safety features. It also features a modern turbocharged engine and premium interior, making it a solid mid-range choice for buyers seeking a balance between style, practicality, and affordability. The CX-9 is a significant threat to European rivals, offering a unique blend of Mazda's style and European luxury.

site_title: Greenwich mansion listings pulled to wait for a better day
summary: Luxury-home listings in Greenwich, Connecticut, have plummeted 31% from the previous year, with sellers removing properties from the market due to lack of interest. Sales of luxury homes fell 13% to 21 transactions, while condo purchases surged 35% to 58 transactions. Smaller homes closer to downtown are selling faster, while oversized estates are lingering on the market. With inventory declining but sales not rising, brokers are shifting tactics to attract buyers, leading to a 34% increase in the median sale price of luxury homes to $6.5 million.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ascendas Reit's CEO Chia Nam Toon resigned for personal reasons, effective November 19. Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust posted a 5.8% rise in Q2 18 distribution per unit to 1.868 Singapore cents, driven by higher rental rates and lower accrued revenue. Sembcorp Industries inked a joint venture agreement with Nishi-Nippon Railroad Co to develop a residential project in Vietnam. SIIC Environment Holdings secured two build-operate-transfer wastewater projects in China's Jiangxi province.

site_title: Grab secures US$700m in debt financing to build S-E Asia's largest fleet
summary: Grab, a Singapore-headquartered ridesharing company, has secured US$700 million in debt financing from leading global and regional banks to build the largest car rental program in South-east Asia. The funds will be used to grow its fleet of private hire vehicles in Singapore and expand GrabRentals beyond Singapore and Indonesia. The company has also partnered with SMRT to build the largest and most advanced taxi and private-hire car fleet in Singapore. This move is seen as a significant step for Grab, which has already raised nearly US$3.5 billion in venture capital and private equity.

site_title: Top restaurant dishes up debts along with fine dining
summary: Le Cirque, a renowned New York restaurant, will close its doors on January 5 after declaring bankruptcy due to unsustainable rent costs. Despite grossing nearly $466,000 in August, the restaurant spent $506,635, resulting in a net loss of $40,666. Co-owner Mauro Maccioni attributes the decline to high rent and low sales, stating the brand will move on and potentially reopen in a new location. The restaurant's bankruptcy filing aims to protect other outlets under the Le Cirque brand, which maintain 10 locations worldwide.

site_title: Dymon Asia hedge fund to raise US$600m in equity expansion
summary: Dymon Asia Capital, a hedge fund manager, plans to raise $600 million in equity for its stock fund, expanding its business. The fund, which oversees $400 million, has returned 13% in the first nine months of 2017 and will be led by a team of eight managers specializing in different areas. The move comes as global hedge funds have attracted $3.8 billion in investor money, with Asian-focused funds gaining over 12% this year, their best performance since 2013.

site_title: Trading in Noble Group shares halted; market looking at potential 11th hour oil-unit sale
summary: Noble Group suspended trading of its shares in Singapore pending a major transaction, including the sale of its oil-trading unit. The company, facing a crisis spanning two years, has been selling units to meet obligations. A potential deal with Vitol Group, the world's largest independent oil trader, may be critical to Noble Group's survival. The company's debt has reached $4.6 billion, with $2 billion maturing by June 30 next year. The sale of the oil unit could leave Noble Group with a largely Asian portfolio and a significant impact on the company's prospects.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust Q4 DPU slips
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust's (FCOT) fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) fell 1.6% to 2.41 Singapore cents due to higher repair rates and lower occupancy rates for its properties. DPU for the full year remained unchanged at 9.82 Singapore cents. The trust's net property income (NPI) decreased 9% to S$26.74 million, mainly due to higher maintenance works and lower occupancy rates. Despite this, NPI for the Australian properties increased 2.5% year-over-year.

site_title: China's Logan Property buys Florence Regency for S$629m
summary: China's Logan Property has acquired the Florence Regency estate in Singapore's Hougang for S$629 million through a collective sale. The 336-unit development was sold after three bidders failed to match the independent valuation of S$629 million. This marks Logan Property's second land parcel in Singapore, following a S$1.003 billion purchase in May. The site's proximity to an MRT station and favorable location are seen as attractive features, with Logan Property expecting to build 1,400 units. The sale price is comparable to nearby sites and reflects a fair value for the site.

site_title: US existing home sales unexpectedly rebound in September
summary: US existing home sales unexpectedly rose 0.7% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.39 million units in September, reversing August's decline. The rebound was attributed to the dissipating effects of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma, but a persistent shortage of properties for sale continued to weigh on activity. Sales were down 1.5% from September 2016, and the median house price rose 4.2% to $245,100. The housing sector remains sluggish due to a 6.4% year-over-year decline in supply.

site_title: GIC diversifies further into renewable energy and tech
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC announced investments in two new ventures: a Japanese solar- and wind-power plant builder, GS Renewable Holdings, and a Chinese e-services platform, Meituan-Dianping. GIC's stake in GS Renewable Holdings was undisclosed, while its investment in Meituan-Dianping was part of a $4 billion funding round led by Tencent. The funds will be used to strengthen Meituan-Dianping's core business and invest in artificial intelligence-related technology. GIC aims to accelerate expansion and become the industry leader in the renewable energy sector.

site_title: Talk of the town
summary: The article discusses the silence surrounding the alleged sexual harassment and assault by Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein, and how it has now broken with the #MeToo movement. Powerful men in the industry have been accused of underestimating their power and only speaking out after the issue gained attention. The article concludes that silence from victims, including men, is not the problem, but rather the lack of effective whistle-blowing channels and the commoditization of social media debates. The #MeToo movement has shown the power of social media to mobilize, but also highlights the need for deeper, more meaningful discussions.

site_title: Brave new app
summary: Soho, a property discovery app, is set to launch in Singapore, aiming to disrupt the local market by providing a platform for property owners to create and manage online profiles, allowing buyers and renters to discover and approach them with offers. Unlike existing platforms like PropertyGuru and 99.co, which charge for listings, Soho will offer a free service for users, with a future subscription model for agents to advertise profiles and manage online rental payments. The app's founder, Jonathan Lui, believes it will unlock greater opportunities for transactions by enabling any property to be discovered, regardless of its current market status.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz GLC 200 review: Less expensive, but no lesser for it
summary: Mercedes-Benz has introduced a new, cheaper version of its GLC SUV, the GLC 200, priced S$10,000 lower than the existing GLC 250 4Matic. The GLC 200 features a 2.0-litre turbo engine, but lacks the 4Matic four-wheel-drive system. Despite this, it handled well in off-road conditions and offers sprightly acceleration, secure handling, and ample space in the back and boot. The decision to opt for the GLC 200 or the GLC 250 4Matic depends on individual priorities and budget.

images.alt_text: The GLC 200 looks every bit as rugged as any Mercedes SUV - towkays may favour the E-Class, but a cowboy would drive this instead.

site_title: Catalist meeting needs of growing companies; getting more investor interest
summary: The SGX Catalist board is attracting more growth companies and investors, with 47% of funds raised in the last two years coming from issuers with majority business outside Singapore. The board has seen a significant increase in institutional ownership and a diversification of sectors and geography. The SGX has also signed an agreement with Nasdaq to facilitate concurrent or sequential listing, enhancing access to capital markets. The number of Catalist-listed companies is expected to surpass 200 by the end of the year, with a total of 14 companies completing initial public offerings this year, raising S$3.1 billion of proceeds.

site_title: Troubled times for rail operator
summary: A rail operator is facing troubled times, but the article does not mention the operator's name or the specific issues it is facing. The article instead focuses on global news, including the election of young leaders such as Jacinda Ardern and Sebastian Kurz, and regional tensions in Spain over Catalonia's independence. Other news includes developments in US foreign policy, the growing influence of China in the AI talent war, and concerns about Hong Kong's credit culture.

site_title: Making the right investment for your vision
summary: An eye doctor emphasizes the importance of proper eye screening and timely treatment in maintaining good eyesight. Cataract and refractive errors can be effectively treated through surgery, but other conditions like glaucoma, age-related macular degeneration, and diabetic retinopathy often have irreversible outcomes if diagnosed late. Early detection and management can lead to better treatment outcomes, and regular eye screenings are crucial for all ages, from childhood to old age.

site_title: Former Secura CEO Paul Lim appointed independent director of Advance SCT
summary: Former Secura CEO Paul Lim has been appointed as an independent director of Advance SCT, effective Friday. The appointment was made due to his "vast experience" in listed companies and contributions to the business ecosystem and government sector. Lim stepped down from his role at Secura Group Limited on October 10, citing personal interests.

site_title: CMT posts flat DPU for Q3; negative rent reversion for first 9 mths
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) posted flat third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.78 Singapore cents, despite a 0.2% dip in gross revenue to S$169.41 million due to lower rentals from Bedok Mall and Plaza Singapura. The trust's portfolio experienced 1.7% negative rental reversion in the first nine months of 2017, mainly due to Westgate's 10.5% decline. Despite this, CMT's distributable income rose 0.3% to S$98.68 million.

images.alt_text: Westgate (above) recorded negative rental reversion of 10.5 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close down on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 3.34 points lower at 1,740.65 on Friday. The index saw 2.62 billion shares traded for RM2.24 billion. The market had 438 losers and 438 gainers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Noble Group halted trading pending a major deal, while Singapore Airlines is expected to place additional Boeing plane orders. Grab secured US$700 million financing and partnered with SMRT to build the largest car rental fleet in Singapore. The Open Electricity Market will launch in Jurong in April 2018. Few more Catalist-listed companies are expected to list by year's end.

site_title: Angelita Teo
summary: The National Museum in Singapore, now 130 years old, has undergone a transformation under the leadership of Director Angelita Teo, who aims to broaden its appeal and stay relevant for a modern-day audience. The museum has seen a significant increase in visitors, with over 800,000 people attending last year. Teo has introduced creative exhibitions, events, and programs, such as the Singapore Night Festival, to engage the public and encourage a museum-going culture. The museum now focuses on inclusivity, offering programs for seniors, people with special needs, and families, and has become a hub for community activities, collaborations, and partnerships.

site_title: IFAs say offers for GP Batteries, PTC Logistics 'fair'
summary: Independent financial advisors (IFA) have deemed buy-out offers for PTC Logistics and GP Batteries "fair" and "reasonable". The offers, pegged at S$1.30 per share, have been urged upon shareholders by the respective IFA. The buyouts, which are separate, have been seen as positive developments for the companies. The IFA's endorsement suggests that the offers are in line with market expectations, providing a level of reassurance for investors.

site_title: Time for some more beauties
summary: Swiss watch giants Richemont and Swatch groups have unveiled new luxury timepieces outside of traditional watch fairs like SIHH and Baselworld, generating buzz throughout the year. Key launches include Glashutte Original's Senator Excellence Perpetual Calendar, Harry Winston's Premier Diamond Second Automatic 36mm, Omega's Speedmaster 38mm "Orbis", Vacheron Constantin's Historiques Triple Calendar 1948, and Hublot's Arturo Fuente tribute. Limited-edition releases also include Piaget's Altiplano 60th Anniversary Pocket Watch and MB&F's Legacy Machine Split Escapement. Other notable releases include Laurent Ferrier's Galet Regulateur and A. Lange & Sohne's Jumping Seconds.

site_title: TADM recovers S$5m in unpaid wages; eyes mandatory mediation for other disputes
summary: The Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM) has successfully mediated salary-related disputes for 3,100 employees, with 90% recovering their unpaid salaries totaling S$5 million between April and September. Building on this success, TADM and the Employment Claims Tribunal are expanding their scope to include mandatory mediation of non-salary-related disputes. This move aims to further resolve workplace disputes and improve labor relations in Singapore.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines names new CEO after Bellew's abrupt departure
summary: Malaysia Airlines appoints Izham Ismail as group chief executive officer designate, replacing Peter Bellew who left to join Ryanair after nearly a year. Izham, who has served as chief operating officer since November, will be the airline's third CEO in two years, following Bellew's predecessor Christoph Mueller's departure. This change comes after Bellew's brief tenure.

site_title: SIA to finalise US$13.8b order from Boeing next week
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is set to finalize a US$13.8 billion aircraft order with Boeing after the weekend, following a letter of intent announced earlier this year. The deal is expected to be formally signed during Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's visit to Washington DC next week. SIA will provide more details after the signing of the purchase agreement.

site_title: Solar installers press homeowners to buy ahead of tariff
summary: US home solar companies, including Sunrun Inc, are warning homeowners to sign up for solar installations before tariffs on imported panels, which they believe will increase costs. The companies claim that panel prices could double in 2018, raising the cost of an average installation by $3,000. This move is seen as a strategy to boost sales as the industry faces a potential price hike due to tariffs.

site_title: London the starting line as Adidas laces up robotic shoe run
summary: Adidas has launched its first city-themed running shoe model in London, part of a six-city plan to capitalize on its new Speedfactory in Germany. The factory uses time-saving robotics to produce small batches of shoes tailored to specific markets and individual consumers. The shoes are designed to respond faster to fashion trends and offer more customization. Following London, the company plans shoe models inspired by Paris, New York, Los Angeles, Tokyo, and Shanghai. This move aims to increase customization and flexibility in production.

site_title: High steaks
summary: In Singapore, the demand for high-quality beef has led to a surge in "designer" beef, with restaurants and butchers competing to source unique breeds and dry-age methods. Australian wagyu and Japanese wagyu are no longer the only options, with Scottish Highland beef and American Angus beef gaining popularity. Dry-aged beef, in particular, is trending, with some restaurants aging their meat for up to 90 days. However, not all consumers care about the origin of their beef, with many prioritizing flavor and tenderness over provenance. The rise of dry-aged beef has led to a shift in consumer preferences, with many restaurants and butchers now offering high-end beef options.

site_title: EU opens investigation into Chinese e-bike imports
summary: The European Commission launched an investigation into Chinese e-bike imports after European producers complained of unfair subsidies and excessive low prices. The investigation, which will conclude within 15 months, follows a complaint from the European Bicycle Manufacturers Association, which said Chinese companies were flooding the EU market at prices below production costs. The move could raise trade tensions with China, particularly if the EU finds illegal subsidies, and is the latest in a series of probes into Chinese exports.

site_title: Daimler profit falls as Mercedes stumbles on diesel costs
summary: Daimler AG's profit fell 14% in the third quarter due to increased costs to fix emissions systems in older diesel cars, with Mercedes-Benz's earnings declining 22% to 2.15 billion euros. The company booked 453 million euros in charges for airbag recalls and upgrades. Despite this, Mercedes's margins remain at a "very good level" of 11.1%, and Daimler expects to boost group earnings and vehicle deliveries for the year. The company is also pushing ahead with plans to grant its car and truck operations more independence, potentially paving the way for spin-offs and deals.

site_title: Few more Catalist IPOs expected by year's end: SGX executive
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) expects a few more initial public offerings (IPOs) on Catalist by year's end, bringing the total number of Catalist-listed companies past 200. The pipeline includes companies from the US and frontier markets such as Armenia. So far this year, 14 companies have completed IPOs on SGX, with 10 listed on Catalist, raising S$3.1 billion in proceeds.

site_title: GE slashes profit outlook as deeper slump sends shares reeling
summary: GE slashes profit forecast, citing a deep slump in power-generation markets and poor cash flows. CEO John Flannery attributed the decline to a "difficult market" and stated that a majority of businesses had solid earnings performance. The company's shares plummeted in premarket trading, setting up a potential extension of the year's biggest loss on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. This cut is part of a repositioning effort under Flannery's leadership, which includes deep cost cuts and potential portfolio changes.

site_title: CMT's Q3 DPU unchanged at 2.78 Singapore cents
summary: Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT) reported unchanged Q3 distribution per unit at 2.78 Singapore cents, with distributable income increasing 0.3% to S$98.7 million. Gross revenue dipped 0.2% to S$169.4 million, while property operating expenses fell 4.2% to S$48.0 million. Net property income rose 1.6% to S$121.4 million, and management fees increased 2.1% to S$11.4 million. The counter closed one Singapore cent lower at S$2.04 on Friday.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust posts 5.8% rise in Q2 DPU
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) posted a 5.8% rise in its Q2 18 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.868 Singapore cents. The increase was driven by higher average rental rates from Festival Walk and Gateway Plaza, and lower accrued revenue for Gateway Plaza in Q2 17. The trust's distributable income rose 7.1% to S$52.5 million, and gross revenue increased 6.1% to S$88.1 million. MGCCT's distribution policy is to distribute on a semi-annual basis, with unitholders expected to receive the distribution on Nov 20, 2017.

site_title: CEO of Ascendas Reit's manager resigns
summary: Chia Nam Toon, CEO of Ascendas Reit's manager AFM, has resigned for personal reasons, effective November 19. Manohar Khiatani, non-executive director and deputy group CEO of AscendasSingbridge, has been nominated as the board's representative to work with AFM's management team. The company stated that operations will continue as usual with the support of an experienced management team. A successor CEO will be named in due course by the board.

site_title: Chinese smartphone upstart that beat Apple is now venturing West
summary: Vivo, a Chinese smartphone brand backed by billionaire Duan Yongping, is expanding into Western markets for the first time. The company, which has successfully competed with Apple and Samsung in China, will start selling in Russia, Taiwan, and Singapore. Vivo aims to target developed markets with higher-end devices, building on its success in China by using a strategy of enlisting thousands of retailers in rural areas. The company's expansion follows that of other Chinese firms, which have squeezed out foreign labels at home and explored markets abroad.

site_title: Singapore shares close 5.82 points higher on broad optimism
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 5.82 points to 3,340.73, driven by broad optimism in global economies and better US earnings. The index tracked Dow futures, which was up over 70 points before closing. Heavyweights Keppel Corporation, DBS, and OCBC supported the index, despite it failing to break the 3,354 barrier. Trading was firm, with gainers beating losers 253 to 188, and turnover reached S$1.2 billion.

site_title: EU leaders 'green-light' internal preparations for Brexit trade talks
summary: EU leaders have approved internal preparations for Brexit trade talks, despite insufficient progress on key divorce issues such as the UK's exit bill, EU citizens' rights, and the Northern Ireland border. The European Council invites EU ministers and Michel Barnier to start internal preparatory discussions by December, with the goal of adopting additional guidelines for the future relationship and transitional arrangements if progress is made. The next phase of negotiations is expected to focus on trade, with EU leaders agreeing to start internal preparations for this phase.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks bounce back on US tax hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.17% after a sharp decline the previous day. Investors were boosted by hopes for US tax-cutting plans by President Donald Trump, which could be market-friendly. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also saw gains, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 28,487.24 and the Shanghai Composite Index at 3,378.65. The rally came after a 2% drop on Thursday, as traders remained optimistic despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: US retailers struggle with hiring
summary: US retailers face difficulties in hiring employees due to low pay and uncertainty, following store closures and bankruptcies. Many retailers, including Macy's and JC Penney, plan to hire fewer seasonal workers for the holidays. The trend is attributed to the industry's struggle against online players like Amazon. Retailers are taking a staggered approach to hiring, filling gaps slowly, to address the labor shortage.

site_title: Moody's changes ESR-Reit's outlook to negative, affirms Baa3 rating
summary: Moody's has affirmed ESR-Reit's Baa3 investment grade rating, but changed its outlook to negative due to pressures on occupancy and rental rates, as well as debt-funded acquisitions. The rating agency expects ESR-Reit's leverage to weaken materially in 2018, exceeding its downgrade trigger of 7.5 times. The Baa3 rating is underpinned by the Reit's well-located industrial assets, diversified tenant base, and financial flexibility. The rating change comes after the Reit's acquisition of 8 Tuas South Lane, which is expected to further weaken its leverage.

site_title: Private sector left in dust in Indonesia's infrastructure push
summary: Indonesia's private sector is struggling to secure infrastructure projects, with state-owned enterprises (SOEs) dominating the market. Despite President Joko Widodo's 2014 plan to reduce SOEs' share of infrastructure investment, the private sector now handles only one in five projects. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati has called for an assessment of SOEs' efficiency, and the government is considering reforms to encourage private sector involvement. The country needs $1.5 trillion in infrastructure investment to catch up with emerging economies, and the World Bank warns that a thriving economy requires active private sector involvement.

site_title: Driving the S$2m Rolls-Royce Phantom
summary: The eighth Rolls-Royce Phantom is designed to usher in a new era for the luxury car maker. With a 92-year history, the Phantom nameplate is the longest-lived model line in automotive history. The new Phantom boasts a unique design, reflecting Rolls-Royce's commitment to timeless elegance. The car's unveiling marks a significant milestone for the company, solidifying its position as a symbol of luxury and sophistication.

site_title: Buyout offer fair and reasonable: IFA tell PTC Logistics shareholders
summary: Independent financial advisors have urged PTC Logistics shareholders to accept a buyout offer at S$1.30 per share, citing a "fair and reasonable" price from a financial perspective. The offer values the firm at S$275.5 million, considering premiums, liquidity, and superior price performance against the Singapore equity market. The IFA's recommendation comes after PTC Logistics received the offer from Respond Logistics, backed by PTC Logistics' chairman Poh Choon Ann and Tower Capital logistics.

site_title: Jurong first to enjoy options for retail power supply
summary: Singapore is set to become the first area in the country to offer households and businesses the option to choose their electricity retailers in April 2023, marking the soft launch of a fully liberalized power market. Retailers have prepared by upgrading their back-end IT systems to handle increased volumes. Switching to the wholesale electricity market could save households 15-25% compared to the current regulated tariff. The move is expected to lead to increased competition in the market, with retailers ready to battle for the household market.

site_title: First long-span wind turbine fans Singapore's renewable energy drive
summary: Singapore has deployed its first long-span wind turbine on Semakau Landfill, producing enough power for 45 four-room HDB units for a year. The turbine is part of the Renewable Energy Integration Demonstrator - Singapore (REIDS) initiative, backed by the EDB and NEA, and is expected to attract S$20 million in projects over the next four years. The initiative aims to develop hybrid "microgrids" that can produce the equivalent of 100 four-room HDB flats' energy requirements, with the goal of occupying over 64,000 sq m of land.

site_title: BHP's chairman says speculation of a set tenure for CEO is false
summary: BHP's chairman, Ken MacKenzie, has denied speculation that CEO Andrew Mackenzie's term is set to end, calling it "false and without merit." MacKenzie, who took office in September, stated that he and Mackenzie were running the company and had met with over 100 shareholders across eight countries, giving him confidence. The chairman acknowledged areas where the company needs to sharpen its focus but reiterated work is in progress to reshape the portfolio and refresh the board, with a review of board skills and experience requirements planned.

site_title: New Zealand shares recover early losses to gain for a 5th week; Australia up
summary: New Zealand shares rose for a fifth straight week, gaining 0.5% for the week, after Prime Minister-elect Jacinda Ardern agreed with Labour Party to form a new coalition government. The benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 5.48 points to a record high of 8,129.55. Australian shares also posted minor gains, driven by consumer shares and financials, with the Australian main index up 0.18%. Gains were offset by declines in the healthcare sector, led by CSL Ltd.

site_title: Titanic victim's letter expected to sell for thousands
summary: A hand-written letter from a Titanic victim, Alexander Oskar Holverson, is set to auction for up to £80,000. The letter, written on embossed Titanic "on-board" stationery, describes Holverson's experiences on the ship, praising its food and music. The letter was found on Holverson's body after the ship sank in 1912. It is expected to fetch a significant sum at the auction, providing a rare glimpse into the lives of first-class passengers on the ill-fated voyage.

site_title: Singapore's game startup Sea raised US$884m in New York IPO
summary: Singapore's game startup Sea Ltd raised about $884 million in its initial public offering (IPO) in New York, selling 59 million American depositary shares for $15 each. The company, backed by Tencent Holdings Ltd, has a net loss of $165.2 million in the first half of the year, but investors are betting on its future growth. Sea's valuation is expected to surpass $4 billion with the IPO, and the company's founder, Forrest Li, believes it can become a major player in the industry despite its losses.

site_title: New Zealand election result stokes housing, migration fears
summary: New Zealand's incoming coalition government, led by Prime Minister-elect Jacinda Ardern, has announced plans to cut net immigration by up to 30,000 and restrict foreign ownership of houses, sparking fears of a housing and migration crisis. The move is expected to deter temporary workers and foreign students, who were previously attracted to New Zealand on the promise of residency. The policy shift is seen as a shift towards a more restrictive immigration policy, similar to those in European and US countries, and may lead to a rush of foreign property investment before new rules are introduced.

site_title: Open Electricity Market to roll out in Jurong in April 2018
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) announced that households and businesses in Jurong will be the first in Singapore to choose their electricity retailers in a fully liberalized power market starting April 2018. Approximately 108,000 households and 9,500 businesses with specific postal codes will be eligible, with the option to purchase electricity from a retailer or SP Group at a regulated tariff. The rollout is part of the EMA's goal to promote competition in the electricity market, offering consumers competitive pricing and innovative packages.

site_title: Europe: Ericsson, Volvo propel stocks as Spain lags
summary: European shares rose 0.2% in early deals on Friday, rebounding from losses, driven by strong earnings reports from Volvo and Ericsson. The STOXX 600 index recovered from its lowest October closing level, while euro zone blue chips gained 0.3%. In contrast, Spain's IBEX fell 0.1% ahead of a special cabinet meeting on Catalonia's autonomy. The IBEX has lagged the STOXX 600 in October, despite a 9% year-to-date gain.

site_title: Simplified rules for Singapore VC managers take effect on Oct 20
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) introduced a simplified regulatory regime for venture capital fund managers on October 20, 2017, reducing the need for directors and representatives with at least five years of experience. The new regime focuses on existing fit and proper and anti-money laundering safeguards, and retains regulatory powers to address errant managers.

site_title: Greenwich mansion listings pulled to wait for a better day
summary: Luxury home listings in Greenwich, Connecticut, have dropped 31% from last year, with sales of high-end homes falling 13% and condo purchases increasing 35%. Sellers are pulling their properties off the market, waiting for a better day, as tastes shift towards smaller, closer-to-downtown homes. The median sale price of luxury homes increased 34% to $6.5 million, while smaller homes are selling faster, with some areas taking up to 7.8 months to sell all listed properties.

site_title: Sembcorp joins hands with Japan's Nishi-Nippon Railroad for residential development in Vietnam
summary: Sembcorp Industries has partnered with Japan's Nishi-Nippon Railroad to develop a residential project in Hai Phong City, Vietnam. The joint venture, held by Sembcorp's subsidiary VSIP JSC and NNR, aims to build landed houses and shophouses with clubhouse amenities. The project is conditional on VSIP JSC completing a master plan revision by mid-2018. NNR holds 70% of the joint venture, with VSIP JSC holding 30%. The development will be situated within the 1,600-hectare VSIP Hai Phong Integrated Township and Industrial Park.

site_title: US dollar rises after US Senate passes budget blueprint
summary: The US dollar rose 0.6% against the yen to 113.17 yen after the US Senate approved a budget blueprint, paving the way for a tax-cut package without Democratic support. The 10-year US Treasury yield rose to 2.3429%, its highest since October 6. The dollar's increase is attributed to market expectations of a potential tax cut, which could boost economic growth and lead to higher interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia's September inflation rate picks up to 4.3% y-o-y, meets forecast
summary: Malaysia's September inflation rate rose 4.3% year-over-year, matching forecast, marking the second consecutive month of gains. Higher fuel costs drove the increase, with the transport index rising 15.8% and the food and non-alcoholic beverages index increasing 4.6%. This surpasses the central bank's 2017 target of 3-4% inflation.

site_title: Grab bags US$700m financing, partners SMRT to build region's 'largest car rental fleet'
summary: Grab has secured up to US$700 million in debt financing and partnered with SMRT to build the region's largest car rental fleet in Singapore. The partnership will utilize SMRT's fleet management capabilities and offer competitive rental terms. Grab aims to have the largest car rental fleet in South-east Asia by the end of 2018, further consolidating its market lead.

site_title: Silverlake Axis plans to acquire three Silverlake private entities
summary: Silverlake Axis, a Singaporean mainboard-listed company, plans to acquire three Malaysian entities - Silverlake Digital Economy, Silverlake Digitale, and Silverlake One Paradigm - owned by its executive chairman Goh Peng Ooi. The acquisition price consists of a base sum of RM154.9 million and a variable performance-based earn-out consideration. The deal aims to strengthen Silverlake's position as a financial services innovation accelerator, with the acquired companies becoming wholly-owned subsidiaries. The earn-out consideration is tied to a 25% year-on-year increase in adjusted post-tax profit over FY18 to FY2020.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel gains 4% as Q3 profit rises 30%
summary: Keppel Corporation rose 4% on Friday after its Q3 profit increased 30% to S$291.8 million, the first year-over-year growth since 2014. The company's multi-business approach offset the downturn in its offshore and marine division. This marked the first time both quarterly revenue and operating profit rose year-on-year.

site_title: Hotelier IHG says hurricanes hit revenue growth in Americas
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG) reported a slowdown in revenues in its Americas business due to the effects of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma. Revenue per available room (RevPAR) rose 0.8% in the third quarter, compared to 1.1% in the second quarter and 1.9% a year earlier. The company attributed the decline to the hurricanes, which impacted group bookings and managed estate performance. However, global comparable RevPAR was up 2.3% in the third quarter, driven by strong growth in European markets. IHG also announced changes to its leadership, including the appointment of Elie Maalouf as an executive director.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks bounce in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded 0.78% in early trade on Friday, recovering from previous day's losses. The Hang Seng Index rose to 28,377.34, while Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices declined 0.20% and 0.22% respectively. This comes amid Chinese economic growth data showing a slight easing.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at record high as central bank raises growth outlook; won edges up
summary: South Korean stocks reached a record high on Friday after the Bank of Korea upgraded its economic outlook, boosting investor confidence. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.7% at 2,489.54 points, driven by strong demand for tech firms like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The South Korean won also edged up, supported by foreign inflows into stocks, closing at 1,131.0 to the dollar. The Bank of Korea raised its 2017 economic growth forecast to 3% from 2.8%, fueling expectations for an interest rate hike as soon as November.

site_title: Noble halts trading pending major deal; was in talks to sell oil trading unit
summary: Noble Group halted trading of its shares pending a major deal announcement. The company has been in talks to sell its oil trading unit to Vitol Group, amid $1 billion of debt under secured credit facilities. The sale comes amid complicated negotiations, with Vitol's CEO stating that a deal is "very, very complicated". The largest debt chunk matures in mid-January, and the outcome of the sale is uncertain.

site_title: Two Singaporeans charged with running fee scam on foreign jobseekers
summary: Two Singaporean men, Terry Tan-Soo I-Hse and Clarence Lim Jun Yao, have been charged with running a fee scam targeting over 300 foreign jobseekers. The men operated three sham companies, submitting 449 work pass applications that were rejected 445 times. They face 442 charges under the Companies Act and Employment of Foreign Manpower Act, with possible sentences of up to seven years in prison or fines of up to SGD 15,000.

site_title: Key challenge to formulate inclusive economic policies: Iswaran
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran emphasized the need for inclusive economic growth, citing challenges such as stagnating incomes and varying productivity levels among firms. To address these, he proposed two-pronged approach: building deep skills in people and supporting enterprises to adopt technologies, innovate, and scale up. Iswaran also highlighted opportunities in the rapid growth of ASEAN, particularly in deepening and diversifying international connections.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index posts record winning streak
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index reached a record high, posting its 14th consecutive day of gains, to close at 21,457.64. The Nikkei 225 rose 0.04% and the broader Topix index gained 0.03%. Nissan dropped due to a production suspension. This marks the longest winning streak in nearly six decades, last seen in 1961.

site_title: Aso says Japan firms' piling up of internal reserves has gone too far
summary: Finance Minister Taro Aso criticized Japanese companies for piling up internal reserves too much, calling for increased spending on wages and business investment. Aso also dismissed media reports that the US demanded bilateral free trade talks with Japan. He met US Vice-President Mike Pence in Washington for an economic dialogue.

site_title: Fragrance's Koh Wee Meng to bid for New Wave at S$0.013/share
summary: Real estate tycoon Koh Wee Meng plans to make a voluntary conditional cash offer for New Wave Holdings at S$0.013/share, representing a 44.4% premium over the company's closing price. Koh seeks majority control but intends to keep New Wave listed. The offer is conditional on obtaining a majority stake in the company, and Koh plans to maintain existing activities with no major changes. He currently holds an 11.26% stake in New Wave, and the offer is facilitated by OCBC bank and investment company JK Global Assets.

site_title: Majority of South Koreans support building 2 new nuclear reactors: survey
summary: A South Korean government-organised committee recommends resuming the construction of two stalled nuclear reactors, citing a survey showing 59.5% of respondents support the move. The reactors were halted in June after concerns over atomic safety, but the survey suggests the public is in favor of proceeding. Shares of Korea Electric Power Corp surged 5.6% following the announcement. The recommendation is expected to be presented to the government for approval.

site_title: Lupita Nyong'o speaks out about Harvey Weinstein
summary: Lupita Nyong'o shares her experience of being assaulted by Harvey Weinstein in 2011. She met him at an awards ceremony in Berlin, where he introduced himself as the most powerful producer in Hollywood. Over several encounters, Weinstein's behavior became increasingly uncomfortable, including a massage in his bedroom that he insisted on. Nyong'o tried to rationalize the situation, but eventually set boundaries, politely declining his advances. The final encounter, at a Tribeca Grill, ended with Weinstein telling her they were "two ships passing in the night" and that she could leave. Nyong'o felt a sense of relief and relief after the encounter, but also a sense of unease about the potential consequences of speaking out.

site_title: Asian shares edge higher, Fed chief speculation tempers appetite
summary: Asian shares rose slightly, edging higher on Friday, despite speculation about the next US Federal Reserve chief, which kept investors wary. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index was up 0.1% in early trading, but down 0.2% for the week. The US dollar and bond yields dipped after President Trump's leaning towards Jerome Powell as the next Fed chair. Japan's Nikkei slipped 0.3% and New Zealand shares fell 0.1% after a nationalist party agreed to form a new government.

site_title: End of Australia auto-making sector as Holden closes doors
summary: Holden, Australia's last remaining car manufacturer, closed its Elizabeth plant in South Australia on Friday, marking the end of a 69-year industry. The closure, blamed on the federal government's withdrawal of subsidies, follows the end of production at Toyota and Ford plants earlier this year. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull expressed sadness, while the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union blamed the government for the industry's demise. The closure will leave 950 staff and marks the end of an era for the nation's auto-making sector.

site_title: GIC invests in e-commerce platform, enters Japan's infrastructure and renewable energy space
summary: GIC, a global investment firm, has made its maiden investment in Japan's infrastructure and renewable energy sector through a partnership with Japan Renewable Energy Corp (JRE). GIC has invested in GS Renewable Holdings GK, JRE's parent, without disclosing the investment's size. This move marks GIC's entry into Japan's renewable energy space. Separately, GIC also participated in a US$4 billion funding round for Meituan-Dianping, a Chinese services e-platform. The investments demonstrate GIC's focus on emerging markets and growth opportunities.

site_title: Tarantino knew of Weinstein misconduct, regrets not doing more
summary: Quentin Tarantino admitted to knowing about Harvey Weinstein's alleged sexual misconduct for decades, despite not stopping their professional relationship. Tarantino told the New York Times he knew of multiple incidents involving prominent actresses, including his ex-girlfriend Mira Sorvino. He expressed regret for not doing more, stating he had marginalized the incidents as mild misbehavior. The allegations against Weinstein have led to his resignation from The Weinstein Company and an ongoing police investigation. Tarantino's close professional relationship with Weinstein spanned decades, including collaborations on films such as Pulp Fiction and Django Unchained.

site_title: Tencent-backed games developer Sea poised to raise US$850m in IPO: sources
summary: Sea Ltd, a Tencent-backed games developer, is set to raise over $850 million in its initial public offering (IPO) with shares priced at $15. The company, which has benefited from Tencent's support, plans to diversify into e-commerce and payments despite rising losses. Sea is valued at over $4 billion, making it one of the most valuable startups in South-east Asia. The IPO, led by Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, is expected to be one of the largest in the region.

site_title: NZ shares dip after new government coalition formed; Australia flat
summary: New Zealand shares dropped 0.032% on Friday, snapping a 13-session winning streak, after the Labour Party and New Zealand First Party formed a coalition government led by Jacinda Ardern. Ardern will be the Pacific nation's youngest leader in over 150 years, with a focus on raising the minimum wage. Utilities, telecoms, and consumer discretionary stocks were hit hard, while Australian shares were little changed. Market participants worry about curbs on migration and foreign ownership, which could hurt growth and attract higher interest rates.

site_title: Tillerson signals impatience with China while vowing to stay on
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson signaled growing impatience with China, particularly on North Korea and trade, while vowing to stay in his position as long as President Trump wants him. Tillerson criticized China's actions in the South China Sea and accused the country of undermining the "international, rules-based order." He also expressed pessimism about resolving the Qatar-Saudi Arabia standoff and said the US is seeking China's help in curbing North Korea's nuclear program. Tillerson emphasized his commitment to serving the country and president, despite rumors of his potential resignation.

site_title: New rules to improve Singapore's industrial energy efficiency from Oct 1, 2018
summary: Singapore will introduce new rules to improve industrial energy efficiency starting October 1, 2018. The National Environment Agency (NEA) will set minimum energy performance standards for motors at the premium level, phasing out inefficient motors. Companies investing in new facilities consuming 54 tera-joules or more annually will be required to review facility design for energy efficiency. Additionally, they must install measurement instruments and report energy use and performance indicators. These measures aim to reduce emissions intensity by 36% by 2030 and align with international standards, ultimately reducing carbon footprint and cost savings for companies.

site_title: Amid South Korea freeze, China says cultural exchanges take the temperature
summary: China has stated that cultural exchanges with South Korea should consider the "temperature" of popular opinion, amid a freeze in ties over an anti-missile system. China's Deputy Media Regulator, Zhang Hongsen, said cultural exchanges are not about exchanging goods, but about aligning with popular feelings and emotions. He emphasized that when popular sentiments align, cultural exchanges can develop positively. This comes as South Korea has pulled K-pop performances, cancelled concerts, and reduced Chinese tourists due to the dispute over the US-made Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) system.

site_title: Singapore shares open up on Friday
summary: Singapore shares rose on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 9.99 points to 3,344.90, driven by gains in Keppel and City Developments. Trading volumes were high, with 80.5 million shares changing hands worth S$112.8 million. The S&P 500 also reached a record, despite US trade uncertainty. The STI has now enjoyed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors remaining positive despite tariff concerns.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks higher on bullish central bank outlook
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, driven by a bullish economic outlook from the Bank of Korea, which upgraded its growth forecast to 3% and is expected to hike interest rates.
