Major tech firms like Samsung and SK Hynix gained 2% and 3.5%, respectively, while utilities shares rose due to a government-organised committee's recommendation to resume nuclear reactor construction. Foreign investors purchased 57.3 billion won worth of Kospi shares, supporting the benchmark index, which closed at 2,483.22 points.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust posts 1.6% dip in Q4 DPU at 2.41 S cents
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 1.6% decline in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.41 Singapore cents, down from 2.47 cents in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to higher repair rates and lower occupancy rates for its properties. Despite this, FCOT's full-year DPU remained unchanged at 9.82 Singapore cents. The trust also announced a S$38 million renovation of China Square Central's retail podium and reported a 1.3% increase in full-year distributable income to S$78.6 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower, Nissan under pressure
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, following a profit-taking session after the benchmark index posted its longest string of gains in nearly 30 years. The Nikkei 225 fell 0.32% to 21,380.80, while Nissan dropped after unveiling plans to suspend production amid an inspection scandal.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust's Q3 DPU up 2.6% at 2.36 S cents
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 2.6% increase in distributable per unit (DPU) to 2.36 Singapore cents in Q3 2017, driven by lower operating expenses and stronger performance from CapitaGreen. Distributable income rose 7% to S$73.11 million, while net property income grew 2.7% to S$58.56 million. CCT also announced a fully underwritten S$700 million renounceable rights issue exercise to fund the acquisition of Asia Square Tower 2, which has a committed occupancy rate of 88.7%.

site_title: Japan's recovery not felt at street level
summary: Japan's economy, touted as the world's third-largest, is experiencing a prolonged recovery, but its benefits are not being felt at the street level. Despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policy, which has resulted in strong growth and solid business confidence, many shop owners and elderly citizens are struggling to make ends meet. Median household income has dropped 20% compared to two decades ago, and deflation and a mountain of debt remain significant challenges. The election highlights a widening gap between workers at big companies and those on temporary contracts, with many young people unable to afford childcare, leading to a declining working-age population.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 1.04 points to 1,745.03. Volume was 50.82 million lots worth RM12.3 million, with 80 gainers outnumbering 67 losers.

site_title: Nissan production shutdown delivers fresh blow to Japan Inc
summary: Nissan Motor Co suspended production at six Japanese plants for two weeks due to uncertified workers performing quality checks. The halt affects 1,000 vehicles per day, with the export of models unaffected. The move is a fresh blow to Japan's manufacturing industry, which is already reeling from scandals. Nissan's CEO Hiroto Saikawa pledged to prevent recurrence and take drastic measures, while the Japanese government vowed to take action against the company. The shutdown is estimated to dent Nissan's domestic sales by 20,000 units and erase 10 billion yen from its operating profit.

site_title: Tech companies to lobby for immigrant 'Dreamers' to remain in US
summary: Nearly two dozen major US tech companies, including Google, Microsoft, and Facebook, are launching a coalition to advocate for legislation allowing young, undocumented immigrants, known as "Dreamers," to remain in the US and pursue permanent residency. The Coalition for the American Dream aims to push Congress to pass bipartisan legislation this year, amid the expiration of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. The companies, which employ over 72% of the top 25 Fortune 500 companies, will take out ads in news publications to raise awareness and pressure lawmakers to act.

site_title: Euro hits 6-day high as US yields fall; kiwi drops most in a year
summary: The euro reached a 6-day high at $1.1858 due to falling US Treasury yields, which favored lower interest rates and a weaker dollar. The move was also influenced by uncertainty surrounding the Catalonia region in Spain and the potential impact on the European Central Bank's policy meeting. The US dollar weakened against the Japanese yen and the New Zealand dollar, with the kiwi experiencing its largest drop in nearly a year.

site_title: Three million Americans carry a handgun daily: study
summary: A US study found that approximately 3 million Americans carry a loaded handgun daily, and 9 million carry one at least once a month. The majority of these individuals are young men from the southern United States, citing personal protection as a primary reason for carrying a gun. This study marks the first in 20 years to examine gun-carrying habits in the US, amid repeated fatal mass shootings.

site_title: Hong Kong-listed Logan Property bags Florence Regency for S$629m
summary: Hong Kong-listed developer Logan Property has acquired Florence Regency, a 336-unit HUDC estate in Hougang, Singapore, for S$629 million. The sale marks the second land parcel in Singapore snapped up by Logan Property, following its purchase of a site in Stirling Road for S$1.003 billion. The collective sale agreement required the sale price to be no lower than the valuation, and JLL, the marketing agent, courted other developers to close a deal within 10 weeks of the public tender's close. The site is zoned "residential" with a gross plot ratio of 2.8.

site_title: Give me Brexit deal I can 'defend' at home, May tells EU
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged European leaders to allow negotiations on a Brexit deal she can "defend" to voters and her party. May emphasized the need for a deal that can be stood behind and defended to the public. She spoke at a Brussels summit dinner, where the 27 leaders will decide whether to advance the talks.

site_title: CDL's two earlier offers met rejection by Millennium & Copthorne's IDs
summary: City Developments (CDL) has made two earlier offers to acquire Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) but was rejected by the company's independent directors. The independent directors rejected a 510p per share offer in August and a revised bid of 552.5p per share in September. CDL now has until November 6 to make a final offer for M&C.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on Catalonia standoff, disappointing Q3 earnings
summary: European shares fell 0.7% on Thursday as a standoff between Spain and Catalonia deepened, with Madrid poised to impose direct rule on the region. The STOXX 600 and Madrid's IBEX 35 indices declined, amidst disappointing Q3 earnings. The decline was also attributed to ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Brazil's govt opens path for 2.9 billion reais loan for cash-strapped Rio
summary: Brazil's National Monetary Council approved measures for the cash-strapped Rio de Janeiro state to obtain a loan of up to 2.9 billion reais (S$1.24 billion) from banks. The loan is aimed to address salary payments to employees, which have been delayed. Two ordinances are expected to be released next week to finalize the loan. Rio de Janeiro is deeply indebted after hosting the World Cup and Olympics, with a total debt of 43.3 billion reais.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB issues 'buy' on Aspen
summary: RHB Securities has issued a "buy" call on Aspen Holdings, citing its strategic partnership with Ikea's South-east Asian franchisee as a key growth factor. Aspen's flagship project, Aspen Vision City, will feature an Ikea store, expected to boost property prices and demand in Batu Kawan, Penang. RHB sees a 41% upside on the stock, with a target price of S$0.31. Key risks include Penang's market concentration and Aspen's execution ability. The broker believes the opening of Ikea outlets in Malaysia has boosted property values in the past, and expects a similar effect on Batu Kawan.

site_title: New Zealand Prime Minister-elect Ardern focuses on final touches in coalition deal
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister-elect Jacinda Ardern is finalizing details of her coalition deal with New Zealand First, one day after becoming the country's youngest leader in over 150 years. Ardern confirmed that most of her party's flagship policies have survived negotiations with Peters, and the parties are expected to release their agreements early next week. The New Zealand dollar fell 1.7% amid concerns over the new government's protectionist agenda, and the country's stock market also declined. Ardern plans to meet with her party to decide ministerial posts in the afternoon.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister-elect Jacinda Ardern said she would spend Friday ironing out issues and ministerial posts with coalition partner New Zealand First, one day after becoming the Pacific nation's youngest leader in more than 150 years.

site_title: Japan's Emperor Akihito likely to abdicate at end-March 2019: Asahi
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito, 83, is likely to abdicate at the end of March 2019, with Crown Prince Naruhito, 57, succeeding him in April, marking the first abdication by a Japanese monarch in nearly two centuries. The government is finalizing the schedule to minimize the impact on the transition, which will occur during the spring of 2019 to avoid conflicting with autumn and winter ritual events. Emperor Akihito has cited health concerns and a desire to rest after years of duty.

site_title: SIA adds Android Pay, Apple Pay services to its mobile app
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has added Android Pay and Apple Pay services to its mobile app, allowing users to pay for flights, seat selection, and travel insurance without needing to enter payment information. Android Pay uses stored credit or debit card details, while Apple Pay stores a unique device account number in the secure element on the mobile device. This update aims to enhance user convenience.

site_title: UK fintech investment set for record-breaking year in 2017
summary: British fintech companies are expected to see record-breaking investment this year, with £825 million (S$1.47 billion) pumped into start-ups since 2017, double the amount from the same period last year. London, with 90% of that investment, is dominating the European fintech sector, outstripping other cities. Despite Brexit concerns, investors are drawn to London's high concentration of financial service players and its ability to partner with established players, with Silicon Valley still pulling in more investment overall.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ekes out record high, turns higher after Fed Powell report
summary: The US stock market closed at record highs on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Dow turning higher after a report suggested Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell is the leading candidate for Fed chair. This news boosted investors' confidence in a continuation of the current monetary policy, which has fueled the market's eight-year bull run. Despite early losses, stocks recovered and reached new records, driven by Powell's potential nomination.

site_title: SIA to buy more Boeing planes, TPP updates may arrive by Apec summit: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expects Singapore Airlines to finalize Boeing aircraft orders during his US visit, with a possible signing of a $13.8 billion order for 20 777-9s and 19 787-10s. He also hopes for updates on the Trans-Pacific Partnership by the Apec summit in November, which will exclude the US. Lee downplays the US's withdrawal from the deal, stating that trade links between the two regions will continue.

site_title: AIA quarterly new business value rises 20%, meets estimates
summary: AIA Group Ltd reported a 20% increase in its value of new business, reaching US$824 million, exceeding analysts' estimates. The growth was driven by fast expansion in China, offsetting moderating sales in Hong Kong. New CEO Ng Keng Hooi's ability to sustain growth momentum is being closely watched, as policy sales to mainland Chinese visitors slowed following currency depreciation and payment curbs.

site_title: SIIC Environment wins two wastewater projects in China
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings has won two build-operate-transfer (BOT) wastewater projects in Jiangxi Province, China. The company's subsidiary, Ranhill Water (Hong Kong) Limited, was awarded the Yongfeng Industrial Park BOT project with a base tariff of 1.91 yuan per tonne, while Ranhill (Wanzai) Water Co Ltd won the Wanzai Industrial Park BOT project with a base tariff of 2.52 yuan per tonne. Both projects have a concessionary period of 29 years.

site_title: Gold recovers from one-week low as dollar, equities sag
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,286.31 an ounce, recovering from a one-week low of $1,276.22, as the dollar index and equities declined. The 10-year Treasury yields dropped, contributing to the dollar's decline. Despite gold's gain, it has lost 6% since September 8. The rally in gold was partly driven by Trump's announcement of fresh tariffs on Canada and tariff threats to others, keeping markets volatile.

site_title: China's bold gas plan could result in winter of discontent
summary: China has ordered state oil companies to accelerate the construction of pipelines to transport natural gas to homes and factories, amid concerns that the country's insufficient infrastructure may cause power outages during peak winter demand. This move is part of Beijing's effort to boost clean fuel use, as millions of homes in northern regions will be heated by gas for the first time. China's lack of infrastructure could lead to disruptions, particularly in colder regions, where gas is being used for the first time.

site_title: Steelmakers' business gets harder and harder
summary: Japanese steel companies face increasing pressure to provide high-quality metals to compete, as customers demand advanced products for weight reduction while maintaining strength and versatility. Kobe Steel's scandal, which involved falsifying data on aluminium, copper, and iron powder sales, highlights the industry's challenges. To remain competitive, Japanese steelmakers must meet stringent quality standards, which could lead to higher production costs and potentially impact the country's industrial economy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, CCT, GuocoLand, New Wave, SIIC
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a 30% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$291.83 million. CapitaLand Commercial Trust's net property income rose 2.6% to 2.36 Singapore cents, driven by lower operating expenses. GuocoLand posted a higher first-quarter net profit of S$165.55 million. Real estate tycoon Koh Wee Meng plans to make a voluntary conditional cash offer for New Wave Holdings at S$0.013 apiece. SIIC Environment Holdings was awarded two build-operate-transfer wastewater projects in Jiangxi Province, China.

site_title: HDB's new online resale portal heralds disruption
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) is introducing an online resale portal, set to launch on January 1, 2018, which will automate many offline processes in a resale transaction, reducing transaction time from 16 weeks to 8. The portal will cut down buyers' and sellers' appointments with HDB officers from two to one, and may also make redundant jobs of agents and small valuation firms that rely on HDB resale valuations. The HDB will use technology to calculate property values, potentially disrupting the valuation industry and affecting valuers who focus on HDB resale valuations.

site_title: Life of a man, told without words
summary: Actor Ramesh Meyappan stars in "Off Kilter," a one-man play about mental illness told without words. The story follows Joe Kilter, a corporate worker who loses his job and descends into anxiety and confusion. Meyappan uses non-verbal expression, including mime and magic tricks, to convey the protagonist's emotional journey. The play explores themes of loneliness and existential fears, resonating with audiences who have experienced similar struggles. Meyappan's performance, directed by Andy Arnold, is a minor miracle, allowing viewers to interpret the intimate world of Joe Kilter.

site_title: Ageing population triggers debate on GDP growth, interest rates
summary: A JPMorgan Asset Management report has sparked debate over the impact of an ageing population on global economic growth and interest rates. The report notes that the global ageing trend is accelerating and synchronizing across countries, with slower labour force gains potentially weighing on economic growth. This raises concerns about the need for lower interest rates to stimulate growth. The report comes as countries such as China and Singapore face significant demographic challenges, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and Singapore's ageing population prompting a re-evaluation of interest rate policies.

site_title: LVMH stocking up on cognac, starting with more vineyards
summary: LVMH's luxury goods maker is addressing a cognac shortage by planting more grapes and expanding production capacity. Hennessy, a major revenue driver, will increase production to 10 million crates annually, with a new 100 million-euro plant expected to lift production capacity. The company aims to boost sales of lower-end "VS" stocks in the US, where cognac is a popular base for cocktails, and plans to release more stocks in the short term, despite a two-year production gap.

site_title: PayPal gets boost from stores looking to compete with Amazon
summary: PayPal is experiencing a boost in sales and growth as more retail stores seek to compete with Amazon by offering digital payment services. CEO Dan Schulman's strategy to expand PayPal beyond websites is gaining traction, with the company's Venmo service handling $9 billion in transactions in the third quarter. PayPal's total payment volume increased 30% to $114 billion, and the company reported a 21% revenue rise to $3.24 billion. Investors are optimistic about PayPal's potential, with shares gaining 6.3% in extended trading, and the company projecting revenue growth for the current quarter.

site_title: London Stock Exchange CEO to step down by end of 2018
summary: London Stock Exchange CEO Xavier Rolet will step down by the end of 2018, a decade after transforming the company through acquisitions. Under his leadership, the LSE's market value rose from under 1 billion pounds to almost 14 billion pounds, driven by diversification. Rolet's efforts to merge with Deutsche Boerse failed, but he ensured his main customers, investment banks, had a significant stake in the exchange's operations, leading to strong growth. Rolet's departure will focus on ensuring a smooth transition to a new CEO.

site_title: US housing starts hit 1-year low
summary: US homebuilding fell to a one-year low in September, with single-family home starts decreasing 4.7% to 1.127 million units. Groundbreaking in the south dropped 9.3% due to Hurricane Harvey and Irma, which disrupted construction in the region. Building permits also declined 4.5% to 1.215 million units. Despite this, housing market fundamentals remain solid, with low unemployment and rising wages, and economists expect housing starts to rebound in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Ascott acquires its first Silicon Valley hotel
summary: Ascott Limited has acquired The Domain Hotel in Silicon Valley, California, for S$81.5 million. The 136-unit hotel will undergo refurbishment and be rebranded as Citadines Cupertino Sunnyvale in the fourth quarter of 2018. The acquisition aims to capture the growing demand from global technology companies and multinational corporations.

site_title: Toyota, Honda, Mazda vouch for safety of Kobe Steel's aluminium parts
summary: Japanese carmakers Toyota, Honda, and Mazda have found no safety issues with aluminium parts made by Kobe Steel Ltd, despite the steelmaker's admission of falsifying quality data on products for over 10 years. The companies' statements suggest that Kobe Steel's cheating scandal may have limited impact on product safety, with Toyota confirming that its aluminium plates supplied by Kobe Steel were safe to use. However, Kobe Steel still faces a US Justice Department probe and must report on any safety concerns by the end of next week.

site_title: Self-taught, 'superhuman' AI now even smarter: makers
summary: A self-taught AI system, dubbed AlphaGo Zero, has surpassed its predecessor in mastering the ancient Chinese board game go, with a 100-0 win rate against its forerunner. The AI learned by itself, using a novel approach called reinforcement learning, and devised its own strategies without human input. This breakthrough demonstrates the potential for machines to achieve superhuman abilities without human guidance, and highlights the importance of algorithms over big data in achieving success.

site_title: North Korea warns threats a 'big miscalculation' in letter to Australia lawmakers
summary: North Korea has sent a letter to Australia's parliament, warning that US President Donald Trump's threats to destroy it will be a "big miscalculation" and an expression of ignorance. The letter, published in an Australian newspaper, states that North Korea is a nuclear power and will not be intimidated. Trump had threatened to "totally destroy" North Korea, which the letter claims is an "extreme act of threatening to totally destroy the whole world." The letter was verified by Australia's foreign ministry, and North Korea's nuclear capabilities are being closely watched globally.

site_title: Health insurer Anthem cuts ties with pharmacy-benefits manager Express Scripts
summary: Health insurer Anthem Inc. has severed ties with pharmacy-benefits manager Express Scripts Holding Co, opting to build its own pharmacy-benefits business in collaboration with CVS Health Corp. Anthem's move aims to contain spiraling drug costs and is part of a trend towards integrated models. The deal will save Anthem at least $4 billion a year on drug costs, with 20% benefiting shareholders. Express Scripts remains well-positioned to compete as a stand-alone firm, with CEO Brian Henry stating its independence is crucial to its value.

site_title: Facebook joins effort to boost newspaper subscriptions
summary: Facebook has announced initiatives to help struggling news organizations gain paid subscribers. The social network giant will test "premium news models" for partner publishers, giving them control over pricing, subscriber relationships, and revenue. This move follows a similar effort by Google, and aims to support the development of sustainable business models for news organizations. The test will be designed in collaboration with a diverse group of partners, with the goal of refining and developing a premium news model that works for various publishers.

site_title: Oil drops more than 1% on profit taking after 4 days of gains
summary: Oil prices dropped more than 1% on Thursday, reversing four days of gains, due to larger-than-expected US product inventories and profit-taking. Brent crude settled at $57.23 a barrel, down 92 cents, while US light crude fell to $51.29, down 75 cents. The decline is attributed to bearish market sentiment amid the Trump administration's tariff outlook. Despite this, oil prices remain 30% above mid-year levels, with US light crude nearly 25% higher than June's lows.

site_title: AmEx profit gets lift from unit built by incoming CEO
summary: American Express Co. reported a 14% increase in profit from its commercial cards division in the third quarter, led by the business built by incoming CEO Steve Squeri. This boost is expected to help the company increase revenue as Squeri takes the helm.

site_title: Jetstar Asia is 'most punctual Asia-Pacific airline'
summary: Jetstar Asia, a budget carrier, has emerged as the most punctual Asia-Pacific airline, according to UK-based OAG's latest on-time performance report. The airline achieved an on-time performance of 86.4% with 14 airlines securing a five-star rating. Changi Airport, also from Singapore, scored 81.3 and a three-star rating for on-time performance. Japan airports dominated the rankings, with nine airports from the country receiving five-star ratings for punctuality.

site_title: When agents migrate, it takes two to tango
summary: AIA Financial Advisers has successfully poached 300 Great Eastern (GE) agents, marking the largest migration in recent years. The move was driven by AIA's promise of greater digital adoption and technology, which appealed to the young and promising agents who crave efficiency in their sales processes. The migration package included significant incentives, but the incident raises concerns about the potential for switching policies, churning, or mis-selling. The regulator has safeguards in place, but more transparency is needed to protect consumers.

site_title: China's Q3 growth holds steady at 6.8%
summary: China's GDP growth remains steady at 6.8% in the third quarter, driven by a robust construction sector and domestic consumption. Despite efforts to dampen the property sector and deleverage company debt, the economy shows no signs of a hard landing. However, concerns linger over the acceleration of state investment growth outpacing private investment, which may hinder the government's push for private-sector innovation. Analysts warn that China's debt problem and focus on investment-led growth may lead to slower economic growth and higher volatility in the long term.

site_title: China policy moves, rate fears maul HK stocks
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.2% on Thursday, led by year's best performers, amid concerns over Chinese deleveraging and rising interbank rates. The Hang Seng Index closed 552 points down, its largest retreat since November, with Geely Automobile, ZTE Corp, and Hong Kong developers experiencing significant declines. China's economic expansion data showed broad momentum in the third quarter, but the lack of market support from the 19th Party Congress meeting fueled the sell-off.

images.alt_text: Flags of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (centre) and Hong Kong (right). The turmoil broke a sense of bullish calm that's prevailed throughout this year in Hong Kong's stock market.

site_title: China's Sept property sales drop for first time in over 21/2 years
summary: China's property sales dropped 1.5% in September, the first annual decline in over 2.5 years, as the country's economy slows down. Despite softening home prices in major cities, property bubbles remain a threat in other parts of the country. Housing starts also slowed sharply, reinforcing expectations of a cooling economy. Analysts predict no big rebound in property activity, citing a volatile market and potential financial risks. Policymakers are prioritizing stabilizing the overheated property market ahead of a critical Communist Party Congress.

site_title: Euro at one-week high as Catalonia crisis fails to deter bulls
summary: The euro reached a one-week high of $1.1837 due to investors' skepticism about the impact of the Catalonia crisis on the single currency. The European Central Bank is set to announce plans to unwind its stimulus policies next week, and the euro has remained relatively resilient despite recent political developments. Analysts expect the euro to face resistance around the $1.1880 level, but some investors are betting on a euro rally ahead of the ECB meeting. The dollar fell against the yen amid speculation about the Federal Reserve's leadership and the Japanese election.

site_title: Classical gems and Norwegian delights
summary: The 900-year-old Nidarosdomens Guttekor, Norway's oldest men and boys choir, will make their Singapore debut with two shows at the Esplanade on Friday and Saturday. The choir, known for their wide repertoire, will perform traditional Norwegian folk songs and classical works like Puccini's Messa di Gloria, which will be sung in its entirety for the first time in Singapore. Led by conductor Bjørn Moe, the choir will be accompanied by the re:SOUND Chamber Orchestra and will showcase Norwegian culture through their performance.

site_title: Unilever results take a hit as bad weather melts ice cream sales
summary: Unilever reported third-quarter sales growth that fell short of estimates, with underlying revenue rising 2.6% due to poor weather in Europe and hurricanes in the Americas cutting demand for ice cream. The company's refreshment business, including ice cream, saw volume decline, with US ice cream sales expected to return to growth next year. Unilever maintained its commitment to invest in fast-growing businesses and forecasted full-year underlying sales growth of 3-5%.

site_title: Oil's biggest traders argue over what price should be
summary: Oil's biggest traders are divided on the price, with some predicting it could rise above $60 a barrel in a year due to growing demand and Opec production cuts, while others believe it could fall to $45 due to US shale production. The disagreement underscores uncertainty over oil supply and demand, with the International Energy Agency increasing its estimate of 2017 oil demand growth. Despite Opec's efforts to cut production, traders remain uncertain about the market's direction, with prices currently trading at $58.14 a barrel.

site_title: North Korea is not just a nuclear threat but a cyberthreat
summary: North Korea poses a significant cyber threat, rivaling its nuclear capabilities. Experts estimate the country has over 6,000 hackers whose skills are improving, allowing them to target infrastructure and private sector systems. The US is vulnerable to attacks due to its heavy internet dependence, making it harder to retaliate. Cyber attacks can cripple power grids, financial networks, and transportation systems, causing social disorder and anarchy. The US has planted sleeper cells in North Korea's networks, but its commitment to the internet makes it more vulnerable to attacks.

site_title: China's big ball of money set for bounce back to stock market
summary: China's stock market is expected to see a rebound as the government's efforts to curb financial risks and redirect cash to the sector may lure investors back in. Analysts predict a 11 trillion yuan ($2.3 trillion) increase in Chinese equity holdings by 2020, driven by improved economic data and earnings. While there is a risk of another speculative frenzy, experts say the current fundamentals are stronger, and the market may experience a more gradual and lasting growth.

site_title: London bourse CEO fires back at Aramco IPO critics
summary: London Stock Exchange CEO Xavier Rolet defended the listing rules for Saudi Aramco's IPO, saying there is no 25% governance rule and that liquidity tests apply. He responded to criticism from the UK Investment Association, which argued that 25% should be the minimum free-float level for premium listed companies in the UK. Rolet cited examples of large companies with less than 25% free float, and proposed changes to the premium listing segment for state-owned businesses, which would exempt sovereign shareholders from certain rules.

site_title: Car2Go adds Mercedes sedans, SUVs to its New York fleet
summary: Car2Go, a car-sharing unit of Daimler AG, is adding Mercedes-Benz sedans and SUVs to its New York fleet, marking a shift from urban micro cars. The move aims to increase utilization rates, which have doubled in cities where Mercedes models are already in the fleet. Car2Go will replace 60% of its 6,000-vehicle North American fleet with Mercedes vehicles by the end of the year, with some Smart cars remaining in dense urban areas. The expansion comes as more carmakers push into car-sharing, potentially creating opportunities for mergers.

site_title: Spain threatens to take control of Catalonia's government
summary: Spain's central government has announced it will take control of Catalonia's government if the region's president, Carles Puigdemont, does not back away from a push for independence. After a deadline was imposed, Puigdemont refused to clarify Catalonia's intentions, instead threatening to declare independence if Madrid does not agree to talks. Spain's Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has vowed to begin the legal procedures to implement Article 155 of the 1978 Constitution, which would grant Madrid control over Catalonia's government and finances.

site_title: Sapphire gains on buy-in by HK-listed property group
summary: Sapphire Corp shares rose 1 cent to close at S$0.315 after two major shareholders sold a 27.96% stake to Hong Kong-listed HKICIM in a share swap. The deal values HKICIM's shares at 51 Singapore cents apiece. Sapphire is an investment management and holding company, while HKICIM focuses on property development and investment. The sale consideration amounts to S$17.62 million for Best Feast and S$17.62 million for Ou Rui. Following the acquisition, HKICIM will hold 28% of Sapphire's issued capital.

site_title: China's central bank chief warns of 'Minsky moment'
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan warned of a potential "Minsky moment" in the economy, citing risks of asset bubbles and debt pressures. Despite a slowdown in economic growth in the third quarter, China's economy is still on track to post its first full-year growth since 2010, driven by public spending and record bank lending. Analysts say the concerns echo past warnings from international economic bodies about high corporate and household debt levels, but China has so far proven doomsayers wrong.

site_title: Modi's economic reforms: a mixed picture
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's economic reforms have been met with mixed views. On macroeconomic reforms, Modi has been successful in keeping inflation under control and attracting record foreign direct investment, but the costs of his "demonetisation" and Goods and Services tax (GST) have outweighed the benefits. However, microeconomic reforms, including sectoral and governance reforms, have been slow, with the government lagging in privatising state-owned enterprises, providing basic services, and reforming the judicial system. This has led to concerns that the economic boom of the past two years may not be sustainable, and the country's ranking in the World Bank's Ease of Doing Business list remains low.

site_title: SAP shares drop in Frankfurt as cloud growth disappoints analysts
summary: SAP shares dropped 2.9% in Frankfurt trading after the company reported slightly missed revenue estimates for its third quarter. Revenue came in at 5.6 billion euros, below analyst expectations, mainly due to weaker-than-expected cloud business subscriptions. Despite this, SAP raised its 2017 sales forecast and reported strong new bookings for its S/4 Hana business software. The company also increased its full-year revenue target and slightly raised its operating profit outlook.

site_title: Planning for an energy future: Asia at a fork in the road
summary: Asia is at a crossroads in its energy transition, with the choice of its energy portfolio having significant implications for the region's future. The region accounts for 62% of global renewable energy employment and is embracing a sustainable energy future. Countries such as China, India, and Singapore are setting ambitious targets for renewable energy, with China aiming to scale up its renewables plans and India targeting 275 GW of renewable energy by 2027. The International Renewable Energy Agency (Irena) estimates that renewables can meet 90% of emissions reductions needed by 2050, and that a forward-looking strategic approach to energy will yield considerable benefits.

site_title: Conservatives campaign against Yellen's reappointment
summary: House conservatives are campaigning against Janet Yellen's reappointment as Federal Reserve chair, citing her ties to the "big banks" and a "failed, status quo monetary policy." Representative Warren Davidson has circulated a letter opposing her reappointment, and some conservatives are also expressing concerns about Jerome Powell, who is also on President Trump's shortlist for chairman. Trump is expected to make a decision soon, with a five-candidate shortlist including Yellen, Powell, Stanford economist John Taylor, and others.

site_title: In his second term, a politically stronger Xi Jinping will face challenges
summary: China's President Xi Jinping reaffirmed his vision of the "China Dream" in his opening address to the 19th National Congress of the Communist Party, emphasizing the country's goal of becoming "prosperous, strong and democratic" by 2050. However, he acknowledged the challenges ahead, particularly in managing the economy, where debt-fuelled growth has become a concern. China's GDP has expanded 50% in five years, but corporate debt stands at 170% of GDP, and the IMF has urged the country to address its debt problem. Xi will need to balance his efforts to consolidate power with the need to tackle economic challenges, which will be no easy task.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SATS Limited, a Singapore-based company, has entered into a six-month memorandum of agreement with Turkish Airlines to provide in-flight catering services at Istanbul New Airport. The agreement aims to expand SATS' international network, particularly in Asia, and diversify its business. SATS will invest in a Turkish catering company, which will operate one of the largest flight kitchens in the world. The completion of the transaction is subject to regulatory approvals and due diligence.

site_title: Beef it up with BT Weekend
summary: The article discusses various topics, including a feature on the latest beef trends, an interview with Michael Craig-Martin, and the state of animation studios in Singapore. It also covers the launch of the app Soho, the controversy surrounding Harvey Weinstein, and the success of the BNP Paribas WTA Finals Racquet Club programme. Additionally, it highlights luxury cars, such as the Rolls-Royce Phantom, and features on mod-Indian cuisine and financial literacy for women.

site_title: Rift within India's central bank panel widens as views differ
summary: India's monetary policymakers disagreed on whether the economy needs another stimulus, with five members voting to keep interest rates unchanged. Governor Urjit Patel, his deputy Viral Acharya, and Pami Dua expressed concerns over inflation, which unexpectedly steadied at 3.3% in September. The Reserve Bank of India lowered its growth forecast to 6.6% for the year, sparking speculation about potential rate cuts. The central bank must balance growth and inflation, with some members calling for rate hikes if inflation breaches 4%.

site_title: COEs end mixed in 2nd round for Oct
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices finished mixed in the second round of bidding for October, with the open category premium increasing by 6.1% to S$52,000. Commercial vehicle COE prices also rose, reaching a two-year high, due to anticipation of a smaller supply for the November-to-January quota. Motorcycle premiums decreased to a two-year low, while car prices for vehicles over 1,600cc or 130 bhp inched up slightly.

site_title: Growth-hungry SMG snaps up clinic for S$7.9m
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) has acquired Babies and Children Specialist Clinic at Mount Alvernia Hospital for S$7.9 million, its first hospital-based clinic in the paediatric space. The acquisition is expected to add breadth and depth to SMG's existing specialty offering, with plans to add a fourth specialist in the first quarter next year. The deal is seen as a step towards long-term earnings sustainability, with SMG issuing 6.3 million new shares to fund the acquisition.

site_title: ST Index rallies for fourth straight day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore rallied for a fourth consecutive day, driven by positive US earnings and China's Q3 growth of 6.8%, which exceeded the government's full-year target. The STI added 5.88 points to finish at 3,334.91, with banking and property counters leading the gains. Trading activity was high, with a total of 3.2 billion units valued at S$1.6 billion.

site_title: Late night at the museum
summary: The Red Dot Design Museum in Singapore has opened at its new location at 11 Marina Boulevard, with extended hours of 2am daily. The museum, which previously closed at 8pm, aims to attract more visitors, including tourists, with its central location. The museum showcases award-winning design works from the Red Dot Design Award, including products and conceptual designs. Visitors can enjoy a virtual tour, shop, and dine at the museum's café, which features Red Dot-winning products and materials. The museum's extended hours may lead to plans for 24-hour operation.

site_title: CSC Holdings being sued for S$7.7m
summary: CSC Holdings, a ground engineering specialist, is being sued by SEF Construction Pte Ltd for alleged backcharges and damages totaling S$7.7 million. The lawsuit claims that CSC's subsidiary, L&M Foundation Specialist Pte Ltd, incurred these costs during a foundation works contract with SEF. CSC maintains that there are no merits to the claims and is seeking legal advice. The company also intends to counterclaim for long outstanding debts owed by SEF.

site_title: China biotech's 'coming-out party' masks long road ahead as innovation still lacking
summary: China's biotech industry is experiencing a "coming-out party" as investors bet on its potential to feed the global pharmaceutical pipeline. Companies like Chi-Med, Beigene, and Zai Lab have seen their shares soar due to recent reforms and promising data on innovative drugs. However, China still lags behind the West in terms of R&D and innovation, contributing only 4% of global drug innovation. The country's traditional strengths lie in generic drugs, and a shift to original research is needed to bridge the gap.

site_title: Happy days are here again - or are they?
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank have projected optimism about the global economy, citing accelerating growth in major economies and buoyant financial conditions. However, a report by the IMF also warns of a potential debt crisis, citing too much money chasing too few yielding assets and increasing indebtedness among major economies. The global debt total has reached a record $217 trillion, equivalent to 325% of GDP. Despite these warnings, financial markets remain optimistic, with stock and bond valuations at historic highs.

site_title: Singapore firm eyes ICO to provide platform for cryptoeconomics
summary: Lattice80, a Singapore-based fintech hub, plans to conduct an initial coin offering (ICO) in 2018 to institutionalize cryptocurrency as a new asset class. The goal is to provide a platform for cryptoeconomics, connecting fintech startups, corporates, financial institutions, governments, and the public. Lattice80 will partner licensed platforms to offer services such as cryptocurrency exchanges, e-payments, and digital banking. The ICO will be conducted in regulated environments, including Singapore, Japan, and the US. The platform aims to provide a new alpha opportunity for institutional investors.

site_title: 2 fund management firms oppose CDL's takeover bid for M&C
summary: Two fund management firms, International Value Advisers and MSD Partners, have joined an investor revolt against City Developments Limited's (CDL) 1.8 billion pound takeover bid for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C). The firms, which own 7% and 1.9% of M&C respectively, have criticized the independent directors for supporting the deal, citing massive value destruction for shareholders. CDL aims to buy 34.8% of the hotelier for 624.3 million pounds, valuing the company at 1.8 billion pounds.

site_title: Boeing invests in autonomous flight tech provider Near Earth Autonomy
summary: Boeing invests in Near Earth Autonomy, a Pittsburgh-based firm developing autonomous flight technologies, including sensor suites and collision detection. This is Boeing's first investment in autonomous technologies through its venture capital arm, Boeing HorizonX. The investment will explore products and applications for emerging markets such as urban mobility. This move follows Boeing's recent acquisition of Aurora Flight Sciences Corp to advance autonomous, electric-powered aircraft development for commercial and military businesses.

site_title: Pressure grows on Noble Group: Vitol says oil deal 'complicated'
summary: Vitol's CEO Ian Taylor described negotiations to buy Noble Group's oil trading unit as "very complicated" and uncertain, potentially affecting the sale's outcome. The deal is crucial for Noble Group's survival, with the company seeking to pay back $1 billion of debt. Technicalities and overall terms and conditions are the main stumbling blocks, with Vitol expressing interest in acquiring certain assets but not others. The sale's complexity has added pressure on Noble Group, which has been under increasing financial stress since a surprise trading loss in May.

site_title: Japan September export growth slows slightly, but expansion trend intact
summary: Japan's export growth slowed in September for the first time in three months, with a 14.1% year-on-year increase, below the median estimate. This slowdown was due to weaker growth in shipments of cars, semiconductors, and electronic parts. Economists expect Japan's exports to resume growth as demand picks up heading into the year-end shopping season and a weak yen increases export competitiveness. Despite the slowdown, other Asian economies, such as South Korea and Taiwan, posted stronger-than-expected shipments.

site_title: A classic that needs some updating
summary: The Stuttgart Ballet performed its iconic Romeo and Juliet by John Cranko at the Esplanade in Singapore, marking the 15th year of the da:ns festival. The production featured lively choreography with modern, quirky moves, but dated set and staging, as well as unimaginative lighting. The dancers' athleticism and characterization were notable, but the ending felt anti-climactic. The performance showcased the company's signature piece, which has become a classic of modern ballet, but may benefit from a modern update for today's audience.

site_title: Sinochem taps banks for Hong Kong IPO of oil assets, say sources
summary: China's Sinochem Group has tapped Morgan Stanley, Citic Securities, and BOC International to work on a potential Hong Kong IPO of its key oil assets, likely to take place in the second half of 2023. The listing will include refining, fuel marketing, and trading assets, but not its struggling upstream business. Sinochem aims to raise capital and revive the company, which has been hit by low oil prices. The IPO plan is part of Beijing's efforts to revive state-owned enterprises and create stronger, more competitive firms.

site_title: The disruptor wins it all
summary: Disruptors like Tesla, Amazon, and Google are dominating industries with their innovative products and services. These companies have successfully disrupted traditional markets with simple, self-explanatory concepts that appeal to consumers. Key features of successful disruption include regularly adding new services, prioritizing user experience, and leveraging simplicity and pricing power. As consumer appetite for disruption grows, companies are adopting a daily routine of innovation, abandoning old versions, and localizing content to stay competitive. Successful disruptors will become the new normal, and disruption will become a core element of every company's strategy.

site_title: Airbus pledges to put sales focus on Bombardier's C Series
summary: Airbus has pledged to prioritize sales of Bombardier's C Series jet, specifically the CS300 variant, over its own single-aisle plane, the A319neo. The move follows a 50.01% stake acquisition in the Bombardier programme, which will utilize Airbus's global sales machine. The C Series has amassed 360 firm orders, with two-thirds for the CS300. Airbus plans to adapt the C Series' technology for future projects, including the cockpit, avionics, and composite materials.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

GuocoLand reported a higher first quarter net profit of S$165.55 million, with revenue increasing 79% to S$361.98 million. IPCO International is seeking legal advice after receiving a requisition notice from a shareholder to convene an extraordinary general meeting. CSC Holdings is being sued by a main contractor for alleged backcharges and damages. New Silkroutes Group announced the acquisition of a 66% stake in a European fund manager for US$2.6 million. Advance SCT posted a net profit of S$158,000 in its third quarter, with revenue increasing 48% quarter-on-quarter.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
There seems to be a mix of unrelated articles. However, I can provide a summary based on the provided articles. 

Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising concerns for policymakers. Companies like Grab and Citigroup have made significant announcements. OCBC's CEO, Helen Wong, is retiring, and Tan Teck Long will take over. Musk's Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event.

site_title: YTL Group founder dies at age 88
summary: YTL Group founder Yeoh Tiong Lay, a prominent businessman and Malaysian philanthropist, has died at the age of 88. He was the founder and executive chairman of the YTL Group, which expanded globally under his leadership. The company, which started as a construction company in 1955, grew into a multinational corporation with operations in various sectors. Yeoh was known for his work ethic, humility, and philanthropy, particularly in education. He received several honors, including the Order of the Rising Sun from Japan and a Doctor of Engineering degree from Heriot-Watt University.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat in early trade
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs early Thursday, falling 0.4% amid a deluge of earnings reports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 shed 0.4% and 0.9%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.9%. The sell-off was attributed to concerns over the European Union and Chinese debt levels, with some analysts describing it as a "mechanical act of overdue selling". Despite this, US stocks have been on a record-breaking rally in recent weeks due to expectations of strong corporate earnings and tax cuts under President Donald Trump.

site_title: Huge Q1 profit jump for GuocoLand
summary: GuocoLand reported a 540% increase in Q1 net profit to S$165.55 million, driven by 79% revenue growth to S$361.98 million. The company attributed the surge to strengthening commercial and residential property markets in Singapore, with private residential property prices rising 0.5% and Grade A office rents potentially picking up. GuocoLand plans to develop a new iconic city-centre project at a secured Beach Road site.

site_title: Credit Suisse appoints Americas industrials co-heads
summary: Credit Suisse has appointed David Hammond and Spyros Svoronos as co-heads of its Americas industrials investment banking and capital markets group. Hammond, who joined in 2012, will continue as global head of metals and mining, while Svoronos, who joined in 2000, will remain global head of chemicals. The appointments were confirmed by a Credit Suisse spokeswoman and will see Hammond and Svoronos report to Orlando Knauss, co-head of Credit Suisse's global industrials group.

site_title: Attention-grabbing Australian food
summary: Australian chef Clayton Wells' Blackwattle restaurant in Singapore's Telok Ayer neighbourhood offers a promising dining experience despite playing it safe. The restaurant's menu features a mix of Australian flavors with Asian influences, including dishes like stormshell clam and octopus with XO red wine vinaigrette. While some dishes, such as the grilled duck hearts and cape gooseberries, are standout successes, others, like the steamed green bone and wagyu tri-tip, fall short. Blackwattle's chef Wells is on the right track, but the restaurant still needs to find its balance between innovation and local palates. Rating: 7.

images.alt_text: Octopus with XO red wine vinaigrette - chunks of octopus swathed in a thick, unctuous sauce, an unexpected liaison of squid ink, XO sauce and red vinegar.

King crab and braised pumpkin seeds in pepper broth (S$32) - a delicate yet full-bodied shellfish broth that you scoop up with strands of crabmeat and softened pumpkin seeds before attacking the chunk of crab leg on top.
Chefs Joeri Timmermans (left) and Clayton Wells.

site_title: Dragon Group acquires Coeur Gold Armenia in RTO
summary: Dragon Group International has acquired Coeur Gold Armenia in a reverse takeover (RTO) for S$500 million in shares and cash. The acquisition aims to diversify Dragon Group's revenue and business, with Coeur Gold Armenia holding exploration rights to mine gold, silver, antimony, and copper in the Azatek and Sofi Bina Mineral Deposits. The deal is contingent on Coeur Gold Armenia's assets being valued at not less than S$500 million. Dragon Group executive chairman and CEO Michael Loh Soon Gnee sees this acquisition as a rare opportunity to enter a market with favorable circumstances in the medium term.

site_title: Alcoa sees China curbs balancing aluminium market
summary: Alcoa Corp forecasts a relatively balanced global aluminium market due to China's efforts to curb production and meet pollution-control targets. China's primary aluminium output shrank to 2.61 million tonnes in September, and the company projects a 300,000-tonne deficit to a 100,000-tonne surplus this year. This improvement is attributed to planned and actual curtailments in Chinese smelting capacity, as well as increased Chinese demand. Alcoa's shares have surged 70% this year, and the company raised its forecast for 2017 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation.

images.alt_text: An aluminium plant in Shandong province. The metal is on pace for its best year since 2009 and leading all but copper among commodities tracked by the Bloomberg Commodity Index.

site_title: Foreign firms wary of growing role of party in their operations
summary: Foreign companies in China have mixed reactions to the ruling Communist Party setting up cells in their firms, despite the law requiring companies to establish a party organisation. While some executives welcome the move, others express concern about the party's growing role in their operations. This development comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: SRX operator sues major consultancies over its valuation service
summary: StreetSine Singapore, a subsidiary of Singapore Press Holdings, has filed a lawsuit against the Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) and 27 other defendants, alleging conspiracy and malicious falsehood. The lawsuit centers around StreetSine's valuation service, which was developed with a grant from the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore. StreetSine claims that SISV and its affiliates pressured them to ban the use of StreetSine's valuation engine, leading to a loss of revenue and market access. StreetSine also alleges that SISV and its affiliates misrepresented StreetSine's valuation service as not meeting SISV standards.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close down on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed down 5 points on Monday, at 1,743.99, due to a lower volume of 3.16 billion shares worth RM2.51 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 544 to 365.

site_title: Britain's new concessions are not enough, EU leaders tell May
summary: EU leaders welcomed a proposal by British Prime Minister Theresa May to unblock Brexit talks, but said concessions to ease fears of EU citizens in Britain were insufficient. May sought to shift focus to trade talks, but EU leaders said more work needed to be done, particularly on citizens' rights and the UK's exit bill. German Chancellor Angela Merkel described some "encouraging" signs, but EU leaders agreed that sufficient progress had not yet been made, with talks set to continue in December.

site_title: Film festival kicks off with thought-provoking flick
summary: The 28th Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) kicked off on November 23 with the highly-acclaimed Mainland Chinese thriller "Angels Wear White," directed by Vivian Qu. The film, which explores the problem of female objectification and corruption in modern-day China, is in competition for three awards at the 54th Golden Horse Awards. SGIFF's executive director, Yuni Hadi, praised Qu's film for bringing a rare female perspective to the state of oppression, reaffirming the festival's commitment to championing Asian cinema.

site_title: Keppel breaks two-and-half year spell with 30% Q3 profit jump
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a 30% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$291.83 million, driven by a multi-business approach that offset the downturn in its offshore and marine division. Revenue rose 10.8% to S$1.62 billion, and operating profit jumped 74.6% to S$324 million. The group has also established a new business unit, Keppel Urban Solutions, to focus on creating smart precincts and cities. Keppel's O&M division has secured new contracts, including a converted floating LNG plant, and has reached agreements to defer deliveries. The company's shares closed at S$7.02, 1.1 cents down.

site_title: Sinochem taps banks for HK IPO of oil assets - sources
summary: China's Sinochem Group has tapped Morgan Stanley, Citic Securities, and BOC International to work on a potential Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) of its key oil assets, aiming to raise capital and revive the company. The planned IPO is expected to take place in the second half of next year, with preparations still in the early stages and the company yet to decide on the public offering size.

site_title: Nissan shuts Japan production as Saikawa's crisis worsens
summary: Nissan temporarily shuts Japan production for two weeks due to a quality inspection crisis under new CEO Hiroto Saikawa. The halt affects local production of 1,000 vehicles a day, but export models remain unaffected. Shares of Nissan and Renault traded lower as the scandal worsens. This comes amidst another industrial scandal in Japan, with Kobe Steel falsifying product data, further damaging the country's reputation for quality.

site_title: Air Berlin and EasyJet said to announce deal on Friday
summary: Air Berlin and EasyJet are set to announce a deal on Friday for the purchase of up to 25 A320 aircraft, following a bid by EasyJet in September for parts of Air Berlin's short haul business. The German insolvent carrier and British budget airline declined to comment on the expected announcement.

site_title: STI adds nearly 6 points to extend rally
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) added 5.88 points to finish at 3,334.91, extending its rally for the fourth straight day. The gains were driven by upbeat growth data from China and positive US earnings. Banking and property stocks were among the key contributors. The rally came despite US Dow futures being down by 100 points.

site_title: SGX queries UMS Holdings over stock price surge
summary: Shares of UMS Holdings Limited surged nearly 9% to S$1.105 per share on October 19, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for "unusual price movements". The stock's volatility increased after an announcement of a proposed bonus issue, which could reduce the per-share price. UMS stated it's unaware of any new information explaining the surge, and a bonus share issue could be a possible explanation. The company is also set to pay a second interim dividend on October 27.

site_title: TSMC foresees double-digit sales growth as iPhone X hits shelves
summary: TSMC forecasts 11-12% revenue growth in the holiday quarter due to the launch of Apple's iPhone X, leveraging its technological edge and role as Apple's main chip supplier. This growth is expected to help the company weather poor smartphone demand globally.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as new batch of Q3 earnings unveils disappointments
summary: European shares declined across most bourses on Thursday, with the STOXX 600 index down 0.2% and major indices in London, Paris, and Frankfurt also falling. Disappointing third-quarter earnings from Publicis, Unilever, and Kion contributed to the decline. Madrid's IBEX remained flat amid tensions over Catalonia's independence, with Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy poised to impose direct rule unless Carles Puigdemont retracts his declaration.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: HDB introduces an online resale portal to reduce meet-ups with officers and halve transaction time from 16 weeks to 8 weeks. COE prices finished mixed in the second round of bidding. Electronics firm Dragon Group acquires Coeur Gold Armenia for S$500m. The Straits Times Index (STI) added 5.88 points, supported by banking and property stocks. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: The introduction of a new online resale portal by the Housing and Development Board (HDB) will cut down the number of appointments required with HDB officers from two to one, and possibly halve transaction time from 16 weeks to eight.

site_title: Thai banking duo's profit lifted by fee and interest income
summary: Thai banking duo Bank of Ayudhya and another lender reported higher third-quarter profits driven by a jump in net interest income. The outlook for Thailand's banking sector has improved due to rising exports and consumption. The central bank noted high capital adequacy ratios and a slowdown in bad loans. Bank of Ayudhya's CEO predicted continued economic momentum and a seasonal rise in lending business, citing a favorable economic environment. The sector's growth is expected to build momentum.

site_title: GL says Q1 net profit up 58% on higher hotel revenue
summary: GL reported a 58% increase in Q1 net profit to US$17.4 million, driven by higher hotel revenue offset by lower earnings from gaming and oil and gas units. Hotel revenue rose despite fewer rooms available due to the refurbishment of the Cumberland Hotel. The company attributed the increase to higher F&B, meetings, and events revenue, as well as improved room revenue from other hotels.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink after five-day rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted almost 2% on Thursday, wiping out their recent gains, as investors focused on data showing a slight dip in Chinese economic growth. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.92% to 28,159.09, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. This comes after five days of gains in the Hong Kong market.

site_title: Greece plans billion euro handout for poor
summary: Greece plans to distribute 1 billion euros in handouts to poor Greeks who have suffered during the seven-year debt crisis. The government exceeded its budget targets this year and expects to return to nearly 2% growth. The "social dividend" will be distributed to social groups that have suffered the biggest pressure during the financial crisis, with hundreds of thousands of Greeks losing their jobs during the six-year recession. The government will make final decisions in late November, once it receives full-year budget data.

site_title: A sharp handling of complicated family matters
summary: Adam Sandler's Netflix film "The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected)" showcases his range as a comedic actor, with a sharp handling of complicated family matters. Written and directed by Noah Baumbach, the black dramedy follows Danny, a struggling son of sculptor Harold Meyerowitz (Dustin Hoffman), as he reunites with his family to discuss his father's legacy after his illness. The film features standout performances from Sandler and Hoffman, with Baumbach's sharp observation of family dynamics making it feel original. The film premiered at Cannes and has received a B+ rating.

images.alt_text: Ben Stiller (left) and Adam Sandler play stepbrothers in this film written and directed by Noah Baumbach.
Above: Dustin Hoffman and Emma Thompson, as husband and wife, round up the ensemble cast.

site_title: COEs finish mixed in the second round of bidding
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for the second round of bidding in October finished mixed, with Category A car premiums decreasing slightly to $41,617, while Category B premiums rose to $49,996. Motorcycle premiums decreased to $4,903, but goods vehicle and bus premiums increased to $51,890. Category E, the open category, saw COE prices rise to $52,000.

site_title: Advance SCT swings to the black in Q3
summary: Advance SCT Limited has reported a net profit of S$158,000 in Q3, reversing a net loss of S$340,000 in the same period last year. Revenue increased 48% quarter-on-quarter to S$24.6 million. The company has been profitable since its current operations and expects to remain so for the next quarter and full financial year. Advance SCT is also seeking to have its shares lifted from the Singapore Exchange's watch-list and extend its exit deadline to March 3, 2018.

site_title: Bank Indonesia keeps key rate unchanged after two surprise cuts
summary: Bank Indonesia kept its benchmark interest rate at 4.25% as expected, pausing after two surprise cuts. The move comes amid concerns over a weaker rupiah, which has dropped 1.2% against the dollar since the August rate cut. Despite subdued inflation, the central bank is cautious about the impact of US interest rate hikes and a shrinking economy. Indonesia's economy has been growing at about 5%, below the 7% target set by President Joko Widodo.

site_title: Airbus A330neo takes off successfully on maiden flight
summary: Airbus successfully completed the maiden flight of its A330neo jetliner, an upgraded version of its A330 family, on October 19, 2017. The wide-bodied plane took off under overcast skies, watched by top executives from Airbus and Rolls Royce, which supplies the engines. The A330neo aims to sharpen competition with the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, offering improved fuel efficiency and reduced emissions. This marks a significant milestone for Airbus, as the A330neo is designed to increase the company's market share in the long-distance jet market.

site_title: Keppel's Q3 profit rises 30%
summary: Keppel Corp reported a 30% rise in Q3 profit to S$291 million, driven by a 30.5% increase in CEO Kerry Mok's pay. Earnings per share rose to 16 Singapore cents from 12.4 Singapore cents. Revenue increased 11% to S$158 million, with all divisions except O&M seeing higher revenues. The company's Q3 performance is a positive note for investors, but the overall market is overshadowed by other news, such as China's slowing GDP growth and the global economic outlook.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks posts longest string of gains in 30 years
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.40% to 21,448.52, its 13th consecutive gain and the longest positive streak in nearly 30 years. The broader Topix index also gained 0.31% to 1,730.04. This follows a strong corporate earnings season and ahead of Japan's weekend elections.

site_title: IPCO seeking legal advice on requisition notice
summary: IPCO International received a requisition notice from James Blythman, a shareholder holding over 10% of the company's shares, requesting an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to consider ordinary resolutions. IPCO is seeking legal advice on the notice, which claims to be a member of IPCO holding in excess of 10% of the issued and paid-up share capital. The notice aims to convene an EGM to consider specific resolutions, but the company's response to the notice is unclear at this time.

site_title: Fintech hub Lattice80 to conduct initial coin offering next year
summary: Lattice80, the world's largest fintech hub, plans to conduct an initial coin offering (ICO) next year, aiming to raise funds for new cryptocurrency ventures. The hub, owned by Marvelstone Group, will partner licensed platforms to offer services such as cryptocurrency exchanges and e-payments. The ICO will be conducted in Singapore, along with other locations, and will aim to institutionalize the emerging asset class, offering a new alpha opportunity for institutional investors.

site_title: Australia shares post 7th day of gains; NZ also up
summary: Australian shares rose for a seventh consecutive day, ending 0.1% higher, despite data showing China's economic growth eased to 6.8% in the third quarter. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,896.1 points. New Zealand's benchmark index also gained 0.1%. Investors are focused on the US tax code overhaul and its potential impact on global markets.

site_title: US wants stronger India economic, defense ties given China's rise -Tillerson
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson stated that the Trump administration aims to "dramatically deepen" cooperation with India, citing its importance as a counterbalance to China's influence in Asia. The US has begun discussing alternatives to Chinese infrastructure financing in Asia and may invite other countries, including Australia, to join US-India-Japan security cooperation, a move Beijing has opposed. This move is seen as a strategic response to China's growing economic and military presence in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher, eyes on China data
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.25% on Thursday, driven by a five-day rally and Wall Street records. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,783.85, while Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices slipped 0.21% and 0.09% respectively. Traders are watching Chinese economic growth data, set to be released later in the morning.

site_title: Saudi needs Aramco billions as recession slows austerity drive
summary: Saudi Arabia is reconsidering its austerity measures amid a recession, which has pushed the economy into a second consecutive quarter of decline. The government's plan to close a budget deficit by 2020 is now seen as overly optimistic, with economists predicting a deficit of US$53 billion this year. To address this, the government may focus on selling state assets, particularly Saudi Aramco, with a potential sale of a 5% stake expected to bring in billions of dollars. This could provide a much-needed injection of funds to boost economic growth and help the government meet its deficit target.

site_title: Android Pay, Apple Pay now available for SIA's mobile app
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has added Android Pay and Apple Pay as payment options to its mobile app, allowing customers to pay for air tickets, booking fees, and other purchases without having to enter payment information. This move provides added convenience and aligns with the growing trend of cashless payments worldwide. SIA's senior vice-president, Campbell Wilson, stated that this feature enables customers to have a seamless and efficient payment experience whenever they make a purchase on the mobile app.

site_title: Prudential to host its first global fintech partnership programme in Singapore
summary: Prudential Singapore has launched its first global fintech partnership programme in Singapore, called PRU Fintegrate Partnership. The programme aims to collaborate with global fintech startups to co-develop digital solutions for customers, addressing 19 insurance-related problem statements. Unlike traditional incubators, PRU Fintegrate offers startups the opportunity to build and validate prototypes at scale. The programme is open to fintech startups worldwide and is part of the Singapore Fintech Festival, set to take place in November.

site_title: China central bank governor Zhou says likely to retire soon
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan is likely to retire soon, according to a statement. Zhou confirmed the retirement in a news conference, with sources suggesting it will happen around March next year. Zhou's successor could be Guo Shuqing or Jiang Chaoliang, both veteran bankers.

site_title: Soilbuild Business Space Reit gets S$200m credit facility, to refinance debts
summary: Soilbuild Business Space REIT has secured a S$200 million secured facility agreement with OCBC Bank and RHB to refinance debts. The facility will partially replace an existing S$185 million loan, leaving a S$15 million balance available for one year. The refinancing will increase the weighted average debt maturity from 2.1 years to 2.9 years.

site_title: Electronics engineering firm Dragon Group buys miner Coeur Gold Armenia for S$500m
summary: Dragon Group International has agreed to acquire Coeur Gold Armenia for approximately S$500 million. The deal includes a cash deposit and shares, with Dragon Group's counter trading 31.7% higher at 5.4 Singapore cents. The acquisition aims to diversify Dragon Group's business, as gold demand is expected to increase and global gold production may peak in the future. The deal was welcomed by Coeur Gold Armenia's CEO, who described it as an "attractive offer".

site_title: Toshiba investigated by Japan's securities watchdog: source
summary: Japan's Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission is investigating Toshiba Corp's accounting practices for the 2016/17 business year, specifically regarding the handling of losses incurred by its US nuclear unit Westinghouse. The investigation is examining the process involved in creating the financial report. A Toshiba spokesman declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won slip despite bullish central bank outlook
summary: South Korean shares ended at a one-week low on Thursday, despite the Bank of Korea's bullish economic outlook, as investors sold heavyweight tech firms like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The central bank upgraded its growth outlook to 3% and kept the policy rate unchanged, boosting chances of a rate hike. The KOSPI index closed down 0.4% at 2,473.06 points, while the won edged down 0.2% against the US dollar.

site_title: China growth eases in third quarter
summary: China's economic growth eased to 6.8% in the third quarter, exceeding the government's target of 6.5% for 2017. The growth was fueled by brisk consumer spending and strong factory output, with retail sales rising 10.3% in September. This steady growth is a boon to President Xi Jinping amid a major Communist Party congress. The economy is transitioning from investment-heavy growth to a stage of high-quality development, according to Xi.

images.alt_text: China's growth eased to 6.8 per cent in the third quarter but remained higher than the government's full-year target, providing a boon to President Xi Jinping amid a major Communist Party congress.

site_title: Too early to discuss consolidation involving Kobe Steel: ex-Nippon Steel chief
summary: A former top executive at Nippon Steel Corp, Akio Mimura, expressed caution on discussing industry consolidation involving Kobe Steel Ltd, citing the unknown impact of its data fabrication scandal. Mimura, a senior adviser and former CEO, stated it's too early to discuss realignment in the industry, emphasizing the need for Kobe Steel to address its practices before offering opinions. He described Kobe Steel's actions as "crossing a line" and expressed disappointment in the company's behavior, highlighting the need for transparency and accountability.

site_title: Old-school metal acts bring the noise
summary: Sebastian Bach, former lead singer of Skid Row, brought his iconic voice and swagger to a sold-out show at Kallang Theatre in Singapore. The 49-year-old frontman performed a 14-song set, including Skid Row classics and covers of AC/DC's "TNT" and Painmuseum's "American Metalhead". Despite middle-age spread, Bach's confidence and stage presence remained intact, with fans singing along to hits like "I Remember You" and "18 and Life". The show was a nostalgic trip for both Bach and the audience, who turned out for a night of old-school heavy metal.

site_title: China sees 'harsh' winter without more gas supply
summary: China's National Development & Reform Commission warned of a "harsh" winter supply situation if natural gas demand exceeds available supplies. The nation's top regulator urged state-owned oil and gas companies to increase production and output from unconventional sources to meet increased demand. This comes as the country's booming gas usage, driven by President Xi Jinping's pro-gas policies, has outpaced infrastructure capacity. China's regulator called on producers to ensure sufficient supply to avoid a severe shortage as weather turns colder.

site_title: China property slowing under pressure from cooling measures
summary: China's property market slowed in September, with sales by floor area falling 1.5% from the previous year, marking the first decline in over two-and-a-half years. Housing starts also slowed sharply, reinforcing expectations of cooling growth in the world's second-largest economy. The decline in property sales comes as Beijing aims to curb soaring home prices without triggering a crash or sharp drop in construction activity.

site_title: Lawrence Wong to attend Apec finance ministers' meeting in Vietnam
summary: Minister for National Development and Second Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong will attend the Apec Finance Ministers' Meeting in Vietnam from Oct 20 to 21. The meeting will focus on key Apec priorities, including infrastructure investment, international taxation, disaster risk financing, and insurance and financial inclusion. Wong will be accompanied by Ministry of Finance officials, marking Singapore's participation in the discussion.

site_title: Huge cave found on moon, could house astronauts: Japan scientists
summary: Scientists at Japan's space agency have discovered a 50 km long and 100m wide cave on the moon, believed to be a lava tube created by volcanic activity 3.5 billion years ago. The cave, located under the Marius Hills, could provide a sheltered base for astronauts, protecting them from radiation and extreme temperature swings. This finding supports Japan's plans to send an astronaut to the moon by 2030, as part of a larger effort to establish a presence on the lunar surface. The discovery was made using data from Japan's SELENE lunar orbiter.

site_title: Asia: Most stocks rally after fresh Wall St records
summary: Asia's stocks rallied after Wall Street hit fresh records, with Tokyo reaching a 21-year high and Shanghai slipping due to data showing China's economic growth moderating to 6.8% in July-September. The US stock market's optimism was fueled by hopes for tax cuts and a potential clear win for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in Japan's election. The weaker yen and rising oil prices also boosted Asian markets, with Sydney, Singapore, and Seoul gaining ground.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks head for longest string of gains in 30 years
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for the 13th consecutive day, nearing a 30-year record, driven by upbeat polls on Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's election victory and a stronger yen.
