summary: Scientists in France have discovered a potential cause of dyslexia, a reading disability, in the arrangement of light-receptor cells in the human eye. The cells, which are responsible for capturing image signals, are arranged in matching patterns in both eyes of individuals with dyslexia, leading to "mirror" images that confuse the brain. A study found that using an LED lamp can "erase" these mirror images, offering a simple method of diagnosis and potentially treating dyslexia. The research, published in the Proceedings of the Royal Society B, could help explain why 700 million people worldwide suffer from the condition.

site_title: European shares slip from highs as results, commodities weigh
summary: European shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday, weighed down by a decline in basic resources and energy stocks, despite gains from results from companies like Danone and Pearson. Credit Suisse rose 1.2% after reports of an activist investor campaign to break up the bank. Individual stocks moved sharply, with Danone hitting a record high and Pearson soaring 7.3% on full-year profit forecasts. However, Merlin Entertainments slumped 16% and Sartorius fell 7.6% due to disappointing results.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hold soft tone on foreign selling, won up
summary: South Korean shares edged lower, down 0.1% at 2,480.71 points, as foreign investors took profit on market heavyweight stocks, particularly SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics. Chipmaker SK Hynix fell 4% and Samsung Electronics lost 1%. Despite this, web portal Naver jumped 5.5%. The South Korean won rose 0.2% to 1,130.3 against the US dollar, driven by the Chinese yuan's strength in global currency markets. Foreign investors offloaded 32.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares, with the investment sentiment described as "not that good" by a stock analyst.

site_title: Trump said to plan Fed Chair pick before Nov 3 Asia trip
summary: President Donald Trump plans to announce his nominee for Federal Reserve Chair before his November 3 Asia trip. Trump is considering five names, including Jerome Powell, John Taylor, Kevin Warsh, Gary Cohn, and Janet Yellen. Taylor has made a favorable impression on the president after an hour-long interview, while Yellen's current term is set to end in February. The nomination is subject to Senate confirmation, a process that can take months to complete. Trump has a history of hiring people with whom he has a strong personal rapport, and Taylor's monetary policy expertise has sparked speculation about his chances.

site_title: HSR land acquisition process has started: Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced the start of the land acquisition process for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR), a bilateral project expected to be completed by 2026. A three-month public consultation will begin on November 1, allowing Malaysians to provide feedback on the project's alignment. The consultation will be held in conjunction with the unveiling of station designs inspired by local elements, including Islamic architecture and traditional Johor customs.

site_title: 'Love for country' behind move to Ryanair, says Malaysia Airlines' CEO
summary: Malaysia Airlines' outgoing CEO Peter Bellew is leaving the airline for Ryanair, citing a sense of responsibility to his native Ireland. Bellew, an Irish national, will join Ryanair as chief operating officer in December to address a pilot-staffing issue. His departure comes after just over a year in charge, following two tragedies in 2014. Bellew denied reports of political interference in his departure, stating that Khazanah Nasional Bhd, the state investment fund, was supportive and there was no interference. The move means Malaysia Airlines must appoint a third CEO in three years.

site_title: Emerging market bonds a rising star for risk-takers
summary: US investors seeking higher returns are turning to emerging market bonds, which have delivered high yields and total returns despite rising interest rates in the US. Funds like the iShares JP Morgan USD Emerging Markets Bond ETF and Pimco Emerging Local Bond fund have paid yields of 4.5% and 5.2% respectively, outperforming comparable US bonds. Despite valuations being stretched, many fund managers believe emerging markets will continue to shine as long as the global economic outlook remains positive, offering higher yields than US bonds.

site_title: Nafta talks prolonged into 2018 amid sharp disagreements
summary: US, Canada, and Mexico extended NAFTA talks into 2018 amid significant disagreements, with the US threatening to scrap the landmark trade pact. Key issues include rules of origin and unfair trade advantages, with the US accusing Canada and Mexico of resisting changes. Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland and Mexican Finance Minister Ildefonso Guajardo Villarreal expressed concerns about the US proposals, while US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer accused their partners of being unwilling to make concessions. The negotiations will continue in 2018, with the next round set to be held in Mexico.

site_title: No such thing as a free meal? It's back - on some airlines
summary: Airlines are reintroducing complimentary meals on domestic flights in the US, reversing a trend that began over a decade ago. Delta Air Lines, American Airlines, and others are offering free breakfast, lunch, or dinner on select flights, including cross-country routes. The move aims to increase customer satisfaction and competitiveness in the market, particularly among business flyers. Airlines are also revamping their snack options, including healthy and gluten-free choices, and incorporating local and seasonal food.

site_title: France arrests 10 over suspected plot targeting politicians
summary: French anti-terror agents arrested 10 people, aged 17-25, over a suspected plot to target mosques and politicians, including government spokesman Christophe Castaner and radical left leader Jean-Luc Melenchon. The suspects, linked to former far-right activist Logan Alexandre Nisin, were arrested in the Paris region and south-east France, with Nisin's mother among those taken into custody. Police found "intentions to commit violent action" involving a place of worship, a politician, and migrants, but the details remained unclear. The plot was deemed in its early stages.

site_title: Dubai Holding sidelines US$20b Jumeirah Central project
summary: Dubai Holding has put on hold plans for the US$20 billion Jumeirah Central project in Dubai, citing a focus on projects that will be ready for Expo 2020 Dubai and attract tourists. The company is instead prioritizing Marsa Al Arab.

site_title: Qatar Emir 'an old friend' of Singapore: President Halimah
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob said the country's growth and development show that size does not determine success, citing the strong relationship between Singapore and Qatar as an example. The two countries have maintained a high-level bilateral mechanism since 2006, with 28 agreements across various fields. They share people-to-people ties and have been active members of the international community. Halimah hosted Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim Bin Hamad al-Thani on a state visit, highlighting the potential for further strengthening their partnership.

site_title: Don't let your cloud rain on your performance
summary: Hackers are increasingly targeting cloud systems, as they are mission-critical for many organizations. The Cisco 2017 Midyear Cybersecurity Report reveals that hackers can infiltrate connected systems faster by breaching cloud systems. A recent incident in Singapore saw hackers attempting to steal government data by breaching university defenses. To mitigate risks, organizations must ensure adequate protection on the cloud and take steps to prevent cloud-based attacks.

site_title: Researchers uncover flaw that makes Wi-Fi vulnerable to hacks
summary: Researchers have discovered a flaw in the widely used WPA2 Wi-Fi protocol that allows hackers to read encrypted information or infect websites with malware. The US Department of Homeland Security has issued an alert, recommending that users install vendor updates on affected products. This vulnerability could be exploited within range of Wi-Fi, posing a significant risk to private communications. Experts are urging users to take immediate action to secure their networks and protect sensitive information.

site_title: US dollar rises on talk of potential Fed chief nominee
summary: The US dollar rose to a one-week high against a basket of currencies on Tuesday, driven by speculation that President Donald Trump was leaning towards nominating a more hawkish Federal Reserve head, such as Stanford economist John Taylor. The dollar index reached 93.729, and interest rates futures implied a 93% chance of a rate hike in December. The euro and sterling also fell, with the euro slipping to a one-week low and sterling dropping below $1.32 for the first time since Thursday.

site_title: Gold falls on hawkish views about possible next Fed chair
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to a one-week low of $1,286.74 per ounce amid speculation of a hawkish US Federal Reserve chair favoring higher interest rates. The possible successor to Janet Yellen, John Taylor, is seen as more likely to raise rates, boosting the US dollar and denting gold. The Fed is expected to raise rates in December and potentially three or four times next year, increasing the likelihood of monetary policy tightening.

site_title: Grim store sales cast shadow ahead of India's festival of lights
summary: India's retail sales have plummeted ahead of the Diwali festival, with many blaming the economic reforms implemented after demonetization. Despite a significant increase in tariffs, consumers are opting to save instead of spending, resulting in a 20-30% decline in sales. The economic reforms, which were intended to boost economic growth, have instead led to a decline in consumer spending, affecting the country's retail sector.

site_title: JLW suggests housing body like Singapore's HDB for Malaysia
summary: Malaysia needs a single authority similar to Singapore's HDB to oversee affordable housing policies and manage demand and supply, according to a property consultancy. JLW suggests creating a centralized index defining affordable homes and their prices, and implementing targeted policies with the private sector. The main challenge lies in reducing the "affordability gap," with half of loan applicants rejected due to significant indebtedness. A central agency could streamline processes, monitor property prices, and prevent speculation, ultimately improving the delivery of affordable homes.

site_title: Jokowi sees low inflation paving way for interest rate reductions
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo stated that the country's success in controlling inflation, which is expected to average less than 4% this year, could pave the way for lower interest rates. However, he emphasized that the decision to cut interest rates lies with the central bank. Widodo made the comments during an interview at Lake Toba, where he had visited a newly upgraded airport.

images.alt_text: "As a former businessman, I will be happy if lending rates fall," says Mr Joko, a former furniture exporter. "All businessmen are happy if lending rates fall, fall and fall. Because costs will be lower, and their products will compete better with products of other countries."

site_title: China's shoppers turn Jack Ma's Ant Financial into a debt giant
summary: China's tech giants, led by Alibaba Group's finance affiliate Ant Financial, are packaging consumer loans into complex financial products and selling them to investors, raising concerns about transparency and risk management. The companies, including JD.com and Baidu, have issued billions of yuan in asset-backed securities (ABS) this year, which bundle small loans into a single investment. Analysts warn that the lack of information disclosure about the underlying assets and risks could lead to systemic problems, and regulators are urged to strengthen disclosure requirements.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines chief returning to Ryanair to help fix pilot problems
summary: Malaysia Airlines' CEO Peter Bellew is leaving to return to Ryanair as chief operations officer, citing the need to address pilot shortages that have resulted in over 20,000 cancelled flights. This marks the third CEO change for Malaysia Airlines in three years, following the disappearance of MH370 and the downing of MH17 in 2014. Bellew will help Ryanair tackle its own pilot shortages, which have also led to significant flight cancellations.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OKH Global failed to complete a S$49 million warehouse sale after buyers cited inability to proceed. OKH is entitled to claim S$1.32 million from PALH and S$297,000 from Bischoff Christian Paul. GLP issued S$205 million of panda bonds with a 4.99% annual coupon. ST Electronics signed a MoU with Saab to establish a Centre of Excellence in Singapore for airport digital towers.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us 'mulling over IPO for US$2 billion Asia unit'
summary: TOYS "R" Us Inc is exploring a potential initial public offering (IPO) for its US$2 billion Asian unit, according to people with knowledge of the matter. The company, which filed for bankruptcy in North America, has been speaking to investment banks to study the feasibility of listing the Asian business on the Hong Kong bourse. However, its ongoing US bankruptcy could make this listing more complicated and harder to market to investors.

site_title: Keppel T&T Q3 net profit down 82% at S$12.8m
summary: Keppel T&T reported a 82% decline in Q3 net profit to S$12.8m due to the absence of divestment gains and contributions from subsidiaries disposed. The company cited a one-off gain of S$55.8m recognized in Q3 2016 from the disposal of a subsidiary, which was partly offset by an impairment loss. The result marks a significant decline from the S$70.3m net profit in Q3 2016.

site_title: As China's leaders gather, market reform hopes fade
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is expected to consolidate his power during the Communist Party Congress, with market reforms taking a backseat to state-centered economic policy and stability. Investors and business leaders are unlikely to see significant market liberalization, with a senior China-based executive stating that "market opening is not coming, it's all about discipline and control." Xi's focus on discipline and control may lead to slower GDP growth, which could put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: US: Dow pierces 23,000 but finishes below milestone
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average briefly surpassed 23,000 points on Tuesday but finished below the milestone due to concerns about sustaining a move above the level. Strong earnings from UnitedHealth and Johnson & Johnson drove the gain, but some analysts, such as Robert Pavlik, believe it may pull back before staying above 23,000. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the S&P healthcare sector gaining 1.3% on news of a bipartisan deal in the US Senate to stabilize Obamacare.

site_title: Guanxi disrupted in O&M debt revamps
summary: Asian companies, such as Ezion Holdings and Nam Cheong, are undergoing debt revamps that involve converting unsecured debt into shares, a process known as guanxi. The conversion ratios proposed by the companies have been met with resistance from note holders, who argue that they would have to carry existing equity holders even after granting the companies extra runway for principal redemption. The companies' reliance on Asian families and their chief executives' personal relationships is being tested, and the outcome of the debt restructuring exercises will strain the goodwill of these families in the investor community.

site_title: Risk premium for oil returns as US-Iran tensions rise
summary: US-Iran tensions and escalating fighting in Iraq have led to a surge in oil prices, with a risk premium returning to the market. Supply cuts by OPEC and rising US output previously capped markets, but rising demand, especially in China, has driven prices up significantly. Global price benchmarks have moved up, and the market is on edge due to the ongoing tensions between the US and Iran, which could impact oil supplies.

site_title: Changi Garden sold to Chip Eng Seng for S$249m
summary: Chip Eng Seng acquired Changi Garden in a collective sale for S$248.8 million, setting a new benchmark for properties in the vicinity with a price of S$888 per sq ft per plot ratio (psf ppr). The sale is expected to yield about 320 residential units and potentially some retail shops, with estimated launch prices ranging from S$1,500 to S$1,600 psf. The acquisition is seen as a bullish sign for the property market, with some analysts predicting a sharp increase in prices.

site_title: US exchanges set for highest number of Asian IPOs since 2010
summary: US exchanges are poised to record the highest number of Asian IPOs since 2010, with 20-24 listings expected in 2017, including 10 Chinese firms and five from Singapore, Taiwan, and Indonesia. Nasdaq and NYSE are targeting firms from South-east Asian economies and startups from Japan and Australia to diversify their listings. This year's IPO proceeds from Asian companies are expected to increase, with sectors like life sciences, e-commerce, and financial technology driving deal activity.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q4 DPU shrinks amid rise in units
summary: Keppel Reit's Q4 DPU decreased to 1.4 Singapore cents due to an expansion in units to 3.35 billion, lower one-off compensation income, and the absence of other gains distribution. Income available for distribution fell 10.4% to S$47 million in Q3 FY2017. Net property income inched up 0.3% to S$31.67 million, while revenue expanded 2.3% to S$40.45 million. Adjusted net asset value per unit fell to S$1.41 as of Sept 30, 2017.

site_title: SGX extends global footprint with new office in Chicago
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has opened its new office in Chicago, expanding its global footprint. This physical presence aims to connect better with the world's largest equities market and serve a growing client base in the US. It also seeks to cater to the increasing demand from international investors to access and manage Asian exposure. The move is expected to enhance SGX's ability to meet the needs of its clients and investors globally.

site_title: What's in China's DNA - war or peace?
summary: China's Communist Party is set to hold its 19th Congress, with leader Xi Jinping expected to solidify his power and revise the party constitution to include his name. Xi has consolidated control over internal security, foreign policy, and the economy, sparking concerns about China's growing power and one-man rule. Despite claiming to be a peaceful nation, China's history shows a history of conquest, invasion, and manipulation of others, including the Korean War and its ongoing claims in the South China Sea. The country's language and culture also reflect a hierarchical structure, with a strong emphasis on authority and obedience.

site_title: Taylor said to impress Trump for Fed chair as Warsh loses favour
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed favor towards Stanford University economist John Taylor, a candidate for Federal Reserve chairman, after a meeting at the White House. Taylor's monetary policy rule, which advocates for higher interest rates, contrasts with Trump's preference for keeping rates low. Former Fed board governor Kevin Warsh has seen his chances fade, with Trump praising Taylor's credentials and academic background. Taylor, along with Janet Yellen, Gary Cohn, and Jerome Powell, is on the president's shortlist to lead the central bank.

site_title: Rousseau-esque angst over modern life?
summary: A book titled "The Veil of Circumstance: Technology, Values, Dehumanization and the Future of Economics and Politics" by Jorgen Orstrom Moller, a retired Danish diplomat, warns of a bleak future for the global economy due to debts, falling productivity, and dehumanization. Orstrom Moller believes that businesses are no longer responsible stakeholders and the current political system has lost connection with citizens, failing to address pressing issues. He predicts a slowdown in the global economy over the next quarter century, with the possibility of it reversing or coming to a standstill.

site_title: Brexit timeline pushed back as May's late push comes up short
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's last-minute push to unblock stalled Brexit talks with the EU fell short, with European leaders now looking to December to move negotiations on to discussions about the future EU-UK relationship. Despite May's efforts to meet with EU leaders, the latest draft of the summit conclusions suggests that "sufficient progress" has not been made, and talks will not move forward until the end of the year. The UK and EU have until March 2019 to thrash out a deal on their future trading relationship and divorce terms.

images.alt_text: Ms May took a political risk by promising to pay into the EU budget and settle the divorce bill in a speech in Florence, Italy, last month and now needs something in return before she can make further concessions.

site_title: STI, Asia stocks ride on Wall Street highs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) extended gains for the second straight day, rising 5.97 points or 0.18% to close at 3,329.03 on Tuesday. The rally was driven by expectations of higher interest rates and optimism from Wall Street, despite a disappointing non-oil domestic exports performance in September. Index heavyweights DBS, OCBC, and Singtel contributed to the gains, while counters from UOL Group and ComfortDelGro lost ground. Asian stocks, including Tokyo's Nikkei and Australian shares, also rose, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng and Shanghai equities remained unchanged or fell.

site_title: Plans for London's historic India Club cook up a storm
summary: Plans to renovate London's historic India Club, a beloved Indian restaurant and bar, are sparking controversy. The club's director, Yadgar Marker, is fighting against a proposal by Marston Properties to turn the building into a boutique hotel, citing its rich history and cultural significance. The India Club, established in the early 1950s, has hosted prominent figures such as Jawaharlal Nehru and has been a hub for intellectuals and politicians. The club has applied for protected status from Historic England, and a petition has gathered over 14,000 signatures in support of preserving the site.

images.alt_text: The India Club, a restaurant and bar on the Strand near London's West End, is trying to use its storied history to block proposals by owners Marston Properties to turn the seven storey building into an upmarket boutique hotel. Loyal longtime customers have been voicing their support. A petition launched by the club had garnered over 14,000 signatures by Monday.

site_title: Industrial output up in Sept as impact from hurricanes fades
summary: US industrial output rose 0.3% in September, as the impact of hurricanes Harvey and Irma began to fade, and construction and utilities production rebounded. Manufacturing output edged up 0.1% after a revised decline of 0.2% in August. Import prices surged 0.7% in September, the largest gain in over a year, driven by rising petroleum and food costs. Despite this, underlying imported inflation remained modest.

site_title: Possibility of hawkish Fed chair props up US$
summary: The US dollar strengthened against other currencies following reports that President Trump is favoring Stanford economist John Taylor to head the Federal Reserve. Taylor's hawkish stance on monetary policy is expected to lead to a faster pace of rate hikes, boosting the dollar. The US two-year Treasury yields hit their highest levels in almost nine years, supporting the dollar's rise. The euro slipped 0.3% to a one-week low, while the euro-dollar index climbed half a percent to its strongest since October 9.

site_title: Muscular dystrophy no barrier to making art
summary: William Eng Wei Xiang, who has muscular dystrophy, collaborated with the Muscular Dystrophy Association (Singapore) and 22 students from the School of the Arts to create bright linoleum prints. The prints will be showcased at the Sunburst: The Business Times-CapitaLand Fundraising Concert, which has already raised nearly S$230,000 for MDAS and the Sota Student Assistance Fund. The event aims to raise money for these beneficiaries and promote inclusion, with the art-making session helping to break down barriers and showcase the capabilities of individuals with muscular dystrophy.

site_title: e-commerce growth set to slow in Singapore: Worldpay
summary: Singapore's e-commerce market is expected to slow down, with 73% of adult Internet users already shopping online, according to Worldpay's annual global payments report. Credit cards remain the preferred payment method, with e-wallets gaining traction. The country's small population and high online shopping penetration are contributing factors to the slowing growth, indicating a mature market.

site_title: Why the Obamas' portrait choices matter
summary: The Obamas' portrait choices for the Smithsonian National Portrait Gallery have significant implications for the state of American art. Kehinde Wiley, an established figurative painter, will paint Barack Obama's likeness, while Amy Sherald, a relatively unknown artist, will paint Michelle Obama's. This decision highlights the work of contemporary and modern African-American artists, reflecting the Obamas' instincts for balancing the expected and the surprising. The choice of Sherald adds a sense of risk, as she was unknown to the curators when the selection process began. The portraits will cost $500,000 and are part of a growing trend in figurative painting that explores themes of race, gender, and identity.

images.alt_text: Kehinde Wiley, who is 40 and known for his art-historically savvy portraits of young black men and women, has been on collectors' must-have lists for more than a decade.

site_title: Waiting to upgrade to the iPhone 8? you're not alone
summary: The iPhone 7 is experiencing a sales boost, with more people interested in buying older iPhones at a cheaper price. The iPhone 7's price cut and the lack of significant new features in the iPhone 8 are contributing to this trend. This shift reflects a broader notion that consumers are not upgrading to the latest smartphone as frequently as they have in the past, with some analysts attributing this to fewer must-have features being added to each generation. The iPhone 8's sales are expected to be reported by Apple on November 2.

site_title: Microsoft 'kept quiet about secret database hack in 2013'
summary: Microsoft's secret internal database for tracking bugs in its software was hacked by a highly sophisticated hacking group in 2013, according to five former employees. The database contained critical vulnerabilities in widely used software, including Windows, and could have been used to mount attacks elsewhere. Microsoft did not disclose the breach to the public or its customers, but tightened security measures after the incident. Experts say the breach highlights the importance of treating accurate bug reports as "keys to the kingdom" and the need for companies to prioritize software security.

site_title: P&G proxy battle: Peltz beaten by a mere 0.2%
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has emerged victorious in its proxy battle against activist investor Nelson Peltz, beating him by a mere 0.2% of shares outstanding. The vote was held at the company's annual meeting, where Peltz lost his bid for a board seat to Ernesto Zedillo. The narrow margin has cast uncertainty over the outcome, with Peltz's Trian Fund Management claiming the results were too close to call. The proxy battle, the largest in history, is expected to head into another stage as the independent auditor reviews the votes.

site_title: Thailand denies baht manipulation ahead of US currency report
summary: Thailand has denied allegations of manipulating its currency, the baht, ahead of a US report on exchange-rate manipulation. The country's central bank faces criticism for not curbing the baht's gains, making Thai goods more expensive. Commerce Minister Apiradi Tantraporn stated that countries aim for weak currencies to boost sales. Thailand appears close to meeting US criteria, but the central bank's inaction has raised concerns about unfair trade practices.

site_title: Move to greener shipping - good news and bad
summary: A recently launched Task Force on Decarbonizing Shipping aims to develop pathways for shipping's decarbonization through five working groups, focusing on industry leadership, technology, transparency, finance, and carbon pricing. The task force, led by industry leaders, will bring together experts to promote innovation and collaboration. However, the initiative may face opposition from the International Maritime Organization (IMO) and industry groups, which have already taken steps to reduce emissions through its Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI). The IMO's progress is dependent on agreement from its member states, and the task force's outcomes will not directly feed into this process.

site_title: Qatar sets sights on Asia private sectors amid Gulf blockade
summary: Qatar, seeking to diversify its economy amid the Gulf blockade, has signed agreements with Singapore to attract private sector investments in Asia. The deals include a bilateral investment treaty, a joint committee to monitor implementation, and four memoranda of understanding. Qatar's Minister of Economy and Trade assured Singapore companies operating in Qatar that business will continue as usual. The agreements aim to boost trade and investment between the two countries, with total trade between Qatar and Singapore reaching $4.3 billion in 2016.

site_title: Nordstrom suspends effort to go private until after the holidays
summary: Nordstrom has suspended its effort to go private until after the holiday season, citing difficulty in obtaining debt financing due to the current retail environment. The company's stock sank 5.3% on Monday to $40.40 per share, down 22.2% from a year ago. Analysts attribute the decision to the volatile winter shopping season, recent hurricanes, unseasonably warm weather, and fast-paced online growth. The family group, which owns 31.3% of the company, formed a special committee to review potential proposals, but lenders are becoming increasingly skeptical of taking on the risk.

site_title: Facebook buys TBH app loved by teens for anonymous quizzes
summary: Facebook has acquired TBH, a popular teen mobile app that lets users anonymously answer questions about their friends. TBH, which translates to "To Be Honest," has over five million users who have sent more than a billion messages. The app aims to maintain positive conversations, unlike other anonymous apps that have been linked to bullying. TBH will operate separately from Facebook, with the social network providing resources to expand and build positive experiences. The acquisition aims to reach flighty teenage users who prefer different communication methods.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported stable cash flows from its key assets, with the newest asset, Data Centre One, contributing higher positive cash flows. The trust's cash generation fluctuates due to time lag between gas tariffs and fuel costs, but smoothens out over time. Discussions with Hydro Tasmania and the banking syndicate on matters related to an undersea cable outage are ongoing.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Reit (KDCReit) reported its Q317 results, which met our expectations.

site_title: US govt calls for Kobe Steel documents on false data
summary: The US Justice Department has requested Kobe Steel Ltd to provide documents related to its data falsification scandal, which has led to a loss of about $1.6 billion in market value. Data tampering on products allegedly occurred for more than a decade, deeper than the company's initial admission. The scandal has affected 500 companies worldwide, including major clients like Boeing, and could result in significant financial and legal consequences, including compensation claims and penalties for unfair competition.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.38 points lower on Tuesday at 1,748.99. The index saw 2.88 billion lots worth RM2.28 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 468 to 395.

site_title: September NODX stuns economists with reversal into contraction
summary: Singapore's exports unexpectedly contracted 1.1% in September, reversing a 4-month expansion streak, led by a decline in electronics shipments. The contraction, or 11% drop from August, exceeded economists' expectations of a 12.7% growth. While some predict a temporary slowdown, others see it as a sign of a longer-term slowdown in growth, with the electronics sector's performance expected to continue to decline. The country's full-year growth forecast of 5-6% may be at risk.

site_title: UK inflation rises to 5-year high on food, transport costs
summary: UK inflation rose to a 5-year high of 3% in September, driven by food and transport costs, surpassing the central bank's 2% target. The increase may prompt the Bank of England to raise interest rates for the first time in over a decade. Core inflation remained unchanged at 2.7%, while manufacturing input prices rose 8.4% due to the weak pound. Officials are concerned that Brexit has left the economy prone to persistent price pressures. The Bank of England will publish new forecasts on November 2.

site_title: Activist investor RBR calls for Credit Suisse break-up
summary: Activist investor RBR Capital Advisors has launched a campaign to break up Credit Suisse, Switzerland's second-biggest lender, into an investment bank, asset management group, and wealth manager. RBR, led by Rudolf Bohli, has built a small stake in the bank and recruited a former Credit Suisse investment bank co-head to support its campaign. The move follows investor frustration with Credit Suisse's turnaround plan and comes after RBR previously launched campaigns against other asset managers and airlines.

site_title: Sting in the tail of latest upbeat economic prognoses
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has released a report indicating that global economic activity is strengthening, with 2017 expected to be the best year for global growth since 2010, at 3.6% in 2017 and 3.7% in 2018. However, the recovery is far from complete, with low inflation and weak growth in many economies, and geopolitical risks. The IMF urges policymakers to boost potential output and build resilience against downside risks, providing an opportunity to tackle key challenges and ensure the benefits of the cyclical pick-up are shared broadly.

site_title: Compulsory acquisition threshold hit for CWT buyout
summary: HNA Holding Group has reached the 90% compulsory acquisition threshold for its S$2.33-a-share offer for logistics firm CWT Ltd. The final closing date of the offer is November 2, after which HNA intends to exercise its right to compulsorily acquire the remaining shares and delist the firm from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Living it up? It'll cost more now in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Lifestyle Index rose 2.4% in 2017, driven by a 7% rebound in property prices. The city remains the most expensive in Asia for luxury living, except for Hong Kong, which jumped to the top spot. The index, which tracks high-end goods and services, also saw a 1.9% increase in China, driven by consumer sentiment and "reshoring" of luxury purchases. Luxury brands are adapting to economic fluctuations by adjusting prices, with Chanel raising handbag prices by over 20% in response to the euro's decline.

site_title: United Food receives 70m renminbi offer for partially-suspended subsidiary Post-Ante
summary: United Food Holdings has accepted an offer to sell its wholly owned subsidiary Post-Ante Trading Ltd for 70 million renminbi (S$14.3 million). Post-Ante has partially suspended operations for two years due to environmental policies in China. The sale will be made to Financial Services Company for Innovative Industry in China Ltd, an investment and asset management company, and the proceeds will be used for working capital and future investments.

site_title: Meet the Social Impact Bond, a win-win solution to problems
summary: A Social Impact Bond (SIB) is a collaborative tool that unites the public, private, and people sectors to achieve social outcomes. It works by having the government specify a social issue, a private investor fund a non-profit to deliver the impact, and an independent evaluator measure the outcome. If the impact is achieved, the government repays the investors. This approach maximizes outcomes per taxpayer dollar, enables non-profits to experiment with effective solutions, and provides investors with a return on their investment. SIBs have been used to tackle various issues, including reducing youth recidivism and diabetes prevention, and are being considered for use in Singapore to address challenges such as youth recidivism and elderly frailty.

site_title: India's digital leap offers multi-trillion-dollar opportunity
summary: India is poised for a multi-trillion-dollar economic boost through digitization, driven by the JAM trinity (Aadhar, Jan Dhan, and smartphone usage) and the implementation of the Goods & Services Tax (GST). Digital payments are expected to increase from 5% of GDP to 20% by 2026, and better credit delivery is anticipated, leading to improved capital allocation, domestic demand, and GDP growth. This trend is expected to have global implications, making India a significant market for global corporations and a test case for other emerging markets.

site_title: Eurowings sees $1 b euros revenue boost from Air Berlin deal
summary: Eurowings is set to receive a revenue boost of over 1 billion euros from Lufthansa's deal to acquire 81 of Air Berlin's planes, expanding its fleet to 210 aircraft and workforce to 10,000. This deal is expected to lift Eurowings' annual revenues to more than 5 billion euros, with the European Commission potentially demanding measures to address competition concerns on some routes.

site_title: Qatari banks are said to cut dollar sales to foreign lenders
summary: Qatari banks are reducing dollar sales to foreign lenders amid a regional standoff with a Saudi-led alliance. Foreign exchange activity between local and international banks is nearly at a standstill, with the central bank providing dollars to local lenders at a pegged rate of 3.64 riyals per dollar. This move may lead to higher costs for foreign banks to obtain dollars, potentially affecting clients in Qatar.

site_title: US industrial output picks up in September
summary: US industrial output increased 0.3% in September, driven by a rebound in construction and utilities production after Hurricanes Harvey and Irma. This follows an upwardly revised 0.7% decline in August. The manufacturing sector edged up 0.1% after an August decline. The percentage of industrial capacity in use increased 0.2 percentage points to 76.0% in September, as the effects of the hurricanes began to fade.

site_title: ESR-Reit still looking to divest assets as it posts 2.3% drop in Q3 DPU
summary: ESR-Reit, a Singapore-based industrial landlord, reported a 2.3% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.964 cents for Q3. The Reit remains focused on divesting non-core assets and managing lease expiries proactively amidst increasing industrial rent pressure. The portfolio has become more balanced with a shift from single-tenanted to multi-tenanted properties. Despite macroeconomic indicators showing improvement, the Reit's strategy aims to navigate the market's challenges and capitalize on the growing demand for green and transition finance.

site_title: DBS launches corporate multi-currency account
summary: DBS Bank has launched a corporate multi-currency account, allowing businesses to manage up to 13 currencies in one single account. The account enables cross-border payments and reduces foreign exchange costs. There is no minimum balance requirement in separate currency accounts, but a minimum balance of S$10,000 is required for the entire account. This move aims to simplify international transactions and improve financial efficiency for businesses.

site_title: US: Wall Street flat at open
summary: Wall Street opened flat on Tuesday, despite upbeat earnings from Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, which failed to fuel optimism for record highs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.07%, the S&P 500 lost 0.01%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.05%. The lack of impact from the banks' earnings suggests traders are focusing on ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Prince William and wife Kate say baby expected in April
summary: Prince William and his wife Kate, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, have confirmed their third child is expected to be born in April. The baby, who will be fifth-in-line to the British throne, was announced as pregnant last month, with Kate suffering from severe morning sickness. This is Kate's second public appearance since the announcement. The royals' office released a statement confirming the due date without disclosing the exact date.

site_title: India's Axis Bank Q2 profit rises around 36%
summary: Axis Bank Ltd reported a 36% increase in second-quarter net profit to 4.32 billion rupees (S$90.2 million), driven by easing provisions for bad loans and a 12% rise in fee income. The bank's gross bad loans as a percentage of total loans decreased to 5.90%, while outstanding loans on its watch list fell 24%. The bank's net interest margin was 3.45%, down from 3.63% a quarter earlier.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO expects to benefit from Airbus, Bombardier deal
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr expects the airline to benefit from future cooperation between Airbus and Bombardier due to the German airline's significant customer base for both companies. Airbus has agreed to buy a majority stake in Bombardier's CSeries jetliner program, a move that is expected to boost the Canadian plane maker. As a launch customer and operator of the CSeries, Lufthansa will likely benefit from the joint development of technology and innovation by the two companies.

site_title: Uber loses another senior figure as European policy chief quits -FT
summary: Uber's European policy chief, Christopher Burghardt, has quit to join Chargepoint, citing his support for electric vehicles. This departure follows a tumultuous period for Uber, marked by regulatory battles and the departure of former CEO Travis Kalanick. New CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has been meeting with London transport regulators to appeal the loss of Uber's London licence, which was revoked earlier this month. Burghardt will become Chargepoint's managing director in Europe in November.

site_title: STI adds 6 points on Tuesday to end at 3,329.03
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 6 points to close at 3,329.03, driven by higher oil prices and inspired by Wall Street's record close. Turnover was 1.5 billion units worth S$1.1 billion, with Singtel, DBS, and Global Logistic among the top counters. The gains came despite a weak performance in Singapore's non-oil domestic exports, which fell 1.1% year-on-year in September.

site_title: Keppel T&T Q3 net profit down 82% at S$12.8m
summary: Keppel T&T posted an 82% drop in net profit to S$12.8 million for Q3 2017, mainly due to one-off gains from a divestment in 2016 and contributions from subsidiaries disposed. Excluding these gains, net profit would have decreased by 27%. Revenue slipped 3.3% to S$45 million, and earnings per share fell to 2.3 cents. No dividends were declared for the period.

site_title: Volvo unveils Polestar model in China
summary: Volvo has unveiled its first Polestar high-performance electric car, the Polestar 1, in China. The luxury coupe will be produced in Chengdu, western China, and priced between $207,362 and $239,264. Volvo plans to invest 5 billion yuan in the brand, with the goal of selling greener cars in the world's biggest auto market. The company aims to make all its car models launched after 2019 electric or hybrids, making it the first major traditional carmaker to phase out internal combustion engine vehicles.

site_title: SGX opens US office in Chicago
summary: SGX, Singapore's largest exchange, has opened its US office in Chicago, expanding its international presence. The move aims to serve a growing client base in the US and cater to international investors seeking Asian exposure. SGX's CEO, Loh Boon Chye, stated that the US presence will enhance access to risk management solutions and price discovery tools, complementing the exchange's global products and platforms. This marks an important milestone in SGX's international expansion strategy, reinforcing its status as Asia's most-connected exchange.

site_title: ESR-Reit reports 2.3% drop in Q3 DPU
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 2.3% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.964 cents for Q3, driven by a 1.6% decline in net property income. The decline was partly mitigated by income from new leases. Occupancy fell to 91.1% due to the inclusion of a newly enhanced asset and a non-renewed lease, with 1.08 million sq ft of space renewed. The company is actively marketing vacant spaces at both buildings.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q3 DPU down to 1.4 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Reit's third quarter distribution per unit (DPU) decreased to 1.4 Singapore cents from 1.6 Singapore cents in the same period last year, amid a 10.4% decline in income available for distribution. Revenue rose 2.3% to S$40.4 million, while net property income increased 0.3% to S$31.7 million. The trust's property portfolio includes several assets in Singapore and Australia, with the number of units increasing.

site_title: Greece, in recession again last year, eyes recovery in 2017-18
summary: Greece's economy contracted by 0.2% in 2016, according to the country's statistics service ELSTAT, confounding international creditors who had predicted growth. The economy's leading think tank, IOBE, predicts a slightly below 1.5% growth in 2017 and 2% in 2018, below government forecasts. The country's high unemployment rate and reduced household consumption are seen as major challenges to recovery, with the jobless rate remaining at 21% and a primary budget surplus goal of 1.75% still uncertain.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat ahead of China party congress, Q3 GDP data
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained unchanged on Tuesday ahead of China's Communist Party congress and third-quarter GDP data. The Hang Seng index hovered around its 10-year peak, influenced by Asian equities' firmness. Investors await President Xi Jinping's policy initiatives and potential economic slowdown signs. Economists expect a 6.8% GDP growth rate in the third quarter, with some traders betting on a possible upside surprise. Energy shares rose on higher oil prices, while industrial stocks fell.

site_title: GLP China issues 1b renminbi bonds on China's interbank market
summary: GLP China has issued 1 billion renminbi (S$205 million) panda bonds with a 4.99% annual coupon, to be repaid and used for business growth in China. The bonds were oversubscribed 2.6 times and marked the company's first international bond issuance on both the Shanghai Stock Exchange and China's Interbank Market. Proceeds will be used to repay existing debt and increase financial flexibility. This move is part of GLP China's efforts to hedge funding operations in local currency and diversify sources of funding.

site_title: British government proposes new M&A rules to protect national security
summary: The British government has proposed new rules to protect national security through mergers and acquisitions in the military and technology sectors. The proposed changes include lowering the revenue threshold for government scrutiny and removing requirements for increased supply share. The aim is to safeguard critical infrastructure while ensuring free trade and inward investment. The government will set out further measures in the autumn, with Prime Minister Theresa May pledging to protect national security.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks up for 11th straight day, hit fresh 21-year high
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index reached a fresh 21-year high, rising for the 11th straight session, with the Nikkei 225 up 0.38% to 21,336.12 and the Topix index up 0.24% to 1,723.37. Strong Japanese corporate earnings outweighed concerns about overheating, driving the market to a record high.

site_title: TV ditches dating shows for splitsville gigs
summary: TV is shifting its focus from matchmaking to divorce, with new shows featuring instant divorce, couples' break-ups, and radical relationship tests. Shows like The Break Up, Divorce For The Better, and Bi The Way aim to help couples move on and find new love. Other formats, such as Pregnant With A Stranger and Celebrity Showmance, challenge unlikely relationships and social media interactions. Meanwhile, talent shows continue to dominate TV schedules, with new formats like Change Your Tune and All Together Now.

site_title: Major Wi-Fi security flaw affects billions worldwide, including almost every Internet user in Singapore
summary: A major Wi-Fi security flaw, dubbed KRACK, has been discovered, putting billions worldwide, including almost every Internet user in Singapore, at risk. The flaw, in the WPA2 protocol, allows hackers to monitor, inject, and manipulate users' network traffic. Experts warn that billions of devices remain unpatched, and users should update their products as soon as security updates become available. While no reports of exploitation have been made, the vulnerability exposes critical weaknesses in the Wi-Fi standard, making it a significant threat.

site_title: US online retail sales likely to surpass US$1 trillion by 2027
summary: US online retail sales are expected to surpass $1 trillion by 2027, growing at a compound annual rate of 12% through 2020 and 9% over the next decade. Online sales currently account for 12% of total US retail sales and 50% of growth. Amazon's share of online sales is projected to increase to 53% by 2027, representing nearly 12% of US retail sales. This growth is expected to boost total sales for the US holiday season, with nonstore sales forecast to rise 11-15% to $140 billion in the last two months of the year.

site_title: Temasek International makes senior leadership changes
summary: Temasek International, the management arm of Temasek Holdings, has announced several senior leadership changes as part of efforts to prepare for its next phase of development. CEO Lee Theng Kiat will take on the role of deputy chairman, while Dilhan Pillay will become deputy CEO, and Chia Song Hwee will assume the roles of president and COO. Tan Chong Lee will be appointed president of Temasek International. The changes aim to promote from within and build a strong culture of ownership, reflecting the organization's confidence in local talent.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 1.1% in September, marking a slowdown after a 16.7% year-on-year surge in August. Chip Eng Seng acquired Changi Garden for S$248.8m, while DBS Bank launched a corporate multi-currency account. A report by DTCC warned of systemic risks from fintech. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.18% to close at 3,329.03, driven by Wall Street's record close and higher oil prices.

site_title: Richemont flags big profit rise in watch market uptick
summary: Swiss luxury goods company Richemont expects a 80% rise in net profit for the first half of 2017, driven by a recovering watch market. Sales were up 12% at constant exchange rates, with profit from ongoing operations increasing by 45%. The company's costly buyback of timepiece stocks in Asia has stopped, contributing to the sharp increase in net earnings. Richemont's portfolio includes flagship brands Cartier, Van Cleef & Arpels, and Jaeger-LeCoultre.

site_title: Credit Suisse targeted by activist investor
summary: Credit Suisse is being targeted by activist investor Rudolf Bohli, who has taken a 0.2% stake in the Swiss bank. Bohli wants to break up the lender into three parts: an investment bank, a wealth manager, and an asset-management business. The move comes as Credit Suisse struggles to boost profitability, with shares falling by a third under CEO Tidjane Thiam. The bank's restructuring efforts have been slow, and Bohli believes the businesses are too integrated.

site_title: S'pore FTA in Africa a question of 'when', not 'if'
summary: Singapore is considering a free-trade agreement (FTA) with Africa, a move that could provide a foothold into the continent's growing economy. Africa is the fastest-growing region after East Asia, and a Singapore FTA could become a benchmark for other deals. The continent's regional integration efforts, such as the Continental Free Trade Area (CFTA), are gaining momentum, with 26 states adopting the Tripartite Free Trade Area (TFTA) in 2015. A bilateral or multilateral deal with a large economy like South Africa or the East African Community (EAC) could be a starting point.

site_title: Philippine president declares Marawi liberated as battle goes on
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte declared Marawi city liberated from pro-Islamic State militants on October 17, 2017, despite 20-30 rebels still fighting and holding 20 hostages. The declaration comes after the killing of two rebel leaders, Isnilon Hapilon and Omarkhayam Maute, and a 148-day occupation. Experts say the government underestimated the extent of extremism in impoverished Muslim areas. The remaining rebels are considered "stragglers" and pose little threat, with Malaysian operative Mahmud Ahmad being seen as no threat.

site_title: US Justice Department seeking information on Kobe Steel's faked data
summary: The US Department of Justice has requested documents from Kobe Steel Ltd regarding falsified product data, escalating a crisis that risks engulfing the Japanese steelmaker. Kobe has admitted to faking certifications on metals since 2007 and is cooperating with the US investigation. The company may face losses of up to 200 billion yen and is considering asset sales and the sale of its real estate unit to raise funds. A global review of its units is likely to reveal further instances of data falsification.

site_title: Old Wall Street losing the war in ETF market
summary: Old Wall Street is losing its market-making edge in the ETF market due to regulation, with nimbler high-frequency traders picking up the slack. The shift has made it easier and cheaper for retail investors to buy and sell ETFs, but also increased the concentration of market-making power among less-regulated firms. Banks, such as Goldman Sachs, have largely exited the business, with some firms, like IMC, and Citadel Securities, considering entering the market. The rise of electronic traders poses systemic risk, as the number of funds tops 2,000, and regulators may reassess the market-making model.

site_title: Europe: Equities stable at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets stabilized on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index declining 0.1% and Paris's CAC 40 rising 0.2%. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index also drifted 0.1% lower. The steady market performance came despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and rising US tariff threats.

site_title: China's stocks, bonds, currency drop in unison before Congress
summary: China's financial markets experienced a synchronized downturn before the start of a crucial Communist Party gathering, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.2% and government bonds retreating. The yuan dropped 0.3% against the dollar, while the 10-year yield rose to a two-year high. Analysts expect little in terms of substantial reforms, leading to concerns over corporate leverage and debt. This selling trend has historically led to further declines in equities, but a deeper selloff is unlikely due to efforts to maintain stable markets.

site_title: Sellers begin to buckle as sky-high London home prices decline
summary: London home prices are declining at their fastest pace since the 2009 financial crisis, with a 2.7% drop in the year through September, according to data from Acadata and LSL Property Services. The top end of the market has fallen 15% from its peak in 2014. Sellers are struggling, with some being told by valuers that properties are worth less than they've offered, leading to a decline in sales and rents. Realtors' share prices are also suffering, with Foxtons Group down 34% and Countrywide down 35% this year.

site_title: Is your business being held to ransom?
summary: Cybersecurity threats are becoming increasingly destructive, with attackers innovating ransomware and Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) campaigns. A global survey found that nearly half of companies suffered at least one cyber ransom incident, with 17% being RDoS attacks. Business email compromise (BEC) scams are more lucrative, costing $5.3 billion between 2013 and 2016. Automation is crucial to help organizations understand and respond to threats, reducing the time spent on detection, investigation, and remediation. Effective security requires prioritizing cybersecurity, investing in automated tools, and maximizing precious resources.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up but dealers cautious after latest gains
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, but with caution, after recent strong gains. Global optimism and corporate earnings continue to drive markets to all-time highs, but investors await the next catalyst. Key markets included Tokyo at 21-year highs, Sydney up 0.7%, and Seoul and Singapore gaining slightly. The dollar strengthened against the euro and pound, with speculation of a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Oil prices were mixed after news of a conflict in Iraq's Kirkuk province.

site_title: NZ dollar hits 2-week high on inflation; Aussie treads water
summary: The New Zealand dollar rose to a two-week high after inflation surpassed expectations, climbing 0.4% to US$0.7217. However, gains were short-lived, and the currency ended the day 0.1% lower. Analysts expect the Reserve Bank of New Zealand to maintain interest rates at record lows due to economic uncertainty. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar hovered around a recent three-week high at US$0.7848, supported by upbeat views on the economy.

site_title: Qian Hu's edible-fish farm dishes out a profit
summary: Qian Hu Corporation, a Singapore-based company, has reported a net profit of S$142,000 for its third quarter, up from S$5,000 a year ago, with revenue rising 14% to S$22.5 million. The company's edible fish business in China, launched in January, has been operationally profitable, with fish segment revenue increasing 17% to S$9 million. The company's accessories business also performed well, with a 14% gain in quarterly revenue to S$10.4 million. Qian Hu's net asset value per share has increased to 45.14 cents, and the company is monitoring its options to exit the Singapore Exchange's minimum trading price watch-list within 36 months.

site_title: Kobe Steel faked quality data for more than 10 years: source
summary: Kobe Steel Ltd, Japan's third-largest steelmaker, has admitted to falsifying product quality and specifications data for more than 10 years, contradicting its earlier claim of only 10 years. The cheating involved plant and quality control managers and affected over 500 companies, including those supplying Japan's bullet trains and Boeing. Despite no safety issues reported, the scandal has hammered Kobe Steel's shares, with investors knocking off US$1.8 billion in value. The company's CEO, Hiroya Kawasaki, has confirmed the extent of the tampering, which has sent shockwaves through global supply chains.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at record high on tech gains, won edges lower
summary: Seoul's stocks reached an all-time high on Tuesday, driven by gains in large tech firms like Samsung Electronics, which rose 1.6%. However, market caution due to possible North Korean action during joint military drills offset gains. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) ended 0.2% higher at 2,484.37 points. The South Korean won edged down 0.4% against the US dollar, closing at 1,132.5.

site_title: Jokowi roots for private investment as Freeport row lingers
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo announced that the country will turn to private investors to develop its infrastructure and natural resources, aiming to attract hundreds of billions of dollars in investment. He stated that government companies will partner with private investors only if there's enough interest, and funding from the national budget will be the last resort. Widodo aims to balance foreign investment with domestic needs, following a dispute with Freeport-McMoRan Inc over majority ownership of its Indonesian unit.

site_title: Qian Hu reports S$142,000 net profit for Q3
summary: Qian Hu Corporation reported its strongest quarterly results with a net profit of S$142,000 for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2017, a significant increase from S$5,000 a year ago. Revenue rose 14% to S$22.5 million, driven by growth across its fish, accessories, and plastics business segments. The company attributed its earnings to its new edible fish farming business in Hainan, despite initial start-up expenses. Qian Hu's stock price surged 6.7% to S$0.16 before the results were released.

site_title: Strong family ties boon and bane to Singaporeans' financial future: HSBC
summary: A survey by HSBC found that 77% of Singaporeans provide financial support to their family, with 46% using half their disposable income to do so. This comes at the expense of their own financial future, lifestyle, and emotional well-being. Despite this, 57% of respondents believe they are good providers and 54% feel appreciated by their family members. The survey suggests that strong family ties can have both positive and negative effects on financial security, and that individuals can mitigate this by prioritizing their finances and planning for the future.

site_title: ST Electronics, Saab to promote use of digital air-traffic towers in region
summary: ST Electronics and Saab Digital Air Traffic Solutions have signed a memorandum of understanding to establish a Centre of Excellence in Singapore for airport digital towers. The centre aims to promote the use of digital air-traffic towers in the region, improving flight journeys and meeting growing customer expectations. This partnership will provide a test bed for technologies and enhance regional adoption of digital air-traffic management solutions.

site_title: US, Japan fail to bridge gap on trade in economic talks
summary: US and Japan failed to agree on a two-way trade deal during economic talks, with Tokyo pushing back against US calls to open up its protected agricultural markets. The US expressed interest in a bilateral free trade agreement, but Japan argued against focusing on the trade deficit. Japan agreed to streamline noise and emissions testing procedures for US auto exports and lifted trade restrictions on US potatoes and Japanese persimmons. No agreement was reached on US complaints about Japan's safeguard mechanism on US frozen beef imports, and no date was set for the next round of dialogue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.05% higher, extending a fourth consecutive gain, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 28,708.58. This follows record-breaking performances on Wall Street's main indexes. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.16% and 0.19% respectively. The gains are attributed to investors brushing off new US trade threats.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us is said to explore options for US$2b Asian unit
summary: Toys "R" Us is exploring options for its US$2 billion Asian unit, including a potential initial public offering, as the company navigates bankruptcy proceedings in North America. The Asian business, which Toys "R" Us owns 85%, has shown growth despite weaker sales in the US and Europe. Deliberations are at an early stage, and the company has not decided which path to pursue. The IPO would allow private-equity owners to recoup some of their investment, but the ongoing bankruptcy could make a listing more complicated.

site_title: North Korea warns that nuclear war could 'break out any moment'
summary: North Korea warned that a nuclear war "may break out any moment" amid escalating tensions with the US and South Korea, who are conducting a joint naval drill. North Korea's deputy ambassador, Kim In Ryong, claimed the country has become a "full-fledged nuclear power" and its nuclear capabilities pose a threat to the US mainland. Russia urged the US to reduce military drills near North Korea, while a possible meeting between US and North Korean officials is expected this week.

site_title: Rio Tinto on track for iron ore record as China's imports surge
summary: Rio Tinto is on track to export a record 330 million tonnes of iron ore in 2017, driven by China's surge in imports and rail capacity increases. China's steel mills imported 100 million tonnes of iron ore in September, a record high, boosting demand for higher-grade raw materials. This is expected to benefit Rio Tinto, which is forecast to see its iron ore exports increase further with the implementation of its autonomous train program by the end of 2018.

site_title: London art auction raises £2m for survivors of deadly Grenfell Tower blaze
summary: A charity auction in London, hosted by Sotheby's, has raised nearly £2 million for survivors of the Grenfell Tower fire that killed around 80 people in June 2017. The auction featured artworks by prominent contemporary artists, including Wolfgang Tillmans and Antony Gormley, with all 31 lots selling. The proceeds, totaling £1.925 million, will be divided equally among 158 surviving families and distributed before Christmas. The event, organized by film producer Hamish McAlpine and art consultant Katie Heller, was a "White Glove" sale, exceeding the pre-auction estimate.

site_title: Singapore third-most expensive Asian city for luxury living: Julius Baer
summary: Singapore has fallen to third place in Asia's most expensive cities for luxury living, behind Hong Kong and Shanghai, due to easing property prices. The cost of luxury living rose 1.42% in US dollar terms, driven by sustained demand for luxury goods and services in Asia. Singapore has the highest prices for cars and lawyers, as well as fine dining, while also being one of the most expensive for Lasik operations. Wealthy Asian consumers are driving global consumer demand, according to Julius Baer Group CEO Boris Collardi.

site_title: Fintech can pose systemic risks: report
summary: A report by Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation (DTCC) warns that fintech may pose a systemic risk to financial systems, citing factors such as competition, concentration, and track record. Fintech's potential to disintermediate incumbents, disaggregate financial services, and decentralize networks could strengthen or weaken financial stability. The report advises monitoring the balance between competition and cooperation between fintech firms and incumbents, as well as the concentration of fintech companies. It also notes that fintech's short track record may create systemic vulnerabilities.

site_title: Microsoft responded quietly after detecting secret database hack in 2013
summary: Microsoft's secret internal database for tracking software bugs was hacked by a sophisticated group in 2013, according to five former employees. The database contained critical and unfixed vulnerabilities in widely used software, including Windows, and could have been used to mount attacks elsewhere. Microsoft discovered the breach but did not publicly disclose it, instead tightening security measures and requiring two authentications for access. The incident highlights the importance of treating bug reports as sensitive corporate information and underscores the need for companies to prioritize security efforts.

site_title: Broker's take: SAC Capital keeps 'buy' on United Global on strong financials
summary: SAC Advisors has maintained a "buy" rating for United Global, citing strong first-half financials and a recent acquisition. The lubricant maker's revenue and net profit rose 8.3% and 33.7% year-over-year, respectively, despite a 13.1% drop in volume. The company's gross margins exceeded estimates at 17.2%, driven by the acquisition of PT Lubritama Indonesia. SAC cited risk factors such as fluctuating base oil prices and raw material costs, but raised its target price to 50 Singapore cents.

site_title: Australia shares end at 5-month high; NZ extends rally
summary: Australian shares ended at a 5-month high on Tuesday, rising 0.7% to 5,889.6, driven by a record close on Wall Street and higher oil prices. The gains were led by financials and materials stocks, with the "Big Four" banks and Rio Tinto Ltd rising between 0.5% and 1.4%. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.3% to 8,112.05, despite a jump in inflation rate that is unlikely to alter the central bank's decision to keep rates on hold.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge up amid caution during joint navy drills; won down
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, despite joint US-South Korea navy drills, amid concerns over North Korea's nuclear program. Foreign investors sold steel shares, offsetting gains in tech firms. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) edged up to 2,482.02 points. The won fell 0.4% against the dollar, while US treasury bond futures gained 0.01 point. Analysts attributed investor caution to worries about North Korea's provocations during the drills.

site_title: Singapore shares open up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 11.41 points to 3,334.47 on Tuesday, boosted by bank shares and expectations of an interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The top gainers included DBS and UOB, with 52 million shares worth S$67.8 million changing hands.

site_title: Bombardier seeking investors for aerospace businesses
summary: Bombardier Inc is seeking investors for its aerospace businesses and considering a sale of some operations due to pressure from US tariffs on its jetliner. The company is studying the disposal of assets such as its Q400 turboprop and CRJ regional-jet unit. This move is part of a turnaround plan aimed at addressing financial challenges.

site_title: Qatar and Singapore reaffirm ties; boost industry, business cooperation
summary: Qatar and Singapore have signed several agreements to deepen cooperation in various areas, including information communication, technology, security, business, and legal. A Bilateral Investment Treaty was signed to boost trade and investment, while Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) were signed in areas such as human resources development, food resource, and building material. The agreements aim to strengthen bilateral ties and promote economic growth. Qatar's Emir, Sheikh Tamim Bin Hamad Al Thani, met with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and reaffirmed the strong ties between the two countries.

site_title: Australia central bank watching energy price developments: official
summary: Australia's central bank is monitoring energy policy developments and potential price hikes, which could affect businesses and private investment. The conservative government is set to reject calls for a clean energy target, instead focusing on affordable electricity. Rising retail electricity prices may contribute to inflation, but not significantly impact household spending. Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor Luci Ellis emphasized the energy crisis has led to reduced back-up power for wind and solar, and states' reliance on rooftop solar and wind power has grown without a stable national carbon policy.

site_title: Ex-Googler raises US$13m betting her home on podcasts
summary: Wang Xiaoyu, a 30-year-old ex-Googler, has raised $13 million for her podcast app CastBox.FM, which has over 1.5 million monthly users and is one of the best-reviewed apps in Google's Play store. The app's unique feature is its search bar that transcribes popular podcasts, allowing users to search by spoken words. CastBox has generated significant success abroad, with Europe and the US being its largest markets, and is set to expand its exclusive content deals and offer revenue sharing to attract more users.

site_title: China Construction Bank prices 3-year S$500m bond issue at 2.08%
summary: China Construction Bank priced a 3-year, S$500 million bond at 2.08% per annum, attracting over S$700 million in flows primarily from Singapore banks and funds. The senior bond is rated A by Fitch and will be listed on the Singapore Exchange. CCB, DBS, and OCBC are joint global coordinators of the deal.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.65 points to 1,752.72. Volume was 152.91 million lots worth RM44.3 million, with 141 gainers and 66 losers.

site_title: Australian shares hit five-month high; NZ edges down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to a five-month high, tracking a record finish on Wall Street and higher oil and copper prices. Copper touched a three-year peak due to upbeat Chinese data, while oil prices jumped due to supply concerns. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,882, marking its fifth straight session of gains.

site_title: Greek central bank chief calls for swift conclusion of bailout review
summary: Greek central bank governor Yannis Stournaras urged the country's foreign lenders to conclude a review of its bailout compliance swiftly, paving the way for further debt relief and a potential return to bond markets. A swift conclusion will allow Greece to lift capital controls and return to normal economic activity. The review is expected to start next week, with Greece aiming to complete it by December. A fast conclusion will also facilitate a discussion on debt relief, which will enable Greek bonds to be included in the European Central Bank's bond-buying program.

site_title: Tough US Nafta demands send ball back into lobbyists' court
summary: The Trump administration has proposed radical changes to the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), including forcing renegotiation every five years and reserving 85% of automotive manufacturing for the US. This has sparked dismay among officials from Mexico, Canada, and US industry groups, who are concerned about the future of the $1.2 trillion trade deal. The proposals have been met with opposition from major industry groups, including the US Chamber of Commerce, and are likely to face significant resistance in Congress and among US employers. The fate of Nafta remains uncertain, with the fourth round of talks set to conclude on Tuesday.

site_title: Quick takes: Disappointing NODX opens door for rollback of GDP expectations
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 1.1% in September, the first year-on-year contraction since April 2017. The drop was more pronounced month-over-month, with a 11% seasonally adjusted decline. Economists attribute the decline to electronics export growth, which fell to -7.9% y-o-y, and pharmaceuticals exports, which plummeted 36% y-o-y. This data has opened the door for a downward revision of GDP growth expectations and a potential rollback of SGD appreciation policy.

site_title: Netflix adds more subscribers than expected, shares hit record
summary: Netflix reported a 5.3 million subscriber gain in the third quarter, surpassing Wall Street's target of 4.5 million. The company forecasts 6.3 million additions for the current quarter, bringing its global customer base to nearly 115.6 million. Shares rose 1.2% to a record high of $205.07 after hours, up 64% this year. The strong performance is attributed to Netflix's early lead in the global internet television market.

site_title: London house prices fall at fastest pace since 2009
summary: London house prices have fallen at their fastest pace since 2009, with a 2.7% decline in September from the previous year, according to Acadata and LSL property Services. This marks the sixth consecutive month of decline. The average price of a home in London is now below £582,000, the lowest since 2015. The fall is welcome news for those struggling to get onto the housing ladder, with the British government announcing an extension of its "Help to Buy" mortgage-assistance programme earlier this month.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS keeps 'buy' on Keppel DC Reit on asset quality
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "buy" rating on Keppel DC Reit, citing the trust's low cost of capital and room for accretive acquisitions. The Reit has seen a 16.8% rise in its Q3 distribution per unit to 1.74 Singapore cents, driven by acquisitions and rental income. DBS expects stable growth in the existing portfolio, leading to inorganic DPU growth. The brokerage has a target price of S$1.44 for the stock.

site_title: Stocks to watch: M1, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Keppel DC Reit, Pacific Radiance
summary: M1's net profit fell 4.8% to S$32.7 million in its third quarter, driven by higher depreciation and interest expenses. Keppel Infrastructure Trust denied a report that its underwater cable is for sale, stating it reviews business strategies regularly for optimal risk-adjusted returns.

site_title: OKH can't complete S$49m sale of warehouse unit, cites buyers' default
summary: OKH Global failed to complete a S$49 million sale of a warehouse investment unit after buyers cited inability to proceed with completion. The intended sale involved the sale of OKH's minority interest in Pan Asia Logistics Investment Holdings and Pan Asia Logistics Holdings Singapore. The buyers' decision was made on Monday, prompting OKH to announce the failed deal.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records as bank shares gain
summary: US stocks ended at records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.4% to 22,956.96, the S&P 500 gaining 0.2% to 2,557.64, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.3% to 6,624.00. Bank shares surged, led by Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, on expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December. Analysts also cited solid third-quarter earnings and a potential tax cut plan.

site_title: Airbus to enter into partnership with Canada's Bombardier
summary: Airbus will take a majority stake in Bombardier's C-Series airliner programme after the US administration imposed a 220% countervailing duty and 80% anti-dumping tax on Bombardier CS100 and CS300 aircraft. The US accuses Bombardier of manufacturing planes with public subsidies and selling them at a loss to Delta Air Lines. The partnership aims to help Bombardier overcome the tariffs and maintain the C-Series programme. Airbus will provide financial and technical support to Bombardier, allowing the Canadian firm to continue producing the aircraft.
