summary: Facebook has rolled out a new feature in the US, allowing users to order food delivery or takeout from various restaurant chains and on-demand services, including Papa John's and DoorDash, directly from the social network. The "Order Food" feature, available on desktop, iOS, and Android applications, lets users browse nearby restaurants, read reviews, and place orders with a few taps. Facebook has been testing the feature since last year and aims to make it easier for users to find and order food without leaving the platform.

site_title: Hillary Clinton blames election loss on sexism during UK book tour
summary: Former US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton blamed her 2016 election loss on sexism and double standards held against women in public life. At a book tour in the UK, Clinton said women are heavily judged and criticized due to sexism, and are generally disliked in positions of power. She encouraged her supporters to get organized and sign up for her platform "Onward Together" to promote citizen engagement and train young leaders. Clinton ruled out running again for top office, but vowed to continue supporting the Democratic party and expressing her views.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as base metals rally; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Monday, reaching a four-month high, driven by a base metals rally, particularly in coking coal and iron ore. The S&P/ASX 200 index hit 5,847.5, with mining stocks like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto gaining up to 2.2% and 2.7%, respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.153% due to a decline in its services sector.

site_title: Australian model latest to accuse Weinstein of harassment
summary: Australian model Zoe Brock accuses Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein of harassment, claiming he stripped naked and demanded a massage in a hotel room meeting in 1997. Brock, 23 at the time, says she was "played" by Weinstein and his colleagues, who manipulated her into the situation. She is the latest in a string of women to accuse Weinstein of sexual harassment, assault, and rape. Weinstein has denied all allegations, but many in Hollywood, including actors Mark Ruffalo and Chris Hemsworth, have condemned his behavior, calling it "absolutely intolerable" and urging people to file criminal complaints.

site_title: US, South Korea conduct joint Navy drills to counter North Korea threat
summary: US and South Korea have begun a week-long joint Navy drill in the Korean peninsula waters to counter North Korea's nuclear and missile threat. About 40 Navy ships from both countries are participating in the exercises from October 16 to 20. North Korea has called the drills a "rehearsal for war" and US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said diplomatic efforts will continue until the first bomb drops. The drills follow a series of North Korean nuclear and missile tests, with tensions escalating amid reports of a potential long-range missile test targeting the US west coast.

site_title: Merkel in poll setback before tough coalition talks
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservative party, the CDU, lost a closely-watched state poll in Lower Saxony, weakening her hand in complex coalition talks. The Social Democrats (SPD) won 37.5% of the vote, while the Greens and Free Democrats (FDP) secured 8-8.5% and 7-7.5% respectively. Merkel must now forge an alliance with the Greens and FDP, a challenging task that could drag on into 2018. The outcome sets the stage for a "Jamaica" coalition, with little room for concessions on issues like asylum seekers and immigration.

site_title: France will expel illegal immigrants who commit crime: Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron announced that the country will expel illegal immigrants who commit crimes, regardless of their immigration status. This move comes after a Tunisian man, Ahmed Hanachi, was allowed to walk free despite having a history of petty crime and was later arrested for stabbing two women to death in Marseille. Macron also confirmed the stripping of the Legion d'Honneur from disgraced Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein. The president's comments come amid a series of reforms aimed at boosting France's economy and addressing social issues, including labor reforms and tax cuts for the wealthy.

site_title: China Fibretech: no Nominating Committee meeting convened
summary: China Fibretech, a Singapore-listed company, has clarified that no Nominating Committee meeting was convened to appoint new directors Choo Han Kiat and Leow Yong Kin. The appointments were made through a board resolution signed by CEO Wu Xinhua and Nominating Committee member Wu Dezhi, which was then circulated to Nominating Committee chairman Low Wai Cheong. The appointments were made after a thorough assessment of the candidates' suitability. The company attributed the lack of new directors to uncertainties surrounding the business.

site_title: Drone hit Canadian airliner: minister
summary: A Canadian passenger plane landed safely after being hit by a drone near Jean-Lesage International Airport in Quebec City, marking the first such incident in the country. The drone collided with a Skyjet plane at an altitude of 450m, causing minor damage. Transport Minister Marc Garneau expressed relief and reminded drone operators that reckless behavior can lead to fines or prison. There have been 131 drone incidents in Canada this year, and the International Air Transport Association reported 856 cases worldwide between 2013 and 2015.

site_title: Promises may backfire on new Jakarta governor
summary: Jakarta's newly elected governor, Anies Baswedan, is facing a rough start in office, with his promises to shield the poor from harsh evictions and provide easy housing loans appearing to backfire. He has delayed the zero deposit housing loans and clashed with the central government over a $40 billion land reclamation project. Analysts warn that his lack of government experience and party support will make it difficult for him to govern the city, which faces significant challenges including traffic congestion, air quality issues, and rising sea levels.

site_title: AEM raises FY17 profit estimates for nine-month, full-year
summary: AEM Holdings raised its profit guidance for the first nine months of 2017 and full year, citing higher sales and margins. The company now expects operating pre-tax profit of S$25.0-27.0 million for the nine months and at least S$32.0 million for the full year. The increase is attributed to strong customer demand, operational efficiency improvements, and better profit margins. AEM will release more financial details when it announces its Q3 2017 results.

site_title: Oil prices jump on fear of new US sanctions against Iran
summary: Oil prices jumped by 1.1% to $57.79 per barrel, driven by concerns over renewed US sanctions against Iran. US President Donald Trump refused to certify Iran's compliance with the 2015 nuclear deal, prompting a 60-day Congressional review of potential sanctions. This could lead to a significant disruption in global oil markets, similar to the 1 million barrels per day cut-off during the previous sanctions. Oil prices also rose due to a falling US rig count, with 5 new oil rigs being cut back in the week to Oct 13.

site_title: May heads for Brussels after Brexit talks deadlock
summary: Theresa May travels to Brussels for talks with EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker after Brexit talks deadlock, with EU officials expressing concern that the process may collapse. The talks aim to discuss a possible post-Brexit transition period, but progress is stalled due to disagreements over Britain's financial offer and other critical divorce issues. The EU has agreed to allow Barnier to explore the options for the transition period, but Germany and France have expressed resistance to further progress without meeting those tests. The talks are seen as crucial as the UK's withdrawal deadline looms in March 2019.

site_title: AI could add £630b to Britain's coffers by 2035
summary: A government-commissioned report suggests that the UK could add £630 billion to its economy by 2035 through the development and deployment of artificial intelligence. To reap the benefits, the UK must become a tech leader in AI research and development, encouraging businesses to adopt machine learning and AI. The report recommends increasing funding for AI education and creating a system to allow broader access to data, which is essential for driving AI adoption in industry.

site_title: Honouring the legacy of the Tolaram Group
summary: The Tolaram Group, a Singapore-based family business, has been awarded the EY-Standard Chartered Family Business Award of Excellence. Chairman Mohan Vaswani attributes the firm's success to the people who have helped it grow, emphasizing the importance of values, entrepreneurial spirit, and risk-taking. He highlights the group's commitment to giving back to the communities that have enabled its growth, with a focus on education, employment, and healthcare initiatives. The company plans to expand its operations in Africa, focusing on FMCG and digital services, while mentoring a new generation of leaders and incorporating new knowledge into its future endeavors.

site_title: China's Zhou warns corporate debt too high, urges fiscal reform
summary: China's People's Bank of China Governor Zhou Xiaochuan warned that corporate debt is too high, urging fiscal reform to constrain local government borrowing. The corporate debt level is estimated at 120-130% of GDP, and the government debt is about 70% instead of 36%. Zhou emphasized the need for financial stability and fiscal discipline, citing opaque systems and price distortions in local government borrowing. He also highlighted concerns about shadow banking and internet firms without financial licenses, calling for better regulation. The central government will "gradually" tackle these problems, with the goal of fiscal reform.

site_title: Buybacks decline on the week; Wee Ee Chao raises UOB-Kay Hian stake
summary: Share buybacks declined on the week, with seven stocks conducting buybacks totaling S$5.13 million, below the S$10.3 million in the previous five sessions. Notable transactions include UOB-Kay Hian chairman Wee Ee Chao buying 400,000 shares at S$1.34 per share, increasing his stake to 26.42%, and Federal International executive chairman Koh Kian Kiong purchasing 820,000 shares at S$0.40 per share, raising his stake to 18.98%. Other notable transactions involve Imperium Crown executive director Yong Chor Ken selling 7.7 million shares and Accrelist executive chairman Terence Tea Yeok Kian buying 8.3 million shares.

site_title: Adapting to survive and thrive
summary: Asia's first generation of high net worth individuals, driven by entrepreneurial spirit, face challenges in making informed investment decisions due to biases and information overload. These biases, such as home bias and behavioral bias, can lead to suboptimal decisions, while the sheer volume of information available hinders time for analysis. An adaptive investment process, leveraging diverse insights and unbiased collective decision-making, is necessary to thrive in today's markets, where markets evolve and adapt over time like natural ecosystems.

site_title: Dollar regains ground on muted inflation data
summary: The dollar regained ground after muted inflation data, with the Consumer Price Index rising 0.5% in September, its largest increase in eight months. The dollar index rose 0.02% to 93.072, despite a weak week, as traders adjusted to the Fed's expected rate hike later this year. US President Donald Trump's decision not to certify the Iran nuclear agreement increased global risk aversion, contributing to the dollar's rise. The euro was down 0.07 to US$1.1821, while the yen slipped 0.37% against the dollar.

site_title: Rubies, the buried and untapped treasures of Pakistani Kashmir
summary: Pakistani Kashmir is home to an estimated half-billion-dollar worth of rubies, but the lack of investment in infrastructure, techniques, and regulations hinders the development of the gem industry. Only one mine and one exploration site exist, and miners face back-breaking work with limited rewards. Experts believe tapping into the gem reserve could transform the region, but lack of funds, rugged terrain, and regulatory issues discourage private firms and international mining companies from investing. The region's rubies are of irregular quality, and the industry is still in its infancy due to transportation restrictions and informal sales.

site_title: Amazon muscling into sportswear with its own labels
summary: Amazon is expanding its private-label sportswear with new suppliers, including Taiwanese vendor Makalot Industrial and Eclat Textile, which produces for Nike, Lululemon, and Under Armour. This move is expected to bring fresh competition to the already-struggling athletic industry, following declining sales forecasts from major brands such as Nike and Under Armour. Amazon has been hiring staff with expertise in private-label athletic apparel and has developed its own brands to fill gaps in inventory, signaling a shift in demand from consumers towards online sales.

site_title: The rise and rise of chatbots
summary: Chatbots are increasingly being adopted by businesses worldwide, with 57% of firms globally using or planning to introduce chatbots this year. However, most chatbots fail due to unclear purposes and poor planning. To avoid this, companies should establish clear business goals and key performance indicators before launching a chatbot. Successful chatbot implementations have been seen in various industries, including banking, insurance, and retail, with benefits such as increased productivity, cost savings, and revenue generation. As chatbots become more sophisticated with AI, they will be able to converse with users verbally, enabling more personal and tailored responses.

site_title: Indonesia set for trillion-dollar economy in bittersweet triumph
summary: Indonesia is poised to become a trillion-dollar economy, with its economy growing to US$932 billion over the past decade, but faces challenges in sustaining growth. Despite President Joko Widodo's government forecasting a 5% growth rate this year, the country lags behind its neighbors in infrastructure development and faces a fiscal shortfall, with 28 million people living in poverty. The government aims to boost tax revenue to 16% by 2019, but faces pressure from a massive infrastructure deficit estimated at US$1.5 trillion.

site_title: Nim Gardens, Ridgewood owners form collective sales committees
summary: In Singapore, property owners are forming collective sales committees (CSCs) for several sites, including Nim Gardens in Seletar Hills and Ridgewood Condominium in District 10. Dover Parkview owners are also planning to form a CSC. However, Nim Gardens' attempt may face challenges due to its age and height restrictions. Ridgewood's previous attempts were unsuccessful, but owners are seeking a reserve price of S$1.65 billion for the site. The formation of CSCs is driven by the en bloc fever, but owners must be pragmatic about pricing to attract developers.

site_title: US softens stance on EU plans to tax Silicon Valley giants
summary: The US is softening its stance on European plans to tax Silicon Valley giants like Apple and Google, officials from Washington said. This shift marks a change from previous frustration over European efforts to collect taxes from US tech firms. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire and OECD Director Pascal Saint-Amans expressed optimism for an international solution, with the OECD set to present a report to G20 finance ministers in April. The US is now open to discussing and potentially harmonizing tax proposals to reduce harm to companies' financial positions.

site_title: Accelerating entrepreneurship in the age of disruption
summary: Singapore's entrepreneurial spirit remains strong, with the country's middle market companies planning to grow their revenues by 26% this year, according to a recent EY Growth Barometer survey. This is driven by careful cost control, entrepreneurial innovation, and early adoption of new technology. The survey highlights the importance of a mindset shift, with entrepreneurs and companies needing to constantly challenge the status quo and be adaptable to disruption. The EY Entrepreneur Of The Year awards programme aims to foster collaboration and innovation, with initiatives such as the World Entrepreneur Of The Year award and the EY Accelerating Entrepreneur Asia-Pacific programme.

site_title: Fed's Yellen says watching inflation closely but US economy is strong
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the economy remains strong, despite subdued inflation, and that interest rates may continue to rise gradually to sustain a healthy labor market. Yellen acknowledged rising uncertainty on the path of inflation but expects soft readings to not persist. The Fed has raised interest rates four times since 2015 and predicts one more rate rise this year, with investors expecting a rate hike in December. Yellen expressed confidence in the economy's ability to exceed its long-term trend in the second half of the year.

site_title: Ivanka Trump touts launch of World Bank businesswomen's fund
summary: Ivanka Trump, a senior adviser to US President Donald Trump, has touted the launch of the Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative (We-Fi), a World Bank program to boost access to capital for women-owned businesses in developing countries. The initiative aims to address a $300 billion annual credit deficit faced by women-owned businesses. The US has pledged $50 million to the fund, with other countries committing $350 million. The initiative is supported by countries such as Germany, Russia, and China, and aims to create economic value, peace, and prosperity in regions.

site_title: Kitchen skills for inmates and meals for the needy - the Samsui way
summary: Singapore Changi Prison Complex has established a 408 sq m central kitchen, allowing inmates to learn kitchen skills and enhance employability after release. Samsui Supplies and Services, in partnership with the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises, has trained 30 inmates in food-hygiene practices and food preparation. The initiative aims to equip inmates with skills, provide employment opportunities, and support societal reintegration. Samsui plans to expand the facilities to benefit more non-profit organizations and inmates, with a goal of preparing up to 6,000 meals daily and delivering 1.8 million meals annually.

site_title: Qatar National Bank aims to refinance US$3b loan by year-end
summary: Qatar National Bank (QNB) is seeking to refinance a US$3 billion loan by year-end, aiming to avoid diplomatic fallout with Gulf neighbors who cut ties with Qatar in June. Foreign banks are hesitant to participate due to concerns of disrupting relationships with clients in Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Bahrain. Several international banks, including Barclays, HSBC, and Deutsche Bank, participated in the original loan but are unlikely to participate in the refinancing. QNB is discussing options with banks to gauge interest and prepare contingency plans.

site_title: Central bankers bet weak inflation won't last forever
summary: European Central Bank officials, including Vice-President Vitor Constancio, expect a pickup in inflation despite weak wages during the current economic recovery. The ECB's medium-term inflation target is expected to return as Eurozone economies reach growth potential, but this is conditional on continued monetary accommodation. Meanwhile, Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expects inflation to return due to modest wage increases and weak inflation relative to the economy's momentum. US Fed Chair Janet Yellen notes that low inflation may be transitory, but also acknowledges that some analysts believe something more structural is at play.

site_title: Gold in early stages of secular bull cycle
summary: Gold is in the early stages of a secular bull cycle, forming higher highs and higher lows since the start of 2017. The metal broke above the $1,300 psychological resistance area in August and corrected, but recent price action suggests a reversal higher. A hammer pattern and bullish follow-through indicate a potential reversal to the upside. Gold is expected to retest the $1,352 and $1,375 resistance areas, while silver aims for the $18.10 and $18.50 resistance areas. However, a structural shift in the uptrend could occur if price breaks below $1,200.

site_title: Plenty of catalysts that could fuel STI's climb
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 16 points on Friday to reach 3,319.11, surpassing a technical resistance level of 3,300 points. The climb is attributed to factors such as higher interest rates, upbeat GDP readings, and the Monetary Authority of Singapore's policy decision. With several catalysts expected in the week ahead, including earnings season and economic data, the STI may continue its upward momentum, with key events including US Fed chair Janet Yellen's appearances and China's 19th National Party Congress.

site_title: St Helena's isolation ends as air link finally opens
summary: St Helena, a British island in the South Atlantic, has finally opened to the world after centuries of isolation with the launch of its first regular commercial flight. The Embraer 190 jet landed on Saturday, marking the end of a five-year construction project and £285 million investment. The airport, built on a mountain peak, allows for air travel from South Africa in just six hours, connecting the island to the world. The move is expected to bring in tourists and improve the standard of living for its 4,000 residents, known as "Saints".

site_title: Saudi Aramco denies shelving international IPO
summary: Saudi Aramco denies shelving its plans for an international initial public offering (IPO), stating the IPO process remains on track for 2018. The company previously considered a private stake sale to foreign governments, but dismissed reports as "entirely speculative." Despite struggling to select an international venue for its listing, Aramco is reviewing all listing options to make the optimal decision. The IPO is a key part of Saudi Arabia's reform program to diversify its economy and reduce its reliance on oil prices.

site_title: Ascenz's services helping shipping sector power ahead
summary: Ascenz, a Singapore-based company, has been recognized as EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Maritime Technology Solutions. The company's CEO, Chia Yoong Hui, pioneered the application of analytics to the maritime industry, helping vessels optimize performance and reduce fuel consumption. With over 400 vessels installed with its solutions, Ascenz is a leading Asian player in ship data acquisition and analytics. The company aims to expand its market, particularly in the European market, and continue research and development in artificial intelligence and machine learning to enhance customer capabilities.

site_title: Rallying behind a common goal paying off for PBA
summary: PBA International Pte Ltd, a diversified engineering company, has won the EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Diversified Engineering award. CEO Derrick Yap attributes the team's success to rallying behind a common goal and creating a culture that fosters growth and learning. PBA believes in empowering its staff, celebrating failure, and encouraging diversity of opinions. The company has a strong track record of innovation and has established an incubator and accelerator program to support entrepreneurs. PBA plans to expand globally and fuel its growth momentum through mergers and acquisitions and reinvestments.

site_title: Now is the time for fiscal and structural reforms, says IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged fiscal and structural reforms to solidify the global economic recovery, which is expected to continue despite subdued inflation and low potential growth. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde said structural reforms are easier to implement when the outlook is stronger, warning policymakers against complacency. The IMF also expressed concerns about uneven recovery and the need to address the impact of prolonged low interest rates on asset prices and economic activity.

site_title: StanChart takes seniors shopping at Courts
summary: Standard Chartered organized a Deepavali shopping trip for 40 seniors from Thye Hua Kwan Bedok Radiance Senior Activity Centre, taking them to Courts Toa Payoh to shop for household items on their wish list. The event was accompanied by volunteers from the bank and the South East Community Development Council. This initiative aims to promote financial inclusion and support the elderly community.

site_title: Gold at 2-1/2-week high on US data, Trump warning on Iran deal
summary: US President Donald Trump's warning on the Iran nuclear deal led to a surge in gold prices, reaching a 2-1/2-week high. The move undermined the case for interest rate rises and weak US inflation data. Gold rose 0.8% to $1,303.5 an ounce, with spot gold up for a sixth straight session. A more confrontational stance on Iran could increase demand for gold as a safe haven, fueling further price gains.

site_title: Sun-powered 5-seater car wows crowd at solar challenge
summary: The Nuon Solar Team's "Nuna 9" car, a Dutch family car, won the World Solar Challenge for the third consecutive time, crossing the finish line at an average speed of 81.2 km/h. The car, which supplies energy back to the grid, was hailed as a demonstration of the future of solar electric vehicles. Team Eindhoven's "Stella Vie" was crowned overall champion based on design, practicality, energy efficiency, and innovation, showcasing a practical and energy-efficient solar car capable of generating more power than it consumes.

images.alt_text: Members of Solar Team Eindhoven from the Netherlands at the finish line in Adelaide. Their family car Stella Vie carried five people at an average speed of 69 km per hour.

site_title: Typhoon Khanun to hit southern China on Monday as Hong Kong eases warning
summary: Typhoon Khanun is expected to hit southern China on Monday with winds of up to 114km per hour, according to China's meteorological agency. Hong Kong has eased weather warnings and transport is slowly returning to normal. Heavy rain is forecast in parts of Guangdong, Guangxi, and Hainan provinces, with some areas expected to receive up to 200 millimeters of precipitation. Hong Kong's weather observatory has lowered its warning to the second lowest level, and ferry services have resumed to nearby islands.

site_title: Oscars academy kicks out disgraced producer Weinstein
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences voted to expel Harvey Weinstein, citing "shameful complicity in sexually predatory behaviour" and sending a message that the era of "wilful ignorance" in the industry is over. The decision comes after multiple women accused Weinstein of sexual harassment, assault, and rape, including actress Rose McGowan, who accused him of raping her. Weinstein's expulsion marks the first time the academy has removed a member, with over 2 dozen actresses accusing him of harassment.

site_title: Digital innovation is not about chasing tech, but the customer
summary: Digital innovation is about understanding the customer and adapting to their needs, rather than just chasing technology. Industry leaders, including StarHub's CEO Tan Tong Hai and KPMG's Ong Pang Thye, emphasize the importance of considering a mix of digital and traditional means for customer engagement. Advances in technology can disrupt strategies, but they also present opportunities for innovation. Companies must adopt a collaborative approach, leveraging startups and innovators to develop purposeful technology enablers and new solutions. A customer-centric mindset, talent, and culture change are also crucial for the success of a digital strategy.

site_title: US moves closer to EU position on taxing tech giants
summary: The US is softening its stance on taxing tech giants like Apple and Google, following recent meetings with European officials. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire stated that the US is open to considering the matter and is willing to engage in discussions. The European Commission plans to present proposals for taxing tech giants next year, and France is threatening to impose punitive corporate revenue taxes. The OECD is seeking a long-term solution and aims to harmonize governments' tax proposals to minimize harm to companies. The US has agreed to create a working group with France to review proposals.

site_title: Hillary Clinton warns Britain on potential trade deal with Trump
summary: Former US presidential candidate Hillary Clinton warned Britain about its potential trade deal with President Donald Trump after Brexit, citing concerns over a lack of trust in trade. Clinton stated that Britain would face significant disruption if it leaves the EU without a negotiated deal with Brussels. She also compared the Brexit vote to her own election loss, highlighting the spread of false information and its impact on voters. Clinton expressed concerns that Britain would be at a "very big disadvantage" if divorce negotiations with the EU failed.

site_title: A saucy tale
summary: The origin and variation of ketchup across borders have puzzled many, with its sweet and tangy flavors differing in Singapore, Canada, and the US. Research reveals that ketchup originated from China's Fujian province as a preserved fish sauce, then traveled to South-east Asia and eventually reached Western palates in the 1600s. The modern tomato-based ketchup emerged in the early 19th century with the influence of Maria Rundell's 1806 cookbook. The saucy evolution of ketchup also led to the introduction of sodium benzoate as a preservative, which was later replaced by vinegar, resulting in the sweeter ketchup found in Asia and the tangier ketchup in North America, with different brands adapting to local tastes and preferences.

site_title: China Sept new yuan loans rise more than expected
summary: China's banks extended more yuan loans than expected in September, with 1.27 trillion yuan in new loans, exceeding analysts' predictions. Household loans rose to 734.9 billion yuan, accounting for 58% of total new loans, while corporate loans were 463.5 billion yuan. The M2 money supply grew 9.2% from a year earlier, beating forecasts. However, regulators' efforts to reduce debt risks and slow economic growth have been mixed, with credit growth remaining elevated and companies showing little sign of reducing debt burdens.

site_title: Qualcomm seeks China iPhone ban, expanding Apple legal fight
summary: Qualcomm has filed lawsuits in China seeking to ban the sale and manufacture of iPhones, targeting Apple's largest market and major revenue source. The chipmaker claims patent infringement and seeks injunctive relief, citing power management and touch-screen technologies used in current iPhones. Apple denies the claims, stating the patents have never been discussed in negotiations. The move is seen as a step to get Apple back to the negotiating table, but may face resistance from Chinese regulators and suppliers.

site_title: Business strategy for the digital age
summary: Business leaders can consider the following questions: Companies in Singapore are experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Grab has been downgraded to 'hold' by CGSI, and Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index. Additionally, Helen Wong will retire as OCBC CEO, and Tan Teck Long has been named her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay has increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Being unafraid to take risks counts at JK Tech
summary: JK Tech Group, a Singapore-based company, promotes a culture of taking risks and embracing failure, citing that "for every successful entrepreneur, there will be nine failed ones." The company's chairman, Lennon Tan, emphasizes the importance of mentorship and start-up platforms in fostering entrepreneurship. JK Tech Group has grown from a pure manufacturing base to a technology-based company, providing automation and software solutions, and is expanding into regional markets through joint ventures and mergers and acquisitions. The company aims to convert its manufacturing-based customers to automation- and solution-based businesses and transform towards Big Data analytics and fintech solutions.

site_title: SIA raises S$2.55m for Community Chest
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) raised S$2.55 million for the Community Chest through three fundraising events as part of its 70th anniversary celebrations. The cheque was presented to Community Chest chairman Phillip Tan and adviser Jennie Chua. The amount will support beneficiaries from about 80 social service organisations under Community Chest.

site_title: US: Wall St ends up after economic data; S&P up for a 5th week
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, ending a fifth straight week of gains, driven by upbeat economic data and gains in technology shares. Retail sales jumped in September, and the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index reached its highest since 2004. Netflix shares surged 1.9% after hitting an intraday record high, while Apple gave the S&P 500 its biggest boost. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.13%, and the S&P 500 gained 0.09%. The Nasdaq Composite reached a record closing high, marking a third week of gains.

site_title: DPM Tharman on two-day visit to Moscow
summary: Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore Tharman Shanmugaratnam is on a two-day visit to Moscow, where he co-chairs the Eighth Session of the High-Level Russia-Singapore Inter-Governmental Commission. He will also attend the Open Innovations Forum 2017 and the Russia-Singapore Business Forum. The visit aims to strengthen trade and investment relations between the two countries.

site_title: Decade after bubble burst, Ireland faces new housing crisis
summary: Ireland faces a new housing crisis 10 years after its property bubble burst, with sales prices up 47% since 2013 and rents increasing by double-digits each year. A supply shortage, particularly in urban areas, drives the issue, with a national average rent of €1,159 per month. Experts predict prices will continue to rise for another two years, but do not expect a new housing bubble. The government has increased its housing ministry budget and promised new developments, but critics argue that the private sector is over-reliant and that affordable solutions are lacking, contributing to a record 23% increase in homelessness.

site_title: Catalan leader calls for calm ahead of Madrid deadline
summary: Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont called for calm ahead of a Madrid deadline for him to clarify whether he has declared independence for Catalonia. He suspended a symbolic declaration of independence on Tuesday and is set to respond to Spain's Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy's ultimatum by Monday. The Spanish government will take control of Catalonia if Puigdemont gives an ambiguous reply, threatening to suspend autonomy if he chooses independence. The Catalan government claims 90% of Catalans voted for independence in a disputed referendum.

site_title: When corporates meet startups and mash-ups
summary: Corporations are increasingly partnering with startups to drive innovation, with 68% of the top 100 companies from the Forbes Global 500 engaging with startups. This trend is driven by startups' agility, ingenuity, and vision, as well as the need for corporations to address gaps in industry expertise, scale, and financial strength. Informal engagement models, such as hackathons and accelerators, are emerging, alongside industrial mash-ups that combine specialized services and capital assets via APIs. Successful partnerships require clear goals, shared project objectives, and executive sponsorship, and are characterized by a flexible and open-minded approach to innovation.

site_title: Regulatory compliance, costs could turn firms away from SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) faces challenges in attracting new listings and boosting trading, with regulatory compliance and high costs cited as deterrents. Alternative platforms like crowdfunding are gaining popularity, offering lower costs and less regulatory hurdles. The SGX's high upfront costs, including initial listing fees and audit fees, make it uncompetitive compared to other exchanges. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is reviewing the Code of Corporate Governance to make it more effective, but some experts argue that reduced compliance costs could harm investors. The SGX needs to find ways to lower costs and make itself more attractive to companies and investors.

images.alt_text: SGX now has to compete with new fundraising avenues on top of the usual global exchanges, which raises questions on how it can reinvent itself to attract new listings and boost trading.

site_title: WWE signs first female wrestler from Arab world in global push
summary: WWE signed Jordanian wrestler Shadia Bseiso, the first female performer from the Arab world, in a global push to tap into lucrative foreign markets. Bseiso, a jiu-jitsu expert, aims to encourage more Arab women to take up sports and break cultural taboos. The signing marks WWE's expansion into new demographics, following recent signings from India and China. Bseiso will undergo training and "character development" in Orlando, with a Jordan-themed persona in mind, and hopes to inspire fans in the region.

site_title: Core leader Xi Jinping set to tighten his grip on power
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is poised to tighten his grip on power as he seeks to become the most dominant leader since Mao Zedong. Xi, who has been in power since 2012, has managed to overrule party tradition and grant himself the title of "core leader." He hopes to have his "thoughts" enshrined in the constitution, cementing his legacy. The 19th Party Congress, which began on Monday, is expected to see appointments of party members in key posts, many of which are expected to be given to Xi's allies.

site_title: 12 things to watch out for at China's 19th party congress
summary: China's 19th Communist Party Congress opened on October 15, 2017, where President Xi Jinping will outline his ambitions for the next five years and beyond. Xi's goal is to become party chairman, potentially concentrating power in his hands. The Standing Committee's significance would diminish, and a more powerful National Security Commission could tackle domestic and foreign threats. Xi's rise to power was confirmed at the 2007 Congress, and his succession will be crucial, with speculation about his potential long-term stay in power after 2022.

site_title: PSA says to cut about 400 jobs at Vauxhall's Ellesmere Port
summary: PSA Group announced plans to cut approximately 400 jobs at Vauxhall's Ellesmere Port facility in Britain by the end of the year. The job losses, equivalent to about a quarter of the facility's staff, will be implemented through a voluntary redundancy plan. The move aims to improve the facility's competitiveness in the face of challenging European market conditions and declining passenger car demand. This decision comes as PSA Group seeks to address manufacturing costs and protect its future in the UK, with plans to consider future investments once Britain's trading relationship with the EU becomes clearer.

site_title: Pentagon identifying new areas to pressure Iran, reviewing plans
summary: The US military is identifying new areas to pressure Iran in support of President Donald Trump's new strategy, which aims to put pressure on the Iranian regime and neutralize its destabilizing influences. The Pentagon is assessing the positioning of its forces and planning to work with allies to constrain Iran's aggressive power projection, particularly its support for terrorist groups. US Defense Secretary Jim Mattis plans to talk with US allies to gain a shared understanding of Iran's actions, and the US military is reviewing plans to increase pressure on Iran, including more aggressive interceptions of Iranian arms shipments and naval forces reacting more forcefully to IRGC speed boats.

site_title: Saudi Aramco in stake sale talks with Chinese investor: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco is considering a stake sale to a Chinese investor as part of its plans for a highly-anticipated international public offering, which is expected to be the world's largest stock sale. The move aims to provide cash for Saudi Arabia's economic reform program, which includes austerity measures to tackle huge budget deficits caused by lower oil prices. The IPO process remains on track, with a decision on which exchange to list on still pending, despite concerns about the impact of the measures on the economy.

site_title: Amazon said to make sportswear push in industry-jolting move
summary: Amazon is reportedly partnering with major athletic-apparel suppliers, including Taiwanese vendors Makalot Industrial Co and Eclat Textile Co, to produce private-label sportswear. The move is part of a long-term effort and involves trial production of small quantities of products. The goal is to shake up the already tumultuous sportswear industry.

site_title: Citi reinvents itself to stay agile and ahead
summary: Citi is transforming its operating model to stay relevant in a rapidly digitizing world by becoming more mobile and digitally focused. The bank is simplifying its processes, automating tasks, and adopting an agile approach to innovation, allowing for faster development and deployment of new products and services. This includes the use of robotics, automation of electronic funds transfer requests, and a simple three-click experience for customers. Citi has also established a global API developer portal to form strategic partnerships and co-create with leading players in digital ecosystems, enabling the rapid deployment of services and capabilities.

site_title: Nanofilm boss has his eye on the horizon
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International CEO Shi Xu has been named EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Advanced Manufacturing. The company, which specializes in filtered cathodic vacuum arc (FCVA) technology, has grown into a multinational technology and manufacturing group with over 1,400 employees. FCVA technology enables the modification of surface properties of materials to perform special functions, and Nanofilm has developed strong capabilities in production, quality assurance, engineering, and research and development. The company aims to continue its growth, expanding into new sectors such as automotive, renewable energy, and medical devices, and becoming a "smart factory and corporation".

site_title: Egypt to renew US$2b financing deal
summary: Egypt plans to renew a $2 billion financing deal with international banks, with the IMF expected to provide another $4 billion in two tranches before the fiscal year ends in June. The government aims to finance the deficit by selling dollar-denominated bonds and euro-denominated debt, and diversifying its sources of financing. Egypt's reform programme has come at a cost, with annual core inflation remaining over 30% and a significant portion of the population living in poverty. The government expects a narrowing of the deficit to 9.5% of GDP during the current fiscal year.

site_title: Weak growth, trade holding back global capital spending
summary: Global foreign direct investment (FDI) flows decreased 2% in 2016 to $1.75 trillion, with weak economic growth and trade trimming capital spending. Developing economies saw a 10% jump in FDI inflows this year, while flows to developed economies remain steady. Singapore's FDI inflows fell 13% to $61.59 billion, and direct investments flowing out of the country also declined. The US remains the top FDI recipient, followed by the UK and China.

site_title: Japan zoo mourns death of love-struck penguin
summary: A 21-year-old Humboldt penguin named Grape, who gained international fame for being smitten with a cardboard cut-out of a cartoon character, has died at the Tokyo's Tobu zoo. Grape had been separated from his former mate Midori and found comfort in the cut-out of Hululu, a character from the Japanese anime "Kemono Friends." Officials said Grape had a brief illness, and the penguin was surrounded by the cut-out until his death. Tributes poured in on social media, with fans calling him a "sweet prince" and praising his ability to bring joy to the world.

site_title: US stance on auto industry sows more doubt about Nafta overhaul
summary: The US has proposed that US-made content account for half the value of cars and trucks sold under the North American Free Trade Agreement, raising doubts about a potential deal. This proposal, aligned with President Trump's goal of reducing the US trade deficit with Mexico and stemming US manufacturing job losses, was met with Mexican sources denouncing it as "absurd" and unacceptable. The proposal is part of the fourth round of negotiations to overhaul the treaty, with a year-end deadline for a deal.

site_title: Federer defeats Nadal to clinch Shanghai Masters
summary: Roger Federer defeated Rafael Nadal 6-4, 6-3 to win the Shanghai Masters, his 94th title and fifth consecutive victory over his rival. Federer, 36, played one-sided tennis, breaking Nadal in the first game and again in the fifth set. The win drew Federer level with Ivan Lendl for 94th career title and narrowed the gap at the top of the world rankings. Federer attributed his success to improved form throughout the week and managing his schedule to conserve his aging body.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Global Yellow Pages (GYP) has entered into a variation agreement to reduce the acquisition price for a plot of land in New Zealand. The original price of NZ$38 million has been lowered to NZ$36 million.

site_title: Europe: European shares climb to four-month high, boosted by Bayer
summary: European shares rose to a four-month high on Friday, driven by gains in Bayer after the German drugmaker sold assets that will aid its acquisition of Monsanto. The Stoxx 600 index climbed 0.4%, marking its fifth straight week of gains, as steel-exposed materials stocks also rose.

site_title: Train fault mars open house at Downtown Line 3
summary: A train fault at Hillview station on Singapore's Downtown Line 2 caused a nearly hour-long delay on Sunday, disrupting the Downtown Line 3 (DTL3) open house event. The train fault led to some trains on the DTL3 being affected, resulting in free bus rides being offered at designated stops. Normal service resumed at 1:20 pm, with SBS Transit apologizing for the inconvenience caused and assuring commuters that services on the DTL3 were running as usual.

images.alt_text: The crowd at Ubi station along the DTL3 on Sunday. A defective train at Hillview station on DTL 2 resulted in some trains on the DTL3 being affected.

site_title: Trump administration rejects World Bank capital increase
summary: The Trump administration rejected a World Bank capital increase, citing inefficiency and the ability to build its capital base through greater internal efficiency. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the bank can allocate its nearly $60 billion in development finance more effectively without additional contributions from its 189 shareholder nations. The move is seen as a blow to the World Bank's global anti-poverty mission, which relies on increased capital to expand lending.

site_title: Tea time treat
summary: The Fullerton Bay Hotel partners with Net-a-porter and Dr. Barbara Sturm to offer a unique Afternoon Tea experience, featuring a Dr. Barbara Sturm skincare gift set worth $188. The set is available for $48 per person from October 1-31, 2017. The collaboration aims to promote the brand's natural ingredients and minimalist skincare approach, maximizing results with minimal products.

site_title: Cathay Pacific up 6.2% as it seeks to cut costs
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd shares rose 6.2% this week, the best performance on Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, after Goldman Sachs added the airline to its conviction list, citing improving demand and supply. The airline is seeking to cut costs, including pilot compensation, amid its worst loss in over 20 years. Goldman analysts believe investors are underestimating Cathay Pacific's potential to boost earnings.

site_title: New procurement guide to help SMEs bid for government contracts, gather feedback
summary: A new government procurement guide has been launched in Singapore to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) bid for government contracts. The guide, "Government Procurement: A Best Practices Guide," provides suggestions on the procedure before bidding, such as attending fairs and clinics, and was developed with inputs from the business community and government ministries. The launch was held at the SME Convention 2017 organized by the Singapore Business Federation. The guide aims to help SMEs navigate the procurement process and gather feedback.

site_title: Tesla fired hundreds of employees in past week: newspaper
summary: Tesla fired between 400 and 700 employees, including engineers, managers, and factory workers, as part of a company-wide annual review. The dismissals were reportedly due to production bottlenecks, which left the company behind its planned ramp-up for the new Model 3 mass-market sedan. Tesla did not confirm the exact number of employees leaving the company.

site_title: Etihad flight from Abu Dhabi makes emergency landing in Australia
summary: An Etihad Airways flight from Abu Dhabi to Sydney made an emergency landing at Adelaide Airport in South Australia on October 14, 2017. A warning indicator activated in the cockpit, prompting the crew to land the Boeing 777 passenger jet at 5am local time. All 349 passengers disembarked via emergency exits. The cause of the incident is not specified.

site_title: Empowering employees
summary: Companies in Singapore offer various flexible work options to empower employees, including flexible work hours, part-time schedules, telecommuting, and job sharing. These initiatives promote work-life balance, increase productivity, and attract and retain talent. Many organizations, such as Accenture, Thales, and PwC, have seen positive staff morale and engagement, while others, like Royal Plaza on Scotts, have successfully integrated flexible work arrangements into their operations. Experts emphasize the importance of understanding individual needs, offering flexible hours tailored to job scopes, and ensuring effective communication between managers and employees.

images.alt_text: Teo Lay Lim, Senior Managing Director, ASEAN, and Country Managing Director, Singapore, Accenture
Kevin Chow, Chief Executive Officer, Thales in Singapore
Yeoh Oon Jin, Executive Chairman, PwC Singapore

site_title: Wordless magic
summary: Ramesh Meyyappan, a deaf actor from Glasgow, performs in the one-man show "Off Kilter" at TheatreWorks in Singapore. The play revolves around a character's obsession with order and routine, which is disrupted when chaos enters his life. Meyyappan, known for his wordless magic, will discuss his craft after the show. "Off Kilter" plays on October 14 at 3pm and 8pm.

site_title: 32 dead, hundreds missing as California wildfires rage
summary: Wildfires in California's wine country have claimed 32 lives, with hundreds still missing. Firefighters made progress against the devastating fires, but authorities are bracing for another wave of hot, dry winds that could fan the flames. The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection is preparing for the strong winds, which could lead to further evacuations and increased risk to life.

site_title: London's housing outlook remains pessmistic as spooked buyers stay away
summary: London's housing market remains pessimistic, with real estate agents reporting their lowest levels of optimism since 2010. The prospect of the Bank of England raising interest rates has added to buyer caution, causing prices to fall and new inquiries to drop to their lowest level since the Brexit vote. National prices grew marginally, but regional differences show a stark divergence, with London being the only area with a negative outlook on a 12-month basis.

site_title: Home shopping network
summary: A new wave of independent retailers is shifting towards experiential shopping by creating intimate, home-style environments, bridging the gap between online shopping and malls. Retailers such as Le Salon, Paqarina Jewellery, and Bernard Godfrey Guitars are tapping into millennials' pursuit of emotional connections, offering personalized experiences and storytelling through their physical spaces. This trend allows retailers to connect with customers, share brand stories, and provide a more relaxed shopping experience, often at a lower cost than traditional mall spaces.

site_title: Electric dream come true
summary: BMW introduces its iPerformance range of plug-in hybrids, expanding its electrification efforts. The German luxury manufacturer, ahead of a charging infrastructure, introduced its i3 electric car and i8 plug-in hybrid in 2014. The new lineup includes an upgraded i3 with a new battery pack, and six additional plug-in models. This move solidifies BMW's commitment to electrification, following its earlier introduction of the i3 and i8.

site_title: Picasso's mansion fails to find new buyer
summary: A New Zealand financier, Rayo Withanage, has two months to purchase Pablo Picasso's mansion in Mougins, France, for 20.1 million euros. Withanage was the highest bidder at an auction in June, but no new bidders emerged, leaving the property in limbo. The estate, where Picasso spent his twilight years, has been on the market since then. Withanage has 60 days to secure the sale, or the property may be put up for auction again.

site_title: Telling Tales
summary: Chinese street storytellers, often illiterate men from the working class, shared myths and classic literature in dialects like Hokkien and Teochew, attracting large male audiences in locations like Chinatown and Boat Quay. With the rise of radio broadcasting in the 1970s, storytelling declined after the Speak Mandarin Campaign in 1979, leading to the demise of radio storytelling in other dialects.

site_title: Larger than life
summary: Nineties rock band Mr. Big is continuing to tour despite drummer Pat Torpey's diagnosis with Parkinson's Disease. The current lineup, similar to the original formed in 1988, features Torpey, singer Eric Martin, guitarist Paul Gilbert, and bassist Billy Sheehan. Mr. Big will perform at the Kallang Theatre on October 15, playing tracks from their latest album Defying Gravity, as well as classics like "To Be With You."

site_title: Not just lip service
summary: Raffles City Singapore is hosting the Lipstick Art Campaign, where unwanted lipsticks will be collected and transformed into artworks by visually-impaired artists from Very Special Arts (VSA) Singapore. The campaign, led by Cultural Medallion recipient Chng Seok Tin, will run until October 31. Donated lipsticks can be dropped off at Raffles City Shopping Centre and participating buildings. The finished artworks will be exhibited at Raffles City Singapore in November, showcasing the creative potential of the collected lipsticks.

site_title: Why do my kids waste hours watching millennials play video games on YouTube?
summary: A father expresses frustration over his children's excessive watching of YouTube videos featuring millennials playing video games. He recalls his own past habit of watching others play video games and notes the lack of interactive elements in these videos. He believes that watching others play games is a sedentary activity that wastes time, unlike interactive games like Minecraft, which he has allowed his children to play. The father worries that this excessive screen time is detrimental to his children's cognitive and social development, and he is at odds with his children over their entertainment choices.

images.alt_text: A screenshot of the interactive game Minecraft.

site_title: Stop hitting the horn, the robot at the wheel can't hear or see you
summary: Self-driving cars, such as those tested in California, are frequently involved in low-speed fender benders with human drivers. The issue arises from a clash between human drivers treating traffic laws as guidelines and autonomous vehicles that refuse to roll through stop signs or exceed speed limits. This culture gap is evident in a recent incident in San Francisco, where a computer-controlled Chevrolet Bolt was rear-ended by a human driver. As companies like Cruise Automation and Waymo ramp up self-driving car testing, human drivers must adapt to the distinct driving styles of robots.

images.alt_text: A Chevrolet Bolt EV test pilot autonomous vehicle. Human drivers keep running into self-driving vehicles because robots don't drive like most motorists.

site_title: Go to sleep, Alexa; and it's not OK, Google
summary: A pre-market Google Home Mini device was found to be recording everything it heard, including TV programs, after being activated by a non-verbal signal. The device's owner discovered thousands of activity records and contacted Google, who quickly shut off the device and rolled out a software update. The incident highlights the potential risks of voice-controlled speakers, including hacking and impersonation. Experts warn that users may be trading privacy for convenience, and consumers must weigh the benefits against the risks. Google has assured users of its commitment to user privacy and product quality.

site_title: China Sept imports blow past forecasts, exports quicken too
summary: China's foreign trade grew at a faster pace in September than expected, with imports increasing 18.7% and exports rising 8.1%. This suggests the country's economy is still expanding at a healthy clip, despite forecasts of a slowdown. The solid September readings are welcome news for Beijing ahead of a major leadership reshuffle. China's trade surplus narrowed to $28.47 billion, and the country's foreign trade is likely to grow at a double-digit pace this year if current conditions continue.

site_title: Malaysia halts all imports from former friend North Korea
summary: Malaysia has halted all imports from North Korea, following global efforts to cut off funding for its nuclear and missile programs. The move comes after the assassination of Kim Jong Un's half brother at Kuala Lumpur international airport and Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak's meeting with US President Donald Trump at the White House. This decision was made ahead of UN and US sanctions that penalized companies and individuals doing business with North Korea. Other South-east Asian nations, such as the Philippines and Thailand, have also reduced imports from North Korea in compliance with sanctions.

site_title: Sweet treats
summary: Chef Manjunath Mural's one-Michelin-starred restaurant The Song Of India offers a special degustation menu for Deepavali, featuring handcrafted mithai and festive dishes. The menu includes signature flavors like Rose Gulkhand Roll and Manglorian Gassi, available from Oct 18 to 22 for S$79++. The mithai selection includes unique options such as gula melaka and feuillantine with melon seeds. This limited-time offer is a great reason to visit the restaurant.

site_title: Oei turns up heat at Raffles Education with ouster bid
summary: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong has made a bid to oust Raffles Education chairman and CEO Chew Hua Seng, who also holds a controlling stake in the company. At the annual general meeting, shareholders questioned Chew's dual roles, and Oei made a late call to replace him. The move comes amid concerns over grade inflation and the company's governance structure. Oei, a substantial shareholder, has sought details about recent share placements and the company's financial performance, sparking a potential power struggle within the board.

site_title: Banks continue to lead STI gains
summary: Banks continue to drive gains in the Straits Times Index, with a 16.02-point increase on Friday, bringing the weekly gain to 27.82 points. The move follows comments from several US Federal Open Market Committee members indicating the economy is strong enough to withstand a third rate hike this year, now expected in December. The probability of this event has increased to 77%. The index finished at 3,319.11, with turnover exceeding S$1.3 billion and a net advance-decline score of 271 to 183.

site_title: Ghostbusting in Taiwan
summary: A Singaporean, afraid of ghosts, stayed at the Grand Hyatt Taipei, one of the world's top 10 haunted hotels, despite initial reservations. The hotel's lobby, featuring a bubbling water fountain, was deemed a fengshui-compliant feature ensuring the hotel's success. The guest, who had been deterred by online rumors, found the hotel's hospitality to be welcoming and the food culture to be intriguing, including oyster mee sua. The experience proved that even the most skeptical individuals can face their fears and discover new experiences.

site_title: Model portfolio: what worked, what didn't and what next
summary: A model portfolio, launched in October 2016, has delivered 12.3% returns since its inception, trailing the simple benchmark's return of 13.5%. The portfolio's performance was driven by strong markets, particularly in Western developed markets and emerging Asia. However, some products underperformed, including a US equity fund and an emerging market bond fund. The portfolio will undergo changes, including switching from the underperforming US fund to a Legg Mason Clearbridge US Large Cap Growth Fund and from the United SGD Fund to the Amundi SGD Income Plus Fund.

site_title: Movie moguls and their formidable webs of protection
summary: Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein's alleged pattern of sexual misconduct has brought attention to the powerful networks of PR flacks and lawyers that protect the industry's darkest secrets. These networks, known as a "protection racket," use charm, smears, and legal action to silence reporters and victims, making it difficult to break a story. The Weinstein Co's significant advertising presence and Weinstein's influence over journalists have also contributed to the delay in exposing his misconduct. The New York Times' publication of the story, which included details of eight settlements, marked a turning point, but the industry's reliance on these tactics remains a formidable obstacle to truth-telling.

site_title: Shares of North American airlines enjoy good lift-off in September
summary: Global airline share prices increased 0.9% in September, the first month-on-month rise since June, driven by a recovery in North American airline shares. The North American index rose 3% in September, with a 25% year-over-year gain, but remains down 3.5% from the start of the year. In contrast, the European index edged down 0.6% and the Asia-Pacific index dropped 1.1%. This marks a positive trend for the airline industry after several months of decline.

site_title: Private equity firms target Australia with new funding tool
summary: Private equity firms in Australia are using unitranche loans, a financing structure that combines senior and subordinated debt, to fund acquisitions. At least four deals have used this structure, with non-bank lenders providing the funds. The trend is driven by low interest rates and global yields, prompting institutional investors to participate in loan deals. This marks a shift in Australia, which has traditionally relied on bank financing, and could introduce new risks for creditors. The unitranche structure is gaining popularity in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Eurozone's recovery accelerating, but earnings growth lags
summary: The Eurozone's economic recovery is accelerating, with the region's companies expected to beat earnings projections for the third quarter, despite a lower growth rate than predicted. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index is 22% above its 10-year average valuation, but analysts say this multiple is "reasonable" due to growing earnings. The International Monetary Fund has raised its forecasts for the euro area, predicting the strongest growth in seven years, and investors are cautiously optimistic about the region's prospects.

site_title: Welcome to the Nobel Prize abyss
summary: The Swedish Academy awarded Kazuo Ishiguro the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2017, sparking criticism for his bleak and humorless storytelling style. Critics argue that the award is a reflection of the Swedish Academy's preference for nihilistic and pretentious writing, dismissing Ishiguro's work as emotionally stunted and enigmatic. The author's writing style, which often focuses on themes of time, memory, and mortality, is seen as a departure from more lighthearted and comedic approaches to literature. Ishiguro's work is compared unfavorably to that of other Nobel laureates, with some arguing that the award is a missed opportunity to recognize a more dynamic and engaging writer, such as Philip Roth.

site_title: The joys of 6
summary: BMW's new 6 Series Gran Turismo, a liftback model replacing the discontinued 5 Series GT, boasts a more practical design and ample space. Weighing 1.8 tonnes, the 640i GT features a comfortable ride, refined engine, and advanced suspension systems. However, its handling can feel detached, and some may find the steering too light. The car's unique shape and size may raise eyebrows, but it offers a balance of sportiness and comfort, making it an appealing option for those seeking a versatile vehicle.

site_title: Sarah Liu
summary: Sarah Liu, founder of The Dream Collective, shares her experiences as a young Asian woman in the corporate world. Liu faced pay gaps and difficult bosses, sparking her to create a female corporate leadership training platform. Despite challenges, Liu notes that biases exist globally, with maternal bias and performance attribution biases affecting women's career trajectories. She advocates for women to take control of their careers, investing in themselves and building a personal brand. Liu believes global gender parity is achievable, citing progress in countries like Singapore, and encourages working with the 80-20 rule to create a new norm.

site_title: Nanofilm Tech's CEO Shi Xu named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2017
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International's CEO Shi Xu was named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2017 Singapore, as well as the EOY award under the Advanced Manufacturing category. He will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year 2018 in Monaco. Shi Xu founded Nanofilm in 1999 with a startup cash of S$300,000, transforming the company into a significant player in coating technology and advanced manufacturing with over 1,500 staff.

site_title: Youth golf gets timely S$240k boost
summary: Singapore's 2017 Community Youth Golf Charity at Sentosa Golf Club Community raised nearly S$240,000, a significant boost for youth golf. The funds will support the promotion of junior golf in the heartlands for over 150 teenagers. The charity, spearheaded by Janice Khoo, aims to help juniors without the means to own golf club membership, having already benefited close to 5,000 students. The event follows the Singapore Golf Association's efforts to expand the player base at the junior level and comes ahead of the Asian Development Tour.

site_title: Bears licking wounds after US$20 trillion global market rally
summary: Global equity markets are on track to reach all-time highs, with nearly 85% of benchmark indexes worldwide up this year, and emerging markets surging 31%. The value of global equities has increased by $20 trillion, comparable to the total value of all equities nine years ago. Despite concerns about stretched valuations and policy uncertainty, experts say the harmonized global economy recovery and strong earnings growth justify the rally, with US corporate earnings expected to rise 11% and European profits set to climb 14% this year.

site_title: Tat Hong positioning itself for future growth
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a Singapore-based crane and construction equipment operator, celebrated its 60th anniversary with a gala dinner at Marina Bay Sands. Founded by Ng Chwee Cheng in 1957, the company has grown to become the eighth largest crane and construction equipment operator in the world, with 5,000 employees across the Asia-Pacific and Australia. CEO Roland Ng announced the company's plans to participate in One Belt-One Road projects, which he believes will drive growth over the coming decades.

site_title: China ETF surges as drive for clean air boosts commodities
summary: China's anti-pollution drive has boosted commodities, particularly metals like aluminium, with the Global X China Materials ETF surging 56% this year. The drive has led to capacity cuts and shutdowns of inefficient mines, resulting in higher prices and healthier profit margins for companies in the ETF. This trend is expected to continue, benefiting companies such as Aluminium Corp of China and Nine Dragons Paper Holdings, and potentially leading to supply disruptions and rising prices in other commodities like cobalt and paper.

site_title: Asean ministers agree on raft of measures to boost transport connectivity, share expertise
summary: ASEAN transport ministers signed five agreements to boost transport connectivity, including reducing trade restrictions and facilitating movement of people and goods. The agreements aim to increase travel convenience, strengthen aviation safety, and enhance transport cooperation among member states. Key initiatives include enabling domestic code-share rights for airlines, reducing restrictions on air transport ancillary services, and simplifying flight crew licensing. The agreements are expected to benefit economies, businesses, and tourism, and contribute to Asean's Vision 2020 and Master Plan on Asean Connectivity 2025.

site_title: Beijing Gas moves to join host of SGX delistings
summary: Beijing Gas Blue Sky Holdings announced its intention to delist from the Singapore Exchange due to "generally thin" trading volume, resulting in a lack of liquidity. The company cited a significant trading volume on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong Limited. The decision follows a trend of companies exiting the Singapore bourse, with 17 companies delisting from January to September this year, driven by factors such as capital deployment and strategic recalibration.

site_title: Hop on board and scoot, rattle 'n' roll
summary: A Singaporean e-scooter rider shares his experience riding a 350-watt electric scooter, citing the challenges of navigating pedestrians, cars, and narrow walkways. Despite following speed limits and being mindful of others, the rider faces hostility from some pedestrians, including a teenager who refused to move out of the way. The rider advocates for more courtesy and awareness among e-scooter users, acknowledging that the industry's reputation is at risk due to accidents involving e-scooters.

site_title: Singha Estate plans deals to help brewer parent diversify
summary: Singha Estate, the real estate arm of Thailand's Boon Rawd Brewery, plans to diversify with a US$1.5 billion warchest, focusing on commercial property and office space. Chairman Chutinant Bhirombhakdi sees Europe as an "interesting" market with assets available at a discount. The company aims to increase overseas revenue to 30% of its total revenue and expand into neighboring countries, including Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, and Myanmar. Singha Estate has over 3,000 hotel rooms in the UK and plans to expand its hotel business globally.

site_title: Nanofilm Tech CEO Shi Xu named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2017
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International's CEO Shi Xu was named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2017 Singapore, and also received the award under the Advanced Manufacturing category. He will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year competition in Monaco in June 2018. Shi Xu founded Nanofilm in 1999 with a startup cash of S$300,000 and has driven the company's growth and expansion, transforming it into a significant player in the coating technology and advanced manufacturing industry.

site_title: Wells Fargo revenue suffers on mortgage banking slump
summary: Wells Fargo's revenue fell 2% to $21.9 billion in the latest quarter, missing Wall Street estimates, due to a 37% slump in mortgage banking. The bank's earnings fell 19% to $4.6 billion, with net income in its Community Banking segment down 31% from a year ago. The slump is attributed to costs related to old mortgage problems and the bank's ongoing scandal over mortgage and sales practices. Wells Fargo's shares fell 3% following the disappointing earnings report.

site_title: Colonial hangover
summary: Hainanese cuisine, a fusion of Chinese and Western influences, is experiencing a resurgence in popularity among chefs in Singapore. The Hainanese, who arrived in Singapore in the mid-19th century, were the first Chinese immigrants to master Western cooking techniques, incorporating condiments like Lea & Perrins into their dishes. By the 1990s, the Hainanese dominance in the industry declined, but a few chefs, such as Han Liguang and Frederick Puah, have kept the tradition alive. They are now introducing new, innovative dishes, including Hainanese chicken rice and lamb stew, while maintaining traditional cooking methods.

site_title: Auditors issue disclaimer of opinion on EMS Energy's FY16 statements
summary: Auditors of EMS Energy have issued a disclaimer of opinion on the company's FY16 statements due to concerns over its ability to continue as a going business concern. The group's current liabilities exceeded current assets by S$126 million and S$39 million, with a significant loss of S$119.67 million. Bank facilities have been withdrawn, and the group's operating subsidiaries have ceased operations. The auditors also raised concerns over potential liabilities from legal claims and the valuation of assets, citing a stalled construction project and uncertain receivables.

site_title: Top Glove inks MOU to buy Eastern Press for RM47.25m
summary: Malaysia-based glove-maker Top Glove Corporation Bhd has signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire Eastern Press Sdn Bhd for RM47.25 million, expected to provide synergistic benefits through improved supply chain coordination and better delivery times. The company reported a 51% rise in net profit to RM98.6 million for the fourth quarter, driven by higher sales in all regions and a replenishment of customer orders. Top Glove will also explore the use of smart technologies and mergers and acquisitions to boost growth.

site_title: Iron out those chinks with Mizuno's MP-18 family
summary: Mizuno has launched its new MP-18 iron family in Singapore, featuring four models that can be mixed and matched for a seamless playing experience. The iron family aims to cater to various player preferences, offering a combination of control and forgiveness in short and long irons. The MP-18 irons have a classic look and feel, with simple color schemes and traditional shapes, while still providing maximum performance. This launch follows the trend of PGA Tour players using combination iron sets, allowing golfers to choose irons that suit their individual needs.

site_title: US inflation jumps in the wake of Hurricane Harvey
summary: US inflation surged to an eight-month high in September, driven by soaring fuel prices, particularly gasoline, which hit an eight-year record. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.5% seasonally adjusted, exceeding expectations. The energy index's 6.1% jump, mainly due to gasoline price increases of 13.1%, accounted for nearly all the September rise. However, the core CPI, excluding food and fuel, rose only 0.1%, below expectations, suggesting the energy-related jump may be transitory.

site_title: Mandalay to build 3,000 Arizona homes with solar and Sonnen batteries
summary: German battery maker Sonnen GmbH partners with home builder Mandalay Homes to outfit 3,000 new Arizona homes with batteries to store excess energy from rooftop solar installations. The batteries, costing between $10,000-$20,000, will be part of the home's sale price and wrapped into the mortgage. Utilities may pay homeowners to use stored power, creating a virtual power plant with 8 megawatt hours of electricity. The project aims to decrease reliance on centralized fossil fuel plants and is seen as a novelty in the US, with similar communities in Germany.

site_title: The problem is rail
summary: A significant disruption occurred on the North-South Line in Singapore's MRT system on October 7, 2017, due to flooding in a train tunnel and a small fire near tracks. The incident, which caused a train to be stuck in floodwater, has become emblematic of the MRT system's persistent disruption problems. Despite a decrease in major disruptions, statistics show they still occur about once a month. The government and rail operators are addressing issues through upgrades and equipment testing, but the frequency of major disruptions remains a concern for public confidence.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Corporation's stock is upgraded from Hold to Add by CIMB with a target price of S$8.58, citing a revised RNAV and oil and gas price-to-book value. Thai Beverage Public Company is upgraded to Buy by DBS Group Research after acquiring a 75% stake in Myanmar Supply Chain and Service Co Ltd, with potential synergies from distribution. The upgrades come as Keppel Corp is seen to benefit from the bottoming offshore and marine cycle and Singapore's residential market, while ThaiBev aims to extend its presence outside of Thailand.

images.alt_text: Thaibev announced that its indirect wholly owned subsidiary, International Beverage Holdings (Singapore) Pte Limited, has acquired an aggregate 75 per cent stake in the shares of Myanmar Supply Chain and Service Co Ltd (MSC) and Myanmar Distillery Co Ltd (MDC), both of which are incorporated in the Republic of the Union of Myanmar.

site_title: Gold prices in India swing to a premium ahead of Diwali
summary: Gold prices in India have surged to a premium ahead of Diwali, the country's major festival, after Indian authorities lifted a regulation that limited gold sales by buyers hesitant to provide identification information. The withdrawal of the Prevention of the Money Laundering Act (PMLA) amendment has led to increased purchases by jewellers, expecting healthy retail demand during Diwali. Local gold prices rose nearly 1% to 29,760 rupees per 10g, while spot gold hit a 2½-week peak of $1,298.32 an ounce, driven by a weaker dollar.

site_title: Allianz joins Shapoorji for US$500m India real estate fund
summary: Allianz, a European asset manager, has partnered with Shapoorji Pallonji Group to raise US$500 million for a Singapore-domiciled fund targeting India's commercial real estate market. The fund will focus on office space and aim to acquire or develop assets worth approximately US$1.5 billion in six key Indian cities. Allianz will own 50% of the fund, while other institutional investors will hold the remaining 50%.
