This investment marks Allianz's entry into India's commercial real estate market and aligns with its strategy to allocate 5% of its global portfolio to the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: LMIR Trust acquires 2 retail malls from sponsor for S$98.1m
summary: LMIR Trust, a retail REIT, has acquired two income-producing malls in Indonesia for S$98.1 million. The malls include Lippo Plaza Jogja and Kediri Town Square, with the transactions boosting net property income by S$7.6 million and distribution per unit by 3.43 cents. The acquisitions will diversify the portfolio geographically and tenant base, reducing concentration risks. The deal is financed via bond issuance and debt financing, and is part of a pipeline of over 40 retail malls from its sponsor.

site_title: Lufthansa's swoop on Air Berlin stirs competition concerns
summary: Lufthansa has signed a 210 million euro deal to take over Air Berlin's units Niki and LG Walter, as well as some short-haul planes. The move has raised concerns about unfair competition, with Austrian authorities and rival airlines such as Ryanair expressing concerns about Lufthansa's dominance in the German market. The European Commission is expected to review the deal, which will see Lufthansa acquire around 80 of Air Berlin's 130 planes. Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr expects the deal to be approved by the end of the year, but acknowledges that some remedies may be required.

site_title: MAS, ABS, Accenture in blockchain tie-up
summary: Accenture has been appointed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) to manage and develop a blockchain-based platform for interbank payments. The project, part of Project Ubin, aims to improve real-time payment settlement and liquidity management. Accenture will use three blockchain platforms to develop and test interbank payment models. This is the second phase of Project Ubin, which focuses on decentralized systems without compromising privacy. The goal is to encourage wider adoption of distributed ledger technology for cross-border applications.

site_title: S'pore Q3 GDP growth shoots past forecasts to hit 3-year high
summary: Singapore's economy experienced its strongest GDP growth in over three years, with a 4.6% expansion in the third quarter of 2017, surpassing forecasts. Manufacturing, led by the electronics sector, drove the growth, but economists expect its pace to slow. The services sector, which accounts for two-thirds of the economy, also showed signs of a broad-based recovery, with growth of 2.6% year-on-year. The construction sector, however, remained a laggard, contracting by 6.3% year-on-year. The official GDP growth forecast for the full year remains unchanged at 2-3%, with economists expecting growth to moderate in 2018.

site_title: China's trade with North Korea slumps as nuclear sanctions bite
summary: China's trade with North Korea decreased in September, with exports falling 6.7% and imports falling 37.9% compared to the same period last year. The decline is attributed to UN sanctions imposed on North Korea, which banned exports of iron, coal, and seafood, and restricted oil imports. China's overall trade with North Korea rose 3.7% to $4.03 billion for the first nine months of the year, with exports increasing 20.9% and imports decreasing 16.7%. The move is seen as a response to pressure from the US to curb North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks in biggest weekly gain since February 2016; Samsung hit by profit-taking
summary: South Korean shares ended the week with the largest gain in 20 months, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rising 3.3% for the week. Samsung Electronics, however, dropped 1.5% due to profit-taking after its forecast of strongest-ever quarterly earnings and vice-chairman Kwon Oh-hyun's surprise resignation. Foreign investors sold KOSPI shares worth 35.8 billion won, while the South Korean won strengthened to its highest level in over three weeks. The top presidential economic adviser expects the stock market to rise further despite external risks.

site_title: MAS keeps neutral stance, softens guidance
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained its neutral stance on monetary policy, keeping the Singapore dollar exchange rate within a zero-per-cent slope band. This move was seen as dovish, with market participants initially expecting a slope increase. The MAS also softened its forward-looking guidance, citing a preference for policy flexibility and a moderation in economic growth next year. Economists expect the MAS to review its policy in April, potentially embarking on a 0.5% per annum slope, but some expect it to remain unchanged.

site_title: Home Couture
summary: Hermès Managing Director Helene Dubrule emphasizes that the luxury brand is not just about its iconic handbags, but about a way of life. The company's "Home Universe" collection, which includes tableware, sofas, and accessories, is made with the same attention to luxury and craftsmanship as its fashion products. With in-house designers and collaborations with top artists, Hermès controls every aspect of production, from design to distribution, allowing for exacting standards across all products. The brand's focus is on timeless elegance and understated style, making it a desirable choice for both fashion enthusiasts and those seeking high-quality home decor.

site_title: Kushners' Manhattan tower set for worst year since 2011
summary: Kushners' Manhattan office tower, 666 Fifth Avenue, is forecast to lose US$24 million this year, marking the worst performance since 2011 refinancing. The property had a net operating income of US$18.3 million and debt payments of US$30.4 million for the six months ending in June, leaving only half of the debt covered. The losses stem from a US$1.2 billion mortgage taken on in 2007, with interest rates climbing as a February 2019 repayment deadline approaches. The 30% vacant building is being searched for an investor to redevelop.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq hit records on strong retail sales data
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq hit record highs on Friday after strong retail sales data in September, easing concerns over a sluggish US economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.17%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.16% and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.31%. The strong retail sales data suggests a rebound in consumer spending, a key driver of economic growth.

site_title: Olam secures revolving credit facility of US$1.75b
summary: Olam International Limited has secured a US$1.75 billion revolving credit facility to refinance existing loans. The facility consists of three tranches, with proceeds to be applied towards loan refinancing. Following the allotment of new shares, Olam's issued ordinary shares increased to 3.12 billion, with 154.74 million warrants remaining to expire in January 2018.

site_title: Goldman's call on Cathay Pacific makes it top Hong Kong stock
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is winning back investors as it seeks to slash costs after its worst loss in over 20 years. Goldman Sachs' conviction call, labeling the airline "unloved and misunderstood," contributed to a 6.2% jump in shares this week, the best performance on Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. Analysts believe Cathay Pacific can boost earnings, citing improving demand and supply, and predict a 15% rise in shares over the next year. Despite still being the lowest rated by analysts, the airline has seen upgrades from three brokerages in the past two months.

site_title: Bank of America profit rises 15% on lower costs
summary: Bank of America reported a 15% rise in quarterly profit to $5.12 billion, driven by lower costs and higher interest rates. Net income and earnings per share increased, while total revenue rose 1% to $22.08 billion. The lender attributed its performance to its cost management and the interest rate environment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close in positive territory
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.06% to close at 28,476.43, tracking a positive reading on Chinese trade. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, with gains of 0.13% and 0.66%, respectively. The positive reading from China was welcomed by traders, contributing to the gains in Asian markets.

site_title: See the light
summary: The See-Through House, one of six GCBs developed on a 120,000-square-foot property in Singapore, was designed by Robin Tan of Wallflower Architecture + Design. Completed in 2016, the residence features a pair of identical two-storey blocks with a pool and garden, and a large tembusu tree in the courtyard. The design prioritizes quietness, subtlety, and transparency, with large glass panels and sliding glass doors. The project was a collaboration between six firms, with the brief emphasizing the need to maintain clear sight lines and protect the surrounding trees.

site_title: BMW, Great Wall confirm Chinese Mini production talks
summary: BMW and Great Wall Motor are in talks to produce Mini models in China, with plans to launch electric and conventional Mini models in the country. The talks, which have been ongoing for 18 months, aim to meet China's zero-emission car quotas. If successful, the partnership could yield a first foreign manufacturing partner for Great Wall and a first Mini assembly site outside Europe for BMW. The deal does not impact BMW's existing Mini facilities in Britain.

site_title: Asean transport ministers agree to strengthen transport cooperation
summary: ASEAN transport ministers signed five agreements to liberalize air services, improve air travel safety, and facilitate cross-border transport. The agreements include Protocol 3 on domestic code-share rights, the Protocol to Implement the Tenth Package of Commitments under the Asean Framework Agreement on Services, and the Mutual Recognition Arrangement on Flight Crew Licensing. The agreements aim to enhance cooperation among member states and support the development of the aviation sector.

site_title: Airbus has not found any suppliers affected by Kobe Steel scandal
summary: Airbus has not found any suppliers affected by the Kobe Steel scandal, which involved data fabrication by the Japanese firm. Airbus does not directly buy products from Kobe Steel, but is investigating if any of its suppliers procure materials from the company. The scandal has affected over 30 non-Japanese customers, including Airbus, according to a Nikkei report.

site_title: "They have to pay", EU's Juncker says of Britain
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker stated that Britain must pay its outstanding financial commitments to the EU before talks can begin on a future relationship after Brexit. He emphasized that a compromise cannot be found on the remaining financial commitments, delaying the start of negotiations. The EU's summit next week is expected to conclude that insufficient progress has been made, further complicating the Brexit process.

site_title: ECB concerned virtual currencies may not be sufficiently guaranteed
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is concerned about the use of virtual currencies due to lack of transparency and trust. ECB Executive Board member Yves Mersch stated that the public has more trust in public currency, citing the uncertainty of private currency issuers and guarantors. This concern comes as Bitcoin has rallied nearly 75% in a month.

site_title: Malaysian stocks up slightly
summary: Malaysian stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.32 points to 1,755.32. A total of 3.21 billion shares were traded worth RM1.98 billion, with 452 gainers outnumbering 396 losers.

site_title: ECB said to consider cutting QE purchases in half next year
summary: European Central Bank officials consider cutting monthly bond purchases in half to 30 billion euros, with a possible extension until September. The move is aimed at reducing support for the region's economy, which has seen robust growth, but some governors remain concerned about weak inflation. The ECB's chief economist Peter Praet suggests slowing down QE to allow for a sustained inflation adjustment. The decision is expected to be finalized on October 26, and the euro strengthened against the US dollar on the news.

site_title: IMF supports ECB proposal to raise provisions on bad loans
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) supports the European Central Bank's (ECB) proposal to increase provision requirements for new non-performing loans. The ECB aims to require lenders to increase loan loss provisions to 100% over two years for unsecured loans and seven years for secured loans. This move is intended to boost the ECB's capital buffers and enhance financial stability in the European economy.

site_title: Judicial management period for Swiber extended to Oct 31, 2018
summary: The Singapore High Court has extended the judicial management period for Swiber Holdings and its subsidiary Swiber Offshore Construction Pte Ltd to October 31, 2018. This decision also grants an extension of time for the judicial managers to submit a statement of proposals and summon a creditors' meeting by March 31, 2018. Swiber Holdings has been under judicial management since October 2016.

site_title: Oil rallies on Chinese import boost and Mideast tensions
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, driven by strong Chinese oil imports and Middle East tensions. Brent crude reached $57.42 per barrel, up 1.17, and is on track for a 3% weekly gain. China's oil imports averaged 8.5 million barrels per day in the first nine months of the year, solidifying its position as the world's largest oil importer. Tensions in Iraq and potential US action on the Iran nuclear deal also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: Che Guevara stamps sell out in Ireland despite outrage
summary: Che Guevara stamps selling out in Ireland despite controversy, with 122,000 printed initially, prompting An Post to print extra stock. The one-euro stamp features an iconic image of the Argentine-born Marxist revolutionary and includes a quote from his father, an Irish civil engineer. The stamp has sparked outrage, with Irish senator Neale Richmond calling it "totally objectionable" and a Cuban exile community member stating it would "celebrate a man who slaughtered so many people".

site_title: STI ends Friday's session up 16 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended Friday's session with a 0.49% gain, rising 16.02 points to 3,319.11. This was driven by shares of OCBC, UOB, and ThaiBev, with high turnover of over 2 billion units worth S$1.3 billion. The advance-decline score was 271 to 183, excluding warrants.

site_title: Mercedes triples BMW gains to tighten hold on luxury-car crown
summary: Mercedes-Benz widened its lead in global luxury-car sales, with deliveries jumping 12% to 1.72 million vehicles in the first nine months of 2017. This surpasses BMW's 3.9% increase to 1.54 million cars, and Audi's 2% decline to 1.38 million autos. Mercedes regained the No. 1 rank in luxury-vehicle sales from BMW for the first time in over a decade, driven by the success of revamped models like the E-Class sedan and SUVs.

site_title: Euro set for biggest weekly rise in a month as political clouds start to lift
summary: The euro is on track for its biggest weekly rise in a month, driven by lifting political concerns and a muted US dollar. The European Central Bank is expected to outline plans to unwind its stimulus program, supporting the euro. Industry data from Italy and Germany indicate a broad-based economic recovery in the euro zone, despite the currency's double-digit gains this year. The US dollar is set for its biggest weekly drop in over a month due to steady declines in Treasury yields.

site_title: General Motors to scale back production at Detroit sedan plant
summary: General Motors plans to scale back production at its Detroit-Hamtramck plant, reducing output by 20% starting October 20. The move aims to maintain stable production and address declining US sedan sales. The plant, which produces four underperforming sedan models, will operate under a reduced schedule and result in around 200 lost jobs. This follows a similar plan to cut production and lay off workers at the plant, which was originally reported by The Wall Street Journal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat, Uniqlo operator rises
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday, tracking falls on Wall Street, but Uniqlo's parent company Fast Retailing rose 3% after reporting strong annual net profits. The Nikkei 225 index inched down 0.02%, while the Topix index fell 0.16%.

site_title: Australian shares end near 4-month high, supported by insurers; NZ firmer
summary: Australian shares ended at a nearly four-month high, supported by insurer stocks, after the government announced healthcare reforms to promote private cover among younger residents. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to close at 5,814.20, its largest gain since March. Meanwhile, New Zealand shares set a record high for the ninth straight day, driven by strong performance in information technology and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on Friday in the red, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.12% to 28,423.65, following a retreat on Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.05%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose marginally. The decline is attributed to traders awaiting the release of Chinese trade data later in the day.

site_title: BA owner IAG interested in failed airline Monarch's Gatwick slots: CEO
summary: British Airways owner IAG is interested in acquiring Monarch's London Gatwick slots, with CEO Willie Walsh stating the reduction in capacity could be beneficial for the industry. Monarch's collapse, along with Air Berlin and Alitalia, has led to a reduction in capacity in Europe's competitive airline sector. Walsh believes this could lead to less growth and capacity in the market, particularly over winter, which he views as a positive for the industry.

site_title: Billionaire gets Tata's 40m users in 'cash-free' deal
summary: Bharti Airtel, India's largest mobile-phone operator, has agreed to absorb Tata Group's mobile-phone business in a "cash-free" transaction, acquiring 40 million customers and airwaves. The deal will settle Tata's past liabilities and pave the way for Bharti to complete the merger. The stock surged 7.8% after the announcement, with Tata retaining its stake in Viom Networks and exploring a merger with Tata Communications. The move aims to overhaul India's crowded wireless market, where Reliance Jio Infocomm has disrupted the industry with free calls and data.

site_title: Auditor issues disclaimer of opinion over EMS's FY2016 financial statements
summary: EMS Energy's auditors, BDO, issued a disclaimer of opinion on the company's FY2016 financial statements due to a lack of audit evidence. The audit raised concerns over going concern doubts, liabilities, property impairment, financial asset valuation, and derivative liabilities. EMS responded by stating its financial position will be "substantially improved" upon successful completion of its High Court-approved schemes of arrangement. The company's financial statements were deemed unreliable, highlighting the need for improvement in its financial reporting practices.

site_title: CAAS net surplus up S$13.8m on government grants
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) reported a net surplus of S$76.44 million for the year ended March 31, 2017, driven by a rise in income from air navigation service charges and aviation levy, and higher government grants. Expenditure increased due to higher salaries and staff benefits. CAAS invested in productivity and manpower capabilities to make Singapore a future-ready aviation hub, with a healthy financial position of S$2.7 billion in net assets.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened flat at 3,308.52 on Friday, tracking Wall Street's retreat. 95.3 million shares valued at S$73.5 million changed hands, with gains outnumbering losses 73 to 46. Key traded stocks included Keppel Corp, City Developments, and Thai Beverage.

site_title: Uber files appeal against London ban
summary: Uber has filed an appeal against a London court's decision not to renew its licence, citing public safety concerns. The decision, made by Transport for London, was based on concerns over the company's approach to reporting crimes, obtaining medical certificates, and a practice known as "greyballing". Uber plans to continue operating in London while awaiting the appeal. The company's new CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, has stated a determination to make things right.

images.alt_text: Uber on Friday filed its appeal against a decision by London authorities not to renew its licence, the US ride-hailing company said.

site_title: Top Glove Q4 profit surges 51%; plans to buy Eastern Press for RM47m
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a 51% surge in Q4 net profit to RM98.6 million, driven by increased sales and higher average selling prices of nitrile gloves. The company plans to buy Eastern Press Sdn Bhd for RM47.25 million and boost production capacity by 78 new production lines. By December 2018, Top Glove aims to produce 59.7 billion gloves per annum, with plans to explore smart technologies and mergers and acquisitions to boost growth.

site_title: One year after King's death, Thais prepare for final goodbye
summary: Thailand marks one year since the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej with sombre ceremonies, as the nation prepares for a final farewell in a cremation ceremony on October 26. The monarch, revered as a demi-god, commanded deep devotion during his 70-year reign. The country has observed a year of collective mourning, with many Thais expunging color from their wardrobes and donning black and white. The cremation ceremony will send Bhumibol's spirit to the afterlife, with the ultra-royalist junta orchestrating the mourning and enforcing strict laws against criticizing the monarchy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy grew 4.6% in Q3, beating expectations, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The Monetary Authority of Singapore maintained a neutral monetary policy stance. The government will ensure SME services remain after merging Spring and IE Singapore into Enterprise Singapore. Asean transport ministers agreed to strengthen transport cooperation, including liberalizing air services. Meanwhile, EMS Energy's auditors issued a disclaimer of opinion over the company's FY2016 financial statements, and Top Glove reported a 51% rise in Q4 profit.

images.alt_text: Singapore's economy grew by 4.6 per cent compared to a year ago for the third quarter of 2017, based on advance estimates of gross domestic product (GDP) growth by the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Friday morning.

site_title: China Sept trade surplus with US highest on record: Reuters calculations
summary: China's trade surplus with the US in September reached a record high of $28.08 billion, surpassing the previous month's surplus of $26.23 billion. This marks the largest single-month surplus with the US since 2008. The January-September trade surplus with the US stands at $195.54 billion. The significant trade imbalance could fuel US President Donald Trump's long-standing complaints about the impact on the US economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.44 points to 1,753.56. The market saw a slight increase in volume, with 130.09 million lots traded worth RM19.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 108 to 53, indicating a relatively positive sentiment.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up but traders cautious after Wall St drop
summary: Asian markets edged up on Friday, despite a drop on Wall Street, as traders remained cautious due to uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's tax plans. The dollar struggled to break out against major peers, while the euro and pound gained support from easing concerns about Spain's Catalan independence crisis and Brexit. Investors will closely follow US consumer inflation data later Friday, which will influence the Federal Reserve's plans for hiking interest rates.

site_title: G7 met to agree on more pressure vs North Korea: Japan's Asakawa
summary: The G7 finance leaders agreed to strengthen cooperation to counter North Korea's attempts to avert UN sanctions, following recent provocations. The move is a show of resolve among advanced economies to boost pressure on the country. This is a rare disclosure of the G7's meeting on the sidelines of the G20 gathering, highlighting their commitment to addressing the issue.

site_title: 'Death by overwork': occupational hazard for Japan's media
summary: A Japanese reporter's death from overwork highlights the country's extreme culture of long hours. The journalist, who worked 159 hours of overtime in the month before her death, died from heart failure at 31. This case is one of dozens of reported deaths due to strokes, heart attacks, and suicides each year. The term "karoshi" describes death from overwork, and the government has released a report showing 7.7% of employees log more than 20 hours of overtime a week. Reforms have been implemented by NHK, including reducing work hours and introducing health standards, but critics say the government is not taking sufficient action to address the issue.

site_title: China's Sept imports from North Korea down 37.9%, drop for 7th straight month
summary: China's imports from North Korea decreased 37.9% in September, marking the 7th consecutive month of decline, according to the General Administration of Customs. This drop, along with a 6.7% decrease in exports to North Korea, resulted in a trade surplus of $1.07 billion for the first nine months of the year. The decline in imports and exports is attributed to strained China-US ties and pressure on China to address North Korea's nuclear and missile programs.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore's Q3 GDP likely to be strongest this year; MAS neutral stance expected, but seen dovish
summary: Singapore's economy grew 4.6% in Q3 2017, surpassing expectations, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintaining a neutral stance and keeping the Singdollar policy unchanged. The MAS expects growth to moderate in 2018, with inflation remaining benign at 0-1%. Economists note that the MAS's dovish stance suggests no immediate need to tighten monetary policies, despite a strong Q3 GDP. The MAS also expects core inflation to trend towards 2% over the medium term.

site_title: Beijing Gas to delist from SGX mainboard
summary: Beijing Gas Blue Sky Holdings announced it will delist from the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX ST) due to low trading volume and resulting lack of liquidity. The decision was made after comparing trading volumes with those on the Hong Kong stock exchange. The company cited thin trading volumes as the reason for its proposed delisting.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end at two-decade high on upbeat earnings
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei stock index reached a 21-year high on Friday, closing at 21,155.18, driven by upbeat Japanese corporate earnings. The index rose 0.96% after a ninth consecutive positive session. However, Kobe Steel plummeted due to a widening quality control scandal. The broader Topix index also rose 0.50%. The strong performance was seen as a sign of the market's resilience despite global economic uncertainty, particularly amid US trade tensions.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 3-month high on healthcare news; NZ notches 7th record day
summary: Australian shares reached a 3-month high on Friday, driven by healthcare stocks after the government announced reforms to streamline private health insurance. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 11.5 points to 5806.0, its best week in 18 years. New Zealand shares also reached a record high for the seventh consecutive session, boosted by information technology and healthcare stocks. The reforms aim to encourage younger Australians to buy private cover by offering discounts of up to 10%.

site_title: Samsung Electronics CEO to step down
summary: Samsung Electronics CEO Kwon Oh-Hyun is stepping down amid a bribery scandal that sent his predecessor to jail. In a statement, Kwon cited the need for a new spirit and young leadership to address the rapidly changing IT industry. This move comes as the company faces significant challenges.

site_title: Hot Stock: Raffles Education closed 12.5% up as tycoon Oei seeks chairman's ouster
summary: Raffles Education shares surged 12.5% to close at S$0.36 on Friday, driven by tycoon Oei Hong Leong's bid to oust chairman Chew Hua Seng. Oei seeks an extraordinary general meeting to remove Chew and replace him with an independent director. He also wants the company to disclose details of a recent share placement. Oei, who holds a 12.88% stake in the company, has been buying shares in the private college operator, but his stake was diluted due to the placement.

site_title: Italy's Gucci bans fur, joining others in seeking alternatives
summary: Italy's Gucci will stop using fur in its designs starting from its spring and summer 2018 collection, joining a growing number of fashion houses seeking alternatives. The brand will sell off remaining fur accessories and clothing in a charity auction, following pressure from animal rights activists and changing consumer tastes. Gucci's decision marks a significant shift in the luxury industry, with other brands such as Yoox Net-A-Porter, Giorgio Armani, and Calvin Klein already adopting fur-free policies.

site_title: Oei Hong Leong seeks to oust Raffles Education chairman
summary: TYCOON Oei Hong Leong has requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting to oust Raffles Education chairman Chew Hua Seng. Oei seeks to replace Chew with an independent director and wants the company to disclose details of recent share placements. Oei, who holds a 12.88% stake in the company, has been buying shares over the past year and now holds 1.07 million shares. Chew and his spouse have a combined 33.57% stake following the recent share placement. The EGM is scheduled to take place on Friday.

images.alt_text: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong has requested to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to oust Raffles Education chairman, Chew Hua Seng.

site_title: Kobe Steel shares tumble, Nikkei says 30-plus foreign customers affected
summary: Kobe Steel shares plummeted over 8% after the Nikkei reported that more than 30 foreign customers, including Daimler AG and Airbus SE, were affected by the company's data falsification. The practice, which impacted around 200 companies, may have spread beyond Japan, according to CEO Hiroya Kawasaki. The stock's decline follows previous warnings from Kawasaki about the potential scope of the issue.

site_title: US, South Korea to launch major navy drill next week
summary: The US and South Korea will launch a major navy drill in the Sea of Japan and the Yellow Sea from October 16 to 26, as a show of force against North Korea's missile and nuclear tests. The drill, involving the USS Ronald Reagan aircraft carrier and South Korean Navy vessels, aims to promote "communications, interoperability, and partnership". The move comes amid escalating tensions between the US and North Korea, with Pyongyang warning of a "nuclear war of aggression". This is the latest in a series of US military drills in the region, including joint aviation exercises with Japan and South Korea.

site_title: Citi hires former BofAML banker Kris Hopkins to head futures execution
summary: Citi Singapore has appointed Kris Hopkins, former head of Singapore futures and options and client execution for Bank of America Merrill Lynch Singapore, as head of futures execution in Singapore. Hopkins will oversee the Singapore futures execution team and report to APAC head of futures execution Kevin Zolkiewicz. The appointment aims to deepen client penetration, improve efficiency, and enhance electronic execution capabilities in the region.

site_title: Kobe Steel's cheating engulfs more divisions; shares resume slide
summary: Kobe Steel Ltd admitted to widespread cheating, including false certification in its steel division, affecting multinational clients including Boeing Co. The firm's shares plummeted 8.7% as it confirmed data tampering in steel wire products. The crisis, which includes allegations of data fabrication and falsification of product quality, has cast doubt on Japan's manufacturing industry and corporate governance. The company's CEO, Hiroya Kawasaki, will brief media later, and the government has ordered Kobe Steel to address safety concerns within two weeks.

site_title: Services for SMEs to remain amid Spring, IE Singapore merger: Sim Ann
summary: Singapore's government will ensure SME services remain after merging Spring Singapore and IE Singapore into Enterprise Singapore. Senior Minister of State Sim Ann said the merger aims to be smooth and services to SMEs will continue. A government procurement guide has also been released to help SMEs leverage growth opportunities in GP projects. The guide outlines steps for businesses to maximise competitive advantage and provide feedback to procuring agencies after unsuccessful bids. The merger is expected to take place smoothly, maintaining support for SMEs.

site_title: South Korea finance ministry says weak domestic recovery holding back economic growth
summary: South Korea's finance ministry stated that weak private consumption and slow job growth are hindering economic expansion, despite robust exports. August retail sales declined 1% from July, and the Bank of Korea's consumer sentiment index hit a three-month low. Consumer optimism has decreased, with the composite consumer sentiment index reaching 109.9, down from a six-and-a-half-year high in July. This suggests that domestic economic growth is being held back, contradicting the country's robust export performance.

site_title: Europe equities stable after record run
summary: Europe's stock markets stabilized on Friday, one day after reaching record highs, despite lingering concerns over Brexit. London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.3% to 7,533.45 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 added 0.1% to 12,995.08 points. Sterling recovered after EU negotiator Michel Barnier's comments on a Brexit deadlock, with a report suggesting a potential two-year extension deal. The Paris CAC 40 was almost flat at 5,362.73 points.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages lowers purchase price for New Zealand land
summary: Global Yellow Pages has reduced the acquisition price for a plot of land in Papakura, New Zealand, from NZ$38 million to NZ$36 million. The new terms include a NZ$3.6 million deposit and a final instalment of NZ$7 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Beijing Gas Blue Sky, Raffles Education, Lian Beng, Tata, Bharti, Singtel
summary: Beijing Gas Blue Sky Holdings confirmed that the Singapore Exchange has no objection to its delisting from the mainboard. Tycoon Oei Hong Leong requested an extraordinary general meeting to oust Raffles Education chairman Chew Hua Seng. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore economy grows 4.6% in Q3; beats expectations
summary: Singapore's economy grew 4.6% in Q3 2017, exceeding expectations and surpassing the 2.9% growth in the preceding quarter. This beats the market consensus forecast of 3.8% growth. The GDP growth is higher than the previous quarter, indicating a strong economic performance.

site_title: Venture capitalist Wavemaker closes US$66m funding round
summary: Venture capital firm Wavemaker Partners has closed a US$66 million funding round for South-east Asia, exceeding its original target of US$50 million. The round received support from the World Bank's International Finance Corporation, with a US$10 million investment. This is the firm's largest funding round to date, bringing its total assets under management to US$185 million. Wavemaker has a presence in Singapore and has invested over 80% of its funds in seed-stage business-to-business and deep technology companies.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS maintains 'buy' on ThaiBev's Myanmar venture
summary: DBS Group Research maintains its "buy" call on ThaiBev's Myanmar venture, citing a 13% upside potential. ThaiBev acquired a 75% stake in Myanmar Supply Chain and Service and Myanmar Distillery for US$742 million. The Myanmar spirits market is expected to grow at a 7.6% CAGR from 2012 to 2017. DBS notes ThaiBev's shares have been flat due to the mourning period in Thailand but expect a rebound after October.

site_title: Croc 'highly likely' to have killed elderly Australian woman
summary: A 79-year-old Australian woman, Anne Cameron, is "highly likely" to have been killed by a crocodile after she wandered away from her care facility on Australia's north-east coast. Her clothing, walking stick, and human remains were found near a creek in Port Douglas. Forensic tests confirm the remains are Cameron's, and authorities believe a saltwater crocodile was responsible. A search is underway to locate the offending reptile, which is considered a protected species.

site_title: Gold climbs to 2-week high ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose to a two-week high ahead of US inflation data due on Friday, as investors focused on potential clues to monetary policy. The US Federal Reserve's September meeting minutes showed policymakers debated the prospect of inflation pick-up and interest rate rises. The dollar also strengthened after US unemployment benefits fell to a one-month low. These developments boosted gold prices, which have been volatile due to US President Trump's tariff moves, including fresh tariffs on Canada and threats to others.

site_title: Amazon Studios chief Roy Price suspended following harassment allegation
summary: Amazon Studios chief Roy Price was suspended on October 12, 2017, following allegations of harassment by producer Isa Hackett. Hackett claimed Price lewdly propositioned her in 2015. The allegations also included ignoring actress Rose McGowan's claim of a sexual assault by producer Harvey Weinstein. Price declined to comment. Amazon stated he was put on an immediate leave of absence. The allegations were reported by The Hollywood Reporter.

site_title: Samsung Electronics on track for record Q3 as chips soar
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a likely record Q3 operating profit of 14.5 trillion won (S$17.3 billion), surpassing analyst estimates, due to strong memory chip prices. Revenue is expected to rise 29.7% from last year to 62 trillion won. The company's chip business is driving the growth, with margins likely increasing due to high demand. This beats analyst forecasts, solidifying Samsung's position as a global memory chip leader.

site_title: The 'worm has turned' on big US tech companies, says author
summary: US tech companies are facing increased regulatory pressure due to their widespread influence in people's lives. Professor Scott Galloway, author of "The Four," believes the "worm has turned" and that companies like Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google will be subject to more scrutiny. This shift is partly due to the misuse of their platforms by foreign governments, according to Galloway. The professor's book highlights the need for greater regulation to prevent the exploitation of these platforms.

site_title: Lian Beng exploring spin-off of property development business
summary: Lian Beng Group is exploring a spin-off of its property development business to be listed on the Catalist Board of the Singapore Exchange, with SAC Capital Private Limited appointed as financial advisor. The proposed spin-off aims to provide transparent valuation, financial independence, and fund raising without relying on the group's financing. This move follows similar spin-offs by World Class Global and Tee Land, and is expected to allow senior management to focus on their assigned business segments and deliver value to shareholders.

site_title: Tesla recalls Model X vehicles for seat fix
summary: Tesla is recalling approximately 11,000 Model X vehicles from the 2016 and 2017 model years due to a potential issue with the second-row seat-backs, which may shift forward during crashes. The company will inspect and adjust the affected vehicles through its mobile service or at service centers. Owners are advised to temporarily avoid having two adults sit in the second row left and center seating positions at the same time. This recall comes after internal testing revealed a possible cable adjustment issue to ensure safety.

site_title: Lufthansa snaps up large parts of failed Air Berlin
summary: Lufthansa has acquired large parts of failed Air Berlin for 210 million euros, expanding its Eurowings budget business. The deal includes Austrian leisure airline Niki, regional airline LG Walter, and 20 additional aircraft. Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr expects EU approval by the end of 2017, while Ryanair plans to refer the matter to the EU competition authority. Air Berlin's assets, including planes, will be sold to easyJet and other bidders, with talks ongoing.

site_title: Tata, Bharti plan consumer mobile business merger
summary: Bharti Airtel Limited (BTL) and Tata Teleservices are set to merge their consumer mobile businesses on a debt-free, cash-free basis. The deal, expected to be completed soon, will benefit over 40 million customers with 4G mobile services. Tata will assume a small portion of unpaid spectrum liability, while BTL will settle all past liabilities. The proposed merger aims to enhance the combined entity's competitiveness in the Indian market.

site_title: S&P warns of Catalan recession if crisis drags
summary: Ratings agency Standard and Poor's has warned that a prolonged crisis over Catalan independence from Spain could push the region into recession. The agency believes that tensions between Catalonia and the central government could lead to a sustained drop in business confidence and potential business disruption. S&P's chief rating officer Moritz Kramer stated that Catalan independence is unlikely to occur, but the uncertainty could have significant economic implications. The warning comes as the crisis continues to drag on, with no clear resolution in sight.

site_title: Hitting a sweet spot after dinner
summary: A writer shares their experience of opening and decanting a 33-year-old bottle of Taylor's 1927 Vintage Port, a rare and expensive wine. The wine is described as having a complex, rich, and sweet flavor profile with notes of citrus, strawberries, and coffee. The writer savored the wine after dinner, enjoying its long, lingering finish. This experience highlights the writer's appreciation for fine wine and the value of savoring rare and aged beverages.

site_title: US dollar steadies ahead of Friday's US inflation data
summary: The US dollar steadied ahead of Friday's inflation data, narrowly avoiding a fifth straight day of losses against a basket of currencies. The dollar index rose 0.06% to 93.074, correcting a week of losses. Investors await inflation data for clues on the next US interest rate hike. Currency strategist Marc Chandler attributed the move to a correction from September's big move. The dollar's stability may provide relief for policymakers as they consider rate hikes amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: 'Many' Fed members favour December rate hike: minutes
summary: US central bankers are divided over a potential interest rate hike in December, with many favoring a rate increase amid persistently weak inflation. The Federal Reserve's September meeting showed no clear consensus on the near-term threat of rising prices, with some policymakers arguing that low inflation could be a longer-term trend. Despite disagreements, the Fed is expected to raise rates at its final meeting of the year in December, with the probability of a hike falling to 86.7% following the release of the minutes.

site_title: Car sector raises alarm over tweaks to Nafta
summary: The US car sector is warning of a "lose-lose" situation if the Trump administration's proposed changes to the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) increase content requirements for cars sourced from Nafta countries. The proposed rule could add complexity and costs, potentially disrupting the auto industry's supply chain. Industry leaders, including Magna International Inc. and the National Automobile Dealers Association, are concerned about the potential impact on consumers and the trade balance between the US, Canada, and Mexico.

site_title: USD/SGD rebound after MAS unveils neutral policy stance
summary: The USD/SGD currency pair rebounded to 1.3549 after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained its neutral policy stance, reversing a decline to 1.3508. Interest rates for the Singapore dollar rose in response to the decision. Analysts at DBS Group Research attributed the rebound to the perceived dovishness of the MAS's policy statement, which led to a "buy the rumour, sell the event" outcome, where investors reacted positively to the announcement.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records; banks, media shares weak
summary: US stocks retreated from records on Thursday, with the financial sector being a major contributor to the decline. Despite strong earnings from JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup, the sector underperformed due to investor skepticism. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq still edged to fresh records, but the rally was not enough to overcome the sector's weakness. The market's optimism appears to be waning, with some analysts suggesting that investors are trimming bank stocks.

site_title: Small quake rattles North Korea nuclear testing grounds, not manmade: South Korea
summary: A small earthquake with a magnitude 2.7 and depth of 3km occurred in North Hamgyong Province, near North Korea's nuclear testing site, on Friday. The quake, which was also measured at 2.9 magnitude by the USGS, did not appear to be manmade, according to South Korea's weather agency. This is the latest in a series of quakes observed in the area following North Korea's sixth and largest nuclear test in September. The cause of the quake remains unclear.

site_title: Global economy chiefs told to reform while going is good
summary: Global economy chiefs were warned to reform and address mounting debts and deepening inequalities before possible setbacks as the global economy accelerates. World Bank President Jim Yong Kim and International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde urged countries to reduce sovereign borrowing, dependence on portfolio capital, and invest in technology to build resilience against overlapping challenges. Despite a 3.6% global economic growth estimate, Lagarde cautioned that it's not time to be complacent and that policymakers must take action to enable more people and countries to benefit from the recovery.

site_title: Oil slips despite larger draw in US stocks
summary: Oil prices slipped despite a larger-than-expected decline in US inventories, as a bearish outlook from the International Energy Agency and concerns over gasoline inventories weighed on the market. Brent crude settled down 1.2% to $56.25 a barrel, while US light crude ended down 1.4% to $50.60 a barrel. Analysts expect oil prices to remain between $50 and $60 a barrel through the end of the year, driven by high US production and a global crude surplus.

site_title: Europe: Record-breaking German stock index tops 13,000 points
summary: Germany's stocks benchmark index DAX reached a record high of 13,002 points for the first time in its 30-year history, driven by relatively attractive valuations and optimism about global economic growth. The DAX rose 0.1% and is up 13% so far this year, supported by a reduction in the threat of Catalan secession and record low interest rates. Key gains were seen in Lufthansa, Volkswagen, and Just Eat, while Deutsche Bank strategists reduced their overweight on German equities.

site_title: Coach Inc reinvents itself into Tapestry
summary: Coach Inc, the parent company of Coach, Stuart Weitzman, and Kate Spade, is rebranding as Tapestry Inc to reflect its new status as a multibrand entity. The name change, effective October 31, aims to convey inclusivity and diversity, as CEO Victor Luis emphasized the company's ability to work with different brands and cultures. This move follows a trend of corporate rebranding, including Google's Alphabet and Tribune Publishing's Tronc, as the company seeks to position itself as a leading American fashion group.

site_title: UK economy shows few signs of comeback as rate hike decision nears: BCC
summary: The UK economy shows little sign of recovery, with sales at services firms steady but pay pressures and investment remaining low, according to the British Chambers of Commerce. Despite a slight improvement in manufacturers' sales, confidence in turnover and profitability reached its highest levels since 2015, but investment intentions remained unchanged. The BCC described the survey as "uninspiring" due to political uncertainty, currency fluctuations, and Brexit's impact on businesses. The Bank of England is considering raising interest rates, but most economists think it would be a mistake to act now, potentially weakening overall UK growth.

site_title: Despite its title, this book is not just for widows
summary: Singapore novelist Balli Kaur Jaswal's third novel, "Erotic Stories For Punjabi Widows," explores themes of identity, belonging, and social culture through the story of Nikki, a first-generation British Sikh woman. The novel follows Nikki's journey as she teaches a writing course at a London Sikh temple, where she discovers a group of illiterate Punjabi widows who use erotic storytelling to express themselves. The book is a humorous and lighthearted take on the patriarchal societies that restrict women's lives, celebrating women's self-fulfillment and individuality.

site_title: Frustrated by Congress, Trump signs order to weaken Obamacare
summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order to weaken the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) by allowing small businesses to buy bare-bones health insurance plans across state lines, starting in 2019. The order aims to give people more access to cheaper plans with fewer benefits, but experts question its impact and legality. Democratic state attorneys general have threatened to sue, citing concerns that the plan could destabilize the healthcare system and leave a sicker patient pool. The move is part of Trump's efforts to dismantle Obamacare, which has been criticized by Republicans and Democrats alike.

site_title: Takeover offer made for Indiabulls property trust at 90 cts apiece
summary: Indiabulls Group has made a takeover offer of S$306 million for Indiabulls Properties Investment Trust (IPIT) at 90 Singapore cents apiece, aiming to delist the business trust from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The offer represents a premium of 252.9% over the unit's last traded price of 26 Singapore cents. With 97.62% ownership, the offeror and parties intend to privatize IPIT, citing the need for flexibility to manage and develop existing investments without regulatory requirements.

site_title: PM Lee to make official working visit to Washington, DC from Oct 22 to 26
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will make an official working visit to Washington, DC from Oct 22 to 26 at the invitation of US President Donald Trump. During the visit, Mr Lee will meet with key administration officials, Congressional leaders, and participate in a moderated dialogue at the Council of Foreign Relations. He will also speak at the Economic Club of Washington DC, discussing US-Singapore bilateral relations, strategic challenges, and opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: A glossy look at what women want
summary: Reese Witherspoon stars as Alice, a 40-year-old single parent and jobless woman, in the romantic comedy Home Again. The film follows Alice's life after her separation from her husband and her subsequent relationship with three young Hollywood hopefuls. Despite Witherspoon's sunny appeal, the movie is criticized for its lack of depth and glossiness, failing to provide a nuanced portrayal of womanhood. The film's portrayal of privilege and reality is also deemed unrealistic, leading to a disappointing and unengaging viewing experience.

site_title: London's global banks still hiring despite Brexit: Hays
summary: Global banks in London continue to hire despite Brexit concerns, with many replacing departing staff in key roles like IT and compliance. Recruiters Hays and Robert Walters report that banks have contingency plans in place but are waiting for clarity on the Brexit deal. Meanwhile, Hays' UK business shows modest signs of improvement, with net fees rising 1% in the last quarter.

site_title: Home shopping and old haunts in BT Weekend
summary: A new wave of independent retailers offers experiential shopping in residential settings, redefining home shopping. China's One Belt, One Road initiative aims to create a new Eurasian continent. The article also explores the history of ketchup and features reviews of various products, including a BMW 6 Series Gran Turismo and a new restaurant offering mod-Indian cuisine. Additionally, it touches on topics such as corporate purpose, financial literacy for women, and zero-waste living.

site_title: Politics stands in the way of development goals
summary: The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) aim to address global issues such as poverty, inequality, and climate change, but consensus-building may hinder progress due to conflicting national interests and populist calls for nationalist policies. Experts warn that technological disruption, geopolitical rivalry, and widening social inequality pose significant obstacles to achieving the SDGs. The lack of a global tax mechanism and monetary policies to ensure equitable development and social peace is also a concern. Furthermore, a focus on women's empowerment and inclusive growth is necessary to address non-inclusive growth patterns and reduce poverty.

site_title: Crazy Horse isn't about all that nudity
summary: Crazy Horse, a Parisian cabaret, is returning to Singapore with "Forever Crazy," a touring production inspired by its founder Alain Bernardin's vision to showcase femininity in various forms. The show features classically-trained dancers with all-natural bodies, celebrating femininity through music, lights, and costumes. Despite controversy over nudity, Crazy Horse Paris claims to have a strong female fan base and engages the mind as much as the eye. The show's creative director, Andree Deissenberg, aims to respect Bernardin's heritage while keeping it fresh and up-to-date.

site_title: Britain 'must assume consequences' of Brexit: French minister
summary: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire stated that Britain must assume the consequences of its decision to exit the European Union. Talks in Brussels between British and EU officials over Britain's future relationship with the single market have reached a "disturbing" impasse. Le Maire expressed regret over the British public's decision, calling it a "historic mistake" that will have "bad consequences" for the British people. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde also warned of a potential "catastrophic" hard break by Britain with the EU, emphasizing the need for a swift and orderly exit to reduce uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore ranked 13th among 200 countries for low bribery risk
summary: Singapore ranks 13th among 200 countries for low bribery risk, categorized as "very low" in the 2017 TRACE Bribery Risk Matrix. The city-state received low scores in "business interactions with government" and "anti-bribery laws and enforcement". Singapore's "capacity for civil-society oversight" scored 46, the highest among the four domains. The country's unique blend of a business-friendly environment and low civil-society engagement contributes to its low bribery risk.

site_title: Global oil market seen balanced in 2018, even with rising output: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a balanced global oil market in 2018, despite rising output. Global demand for crude oil is expected to grow by 1.4 million barrels per day, moderating from 1.6 million barrels per day in 2017. The growth in consumption is expected to offset the rise in output, erasing a three-year-old overhang of unused fuel. This balance is expected to be maintained throughout 2018.

site_title: Singapore's Aug retail sales up again to beat forecasts
summary: Singapore's retail sales in August rose 3.5% from the same month last year, exceeding forecasts, with a total value of S$3.7 billion. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail sales fell 1.2%. Petrol service stations, recreational goods, and medical goods and toiletries led the growth, while optical goods, food retailers, and mini-marts saw declines. Analysts expect sustained retail sales growth in the fourth quarter due to the festive season and strong visitor arrivals.

site_title: Citic Envirotech taps buoyant demand in fixed income market
summary: Citic Envirotech priced an S$240m issue of senior perpetual securities at 3.9% with over S$1.4b in demand from 87 accounts in Singapore and Hong Kong. The firm plans to use the proceeds to refinance debt and for general corporate purposes, following investments in Chinese hazardous waste treatment facilities. Strong demand in the fixed income market, driven by expectations of a hawkish stance from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, contributed to the buoyant demand.

site_title: Lotte says it has several suitors for its China stores
summary: Lotte Group, South Korea's No 5 conglomerate, has several firms interested in acquiring its Lotte Mart stores in China, with a potential sale by the end of this year. The decision comes after the company shut down most of its hypermarkets and supermarkets in China due to political tensions. Lotte has been generating operating losses of over $119.6 million per year and has been affected by internal power struggles and a corruption scandal. The size of the deal is expected to be around $200 million.

site_title: India can't drill solo to meet oil supply goals: consultant
summary: India needs overseas help to boost oil production from ageing fields to meet its goal of lowering crude imports by 10% by 2022. Wood Mackenzie consultant Neal Anderson says seeking only new discoveries won't meet the timeline, citing a long lead time. India seeks $300 billion in investments over 10 years and is finalizing a policy to encourage producers to increase output from existing fields. The government has relaxed rules and plans to auction bigger areas to encourage investments, with state-owned ONGC working with overseas service companies to reverse a decline in crude oil production.

site_title: Foreign delegates tour upcoming stations for Downtown Line 3
summary: Foreign delegates from China, Japan, and South Korea toured Downtown Line 3 (DTL3) stations in Singapore, inspecting work by their contractors. The 42 km-long DTL, set to open on Oct 21, will be Singapore's longest underground and driverless MRT line, connecting north-western and eastern areas to the Central Business District and Marina Bay. The 16-station line will surpass the 35.7 km Circle Line in length.

site_title: Fairer treatment for the fairer sex
summary: The M1 Singapore Fringe Festival will highlight women's struggles and experiences, running from January 17 to 28. Inspired by artist Amanda Heng's 1999 performance "Let's Walk," the festival will feature 15 works from seven countries, including "The Immortal Sole" by Edith Podesta, which reinterprets "The Little Mermaid" through a contemporary lens. Other notable works include "Hayat" by Pink Gajah Theatre, which explores the politics of the female body, and "Displaced" by Ground Clover Theatre, examining the history of migration and strife through three women's stories.

site_title: Driverless cars are giving engineers a fuel economy headache
summary: Self-driving cars are facing a challenge in meeting fuel economy and carbon emissions targets due to the significant power drain from autonomous technology. Prototype cars consume 2-4 kilowatts of electricity, equivalent to 50-100 laptops, and may not be able to run on battery power alone. To offset this, carmakers are considering hybrid-electric models, such as plug-in hybrid EVs, to extend range and mitigate the impact of autonomous systems on the battery pack. Companies like GM and Tesla are planning to deploy fully autonomous cars in the next few years, but may need to make fuel efficiency gains elsewhere in the vehicles to compensate for the increased power consumption.

images.alt_text: A Chevrolet Bolt electric vehicle. As major markets from California to China ratchet up pressure to curb pollution, carmakers will have to find creative new ways to offset emissions produced by feeding the car's increasingly intelligent brain.
Mr Musk imagines a future where Tesla owners can rent out their autonomous cars as robotaxis when they're not using them.

site_title: IMF chief urges more support for global trade
summary: IMF managing director Christine Lagarde urged global leaders not to reject international trade, citing its benefits despite challenges. The rapid lowering of trade barriers has caused significant dislocation, including job losses and higher inequality. Lagarde emphasized the need for a more inclusive global trading system that works for all. This comes as the US has withdrawn from several trade agreements, including the Trans-Pacific Partnership and the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. With stronger global economic growth, governments can secure the benefits of international trade, boosting living standards and reducing inequality.

site_title: Taiwan fines Qualcomm NT$23.4b for antitrust violations
summary: Qualcomm Inc has been fined NT$23.4 billion (S$1.1 billion) by the Taiwan Fair Trade Commission for antitrust violations, alleging the company had a monopoly over modem technologies and refused to license its technology to other industry players. Qualcomm has disagreed with the decision and plans to challenge it in court. This fine follows similar regulatory challenges in the US, China, and Europe, with allegations that Qualcomm uses its dominant position to charge unfair royalty rates for its patents. The company also faces a global legal battle with Apple over licensing practices.

site_title: Cautious Fed pins US dollar to 2-week low; euro rises
summary: The US dollar reached a two-week low against a broad basket of currencies due to the Fed's cautious outlook on inflation. The dollar was flat at 93.053, its lowest since September 26, as policymakers indicated limited future interest rate increases. The euro rose to a two-week high at $1.1878, driven by strong economic data in the eurozone and the potential for the European Central Bank to wind down its stimulus plan. Industry data from Italy beat forecasts, supporting the euro's rise.

site_title: Mantra rolls out red carpet for Accor's A$1.18b bid
summary: Australia's No 2 hotel company Mantra Group agreed to a $1.18 billion buyout from France-listed Accor, combining the country's top two hotel groups. The deal would give the combined group about 50,000 rooms, or 11% of Australia's hotel market. The offer price is a 23% premium to Mantra's last trade, but the merger needs regulatory approval from the Foreign Investment Review Board and antitrust regulator ACCC. If approved, the merger could put pressure on Australia's third-largest hotel company, Marriott International.

site_title: Trump says his tax plan will help middle class, boost economy
summary: US President Donald Trump announced his tax plan, claiming it will benefit the middle class and boost the economy. The plan, which includes a 20% corporate tax rate and a reduced top individual tax rate, is expected to provide a $4,000 pay raise for the average household. However, critics argue that the plan will mainly benefit corporations and the rich, with the wealthiest Americans potentially seeing a 8.5% increase in after-tax incomes. The plan's details are being worked out by Congress, with a possible vote by January.

site_title: Singapore's hidden home-sharing economy quietly on the rise
summary: Singapore's home-sharing economy is quietly growing despite government restrictions. A surge in tourist arrivals isn't being matched by hotel receipts, suggesting more visitors may be staying in private homes. The Urban Redevelopment Authority has introduced a three-month minimum for private rentals, but a public consultation process has yet to yield a clear consensus. Economists believe home-sharing attracts a new segment of visitors and could benefit local neighborhoods, but the industry's future remains murky as lawmakers debate regulation and taxation.

site_title: Appeal trial for Samsung heir starts in Seoul
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae-Yong is appealing his five-year sentence for bribing former South Korean President Park Geun-Hye. Lee's lawyers claim the payments were donations, while prosecutors argue they were bribes worth 8.9 billion won. The original verdict found Lee guilty of bribery, perjury, and other charges. The appeal trial is ongoing, with a verdict expected by February 2018. Prosecutors are also appealing part of the original verdict, seeking harsher sentences for all five convicted Samsung executives.

site_title: Clock ticks away at UK's Brexit transition options
summary: The UK's Brexit transition options are dwindling, with a March 2019 deadline looming. Negotiators in Brussels are struggling to make progress, with the EU warning that a breakdown in talks could occur if London fails to settle divorce terms by December. The EU is considering a "virtual status quo" transition, where Britain would remain in most EU systems but without voting rights, similar to Norway. Businesses are sounding the alarm, warning of a "very hard Brexit" in 2019 and urging a clear transition agreement by the end of the year.

site_title: Facebook COO meets US govt panel probing Russian ads
summary: The US House Intelligence Committee hopes to release campaign ads purchased by Russians on Facebook as soon as possible after meeting with Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg. The ads, which aimed to stir tension on divisive issues, were created by operatives linked to the Russian government. Facebook has already turned over over 3,000 ads to congressional investigators and plans to scrub personally identifiable information before release. The committee's leaders expressed hope that the ads would be released publicly after a November 1 hearing featuring officials from Facebook, Google, and Twitter.

site_title: Boeing spat puts N Ireland jobs at risk: UK Labour Party
summary: The UK Labour Party accuses Boeing of being a "subsidy junkie" and of ruining Bombardier, a Canadian aircraft manufacturer, after the US imposed 300% duties on Bombardier's C Series aircraft. The dispute threatens thousands of jobs in Northern Ireland, where Boeing has a significant presence. Labour's trade spokesman, Barry Gardiner, plans to investigate whether Boeing's contract with Monarch Airlines Ltd, which filed for insolvency, constitutes an anti-dumping case. The move puts pressure on Prime Minister Theresa May to protect Bombardier jobs while also pursuing a trade deal with the US.

site_title: New carbon tax 'could boost Singapore's edge'
summary: Singapore's upcoming carbon tax may boost the country's economic competitiveness by emphasizing energy-efficient and low-carbon growth. Environment Minister Masagos Zulkifli stated that companies must stay ahead to stay competitive, despite initial concerns. The carbon tax, set to affect 30-40 emitters, aims to cut emissions and improve energy efficiency. ExxonMobil's new co-generation plant, launched on Thursday, is expected to cut emissions by 265 kilotons and improve energy efficiency by 4-5%. The government aims to cut emissions intensity by 36% by 2030, despite global uncertainties.

site_title: Facebook touts US$199 Oculus Go VR headset in mainstream push
summary: Facebook has unveiled a US$199 Oculus Go wireless virtual reality headset, aiming to make VR technology more accessible to the masses. The new headset will be available in early 2018 and is designed to be light and comfortable. Facebook also trimmed the price of its high-end Oculus Rift headset and controllers by US$100, to US$399. CEO Mark Zuckerberg believes VR will enable remote connections and experiences, and the company plans to reach one billion people in virtual reality, with a focus on gaming, social networking, and immersive experiences.

site_title: China gobbles Amazon rainforest ore to clean its polluted skies
summary: China is increasing its demand for high-grade iron ore from the Amazon rainforest to clean its polluted skies, leading to a surge in exports from Brazil. Vale SA, a leading Brazilian mining company, is shifting production to develop more high-grade deposits in the Amazon, despite environmental concerns. The move is driven by China's efforts to reduce pollution and improve air quality, as well as Vale's need to reduce debt. Brazil's exports of iron ore are expected to reach a record 460 million tonnes by 2021, but environmentalists warn that the increased mining activity could lead to further damage to the world's largest rainforest.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan set sights on next bank crisis
summary: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan are offering derivatives that enable investors to bet on or against high-risk bank bonds, which financial regulators can wipe out in case of a banking crisis. These total-return swaps, tied to AT1 notes, allow investors to hedge against potential losses or gains, with the average yield on the debt being around 4.8%. The market for AT1 notes has ballooned to $150 billion, with some investors seeking to protect themselves from potential price drops or another banking crisis.

site_title: Singapore's fund management industry faces stiff challenges ahead
summary: Singapore's fund management industry faces significant challenges, with assets rising only 3% in 2016 to S$2.7 trillion, despite a strong asset market performance. Alternative assets, including hedge funds and private equity, grew 17% in 2016, but net inflows were the lowest in five years at S$116 billion. The industry's muted growth is puzzling, given Singapore's growing affluence and need for retirement savings. Private bank clients prefer offshore funds, and clients are shifting to passive indexed mandates, making it challenging for active managers to attract assets.

site_title: Bitcoin bursts through US$5,000 for first time
summary: Bitcoin has reached a new record high of $5,183.97, breaking the $5,000 threshold for the first time since its launch in 2009. The surge comes as the cryptocurrency's community of users controls and regulates the currency, but also raises concerns about speculative trading and potential abuse by criminals.

site_title: Bewitched by animated fantasy's charms
summary: Studio Ghibli's youngest director, Hiromasa Yonebayashi, has released Mary And The Witch's Flower, a charming animated adventure based on Mary Stewart's children's book. The film, directed by Yonebayashi, follows Mary, a clumsy but kind redhead who discovers a magical land inhabited by witches and sorcerers. The film pays tribute to Ghibli's female-led fantasies, with elaborate hand-painted backgrounds and a visual feast. Despite being a nod to similar films, Mary And The Witch's Flower stands on its own as a delightful adaptation that showcases the spirit of Ghibli lives on outside the studio.

site_title: Royalville in Bukit Timah priced at S$368m in collective sale
summary: Royalville, a 16,181.5 sq m prime freehold residential site in Bukit Timah Road, has been launched for a collective sale by owners asking for S$368 million. The land rate is estimated at S$1,376 psf ppr, potentially translating to a breakeven price of S$1,950-2,100 psf and selling price in the range of S$2,150-2,500 psf. The site, which comprises 93 residential units and 11 shop units, is zoned residential with a gross plot ratio of 1.4 under Master Plan 2014, and is within 260 metres of Sixth Avenue MRT Station.

site_title: Inspiring other women with their real-life stories
summary: 61-year-old Office manager Molly Lim is making her stage debut in "Women of WINGS: Their Stories, Our Inspiration," a theatre production celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Society of WINGS, a non-profit empowering women aged 40+. The show features real-life stories of 12 women, including popular artists and actresses, and aims to inspire women to live happy, healthy, and financially secure lives. Directed by Jeffrey Tan, the production is a "big celebration" that showcases the women's resilience and determination.

site_title: Oxley to issue 22.75m shares via placement at S$0.59 apiece
summary: Oxley Holdings Ltd has entered into a placement agreement with Maybank Kim Eng Securities to issue 22.75 million treasury shares at S$0.59 apiece, representing a 8.3% discount to the volume weighted average price. The placement is expected to raise S$12.95 million in net cash proceeds, primarily for working capital purposes. The shares will account for approximately 0.77% of Oxley's issued share capital. The move aims to increase the liquidity of its shares.

site_title: Banks drive ST Index's 22.8-point advance
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 22.81 points to 3,303.09, driven by gains from the three major banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, amid expectations of a US interest rate hike in December. The US Federal Open Markets Committee minutes showed a strong economy and potential for a third rate hike in 2017. Implied probability of a December rate hike rose to 76.7%, boosting bank stocks.

site_title: What's needed for digital transformation
summary: Companies must address key areas such as customer experience, agility, vision, and ecosystem development to successfully embark on digital transformation. However, many organizations are struggling, with 40% of Fortune 500 companies predicted to cease existence in 10 years due to the digital revolution. Digital transformation requires new knowledge and checks, rather than simply adopting new technology. Failing to adapt can lead to significant consequences, emphasizing the need for timely and effective digital transformation strategies.

site_title: Making financial disclosures more readable
summary: Financial disclosure documents are often wordy and difficult to understand, making it hard for investors to make informed decisions. To improve readability, companies should use plain English when drafting documents, presenting information in a clear and concise manner, and keeping the length short without compromising accuracy. Regulators worldwide, including the SEC and MAS, have encouraged the use of plain English. Readability formulas, such as the Bog Index, can measure the difficulty of a text and provide insights into the readability of financial disclosures. A study found that while most companies fare reasonably well, more can be done to enhance readability and ensure that information is easily understandable to investors.

site_title: Lloyds buys Zurich UK's pensions, savings business
summary: Lloyds Banking Group has agreed to buy Zurich Insurance's UK workplace pensions and savings business for an undisclosed price. The deal is part of Lloyds' expansion into retirement services, following rule changes allowing pensioners to spend their pension pots more freely. The Zurich UK business has £15 billion in assets under administration and 500,000 customers. Around 200 Zurich employees will transfer to Lloyds, and the deal will give Zurich distribution rights for group life protection to Lloyds' corporate clients.

site_title: Asean steps up efforts on seamless sea and sky
summary: The 23rd Asean Transport Ministers Meeting in Singapore focused on integrating the region's air, ship, and land borders. Leaders pledged to further liberalize air services and sign a pact to facilitate cross-border bus transport services. The Asean Framework Agreement on the Facilitation of Cross-Border Transport of Passengers by Road Vehicles will simplify requirements for cross-border bus transport. The goal is to create an extensive, efficient, and well-integrated Asean, enabling freer flow of people, trade, and commerce within and beyond the region.

images.alt_text: From left: Setia Haji Mustappa bin Haji Sirat (Brunei), Hiroshi Narahira (Japan), Arkhom Termpittayapaisith (Thailand), Liow Tiong Lai (Malaysia), Lim Hong Hin (Asean), Khaw Boon Wan (Singapore), Sun Chanthol (Cambodia), Arthur Tugade (Philippines), U Thant Sin Maung (Myanmar), Bounchanh Sinthavong (Laos), Budi Karya Sumadi (Indonesia), Le Dinh Tho (Vietnam) and Dai Dongchang (China).

site_title: YuuZoo's long reply still does not address issues over its response to SGX queries
summary: A Singaporean journalist, Mak Yuen Teen, criticizes YuuZoo Corporation's corporate governance practices, citing issues with its response to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and its incorporation in Bermuda. YuuZoo's CEO, Mohandas, responds with a lengthy letter, claiming Teen's criticisms are unfounded and taken out of context. Teen argues that YuuZoo's responses to SGX queries have been contradictory and unhelpful, and that the company's incorporation in Bermuda raises concerns about regulatory oversight. Teen's criticism is aimed at alerting investors to corporate governance risks at YuuZoo, which has seen its share price decline since its listing in 2014.

site_title: CPPIB invests up to US$350m in Keppel's data centre fund
summary: Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) has invested up to US$350 million in Keppel's data centre fund, Alpha Data Centre Fund (ADCF), doubling the fund's initial target size to up to US$1 billion. The fund's total assets under management could reach US$2.3 billion when fully leveraged and invested. The investment aims to tap into the growing demand for quality data centre space in the Asia-Pacific region, where digital infrastructure is relatively under-developed.

site_title: Will minority owners of M&C bite?
summary: City Developments (CDL), the majority owner of Millennium & Copthorne (M&C), plans to buy the remaining 34.8% stake in the London-listed hotel chain for £624.3 million (S$1.1 billion), valuing the hotel group at £1.8 billion. Minority shareholders will receive 552.5 pence in cash for each share. The move is seen as attractive, with CDL's share price climbing steadily from S$11.75 to around S$12.20. Analysts consider the offer fair and reasonable, but minority shareholders' decision to accept remains uncertain.

site_title: Stagnant spending drives Japan's retailers to shop for growth abroad
summary: Japanese retailers Fast Retailing Co and Seven & i Holdings Co are expanding abroad to drive growth due to stagnant spending and soft wage growth at home.
