summary: The Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency (IREDA) listed a 5-year green rupee-denominated bond, raising 19.5 billion rupees (S$405.43 million) with an annualised coupon of 7.125%. The bond's listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) marks 75% of listed Masala bonds by Indian issuers being listed on the bourse, with over 80% of listed offshore bonds valued at US$66 billion. IREDA plans to continue capital raising initiatives in the bond market to support India's renewable energy sector.

site_title: Hot chips expected to make Samsung's Q3 profit sizzle
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is expected to forecast a record third quarter profit on Friday, driven by strong demand for memory chips and mobile earnings. The company's mobile division is expected to post an operating profit of about 3 trillion won, up from 100 billion won in the third quarter of 2016. The success of the Galaxy Note 8 smartphone and brisk sales of the latest model are expected to boost Samsung's performance further. Analysts predict a 14.3 trillion won operating profit for the July-September period, nearly three times the profit of the same period last year.

site_title: What more can be done to take the market forward?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) proposes changes to give greater flexibility to trading representatives and broking firms, aiming to increase investor participation and attract new listings. However, critics argue that the market is over-regulated and needs more investment-worthy listings, particularly in sectors such as technology and healthcare. The government must strike a balance between enforcement and quality control to address concerns about speculative behavior and restore confidence among investors. To boost the market, SGX should consider listing large local enterprises and amending listing rules to accommodate new economy-type tech startups and companies catering to the needs of millennials.

site_title: Home rental market remains subdued in Sept: SRX Property
summary: Singapore's housing rental market remained subdued in September, with SRX Property data showing a 0.1% drop in non-landed residential rents, led by the city-fringe region. Analysts expect rents to stabilize next year when the supply of completed units tapers off. Despite this, HDB flat rents fell 0.9% in September, with some landlords offering incentives to keep rents unchanged. The vacancy rates are expected to improve next year, with rents of both private homes and HDB flats expected to bottom out by the end of 2018.

site_title: STI ends lower in another muted session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended lower on Wednesday, falling 8.67 points to 3,280.28, despite the Dow Jones Industrial Average hitting its 47th all-time high in the US. Traders attributed the lack of reaction to the Dow's milestone to a lack of correlation between US and Singapore markets. The turnover figures were also low, with S$1.1 billion traded on two billion units. All three major banks weakened, while City Developments Ltd's stock rose after announcing a bid to take its London-listed hotel subsidiary private. Experts predict a complex and potentially contentious tax reform process in the US, which may impact global markets.

site_title: EU banking system now in better shape: ECB official
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) official, Andreas Dombret, says the EU banking system is now in better shape, with eurozone banks having built up more capital and liquidity since the 2008 financial crisis. The economy is growing, with real GDP expected to grow at 2.2% this year, and employment, investment, and consumer confidence are improving. However, deposit insurance remains a missing piece, with no common European scheme in place, due to differences in economic and legal realities among EU countries. Brexit poses uncertainty for the financial industry, with banks preparing for a potential hard Brexit.

site_title: Singapore accountants 'unprepared for the future'
summary: A study by CPA Australia and EY found that Singapore's accounting and finance professionals are unprepared for the future, with 8 in 10 lacking the skills to meet job demands in the next decade. The current curriculum is deemed inadequate, and organizations are not supporting efforts to develop future-ready skills. The top drivers of change identified include digital technologies, business-model disruptions, and increased regulation. To address this, CPA Australia launched a training program, "Finance for the Future," in partnership with NTUC and the Employment and Employability Institute, to expand technical skills and business competencies.

site_title: Here's why you can't afford a house, Bank Negara tells Malaysians
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia has stated that houses are not affordable due to rising prices, with the median house price being 4.4 times the median annual household income. The central bank claims that access to financing is not the issue, but rather the need for stricter lending rules to curb speculation and promote responsible lending. The bank has left borrowing costs unchanged at 3% and has resisted calls to loosen mortgage lending. Despite this, the housing market remains unaffordable, with only half of people in Kuala Lumpur owning a home, and the median age of Malaysia's population is 28 years, indicating a growing demand for housing.

site_title: Big payout for Springsteen as Broadway run begins
summary: Bruce Springsteen's Broadway show, "Springsteen on Broadway," grossed US$2.33 million from its first five performances, earning more than 26 other shows. The show's average ticket price was US$497, the highest on Broadway, with some seats sold for US$850. The run, which began October 3 and ends February 3, is sold out, and discounted tickets are available through a digital lottery. The strong performance is part of a banner season on Broadway, with overall grosses up 20% and attendance up 6% compared to last season.

site_title: New Silkroutes shares pick up on dental clinic acquisitions
summary: New Silkroutes Group's shares rose 6.3% to close at 42 Singapore cents after its subsidiary acquired a 70% stake in three dental clinics in Singapore. The acquisition is part of Healthsciences International's expansion into the healthcare business. In a separate filing, the company's auditor expressed uncertainty about prepayments made to a supplier and an outstanding amount due from the disposal of subsidiaries. Meanwhile, NSG announced a subscription agreement with an investor to issue 3.068 million new shares, boosting its capital and expected to be completed by October 30.

site_title: Wildfires could give California wines smoky taste
summary: Wildfires in northern California's Napa Valley and Sonoma regions damaged or destroyed at least 13 wineries, but smoke from the fires may pose a greater risk to the remaining grapes. Exposure to heavy smoke can alter the grape's chemistry, resulting in a smoky taste and aroma, particularly in red grapes. Experts estimate that up to a third of the crop remains on the vines, and some vintners have already begun harvesting. The impact of smoke on the wine industry may be more significant due to the trend of "hang time" in grape harvesting, which can intensify the effects of smoke over time.

site_title: BMW eyes China JV with Great Wall Motor: source
summary: BMW is considering a joint venture with Great Wall Motor in China, with the possibility of opening an assembly plant in Changshu. The venture would be BMW's second in China and follows a similar partnership with Brilliance China Automotive. The move aims to stay ahead of rival Mercedes-Benz in China's premium car market. Great Wall's shares surged 14% after the news, while Brilliance's shares declined 2.76%. The deal is seen as BMW's response to increased competition in the market, with China targeting electric and hybrid cars to make up 20% of sales by 2025.

site_title: BlackRock names former Obama aide to run sustainable investing
summary: BlackRock has appointed Brian Deese, a former senior Obama administration official, to run its sustainable investing strategies. Deese, 39, led environmental initiatives for the Obama White House and will report to Richard Kushel. This move comes as ethical investing has become one of the fastest-growing strategies on Wall Street, with global socially responsible investments reaching $23 trillion by 2016. The platform will be renamed BlackRock Sustainable Investing, with Deborah Winshel focusing on philanthropy commitments.

site_title: Nafta talks hit contentious phase as Canadian PM fights for trade pact
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is set to meet with US President Donald Trump and lawmakers to discuss the modernization of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) amidst contentious new US demands. The US is seeking to sharply increase content requirements for autos and auto parts, trade experts say this proposal will likely stall the talks. Trudeau aims to remind Trump of the trade pact's merits and find areas of agreement to improve outcomes for both countries. The talks, which began in 2017, are at risk of collapse due to aggressive US demands.

site_title: Tax cuts to spur growth, consumption in KL Budget 2018?
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister is set to table the 2018 Budget, which may include tax cuts to spur economic growth and consumption. Analysts suggest a cut in corporate taxes could increase business competitiveness and encourage investments, while a reduction in personal taxes could boost private consumption. Some propose lowering individual income tax rates by 1-2% and increasing tax reliefs for corporations. However, a one-per-cent cut in corporate taxes is expected to result in significant revenue loss, estimated at RM2.5 billion.

site_title: Election compass to continue directing Malaysia's policies
summary: Malaysia's next general election is uncertain, but Prime Minister Najib Razak is expected to call for elections before August 2018, capitalizing on the fragmented but formidable opposition. The economy, which has grown 5.8% in the second quarter, will be a key factor, but Najib faces challenges from his mentor-turned-opponent, Mahathir Mohamad, and the fractured opposition coalition. The election will be a high-stakes, knife-edge battle, with Najib battling a corruption scandal and rising concerns over the cost of living and economy. The election is likely to shape Malaysia's policies, with the government expected to direct its policies by the election compass until the polls.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei stock index closes at 21-year high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 stock index closed at a 21-year high, reaching 20,881.27, driven by a global equities rally. The index rose 0.28% or 57.76 points. This marks its best finish since December 1996. The Japanese market follows US counterparts, which hit fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Nafta talks to resume amid US-Canada aircraft dispute
summary: US-Canada trade talks resumed amid a dispute over Bombardier aircraft. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with US President Donald Trump at the White House, while negotiations on the North American Free Trade Agreement continued in Arlington, Virginia. The US seeks retaliatory import duties on Bombardier aircraft, claiming Canadian government subsidies. The talks aim to revamp the landmark trade pact.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says to cut taxes, ease housing crunch in maiden policy address
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced in her maiden policy address that the city will cut company profits tax to 8.25% for the first $2 million of earnings, aiming to ease the housing crunch. She also plans to increase land supply and launch a new housing scheme to help families buy flats, addressing the city's astronomical housing prices.

site_title: Tennis - Kyrgios fined US$10,000 for Shanghai walk off
summary: Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios has been fined $10,000 and deducted $21,000 for walking off the court during his first-round loss to Steve Johnson at the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios cited a stomach bug and shoulder problem as reasons for his abrupt exit. This is not his first disciplinary action, as he was previously fined $16,500 and banned for eight weeks for deliberately throwing a game last year.

site_title: Malaysia shares close lower
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.92 points to 1,757.21, closing lower on Wednesday. The index had 420 losers and 419 gainers, with a total of 3.17 billion shares traded for RM2.31 billion.

site_title: Sterling flat after gains as doubts resurface
summary: Sterling remains flat despite two sessions of gains, as doubts resurface about the UK's interest rate hike expectations amidst uncertain Brexit negotiations. UK manufacturing output rose 0.4% in August, beating forecasts, but futures markets still price in 50 basis points of Bank of England rate increases over the next year, the most in the developed world apart from Canada.

site_title: Alibaba launches US$15b global R&D programme, to open lab in Singapore
summary: Alibaba launched a US$15 billion global research program, the Alibaba DAMO Academy, to advance cutting-edge technology and narrow the technology gap worldwide. The program, led by CTO Jeff Zhang, will open research labs in seven markets, including Singapore, the US, and China. Over the next three years, Alibaba expects to invest heavily in research and development, aiming to increase technological collaboration globally. The initiative seeks to make the world more inclusive by bridging the technology gap.

site_title: Europe:Madrid stock market jumps at open
summary: Madrid's stock market surged 1.57% at open on Wednesday following Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont's announcement that independence talks with the Spanish government would be suspended. This move allowed for a tentative initial gain in other European markets, including the London FTSE 100, Frankfurt's DAX 30, and Paris's CAC 40. Analysts believe Catalan separatists are open to discussion, potentially easing tensions and bolstering investor confidence.

site_title: Toshiba removed from watchlist at Tokyo stock exchange
summary: Toshiba Corp has been removed from the Tokyo stock exchange's watchlist for delisting after demonstrating improved internal controls and corporate governance following an accounting scandal in 2015. The company has made progress in its bookkeeping and disclosed significant losses in its nuclear business. However, Toshiba still faces the risk of delisting if it fails to meet listing requirements, including maintaining negative shareholders equity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day lower, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 0.36% to 28,389.57, following a disappointing policy address from new chief executive Carrie Lam, who failed to outline plans to boost land supply. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.16%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.18%. The market reaction was largely driven by investor expectations of a boost in land supply, which was not met in Lam's address.

site_title: Singtel, Ericsson to invest S$2m over 3 years to spearhead Singapore's 5G development
summary: Singtel and Ericsson have partnered to establish a Centre of Excellence in Singapore, investing S$2 million over three years to develop the city-state's 5G mobile network infrastructure. The centre aims to support Singapore's Smart Nation initiatives and facilitate knowledge sharing among telcos. 5G is expected to roll out globally from 2020, and the centre's goal is to help industries understand the transformational value of 5G.

site_title: Singapore's death penalty reform flawed: Amnesty
summary: Amnesty International has criticized Singapore's death penalty reform as flawed, stating that courts still impose death sentences on individuals who could show more leniency. Despite a decrease in death sentences, judges have discretion to impose life imprisonment only after public prosecutors decide who meets the criteria, a process described as "murky and non-transparent." The group urges the government to end capital punishment, citing examples of low-level drug offenders being sentenced to death.

site_title: Asian shares hit decade highs, Catalan fears ease
summary: Asian shares reached decade highs on October 11, 2017, driven by Wall Street's record highs and concerns about the US dollar. The euro surged to a 10-day peak after Catalonia's leader suspended plans to leave Spain, easing euro zone stability concerns. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.5% to 546.38, with Australian and South Korean stocks also reaching record highs. The International Monetary Fund upgraded its global economic growth forecast, boosting investor sentiment.

site_title: Tech mergers and acquisitions to hold strong over next 12 months: poll
summary: Tech M&A activity is expected to remain strong over the next year, with 51% of respondents anticipating an increase in deal flow compared to the previous year. Despite a slowdown in global tech and telecom deals in the first three quarters, dealmakers attribute this to "less shopping by corporate acquirers" due to pricey valuations and less suitable targets. Mainstays like IBM are cited as examples of companies finding it challenging to acquire suitable targets.

site_title: Hong Kong developer stocks fall as Lam's speech skirts land issue
summary: Hong Kong developer stocks declined after Chief Executive Carrie Lam's maiden policy speech failed to address the land supply issue, a key concern for the city's affordable housing market. Lam vowed to introduce "starter homes" for first-time buyers, but details on how to increase land supply were not provided. Investors had expected Lam to speed up the conversion of agricultural land for residential developments, which would benefit property developers. Lam's speech did include other initiatives to ease social tensions, but its impact on the property market was limited.

site_title: Veteran corporate banker Eddy Henning joins ING Bank
summary: ING Bank appointed Eddy Henning as head of Corporate Client Coverage, Transaction Services and Corporate Finance Asia, effective January 1, 2018. Henning, a veteran corporate banker, joins ING after 28 years at Deutsche Bank, where he held positions including Apac head of MNC Coverage in Singapore. He will provide senior banker coverage for Asian corporate clients and help grow ING's outbound activities to Europe, succeeding Manuel R Salak III, who retired in July 2017.

site_title: Singapore bunker fuel supplier Uni Petroleum does not renew licence
summary: Singapore-based marine fuel supplier Uni Petroleum Pte Ltd did not apply to renew its supply licence, marking its departure from the market. This is the third supplier to leave the market this year, following Panoil Petroleum and Universal Energy, which had their licenses revoked due to regulatory violations. With 55 licensed bunker fuel suppliers remaining, the departure is expected to have little impact on the market. Uni Petroleum was the 45th largest bunker fuel supplier in Singapore in 2016.

site_title: Philips suspends production of defibrillators for US market
summary: Philips, a Dutch electronics giant, has temporarily suspended production of defibrillators for the US market to allow closer inspections by the FDA. The decision, reached after talks with the Department of Justice, is not related to product quality and poses no health risk to patients. The production halt is expected to last until mid-2018 and may cut earnings by 20 million euros. Philips will continue to produce defibrillators for export at its US plants but will halt manufacture for the US domestic market.

site_title: Banyan Tree to run new Mandai eco-friendly resort by 2023
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings plans to open its first Singapore resort in Mandai by 2023. The 4.6-hectare resort will be part of an integrated nature and wildlife project, sharing facilities with the existing Singapore Zoo. The design and operation will prioritize environmentally sound principles, offering the first full-service accommodation option in the area. The resort will be jointly developed by Mandai Park Holdings and Banyan Tree, with existing wildlife park facilities relocated for the project.

site_title: Malaysian sultans in rare intervention on intolerance
summary: Malaysia's nine state sultans have issued a rare statement expressing concern over rising intolerance in the multi-ethnic country. They urged people to follow the principles set out in the country's constitution, which emphasize respect for everyone regardless of faith or ethnicity. The statement comes after controversy over laundrettes banning non-Muslim customers. The sultans emphasized the importance of unity and harmony among citizens, highlighting their commitment to issues of unity and harmony in a multi-ethnic and multi-religious country.

site_title: EU revises plan on banking safety net to win over Germany
summary: The European Commission has proposed revised measures to strengthen the EU banking sector, aiming to win over Germany, the largest EU economy. The plan, softer than initially proposed, reduces the sharing of banking risks and proposes stricter conditions for access to EU-level safety nets. The European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) would intervene only after national insurance schemes are fully used, reducing the financial burden on individual member states. The plan should be agreed upon by next year and aims to increase market confidence and protect savers in the event of a major banking crisis.

site_title: SPH grows net profit 32% in FY17, but will hasten job cuts as media business struggles
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 32% increase in net profit to S$350.1 million in FY17, driven by a gain from a partial divestment and a fair-value gain from investment properties. However, operating revenue shrank by 8.2% to S$1.0 billion, mainly due to a decline in media business revenue. The company will accelerate job cuts, reducing 230 jobs, to deal with challenges in its core media business. SPH will also invest in digital capabilities and data analytics to enhance its operations.

site_title: BMW eyes China joint venture with Great Wall-source
summary: BMW is reportedly considering a joint venture with Chinese automaker Great Wall Motor, potentially opening an assembly plant in Changshu, China. The move would be BMW's second joint venture in China, following its existing partnership with Brilliance China Automotive Holdings. A joint venture with Great Wall would allow BMW to operate in China without requiring a majority stake, as foreign carmakers must partner with local companies. The exact details of the proposed venture are unclear, but it would mark a significant expansion for BMW in the world's largest auto market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore finance professionals are not equipped for the future, with 8 in 10 saying they lack skills to meet job requirements in the next decade. The current curriculum is also deemed inadequate. Non-landed private home rents fell 0.1% in September, while HDB rents dropped 0.9%. Singtel and Ericsson are investing S$2 million to develop Singapore's 5G mobile network infrastructure. Despite a recent slowdown, tech M&A is expected to remain strong over the next year. Foreign companies can re-domiciliate to Singapore under a new inward re-domiciliation regime.

site_title: Australia's corporate watchdog to investigate interest-only home loans
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog will investigate individual home loan records to ensure mortgage providers aren't selling interest-only loans that favor speculative investors and drive rapid housing price gains. Regulators have intensified pressure on major banks to slow lending amid concerns about excessive debt in the property market. The investigation aims to prevent financial stability risks and excessive debt.

site_title: Genting Singapore markets debut Samurai bonds
summary: Genting Singapore has launched its maiden Samurai bonds, a yen-denominated debt instrument with three tranches: a three-year fixed tranche priced at yen offer-side swaps plus 45-55bp, a five-year tranche at plus 55-65bp, and a seven-year tranche at plus 75-85bp. The bonds are rated A3/A- (Moody's/Fitch) and are expected to earn an A from R&I, offering investors a relatively stable and secure investment opportunity.

site_title: Saudi preparing tougher rules for insurers - sources
summary: Saudi Arabia's central bank is preparing new, tougher rules for insurance companies as part of efforts to create a smaller number of stronger market players. The proposed changes, set to be introduced in the coming months, will require insurers to significantly boost capital and improve internal risk controls. Current requirements of 100 million Saudi riyals will likely be increased, aiming to trigger industry consolidation and force weaker companies to merge with stronger ones. The move follows the sector's struggles, including health insurance suffering due to expatriate departures and rising hospital costs.

site_title: Picasso's mansion set to sell for 20m euros
summary: Picasso's French Riviera mansion, where his last wife tragically shot herself, is set to be sold at an auction for over 20 million euros. The 18th-century estate, which had belonged to the Guinness brewing family and was visited by Winston Churchill, features Picasso's studio, but no original artwork remains. The sale comes after a Dutch owner's financial difficulties led to the estate being put up for auction. A Sri Lankan financier had initially offered 20.1 million euros, but the sale will be finalized under the eyes of a judge if the price is met.

site_title: Samsung beware: Korea lays welcome mat for activist shareholders
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in has met with overseas investors to change perceptions that the country's markets favor family-run conglomerates, known as chaebol. The government aims to take on these dynasties, which have dominated Korea's economy for decades. A new bureau will investigate chaebol activities, and the pension fund will have a greater say at shareholder meetings. The goal is to attract more aggressive and long-term foreign investors, who have been passive in Korea due to concerns about the market's favoritism towards local companies.

site_title: Two-Michelin-starred Restaurant Andre to close next year
summary: Two-Michelin-starred restaurant Andre, run by Taiwan-born chef Andre Chiang, will close its doors on February 14 next year after its seventh anniversary. The decision comes after Chiang expressed his satisfaction with the restaurant's achievements, including being ranked No. 14 on the World's 50 Best Restaurants list. Chiang also wishes to "return" his Michelin stars and not be included in the 2024 guide, making him the first Singapore restaurant to do so. The last service will be held on February 14.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit record high on bullish expectations for Q3 earnings
summary: South Korean stocks reached a record high on Wednesday, driven by expectations of robust third-quarter earnings from companies like Samsung Electronics. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,458.16 points, a one-per-cent gain, with Samsung Electronics climbing 3.5% for a third consecutive session. The tech giant's shares ended at a record high of 2,732,000 Korean won. This boost in market sentiment is attributed to strong earnings forecasts for the third quarter.

site_title: Accrelist to raise S$4m via proposed share placement to support e-medical and e-wallet initiatives
summary: Accrelist, a systems integration specialist, plans to raise S$4 million through two equal tranches of S$2 million each in proposed new share placements to support e-medical and e-wallet initiatives. 75% of the funds will be used for mergers and acquisitions in the e-medical arena, while 25% will be used for working capital purposes for its subsidiary, WE Pay. The company will issue 500 million shares at S$0.008 per share, with half going to investor Liu Song and the other half to Summit Planners Advisory Group. The placement is subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Driverless cars are giving engineers a fuel economy headache
summary: Driverless cars face a fuel economy headache due to their high power consumption. Prototypes consume 2-4 kilowatts, equivalent to 50-100 laptops, and may not be able to run solely on battery power. This poses a challenge for automakers to meet emissions targets and fuel economy standards. To offset the issue, some experts suggest using gasoline-electric hybrid models, while others propose using plug-in hybrid EVs with an additional gasoline engine. Automakers, such as GM and Ford, are planning to deploy their first fully self-driving cars in the next few years, and will need to find creative solutions to address the power-hungry needs of autonomous systems.

site_title: Despite sanctions, Russian organisations acquire Microsoft software
summary: Despite US sanctions, Russian state organisations and firms have acquired Microsoft software, according to official documents. The acquisitions were made through fictitious data and exploited a gap in Microsoft's ability to track sales. The sanctions, imposed in 2014 over Russia's annexation of Crimea, are not effectively enforced, highlighting the limitations of foreign governments in enforcing sanctions.

site_title: Australia shares reach highest in nearly 8 weeks; NZ keeps setting records
summary: Australian shares reached their highest in nearly 8 weeks on October 11, 2017, driven by financial and industrial stocks and a strong domestic consumer confidence reading. The gains were aided by a lift in the Australian dollar. Global investors were buying into the Aussie exposure, according to a market strategist. The upbeat reading was a result of a survey by the Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 0.19 points to 1,761.68. Gainers outnumbered losers 135 to 48, with a total volume of 90.17 million lots worth RM28.1 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong shares continued their upward trend on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.46% to 28,622.01. This follows a record close the previous day. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.50 points to 3,381.49. The US stock market also reached fresh records, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Green Masala bond listing spices up SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) welcomed the latest "Masala" green bond listing by the Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency (IREDA), raising 19.5 billion rupees through a five-year bond with an annualised coupon of 7.125%. This listing increases the percentage of listed Masala bonds by Indian issuers on the bourse to 75%.

site_title: New regime allows foreign companies to re-domicile to Singapore
summary: Singapore has introduced an inward re-domiciliation regime, allowing foreign companies to transfer their registration from their home jurisdiction to Singapore. This change, made to the Companies Act in March, enables companies to re-domicile in Singapore instead of setting up a subsidiary. The new regime is effective starting Wednesday and is expected to attract more foreign companies to the city-state.

site_title: North Korea hackers stole South Korea-US military plans to wipe out its leadership
summary: North Korea hackers allegedly stole 235 gigabytes of classified military documents from South Korea's Defence Integrated Data Centre in September 2016. The documents included wartime operational plans to wipe out the North Korean leadership. The South Korean government confirmed the hack in May 2017, with a lawmaker stating that the stolen information includes South Korea-US military plans. The North Korean hack is believed to have been carried out by North Korean hackers.

site_title: Singapore shares inch up in early trading on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% in early trading on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,298.47. About 127.1 million shares changed hands, with Rowsley being the most actively traded counter. The gains followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while global markets also reached record highs, with the Dow and S&P 500 up 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore Sept non-landed private home rents dip 0.1%; HDB rents fall 0.9%: SRX
summary: Singapore's non-landed private home rents fell 0.1% in September, while HDB rents decreased 0.9%, according to SRX Property. Rental volumes for non-landed homes dropped 12.6% to 3,799 units, and HDB rentals fell 1.6% to 1,625 units. These declines are attributed to lower demand, with the Core Central Region seeing a 0.4% increase and the Outside Central Region a 0.8% increase.

site_title: Emirates to quit some New Zealand flights as part of new Qantas pact
summary: Emirates plans to end most of its flights between Australia and New Zealand as part of a renegotiated joint venture with Qantas Airways, allowing the airlines to leverage their network strengths. Qantas will quit flying to Dubai and add more flights from Melbourne and Brisbane to Auckland. Emirates will retain a daily Sydney-Christchurch flight and evaluate potential new direct services between Dubai and New Zealand. The changes are part of a win-win arrangement, with Qantas in a stronger financial position than Emirates.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Trendlines, China Jishan, Lafe, SUTL
summary: Trendlines Group proposed a S$14.03 million placement of new shares and strategic review to cut costs. China Jishan Holdings called off a real estate unit disposal, preventing the SGX from considering it a cash business. Lafe Corp chairman Christopher Ho's general offer for shares is now unconditional after receiving enough acceptances. SUTL Enterprise secured its second management contract in China for an integrated marina project.

site_title: US Navy says deadly McCain collision near Singapore was preventable, relieves ship commander
summary: The US Navy has attributed the deadly collision of the USS John S McCain with a merchant ship near Singapore in August to poor judgment by the commanding officer and poor leadership by the executive officer. The incident, which killed 10 sailors, is part of a spate of US naval collisions this year. The Navy has relieved the ship's commander and his deputy from their duties in response to the incident. This leadership shake-up comes as the US Navy navigates increased tensions with North Korea and operations in the South China Sea.

site_title: US dollar wavers on US tax overhaul worries, euro hits 12-day high
summary: The US dollar weakened against the euro, reaching a 12-day high, amid concerns over President Trump's tax overhaul plan. The euro rose 0.15% to $1.1824, while the dollar edged away from a 10-week high. Speculation that the tax plan may stall contributed to the dollar's decline. Stronger-than-expected US wages data previously lifted the dollar to a seven-week low.

site_title: Air, land pacts to be signed at 23rd Asean Transport Ministers Meeting
summary: Transport ministers from 10 Asean member states and three dialogue partner countries are set to sign air and land transport agreements in Singapore on October 12-13. The agreements aim to liberalize air travel, enhance tourism, investment, and people-to-people connectivity. The agreements also focus on improving air safety and efficiency. This marks Singapore's hosting of the 23rd Asean Transport Ministers Meeting, the first since 2007. The meeting involves around 200 delegates and aims to strengthen regional cooperation in transport. The agreements are expected to be adopted by the end of the meeting.

site_title: Volvo East Asia wins LTA tender for 50 diesel hybrid buses
summary: Volvo East Asia won a tender from the Land Transport Authority (LTA) for 50 diesel hybrid buses worth S$30 million. The buses, to be rolled out by mid-2018, will help the LTA assess operational challenges in Singapore's tropical climate and aid in vehicle maintenance. This move aims to build a greener bus fleet, contributing to the transport authority's efforts to reduce emissions.

site_title: Customers are still the centre of digital innovation
summary: Industry leaders emphasize the importance of prioritizing customers in digital innovation strategies, as technology advancements and disruption are inevitable. CEOs and experts advise organizations to adopt a customer-centric approach, leveraging technology to enhance customer experience and create value. Collaboration with start-ups, innovators, and data analytics are key to transforming businesses and achieving competitive advantage. Having the right mindset, measuring success, and investing in the right people are also crucial for succeeding in digital innovation.

site_title: Broker's take: Headphones, car production sustain UOB's 'buy' call on Memtech
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintains its "buy" call on Memtech, with a target price of S$1.33, up 27.3% from its previous TP of S$1.18. The company's booming electronics demand, driven by a potential privatisation, expansion into new precision engineering segments, and strong demand for wireless headphones, are key catalysts. The electrifying surge in Tesla's Model 3 production is also expected to benefit Memtech, with demand forecast to exceed 700,000 units per year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks inch lower at open
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.04% to 20,814.75, and the Topix index down 0.01% to 1,694.93. The market pause comes after the Topix index hit a 10-year high, with investors weighing a Kobe Steel scandal.

site_title: Trump names Hargan as acting Health and Human Services Secretary
summary: President Donald Trump has named Eric Hargan as the acting Health and Human Services Secretary, replacing Don Wright who held the position since Tom Price's resignation in September 2017 due to private jet travel expenses. Hargan, a former corporate lawyer and member of Trump's transition team, previously held various positions in the department, including deputy secretary under President George W Bush.

site_title: Trump meets advisers to discuss North Korea options: statement
summary: US President Donald Trump met with his national security team to discuss options for responding to North Korea's recent missile and nuclear tests. The briefing, led by Defense Secretary James Mattis and General Joseph Dunford, focused on various options to address North Korean aggression or prevent nuclear threats. Trump has expressed frustration with diplomatic efforts, stating that only one approach will work, amid an escalating war of words with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

site_title: New Silkroutes' auditor flags prepayments to supplier; group makes dental clinics purchase
summary: New Silkroutes Group's independent auditor expressed concerns over unverifiable prepayments of US$500,494 and US$4.4 million to a supplier for iron ore fines. The company also faces uncertainty regarding an outstanding US$3.48 million due from the disposal of subsidiaries. Meanwhile, the group's subsidiary Healthsciences International (HSI) is acquiring 70% stake in three dental clinics in Singapore for S$3.2 million, expanding its healthcare business.

site_title: Singapore finance professionals not equipped for the future: poll
summary: A survey of 150 Singapore-based finance professionals found that 8 in 10 are not equipped with the skills to meet job requirements in the next decade. The current curriculum is deemed inadequate, and organizations are also not helping professionals develop future-ready skills. In response, CPA Australia launched a new training program, Finance for the Future, with 20 courses to expand technical skills in areas such as accounting standards, financial risk management, and data analytics. This move aims to equip the workforce with future-ready tools and knowledge to address the changing profession.

site_title: Nearly 700,000 UK nationals affected by Equifax breach: company
summary: Nearly 700,000 UK nationals may have had their personal data compromised in the Equifax breach, which occurred from mid-May to July 2017. The US credit reporting agency said the attackers accessed a file containing 15.2 million records on 693,665 British nationals. Equifax is notifying affected individuals and offering advice, with the company taking the breach "extremely seriously". The breach is not the largest on record but could have leaked sensitive financial information.

site_title: Fed's Kaplan keeping open mind on US rate hikes; says tax reform may be painful for some states
summary: Dallas Federal Reserve Bank President Robert Kaplan said he will keep an open mind on US interest-rate hikes as he assesses the economy's progress toward full employment and upward inflation. He expressed concerns about globalisation and technology keeping inflation muted despite low unemployment. Kaplan also warned that limiting state and local tax deductions in a potential US tax reform could be painful for some states, exacerbating population drain. He will continue to monitor the economy's progress toward meeting the 2% inflation objective in the medium term.

site_title: China Jishan calls off asset disposal, may stave off cash company status
summary: China Jishan Holdings has called off a planned sale of a real estate unit, Shao Xing Yue Sheng Real Estate Property Development Co, due to a disagreement with the buyer over the revised purchase price. The original price was 785.8 million yuan, but an independent valuation assigned a higher value, leading to a revised price of 1.18 billion yuan. If the deal had gone through, the Singapore Exchange would have considered China Jishan as a cash company, potentially suspending its stock. The company's decision may stave off its potential cash company status.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint unit to buy 3 firms in Germany
summary: Frasers Centrepoint's indirect subsidiary Frasers Property Investments (Europe) has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire three German companies for 42.4 million Euros. The deal involves acquiring 94.8% stakes in Logipark Moosthenning GmbH and HJäger Ges für Projektentwicklung von Immobilien mbH, and fully acquiring Simblafis GmbH. The acquisition will be funded by borrowings and internal resources, and the companies hold a site leased to a German car manufacturer with a gross lettable area of 72,558 square metres.

site_title: Kobe Steel scandal grows as more carmakers hit: report
summary: Japan's six major carmakers, including Nissan and Honda, used products from Kobe Steel, which admitted to falsifying quality data, a scandal that has grown beyond the initial company. The transport ministry has asked for urgent checks to see if recalls are necessary. Kobe Steel's internal probe found data fabrications for 19,300 tons of aluminum products, 2,200 tons of copper products, and 19,400 units of aluminum castings and forgings. The company's stock plummeted 22% on Tuesday, wiping almost a billion dollars off its market value. It's unclear if the scandal affects product safety.

site_title: Logistics startup Lalamove raises US$100m for growth
summary: HONG KONG-BASED logistics startup Lalamove has raised US$100 million in its latest funding round, led by ShunWei Capital. The new investment will be used to expand markets, invest in talent, and develop new product features. Lalamove now services over 15 million users and has over two million drivers, offering delivery in 100 cities. The company aims to capitalize on the growth of last-mile delivery, with ShunWei Capital partner Cheng Tian calling Lalamove an "important investment" in the mobile logistics sector.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong-based logistics startup Lalamove which has a presence in Singapore, has raised US$100 million in its latest round of funding.

site_title: British PM May refuses to say if she'd vote for Brexit now
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May refused to say whether she would vote for Brexit in a new referendum, citing "good reasons" for her initial support of EU membership. She stated that circumstances have changed since the 2016 vote and that she would make the same decision again. Despite her uncertainty, May vowed to push on with Britain's departure from the EU, amid a backdrop of infighting within her Conservative Party over Brexit and a recent chaotic conference address.

site_title: Spackman spends S$7.6m in cash and shares to acquire studio, raise talent agency stake
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group acquired Korean film production company Studio Take for S$3.9 million in cash and shares, with Spackman issuing 25.69 million shares at 13 Singapore cents apiece. The acquisition aims to expand Spackman's annual movie production capacity. In a separate deal, Spackman raised its stake in talent agency associate Spackman Media Group Ltd to 29.12% by issuing US$2.7 million worth of shares. The acquisition is expected to benefit Spackman's film production business and allow for increased integration with its existing culture.

site_title: Australia shares touch near 1-month high, NZ hits record
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to a near one-month high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 5,770.6. The rally was led by miners, financial stocks, and foreign buying after the Australian dollar rose 0.2% against the US dollar. New Zealand shares also reached a record high, with the S&P/NZX 50 index up 0.2%. The strong market performance was attributed to global investors buying into Australian exposure and a softer US dollar.

site_title: Lafe chairman's offer now unconditional; deadline extended to Oct 30
summary: Lafe Corp chairman Christopher Ho's general offer for his 90 Singapore cent-per-share shares is now unconditional after receiving enough acceptances to reach 74.98% of the company's shares. The offer period has been extended to Oct 30, following an initial 65% threshold. Ho initially sought to take the company private, but lowered the conditionality hurdle to facilitate the offer.

site_title: Spanish government says any dialogue with Catalonia must be within the law
summary: Spanish Deputy Prime Minister Soraya Saenz de Santamaria stated that Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont should follow the law for any dialogue to occur, and no one can impose mediation. Puigdemont declared Catalonia's independence, but suspended it to seek a mediated solution with Spain. The Spanish government will meet on Wednesday to decide its response.

site_title: Hammond won't budget now for a 'no-deal' Brexit: The Times
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond will not include spending for a "no-deal" Brexit in the upcoming budget, citing the need for contingency planning and the government's efforts to secure a negotiated EU exit. Hammond supports preparedness for all outcomes, including a no-deal scenario, but only authorizes spending when it's responsible. He emphasizes the government's commitment to finding necessary funding, ensuring it's spent only when necessary.

site_title: PM Lee to meet President Trump at the White House on Oct 23
summary: US President Donald Trump will welcome Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the White House on October 23, marking the second meeting between the two leaders. The visit aims to reaffirm the strong bilateral ties between the US and Singapore, with discussions on economic, political, security, and people-to-people ties. The meeting comes ahead of Trump's maiden trip to the Asia-Pacific region and signals the Trump administration's continued engagement in the region.

images.alt_text: United States President Donald Trump will welcome Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the White House on Oct 23, the US leader's press secretary announced yesterday.

site_title: US signals tougher stance with tech companies on encryption
summary: US Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein criticized tech companies for prioritizing sales over stopping crime, suggesting Silicon Valley is more willing to comply with foreign government demands for data than US authorities. He called for Congress to write legislation mandating access to encrypted products when a law enforcement agency obtains a court order, but tech companies and cyber security experts warn this would weaken cyber security for everyone. The move reignites the decades-old feud over encryption, with some lawmakers expressing interest in legislation requiring companies to help law enforcement access encrypted data.

site_title: Disney, Fox, others said to join forces for download service
summary: Several major Hollywood studios, including Disney, 20th Century Fox, Warner Bros., and Universal Pictures, are joining a new digital film service called Movies Anywhere. The service allows consumers to buy and store movies in a digital locker for access on various devices. The move aims to compensate for declining DVD sales and disappointing box office results. Viacom's Paramount Pictures is not joining due to a disagreement over financial terms, but may consider it later. The service uses proprietary storage technology and offers films from Disney's brands.

site_title: US flies bombers over Korean peninsula with South Korean, Japanese fighter jets
summary: US Air Force B-1B Lancer bombers flew over the Korean peninsula with South Korean and Japanese fighter jets in a show of force amid high tensions over North Korea's nuclear and missile programs. The exercise, part of a regular drill to bolster military defenses, took place late on Tuesday and involved air-to-ground missile drills in waters off the east coast of South Korea. The move comes as North Korea prepares for its Communist Party Congress and amid concerns about potential provocations, including the threat to shoot intermediate-range missiles towards Guam.

site_title: Gold rises but US rate expectations cap gains
summary: Gold rose to nearly two-week highs on Tuesday, supported by geopolitical tensions in Spain and North Korea, but gains were capped by expectations of a US interest rate increase. The dollar index fell, and US Treasury yields dropped, while spot gold rose 0.5% to $1,289.81 an ounce. Precious metals rose, with silver up 1.3% and platinum up 2.3%. Despite the gains, traders expect a nearly 90% chance of a December US rate hike, which can negatively impact gold prices.

site_title: Hollywood mogul Weinstein accused of rape: New Yorker
summary: Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein has been accused of rape by three women, including Italian film star Asia Argento and aspiring actress Lucia Evans. Argento alleges Weinstein forced oral sex on her 20 years ago, while Evans claims he forced her to perform oral sex in 2004. A fourth woman, who remains anonymous, also accuses Weinstein of forcing himself on her. Weinstein denies all charges, stating he was unaware of the allegations. The accusations are a significant escalation of the scandal engulfing the Oscar-winning producer, who was sacked from The Weinstein Company over harassment allegations.

site_title: US businesses fear Nafta doomed; Mexico warns of consequences
summary: US businesses and the US Chamber of Commerce have expressed concerns that the Trump administration's proposals to renegotiate NAFTA may sabotage the agreement, citing "poison pill proposals" that could harm US industries and the economy. Mexico's foreign minister warned that the demise of NAFTA would hurt bilateral cooperation and affect Mexico's efforts to combat drug trafficking and immigration. The renegotiation talks, which started on October 10, have been prolonged, and US businesses have lined up to support the existing agreement.

site_title: Oil rises above US$56 on Saudi export cut
summary: Oil prices rose above US$56 a barrel on Tuesday, supported by Saudi Arabian export cuts in November and comments from Opec and trading companies that the market is rebalancing. Saudi Arabia cut November allocations by 560,000 barrels per day, and the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is cutting output by 1.8 million barrels per day until next March to get rid of a supply glut. US crude gained 97 cents to US$50.55, with Brent crude up 80 cents at US$56.59 a barrel.

site_title: First Reit completes Siloam Hospitals Buton, Lippo Plaza Buton purchase
summary: First Reit completed the acquisition of Siloam Hospitals Buton and Lippo Plaza Buton in Indonesia for S$28.5 million, adding to its portfolio of 19 properties across Indonesia, Singapore, and South Korea. This marks the trust's second acquisition of a hospital and retail mall, following the 2015 Kupang Property purchase. The acquisition was financed through internal cash and a bank loan.

site_title: Europe: Bourses brace for crucial Catalan meeting after close
summary: European bourses closed flat on Tuesday as investors awaited a possible unilateral declaration of independence at the Catalan parliament, potentially leading to turmoil on Spanish markets. Despite this, London's FTSE 100 rose 0.4% due to strong gains in domestic banks. Luxury group LVMH's strong Q3 results boosted consumer goods stocks, while Swiss fragrance maker Givaudan jumped 3.1% after beating sales forecasts. Lufthansa's shares rose 2.5% after a deal with its pilots' union, while BAE Systems shed 0.3% after announcing 2,000 job cuts.

site_title: New Zealand 'kingmaker' reneges on election deadline
summary: New Zealand's Winston Peters, known as a "kingmaker," has reneged on a self-imposed deadline to announce an end to the country's election deadlock. Peters had promised to make his decision by October 12, but now says it will be made "as soon as possible after Thursday night." The decision is crucial for Prime Minister Bill English and opposition leader Jacinda Ardern, who need Peters' support of his New Zealand First party to claim victory in the September 23 election. Peters' delay is seen as a departure from his previous guarantees, sparking criticism from politicians.

site_title: Low-cost housing in India hits a wall
summary: Indian architect Sheila Sriprakash emphasizes the need for sustainable, low-cost homes amid the country's housing shortage. Despite government initiatives and builders' pledges to create affordable housing, Sriprakash notes that many homes are designed with luxury features, compromising quality and affordability. She advocates for flexible, incremental designs that cater to changing needs and environments. With India's estimated 20 million urban housing shortage, Sriprakash stresses the importance of sustainable design to address climate goals and improve living conditions.

site_title: Secura Group CEO resigns to 'pursue personal interests'
summary: Secura Group CEO Paul Lim Choon Wui has resigned to pursue personal interests, stepping down after leading the company since 2016. CFO Lim Siok Leng will oversee the business until a new CEO is appointed. The board will identify a suitable candidate to fill the role, and an appointment will be made in due course.

site_title: China Environment unit loses civil suit, ordered to pay loan plus interest
summary: China Environment unit, Fujian Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co (FJDY), has lost a civil suit to Zhongxin Bank, ordered to pay a loan of 36.67 million yuan (S$7.6 million) plus interest. The judgment, awarded to the plaintiff, is due within 10 days, with potential for selling off FJDY's assets if payment is not made. The guarantors, Huang Min and his wife, are liable for the remaining sum. FJDY must pay 99,500 yuan in legal fees and 229,234 yuan in court costs.

site_title: Last privately owned Da Vinci to go on sale for US$100m
summary: The last privately owned Leonardo Da Vinci painting, "Salvator Mundi," will be auctioned off in New York on November 15 for an estimated US$100 million. Certified as authentic in 2005, the 1500-era painting depicts Jesus Christ and is one of fewer than 20 Da Vinci works still in private hands. The sale is rare, as very few pre-19th-century artworks remain in private ownership. A third-party guarantee ensures the painting will sell for the estimated price.

site_title: US: Dow ends at record high as Wal-Mart surges on forecast
summary: US stocks finished modestly higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching a fresh record at 22,830.68. Wal-Mart surged 4.5% after projecting fiscal 2019 sales would rise at or above 3% and announcing a $20 billion share repurchase program. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with investor sentiment strong ahead of major earnings reports and President Trump's tax cut proposal. The International Monetary Fund increased its forecast of US growth, but warned that progress on economic policies is needed.

site_title: China seen curbing market swings ahead of party congress
summary: Chinese state-backed funds intervened in the country's stock market on Monday, selling shares of large-cap companies to limit gains ahead of a key leadership reshuffle. The funds, which had been buying stocks to support the market, reduced their purchases in an effort to restrain market swings. The Shanghai Composite Index erased half its gain by the close, with some stocks, such as Industrial & Commercial Bank of China and China United Network Communications, experiencing significant declines. The government's intervention aims to maintain stability in the market before the Communist Party congress.

site_title: Euro rises to 1-week high on German trade data
summary: The euro rose to a 1-week high against the US dollar, reaching $1.1800, following robust German trade data and comments from European Central Bank executive board member Sabine Lautenschlaeger, who called for asset purchases to be rolled back in 2018. Despite ongoing political uncertainty, particularly in Spain, the economic data suggests a positive outlook for the euro, potentially supporting its value before the ECB's policy meeting on October 26. The euro's rise contrasts with a decline in the US dollar, which dropped a fifth of a percent against a trade-weighted basket of its rivals.

site_title: Diesels driving on in 2018 despite new tax
summary: Diesel car sales in Singapore will continue despite the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) taking effect on January 1, 2018. Car distributors are offering discounts on existing diesel models, with some potentially raising prices by up to $50,000. Brands like Porsche, Land Rover, and Renault will continue to offer diesel variants, with some, like the Porsche Macan S Diesel, facing a $20,000 penalty. Other European brands have cleared their stocks and will not bring in new diesel models.

site_title: StanChart says it reviewed transfer of US$1.4b funds, 'proactively' notified authorities
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (StanChart) conducted a full review of trust structures related to a $1.4 billion fund transfer from Guernsey to Singapore in 2015, and proactively notified authorities. Indonesia's Finance Ministry stated that no Indonesian public officials were involved, and the transfers were "business transactions" with no connection to the military. Regulators, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Guernsey's Financial Services Commission, are investigating the matter, with MAS taking a serious view of potential breaches of anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism requirements.

site_title: SGX gives brokers more flexibility
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has proposed changes to securities trading and market practices aimed at increasing efficiency and reducing compliance costs. The changes include loosening rules on customer account opening, allowing brokers to conduct business outside the office, and removing minimum security deposits. The aim is to give brokers more flexibility and move away from a prescriptive approach. The public consultation on the rule changes is open until November 7.

site_title: UK factories pick up pace; BOE on track to up rates
summary: UK factories experienced their strongest two months of 2017 in July and August, with manufacturing output rising 0.4% in August and industrial output growing 0.2% in the same month. The data suggests the Bank of England may raise interest rates soon, with most policymakers believing a rate hike is likely in the coming months. However, the UK economy remained in a low gear in the third quarter, with the goods trade deficit hitting an all-time high of £14.245 billion in August.

site_title: Vickers Venture raises US$230m for its largest VC fund yet
summary: Vickers Venture Partners has raised US$230 million for its fifth fund, surpassing its previous four funds in total capital raised. The firm, which invests in early-stage companies, has a strong track record with a net internal rate of return (IRR) of 38% and a net multiple of 5.4 times. Fund V targets three markets: China, South-east Asia, India, and the US, with a focus on "deep tech" investments. The firm has offices in five locations and plans to open an office in San Francisco next year.

site_title: China needs to ponder history, too, for better Japan ties
summary: China and Japan have seen a sudden improvement in relations, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe visiting the Chinese embassy to mark the 45th anniversary of diplomatic relations. Foreign Minister Wang Yi expressed hope that Japan will adopt a more positive policy towards China, while China expects Japan to make concessions on historical issues such as the Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands. The two countries have agreed to improve bilateral cooperation, but China's demands include Japan stopping joint military exercises with the US and selling weapons to countries with suspicion. A thaw in relations was laid groundwork in May, with Abe expressing interest in joining the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.

site_title: Singapore, Asia investors bank on US stocks in Q2 as others scale down
summary: Singapore investors and other Asian investors shifted their focus to buying US stocks in the second quarter, with Singapore investors purchasing a net US$1.35 billion worth of US equities, the third largest Asian purchase after South Korea and Japan. This marked a turnaround from the first quarter, where Asian investors sold a net US$2.04 billion in US stocks. The US Treasury's data shows that foreign investors overall were buying more US stocks than they sold in the second quarter, netting US$10.76 billion in purchases.

site_title: Cisco gears up for transition to digital-ready networks
summary: Cisco is launching an integrated approach to help companies in Asia become more efficient, secure, and innovative by transitioning to digital-ready networks. With 95% of network operations still done manually, the company aims to unlock the power of data and provide visibility to automate processes. Cisco's Digital Network Architecture (DNA) and Software Defined Access (SDA) will enable companies to manage users and devices more effectively, predict and prevent network problems, and reduce the risk of cyber attacks, which are prevalent in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SPH Reit is expected to continue delivering steady distributions despite market uncertainties, driven by sticky occupancies and low gearing. DBS Group Research raises its target price to S$1.07, citing the potential acquisition of Seletar Mall. Meanwhile, Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) is expected to maintain an acquisition rate of A$150-200 million and potentially acquire European assets in the long term. The research firm raises its target price for FLT to S$1.20, maintaining an "Add" rating and projecting total returns of 17% for FY2018.

site_title: SPIVA Scorecard should look into fees' impact on fund performance
summary: S&P Dow Jones Indices released its biannual SPIVA Scorecard, showing that 15% of US equity funds and 9% of international funds beat their benchmarks over 15 years. However, Capital Group argues that funds with low expenses and high manager ownership can outperform, citing its own Select Investment Scorecard, which found 86% of US large-cap Select Equity funds beat the S&P 500 over 10-year periods. A study using Capital Group's methodology found 58% of US funds and 100% of foreign funds beat their benchmarks over 15 years when including low fees and high manager ownership criteria.

site_title: BT and CapitaLand team up to stage a Sunburst of joy
summary: A concert titled "Sunburst: The Business Times-CapitaLand Fundraising Concert" will be held on Oct 20 to raise funds for the Muscular Dystrophy Association of Singapore (MDAS) and the School of the Arts (Sota) student assistance fund. The event, organized by The Business Times, features emerging musical talents and has already raised nearly S$230,000 for the beneficiaries. Senior Minister of State Sim Ann is the guest of honour, and the concert aims to promote inclusivity and support for those with physical disabilities.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Financial mints a new billionaire
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Financial has made Min Luo, founder of Qudian Inc, a new billionaire after the online loan provider's US IPO. Qudian's success is largely attributed to its partnership with Alibaba, which provides customers and credit scores. The company's return on equity of 55% and low cost of acquiring new borrowers have contributed to its success. However, reliance on Ant Financial also poses a key risk, particularly as Ant Credit competes directly with Qudian's service.

site_title: Defeated terrorists in Marawi pose wider threat to S-E Asia
summary: Philippine security forces are engaged in ongoing clashes with a small group of terrorists in Marawi, a city in the southern island of Mindanao. The conflict began in May when hundreds of terrorists, including those from Malaysia and Indonesia, seized the city. The government's efforts to recapture it have caused major structural damage, with estimated reconstruction costs of $1 billion. The situation poses a threat to Southeast Asia as a whole, and experts warn that the government's handling of the aftermath could "lose the peace." A comprehensive solution to Mindanao's instability requires addressing four fundamental factors: poverty, governance, economic investment, and the appeal of extremist ideologies.

site_title: Can you sue a robot? Estonia working on law to address their legal status
summary: Estonia is working on legislation to address the legal status of artificial intelligence, with a proposal to create the term "robot-agent" that would grant AI a separate legal personality. The country's economy ministry is drafting laws to regulate AI in disputes, with a goal of implementing the rules within a couple of years. Estonia aims to stay ahead of the pack in regulating robotics, with a focus on making it easier for companies to use digital technologies. This move is seen as a step to address regulatory issues presented by increased automation, including self-driving cars and drones.

site_title: Horse-trading begins for Eurogroup chairmanship
summary: Horse-trading has begun for the Eurogroup chairmanship following the end of Jeroen Dijsselbloem's nearly five-year term. Potential hopefuls include Bruno Le Maire, Mario Centeno, Luis de Guindos, Peter Kazimir, and Pierre Gramegna. The succession is important as it may influence top EU jobs, including the European Central Bank and European Commission. Spain's Luis de Guindos is seen as a frontrunner for ECB vice-president, which could pave the way for a northern European to succeed Mario Draghi as ECB president.

site_title: Three ways of driving a vehicle called eurozone
summary: The European Union is considering three options for the eurozone: a "more united union" with uniform steps by all EU members, led by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker; a vision for Europe proposed by French President Emmanuel Macron, which allows for more differentiation among EU countries; or business as usual, putting eurozone reforms on the backburner. A "more united union" would require EU members to adopt a single currency and banking union, while Macron's vision would allow for more flexibility among countries. However, with the economic crisis subsiding and the UK's departure from the EU, policymakers may decide to prioritize other areas over eurozone reforms, which could lead to serious risks, including cost divergences and interest-rate differentials.

site_title: Not time to pop the champagne yet
summary: Reports from international accountant Moore Stephens indicate rising confidence and falling operating costs in the shipping industry. The Shipping Confidence Survey shows confidence reached its highest rating in three years, with owners feeling more optimistic than brokers and charterers. However, experts caution that increased confidence may lead to over-investment and that costs could rise due to upcoming regulations such as the Ballast Water Management Convention and sulphur emission limits.

site_title: Trendlines proposes S$14m share placement
summary: Trendlines Group, a Singapore-based innovation company, proposes a S$14.03 million share placement to raise funds for general working capital and investments in portfolio companies. The company will also undertake a strategic review of its operations within a reasonable period of time. This move could significantly boost value for its shareholders and startups, and may potentially implement a dividend policy.

site_title: Baidu 'checks out 3 billion fake news claims every year'
summary: Baidu, China's largest search engine, claims to verify around 3 billion fake news claims annually. The company works with government agencies to tackle the issue, using technology to spot potentially spurious information. Baidu's president Zhang Yaqin emphasized the need for cooperation between tech companies and external organizations to curb the spread of fake news. The company is expanding its AI labs in the US and plans to acquire more companies to prepare for its driverless car project, set to launch in China in 2018.

site_title: Trendlines proposes S$14m share placement, plans strategic review
summary: Trendlines Group, an Israel-based incubator for medical and agricultural technology startups, proposed a S$14.03 million share placement of new shares at 14.03 Singapore cents apiece. The placement, not underwritten, aims to cut costs, increase efficiency, and enhance shareholder value. A strategic review of operations, including a possible dividend policy, will also be undertaken. The placement, if successful, will represent 19.66% of the existing share capital and 16.43% of the enlarged share capital.

site_title: Olam's 5.6% surge prompts SGX query
summary: Olam International's shares surged 5.63% to a high of S$2.25 before being issued a trading query by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at 3pm. The company stated it was unaware of any information not previously announced that could explain the unusual rise. This marks the second trading query issued to Olam in less than four months, following a June 23 query. Olam's shares closed 4% higher at S$2.23 after around 2.64 million units changed hands.

site_title: Deutsche Bank chief losing investors' patience and support
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan is losing investor support due to his inability to deliver on his turnaround plan, with some investors wanting him replaced if results don't improve in the next few quarters. Revenue has declined since he took over in 2015, and despite settling legacy misconduct cases and raising fresh capital, the bank's shares have lost almost 8% since Cryan raised €8 billion in April. Tension between Cryan and chairman Paul Achleitner adds pressure, particularly over Cryan's lack of meetings with key investor HNA Group.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

SUTL Enterprise secured its second management contract in China for an integrated marina in Suzhou. The 10-year contract was awarded by Suzhou Taihu SanShan Island Marina. Epicentre Holdings' auditor BDO withheld its opinion on the company's FY2017 accounts due to a lack of evidence for certain transactions. YHI International entered into a joint venture agreement with Aung San Company to develop the marketing business of automobile and industrial products in Myanmar. Jiangsu Sunpower Pressure Vessels Equipment Manufacturing was awarded a contract worth 94.8 million yuan by Inner Mongolia Tongwei High-Purity Crystalline Silicon Co.

site_title: May gets Brexit hardliners' backing for no-deal stand
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has released two policy papers outlining contingency plans for leaving the European Union without a deal, gaining support from Brexit hardliners in her cabinet. The plans include steps to minimize disruption for businesses and travelers, and include a new "standalone" system for the UK to manage customs and value-added tax. May is walking a fine line to engineer momentum in Brexit talks while appeasing anti-EU lawmakers, with the EU saying "sufficient progress" is needed on separation issues before trade talks can proceed.

site_title: White House chaos in policymaking a cause for global concern
summary: The White House's policymaking process under President Donald Trump has raised global concerns due to its chaotic and unpredictable nature. Trump often undermines his Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's diplomatic efforts, making contradictory statements on critical issues such as North Korea and Iran. This approach has led to fears of a military attack on North Korea and potential destabilization in the Middle East. Republican Senator Bob Corker has warned that Trump's impulsive decisions could set the US on the path to World War III, prompting calls for greater concern about the US's role in the world.

site_title: European equities set to surge
summary: European equities are poised for a significant surge due to normalizing interest rates and improving profit margins. Analysts predict a 30% market appreciation over three years, driven by interest rates normalizing at low levels and bond yields reverting to pre-Trump levels. The Phillips Curve relationship between unemployment and inflation has broken down, reducing the incentive for interest rate hikes. With declining bond yields and central bank predictions, inflation is expected to remain under control, leading to higher market multiples and potential 30% gains.

site_title: Hotels go on charm offensive with help from celebrities
summary: Hotels such as Marriott are offering unique experiences to loyal customers, including masterclasses with Michelin-starred chefs, snorkelling with Jean-Michel Cousteau, and basketball tips from NBA standout Dwyane Wade. To compete with home rental services like Airbnb, hotels are focusing on self-improvement activities, which are expected to be a growing trend among younger travellers. Marriott is investing in its loyalty programs, offering exclusive packages that allow members to redeem points for transformative experiences.

site_title: SGX's top 20 China-linked firms achieve 39.8% average return
summary: The top 20 China-linked firms listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) achieved a market capitalization-weighted total return of 39.8% year-to-date, outperforming the 8% return of the Shanghai Stock Exchange Composite Index. The 20 companies, with a combined market capitalization of S$25.3 billion, have diverse industries and maintained high price-to-earnings and price-to-book ratios. The five best performers were Delong Holdings, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and others, with average returns on equity of 16.2%.

site_title: The next leap in networking infrastructure
summary: Intent-based networking systems provide life cycle management for network infrastructure, enabling companies to improve network availability and agility. This new technology uses machine learning and advanced automation to adapt networks according to changing conditions. Gartner predicts over 1,000 large enterprises will adopt intent-based networking systems within the next four years. Cisco Systems has developed a digital network architecture (DNA) to work with intent-based networking systems, mitigating cyber attacks and providing built-in security and business insights. The technology has the potential to transform traditional networking infrastructure and make networks simpler for power users to deliver sophisticated operations.

site_title: Skin-tight gear and 'climbing' yoga poses turning heads in Myanmar
summary: Fitness enthusiasts in Myanmar are taking the latest body-bending trend to new heights by combining yoga with climbing. Khin Myat Thu Zar, a 32-year-old former lawyer, teaches climbing yoga classes at a newly opened centre in Yangon, where students pay $12 for an hour-long session. The trend, popular among Myanmar's growing middle class, requires strength, courage, and mental stability. While the classes are only affordable for the wealthy, they offer a unique way to boost fitness and inner peace, with some participants citing improved yoga skills and reduced stress.

site_title: Stocks end mixed in low-volume session
summary: Singapore stocks ended mixed in a low-volume session, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,288.95, down 2.61 points from the previous day. The index was boosted by afternoon short-covering after a positive session for US Dow futures. Active stocks included DBS, UOB, and OCBC, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Singtel fell. Olam International jumped 9 cents to S$2.23 after a query from the Singapore Exchange. The property sector saw gains from City Developments Ltd, which is considering a potential offer for Millenium & Copthorne.

site_title: Analysts take heart in SRX condo resale data for September
summary: SRX Property's September resale data showed a 10.9% decline in resale volume to 1,162 units, but analysts are optimistic due to the year-over-year increase of 64.8%. The resale price index for non-landed private homes rose 0.1% month-over-month, with a 4.3% year-over-year gain. Analysts attribute the market's resilience to the Hungry Ghost festival's end and expected property market upturn. Resale volumes are projected to grow to 12,000-14,000 units this year, up 52-77% from last year.

site_title: Metals scandal forged over a decade puts big dent in Japan Inc
summary: Kobe Steel, a Japanese industrial company, has admitted to falsifying data on the strength and durability of aluminum and copper products used in aircraft, cars, and possibly space rockets. The company's CEO, Hiroya Kawasaki, is leading a committee to probe quality issues, which were found to be systematic and dated back over 10 years. The scandal has affected over 200 companies, including Toyota, Honda, and Subaru, with some using materials that were subject to falsification. The incident raises concerns about the integrity of Japanese manufacturers and follows recent scandals involving Takata Corp and Nissan Motor Co.

site_title: Apple praises French iPhone supplier before meeting Macron
