summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook visited Eldim, a French firm, ahead of a meeting with President Emmanuel Macron to praise their work on facial recognition technology for the iPhone X. Cook tweeted "Bravo for your work!" and met Macron, who has called for tech companies to pay more in taxes in Europe. The meeting was seen as constructive and forward-looking, with no discussion of past issues or specifics on taxing digital platforms. Eldim has worked with Apple on research projects for nearly a decade, and their optical technology is a key feature of the iPhone X.

site_title: SUTL secures 10-year management contract for new Suzhou marina
summary: SUTL Enterprise secures a 10-year management contract for a new integrated marina at Sanshan Island in Taihu Lake, Suzhou, China. The marina will feature a private marina, yacht membership club, and facilities. SUTL Enterprise will be responsible for conceptualization, design, and pre-opening management, as well as day-to-day operations and membership sales. The marina is expected to attract high-spending tourists, with Sanshan Island attracting over a million visitors annually. This marks SUTL Enterprise's second management contract in China, following its successful ONE°15 Marina Guishan project in Zhuhai.

site_title: Nobel winner's lonely, savvy and funny route to the Prize
summary: Nobel Prize winner Richard Thaler, known for his behavioral economics approach, offers a cautionary tale of how to bring meaningful change to a large organization without being ostracized. Thaler, who was once a lone voice criticizing the mainstream economic view, found success by collaborating with others and couching his work as an extension of the mainstream. His efforts, which began in the 1980s, have influenced generations of graduate students and contributed to the respectable status of behavioral research in economics. Thaler's approach serves as a model for those seeking to effect change within a large organization.

site_title: US:Wall St scales new records on gains in Wal-Mart, energy stocks
summary: US stocks reached new records on Tuesday, driven by gains in energy stocks and Wal-Mart's US$20 billion share buyback plan. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all scaled new highs, with the Dow up 50.31 points, the S&P 500 up 6.6 points, and the Nasdaq up 22.53 points. Energy prices rose 1% due to Saudi Arabian export cuts, while Wal-Mart's forecast of 40% online sales growth boosted its 3.8% gain. The rally is expected to continue through the third-quarter earnings season, despite elevated valuations.

site_title: Innovative funding for catastrophes builds resilience
summary: Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria have caused estimated damages of $200 billion in the US and $45-$95 billion in Puerto Rico. The disaster response has shown shortcomings, particularly in Puerto Rico, and the federal government must improve its response to avoid losing hope and human capital. Innovations in disaster risk-financing, such as the Caribbean Catastrophe Risk Insurance Facility, aim to facilitate risk-sharing among hurricane-prone countries and provide immediate relief. The human cost of natural disasters should end with the onset of disaster, and responsive financing is crucial for survivors to recover and rebuild.

site_title: Bling it - Singapore launches world's first diamond bullion
summary: Singapore has launched the world's first diamond bullion, offering investors a new way to diversify their portfolios. The bullion, produced by the Singapore Diamond Mint Company, is available in two cases - silver and gold - with prices at US$100,000 and US$200,000, respectively. The exchange, backed by investors including Temasek Holdings, aims to surpass its first-year target of US$100 million in trading volumes, with the current trading volume already exceeding US$165 million. The diamond bullion is tradeable, fully fungible, and portable, with real-time pricing data and authentication through a mobile app.

site_title: Thai junta chief vows elections in November 2018
summary: Thai junta chief Prayut Chan-O-Cha announced that the country will hold elections in November 2018, more than four years after the military seized power. This decision comes after repeated delays in restoring civilian rule, with the junta's new charter expected to limit democracy. Prayut had initially promised to return power within 18 months after the 2014 coup.

site_title: GRP to take up 51% stake in Malaysian property development firm
summary: GRP Limited has agreed to acquire a 51% stake in Malaysian property development firm Multiple Lodge Sdn Bhd (MLodge) for RM510,000. The acquisition includes a joint venture development agreement with landowner Karib Tropika Sdn Bhd to develop 19.35 acres in Ipoh, Malaysia into a mixed housing and commercial development.

site_title: Abe takes aim at rivals, focuses on sound policy in election campaigning
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is campaigning for a snap election on October 22, aiming to maintain his near five-year hold on power despite suspected cronyism scandals and rising regional tensions. Abe's Liberal Democratic Party faces a new party, Party of Hope, led by Tokyo governor Yuriko Koike, which could upset his calculation. Abe's first official campaign speech focused on policy, saying "what creates our future is not a boom or slogan, but policy." Recent polls show the LDP in the lead, but a poor performance could prompt calls to replace Abe or deny him a third term as LDP leader.

site_title: GE's new CEO under pressure to overhaul company amid decades-long slide
summary: General Electric's new CEO, John Flannery, is under pressure to overhaul the company amid a decades-long decline. He has added an activist shareholder to the board and is considering changes to the company's portfolio and cost-cutting measures. Flannery is also weighing the possibility of cutting the dividend for the first time since the 2009 financial crisis. Analysts expect the company to report weak earnings and cash flow, which may lead to a dividend cut. Flannery plans to outline his plans in a presentation on November 13, aiming to turn the company around.

site_title: Sunpower unit clinches 94.8 million yuan contract
summary: Jiangsu Sunpower Pressure Vessels Equipment Manufacturing, a subsidiary of Sunpower Group, has secured a 94.8 million yuan contract to supply four cold hydrogenation reactors to Inner Mongolia Tongwei's high-purity crystalline silicon project. The project, expected to enter production in 2018, will have a positive impact on Sunpower's FY2018 results. The delivery of products is scheduled for the first half of 2018.

site_title: A good dose of digital is what healthcare needs
summary: Singapore's healthcare sector faces significant challenges, including a growing epidemic of diabetes and non-communicable diseases, as well as a shortage of healthcare workers. However, digital technologies can help address these issues. According to a report, 56% of healthcare organisations in the region have a digital transformation strategy, and 34% have reported major digital disruption. The key to success lies in prioritising four goals: improving operational efficiency, enhancing the patient experience, improving agility, and managing risks. Digital technologies can be used to collect data, turn it into insights, and make real-time decisions to improve patient care and reduce errors.

images.alt_text: As the population ages rapidly and more have chronic ailments, healthcare organisations like hospitals will find it a struggle to keep up.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets dipped at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling fractionally to 7,506.41 points, Paris's CAC 40 dropping to 5,364.16, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 losing 0.1% to 12,959.72. The decline comes as investors weigh the impact of US-EU trade talks and uncertainty surrounding the US economy.

site_title: Vatican bank starts legal case in Malta over US$20m lost investment
summary: The Vatican bank has initiated a lawsuit in Malta against individuals deemed responsible for a $20 million loss in investment funds. The case stems from the bank's participation in questionable investment transactions between 2012 and 2013, when it lacked a president. Pope Francis has emphasized financial reform and honesty as part of his papacy. The Vatican bank has been undergoing reforms since 2013, closing thousands of accounts and addressing past scandals related to money laundering and tax evasion.

site_title: Thai PM Prayuth sets Nov 2018 for election after false starts
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha announced a general election for November 2018, the most precise date given since the 2014 military coup. The exact date will be announced in June 2018. The announcement aims to end a decade of political turbulence and root out corruption. The new constitution, signed by King Maha Vajiralongkorn, provides for a proportional voting system, which may reduce the influence of major political parties. Analysts expect a slow resumption of political activities after the king's funeral, which may reduce pressure for an election.

site_title: SGX loosens some rules on remisiers to encourage new entrants
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is loosening rules for remisiers to encourage new entrants in the industry. The proposed changes include removing the requirement for trading representatives to inform customers and SGX when working outside the office, and obtaining customer permission. This move aims to improve the industry's competitiveness and attract new talent.

site_title: Firms can tap new state scheme to help local workers learn from overseas experts
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has launched a pilot program to fund 30-90% of salary and training for local workers and foreign trainers to acquire skills from overseas experts. The Capability Transfer Programme aims to enhance the local workforce's capabilities and support companies in various sectors, including interior furnishing, food manufacturing, and the automotive industry. The program is part of efforts to strengthen the "Singaporean core" and complement local and foreign workers.

site_title: BAE to cut almost 2,000 jobs as Eurofighter backlog dwindles
summary: BAE Systems will cut almost 2,000 jobs due to a dwindling Eurofighter Typhoon backlog, with 1,400 positions eliminated in the military-aircraft unit, 375 in the maritime division, and up to 150 in the cyber-security arm. The company aims to align its workforce with near-term demand, following a surprise order from Qatar worth £8.6 billion. The move is necessary despite a predicted 5-10% increase in full-year earnings per share.

site_title: Koh Bros Eco Engineering receives regulatory approval for proposed rights cum warrants issue
summary: Koh Bros Eco Engineering has received regulatory approval from the Singapore Exchange to list shares and warrants for a proposed rights cum warrants issue. The issue involves up to 299.02 million new shares at S$0.055 per share, representing a 40% discount from the last traded price. The new shares come with detachable warrants for an additional share at S$0.10 per share. The move is part of the company's plans to raise funds and expand its business.

site_title: YHI unit in joint venture with Myanmar firm to market car and industrial products
summary: YHI International has entered a joint venture with Myanmar firm Aung San Company to market car and industrial products in Myanmar. The joint venture, YHI Aung (Myanmar) Company Limited, will have YHI contributing 19% of the initial paid-up capital and Aung San contributing 81%. The company expects minimal impact on earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current financial year. YHI International shares ended at S$0.39 on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: BOJ governor Kuroda pledges to stick with quantitative easing
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) raised its assessment of four regional economies due to strong exports, consumer spending, and construction, indicating a healthy pace of growth. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated the central bank's commitment to quantitative easing until inflation reaches its 2% target. Kuroda stated that inflation is likely to accelerate towards 2% due to improvements in the output gap and inflation expectations, with Japan's economy expected to continue expanding moderately in the future.

site_title: HK regulator aims for 'northbound' China investor ID system by mid-2018
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission plans to implement a real-time investor identification system for "northbound" trading with China by mid-2018 to detect potential misconduct. The system will be developed in conjunction with the China Securities Regulatory Commission and aims to increase transparency. This move comes as China seeks to open its markets to foreign investors and Hong Kong aims to increase its exposure to high-growth sectors. The system will also help detect market misconduct and provide a world-class regulatory environment for risk management products.

site_title: Australian shares end flat; NZ closes at record high
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Tuesday, closing 0.02% lower at 5,738.1, after a rally in smaller miners was offset by losses in financial stocks. Spot gold rose 0.2% to its highest in over a week, contributing to a 1.2% gain in the Australian gold index. The benchmark rose 0.5% on Monday, its previous day.

site_title: Airbnb's Chinese rival Tujia raises US$300m for global jaunt
summary: Beijing-based startup Tujia.com has raised $300 million to fund a global expansion, valuing the company at over $1.5 billion. Tujia, Airbnb's Chinese rival, now handles over 650,000 listings globally and aims to increase its listings in Japan and other destinations. The company faces competition from Airbnb, which has doubled its investment in China and plans a more aggressive approach. China's travel accommodation sharing industry is expected to grow significantly, with Chinese travelers taking 67% more trips in 2020.

site_title: Scientists find US$1.8m worth of gold in Swiss wastewater
summary: Scientists at the Swiss Federal Institute of Aquatic Science and Technology discovered that approximately 43 kilograms of gold, worth around US$1.8 million, passes through Switzerland's wastewater annually. This gold is primarily from the country's gold refineries in the southern Ticino region. The study also found about 3,000 kilograms of silver, equivalent to US$1.7 million, going to waste every year. Switzerland, a major gold-refining hub, could potentially benefit from recycling this gold.

site_title: Qantas raises A$350m from loan that allows switching aircraft used as collateral
summary: Qantas Airways has raised A$350 million from a loan that allows it to switch the types of aircraft used as collateral, in what is considered the world's first aviation financing of this type. The eight-year loan, structured by BNP Paribas, will help the airline refinance part of its secured debt and provides more flexibility in terms of aircraft encumbrance. This move is seen as a strategic move to monetize its assets, with Qantas reporting near-record profits in the year to June.

site_title: Japan government, Tepco liable for Fukushima crisis: court
summary: A Japanese court ruled that the government and Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) are liable for the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, ordering them to pay damages to local residents. The court found that the government could have foreseen and avoided the disaster, and awarded up to 360,000 yen to each of the 12,000 plaintiffs. This is the second time the government has been ruled liable for the meltdown, with the total damages amounting to 500 million yen.

site_title: Bolshoi, Met in opera tie-up for first time
summary: The Bolshoi Theatre and the Metropolitan Opera have announced a historic co-production partnership, with three operas to be staged in both Moscow and New York between 2019 and 2022. Russian soprano Anna Netrebko will star in lead roles in the productions of Verdi's Aida, Strauss's Salome, and Wagner's Lohengrin. The collaboration comes as a positive step despite frosty political relations between Russia and the US, with both opera houses emphasizing the artistic value of the partnership.

site_title: Iraq, Iran boost oil exports in sales battle with Saudis
summary: Iraq and Iran increased oil exports in September, taking advantage of Saudi Arabia's slower shipments to win buyers in key markets. Iraq shipped 3.98 million barrels per day, its highest since December, while Iran's exports rose to 2.28 million barrels per day, the most since February. Saudi Arabia's exports were 6.68 million barrels per day, the second-lowest for the year. The move highlights internal tensions within OPEC as Saudi Arabia seeks to re-balance the global market.

site_title: Indonesia aims to finish first phase of key Java rail line by 2019
summary: Indonesia aims to complete the first phase of its Jakarta-Surabaya rail project by 2019, with the goal of reducing travel times from around 10 hours to five hours. The project, valued at around $4.45 billion, will mostly involve upgrading an existing line, cutting investment costs by nearly half. Japan was initially involved in discussions on the project, but its involvement is unclear. The project's progress has been slow, with the Jakarta-Bandung rail link still in the early stages of construction.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed in low volume
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day mixed in low volume, with the Straits Times Index falling 2.61 points to 3,288.95. The early selling of banks was followed by afternoon short-covering, trimming the loss. Trading volume was low at 1.5 billion units worth S$960.1 million, with 246 rises and 184 falls. The market was described as "uninspiring" by brokers, who had few positive comments. The low volume was likely due to the US bond market being closed for Columbus Day.

site_title: IMF raises Japan growth forecast for 2017 to 1.5%
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its growth forecast for Japan's economy to 1.5% for 2017 and 0.7% for 2018, citing a pickup in exports and stronger consumer spending. The upgrade comes despite warnings of a shrinking labor force and weak inflation. The IMF expects Japan's economy to weaken after 2017 due to fading government stimulus and moderating consumer spending. The report also emphasizes the need for Japan to address low birthrates, increase women's participation in the workforce, and prepare for a planned sales tax rise in 2019.

site_title: Aramco plans 'mega investment' for fully integrated business in India
summary: Saudi Aramco plans a "mega investment" for a fully integrated business in India, with a focus on partnering a planned refinery project in Maharashtra. The company aims to create a significant presence in the world's fastest-growing oil market, which has been diversifying its oil supply sources. India's oil demand is forecast to grow 135,000 barrels a day this year and 275,000 barrels a day in 2018. The partnership would be an extension of Aramco's strategy to lock up market share in Asia, driven by global oil demand growth.

site_title: Wal-Mart launches $20 bln buyback plan
summary: Wal-Mart has launched a $20 billion share buyback plan, replacing a previous $20 billion plan approved in 2015. The company forecasts US online sales to increase by 40% in the fiscal year ending January 2019, with overall net sales expected to rise by at least 3%. Wal-Mart aims to leverage its 4,700 stores to create a more hassle-free experience for online shoppers, competing with Amazon.com Inc. The company also expects to add 1,000 locations for shipping online grocery orders in fiscal year 2019.

site_title: Acuris, with new investor GIC on board, poised to make inroads in Asia
summary: Acuris, a global financial intelligence firm, has secured a new investor, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, with a majority stake. The partnership is expected to provide Acuris with access to larger capital, fueling future growth and acquisitions. Acuris, which has delivered double-digit growth, plans to expand in Asia, leveraging GIC's expertise and resources. The company's Asia-Pacific managing director, Simon Anam, stated that GIC's involvement will aid in product development and acquisitions, and he is optimistic about the firm's future prospects.

site_title: Canada housing starts, building permits fall as long boom cools
summary: Canada's housing starts fell 10.7% in September to 217,118 units, exceeding expectations for a 210,000 annual rate. However, the decline was largely driven by a drop in multiple starts, while single starts rose 8.2%. A separate report showed a 5.5% decrease in building permits in August, surpassing forecasts for a 1.0% decline. The long housing boom appears to be cooling, particularly in Toronto, where a foreign buyers tax has reduced sales. Despite this, residential construction remains robust, with a pace of starts exceeding demographic needs.

site_title: Fund managers drawn to A$2.3 trillion pension pie
summary: Global fund managers are increasingly setting up shop in Australia, drawn to the nation's A$2.3 trillion pension savings pool and new local investment opportunities. The trend is driven by low interest rates in North America, Europe, and Asia, prompting money managers to seek assets they had previously seen as too risky. Many Australian funds are also outgrowing local equity and corporate bond markets, leading them to seek overseas investments and alternative assets. The Australian pension market is swelling due to mandatory retirement saving rules, with around 41% of new investment deals involving alternative money managers.

site_title: China set to meet, or even beat, 2017 growth target of 6.5%
summary: China's economy is expected to meet or exceed its 6.5% growth target for 2017, according to the head of the Statistics Bureau, Ning Jizhe. The country's growth rate accelerated to 6.9% in the first half, driven by government infrastructure spending and a property boom. This would be the first time the growth rate beats the target in seven years. Policymakers are now more willing to tackle mounting debt and push for structural reforms, and analysts expect a moderate slowdown in the coming months.

site_title: Complacency throws markets off course
summary: The stock market is experiencing complacency due to artificially depressed interest rates and explicit guarantees from central banks, throwing regression to the mean off course. Since 2008, interest rates have been kept artificially low, and the US Federal Reserve has intervened to rescue the economy, creating a moral hazard that has led to a constantly rising market. As a result, investors are becoming increasingly complacent, with the VIX Index at a 20-year low, indicating a lack of expected volatility. This has led to a lack of risk in the market, making it difficult to predict future movements.

site_title: JPMorgan, Temasek lead US$100m investment in payments company Bill.com
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co and Temasek Holdings have led a US$100 million investment in Bill.com, a payments company that helps businesses digitize their payments. Bill.com, which processes US$50 billion in payments annually, aims to expand its distribution and enhance its product with the funding. The investment underscores a growing interest in backing young financial technology companies, with JPMorgan and Temasek joining existing investors American Express Co and Silicon Valley Bank. The company's technology can integrate payments into banks' and accounting software providers' websites, aiming to modernize financial services in the US.

site_title: Ford taps Silicon Valley startup for new ways to book rides
summary: Ford has partnered with Silicon Valley startup Autonomic Inc to develop new transportation service applications using its software platform. The first such business is a "micro-transit" service called Non-Emergency Medical Transport, launched by Ford and Michigan-based Beaumont Hospital. Ford aims to build new in-vehicle and mobility-related services with various partners using the Autonomic platform, which could enable digital payment processing and data flow between vehicles and customers. This move is part of Ford's efforts to explore digital services and supplement its existing businesses.

images.alt_text: With the help of Autonomic's software platform, Ford plans to build new in-vehicle and mobility- related services with its partners, says Ford CEO Jim Hackett.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise, bolstered by telecom and property firms
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.6% on Tuesday, driven by gains in telecoms and property firms. The Hang Seng index reached 28,490.83 points, while the China Enterprises Index rose 0.3%. State-owned China Telecom Group jumped 4% to a one-year high, following expectations of benefits from China's 5G technology development.

site_title: Global bank capital rules near completion 10 years after crisis
summary: Global regulators are near completion of bank capital rules 10 years after the 2008 financial crisis. A plan to restrict how low banks can drive their capital requirements by measuring asset risk has been agreed upon, with a 72.5% floor. The final deal must be approved by central bank governors and supervisors. The rules aim to prevent the next financial crisis, but some countries, including France, are still opposed to the measure, which they believe will punish banks with low-risk assets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private apartment and condo resale prices rose 0.1% month-over-month in September 2017, according to SRX Property. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) relaxed some rules on remisiers to encourage new entrants. Analysts praised City Developments' (CDL) plans for a potential privatisation of its London-listed hospitality arm. Meanwhile, Standard Chartered Bank reviewed a $1.4 billion fund transfer and notified authorities. The Singapore Diamond Mint Company launched Diamond Bullion, exclusively listed on the Singapore Diamond Investment Exchange. Aon developed its innovation centre and Koh Bros Eco Engineering received regulatory approval for a proposed rights cum warrants issue.

site_title: India wants foreign investors for US$300b worth of energy projects
summary: India aims to attract foreign investors for $300 billion worth of energy projects over the next decade, with a goal of reducing oil imports to 67% by 2020. The projects include increasing refining capacity, oil and gas block exploration, and gas infrastructure development. The country's oil and gas output has been stagnant, while fuel demand has risen, resulting in a large import bill. The government has relaxed rules and taken steps to boost foreign investment in the sector, with BP and Reliance Industries announcing a $6 billion investment plan.

site_title: Paul Lim steps down as CEO, executive director of Secura Group
summary: Paul Lim, CEO and executive director of Secura Group Limited, has stepped down to pursue personal interests and spend more time with his family. The board will identify a suitable candidate to fill the role, with an appointment to be made in due course.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as North Korea fears ease
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Tuesday as North Korea failed to take provocative action to mark an anniversary, lifting the benchmark Nikkei 225 index 0.64% to 20,823.51, its highest in over two years. Meanwhile, Kobe Steel's shares plummeted after admitting to falsifying quality data for hundreds of clients.

site_title: Trading halts: Alliance Mineral, Trendlines
summary: Trading halts occurred on the Singapore Exchange for Alliance Mineral Assets and The Trendlines Group. Alliance Mineral Assets' stock halted at 9:01am due to an announcement, while Trendlines Group's trading paused at 12:38pm pending an announcement. No further information is available on the reason for the halts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.9 points to 1,761.13, amidst a trading volume of 2.8 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks peak to 11-week high as major techs rally after holiday break
summary: South Korean shares surged to an 11-week high, closing up 1.6% at 2,433.81 points, driven by major tech shares like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, which rose 3% and 7%, respectively. The gains came after a six-day break, catching global stock gains. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) has its highest closing level since July 27.

site_title: Magnitude-6.3 earthquake strikes northern Chile: USGS
summary: A 6.3-magnitude earthquake struck northern Chile, 70km east of the coastal city of Arica, at a depth of 82km. Chile is earthquake-prone, having experienced three quakes over magnitude 8 in the past seven years. The country lies on the Ring of Fire, a fault line prone to frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.

site_title: UN refugee agency reports sudden surge of Rohingya refugees
summary: The UN refugee agency reports a sudden surge of Rohingya refugees crossing into Bangladesh from Myanmar, with over 11,000 arriving on Monday. This marks a significant increase from the previous rate of about 2,000 refugees per day. The influx is attributed to a violent government crackdown following insurgent attacks on security forces. The UNHCR is on high alert, citing the sudden surge as a major concern.

site_title: HK regulator plans investor identification system around mid 2018
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission plans to implement a real-time investor identification system for "northbound" stock trading around mid-2018, aiming to detect potential misconduct in foreign investors buying and selling Chinese stocks. The system, seen as a key step to open up China's capital markets, has enormous potential for trading risk management products in the Asian financial hub.

site_title: ICT solutions provider Adventus names RHT Capital as Catalist sponsor
summary: Adventus Holdings, an ICT solutions provider, has appointed RHT Capital Private Limited as its new Catalist sponsor, replacing Stamford Corporate Services Private Limited. The change takes effect immediately. Adventus closed at one Singapore cent a share on Monday. RHT Capital has made itself available for discussion with Stamford Corporate Services regarding any non-compliance with Catalist rules.

site_title: Indonesia's Garuda estimates US$200m from GMF AeroAsia stake sale : CEO
summary: Indonesia's flag carrier Garuda Indonesia estimates its unit GMF AeroAsia can raise $200 million by selling a 20% stake to a strategic buyer, with a potential sale expected to be signed in early December. GMF AeroAsia has a partnership with Air France Industries KLM Engineering & Maintenance, but it's unclear if this is related to the planned stake sale. The company plans to use proceeds from the sale to finance expansion and debt repayment.

site_title: China Environment unit loses civil suit, ordered to pay loan plus interest
summary: China Environment's subsidiary Fujian Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co lost a civil suit to Zhongxin Bank, ordered to pay a loan of 36.67 million yuan and interest. The judgement, awarded on November 2, 2016, requires FJDY to settle the debt within 10 days, with punitive interest of 9.46125% annually from December 19, 2016.

site_title: Australian shares tick up led by financials, property; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.16% to 5748.3, driven by gains in financials and real estate stocks, while material stocks fell due to weak commodity prices. The Australian financial index rose 0.2%, with AMP Ltd and Genworth Mortgage Insurance Australia Ltd leading gains. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat at 8009.8, as gains in industrials and information technology stocks were offset by falling materials and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Airbnb's Chinese rival raises US$300m for global jaunt
summary: Tujia.com, a Chinese vacation rental platform, has raised $300 million to fund a global expansion, valuing the company at over $1.5 billion. The online travel giant now handles over 650,000 listings globally and is focusing on serving the world's largest population of domestic and international travelers. Tujia aims to increase its presence in Japan and take on Airbnb, which has quadrupled its Chinese tech team to grow its domestic market share.

site_title: Global debt funds set up Aussie shops as A$2.3t calls
summary: Global debt fund managers are setting up operations in Australia, drawn to the country's A$2.3 trillion pension savings pool. New York-based credit hedge fund GoldenTree Asset Management and alternative credit manager THL Credit Inc. have opened offices in Sydney, while Oaktree Capital Management, which already manages Australian pension money, has also established a presence in the country. This trend is driven by low interest rates and the need for investors to seek assets in a growing Australian market.

site_title: Hot stock: Olam's 5.6% share price surge prompts query from SGX
summary: Olam International's stock surged 5.6% on the Singapore Exchange, prompting a trading query from the SGX. This is the second query issued to Olam in less than four months, following a June query. The company replied that it was not aware of any information that could explain the share trades and was in compliance with SGX's listing rules. Temasek Holding recently exercised warrants to raise its stake in the company.

site_title: Ireland bracing for loss in fight for post-Brexit spoils: source
summary: Ireland is unlikely to win the bids to host the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Medicines Agency (EMA) after the UK's departure from the EU, a source says. Frankfurt is considered a leading candidate for the EBA, while Amsterdam and Copenhagen are top contenders for the EMA. Ireland's geographical location and lack of natural allies make it a less favorable candidate for the organizations.

site_title: Singapore healthcare sector's online-jobs growth up 15.2% in Q3: JobTech
summary: Singapore's healthcare sector experienced the strongest online-jobs growth at 15.2% in Q3 2017, followed by offshore and marine at 12.8%. The electronics and semiconductor segment saw its first negative growth since Q4 2016, potentially indicating a softening in manufacturing output. The biotech and pharmaceuticals sector declined 0.4%. The survey found that 24% of online-jobs require programming skills, and 19% require data management or statistical software skills.

site_title: Honeywell puts more of its chips on aerospace
summary: Honeywell International Inc plans to unveil a corporate makeover, focusing more on aerospace technology and spinning off assets to concentrate on this sector. The move comes after activist investor Third Point Capital urged the company to divest non-core businesses. Analysts expect the aerospace business to benefit from growing commercial and military production, as well as rising demand for connected aircraft services.

site_title: China's yuan jumps after firmer-than-expected official fix
summary: China's onshore and offshore yuan jumped to their strongest level in over two weeks, breaching a key psychological threshold and gaining 0.5% against the US dollar. The People's Bank of China set a firmer-than-expected official yuan midpoint of 6.6273 per dollar, citing a day earlier's spot yuan performance. This move is seen as authorities working to stabilize the currency ahead of a key national leadership meeting next week, following firmer-than-expected guidance.

site_title: Asia: Markets move cautiously after tepid US lead
summary: Asia's markets moved cautiously on Tuesday, with Seoul's Kospi jumping 2% after a long weekend, while Tokyo rose 0.4%. Hong Kong and Shanghai dipped 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively. US markets ended down due to the Columbus Day holiday, snapping a nine-gain streak for the Nasdaq. The euro rose against the dollar following a forecast-beating German industrial output report, while the pound remained slightly healthier despite uncertainty over UK Prime Minister Theresa May's future.

site_title: Taiwan President Tsai pledges to defend island's freedoms
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen pledged to defend her island's freedom and democracy during her National Day speech, warning that Taiwan would not bow to pressure from Beijing. Tsai emphasized the importance of democracy and freedom, obtained through Taiwan's people's efforts. She also stated that her government is seeking breakthroughs in ties with Beijing and promised consistent and stable policies. Tsai's speech aimed to reassure the Taiwanese people and the international community about her administration's commitment to Taiwan's sovereignty.

site_title: Qantas raising A$350m in loan, allows switching aircraft types used as collateral
summary: Qantas Airways has secured an A$350 million loan, allowing it to switch the types of aircraft used as collateral, in what is considered the world's first aviation financing of this type. The eight-year loan, structured by BNP Paribas and National Australia Bank, will help Qantas refinance part of its secured aircraft and other debt maturing in 2018. This move gives Qantas more flexibility in its fleet management and allows it to monetize its assets. The loan has been oversubscribed by 10 financial institutions, offering long-term dollar-denominated returns.

site_title: Las Vegas killer was high roller, Valium user: CNN
summary: Stephen Paddock, the 64-year-old Las Vegas mass killer who killed 58 people and wounded 500, was a high-roller who gambled for 14 hours a day, 365 days a year. He was a compulsive video poker player and used the anxiety drug Valium. Paddock's background, which included owning numerous properties and working as an IRS agent, has raised questions about why police couldn't locate him sooner. A security guard, Jesus Campos, was shot six minutes before the attack, and Paddock's motivations remain unclear.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong shares opened slightly higher on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.15% to 28,368.47, following a weak lead from Wall Street. However, the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined, with the latter dipping 0.62 points to 2,013.81. The gains were muted due to ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: South Korea: Tech shares start post-holiday trade with surge on earnings hopes
summary: South Korean tech shares, led by Samsung Electronics, surged on Tuesday, catching up with global stock market gains after a week-long break. Shares in Samsung jumped 4.3% and SK Hynix Inc rose as much as 8.6%, while Samsung SDI gained 8.1%. The tech giant is expected to report record profit in its July-September quarter, with analysts predicting 14.3 trillion won in operating profit. The Seoul stock index rose 1.9% as investors bet on strong earnings.

site_title: Vickers Venture completes largest fundraising yet with US$230m
summary: Vickers Venture Partners, a Singaporean venture capital firm led by Finian Tan, has completed its largest fundraising yet with US$230 million. This includes US$190 million in its fifth fund and a yuan-denominated vehicle of US$40 million. The firm is focusing on "deep technology" and impact, targeting investments in emerging markets such as digital wallets and health. Vickers has a portfolio of companies including Kpisoft, SiSaf, and MatchMove Pay, and plans to open a new office in San Francisco in 2018.

site_title: SMU, Spring, EDB launch retail industry development centre
summary: Singapore Management University (SMU), Spring Singapore, and the Economic Development Board (EDB) have launched the Retail Centre of Excellence (RCoE) to research and provide insights into Singapore's retail industry. The centre, led by SMU marketing professor Kapil Tuli, is housed at SMU's Lee Kong Chian School of Business and features founding members from prominent retail companies. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Sim Ann stated that the centre aims to position Singapore as a thought leader for the retail industry in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: More measures needed to boost disaster resilience in Asia-Pacific: United Nations
summary: The United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) reports that Asia-Pacific countries need more measures to boost disaster resilience as natural disasters become more frequent. Between 2000 and 2015, low-income countries experienced 15 times more disaster deaths than high-income countries. By 2030, 40% of global economic losses from disasters are expected to occur in the Asia-Pacific region, with small island developing states and least developed countries facing significant losses. The UN emphasizes the need for early warning systems, innovative disaster risk financing, and collaboration among countries to address climate change-related risks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH Reit, Boustead Projects, Jason Marine, Epicentre
summary: SPH Reit reported a 0.7% improvement in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, with gross revenue rising 1.3% to S$52.9 million. Boustead Projects secured S$56 million in contracts in Singapore, while Jason Marine issued a profit warning due to softer demand caused by depressed oil prices. Epicentre Holdings' auditor flagged issues with financial statements, leading to an independent review by Deloitte & Touche.

site_title: StanChart says it reviewed transfer of funds, 'proactively' notified authorities
summary: Standard Chartered Bank said it reviewed the transfer of $1.4 billion in funds from Indonesia to Singapore in 2015 and proactively notified authorities. The move comes amid allegations that the bank moved assets on behalf of Indonesian clients to avoid tax transparency rules. Regulators in Europe and Asia are also investigating the matter. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said it will take firm action against any financial institution found to have breached anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing requirements. Standard Chartered is cooperating with regulators and declined to provide further information.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS maintains 'hold' on SingPost with launch of retail mall
summary: DBS Securities maintained its "hold" call on SingPost, citing the potential boost to rental income from the launch of the retail wing of SingPost Centre. The mall, which opened after S$150 million redevelopment works, has 80.4% committed occupancy and is expected to contribute to rental income from FY2019. DBS targets a S$1.26 price for the stock, citing a need for SingPost to stabilize the mall segment's operating profit and deliver a sharp recovery in logistics and e-commerce operation profits.

site_title: Aon developing Singapore innovation centre; to raise headcount by 40%
summary: Aon is developing a new innovation centre in Singapore, set to increase its headcount by 40% over the next five years. The centre, ACIA, aims to foster collaboration between Aon and global innovation partners. With a current workforce of over 100 in Singapore, ACIA has established itself as a key player in analytics and innovation. The centre's development is seen as a key step in Singapore's growth in the digital economy, with the government aiming to grow data and analytics capabilities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 3.35 points to 1,760.68. Volume was 134.46 million lots worth RM 36.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 131 to 59.

site_title: Public-sector strikes add to pressure on France's Macron
summary: French civil servants, angered by President Emmanuel Macron's plans to freeze pay, eliminate 120,000 public jobs, and cut funding to regional governments, have gone on strike, affecting hospitals, schools, and transportation. The strike is the fourth in a series, with 9 unions representing 5.4 million workers calling for a nationwide protest to show their "profound disagreement" with Macron's cost-cutting agenda. The strike is seen as a challenge to Macron's pro-business policies and has sparked concerns that the president will continue to implement his agenda unless other workers join the protest.

site_title: China central bank boss calls for reform amid congress countdown
summary: China's People's Bank of China Governor Zhou Xiaochuan has called for financial sector reform, citing the need for foreign trade and investment, a market-based foreign-exchange rate mechanism, and relaxation of capital controls to free up the yuan. This comes as China prepares for its Communist Party leadership transition and Zhou's expected retirement. The central bank chief emphasizes the importance of seizing the "window of opportunity" for reforms, warning that missed opportunities will result in higher costs.

site_title: NZ dollar near 4-month lows on election negotiations; Aussie edges up
summary: The New Zealand dollar is near four-month lows due to concerns the opposition Labour Party may form a ruling coalition after a final vote count showed they have 54 seats. Analysts expect Labour and the Greens to form a coalition with the small conservative party New Zealand First, which could lead to further losses in the kiwi. In contrast, the Australian dollar edged up after a private survey showed business conditions in Australia were at their highest since early 2008, supporting the currency's recovery.

site_title: Stocks in Asia mostly higher; US dollar declines
summary: Asian stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by Japan and South Korea reopening after holidays, while US dollar declined and Turkey's lira maintained losses. The Kospi index in Seoul jumped 1.9% and Tokyo shares fluctuated, while the US dollar fell against major peers. Global stocks near a record high, and Treasury yields have climbed as traders expect a Fed rate hike in December. Earnings season begins for major US banks this week, and Spanish assets will be in focus with Catalan President Carles Puigdemont's declaration of gradual independence.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower amid North Korea jitters
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on October 10, 2017, due to a stronger yen and concerns over a possible North Korea missile launch. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.11% and the Topix index fell 0.18%. The market reaction was likely influenced by the rising tensions between North Korea and the international community.

site_title: Samsung Electronics shares jump on expected record Q3 memory chip profit
summary: Samsung Electronics shares surged 4.5% after the company was expected to announce record profits in memory chips for the July-September quarter. This marked the largest intraday percentage gain since October 2016. SK Hynix Inc, the world's second-largest memory chip maker, also saw its shares jump 4.3%. The strong performance was attributed to positive market expectations.

site_title: Uber, Airbnb get dragged into Scandinavian welfare economics
summary: Denmark aims to integrate the sharing economy, including companies like Uber and Airbnb, into its welfare model by updating tax and labor laws. The government estimates one-fifth of Danes use or offer shared services, a proportion expected to increase. Despite Uber's previous departure, the company plans to return. Airbnb will be allowed to operate, with a voluntary tax program and changes to property rental laws. The Danish government sees the sharing economy as a way to expand services, not curtail them, with "enormous potential" for growth.

site_title: Singapore shares inch up in early trading on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares rose slightly in early trading on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 1.5 points or 0.05% to 3,293.06. The market saw a slight edge in gains, with 102.8 million shares changing hands worth S$91.6 million.

site_title: Diamond bullion to be listed in Singapore
summary: The Singapore Diamond Mint Company (SDM) has launched Diamond Bullion, a portable, credit card-sized package of investment-grade polished diamonds, exclusively listed on the Singapore Diamond Investment Exchange (SDiX). The bullion is valued at US$100,000 and US$200,000 and will be traded globally with real-time pricing data. This move aims to make diamonds a fungible product, allowing for instant price transparency and liquidity. The SDM chairman, Francis Yeoh, describes the Diamond Bullion as the "Gold Bullion for diamonds," offering investors a new way to access the value of diamonds.

site_title: UK consumers spend more to meet higher food and clothing prices
summary: UK consumers increased their spending in September by 1.9% on a like-for-like basis, driven by higher prices for food and clothing after the Brexit vote. This marks the fastest pace of growth so far in 2017, excluding Easter-related sales in April. Despite the rise, consumers are focusing on essential purchases, with non-food sales up only 0.5% and big-ticket items being delayed. The Bank of England expects a pick-up in spending, but consumers remain cautious.

site_title: Australia business activity holds strong despite retail woes:survey
summary: Australia's business conditions index reached its highest level since 2008, staying at +14 in September, driven by strong construction and mining sectors. Despite retail struggles, the index of business confidence rebounded to +7, while sales and profits rose to historically high levels. The upbeat outcome contrasts with cautious consumer spending, which could weigh on overall growth. Policymakers have expressed concerns about slow wage growth and high household debt, but the survey suggests businesses are faring well, potentially paving the way for interest rate hikes in the second half of 2018.

site_title: Private apartment, condo resale prices inch up 0.1% m-o-m in Sept: SRX Property
summary: Singapore's resale prices of private apartments and condos increased 0.1% month-over-month in September 2017, according to SRX Property. This follows a 0.9% rise in August 2017. Year-over-year, prices rose 4.3% from September 2016, while the resale volume decreased 10.9% month-over-month to 1,162 units, but was 64.8% higher than September 2016. The city fringe region saw the highest price gain, followed by the Core Central Region.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE on the defensive as stronger pound drags
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index fell 0.2% to 7,507.89 points on Monday, weighed down by a stronger pound that dragged down dollar-earning stocks such as miners and oil majors. The pound's bounce from lows after the weekend countered its previous decline, putting pressure on the index. Analysts said the FTSE is overbought and due for a correction, but still expected to rise due to positive economic indicators.

site_title: US dollar retreats from 10-week highs as euro gains, stocks dip
summary: The US dollar retreated from a 10-week high against a basket of currencies as the euro strengthened, driven by German industrial output data and comments from European Central Bank Executive Board member Sabine Lautenschlaeger. The dollar index fell 0.1% to 93.668, while the euro edged up 0.1% to US$1.1748. Analysts cited modest US economic growth and overseas central bank considerations as limiting the dollar's recovery. Tensions between the US and North Korea also weighed on the dollar.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts keep 'buy' on CDL's plans for potential M&C bid
summary: Analysts have given a thumbs-up to City Developments' (CDL) potential privatization of its London-listed hospitality arm, Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C). Maybank Kim Eng maintained its "buy" recommendation with a target price of S$11.75, while OCBC Investment Research also recommended a "buy" call with a fair-value estimate of S$12.90. CDL has negotiated a cash takeover price of 552.5 pence per M&C share, which is expected to be accretive to the group if fully consolidated.

site_title: Oil prices climb after Opec signals possible deal extension
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday after OPEC signaled a possible deal extension to restore market balance. Brent crude climbed 17 cents to $55.79 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 0.6% to $49.58 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is set to discuss its pact to reduce output in Vienna on November 30. OPEC Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo said consultations were underway for an extension of the agreement, which could lead to more oil-producing nations joining the pact.

site_title: Google finds Russian-financed content: Washington Post
summary: Google has found evidence that Russian operatives spent tens of thousands of dollars on ads across its platforms, including YouTube, Gmail, and DoubleClick, to spread disinformation during the 2016 US presidential election. The company has strict ads policies, but is taking a deeper look into potential abuse. This discovery comes as other social media giants, Facebook and Twitter, have also found evidence of Russian-financed content. US justice officials are probing alleged Russian involvement and possible collusion by the Trump campaign.

site_title: SingPost Centre delivers mail, mall and more
summary: The SingPost Centre, a five-storey mall in Singapore, has reopened after a two-year redevelopment, doubling its gross retail floor area to 269,000 square feet. The mall now features major tenants such as FairPrice, Golden Village, and Kopitiam, as well as a new General Post Office (GPO) and a digital network offering anytime and anywhere access to postal services. The GPO features automated systems and self-service kiosks, aiming to improve operational efficiency and provide a better experience for customers.

site_title: Epicentre auditor withholds opinion; company sets up independent review
summary: AUDITOR BDO has withheld its opinion on Epicentre Holdings' FY2017 accounts due to a lack of evidence for certain transactions, including consultancy services agreements and advances to a supplier in China. The company has appointed Deloitte & Touche for an independent review. BDO questioned the commercial reasons, economic substance, legality, and legitimacy of these transactions, as well as the source of funds and loan novation agreements. Epicentre has borrowed S$1.76 million at 24% interest, which was subsequently novated to the company's chairman. The independent review aims to clarify the issues.

site_title: MAS issues stern money laundering warning; Jakarta starts StanChart probe
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a stern warning against money laundering, following a report that Standard Chartered (StanChart) transferred $1.4 billion held by Indonesian clients in a Guernsey tax haven to Singapore in 2015, just before the Channel island implemented tax transparency rules. MAS is investigating the matter, which is also being probed by Indonesia's financial regulator. The bank's processes and staff actions are being examined, but no collusion with clients is suspected. MAS has a robust anti-money laundering regime in place and has taken firm action against institutions with control deficiencies.

site_title: Gold recoups previous week's losses as dollar eases
summary: Gold prices rose on Monday, erasing previous week's losses, due to a weaker dollar and the return of Chinese buyers. The metal rebounded after falling to a two-month low, with spot gold up 0.6% at $1,283.16 an ounce. Geopolitical concerns and expectations of a US interest rate hike in December also supported gold prices. Analysts believe the metal may have bottomed out, and China's central bank holding off from adding to gold reserves lent further support.

site_title: The 'spoils society' sows seeds for resentment and discord
summary: The "spoils society" is advancing, characterized by a shift in economic interests from creating new wealth to grabbing existing wealth, leading to redistributive struggles and economic stagnation. A new book, The Captured Economy, by Brink Lindsey and Steven M. Teles, argues that self-serving arrangements mainly benefiting the rich impose excess costs on the poor and middle-class, reducing economic growth. Examples include restrictive zoning, occupational licensing, and artificially high prices that redistribute wealth, hindering economic growth and fostering resentment and discord.

site_title: UN slaps global port ban on ships for North Korea sanctions violations
summary: The UN has imposed a global port ban on four North Korean ships found violating sanctions, the first such action. The ships, identified as Petrel 8, Hao Fan 6, Tong San 2, and Jie Shun, were found transporting prohibited goods such as coal, seafood, and iron ore. The ban, effective October 5, marks an unprecedented move by the UN Security Council panel on North Korea sanctions. The designation does not include asset freezes or travel bans, but restricts the ships from docking at any port worldwide.

site_title: Still shedding assets but worst is over: Tat Hong CEO
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a crane supplier, has expressed optimism that the worst of its asset sales is over. CEO Roland Ng stated that the company is turning around and expects to sell another 30 cranes, despite some losses. Tat Hong plans to adopt a more asset-light model, procuring cranes from other companies, and aims to increase its share of other companies' cranes in China from 10% to 30%. The company's shares have risen in the past month after discussing potential transactions.

site_title: French bankers facing pressure to return home amid Brexit fears
summary: French investment banks are expected to return home to Paris amid Brexit fears, with senior staff anticipating pressure from the government to base more jobs in France. Despite uncertainty around a "hard" Brexit, French banks feel they can afford to wait due to existing EU licenses through their Paris headquarters. The government has introduced measures to attract banks, including tax breaks and international schools, and former Bank of France governor Christian Noyer has made pitches to banks to relocate. France's two biggest investment banks, BNP Paribas and Societe Generale, are not yet set to make firm plans, but some have expressed willingness to move jobs to Paris.

site_title: US: Stocks fall; Nasdaq winning streak ends
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, with the Nasdaq falling 0.2% to 6,579.73, snapping a nine-day gain streak and six straight records. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also fell 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively. Investor optimism about upcoming earnings and a US tax cut was tempered by light trading volume due to the Columbus Day holiday. Several major companies, including General Electric, Tesla Motors, and Viacom, reported earnings or made announcements that negatively impacted their shares.

site_title: Eurogroup head Dijsselbloem to step down in January
summary: Dutch Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem will step down as head of the Eurogroup in January, after his party suffered a drubbing in national elections. He will remain in office until the end of his mandate, despite losing his ministerial job. The vacancy will spark a competitive bidding process, with several eurozone figures vying for the position, including French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire and European Economics Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici. The departure of Dijsselbloem leaves a void at a crucial moment, as the eurozone prepares to set out on major reforms towards better integration in the single currency bloc.

site_title: Irish finance minister to get creative with budget boost
summary: Ireland's finance minister, Paschal Donohoe, will need to be creative in Tuesday's budget to balance the state's books and fund additional spending. The budget package is expected to target 900-1 billion euros, with a focus on increasing stamp duty on commercial property to boost revenue. The government aims to stick to a 2:1 ratio of spending increase to tax cuts, with a focus on welfare payments and healthcare. The budget comes amid sluggish consumer sentiment and increasing living costs, and will likely be the last significant boost before the next election.

site_title: Competition watchdog raises concerns over Wilhelmsen-Drew deal
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has raised concerns over the proposed acquisition by Wilhelmsen Maritime Services AS of Drew Marine's technical solutions, fire, safety, and rescue businesses. The CCS notes that the two parties are the largest players with extensive global networks, potentially reducing competition and leading to price increases and decreased product quality. The CCS will conduct a Phase 2 review, expected to take 120 business days, to determine if the deal would substantially lessen competition in Singapore's marine sector.

site_title: Russians in Silicon Valley can't shake off shadow of computer hacking
summary: Russian investors and entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley are facing a growing stigma due to Russia's involvement in computer hacking and election interference. Some have reported being treated differently socially and professionally, with investors questioning the "cleanliness" of their money. However, others claim they have not experienced any changes, and interest in hiring Russian tech talent is increasing. The tension is a new phenomenon, as Russian immigrants played a significant role in building Silicon Valley's tech giants in the past.

site_title: US dollar nears 10-week high on rate-hike bets
summary: The US dollar reached a 10-week high due to strong US wages data and bets on a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December. Sterling recovered 0.9% as UK political uncertainty eased. The dollar index hit its highest level since late July at 94.267, before inching down 0.1% to 93.701. Investors focused on upcoming US inflation and retail sales data, as well as minutes from the Fed's latest policy meeting, as the Fed's tightening path remains a concern.

site_title: Amazon faces uphill struggle in S'pore from malls and Alibaba
summary: Amazon faces significant challenges in Singapore's crowded retail market, where online shopping is less popular than in other developed countries. Despite a new venture into Singapore, Amazon lags behind local e-commerce leader Lazada and its parent Alibaba, with delivery delays and limited product offerings. Singapore's mature retail market makes it harder for Amazon to grow, with only 4.6% of retail sales taking place online last year. Amazon's physical store presence is seen as key to success, with other retailers like Vivre Activewear and Lazada also expanding their physical presence.

site_title: A Trump U-turn on Iran will raise trans- Atlantic tensions
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to announce whether he will certify Iran's compliance with its nuclear agreement with the West, potentially raising trans-Atlantic tensions. Trump has expressed dissatisfaction with the deal, and his refusal to certify it could lead to re-imposed US sanctions. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani's political position is vulnerable if the agreement fails, as it undermines his economic and foreign policy vision. EU leaders, including Federica Mogherini, are working to keep the agreement alive, which could deepen divisions with Washington.

site_title: Temasek's Vertex Ventures raises US$210m for South-east Asian deals
summary: Vertex Ventures, the venture capital arm of Temasek Holdings, has raised US$210 million for South-east Asian deals, exceeding its target of US$150 million. This is the firm's third South-east Asian fund and marks a record in the region. The money will be used for early stage investments, including those in ride-hailing company Grab, which Vertex was the first institutional backer of. Vertex plans to expand its presence in other South-east Asian cities and continues its strategy of investing in enterprise technology, financial technology, and consumer Internet startups.

site_title: TSMC ready to spend US$20b on its most advanced chip plant
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) is planning to spend over $20 billion on its next-generation chip plant, the most advanced technology it has ever built. The 86-year-old founder, Morris Chang, says the investment is necessary to stay ahead of competitors like Intel and Samsung Electronics Co. in cutting-edge semiconductor production. The company, which assembles mobile phone processors for Apple Inc, currently spends $10 billion annually, which may increase to $11 billion as the technology becomes more intricate.

site_title: KL banks deny being tightfisted with home buyers
summary: Malaysia's commercial banks have denied being tightfisted with home buyers, citing that 7 out of 10 loans approved in the year to August were to first-time home buyers under the affordable homes category, totaling RM42 billion. The banks' average processing time for housing loans is 2-9 working days, and they will continue to exercise prudent and responsible lending. Despite a housing supply and demand mismatch, the banks' actions contradict claims by developers that stringent lending is a significant stumbling block to improved sales.

site_title: Markets hold their breath; hope Catalonia will step back from brink
summary: Catalonia's referendum on independence from Spain has sparked uncertainty, with the region's president, Carles Puigdemont, set to address the parliament on Tuesday. Despite a massive Barcelona protest in favor of unity, polls suggest 90% of the 2.3 million people voted in favor of independence, but the turnout was only 43%. Markets remain calm, but companies are considering relocating their headquarters to Madrid, and experts warn that a potential independent Catalonia could lead to economic instability and potentially even EU sanctions.

site_title: Buyers eye Sinopec's troubled Argentina oil assets
summary: China's Sinopec is selling its troubled oil assets in Argentina to about a dozen buyers, including Sonangol and Rosneft, for $750 million to $1 billion. The assets, mainly in Santa Cruz, have been losing value due to labor headaches and declining oil output. Sinopec had initially paid $2.45 billion for the assets in 2010, but is now seeking a lower price. The sale is part of Sinopec's efforts to diversify its oil sources and cut losses, following worsening economic conditions and social unrest in Argentina.

site_title: Sembmarine shares buoyed by US$1.3b sale of jack-up rigs
summary: SembCorp Marine's share price rose 4.6% to S$1.815 after selling nine jack-up drilling rigs to Borr Drilling for US$1.3 billion. The deal significantly improves the company's liquidity position, despite a US$15 million loss. The sale reduces Sembmarine's net gearing to 76% by end-2018. UOB Kay Hian upgraded its rating to 'buy' and raised its target price to S$1.90, citing the removal of an overhang from insufficient provisions due to undelivered rigs.

site_title: Bond party set to cool in India as inflation, fiscal risks loom
summary: India's bond market is expected to cool due to accelerating inflation and fiscal risks. The benchmark 10-year yield has risen to 6.76%, its highest close since mid-May, and is predicted to jump to 7% or more by end of March. The Reserve Bank of India's decision to leave interest rates unchanged and raise inflation forecasts has exacerbated the decline in bond prices, with potential increases in government borrowing and widening fiscal deficit posing significant risks. Local investors are pessimistic, but overseas investors see the selloff as an opportunity to buy into the market.

site_title: Psst, want to buy a private jet at half price?
summary: Corporate jet manufacturers are flooding the market with new aircraft, leading to deep discounts and a three-year slide in prices of used planes. Major manufacturers, including Gulfstream and Bombardier, have slowed production due to sagging demand, but discounts are not enough to halt declines in aircraft values. The market is experiencing a buyer's market for used aircraft, with prices down 16% from last year and some pre-owned planes selling for as little as 56% of their original list price.

site_title: SilkAir to take over Scoot's Yangon flights
summary: SilkAir, a regional arm of Singapore Airlines, will take over Scoot's Yangon flights starting October 29, increasing its weekly flights to 15 non-stop services. This transfer aims to optimize aircraft utilization and free up Scoot's resources for other network development. Existing Scoot passengers will be re-accommodated on SilkAir, while those who prefer to cancel can opt for a full refund. The change will also reduce Scoot's network to 60 destinations across 16 countries.

site_title: Singapore brands lack support from local consumers: study
summary: A study by Nanyang Technological University and NTU Singapore's Institute on Asian Consumer Insight found that Singaporeans prefer foreign brands over local ones, with only 12.5% of the population choosing local brands. This ranks Singapore the lowest among Asian nations such as Japan, South Korea, and Thailand, which have higher percentages of consumers preferring local brands. Experts attribute this to Singapore's cosmopolitan nature and the need for local brands to focus on quality rather than price to gain consumer loyalty.

site_title: India faces dampened demand, stagnant lending, slowing growth
summary: India's economy faces a dampened demand, stagnant lending, and slowing growth due to a cash ban and high oil prices. Consumption, driven by government policies, is expected to be the main driver of growth, but job security remains a concern with manufacturing jobs forecast to decline 30% this year. Policymakers lack room for a stimulus due to a widening budget deficit and accelerating inflation.

images.alt_text: Workers cleaning hides at a tannery in India; manufacturing jobs are forecast to fall about 30 per cent this year, and broader surveys show that the hiring outlook is near a 12-year low.

site_title: Reading MAS's policy moves: It's all in the choice of words
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is set to release its monetary policy statement this week, with economists divided on whether it will maintain its neutral policy stance or drop the "extended period" phrase. The MAS's tone and language are crucial, with a more positive tone potentially driving a rally in the Singapore dollar and a shift to an upward-sloping policy band. Economists expect a tightening in 2018, but the timing depends on the pace of recovery in coming quarters, with the MAS likely to restore a positive slope next April amid persistently positive data surprises.

site_title: Alliance Mineral CEO: Better terms in latest agreement with Burwill
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets Ltd, a lithium mining company in Western Australia, has secured better terms in its agreement with Burwill Commodity, a funding and equity partner. The company will receive more lenient delivery terms and can deliver lithium concentrate as late as May without incurring a penalty. Burwill has also increased its offtake amount to 70,000-75,000 tonnes in 2018 and 80,000-85,000 tonnes in 2019, at a price of US$880 per tonne. The new agreement is more favorable to Alliance Mineral and will provide the company with US$132-140 million in revenue.

site_title: A coordinating institution to give impetus to OBOR is needed
summary: China's "One Belt, One Road" (OBOR) project, aiming to link Asia with Europe via land and maritime highways, faces challenges without a central authority to coordinate projects in 64 countries. The Indian government's objection to the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor due to disputed territory and US backing New Delhi on the issue highlight the project's complexities. A coordinating institution or multilateral process is needed to address administrative, logistical, and political hurdles, with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) potentially playing a role in this regard.

site_title: Realpolitik lessons amid self-determination ideals
summary: Catalonia and Iraq's Kurds are seeking independence, challenging the international status quo. Despite the right to self-determination being a basic principle in international law, the path to statehood appears impossible due to opposition from global powers and the need for significant economic and military resources. Realpolitik considerations outweigh idealistic principles, and negotiations with Spain and Iraq are recommended to reinforce political autonomy. The Catalans and Kurds' demands for independence may be impossible to achieve anytime soon, but they can continue to dream of national independence in the future.

site_title: Big pharma gets a boost as China speeds up new drug approvals
summary: China has implemented new rules to speed up approvals of medicines and medical devices, allowing data from overseas clinical trials to be used for drug registrations. The changes are expected to cut delays in the launch of new drugs by several years, benefiting multinationals such as Pfizer and AstraZeneca, and Chinese drugmakers. The move is also seen as a growth opportunity for the pharmaceutical market, which is the second-largest in the world. The changes are part of a broader overhaul of China's drug regulatory system, aimed at improving patients' access to new medicines and increasing revenues for pharmaceutical companies.

site_title: Troubled China Sky eyes revamp via reverse takeover
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co Ltd is restructuring through a reverse takeover despite financial and legal troubles. The company listed various projects, including rural urbanisation, retirement living, and tourism development, to potentially inject new capital. It is also dealing with lawsuits filed against its Chinese subsidiary, Qingdao Zhongda Chemical Fibre Company Ltd, including a guarantee for a "fraudulent loan" of 790 million yuan. The group is awaiting Chinese authority approval to change its legal representative, citing an inability to find a suitable candidate due to unresolved issues surrounding its subsidiaries.

site_title: Industrial manufacturers must extract more value from digital innovation
summary: Industrial manufacturers in ASEAN must adopt Industry X.0, a circular approach to industrial value creation, to stay relevant and drive revenue growth. Industry X.0 leverages Industry 4.0 technologies, such as cyber-physical systems and cloud computing, to create smart products and plants. Companies must develop an ecosystem, business model, and capabilities to differentiate themselves from competitors. Accenture research found that only 20% of C-level executives have a holistic strategy for harnessing the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT). To succeed, companies must master the radical digital transition and adopt an innovation-driven growth model, including the Brilliant Innovator approach, which yields the highest returns.

site_title: OCBC, StarHub launch S$6m 'We Economy' tie-up
summary: OCBC and StarHub have launched a S$6 million partnership to drive a "Singapore-centric We Economy". The 12-month collaboration aims to develop Big Data, AI, and IoT capabilities to deliver integrated, relevant customer solutions. Both companies will build partnerships across industries and invest in a network of partners, offering a merged customer base of over 5 million. Customers can enjoy cash credits and rebates with both banks and telco, and the partnership is seen as a high-profile example of the We Economy at work.

site_title: Dove sorry for advert branded racist
summary: Dove, a personal care brand owned by Unilever, apologized for a body wash advert that showed a black woman revealing a white woman underneath, sparking accusations of racism. The three-second video clip was posted on Facebook and removed after backlash on social media, with critics citing the ad's "diminishing" effect on diversity. Dove said it deeply regretted any offense caused and vowed to do better in representing women of color. The incident has sparked conversations about diversity and representation in advertising.

site_title: Blade Runner sequel stumbles at US box office
summary: Blade Runner 2049 underperformed at the US box office, taking in $31.5 million over the weekend, 30% less than expected. The film, starring Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford, drew mostly male audiences, with 71% of ticket buyers being men. Despite positive reviews, the film's two-hour runtime and complex plot may have limited its appeal. The film did better overseas, with Sony Pictures Entertainment reporting $50.2 million in partial international release. The film's production cost was at least $200 million.

site_title: Reading PBOC signals takes 'mosaic approach': Goldman Sachs
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), may adjust monetary policy in the coming months due to changes in the economy or shifting agendas of top political leaders following the 19th Party Congress. Goldman Sachs analysts recommend a "mosaic approach" to understand policy intentions, analyzing a range of signals, including interbank rates and quarterly reports. The PBOC has been reining in debt risk and pledging "prudent and neutral" policy, with the benchmark lending rate unchanged for almost two years. A potential policy rate adjustment could be triggered by the upcoming party leadership reshuffle.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine announced the sale of nine Pacific Class 400 jackup drilling rigs to Borr Drilling for $1.3 billion. The sale is expected to be completed over 14 months, with Borr paying an upfront down payment of $500 million. Amara Holdings is expected to see a 35% increase in net profit in 2018 due to higher occupancy rates and a new hotel in Shanghai. Analysts maintain a "BUY" rating for both Sembcorp Marine and Amara Holdings, with fair value estimates of $1.98 and $0.88, respectively.

site_title: Noble responds to SGX queries on sale of gas and power unit
summary: Noble Group sold its gas and power unit, Noble Americas Gas & Power Corp, to Mercuria Energy America Inc for US$102 million, less than the initially indicated US$261 million. The discrepancy arose due to changes in working capital and amounts placed in escrow, with the actual amount being derived from the estimated net working capital of US$249 million. Noble attributed the decrease to the settlement of customer invoices, which lowered trade accounts receivable and converted working capital into cash.

site_title: Accor bids A$1.18b for Mantra
summary: Accor, France's largest hotelier, has bid A$1.18 billion (S$1.25 billion) for Mantra Group, combining the two largest hotel owners in Australia. The offer is a 23% premium to Mantra's closing price, valuing the company at A$4.02 per share. The deal aims to capitalize on Australia's surging tourism, with 7.9 million visitors in the past financial year.
