summary: STEM Med, a subsidiary of TalkMed Group, has formed a joint venture with A DrBrand (ADB) called DrSG Cellular Wellness. The JV has an issued and paid-up capital of S$100, with STEM Med holding 60% of the shares. The partnership aims to develop customized skin care and hair rejuvenation products using protein-rich derivatives. The incorporation of the JV will not impact TalkMed's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year. The JV will utilize the expertise of STEM Med and ADB in stem cell technology and aesthetics, respectively.

site_title: Exponential moving averages will dictate if uptrend remains valid
summary: The US equity market continues to set new record highs, with the S&P 500 index reaching a 14% year-to-date gain. Despite rising geopolitical tensions, the current uptrend remains unshakeable. The 20 and 60-day exponential moving averages (EMAs) are expected to dictate the market's direction, with a correction likely to occur when the RSI enters extremely overbought conditions. A major trend reversal will only occur if the S&P 500 index breaks below the 20 and 60 EMAs significantly, with the 20 EMA crossing below the 60 EMA providing further confirmation.

site_title: Duterte's support tumbles after minors die in Philippine drug war
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's popularity has plummeted by 18 percentage points to 48% following the deaths of minors in his deadly drug war, according to a Social Weather Stations survey. The decline was most pronounced among the poor and urban residents. Human rights groups have accused Duterte's administration of condoning extra-judicial killings, while the government claims around 3,800 people have died in the war, with some groups estimating the number to be over 7,000. Duterte's trust rating has also dropped 15 percentage points to 60%.

site_title: US Treasury report calls for easing of dozens of Wall Street rules
summary: The US Treasury Department released a 220-page report urging the easing of dozens of Wall Street rules, including those imposed after the 2008 financial crisis. The report, which was released by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, calls for regulators to streamline the regulatory system and make US capital markets a source of economic growth. The proposals, which include adjustments to rules stemming from the Sarbanes-Oxley and Dodd-Frank Acts, are expected to be implemented by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC).

images.alt_text: "By streamlining the regulatory system, we can make the US capital markets a true source of economic growth which will harness American ingenuity and allow small businesses to grow." - US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin.

site_title: Why top-down approach to cool Toronto housing is an uphill battle
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's efforts to curb Toronto's runaway home prices are expected to be an uphill battle due to market dynamics and weak economic fundamentals. A study by the Canada Mortgage & Housing Corp found that supply constraints and speculation accounted for 40% of the 40% surge in Toronto home prices between 2010 and 2016, rather than demand. The report suggests that addressing the affordability crisis in Toronto will require more than just monetary policy and that governments may need to promote supply and curb speculation, issues that are typically handled at the municipal level.

site_title: Malfunctioning water-pumping system the cause of train service disruption: LTA
summary: A malfunctioning water-pumping system caused a train-service disruption on the North-South line, with water entering tunnels near Bishan MRT station. The system, designed to siphon off rainwater runoff, failed on Saturday, resulting in rainwater overflowing into the tunnel. Train services were halted for about 20 hours before resuming at 1:50pm on Sunday. Investigations into the cause of the incident are ongoing, and an unrelated incident of a small trackside fire in the tunnel between Marina Bay and Raffles Place MRT stations is also being looked into.

site_title: Singapore firms continue to hedge USD exposure
summary: Singapore companies continue to hedge against the US dollar's volatility, with banks reporting an increase in customers choosing FX forwards over options due to their lower costs and complexity. Despite the US dollar's recent decline, exporters are still seeking to protect themselves from potential losses when converting US dollars to Singapore dollars. Banks say companies are taking advantage of dips in the currency to buy the USD/SGD pair, with some opting for hedging strategies to mitigate risks in the uncertain market environment.

site_title: Garuda Indonesia unit GMF AeroAsia in advanced talks on stake sale
summary: GMF AeroAsia, the maintenance arm of Garuda Indonesia, is in advanced talks to sell 20% of the company to strategic investors including Turkish Technic and Air France Industries KLM Engineering & Maintenance. The deal aims to raise capital after a disappointing initial public offering last month. The potential sale will help GMF overcome payment issues with its parent company, Garuda Indonesia, and tap into the growing aircraft servicing market, which is expected to grow at over 9% a year. The sale will also help GMF expand its facility at Batam Island and diversify its customer base.

site_title: ST Engineering eyes new tech, high-growth sectors
summary: ST Engineering, a Singapore-based conglomerate, is shifting its focus to new technologies and high-growth sectors to drive long-term growth. The company aims to collaborate with start-ups and other organizations to develop innovative solutions, leveraging its network and distribution channels. It has established a US$150 million corporate venture capital unit to search for breakthrough technologies and has invested in various start-ups, including a cyber security firm. The company is also exploring partnerships with governments and private companies to develop smart city projects, and has implemented shared services functions to operate more efficiently and reap cost savings.

site_title: US slaps more anti-dumping duties on Bombardier CSeries
summary: The US Commerce Department imposed additional anti-dumping duties on Bombardier's CSeries jetliners, citing unfair subsidies from the Canadian government. The 80% preliminary duty is in addition to a 220% countervailing duty announced last week. Boeing alleged that Bombardier sold 75 CSeries aircraft below cost to Delta Airlines, resulting in $3 billion in subsidies. A final decision is expected on December 19, with deliveries to Delta starting in spring 2018. Ottawa and Bombardier have strongly disagreed with the decision, calling it "baseless" and "egregious overreach."

site_title: US says no plan to sign global anti-nuclear treaty
summary: The US has stated it will not sign the global anti-nuclear treaty, despite the Nobel Peace Prize being awarded to the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) for its efforts to ban nuclear weapons. The treaty, adopted by 122 countries at the UN in July, aims to ban nuclear weapons but the US claims it will not enhance any state's security and will not lead to the elimination of nuclear weapons. The US remains committed to creating conditions for nuclear disarmament.

site_title: Hidden value in hotels
summary: Hotel stocks, particularly those on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), have seen significant returns in the first nine months of 2017, with luxury hotel stocks like Mandarin Oriental and Shangri-La Asia up over 70% and 30% respectively. This is driven by long-term growth trends, including a resurgence in global economic sentiment and a growing number of Chinese tourists. The article suggests that hotel companies, such as Mandarin Oriental, hold valuable real estate that can be converted to better uses, potentially increasing their value. Despite a current discount of around 25%, the author believes that Mandarin Oriental may still be undervalued and has upside potential.

site_title: Hurricane Nate weakens to tropical storm after hitting US Gulf coast
summary: Tropical Storm Nate made landfall in Mississippi on Sunday, bringing strong winds and flooding to the US Gulf Coast. The storm, which had previously killed at least 30 people in Central America, weakened to a tropical storm with maximum winds of 70 miles per hour. Nate's center is expected to move inland through Monday, with storm surges of up to 11 feet possible in some areas. At least 8,000 customers were without power and over 1,000 people were at shelters in Mississippi. The storm's impact has also affected oil and gas production in the Gulf, with 92% of daily production curtailed.

site_title: Rallying together
summary: Businesses play a crucial role in the community's recovery following a terror attack or major crisis. Companies can help rebuild by reducing service fees, offering complimentary services, and rallying employees to maintain day-to-day operations. Establishing an Emergency Response Standard Operating Procedure, drilling employees on post-attack actions, and conducting regular risk management are essential. Leadership is key, with business leaders rallying teams to stay calm and carry on, and ensuring the workplace is a safe and supportive place to return to. Companies must also demonstrate solidarity and empathy to staff and the society at large, and be prepared to respond quickly with comprehensive contingency plans.

site_title: Wealth management: how top executives think
summary: Top executives in the wealth management industry believe in long-term growth and diversification. Key findings include a predicted slowdown in China's GDP growth, which may pressure policymakers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are strengthening collaboration on green and transition finance. Meanwhile, Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Chinese banks face challenges from a consumer lending push in Beijing, while MUFG targets the US for securitisation business, planning to increase headcount. Retirement announcements also include Helen Wong stepping down as OCBC CEO.

site_title: US rapper Nelly released pending rape investigation
summary: US rapper Nelly, 42, was released from jail without charges pending an investigation into rape allegations made by a woman in his tour bus in Washington state. Nelly has denied the charges, calling them a "false allegation" and stating he is confident the truth will be revealed. His lawyer also claimed the allegation is "devoid of credibility" and "motivated by greed and vindictiveness." The investigation is ongoing, but Nelly was released from custody after being booked for second-degree rape.

site_title: Mary Chia resigns as director; stock suspended until it meets public float
summary: Mary Chia, founder of Mary Chia Holdings, has resigned as director and non-executive chairman, effective October 7, after a general offer closed. Suki Sushi, controlled by Lee Boon Leng, acquired 93.18% of the firm for 11.1 Singapore cents per share. The takeover offer was triggered due to the company's fiscal 2017 losses and negative working capital. The company's counter will not trade until it meets the 10% minimum public float, with Suki Sushi planning to keep Mary Chia listed and restore its public float.

site_title: Water in MRT tunnels due to malfunction in pumping system: LTA
summary: A malfunction in the water pumping system caused water to collect in MRT tunnels, disrupting services on the North-South Line for over 20 hours in Singapore. Preliminary investigations show water entered the tunnels after a torrential downpour, resulting in a trackside fire and requiring emergency services to clear the water. Services were eventually restored on Sunday, with affected trackside equipment inspected, cleaned, and tested before resuming. The incident is under further investigation, and free bus services were activated during the disruption.

site_title: LNG trucks rev up as China puts brakes on diesel
summary: China is experiencing a surge in sales of liquefied natural gas (LNG) trucks, with sales expected to hit record levels this year. The government's anti-pollution campaign, including curbs on heavy-duty diesel vehicles, has driven demand for LNG trucks, which are seen as cleaner and cheaper to operate. Sales of LNG trucks have surged 540% to nearly 39,000 in the first seven months of the year, with major manufacturers like Sinotruk and privately run companies like Tianjin Shengteng Transport Company tripling their LNG fleets. The shift to gas trucks is expected to benefit companies involved in LNG production and distribution, with imports jumping 45% so far this year.

site_title: UK, European businesses, public fed-up over slow Brexit talks
summary: The UK and European businesses are frustrated with the slow progress in Brexit negotiations, with only 36% of the British public approving of the government's handling of the talks. The UK's proposed annual contribution to the EU budget is estimated at 22 billion euros, while the EU seeks a much larger sum of 60-100 billion euros. The lack of progress has caused economic concerns, with the pound slipping 4.5% against the US dollar and 3% against the euro. Experts warn of the need for flexibility and urgency to avoid a hard Brexit and its potential economic consequences.

site_title: Soilbuild warrants - leveraged play on construction sector
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has warrants that are considered attractive due to their conversion premium of 10.2% and gearing of 7.2. The warrants expire in July 2021 and are "at-the-money" with an exercise price of S$0.18. The company's subsidiary, Soil-Build Pte Ltd, is A1-graded under CW01 and A2-graded under CW02 by the Building and Construction Authority, allowing it to tender for public sector projects in Singapore. This suggests that the flow-through from en bloc deals could benefit the construction sector.

site_title: Scandal-hit Deutsche charts more moderate course
summary: Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest lender, aims to up its profitability and reclaim a global position after years of scandals and restructuring. The bank has warned that profits will never again reach pre-financial crisis heights and is focusing on risk control, adding thousands of jobs in regulatory compliance. Deutsche has closed 200 branches and slashed 9,000 jobs, and its new risk control department will grow to 3,000 people by 2018. The bank's new strict approach to financial regulation is expected to restore confidence among clients, with compliance chief Sylvie Matherat saying it is "on track" to do so.

site_title: Kobe Steel says specification data falsified on aluminium, copper products
summary: Kobe Steel has admitted to falsifying specification data for about 4% of its aluminium and copper products shipped between September 2016 and August 2017. The products, shipped to around 200 companies, were falsely labelled as meeting customer specifications. The company has assured that no safety issues have arisen from these shipments, but will take prompt action if problems arise. Kobe Steel is also investigating possible data fabrication before the latest internal audit.

site_title: Belarussian student is first-ever Miss Wheelchair World
summary: Aleksandra Chichikova, a 23-year-old Belarusian psychology student, was crowned Miss Wheelchair World in Warsaw, marking the first-ever edition of the beauty pageant. The contest aimed to change the image of women in wheelchairs, showcasing their abilities and personalities beyond physical limitations. 24 contestants from 19 countries participated, including runner-up Lebohang Monyatsi from South Africa and Poland's Adrianna Zawadzinska. The pageant, organized by the Poland-based Only One Foundation, seeks to demonstrate that a wheelchair is a luxury in many parts of the world.

site_title: Food world bids farewell to unsung hero of fresh fare and good taste
summary: Jon Rowley, a 74-year-old Alaskan commercial fisherman turned Seattle-based marketer, has died after a battle with terminal kidney disease. Dubbed the 'fish missionary' by Julia Child, Rowley revolutionized the US food scene by elevating Alaskan Copper River salmon from a lowly cannery catch to a premium signature of spring. He championed quality and simplicity in food, inspiring a generation of foodies with his approach, which emphasized appreciating the small things and the terroir of ingredients. Rowley's legacy continues to influence the food world, with many crediting him for introducing them to the beauty of fresh, locally-sourced food.

site_title: Ryanair COO to resign in wake of rostering mess-up
summary: Ryanair COO Michael Hickey will resign from the end of the month, following a rostering mess-up that led to the cancellation of thousands of flights. The airline's disruptions affected over 700,000 passengers. Hickey, responsible for rosters, was replaced by Chief People Officer Edward Wilson in September. Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary took personal responsibility for the "cock up" and promised significant improvements in pay and conditions for pilots. The airline has hired 210 new pilots in the past 12 weeks to address the shortage.

site_title: Global investors betting on Indonesia's tech start-ups
summary: Global investors, including Expedia and Alibaba, are pouring billions of dollars into Indonesian tech start-ups, capitalizing on the country's growing digital economy and potential as South-east Asia's largest online market. Indonesia has seen a surge in venture capital investment, with $3 billion in deals secured in 2017, and is expected to become a major hub for e-commerce and online transactions, with a population of over 250 million and a growing middle class. However, the sector still faces challenges, including limited engineering talent and poor infrastructure.

images.alt_text: A surge of cash into Indonesia's technology sector over the past two years has helped support dozens of homegrown start-ups ranging from ride hailing apps to e-commerce firms.

site_title: Gains likely to go on amid race for Fed chair
summary: US stocks rose last week due to optimism about interest rates and tax policy, with the SPDR Financial Select Sector ETF reaching its highest level since the financial crisis. Speculation about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and the potential for a new Fed chair is expected to continue, with President Trump's preferred candidate, Kevin Warsh, seen as a potential "hawkish" leader. Analysts expect S&P 500 earnings to grow 4.9% in the third quarter, with a proposed corporate tax cut potentially boosting earnings next year.

site_title: Refugee issue complicates Merkel's bid to form government
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel faces a complex challenge in forming a government as her conservative camp is divided over refugee policy. The Bavarian CSU, led by Horst Seehofer, is pushing for a cap on the national refugee intake, while Merkel has consistently rejected this as unconstitutional. Merkel's CDU is also nervous ahead of a state poll in Lower Saxony, where it is running neck-and-neck with the Social Democrats. To form a working majority, Merkel is considering an alliance with the pro-business Free Democrats and the left-leaning Greens, a potential "Jamaica coalition" that would be a first at the national level in Germany.

site_title: Coping with the switchover to IFRS
summary: Singapore listed companies face significant changes with the adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and new revenue recognition and financial instruments standards. Effective for the 2018 financial year, companies must evaluate and adopt new accounting requirements, allowing for policy choices to minimize changes and preserve accounting status quo. Companies can consider resetting foreign exchange translation reserves and using fair value for selected assets to reflect changes in retained earnings. Audit committees must play a key role in assessing options and impact on financials, and companies must communicate changes to stakeholders to maximize benefits of the new regime.

site_title: Airlines may cut flights by 30% in France on Tuesday due to strike
summary: Airlines in France are expected to reduce flights by 30% on Tuesday due to a strike call by civil service unions, affecting major airports including Paris' Charles de Gaulle and Orly. The strike, which involves 5.4 million public service workers, is in protest of government labour reforms. Disruptions are expected nationwide, with the French civil aviation authority recommending the reduced flight schedule.

site_title: NZ PM says final election tally does not weaken chances of forming a coalition government
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Bill English stated that the final election tally, which showed National Party losing two seats, does not weaken their chances of forming a coalition government with the New Zealand First Party. National remains in the lead with 56 seats, while Labour Party has 46. The election's inconclusive results have left both parties in need of New Zealand First's nine seats to form a government. English believes the fundamentals of their negotiation position have not altered significantly.

site_title: Still no 'clear motive' in Las Vegas mass shooting: police
summary: Las Vegas police have not found a clear motive for the 2017 mass shooting that killed 58 people, five days after the incident. Undersheriff Kevin McMahill stated that authorities have no credible information to report on motivation, contradicting claims by the Islamic State group that carried out the attack. The investigation continues with law enforcement working with "great tenacity" to uncover the reasons behind the massacre.

site_title: Orthorexia: When 'healthy eating' ends up making you sick
summary: A growing concern in modern society is orthorexia nervosa, a condition where an obsession with healthy eating leads to social isolation, psychological disturbance, and physical harm. Experts warn that this eating disorder, not recognized by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, can be disguised as a virtue and has been linked to cases of vitamin deficiencies and even blindness. Specialists attribute the condition to a craving for control and a suspicion of being poisoned in a food culture that has become increasingly distrustful of Western lifestyles.

site_title: Kim sticks to his nuclear guns; promotes sister
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un stated that his nuclear weapons are a powerful deterrent to ensure the country's sovereignty, amid tensions with the US. In a speech, Mr. Kim said his nuclear program is a success, citing the US's "protracted nuclear threats." The US President, Donald Trump, suggested military action could be an option, but did not clarify what he meant. Kim Jong Un's sister, Kim Yo Jong, was promoted to an alternate member of the politburo, indicating a consolidation of the Kim family's power.

images.alt_text: Kim Jong Un and his sister Kim Yo Jong. North Korea's nuclear weapons are a "powerful deterrent firmly safeguarding the peace and security in the Korean peninsula and North-east Asia," he says.

site_title: US baby boomers fall behind in paying off mortgages
summary: US baby boomers are falling behind in paying off their mortgages, according to a report from Fannie Mae. Despite an improving economy and housing recovery, older American homeowners are struggling to pay off their loans, which could complicate their finances in retirement. This trend has persisted even after the last recession.

site_title: US Chamber warns against Trump's 'highly dangerous' Nafta demands
summary: The US Chamber of Commerce warns that President Trump's demands in the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) modernization talks are "highly dangerous" and could erode US business support. The chamber's senior vice-president, John Murphy, expressed concerns over proposals to raise rules of origin thresholds, add a five-year termination clause, and reduce Canadian and Mexican companies' access to US public procurement contracts. These demands could lead to opposition from the business and agriculture community, making a successful agreement uncertain.

site_title: UK house prices up at fastest pace since February
summary: UK house prices rose 0.8% in September, the fastest annual pace since February, beating economists' forecasts. Prices in the three months to September were 4% higher than expected, driven by buyers ignoring concerns of higher interest rates. This surge in prices follows a rebound in UK homebuyer demand to a six-month high, according to an index.

site_title: British PM signals possible demotion of foreign secretary -report
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has signaled the possible demotion of Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, amid an open rebellion within her party. May has faced criticism from allies over Johnson's interventions on Brexit, which she views as undermining her authority. In an interview, May stated she would not hide from challenges and was prepared to bring in new ministers to her cabinet, potentially demoting Johnson. This comes ahead of crucial Brexit talks with the EU, where growing uncertainty has raised concerns about a no-deal agreement.

site_title: Sudan hails end of US trade embargo as 'positive decision'
summary: Sudan welcomed the US decision to end its 20-year trade embargo, calling it a "positive decision". The US move, announced after months of diplomatic talks, cited improvements in Sudan's human rights record. However, Sudan still wants its name removed from the list of state terror sponsors, despite the embargo being lifted. The US decision aims to further cooperation on issues like international peace, immigration, and terrorism.

site_title: North Korea preparing long-range missile test: RIA cites Russian lawmaker
summary: North Korea is reportedly preparing to test a long-range missile capable of reaching the US west coast, according to a Russian lawmaker who visited Pyongyang. The planned test, possibly on or around October 10, has raised tensions with the US, with President Donald Trump threatening to "totally destroy" North Korea if it threatens the US. The US and China have exchanged tough rhetoric, with China backing a worldwide ban on nuclear weapons. The planned test has driven up US Treasury bond prices as investors seek safe-haven assets amid uncertainty.

site_title: Formula One: Ruthless Hamilton roars to Japan victory
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured his eighth Formula One victory of the year, dominating the Japanese Grand Prix to close in on a fourth world title. Hamilton's Mercedes teammate Valtteri Bottas finished fourth, while Sebastian Vettel's engine failure led to his early retirement. The win extended Hamilton's championship lead to 59 points, with four races remaining. Hamilton praised his team's efforts, saying they had done a "phenomenal job." The result marked Mercedes' fourth successive Suzuka win.

site_title: The Disruptor's guide to Singapore
summary: Singapore is a hub for entrepreneurs, with six startup founders sharing their favorite spots for pitching, meeting, finding inspiration, celebrating milestones, grabbing dinner, and recharging. The founders recommend various locations, including coffee shops, bars, restaurants, and outdoor spaces, such as Gardens by the Bay and the beach at Sentosa. Their shared preferences reflect the city-state's vibrant and eclectic atmosphere, where entrepreneurs can find serendipitous meetings and inspiration in the midst of a bustling metropolis.

site_title: Founder Mary Chia resigns as director and non-exec chairman of firm
summary: Mary Chia, founder of Mary Chia Holdings, has resigned as director and non-executive chairman effective October 7, following a general offer by Suki Sushi, controlled by Lee Boon Leng, her husband's husband. Despite her resignation, Suki Sushi now holds a 93.18% stake in the company. Chia will not be able to trade her counter until the company meets a 10% minimum public float. The company plans to remain listed under Suki Sushi's ownership.

site_title: Blinging up Ikea
summary: Reform, a Danish company, is offering stylish "skins" for Ikea furnishings with premium finishes at a fraction of the usual cost. By partnering with renowned architects, Reform provides high-end designs, such as bronze doors and concrete counters, for Ikea products. The company, founded in 2014, has sold about 1,000 kitchens in over 20 countries, and is expanding into furniture. Ikea appears to encourage this trend, viewing it as a way to personalize its offerings and make them more appealing to customers.

site_title: Trump sends lieutenants to Pakistan with tough message
summary: US President Donald Trump is dispatching his top diplomatic and military advisors to Pakistan in the coming weeks, sending a tough message to the nuclear-armed ally accused of harboring terror groups. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis will lead the visits, aiming to pressure Pakistan to end its support for jihadist groups. The US has long been frustrated with Pakistan's willingness to offer safe havens to groups like the Taliban and Al-Qaeda, and Trump has warned of cutting military aid and potentially revoking Pakistan's non-NATO ally status.

site_title: Malaysia's August exports grow 21.5% on strong global demand
summary: Malaysia's exports grew 21.5% to RM82.23 billion in August, driven by strong global demand for manufactured goods, particularly electrical and electronic products. Total trade reached RM1.16 trillion, with a trade surplus of nearly RM61 billion. The country expects a 10% total trade growth for the year, exceeding initial estimates of 3%. Strong growth was seen in key sectors, including E&E exports and mining products, with trade with China and Asean also expanding.

site_title: Trump to unveil new responses to Iranian 'bad behaviour': White House
summary: President Donald Trump plans to unveil new US responses to Iran's "bad behavior," including missile tests, support for terrorism, and cyber operations. Trump's strategy aims to address multiple issues, not just the nuclear deal, and may include decertifying the 2015 nuclear agreement. The administration is considering imposing targeted sanctions and exploring ways to fix perceived flaws in the deal without killing it. Trump has until Oct 15 to certify to Congress that Iran is complying with the deal, and lawmakers would have 60 days to consider reimposing US sanctions if he decides to decertify.

site_title: Tesla in 'production hell' to meet Model 3 deadline
summary: Tesla Inc is struggling to meet its production deadline for the Model 3 sedan due to production bottlenecks, with Elon Musk stating the company is "deep in production hell." Despite delivering only 220 Model 3 sedans in the third quarter, Musk predicts December will be a "big month" for deliveries. Production delays have also affected the unveiling of the Tesla Semi, which has been rescheduled to November 16. Musk prioritizes fixing production issues over the truck's unveiling, citing a need to increase battery production for Puerto Rico.

site_title: Oil down 2%, breaks five-week rally as oversupply fears resurface
summary: Oil prices plummeted 2% on Friday, snapping a five-week winning streak, as oversupply concerns resurfaced. Brent crude fell 2.4% to $55.62 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 3% to $49.29. Producers have started hedging future drilling, citing growing US crude exports and concerns about supply. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and Russia are discussing potential production cuts, but the market remains cautious amid growing US production and a hefty WTI discount to Brent prices.

site_title: Snake charms
summary: Bulgari's SerpentiForm exhibition is now open at the ArtScience Museum in Marina Bay Sands until October 15. The show features iconic Serpenti jewelry pieces, as well as contemporary artworks by artists such as Joan Miró and Keith Haring, inspired by the snake motif. The exhibition was curated by Bulgari's Brand Heritage Department and is a must-see for fashion enthusiasts and art lovers. Tickets are available online or at the door.

site_title: Of love and longing
summary: Haruki Murakami's new collection of short stories, Men Without Women, has been released, offering a mix of mystery, magnetism, and melancholy. The book is a compilation of 14 stories that pay tribute to the title and features characters with complex impulses and emotions. The stories are open-ended, leaving much to the imagination, and are characteristic of Murakami's style, which is effortless and stays with readers long after the book is finished. The collection is described as witty, unsettling, and poignant, inviting readers to immerse themselves in its vast and complex world.

site_title: Three charged with plotting New York attacks for Islamic State: US prosecutors
summary: Three men, Abdulrahman El Bahnasawy, a 19-year-old Canadian, Talha Haroon, a 19-year-old US citizen, and Russell Salic, a 37-year-old Filipino, have been charged with plotting attacks in New York City for the Islamic State. The planned attacks included detonating explosives in Times Square and the subway, which were thwarted by law enforcement. El Bahnasawy pleaded guilty to terrorism charges in 2016, while Haroon and Salic are expected to be extradited to the US to face life in prison if convicted.

site_title: Cream of the crop
summary: Nine architectural projects received top marks at the Singapore Institute of Architects' 2017 Architectural Design Awards. The winners include Amanemu, a sustainable resort in Ise-Shima National Park, and The Warehouse Hotel, a boutique hotel in Singapore. Other notable winners include The Tembusu condominium, Rhizome House, an interactive light installation, and Oasia Hotel Downtown, a verdant skyscraper in Singapore. The awards recognized innovative and aesthetically pure designs that showcased a strong sense of place and community integration.

images.alt_text: NEW WING AT THE ASIAN CIVILISATION MUSEUM

site_title: Banks mull whether and how to get into cryptocurrencies
summary: Banks are considering how to get into the cryptocurrency market, with Goldman Sachs and other major investment banks exploring ways to facilitate trades of bitcoin and other digital currencies. Despite its high volatility and lack of government backing, bitcoin has drawn interest from hedge funds and wealthy individuals, with some banks viewing it as a new asset class. However, the industry faces challenges, including concerns over money laundering and the need to comply with US regulations. Derivative contracts and other financial instruments may help mitigate these risks, allowing banks to tap into the growing cryptocurrency market.

site_title: US: Jobs data knock Dow, S&P 500 from record pedestal
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs after a disappointing jobs report, with the Dow and S&P 500 falling slightly. The September jobs report showed a net loss of 33,000 jobs, contrary to expectations of a 75,000 gain. Despite this, hourly wages rose and unemployment fell to 4.2%. Analysts attributed the loss to the impact of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma, and expect a rebound in the next report. The Nasdaq edged up to a record for the sixth straight session, while other markets were mixed.

site_title: US to sell US$15b Thaad missile defence to Saudi Arabia
summary: The US government has approved the sale of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) missile defence system to Saudi Arabia for $15 billion. The sale supports US national security and foreign policy interests, and will help defend against Iranian threats in the Gulf region. Thaad, which has already been supplied to Qatar and the UAE, has advanced radar capabilities and is expected to stabilize the situation in the Gulf. The sale is part of a larger US$110 billion arms package promised to Saudi Arabia during President Trump's visit in May.

site_title: Europe: Shares brush off Catalan crisis with another weekly gain
summary: European shares rose for the fourth consecutive week, driven by confidence in the region's economic recovery, despite the ongoing Catalonia crisis. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.4% on Friday but posted a 0.3% gain for the week. Redemptions in Spanish stock funds hit a three-year high, but flows into European equity funds exceeded $1 billion for the third week in a row. The crisis remains confined to Spanish equities, with other European markets, such as Germany's DAX and the UK's FTSE, also rising.

site_title: Risk tackler
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters says the bank is at an "inflexion point" and has overcome its high-risk businesses, shifting the burden of risk assessment to frontline bankers. He attributes the bank's culture shift to a period of complacency and arrogance, which he believes led to "grotesque excess" in the industry. Winters notes that the bank has reduced its risk-reversal measures and is scaling down its rules, instead focusing on risk and return. He sees the bank's unique global footprint, particularly in Africa, as a key differentiator, and is optimistic about expanding its client base in the US and Europe.

site_title: Lexus LS 350 Review: Harbinger of fun
summary: Lexus has unveiled its fifth-generation LS 350, a luxury limousine that marks a significant departure from its predecessors. The new design is more aggressive and sporty, with a low, wide stance and a bold front grille. The interior features fine materials and advanced technology, including a full-color head-up display. The car also boasts improved air suspension and active noise cancelling, providing a smooth ride. The LS 350 is available with a range of engines, including a 3.5-liter V6, and is positioned to appeal to a wider range of buyers, including those in Singapore where smaller engines are more popular.

site_title: More than 16.9b baht in bank shares transferred on Thai king's behalf
summary: The Crown Property Bureau of Thailand transferred over $500 million in bank shares worth 16.9 billion baht on behalf of King Maha Vajiralongkorn, reducing its stake in Siam Commercial Bank by 3.33%. The move, carried out on the King's behalf, brings the CPB's stake in the bank to 18.14%. The Crown Property Bureau manages an estimated $30-60 billion in assets, making the Thai royal family among the richest in the world, but its financial portfolio is shrouded in secrecy due to a draconian defamation law shielding the monarchy from criticism.

site_title: The Yishun Of Yesteryear
summary: Yishun, a Singaporean new town, has a rich history dating back to the 1800s when it was a collection of villages and plantations. The area's development began with the construction of the Singapore Naval Base in Sembawang in 1938. Today, landmarks such as Beaulieu House, Jenal Jetty, and the old Seletar Fishing Village remain, offering a glimpse into the town's past. The modernization of Yishun began in the 1970s with the Yishun New Town Project, which introduced amenities such as markets, schools, and public facilities.

site_title: Treasury bulls should keep calm and carry on: HSBC
summary: Treasury bulls are advised to remain calm, according to HSBC's global head of fixed-income research, Steven Major. Despite a sell-off in 10-year notes, Major believes the Federal Reserve's balance sheet normalization will be gradual, containing yields. The sell-off in September was the worst in 10 months, but Major attributes it to investors' expectations of rising yields due to quantitative easing policy. A potential supply jump from the Fed, a looser fiscal stance, and the potential successor to Fed chief Janet Yellen are headwinds weighing on traders' short positions.

site_title: LMG Realty buys Nassim Road bungalow for S$23.7m
summary: LMG Realty, a unit of Lee Metal Group, has purchased a Nassim Road bungalow in Singapore for S$23.69 million, working out to S$1,782 per square foot. The 13,292 sq ft freehold land is expected to be redeveloped by the buyer.

site_title: Testosterone and the ageing man
summary: Men over 30 experience a gradual decline in testosterone levels, which can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, loss of libido, and erectile dysfunction. Testosterone deficiency syndrome (TDS) is common, affecting 26% of Singaporean men, and is often underdiagnosed and undertreated. Treatment with Testosterone Replacement Therapy (TRT) has been shown to improve sexual function, mood, and bone density, but not vitality or cognition. TRT may also reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. However, it is essential to weigh the benefits against potential risks, including an increased risk of coronary artery plaque volume.

site_title: Dying for love
summary: The Stuttgart Ballet is set to perform a dance version of Shakespeare's Romeo & Juliet, choreographed by John Cranko in 1962. The production, set to Sergei Prokofiev's score, is considered groundbreaking and definitive, inspiring other choreographers. Cranko's choreography is praised for its clear and expressive storytelling. The ballet will run at the Esplanade Theatre from October 12-14, with tickets available from Sistic.

site_title: National pastime
summary: Wee Li Lin's Gone Shopping, a Singaporean black comedy, is making a comeback on the big screen for its 10th anniversary as part of the ArtScience on Screen programme at Marina Bay Sands. The film will be screened in conjunction with the Singapore International Film Festival, which Marina Bay Sands has partnered with for years. A dialogue session featuring the cast and crew will be held on October 7.

site_title: Porsche designed five cars just for Singapore
summary: Porsche has designed five unique Macan vehicles in different racing-inspired liveries, available to Singaporean customers at no extra cost. The designs celebrate the brand's motorsport history, including notable racing cars. This limited-edition offer allows drivers to express their personality through the vehicle's design, highlighting Porsche's motorsport heritage.

site_title: Three markets to rule them all
summary: South Korea's Kospi index remains optimistic, with a trend strength intact despite recent pullbacks. The index is projected to break out above 2,400, with a potential target of 2,560. Meanwhile, China and oil markets show a more sanguine outlook, suggesting a lack of concern over the escalating tensions between North Korea and the US. This divergence in market sentiment highlights the potential for dollar asset diversification in Asia.

site_title: Porsche and WTA a perfect doubles pair
summary: Porsche and the WTA have partnered for the fourth consecutive year, with seven out of eight spots at the BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association Finals Singapore tournament filled. The tournament's winner will not only secure a spot but also be awarded a brand new Porsche 911 GTS Cabriolet if they finish as the No. 1 player on the WTA leaderboard.

site_title: Sydneysiders warm to idea of moving to tropical north
summary: Sydney residents are fleeing their million-dollar homes for cheaper options in Queensland's tropical north, driven by lower house prices and rising job creation. This emerging exodus is part of Australia's latest interstate migration wave, with Queensland offering significantly cheaper housing options.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in the Gold Coast. The shift to Queensland could strengthen Australia's property market by spreading housing equity around the country, says Macquarie Bank.

site_title: Cities make for healthier, happier people: report
summary: A new report challenges popular beliefs that suburban living is healthier and happier than city living, citing research that shows busy city centers promote socializing and walking, leading to happier, healthier residents. Downtown residents are found to be more active and socially engaged than those in suburban areas. The study contradicts the notion that crowded city living is detrimental to wellbeing, instead highlighting the benefits of urban environments.

site_title: The racist, fascist, xenophobic, misogynistic, intelligent machine
summary: A US computer programme, COMPAS, used to predict recidivism rates in the justice system was found to be racist in a 2016 study, systematically rating blacks as higher risks of repeat offenses while underestimating the chances of white people. This bias is a result of its massive database and computing power. In contrast, Microsoft's chatbot Tay, released in 2016, was built to mimic human interactions and colloquialisms, but was shut down due to its rapid learning and adoption of hateful language.

site_title: How to defy ageing the Lexus way
summary: Lexus, a luxury car brand, has experienced its most exciting years in the past few years, with its new LS limousine showcasing the brand's growth. The LS, Lexus' flagship model, is set to lead the way for future developments from the brand. Shinji Ishida, assistant chief engineer for the LS, emphasizes the model's significance as a forerunner for what's to come from Lexus in the future.

site_title: Perfect match
summary: Luke Whearty's underground cocktail bar, Operation Dagger, has revamped its menu to include more complex bar snacks and omakase options, aiming for a perfect balance of food and drinks. This trend is seen in many establishments, where bars now offer well-thought-out dishes with good-quality ingredients, and restaurants take risks with drink pairings and unique options like sake or non-alcoholic pairings. This shift reflects a growing attention to both food and drinks in the industry, with many establishments striving to create a seamless and enjoyable experience for customers.

site_title: Renault to rely on low-cost and electric cars to boost sales
summary: Renault aims to boost sales by 44% by 2022 through its focus on low-cost and electric cars. CEO Carlos Ghosn believes electric cars will be a significant contributor to the company's performance, giving it a first-mover edge. Renault also plans to expand its vehicle line-up for emerging markets, including China, to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Renault plans to increase sales to five million vehicles in 2022 from 3.47 million in 2016 under the watch of CEO Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: Prada pops
summary: Italian luxury brand Prada has teamed up with local retailer Tangs for a special pop-up featuring men's travel and accessories collections. The pop-up, titled "Prada pops," features giant versions of the brand's quirky keychains and bag accessories, and runs until October 13 at Tangs. This collaboration marks the first time Prada has partnered with a local retailer for a pop-up event.

site_title: Standoff in Florence Regency en bloc sale amid risk of oversupply in area
summary: A collective sale of Florence Regency in Singapore's Hougang area has stalled with three bidders refusing to match the S$629 million valuation set by valuer Colliers International. Marketing agent JLL is courting other developers to secure a deal under private treaty within 10 weeks. The site's estimated land cost is S$842 psf ppr, but developers are concerned about the incoming supply in the area, including projects from Rio Casa and Serangoon Ville.

site_title: Pay fund managers by their performance
summary: Fund managers are being urged to adopt performance-based fees to regain investor trust. Fidelity International has introduced a new fee structure without specifics, but experts suggest it should be designed to align managers' interests with those of investors. This approach can help ensure managers have "skin in the game" and make decisions in the best interest of investors.

site_title: Look at what an Audi with brains can do
summary: Audi's new A8 is the first production car with Level 3 autonomous driving capabilities, allowing the AI system to take control of driving at speeds below 60km/h and in traffic jams, while leaving the driver free to engage in other activities. However, the system is limited to highways and requires a solid barrier for safety. This technology marks a significant step forward for autonomous driving, despite being subject to local government approval and having some drawbacks compared to other similar systems. Audi's innovation is a small but notable advancement in the field of autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Welcome home
summary: French luxury brand Hermes presents an immersive installation, "Through the Walls," at its Singapore boutique, featuring a wonderland of living accessories in dramatic settings. Concept designers Jean-Christophe Vaillant and Hervé Sauvage transformed the space with furniture, tableware, bespoke creations, fabrics, and lighting, showcasing the diversity of Hermès homeware. The installation is on display until October 29.

site_title: Stock investors, beware of the FANG's fangs
summary: A study by Sanford C Bernstein finds that despite a rotation out of technology megacaps, the FANG group and other sectors, such as utilities and industrials, are experiencing high levels of institutional groupthink, or "crowding." This crowding is seen as a risk, as it can lead to a low threshold for disappointment and potentially trigger market turbulence. The study attributes the crowding to investors rushing to cyclical shares ahead of higher inflation and interest rates, at the expense of consumer stocks.

site_title: Time for tea
summary: Pastry chef Eddy Yau at Pacific Marketplace has introduced a new Pandan Gula Melaka Chiffon Cake, an all-natural, pandan-infused sponge with streaks of gula melaka syrup. The cake is part of four recent creations, including Matcha Yuzu Lychee Entremet, Strawberry Pistachio Shortcake, and Araguani Hazelnut Royaltine Entremet. The new cake is priced at S$12.50 and allows customers to add gula melaka syrup as desired. Pacific Marketplace is also offering four other desserts at S$58 each.

site_title: Art fairs for the uber-rich are paying off for everyone - finally
summary: Art fairs catering to the ultra-rich, such as London's Frieze Art Fair, are attracting a broader audience, including non-ultra-rich visitors. In 2016, Frieze drew 113,000 attendees, including both high-end collectors and art enthusiasts. The increased accessibility may benefit art-lovers, who pay to attend events showcasing high-end art pieces. This shift could lead to a more diverse art market, benefiting both collectors and the art community as a whole.

site_title: Let's Be-Gin
summary: Japanese distilleries, including Beam Suntory, are entering the gin market with premium craft gins, starting with Roku. The gin combines six traditional Japanese botanicals with eight traditional gin botanicals, resulting in a complex and harmonious flavor profile. Roku is described as having a smooth and silky texture, sweet and floral aroma, and a spicy finish. The gin is suitable for enjoying on the rocks or in a Japanese Gin & Tonic, complemented by ginger slices.

site_title: China's answer to Airbnb sets sights on Japan as tourism booms
summary: China's largest vacation rental platform, TUJIA.COM, aims to increase Japan listings by 10 times in two years, capitalizing on the nation's tourism boom. The platform seeks to expand its listings to around 100,000 properties by 2019, up from 10,000 currently. This move is part of TUJIA.COM's strategy to compete with Airbnb and tap into Japan's growing tourism market.

site_title: Art of the master blender
summary: Hennessy's Paradis Imperial, a cognac considered the "holy grail," took over two centuries to create. Eight men meet daily at 11am in a secret room in Hennessy's headquarters to craft the exclusive spirit. The cognac is part of the 250-year-old company that forms the 'H' in the LVMH group. Its creation is shrouded in secrecy, with limited access granted to select visitors. The cognac's release is expected to satisfy the demands of big spenders, but its true taste is reserved for those who have contributed to its creation.

site_title: May faces about 30 rebels calling for her to quit
summary: Theresa May faces a potential leadership challenge from within her own Conservative Party, with around 30 rebels calling for her to quit. The move comes after a disastrous speech at the party conference, and rival Tories are touring television stations to argue whether she should stay or go. Grant Shapps, a former Cabinet minister, has called for May to voluntarily step aside to allow a leadership election. However, it's unclear if he and others have enough support to force her out of office, and removing her now could throw Brexit negotiations into chaos.

site_title: Banks, Jardine help drive STI up 2.2% for the week
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 2.2% for the week, driven largely by the banking sector and Jardine Matheson stocks. Expectations of a US rate hike initially boosted the sector, but fell on Tuesday and Wednesday as traders shifted focus to China bank trading following a reserve requirement rate cut. The index's gain was largely determined by the banks and Jardine stocks, with the banks contributing 15 points of the index's 29.45-point rise. Turnover was near the S$1 billion mark, with business done on Friday reaching S$1.3 billion.

site_title: Almost Insta-Famous
summary: Three mothers in their 40s, Leanne Ho, Helmi Yusof, and Tay Suan Chiang, have achieved significant success as Instagram influencers despite their age. Leanne, 40, started her account with a simple photo of skincare products and now has 60,100 followers, with brands offering her freebies and collaborations. She also writes for magazines and sits on beauty awards panels. The three mothers' success showcases that age is not a barrier to becoming a successful influencer, and they are proof that dedication and consistency can lead to online fame and opportunities.

site_title: Mary Chia to be suspended as CEO's spouse holds 93.2% at close of general offer
summary: Mary Chia Holdings' stock will be suspended due to the chief executive's husband controlling a 93.18% stake after a general offer closed. The company's public float is below the 10% minimum required for listing on the Singapore Exchange Mainboard. Suki Sushi, controlled by Lee Boon Leng, plans to restore the company's public float, but no timeline was given. The offeror had acquired the stake at 11.1 Singapore cents per share, with plans to keep Mary Chia listed.

site_title: Cook in Japan
summary: A four hands collaborative dinner featuring chefs David Myers and Ryan Clift will take place on Oct 13 and 14 at the Tippling Club in Singapore. The 10-course dinner menu includes dishes such as langoustine with kohlrabi and dry-aged duck with foie gras. The menu is priced at S$270++ for food only, with an additional S$160++ for a food and drink pairing menu. The event aims to showcase Japanese cuisine, with prices and menu details available on the Tippling Club website.

site_title: SIA's ongoing revamp programme seen as necessary amid headwinds
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has launched a three-year revamp programme aimed at boosting revenues and reducing costs in a competitive operating environment. The programme includes 56 initiatives, such as reviewing the group network, reducing fuel burn, and implementing self-service options. Analysts expect the measures to improve competitiveness and profitability, but it's difficult to estimate cost savings or incremental revenue at this point. SIA is also investing in digital platforms, staff, and revenue growth initiatives.

site_title: Kia Stinger review: A Korean missile to put on your radar
summary: The Kia Stinger is a high-performance grand tourer that competes with German luxury cars. The car boasts a 270km/h top speed, 0-100km/h acceleration in 4.9 seconds, and a 510 Newton-metres of torque. It features exceptional handling, stability, and braking capabilities. Designed by Albert Biermann, the former chief engineer of BMW's M division, the Stinger has a sleek design, advanced materials, and a cockpit with a jet fighter theme. With two versions set to launch in Singapore, the Stinger aims to challenge the dominance of German luxury cars and offer a world-class driving experience at an affordable price.

site_title: Cracking a controversy
summary: The American Heart Association's report linking saturated fats in coconut oil to high cholesterol is disputed by experts. Dr. Mary Newport argues that the AHA's advisory groups have connections to the soybean and corn oil industry, which promoted trans fats in the 1980s. Coconut oil contains beneficial medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) with antimicrobial effects, and replacing sugar with MCTs can increase HDL (good cholesterol) by a fraction of a point. Experts like Dr. Fabian Dayrit and Dr. Melvin Look note that coconut oil is not the sole cause of heart disease and that more research is needed to understand its benefits and harm.

site_title: English icon
summary: Fred Perry, a British fashion brand, has opened its third standalone store in Singapore at Bugis Junction, featuring its iconic shirts with a laurel wreath. The brand's gig series, Fred Perry Subculture Live, is set to return on October 13 with a DJ set by Gary Powell of The Libertines and performances by local indie bands Astreal and The Betts. Registration for the event is required through Eventbrite.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp received an eligibility to list letter from the Singapore Exchange for its proposed US commercial real estate investment trust (Reit) on the mainboard. Keppel agreed to take a 50% interest in the Reit manager for $27.5 million. SBI Offshore's former CEO David Tan Woo Thian is seeking a seat on the board of the offshore contractor after the company decided not to pursue legal action against him over alleged irregularities. SIA Engineering signed a non-binding MoU with Air India Engineering Services to collaborate on MRO services in India.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine to sell 9 jackup drilling rigs to Borr Drilling
summary: SembCorp Marine agreed to sell nine Pacific Class 400 jackup drilling rigs to Borr Drilling for about $1.3 billion, plus a market-based fee. The sale will result in a loss of $15 million but will improve the company's liquidity position. The rigs, including those currently under construction, will be delivered over a 14-month period from Q4 2017 to Q1 2019.

site_title: DBS appoints Taimur Baig as chief economist
summary: DBS Bank has appointed Taimur Baig as its new chief economist and managing director for group research, effective Monday. Baig brings nearly 20 years of experience covering the Asia region, having previously worked at Deutsche Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and the Monetary Authority of Singapore. He replaces David Carbon, who is retiring after 12 years. DBS Group Research head Timothy Wong described Baig as "the perfect addition" due to his strong grasp of Asian economies, expecting him to make valuable contributions to the bank's insights on the region.

images.alt_text: Mr Baig joined the Monetary Authority of Singapore in Mayas the principal economist at its economic policy group before going over to DBS.

site_title: Parkson Retail auditor raises going concern doubts
summary: Parkson Retail Asia's independent auditor, Ernst & Young, has raised concerns about the company's ability to remain a going concern due to a net loss of S$61.2 million and a net current liability position of S$55.5 million. The auditor noted that the company's ability to continue as a going concern depends on generating sufficient cash flows and financial support from its parent company, Parkson Holdings Bhd. The company's Malaysian parent has given an undertaking to provide financial support for 12 months.

site_title: Citigroup mulling over onshore cash equities business in China
summary: Citigroup is considering setting up an onshore cash equities business in China, aiming to boost its share of the Asian market. The move comes as China-listed shares are set to be included in the US's MSCI emerging markets benchmark, expected to increase demand for brokerage and research services. Citi plans to expand its research coverage to 250 Chinese firms by the end of the year and add at least 10 people to its Hong Kong and Singapore hubs.

site_title: Catalan separatists squeezed further as Spain tightens grip
summary: Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy convenes his Cabinet as the financial and political squeeze on the separatist government in Catalonia tightens. Catalan President Carles Puigdemont risks economic damage and European isolation if he pushes ahead with plans to declare independence, despite ignoring Spain's highest court. Several major companies, including CaixaBank and Gas Natural SDG, are considering exiting Catalonia due to the escalating crisis. A meeting on Monday may lead to a declaration of independence, which would require a "Yes" vote to leave under two Catalan laws, potentially leading to a constitutional dispute and economic consequences.

site_title: Buoyant en bloc market lifts CDL, UOL
summary: CDL and UOL saw significant gains in share price and trading activity on Friday, driven by a buoyant en bloc market. CDL closed at S$11.60, up 1.67% from Thursday, while UOL rose 4.3% to S$8.55. The en bloc market has seen a surge in deals, with collective sales quadrupling to S$5.2 billion year-to-date. Analysts from JP Morgan Securities Singapore predict a sustainable en bloc cycle, citing record-low unsold near-term pipeline and low replenishment-to-sales ratio.

site_title: Sonic powerhouses
summary: HARBETH, a British firm founded in 1977, has released a special edition of its Super 5 Plus loudspeaker to commemorate its 40th anniversary. The speaker features a walnut finish and upgraded components, and is praised for its open, smooth, and natural sound. A new Jimi Hendrix tribute album, "Jimi Hendrix: A Tribute," is also available, featuring lesser-known artists and well-known tracks. The album is considered essential listening for Hendrix and jazz fans. The special edition speaker retails for S$6,580.

site_title: String of SGX queries leaves China Taisan under a cloud
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is scrutinizing China Taisan Technology Group Holdings over concerns about the suitability of newly appointed directors and the valuation of its assets. The regulator has asked for more details on key boardroom appointments, including non-executive chairman Thomas Francis Darden II, executive director Steven Hartanto, and lead independent director Ng Eng Ho. The company has also been questioned about its financial books and the certification of its valuers, following a series of red flags, including a net loss of over $26 million and significant doubts over its ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Jean Tan
summary: Jean Tan, executive director of the Singapore International Foundation (SIF), emphasizes inclusiveness and diversity in building friendships and positive change between Singapore and the world. Through various programs, such as education, healthcare, environment, and business, the SIF encourages cross-cultural exchange and people-to-people interaction. Initiatives include promoting volunteer cooperation, inspiring digital storytelling, and nurturing young social entrepreneurs. With a focus on making a difference, the SIF partners with local NGOs and corporates to implement projects in 35 countries, aiming to build a better world through collaboration and inclusivity.

site_title: SIA Engineering inks MOU with Air India to service Indian market
summary: SIA Engineering Co has signed a non-binding MOU with Air India Engineering Services to collaborate on offering maintenance, repair and overhaul services in India. The partnership will provide line maintenance, engineering training, and ancillary services at various Indian airports, offering customized packages to domestic and foreign airlines. The agreement is expected to have a limited financial impact on SIA Engineering.

site_title: EU braces for Brexit talks collapse as May falters
summary: The EU is bracing for a potential collapse of Brexit talks as British Prime Minister Theresa May's government faces internal divisions. Despite May's warnings of a "no-deal" scenario, EU leaders believe it would primarily harm Britain, not the continent. In preparation for a possible deadlock, the EU is stepping up contingency planning, including protecting the carbon market and moving euro-denominated securities clearing to the continent. EU officials warn that businesses should be prepared for the worst, and a senior diplomat suggests that a change in British leadership would not significantly improve the negotiating position.

site_title: Toyota plans to build new Auris in UK on assumption of Brexit transition deal
summary: Toyota plans to build the next-generation Auris car at its British car plant in central England, assuming a transitional Brexit deal is secured. The decision is expected to secure thousands of jobs and provide a boost to Prime Minister Theresa May. Toyota's board will make the final decision by the end of the year, with the company having a working assumption that the UK will retain the model due to the uncertainty surrounding the trading relationship with the EU.

site_title: En bloc fever benefits only a few
summary: En bloc fever in Singapore's property market has reached a new height, with a record-breaking S$906.7 million bid for the Katong condominium Amber Park. However, this boom only benefits a small segment of the population, with analysts warning that the market may be unsustainable due to cooling measures and economic concerns, including rising unemployment and HDB resale prices. Experts caution that the benefits of the market boom will accrue to only a few, while the majority of Singaporeans will not experience the same level of wealth growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Venture Corporation's recent quarter saw a historical-high performance, with consistent revenue growth for 15 consecutive quarters. DBS Group Research maintains a BUY call with a target price of S$21.00, citing attractive earnings growth and dividend upside. Keppel Corporation secured a S$100 million FPSO conversion contract, maintaining a BUY call with a target price of S$7.36.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore property stocks surged as en-bloc sales reached a 10-year high, with collective sales quadrupling to S$5.2 billion. Analysts at JP Morgan believe the market is poised for a sustainable three-year en bloc cycle. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines plans cost-cutting initiatives to offset stiff competition, and over 250 companies have adopted a new standard on flexible work arrangements.

site_title: DMX sues Deloitte, alleging professional negligence
summary: DMX Technologies Group, a digital media solutions provider, is suing Deloitte & Touche LLP for alleged professional negligence. The suit centers on a "clean opinion" stamped by Deloitte over 13 years, from 2001 to 2013, which DMX claims should have revealed issues with transactions that led to significant losses. The company alleges that Deloitte failed to obtain sufficient supporting documents, leading to cumulative losses of over US$90 million. DMX's current management is seeking damages and transparency.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended higher on Friday, closing at 1,764 after 2.49 billion lots valued at RM1.95 billion were traded. The index slipped 4.91 points. Gainers outnumbered losers, with 488 stocks gaining and 349 losing.

site_title: September US payrolls shrink by 33,000 in wake of hurricanes
summary: US payrolls contracted by 33,000 in September, the first time in seven years, due to major hurricanes in southern states. Despite this, the unemployment rate fell to a 16-year-low of 4.2%, while wage gains accelerated. The hurricanes had a "net effect" on nonfarm payrolls, but no discernible effect on the national unemployment rate. The Labor Department noted that data-collection rates were within normal ranges, and other labor market indicators, such as the participation rate and U-6 underemployment rate, remained solid.

site_title: Volkswagen Arteon review: Art attack
summary: Volkswagen's new Arteon model has been unveiled, aiming to propel the brand into the luxury leagues. The sleek four-door coupe boasts a 2.0-litre turbocharged engine with 280hp, rivaling the BMW 430i Gran Coupe. The Arteon features an elegant design, adaptive damper system, and semi-autonomous driving systems, including adaptive cruise control. It offers ample interior space, refinement, and straight-line performance, with a massive cargo room. Two petrol-driven models will be launched in 2018, marking Volkswagen's attempt to enter the luxury market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks at more than two-year highs after Wall St record
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a two-year high on Friday, driven by record peaks on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 up 0.30% and the Topix index up 0.28%. Investors expect bumper US corporate earnings and a potential signing of President Trump's tax cut plan. This marks the fifth straight gain for Tokyo stocks, with the highest close since August 2015.

site_title: New Audi A8 seeks luxury through technology
summary: Audi's new A8 sedan boasts over 40 advanced systems, including Traffic Jam Assist, a hands-free driving feature that takes control at speeds below 60km/h. The fourth-generation model features organic LED taillights, a turbocharged V6 engine, and AI Suspension, which provides a smooth ride and can pre-empt large bumps. With its elegant design and impressive technology, the A8 is a luxury powerhouse that sets a new standard for the industry. Pricing and options for features like AI Suspension and all-wheel steering will be revealed closer to its Singapore launch in mid-2018.

site_title: Secret code set in motion HSBC currency front-running: US prosecutors
summary: HSBC currency trader Mark Johnson is on trial in federal court in Brooklyn, accused of a scheme that produced a US$8 million profit for his bank. Johnson allegedly used a secret code, "my watch is off," to signal fellow traders to launch a buying spree of pounds ahead of a US$3.5 billion client order. The scheme involved Johnson, Stuart Scott, and other traders making about US$3 million in profit. Prosecutors argue the trades were designed to take advantage of the client order and were not for the benefit of a fellow trader, Frank Cahill.

site_title: Keppel receives eligibility-to-list letter from SGX for planned US commercial Reit
summary: Keppel Corp has received an eligibility-to-list letter from SGX for its proposed US commercial Reit, Keppel-KBS US Reit. The company will take a 50% interest in the Reit manager for $27.5 million. A decision on the IPO has not been made, with additional requirements needed before listing can proceed. Keppel's wholly owned subsidiary, Keppel Capital, will jointly sponsor the Reit with KBS Pacific Advisors, the other 50% owner of the manager.

site_title: MSCI China Index close to erasing gap with Shanghai for the first time in 20 years
summary: The MSCI China Index is closing in on the Shanghai Composite Index for the first time in 20 years, with a gap narrowing to its narrowest since 2014. The MSCI China Index trades at 17.4 times reported earnings, while the Shanghai Composite Index trades at 17.5. This comes as mainland markets are expected to catch up when they reopen on Monday, following a 4.2% gain for the offshore gauge this week. The narrowing gap highlights the growing appeal of mainland equities, particularly among overseas investors in companies like Tencent and Alibaba.

site_title: Ryanair takes on competitors over crisis
summary: Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, has apologized to its pilots and offered higher pay, aiming to retain staff amid a pilot shortage crisis. The airline's CEO, Michael O'Leary, has pledged to improve working conditions and beat competitors' offers. EasyJet, which has benefited from Ryanair's flight cancellations, is now seen as a potential beneficiary, with analysts predicting it could capture market share due to the collapse of Monarch Airlines. The airline industry faces challenges amid Brexit uncertainty and a shortage of pilots.

site_title: France to make least wine in 60 years as frost, rot hit grapes
summary: France is expected to produce the smallest wine vintage in 60 years, with a 19% decline in production to 36.9 million hectolitres. The decrease is mainly attributed to spring frost and drought in various regions, including Bordeaux, Champagne, and the southeast. This would be the lowest production since 1957, when a spring freeze destroyed flower buds. Italy's wine production is also expected to fall, but to a lesser extent, with a 24% decline forecast.

site_title: SBI Offshore's ex-CEO rekindles boardroom fight, now seeks directorship
summary: SBI Offshore's former CEO, David Tan Woo Thian, is seeking a seat on the board as a non-executive director, despite the company deciding not to pursue legal action against him over alleged irregularities in past transactions. The decision not to pursue action was based on the assessment of commercial "net benefits" with no material financial loss to the company. A reconvened extraordinary general meeting (EGM) will be held to consider Mr Tan's appointment, following a similar EGM that was adjourned in 2016.

site_title: Owners moving fast to catch collective sales wave
summary: Singapore property owners are capitalizing on developers' appetite for land by moving fast to sell their collective sales. Vista Park and How Sun Park are near achieving 80% approval, with owners seeking S$345 million and S$72 million respectively. This follows a surge in collective sales, with 16 deals worth S$5.83 billion this year, up from S$1 billion last year. Experts predict the en bloc market can be sustained until mid-2018, driven by positive market sentiments and decreasing concerns over oversupply and policy changes.

site_title: DBS appoints Taimur Baig as new chief economist
summary: DBS Bank has appointed Taimur Baig as its new chief economist and managing director for group research, replacing David Carbon who is retiring. Baig, a veteran economist with over 20 years of experience covering the Asia region, joins DBS after previously working at Deutsche Bank and the International Monetary Fund. His expertise in international finance, macro risk, and exchange rate analysis will contribute to DBS's deep insights on the Asian economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish higher, STI up 2.2% for week thanks to banks, Jardine
summary: Singapore stocks rose 2.2% for the week, driven by gains in the banking sector and Jardine Matheson. Initially, the sector rose on expectations of a December US rate hike, but fell after traders switched to China banks trading in Hong Kong following a reserve requirement rate cut. The Straits Times Index gained 72 points, with the banks and Jardine Matheson accounting for 15 points of its rise. This week's rally was largely determined by the banks and Jardine stocks, with the index closing at 3,291.29.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally to hit 10-year high
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a 10-year high, closing at 28,458.04 on October 6, 2017, with a 0.28% increase. This followed a record on Wall Street and ahead of US jobs data release. Chinese markets were closed for a week-long public holiday, contributing to the rally.

site_title: Former Thai PM Thaksin to be charged with royal insult: attorney general
summary: Thailand's former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra will be charged with royal insult and computer crimes, according to the attorney general. Thaksin, who fled Thailand after being overthrown in 2006, lives in exile. A court issued a second arrest warrant for his sister, Yingluck, who fled Thailand in August to avoid conviction in a criminal negligence case. The charges against Thaksin stem from an interview he gave to South Korean media in 2015, and could carry a sentence of up to 15 years.

site_title: Severe train disruptions in Germany after deadly storm
summary: A powerful storm, Storm Xavier, hit northern and eastern Germany, killing seven motorists and causing severe train disruptions. Thousands of commuters were affected, with trains linking Hamburg, Hanover, and Berlin cancelled due to unusable tracks. Hundreds of passengers spent the night in stations, and regional trains in the capital, Berlin, operated with partial services. The clearing work is expected to last all day, and emergency crews are still removing fallen trees from tracks.

site_title: Norway takes hard look at climate risk for vast oil riches
summary: Norway is launching a commission to assess the climate risks associated with its vast oil and gas resources, worth an estimated 47 billion barrels. The move comes as renewable energy sources gain popularity and the country's economy faces uncertainty. The commission, led by economist Martin Skancke, will explore physical threats and the impact of changing energy consumption on the value of oil and gas resources. The findings are expected by December 2018, amid a debate over the future of Norway's petroleum industry and the moral sense of investing in fossil resources.

site_title: easyJet reports record summer sales as rivals struggle
summary: British budget airline easyJet reported record high summer sales, benefiting from rivals Ryanair's struggles and the collapse of Monarch. EasyJet expects a year profit of £405-410 million, surpassing expectations. The airline sees opportunities to grow and strengthen its positions in Europe's leading airports amid sector turmoil. Analysts predict easing pressure on ticket prices, and easyJet has expressed interest in assets from Air Berlin and Alitalia.

images.alt_text: easyJet has expressed interest in assets from Air Berlin and Alitalia, which have both entered insolvency proceedings.

site_title: MAS panel on cybersecurity meets, discusses ways to protect financial sector
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) Cyber Security Advisory Panel (CSAP) met to discuss ways to protect the financial sector from cyber threats. The panel emphasized the importance of basic cyber hygiene practices, strengthening competency and capability of financial institution boards, and conducting realistic penetration tests. Members also advocated for the use of data analytics and machine learning to analyze cyber incident data. The CSAP will convene again in 2018 to continue advising MAS on strategies to enhance cyber resilience in the financial sector.

site_title: Singapore property stocks jump as big sales buoy sentiment
summary: Singapore property stocks jumped as a surge in en-bloc sales boosted market sentiment. En-bloc sales, where groups of owners sell apartment blocks at a premium, reached a 10-year high, totaling over S$5 billion this year. Developers such as Kingsford Huray Development and City Developments Ltd saw significant gains, with UOL Group Ltd's shares rising 4.3%. Analysts attribute the surge to the trickle-down effect of en-bloc sales on demand and supply, leading to rising home prices for the first time in four years.
