site_title: Australia: Shares end 1% higher; NZ hits record high
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Friday, driven by gains in financial and material stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,710.70, with the "Big 4" lenders and mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto leading the gains. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also reached a record high, edging up 0.1% to close at 7,977.34.

site_title: Zhao Yang Geotechnic wins tender for Tuas South industrial site
summary: JTC has awarded the tender for the Tuas South industrial site (4,802 sqm) to Zhao Yang Geotechnic for S$2.8 million, the highest bid. The site has a 20-year tenure and a gross plot ratio of 1.4. The tender was launched on June 30 and closed on August 25, with three bids submitted.

site_title: Abe's free education plan may slow Bank of Japan's inflation drive
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's free education plan could slow the Bank of Japan's efforts to spur inflation, according to economists. The plan, which could shave up to 0.7 percentage point from core CPI, may have a significant but temporary impact on inflation. The BOJ's benchmark consumer price index could be affected, potentially pushing back the normalization of monetary policy. The plan's effects are uncertain due to the ongoing election and the need to finalize policy details.

site_title: Over 250 Singapore firms adopt new tripartite standard on flexible work arrangements
summary: Over 250 Singapore firms, including public service employers, have adopted a new tripartite standard on flexible work arrangements (FWAs), benefiting over 210,000 employees. The standard, developed by the Ministry of Manpower, National Trades Union Congress, and Singapore National Employers Federation, aims to improve work-life balance and attract/retain talent. Employers adopting the standard will be listed on the Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices (TAFEP) website and can use a logomark for recruitment efforts. The progressive implementation of FWAs will help employees meet their needs and improve workplace productivity.

site_title: Parkson auditor raises going concern doubt; company's parent pledges financial support
summary: Parkson Retail Asia's independent auditor, Ernst & Young, has raised a "material uncertainty" about the company's ability to remain a going concern due to a net loss of S$61.2 million and a net current liability position of S$55.5 million. The company's Malaysian parent, Parkson Holdings Bhd, has pledged financial support for 12 months to alleviate concerns, but the auditor notes that the group's ability to continue as a going concern depends on generating sufficient cash flows and continued financial support.

site_title: Citigroup considering onshore cash equities business in China
summary: Citigroup is considering setting up an onshore cash equities business in China, aiming to boost its share in the Asian market. The bank plans to add at least 10 people to its Hong Kong and Singapore units and increase research coverage of Chinese stocks to 200 by year-end and 250 in the longer term. This move comes as China-listed shares are set to be included in the MSCI's emerging-markets benchmark, expected to drive demand for brokerage and research services.

site_title: North Korea says it is operating some factories left by Seoul
summary: North Korea is operating some factories left behind by South Korean companies in the Kaesong industrial complex, following South Korea's withdrawal from the joint venture. The South had suspended operations due to allegations that funds were being used for nuclear weapons. North Korea claims the factories are now under their control and will continue to operate despite international sanctions. The move is seen as a challenge to South Korea's efforts to protect its companies' property rights.

site_title: Watch-list firm China Taisan in SGX's crosshairs
summary: China Taisan Technology Group Holdings, a watch-list firm on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), is under scrutiny after a series of queries from the regulator. The queries follow boardroom changes, including the redesignation of a major shareholder as executive director, and questions about the firm's valuation and internal controls. The SGX has demanded further details on the valuation of China Taisan's assets and the certification of its valuers, and has asked the company to make the valuation report available to shareholders for inspection.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally with US stocks as tax cut hopes boost dollar
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday, following a record close on US stocks, as tax cut hopes boosted the dollar and fueled expectations of further gains. The Labor Department's upcoming jobs creation figures for September, improving factory orders, jobless claims, and exports, added to the positivity. The S&P 500 closed at an all-time high, with Asian markets such as Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Singapore also seeing gains, driven by optimism over US tax reform and global economic growth.

site_title: Consolidation may lead to 10-15 state banks: India government adviser
summary: India's government may consolidate its state-run banks, potentially reducing the number to 10-15 majority-owned lenders from 21. The government may cut its stakes in banks to 52% while retaining majority ownership. More funds will be injected into banks in the next few months. This move aims to improve the sector's stability and efficiency.

site_title: Singapore's retrenched mid-career professionals get lifeline into tech sector, startups
summary: Singapore offers a lifeline to mid-career professionals who lost their jobs through a networking and sharing event, in partnership with Protégé, Glints, and BEAM. The event provides career booths and a platform for budding entrepreneurs to pitch ideas to investors. This initiative comes as Singapore experienced a dip in layoffs and unemployment in the first half of the year, with 3,500 layoffs from the services and manufacturing sectors. The event aims to raise funds, create visibility, and opportunities for partners at all levels, supporting the tech sector and startups.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets stable before US jobs data
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained steady at the open on Friday, awaiting US jobs data. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% to 7,516.82 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gained 0.1% to 12,979.34 points. The Paris CAC 40 dipped fractionally. The stability comes as investors focus on US-EU trade talks and await key US jobs data, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Malaysia August export growth at 21.5% yoy; above forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports in August grew 21.5% year-over-year, beating forecasts, driven by manufacturing sector and LNG exports. This was slower than July's 30.9% growth. August imports grew 22.6%, leading to a widened trade surplus of RM9.9 billion. Exports to China, EU, and the US also rose, with shipments to the US increasing 14.5%.

site_title: Fed working on capturing non-finra banks' Treasury trade data
summary: The Federal Reserve is working on collecting data on non-Finra banks' Treasury trade data, following the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority's (Finra) efforts to gather statistics on a limited group of transactions. Fed Governor Jerome Powell stressed the need for a level playing field, but market-makers and high-speed trading firms argue that the current efforts exclude non-Finra members, missing a significant portion of the market. Regulators aim to improve transparency, which was lacking after an episode of unusual volatility in 2014.

site_title: German industrial orders jump on vibrant demand from abroad
summary: German industrial orders surged 3.6% in August, the strongest monthly increase since December, driven by strong foreign demand, particularly from outside the euro zone. Domestic demand rose 2.7% while foreign orders jumped 4.3%, with a 7.7% increase from non-euro zone customers. The positive trend is expected to continue, supporting overall growth in Europe's largest economy. This beats forecasts and supports a 2017 growth forecast of 1.9% for the German economy, with some economists predicting a higher gear in the industry.

site_title: Japan ad agency Dentsu fined for making employees do too much overtime
summary: Japan's advertising giant Dentsu Inc has been fined 500,000 yen (S$6,013) by a Tokyo court for making employees work overtime beyond legal limits. The fine comes after a 24-year-old employee, Matsuri Takahashi, died by suicide in 2015 due to overwork, prompting a national investigation into the issue of "karoshi" (death by overwork). The fine is part of a larger effort to reform employment practices, including caps on overtime and better pay for part-time and contract workers.

site_title: Japan to show off new heavy lift military plane in search for first overseas arms sale
summary: Japan's air force is set to showcase its new C-2 long-range heavy lift military cargo plane in the Middle East and New Zealand, marking its first overseas display. The C-2, built by Kawasaki Heavy Industries, has the capability to lift nearly four times as much as Japan's older C-1 transports and fly six times as far. A successful sale of the C-2 would secure Japan its first major overseas arms contract, following Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's 2014 lifting of a decades-old ban on arms exports.

site_title: Five dead, seven missing after Chinese boat, Hong Kong tanker collide
summary: A collision between a Chinese fishing boat and a Hong Kong oil tanker occurred off Japan's western coast, resulting in five deaths and seven missing. The Chinese vessel, the "Lurong Yuanyu 378", capsized, with four crew members rescued. The Hong Kong tanker, "Brightoil Lucky", was carrying 21 crew members, all of whom are believed to be safe. Japan has deployed patrol boats to search for the missing crew.

site_title: Florence Regency seeks buyer in private after tender bidders won't raise offers
summary: The owners of Florence Regency, a 336-unit HUDC estate in Hougang, will continue to seek a buyer willing to pay at least S$629 million after public tender bids declined to raise offers. The owners had initially received bids exceeding S$600 million, but none met the valuation price set by an independent valuer. The private treaty period will last for 10 weeks, with a second tender exercise possible if no buyer is found by Dec 5. The en bloc property market has seen increased activity this year, with other notable sales and tenders announced.

site_title: Australia: Material and financial stocks buoy shares; NZ higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 5,690, driven by financial and material stocks, as the S&P 500 hit fresh highs on Wall Street. Mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, and healthcare stock CSL Ltd, gained 1.9% and 1.4% respectively. The Australian dollar fell 0.1% to 0.77 USD, supporting foreign-denominated earnings. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand rose 0.17% to 7,988.49.

site_title: EU drugs agency issues £31.8m staff tender on Brexit fallout
summary: The European Medicines Agency (EMA) has issued a £31.8 million tender for temporary workers due to Brexit fallout, with around 890 employees set to relocate from London. The EMA, which approves and monitors the safety of drugs across Europe, must be based in an EU country. A staff survey found that between 19-94% of employees are likely to leave depending on the chosen location, with Amsterdam, Barcelona, Vienna, Milan, or Copenhagen being the best options for retaining staff. The agency is preparing for the move amidst huge uncertainty and potential staff departures.

site_title: Japanese reporter died after 159 hours of overtime
summary: A Japanese reporter, Miwa Sado, died from heart failure after logging 159 hours of overtime in a month, leading to a re-examination of Japan's notorious long working culture. Sado, 31, was found dead in 2013 after covering Tokyo assembly elections and a national parliament vote. NHK, the public broadcaster, has vowed to reform its working practices after the revelation, with President Ryoichi Ueda pledging to improve work conditions and cooperate with Sado's parents to prevent similar incidents. The case highlights the country's karoshi problem, which has sparked widespread concern.

site_title: Macau casinos plunge as Golden Week visitor numbers disappoint
summary: Macau casino operators, including Galaxy Entertainment Group and Sands China, plummeted after visitor arrivals from mainland China over the Golden Week holidays fell 5.1% in the first four days, disappointing analyst estimates for mid-high single-digit growth. Galaxy Entertainment Group's shares dropped as much as 5% and Sands China's fell 4.4%, poised for its biggest loss since December, with analyst Alfred Lau attributing the sell-off to high valuations and a "minor disappointment" in visitor numbers.

site_title: ThaiBev looks to food and abroad for growth after sales dip
summary: Thai Beverage's (ThaiBev) sales dropped 6% year-on-year to 142 billion baht in the first nine months of its fiscal year due to slow economic growth and a year-long mourning period after the death of King Bhumibol. The company expects an upturn after the mourning ends and plans to launch new spirit products. ThaiBev is also expanding its food business and increasing prices of spirits by 2% to offset the impact of a sugar tax and new alcohol excise tax. The company aims to grow its beer market share in Southeast Asia through mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: China approves HP's US$1.1b buy of Samsung's printer business with curbs
summary: China has approved HP's $1.1 billion purchase of Samsung's printer business, pending certain restrictions. The Ministry of Commerce requires HP to sell A4 format laser printers on "fair and reasonable" terms, report prices and data every six months, and not buy stakes in other printer manufacturers. HP must also ensure compatibility with third-party suppliers and not restrict compatibility. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter, with HP gaining an intellectual property portfolio of 6,500 printing patents and 1,300 researchers and engineers.

site_title: Dispute resolution clash could derail Brexit deal, warns UK think tank
summary: A UK think tank warns that a dispute-resolution system proposed by Britain to replace the European Union Court of Justice could derail the Brexit deal. The Institute for Government says the UK and the European Commission are far apart, and irreconcilable differences could lead to a failed negotiation. The UK has two options to break the stalemate: adopting a European Free Trade Association-type court model or creating a new, untested structure. The think tank advises the government to start an informed debate to mitigate the risk of a deal collapse.

site_title: Singapore shares open up on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.42 points to 3,266.26, driven by a 0.4% gain on Thursday. Traders drew inspiration from Wall Street's record close, with the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite also reaching new highs. The rally comes ahead of GDP data release and amid US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Broker's take: JP Morgan says Singapore en bloc frenzy is sustainable
summary: JP Morgan analysts predict a sustainable three-year en bloc cycle in Singapore's property market, driven by a record-low unsold near-term pipeline, low developers' replenishment-to-sales ratio, and insufficient confirmed list sites. En bloc sales have quadrupled year-over-year to S$5.2 billion, with 2017 seeing the third-largest value in en bloc deals. However, hikes in development charges and a large launch pipeline in 2019-2020 could derail momentum. Analysts recommend City Developments (CDL) and UOL Group as top property stock picks.

site_title: London's housing market stalls; time to buckle up?
summary: London's housing market has stalled, with prices falling for the first time in eight years. The market's slowdown is attributed to Brexit uncertainty, rising inflation, and unaffordability, with house prices now costing 10 times the average salary. Potential buyers are holding off, and experts predict a flat market for the foreseeable future, with some forecasting a 9-17.5% price drop or rise over the next three years. The market's slowdown has significant implications for consumer demand and economic growth, with the value of the UK's housing stock reaching a record £6.8 trillion.

site_title: Singapore Q3 advance GDP estimates out on Oct 13: MTI
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) will release Singapore's third quarter advance GDP estimates on Oct 13. Private sector economists expect the economy to grow 3.1% in Q3, with non-oil domestic exports projected to increase 7.4% and manufacturing at 6.6%. The full-year GDP growth forecast remains unchanged at 2.5%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, tracking rallies on Wall Street, amid growing confidence in US corporate earnings and President Trump's tax cut plan. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.37% to 20,705.75, while the Topix index increased 0.32% to 1,687.91. This follows a similar trend on US stock markets, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Five children, woman dead in Japan 'arson attack'
summary: A deliberate fire at an apartment in Hitachi City, Japan, killed five children and a woman. The father of the family, in his 30s, was found to have started the blaze. A sixth child found in critical condition later died in hospital. Authorities cited unnamed sources saying the father was the one who started the fire, which occurred approximately 100km north of Tokyo.

site_title: Singapore Airlines plans wide-ranging cost cuts to offset stiff competition
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to implement over 50 cost-cutting measures, including reducing fuel burn and reviewing supplier relationships, as part of a three-year transformation plan. The airline, facing stiff competition from Chinese and Middle Eastern rivals, aims to increase competitiveness and offset lack of domestic flight markets. CEO Goh Choon Phong reported progress on the plan, which includes initiatives such as self-service options and reducing in-flight food waste. The airline has already made changes, including handing routes to budget carrier Scoot and merging SilkAir's finance team with its parent.

site_title: Global growth picking up despite social tensions, Lagarde says
summary: The International Monetary Fund's Managing Director Christine Lagarde said the world economy is gaining strength despite social tensions, with a "cyclical pickup" in investment and trade in advanced economies. The IMF's updated forecast is expected to be "even more optimistic" when released next week, with global growth projected to reach 3.5% this year and 3.6% in 2018. However, Lagarde warned that the global economy faces threats, including high debt levels, rapid credit expansion, and excessive risk taking, which could lead to increased inequality and social unrest.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge higher as Spain's IBEX pulls out of nosedive
summary: Spanish stocks rebounded on Thursday, driven by escalating tensions over Catalonia, with Spain's IBEX index up 2.5% and banking stocks leading gains. Analysts attributed the rise to the country's improving economic growth, with Caixabank and Banco Sabadell rising 6.2% and 4.5% respectively. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.2% lower, while Germany's DAX was flat. The IBEX is expected to end 2017 up 14%, with other European indexes also predicted to rise, despite some declines in shares from Assa Abloy and Osram Licht.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 0.75% to 28,591.00 at the open on Friday, driven by optimism over the global economy and a record close on Wall Street. Financial markets in mainland China are closed for a week-long holiday. The rally follows recent gains in other Asian markets, with Singapore's STI up 0.4% on Thursday. The Hang Seng Index's 0.75% increase is a reversal of Thursday's 0.45% decline, as traders brush off new US threats and focus on the global economy.

site_title: Japan workers' wages rise in positive sign for consumer spending
summary: Japan's wages rose 0.9% in August from a year earlier, reversing a decline, and are expected to boost consumer spending. Nominal wages increased, while inflation-adjusted real wages rose 0.1% for the first time in eight months. Special payments jumped 6.1%, and overtime pay increased 1.5%. The data suggests a gradual pick-up in workers' income, but wage growth may not be enough to dispel concerns over the sustainability of consumer spending.

site_title: US dollar hits 7-week highs before US jobs data; sterling slips
summary: The US dollar reached a 7-week high against a basket of currencies, driven by hopes for progress on US tax reforms and strong business spending data. The dollar index rose to 94.016, its strongest level since August 17. Meanwhile, sterling slipped to fresh four-week lows due to divisions within the British government and concerns over Prime Minister Theresa May's leadership. The US jobs data, due later Friday, is expected to show a slowdown in jobs growth, with nonfarm payrolls likely increasing by 90,000 jobs in September.

site_title: South Korea: Financial markets closed on Friday
summary: South Korea's financial markets closed on Friday due to a public holiday. Trading resumed on Tuesday, October 10. Meanwhile, in other markets, Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, and Asia's traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend their stocks rally. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with investors showing optimism despite split Fed views.

site_title: Ryanair promises pilots significant improvements in pay, conditions
summary: Ryanair has promised pilots significant pay and conditions improvements, exceeding rival rates and enhancing job security. The airline, the largest in Europe, has faced criticism and pilot departures after canceling thousands of flights due to pilot shortages. CEO Michael O'Leary sent a letter to pilots, offering pay increases of €5,000-€10,000 and loyalty bonuses of €6,000-€12,000. The moves aim to address pilot demands for better roster systems, pay, and local employment conditions.

site_title: Switch Inc's IPO prices at US$17 per share
summary: Switch Inc raised about $531.3 million from its initial public offering priced at $17 per share, making it the second-largest US technology listing this year. The company, which operates data centers for major customers like Amazon and eBay, aims to use the proceeds to buy out investors in Switch Ltd and take control of it. The IPO valued Switch at up to $4.2 billion, with Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, and Wells Fargo Securities among the top underwriters.

site_title: Tokyo's governor Koike mulling over taxing cash reserves of large firms
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike's Party of Hope considers taxing large companies' cash reserves, exceeding 300 trillion yen. The proposal aims to increase revenue, despite the party's unlikely win in the Oct 22 general election. The manifesto also includes plans to freeze sales tax, phase out nuclear power by 2030, and expand renewables to 30% of energy mix. Koike's party seeks to challenge Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Liberal Democratic Party, potentially leading to Abe's ouster if they lose seats.

site_title: UK retail sales show biggest jump in over three years: BDO
summary: UK retail sales rose 2.9% in September, the largest jump in over three years, according to a survey by BDO. This growth, despite underlying slow growth, suggests consumers are coping with income squeeze. The Bank of England expects consumer demand to pick up, but may need to raise interest rates to combat inflation. Retailers welcomed the positive growth, which follows a two-year high in early September, as a relief after past autumn challenges.

site_title: Fitch joins S&P in issuing Catalonia debt downgrade warning
summary: Fitch has joined Standard & Poor's in warning that Catalonia's sovereign debt rating may be downgraded due to escalating tensions with Madrid over the region's push for independence. The ratings agency notes that "unforeseeable events" could disrupt state liquidity funds, affecting Catalonia's ability to service its debt. Fitch and S&P have placed Catalonia's ratings on "CreditWatch with negative implications," citing the risk of damage to government coordination and communication, which is essential for servicing its debt. The current tensions are expected to ease in the medium term, according to Fitch.

site_title: Battle of the brands in Japanese elections as opposing parties start to sound alike
summary: Japan's general election is nearing, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Liberal Democratic Party facing a challenge from Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike's Party of Hope. Despite their differences on nuclear power and sales tax, the two parties' platforms are largely similar, leading many to question whether voters can make an informed choice. Koike's party trails the LDP in surveys, and she is unlikely to win, but may still be able to damage Abe's reputation enough to prompt his ousting as leader. The election is seen as a test of Abe's leadership and the LDP's ability to adapt to changing times.

site_title: Two die as Saudi police crack down on IS-linked group
summary: Saudi police raided IS-linked cell hideouts, killing 2 and arresting 5, foiling fresh attacks. The raids targeted hideouts in Riyadh, where explosive belts were being made and a man refused to surrender, blowing himself up. The group has claimed bombings and shootings against Shiites and security forces since 2014. Saudi Arabia is part of the US-led coalition battling the extremist group in Syria and Iraq.

site_title: Gulf oil producers curtail output ahead of Tropical Storm Nate
summary: Oil and natural gas operators in the US Gulf of Mexico have curtailed production ahead of Tropical Storm Nate, which is forecast to strengthen into a hurricane before making landfall in Louisiana. As of Thursday, about 14.6% of US Gulf oil production was offline, with 6.4% of natural gas output also shut. Major producers like BP, Chevron, and Royal Dutch Shell have suspended production, while Exxon Mobil Corp and others have withdrawn personnel from their platforms. Refineries in Louisiana are preparing for the storm, with some planning to continue operations despite Nate's projected path.

site_title: East looks West in property buys as West looks East
summary: Asian investors are putting record amounts into offshore property, with a 98% year-on-year increase in outbound investment by Asian investors to $45.2 billion in H1 2017. Chinese firms led the way, investing $25.6 billion, but new guidelines limiting "irrational" investments may lead to more selective strategies focusing on the "One Belt, One Road" initiative. Meanwhile, Singaporean investors are diversifying, leading the way into new markets, and European investors are also targeting Asian property for diversification and steady income.

site_title: US probe met ex-British spy over Trump claims: CNN
summary: US investigators met with former British spy Christopher Steele to discuss a dossier on President Donald Trump's alleged campaign ties to Russia. The dossier, compiled by Steele, includes unsubstantiated claims of Russian blackmail videos and regular contact between Trump advisors and Russian officials. The meeting occurred this past summer and was kept secret until now. The dossier has been taken more seriously by the FBI and US intelligence community than publicly acknowledged. The investigation, led by special counsel Robert Mueller, is exploring possible Trump campaign collusion with Russian interference in the 2016 election.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yongnam, DMX, United Food, Soilbuild Construction
summary: Yongnam Holdings is issuing S$12.1 million of new shares at 25.5 Singapore cents apiece to raise working capital, a 6% discount from its Thursday closing price. DMX Technologies Group is suing former auditor Deloitte & Touche LLP over accounting irregularities. United Food Holdings acquired 80% stakes in three Chinese animal feed companies for S$24.5 million. Soilbuild Construction Group won a S$50 million contract for a factory development in Singapore.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian keeps 'buy' on OCBC ahead of results
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintained its "buy" call on OCBC Bank ahead of its Q3 results on Oct 26, forecasting a 1.6% net profit increase to S$958 million. The broker expects healthy loan growth of 1.5% and a 12% year-on-year growth in fee income. However, it anticipates a 6% increase in bank provisions due to deteriorating collateral valuations. The target price is set at S$13.38, representing an 18.9% upside over the current stock price.

site_title: Gold dips after strong US data lifts dollar
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.34% to $1,270.01 an ounce after strong US economic data lifted the dollar and fueled expectations of interest rate hikes. The dollar index reached a 2-1/2-month high, boosting bond yields and putting pressure on gold. However, San Francisco Federal Reserve President John Williams' comments on low annual US economic growth may support gold prices. Investors await US non-farm payrolls data on Friday, which could impact gold prices.

site_title: China's answer to Airbnb sets sights on Japan as tourism booms
summary: Tujia.com, China's largest vacation rental platform, aims to boost Japan listings by 10 times in two years as the country's tourism boom continues. The platform seeks to increase listings to about 100,000 by 2019, with about half owned by Chinese investors. Japan's tourism industry is expanding rapidly, with record tourist arrivals and a strain on the hotel industry. Tujia charges owners 3% of their accommodation rates, and the service is available in seven Asian countries, including Singapore and Thailand. The company plans to double its Japanese staff by 2019 and increase listings to 200,000 by 2025.

site_title: Trump expected to decertify Iran nuclear deal, official says
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to announce that he will decertify the landmark international deal to curb Iran's nuclear program, potentially causing the 2015 accord to unravel. Trump has called the pact an "embarrassment" and "the worst deal ever negotiated," and has been weighing whether it serves US security interests. If he declines to certify Iran's compliance, Congress would have 60 days to decide whether to reimpose sanctions, which could worsen Middle East tensions and trigger a regional arms race.

site_title: Malaysian pension giants 'eyeing stakes in foreign-owned insurers'
summary: Malaysia's two largest pension funds, Employees Provident Fund (EPF) and Kumpulan Wang Persaraan (KWAP), plan to discuss acquiring minority stakes in foreign-owned life insurance companies in the country. The move comes as the government enforces caps on overseas ownership, with foreign insurers having until June 2018 to trim their holdings to 70% or less. EPF and KWAP, managing a combined US$203 billion, have requested central bank approval to start negotiations with potential targets, including Prudential Plc, Great Eastern Holdings Ltd, and Tokio Marine Holdings Inc.

site_title: Lockmaker Assa Abloy searching for key man to succeed CEO
summary: Swedish lockmaker Assa Abloy is searching for a successor to CEO Johan Molin, who may step down next year to become Ericsson's chairman. Assa Abloy's shares fell 5% after the announcement, while Ericsson's shares rose 1.6%. Molin has led Assa Abloy to sharp sales growth and strong operating margins since becoming CEO in 2005. The move adds to speculation about Molin's potential role at Ericsson, which has been struggling with declining profitability.

site_title: US: Stocks end at fresh record peaks; Nasdaq +0.8%
summary: US stocks surged to fresh records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.5% to 22,775.39, the S&P 500 rising 0.6% to 2,552.07, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 0.8% to 6,585.36. The market's confidence in the US corporate earnings outlook and the prospects of President Trump's tax cut plan drove the gains. The latest records followed benign US data, including a shrinking trade deficit and lower jobless claims. Analysts expect the market to remain bullish, with some attributing the recent strength to the potential signing of a tax plan or stimulus.

site_title: Oil rises 2%, boosted by potential Opec deal
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, boosted by potential OPEC deal to limit production through 2018. Russian President Vladimir Putin said the deal could be extended to the end of 2018, while Saudi Arabia's King Salman visited Moscow. US crude rose 1.6% to $50.79 a barrel, while Brent futures settled at $57 a barrel. The deal could lead to renewed US sanctions against Iran, potentially limiting Iranian oil sales.

site_title: Mattel scraps plan for digital assistant for kids
summary: Mattel has scrapped its plan for a digital assistant for kids, Aristotle, following complaints from privacy groups and lawmakers. The device was set to be a kid-friendly alternative to Amazon's Alexa and Google Home, but concerns were raised about its potential to undermine privacy and expose children to marketers, hackers, and other threats. US Senator Ed Markey and Representative Joe Barton had also warned of privacy issues with the device. Mattel's new CTO cited the device not aligning with the company's technology strategy, leading to its cancellation.

site_title: China Taisan responds to SGX queries on its assets valuation, valuers certification
summary: China Taisan Technology Group Holdings has responded to Singapore Exchange (SGX) queries regarding the valuation of its assets and the certification of its valuers. The company's machineries are valued at 154.1 million yuan (S$31.65 million) in 2016, down from 316.4 million yuan in 2015. The firm's valuation report will be made available for inspection by shareholders. China Taisan clarified that its valuers are certified by the China Assets Appraisal Board and the Ministry of Finance PRC, but not the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC).

site_title: DMX sues ex-auditor Deloitte over accounting irregularities
summary: DMX Technologies is suing former auditor Deloitte & Touche LLP in the High Court over accounting irregularities discovered in 2015. DMX claims professional negligence, alleging Deloitte issued clean opinions from 2001 to 2013 despite failing to obtain necessary confirmation from suppliers and end users. This led to the dismissal of several executives and legal proceedings. DMX's stock has been suspended since March 2015, when it changed auditors from Deloitte to PwC.

site_title: US gun lobby agrees to target 'bump stocks' after Las Vegas massacre
summary: The US gun lobby, the National Rifle Association, has agreed to restrict "bump stocks" after the Las Vegas massacre, where a gunman used the devices to fire hundreds of rounds per minute. Bump stocks allow semiautomatic rifles to operate as if they were fully automatic machine guns, which are outlawed in the US. The NRA said bump stocks "should be subject to additional regulations." Senior Republicans, including House Speaker Paul Ryan, also signaled a willingness to deal with the sale of bump stocks. The move comes amid a long-standing US debate over regulation of gun ownership, with Democrats pushing for new legislation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 2.65 points to 1,761.74. The market saw 129 gainers for every 42 losers, with a total trading volume of 76.99 million lots worth RM23.8 million.

site_title: Hollywood mogul Weinstein apologises after sex harassment claims
summary: Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein issued an apology after the New York Times published a report accusing him of sexual harassment over several decades. He admitted to causing pain with his past behavior and apologized, while also announcing a leave of absence to address the issue. Weinstein denies many of the accusations as "patently false" and has reached private settlements with at least eight women, including celebrities such as Ashley Judd. The allegations date back nearly three decades and include claims of inappropriate behavior, including a massage request from Weinstein while naked.

site_title: Brunei sultan marks golden jubilee in style
summary: Brunei's Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah marked his 50-year reign with a lavish ceremony and procession, attended by tens of thousands of well-wishers. The 71-year-old monarch has ruled the oil-rich nation since 1967, despite facing controversies such as the introduction of strict Islamic laws and a high-profile feud with his brother. Analysts warn of economic challenges as oil prices fall and reserves dwindle, but the sultan's government provides subsidies for citizens' welfare, education, and health. The celebrations are part of a two-week event marking the golden jubilee of one of the world's richest men.

site_title: OCBC joins fixed-rate home loan battle
summary: OCBC Bank launched a two-year fixed-rate home loan at 1.65% per annum based on the OCBC Home Rate (OHR) benchmark, which is linked to the Sibor. The loan features a one-time free conversion, partial pre-payment of up to 50% of the original loan amount, and a reduced pre-payment penalty. This move joins other banks in offering two and three-year fixed-rate packages, with DBS Bank being the largest housing-loan provider. The move aims to attract customers seeking transparency and flexibility in their home loans.

site_title: US$ stalls; pound, A$ stay under pressure
summary: The US dollar settled below a seven-week high, as investors consolidated positions despite the economic outlook remaining under pressure. Sterling and the Australian dollar remain under pressure due to concerns about economic growth. Analysts say the US dollar's gains have been too meagre, leaving room for further increases.

site_title: Some Catalist stocks shine, but traps lurk
summary: The 10 largest Catalist stocks in Singapore have averaged a 35% return this year, outperforming blue chips. However, these stocks are more volatile and riskier. The rally is attributed to global market trends, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) also rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Basic digital skills for S'poreans in a variety of sectors for just S$50
summary: Singapore has launched a two-day training program, SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace, to teach basic digital skills to 100,000 Singaporeans over the next three years for S$50. The initiative aims to prepare citizens for the future economy. Minister for Education Ong Ye Kung launched the program, which will benefit all Singaporeans and permanent residents.

site_title: BMW, Mercedes relying on volume to confront Tesla
summary: BMW and Mercedes are shifting their strategy to mass-produce electric cars based on conventional vehicles, defying skeptics who believe they need more radical designs to compete with Tesla. The German luxury carmakers plan to produce electric variants of existing models, using the same production lines as their petrol-powered counterparts, to bring economies of scale and reduce costs. This approach aims to make electric cars more competitive, with battery prices expected to continue falling, and could potentially help the companies stay ahead of Tesla's volume assault on the premium car market.

site_title: An unsettling and original Malaysian family drama
summary: Malaysian filmmaker Saw Teong Hin's semi-autobiographical drama "You Mean the World to Me" showcases originality and creativity in the family drama genre, reminiscent of Wes Anderson's work. The film explores themes and emotions with a unique perspective, setting it apart from common clichés found in the genre.

site_title: HDB resale price fall not seen derailing recovery
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore slipped 0.3% in September from August, reversing a 0.2% uptick in August, according to SRX Property flash estimates. Resale transaction volumes declined 14% in September from August, but market watchers believe the market remains on track for stabilization. Experts attribute the decline to buyers holding off purchases before the Hungry Ghost Festival and diversion of demand to the re-offer of Balance Flats Exercise in August. Despite a 0.7% quarterly decline in HDB resale prices, they expect prices to rise moderately by up to 3% next year.

site_title: Keppel unit bags FPSO conversion contract from SBM Offshore
summary: Keppel Corporation's shipyard unit secured a contract with SBM Offshore NV to convert a very large crude carrier into a floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessel. The estimated value of the deal is between S$100 million and S$150 million. This contract adds to Keppel's year-to-date contract wins, valued at S$1 billion.

site_title: Downloads Down Under slower than even Kenya
summary: Australia's A$49 billion broadband network, intended to drive a digital revolution, has been plagued by cost overruns and construction delays. The project, considered the nation's biggest infrastructure investment, has turned into a political football. The botched project risks becoming a symbol of government mismanagement. Despite its massive investment, Australia's broadband network is now slower than even Kenya's, according to recent reports.

site_title: Second-liner property stocks now in play
summary: Several small- and mid-cap property stocks, such as Oxley Holdings, Tuan Sing, and Wing Tai Holdings, have surged to multi-year highs following the release of URA figures indicating a market recovery. These smaller developers have outperformed larger peers, with Oxley gaining 14.7% and Tuan Sing rising 8%. The rally contrasts with the modest price movements of bigger property companies, which have mostly improved by 0-2%.

site_title: UK energy suppliers hit by May's price-cap plan
summary: The UK government has implemented a plan to cap prices of standard variable tariffs (SVT) for household energy suppliers, which is expected to save customers hundreds of millions of pounds. The cap will be imposed on SVT rates for gas and electricity, but details are scarce and doubts remain about its implementation. Prime Minister Theresa May announced the plan, but its impact and effectiveness are yet to be determined.

site_title: Modi must 'take blame' for India's jobs crisis in looming polls
summary: Former Indian finance minister Yashwant Sinha criticizes Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government for its handling of the economy, citing a slowdown in growth, hurt job creation, and a poorly planned national sales tax. Sinha says Modi will "have to take the entire blame" himself as voters become increasingly angry about the lack of job growth. The criticism comes as India's economy faces a four-year low growth estimate and a widening current account deficit. Sinha's comments are seen as a significant challenge to Modi's administration ahead of upcoming state and federal polls.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi is running out of time to turn around India's US$2.3 trillion economy before impending elections, leaving the party reliant on "good marketing" to win over voters, a former Indian finance minister and member of the ruling party said.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: City Developments Ltd acquired Amber Park for S$907 million or S$1,515 per square foot, marking a new record for the Amber Road precinct. This deal is expected to pave the way for more en bloc deals in the area and may signify CDL's renewed focus on Singapore. The acquisition translates to a profit before tax margin of 5-10% on a selling price of S$2,100-2,200 per square foot.

site_title: Russia, Saudi Arabia cement new friendship with king's visit
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin hosted Saudi Arabia's King Salman for talks at the Kremlin, cementing a new friendship that could impact world oil prices and Middle East conflicts. The two countries agreed on joint investment deals worth billions, despite no breakthrough on Syria's civil war. They also signed a memorandum of understanding on the purchase of S-400 air defense systems. The visit marked a significant step in strengthening ties between Russia and Saudi Arabia, with both leaders expressing desire for mutually beneficial partnerships and a positive impact on regional and global stability.

site_title: Brunei sultan marks golden jubilee in style
summary: Brunei's Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah marked his 50-year reign in style with a lavish ceremony and a chariot procession through the streets, attended by tens of thousands of well-wishers. The event took place at his golden-domed palace, where the sultan held a tradition-filled ceremony. This milestone marks the longest-reigning monarch in the world, surpassing King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand.

site_title: Excelsior sale flop a 'reality check'
summary: Hong Kong property developer Irene Lee, chair of Hysan Development, describes the scrapped sale of The Excelsior hotel as a "reality check" in the city's heated property market. Lee stated that her firm did not bid on the hotel, which was auctioned in 1841, but refused to confirm local media reports. The sale flop is seen as a sign for developers to be sensible in their investment decisions amid rising prices and intense competition.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows on strong exports
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed by 2.7% to $42.4 billion in August, the smallest since September 2016, driven by a two-and-a-half-year high in exports. This tempered expectations of a sharp slowdown in third-quarter GDP growth due to storms. The decline in the trade deficit is seen as a positive sign for the US economy.

site_title: Aussie miner Alliance Mineral placing A$19.6m of shares to HK-listed Burwill
summary: Australian mining firm Alliance Mineral Assets Limited is placing A$19.575 million of shares to Hong Kong-listed Burwill Commodity amid uncertainty about its ability to operate as a going concern if it cannot raise more funds. The company incurred a loss of US$4.8 million for the past financial year and experienced net cash outflows from operating activities of US$1.91 million. Its auditor, Ernst & Young, has raised concerns about the firm's financial stability.

site_title: Cairnhill Mansions owners gunning for S$362m
summary: The owners of Cairnhill Mansions in Singapore's prime district 9 are selling the freehold development for S$362 million. Over 80% of owners have signed a collective sale agreement, with the developer required to sell units at above S$3,000 psf. This price point is achievable, according to observers, as the market is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark in the upcoming Q3 condo launches.

site_title: S'pore's hotel market draws investors
summary: Potential buyers in Singapore's hotel market are scouting for properties ahead of an anticipated rise in visitor arrivals. The pipeline of hotel rooms is expected to narrow after this year, according to consultants. With no major hotel transactions since 2015, investment sentiment is picking up, driven by the anticipated increase in visitor arrivals and tighter supply. Foreigners are leading the investment wave, indicating a benign supply outlook for the sector.

site_title: May wins support - driven by sympathy
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party conference speech went wrong, with her struggling to deliver her closing speech due to a cough. Despite sympathy from activists, her performance was seen as a lack of authority and reassertion of her leadership. The party lacks fresh talent, with likely successors faltering, including Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Brexit Secretary David Davis. This has raised concerns about her ability to lead the country through Brexit negotiations and has sparked speculation about a potential leadership challenge.

site_title: Catalan stand-off touches separatist hearts beyond Spain
summary: The Catalan stand-off between Madrid and separatist supporters has sparked global criticism, with politicians from regions with their own separatist movements calling for a peaceful resolution. Despite Spain ruling out talks until Catalonia acts within the law, Catalan leaders claim the result shows its people want to leave Spain and will push ahead with secession. The European Union is urged to intervene, with some politicians labeling the EU "hypocrites" for ignoring the crisis. The use of force by Spanish police has injured hundreds, with many questioning the constitutionality of the crackdown.

site_title: Kingsford Huray bags Normanton Park for S$830.1m
summary: Kingsford Huray Development has acquired the Normanton Park collective sale site in Singapore for S$830.1 million, the highest price achieved for a 99-year leasehold site this year. The site has a balance lease term of 59 years and is located near Science Park and Kent Ridge Park. The development is expected to have over 1,200 residential units, with an average selling price of around S$1,785 psf. The sale price exceeds the reserve price of S$800 million set in the collective sale agreement.

site_title: Marcos' son says he's confident of becoming Philippine VP
summary: Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr., son of late Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos, expressed confidence in ousting the current vice-president in a legal challenge, potentially placing him a heartbeat away from the presidency. He also confirmed talks with President Rodrigo Duterte to end the government's hunt for billions of dollars in national assets allegedly stolen by his parents. This development comes as Marcos Jr. seeks to clear his family's name and restore their wealth.

site_title: Are things improving at YuuZoo or is it more of the same with no real change?
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has faced continued scrutiny from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding its disclosures and corporate governance practices. Despite appointing two new independent directors from Finland, which is ranked as the most transparent country in the world, serious questions remain. The company's responses to SGX queries have raised more questions than answers, including discrepancies in its financial statements and unclear information about its business operations, including the ownership and management structure of its joint ventures. The SGX has asked for a review of YuuZoo's disclosures and terms of reference, further highlighting concerns about the company's transparency and accountability.

site_title: Carlos Ghosn's hand-picked successor faces first major crisis with Nissan recall
summary: Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa faces his first major crisis just six months into his tenure as CEO, following a shocking recall of 1.2 million vehicles in Japan due to un-certified inspectors approving vehicle quality. The recall, costing 25 billion yen (S$303 million), covers all models produced in Nissan factories in Japan for local sale. This lapse has been described as "shocking" by Saikawa, who has been tasked with saving Nissan, a legacy of the turnaround work done by his predecessor Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: Restaurants on diet after years of fattening up US job gains
summary: US restaurants, which have added 2.3 million jobs since 2009, are experiencing a slowdown in hiring due to competition, overbuilding, and automation. Major chains like McDonald's and Subway have cut back on new-store openings and closed locations, while supermarkets are pushing prepared foods and meal kits are becoming more affordable. Restaurants face increasing labor costs and a tight job market, with some experts warning that the industry's growth is "punching above its weight" and that the best times for restaurant employment have passed.

images.alt_text: McDonald's and Wendy's plan to install hundreds of digital ordering kiosks by year-end to boost sales as labour costs rise.
McDonald's and Wendy's plan to install hundreds of digital ordering kiosks by year-end to boost sales as labour costs rise.

site_title: German industry body warns its companies of 'very hard Brexit'
summary: Germany's BDI industry federation warns its companies of a "very hard Brexit," citing infighting in London over Britain's EU exit strategy. BDI chief Joachim Lang advises German firms to prepare for the worst-case scenario, as Britain's governing party is at odds with itself. This could lead to significant legal, economic, and business problems. Germany exports 116 billion euros to Britain and employs 400,000 people there, making the impact significant. Brexit talks have stalled, with EU negotiator Michel Barnier saying no sufficient progress has been made.

site_title: Emas to resume quarterly reporting from November
summary: EMAS Offshore, a Singapore-based oil and gas company, plans to resume regular financial reporting in November, a key step to remain listed and potentially resume trading. The company, backed by white knight investors, aims to report quarterly financial reports on the Oslo Bors and Singapore Exchange. This move comes after Emas agreed to restructure its debt under a scheme of arrangement, with the company expecting to publish its audited annual report for 2016 by December 8. The move aims to resolve financial difficulties and enable the company to remain listed on the Oslo Stock Exchange and Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Blade runner sequel set to be a classic
summary: Blade Runner 2049, a sequel to Ridley Scott's 1982 classic, is set to be a sci-fi classic 30 years in the making. The film, directed by Denis Villeneuve, explores the existential question of whether machines can have a soul, amidst a dystopian post-apocalyptic Los Angeles. Starring Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford, the movie follows a replicant hunter as he uncovers a mystery that could "break the world." With stunning visuals, a multi-layered storyline, and impeccable casting, Blade Runner 2049 stands as a worthy companion piece to its predecessor.

site_title: PM Lee meets Singapore community in Brunei
summary: PM Lee meets with the Singapore community in Brunei as part of the country's golden jubilee celebrations of Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah's ascension to the throne. A large crowd of 60,000 gathered to witness the festivities, with some attendees hoping to catch a glimpse of the sultan. Lee, who is on a scholarship in Brunei, expressed admiration for the sultan's work in transforming the nation. The event is part of Brunei's celebrations marking 50 years of Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah's rule.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee met about 250 Singaporeans at the Royal Brunei Polo and Riding Club, where they tucked into rojak and chicken satay.

site_title: Google launches new phones, speakers in hardware push
summary: Google unveiled its second-generation Pixel smartphone, along with new voice-enabled home speakers, Pixelbook laptop, wireless earbuds, and a small camera, showcasing its developed operating systems and services. The Pixel 2 smartphone starts at $649 and will be available on October 19. The Pixelbook laptop, priced at $999, will support Google Assistant and is set to be available in stores from October 31. The company aims to re-imagine hardware from the inside out, focusing on core ad sales business and competing with Apple's iPhone.

site_title: Nice place for satisfying tempura craving
summary: Mizuki, a Japanese restaurant located on the fifth floor of Ngee Ann City, offers high-quality tempura and sushi. Despite its unassuming location, the restaurant boasts elegant wooden decor and serves expertly prepared dishes, including a whole oyster battered to perfection. While not the cheapest option, Mizuki ranks alongside other top contenders, such as Tenshin and Ippoh, in terms of quality and price. The reviewer praises the chef's 12-year experience in Hong Kong and the restaurant's commitment to traditional Japanese cooking methods, making it a great alternative for those with Tokyo withdrawal symptoms. Rating: 7/10.

site_title: Model Factory to help SMEs test production line solutions
summary: A new model factory has been launched in Singapore to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) test production line solutions. The 6,500 sq ft facility, called Model Factory@SIMTech, offers hands-on training and live demonstrations of advanced manufacturing technologies, including the Manufacturing Control Tower (MCT) technologies. The facility aims to speed up technology adoption by SMEs and is part of A*STAR's efforts to support Singapore's manufacturing sector, which contributed 20% to the country's GDP in 2016. The launch was attended by Senior Minister Koh Poh Koon and marked the signing of two memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with German and Singaporean associations.

site_title: Connecting past and present in Sarkasi's art
summary: The NUS Museum's exhibition, Always Moving: The Batik Art of Sarkasi Said, challenges the traditional understanding of past and present by highlighting the interconnectedness of historical events. The exhibit showcases the batik art of Sarkasi Said, which blends traditional and modern techniques, blurring the lines between past and present. This exhibition aims to break the dichotomy between then and now, presenting a more fluid and dynamic understanding of history.

site_title: Singapore, Thailand weigh e-payment link
summary: Singapore and Thailand are discussing a link between their national digital payment systems, PayNow and PromptPay, to curb cash use. This regional alliance would connect South-east Asia's first national digital-payment platforms. The talks are at a preliminary stage, with Bank of Thailand director Naphongthawat Phothikit stating that efforts aim to reduce cash transactions.

site_title: Writing to exorcise his personal demons
summary: Malaysian filmmaker Saw Teong Hin has released his semi-autobiographical film "You Mean the World to Me," which tells the story of his painful past and his struggle to exorcise his personal demons. The film, which was initially staged as a play in 2014, was adapted into a movie with the help of cinematographer Christopher Doyle, who was convinced by the film's idyllic script and charming setting. The film's success has struck a chord with Malaysian movie-goers, becoming the country's third highest-grossing movie of 2017. Saw dedicated the film to his late mother, saying it was written out of love and a desire to understand his past.

site_title: Home is where the heartbreak is
summary: The musical "Fun Home" by Pangdemonium tells the story of Alison Bechdel's coming-of-age as the daughter of a closeted gay man, Bruce, and his unhappily married wife, Helen. The production, directed by Tracie Pang, features strong cast performances and impressive set design, but is also unrelentingly sad, leaving the audience with unanswered questions about the characters' experiences. The musical, based on Alison Bechdel's graphic memoir, explores themes of emotional wounds, family secrets, and the struggles of growing up in a dysfunctional household.

site_title: Kazuo Ishiguro: Social worker turned Nobel Prize winner
summary: Kazuo Ishiguro, a 62-year-old British writer of Japanese origin, was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. A prolific writer since the early 1980s, Ishiguro is known for novels like "The Remains of the Day," which won the Booker Prize in 1989 and was adapted into a successful film starring Anthony Hopkins. Despite his success, Ishiguro remains reclusive. He is one of the UK's most successful yet lesser-known novelists, with works translated into dozens of languages.

site_title: Boeing reports 7.4% rise in Q3 plane deliveries
summary: Boeing reported a 7.4% increase in Q3 plane deliveries, with 202 jetliners delivered in the third quarter, up from 188 in the same period last year. The company delivered 145 single-aisle 737s and 35 787 Dreamliners.

site_title: Addvalue, partner to offer new chat app tapping market of fishing vessels
summary: Addvalue Technologies has partnered with a company to offer a maritime product and data solutions bundle for deep-sea fishing vessels. A two-month market trial is set to begin in November, targeting at least 500 fishing vessels. The commercial rollout will follow the successful trial.

site_title: Vegas attack's impact on tourism temporary; full recovery within months
summary: A mass shooting in Las Vegas on October 1, 2017, killed 58 people, leaving the city's tourism industry temporarily impacted. Experts predict a full recovery within months, as the city's iconic Strip still had a heavy police presence. Tourism is vital to the city, with 43 million visitors annually, generating nearly $60 billion in economic activity. However, the attack may deter potential travelers concerned about safety, and hotels will need to implement new security protocols. Despite this, conferences and events are expected to continue unaffected.

site_title: Australian retailers hit by worst sales decline in 4 years
summary: Australian retailers experienced their worst sales decline in 4 years, with a 0.6% drop in August, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This decline was driven by debt-laden consumers cutting back on spending, particularly in food, furniture, and clothing. The slump in sales also casts a shadow on the Reserve Bank of Australia's forecast for the economy to accelerate at 3% over the next two years. The data is a surprise, with online retail turnover showing a 6.3% increase in August, and a trade surplus widening to $989 million.

site_title: Goldman, Carnegie outpace rival banks in Nordic IPO boom
summary: Goldman Sachs and Carnegie Investment Bank outpaced rival banks in the Nordic IPO boom, with Carnegie leading in advising on Nordic IPOs and Goldman ranking second among non-Nordic banks. The region saw a record number of IPOs in 2017, with 88 listings through September, but the value of those listings was down about 20% due to larger deals skewing the comparison. The market favors smaller companies and growth, with private equity benefiting from the conditions.

site_title: A day of living their dream jobs
summary: More than 700 underprivileged children in Singapore spent a day living their dream jobs at KidZania Singapore as part of the annual Children's Day celebration. The event, organized by Children for Children, allowed kids to earn KidZos and experience various professions. This year's event also included children with special needs for the first time. The program was made possible by sponsors and aims to promote inclusivity and provide a fun, educational experience for underprivileged children.

site_title: Mature influencers and manic intelligence in BT Weekend
summary: A recent article highlights mature influencers who have gained popularity on Instagram, defying the traditional notion that influencers must be in their teens or 20s. The article also touches on various topics such as restaurants paying equal attention to food and drink, the growing trend of artificial intelligence learning prejudice, and reviews of books, music, and cars. The article showcases the diversity of content in the magazine, catering to a wide range of interests.

site_title: Jazzing up the scene with his soulful baritone
summary: Gregory Porter, a 45-year-old jazz singer, has gained widespread recognition for his soulful baritone voice. His major label debut "Liquid Spirit" and follow-up "Take Me to the Alley" both won Best Jazz Vocal Grammys. Porter's genre-bending sound, which combines pop with jazz, was showcased in his recent headline show in Singapore, where he performed a mix of original tracks and covers. Critics praise Porter's ability to create a comforting and soothing atmosphere with his music, making him a standout in the jazz scene.

site_title: California closes the door on Wells Fargo's closed-door tack
summary: California has passed a law blocking Wells Fargo's use of closed-door arbitration to keep customer complaints under wraps, following the bank's fake-accounts scandal. The law prohibits financial firms from forcing customers into arbitration when employees used clients' information to commit fraud. Wells Fargo has been fined $185 million over its practice of opening unauthorized accounts, and the company has also faced other consumer disputes. The law aims to increase transparency and hold firms accountable, as regulators and lawmakers have criticized the bank's use of mandatory arbitration.

site_title: Virtuous cycle in broking research needed to avoid future Cromwells
summary: The withdrawal of Cromwell Property Group's IPO in Singapore highlights the need for a virtuous cycle in broking research to evaluate complex financial instruments. Despite the growth of non-standard financial products, brokers lack the necessary expertise to properly assess these instruments, leading to a lack of research support for many IPOs. The industry's focus on larger companies and reduced commissions have marginalized research departments, making it difficult for smaller firms to garner coverage. To address this issue, brokers must create a cycle where increased coverage stimulates investor interest, leading to more activity and higher revenues that prompt broader coverage.

site_title: Same old tune in US gun control debate
summary: The US gun control debate continues, with a mass shooting in Las Vegas prompting calls for stricter laws. Democrats advocate for universal background checks and banning certain types of weapons, while Republicans argue that such measures infringe on the Second Amendment. Despite evidence that reasonable gun control laws can make a difference, the debate remains stuck due to the political power of the National Rifle Association and the balance of power in Congress. The US has seen a pattern of mass shootings, with no clear solution in sight, as the country struggles to balance gun rights with public safety concerns.

site_title: Bison charging ahead through JVs with 2 Japanese companies
summary: Bison Consolidated, a Malaysian convenience store operator, has entered joint ventures with two Japanese companies, Gourmet Kineya Co Ltd and Ryoyupan, to produce ready-to-eat food and bakery products for its over 360 outlets. The partnerships aim to boost quality and customer loyalty, with Bison investing RM35.7 million (S$11.5 million) in the ventures. The company plans to add 70 new outlets annually, driven by positive same-store sales growth and strong earnings growth, with a focus on providing accessibility, quality, and convenience to customers.

site_title: What's keeping women out of the boardroom
summary: Despite government and corporate efforts to increase gender diversity, women remain underrepresented on company boards in Asia, particularly in the largest public companies. In 2017, women held just one in eight board seats, with many senior positions held by women failing to translate to board-level positions. This is partly due to outdated perceptions that women are not suited for male-dominated boards, with traditional corporate norms often resulting in a male-dominated board with a token female member.

site_title: Ghosts take up residence at the Vic
summary: The Victoria Theatre is set to host two classic plays, "Poop!" and "The Spirits Play", exploring themes of life, death, and war. "Poop!" tackles cancer and suicide with humor, whimsy, and puppetry, while "The Spirits Play" is a poetic and heart-wrenching work about war. The plays, written by Chong Tze Chien and Kuo Pao Kun, respectively, will be staged back-to-back as part of The Finger Players' season of contemporary classics, challenging audiences to confront the complexities of human existence.

images.alt_text: Directed by Oliver Chong, The Spirits Play looks at the horrendous effects of war through the eyes of five wandering spirits.
Chong Tze Chien's Poop! is a funny yet poignant play about illness and suicide.

site_title: US factory orders rise; core capital goods orders revised higher
summary: US factory orders rose 1.2% in August, exceeding economists' forecast of a 1% increase. Core capital goods orders, a measure of business spending, also rose 1.1% in August, revised higher from the initial 0.9% increase. Strong business spending on equipment is helping to support manufacturing, which accounts for 12% of the US economy. The data suggests that robust business spending could offset economic drag from Hurricanes Harvey and Irma.

site_title: GM unit more than doubles self-driving car test fleet in California
summary: General Motors' self-driving unit, Cruise Automation, has more than doubled its test fleet in California to 100 vehicles from 30-40 over the past three months. The company reported six minor crashes in September, all caused by other vehicles, and 13 collisions in 2017. Cruise is testing vehicles in San Francisco to develop software for navigating congested urban environments, with investors watching its progress closely, expecting potential deployment of robot taxis within the next year or two.

site_title: Kobe Bryant's sports drink enters octagon in UFC deal
summary: Kobe Bryant's sports drink brand BodyArmor has partnered with the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) in a major sponsorship deal. BodyArmor co-founder Mike Repole sees parallels between the drink and the sport, both facing entrenched industry incumbents. The partnership, valued at an undisclosed amount, will feature BodyArmor on the UFC website and social media channels, as well as in the octagon during fights. BodyArmor aims to increase brand visibility and appeal to consumers looking for a newer alternative to Gatorade and Powerade.

site_title: SIAEC struggles to recover from 6-year low despite buyback
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) conducted its largest share buyback exercise in less than a year, purchasing 419,300 shares for S$1.36 million at S$3.15 to S$3.35 each. The buyback, worth S$2.33 million, aims to stabilize the stock price, which has slumped to a six-year low of S$3.15. Despite this, analysts remain cautious due to the challenging outlook for the MRO sector, with most expecting a slow recovery. The buyback is part of SIAEC's July 2017 mandate to purchase up to 22.39 million shares.

site_title: World Cup 2018: Video-assisted referee could be delayed
summary: FIFA officials consider delaying the introduction of video assistant referees (VAR) for the 2018 World Cup, despite President Gianni Infantino's previous assurance. The trial period, which began in various countries, may be extended if the results are not satisfactory. The International Football Association Board (IFAB) plans to review the experiment's outcome and discuss the decision with FIFA later this year. The use of VAR in the 2018 World Cup will be decided solely by FIFA, pending approval by IFAB.

site_title: Rush for drilling rights in remote part of Canada
summary: Investors are rushing to secure drilling rights in a remote area of Canada's oil sands, known for producing crude at lower costs. The Clearwater shale and sandstone formation, 200km south-west of Fort McMurray, holds pockets of oil 600-700 meters below the ground, with crude selling for C$10 a barrel. Companies like Deltastream Energy Corp and Cenovus Energy Inc are leading the charge, with drilling rights sold for record prices. The area's development is in its infancy, but results are promising, with wells producing up to 300 barrels a day, making the play economically viable at current oil prices.

site_title: In the world's most liveable cities, few can afford to buy a home
summary: Home ownership among young Australians has reached a record low, with only 45% of 25-34 year-olds owning their own home. The country's property boom, fueled by record low interest rates and a lack of supply, has driven up prices by over 140% in the past 15 years. This has led to a surge in household debt, with mortgages pushing the economy's 26 years of growth at risk. Experts warn that the issue will take at least two decades to fix, and that the government's failure to address it is heaping pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Rebounding banks help push STI up
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 25.19 points to 3,261.84 on Thursday, driven by a rebound in the three major banks - DBS, UOB, and OCBC - which collectively added 12 points to the index. The low turnover of 1.2 billion units worth S$957.3 million was largely due to the closure of Hong Kong for the Mid-Autumn Festival. The rebound was attributed to expectations of a business-friendly budget proposed by the Trump administration and anticipation of a December US interest rate hike, which would widen bank margins.

site_title: Wells Fargo board can't duck investor claims over fake accounts
summary: A US federal judge ruled that Wells Fargo executives must defend a lawsuit alleging they profited from creating millions of fake customer accounts. The lawsuit claims the executives "repeatedly and brazenly" failed to serve the bank's best interests. The judge dismissed insider-trading claims against CEO Tim Sloan, former CEO John Stumpf, and former head of community banking Carrie Tolstedt. The ruling allows shareholders to proceed with the lawsuit, which accuses top executives of steering the bank into the worst scandal in its modern history.

site_title: Trump could push Justice Department into Puerto Rico debt fight
summary: President Trump could push the Justice Department to defend Puerto Rico's 2016 federal law aimed at slashing the island's debt and pension obligations, potentially inserting the federal government into a complex insolvency case. The judge overseeing the case has set a Nov 6 deadline for the Justice Department to decide whether to defend the law, known as Promesa, or leave the job to a federal oversight board. If the Justice Department becomes a party to the bankruptcy, Trump could directly influence the final restructuring plan, but this move would add complexity to the already difficult case.

site_title: Celebrating entrepreneurs who dare
summary: Singapore's Emerging Enterprise Award 2017 recognized the achievements of three top startups: Ace Water, Greenology, and Secretlab. The companies were chosen for their innovative spirit, bold vision, and resilience, as well as their consistent and sustainable growth. They won the top prize, Best Innovation Award, and the Most Promising Startup Award. The awards were supported by various organizations, including Mastercard, Acorn Marketing, and INSEAD. This milestone edition celebrated 10 years of the award, with Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran in attendance as guest of honour.

site_title: StanChart is said to be probed on US$1.4b client transfers
summary: Standard Chartered is under investigation by regulators in Europe and Asia over the transfer of $1.4 billion in client assets from Guernsey to Singapore before new tax transparency rules were introduced. The bank's internal inquiry found that employees raised questions about the timing and source of the funds, but the transfers were approved by the financial crime compliance team. Regulators, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Guernsey's Financial Services Commission, are examining the bank's processes and whether staff breached its code of conduct. The investigation is part of a larger scrutiny of the bank, which has faced misconduct issues under CEO Bill Winters.

site_title: British author Kazuo Ishiguro wins Nobel Literature Prize
summary: British author Kazuo Ishiguro has won the 2017 Nobel Literature Prize for his novels of great emotional force, which have uncovered the abyss beneath our sense of connection with the world. Ishiguro, 62, is best known for his novel "The Remains of the Day" and has written eight books, including the critically-acclaimed dystopian work "Never Let Me Go." The award recognizes Ishiguro's exploration of themes such as memory, time, and self-delusion, and his unique perspective as a Japanese author who has experienced displacement and exile.

site_title: KPMG South Africa finds no evidence that errors are 'systemic'
summary: KPMG South Africa's CEO, Nhlamu Dlomu, told parliament that the company hasn't found evidence of systemic errors in its work for the Gupta family and tax authority, despite internal and external investigations. Eight senior executives quit, and the company will continue to address issues. KPMG South Africa withdrew a report on a rogue unit at the Revenue Service and offered to refund a 23 million-rand fee. The company faces probes by regulatory bodies and has lost business from several companies due to its involvement with the Gupta family.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq hit fresh record-highs
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite hit fresh record-highs on Thursday, driven by technology stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 3.81 points, while the S&P 500 gained 2.96 points and the Nasdaq added 22.84 points. The record-highs come despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Far East inks deal to buy S$22.5m property at Ubi Avenue 3
summary: Far East Group has signed a deal to purchase a property at Ubi Avenue 3 in Singapore for S$22.5 million. The 51,000 sqft property has a 60-year leasehold tenure and will be used to consolidate the group's operations, enhancing management oversight and operational efficiency. The acquisition will be funded by existing cash and bank borrowings.

site_title: Pound falls to 4 week low as May speech fuels Tory rebels
summary: The pound fell to a 4-week low due to speculation that UK Prime Minister Theresa May could face a leadership rebellion within her party following a disastrous speech. Sterling declined 0.9% to US$1.3134, with demand for dollar longs intensifying. Up to 30 Tory lawmakers are prepared to sign a letter calling for her resignation, but experts suggest this may be a short-term move.

site_title: United Food to buy 80% stakes in 3 animal feed-related companies for 120m yuan
summary: United Food Holdings has agreed to buy 80% stakes in three animal feed-related companies in China for 120 million yuan (S$24.5 million). The acquisition, funded by internal resources, aims to expand United Food's presence in China, gain expertise, and strengthen its foothold in the market. The three companies are Chengde Purun Shengwu Zhiyao Co, Hebei Xingrun Shengwu Keji Gufen Co, and Benchmark Ltd, which develop and make animal feed products with traditional Chinese medicine extracts and other additives.

site_title: Wanting in a way, yet strangely engrossing
summary: Mark Felt, a 30-year veteran of the FBI, was a key figure in bringing down President Richard Nixon's presidency due to his involvement in the Watergate scandal. Felt, who was nicknamed "Deep Throat," secretly fed classified information to reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, leading to their Pulitzer Prize-winning coverage. The 2017 film "Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House" tells Felt's story, exploring his moral crisis and the events that led to Nixon's downfall.
