The film highlights contemporary parallels to the Trump administration's actions, making it an engrossing watch despite some flaws.

site_title: Late British PM Heath suspected of abusing five boys
summary: Former British Prime Minister Edward Heath was suspected of abusing five boys, with seven allegations of rape and indecent assault, if he were still alive. The allegations, which spanned between 1961 and 1992, were investigated by Wiltshire police after a two-year probe, which found no corroborative evidence but raised significant suspicions. Heath, who died in 2005, would have been interviewed under caution over the allegations, which have tarnished his reputation. The investigation was part of a broader probe into historical child sex abuse, with no inference of guilt made.

site_title: Bombardier eyes Asian markets amid US trade spat with Boeing
summary: Bombardier is focusing on expanding into Asia, particularly India, to boost sales of its Q400 and CSeries narrow-body jets amid a US trade spat with Boeing. The company sees India's regional connectivity scheme as a growth engine, with a deal to sell 50 Q400 planes to SpiceJet valued at $1.7 billion. Bombardier trails ATR in turboprops and is locked in a trade dispute with Boeing, which alleges the CSeries received launch aid. Despite the spat, Bombardier's customers are focused on the economics of the jet, which boasts fuel efficiency.

images.alt_text: Bombardier is betting on fast-growing markets like India to boost sales of its Q400 and CSeries narrow-body jets, a senior executive said on Thursday, at a time when the Canadian planemaker faces a trade row over sales to the United States.

site_title: ST Telemedia data centre unit acquires stake in UK's Virtus
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (GDC) has acquired Virtus Data Centres, a UK-based data centre provider, after buying Brockton Capital's entire stake. The acquisition, price undisclosed, further expands ST Telemedia GDC's network of over 50 data centres in key economic hubs. Virtus operates a co-location platform with four facilities and plans for two new ones near Stockley Park. The acquisition aims to expand ST Telemedia GDC's presence in the UK and European markets, supporting customers' growth plans and cementing its footprint in the region.

site_title: ECB focused on pace versus duration as caution rules QE plan
summary: European Central Bank policy makers are debating the pace versus duration of monthly asset purchases under quantitative easing, with a focus on balancing size and duration to maintain sufficient flexibility and avoid market disruption. Despite inflation lagging behind the ECB's goal, officials agree substantial support is needed to ensure inflation returns to target. The decision on asset purchases will be made on October 26, with differing preferences among officials on the way forward. The euro has strengthened 10% against the dollar this year, adding to concerns about inflation.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank policy makers kicked off their debate about next year's monetary stimulus by focusing on how to balance the size and duration of monthly asset purchases.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows on strong exports
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to $42.4 billion in August, the smallest since September 2016, due to strong exports. Exports rose 0.4% to $195.3 billion, with increases in consumer and capital goods, while fuel exports fell. The decline in imports, at 0.1%, also contributed to the narrowing trade gap. The trade deficit's contribution to GDP growth is expected to be positive, potentially offsetting the economic impact of hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria.

site_title: Yongnam to place S$12.1 million of shares at S$0.255 apiece for working capital
summary: Yongnam Holdings is issuing 47.5 million shares at S$0.255 apiece, raising S$12.1 million for working capital. The placement price is 6% below Thursday's closing price. If completed on Dec 31, 2016, the net loss per share would have narrowed to 7.13 cents, and the net tangible asset per share would have been diluted to 59.49 cents. CIMB Securities is the placement agent, and the net proceeds will be used for working capital.

site_title: Australia closing in on Qatar as world's top LNG exporter
summary: Australia is poised to surpass Qatar as the world's top liquefied natural gas (LNG) exporter by mid-2018, with exports forecast to rise 16% to 74 million tonnes by 2019. New LNG projects, including Chevron's Wheatstone and Royal Dutch Shell's Prelude, will add to Australia's export capacity, taking it to around 88 million tonnes. This will contribute to a 2% increase in Australia's overall resource and energy export earnings to a record A$211 billion in 2018.

site_title: Croesus sets last day of trading for Oct 10
summary: Croesus Retail Trust, a Japanese mall real estate investment trust, will be suspended from trading on October 11 and expected to be delisted on October 27, following a court's sanction of its privatization scheme. The trust's manager, Croesus, announced the last day of trading on October 10.

site_title: Peter Lim files police report against scammers
summary: Singaporean billionaire investor Peter Lim has filed police reports against online scams involving false and misleading accounts using his name and images. Scammers have set up fake Facebook accounts and claimed to endorse cryptocurrency investments, leading to at least two victims being scammed. Lim's firm Kestrel Capital has warned the public against falling for the scams, stating that Lim does not have a Facebook account and has not endorsed any cryptocurrency investments. The scams are the latest in a series of reports filed by Lim against online scams involving his name and images.

site_title: Fed's Powell says more US regulation not always the answer
summary: Fed Governor Jerome Powell stated that more US regulation is not always the best solution to problems in financial markets, emphasizing the need for a balanced approach. He suggested that industry groups can help fill regulatory gaps, and that regulations should consider market impact. Powell's comments may outline his potential approach to running the US central bank, which could influence monetary policy decisions. The comments come as President Trump considers replacing Fed Chair Janet Yellen, with Powell being a contender for the position.

site_title: Boeing-backed, electric-hybrid airliner set to hit market in 2022
summary: A Seattle-area startup backed by Boeing and JetBlue plans to launch a small, hybrid-electric airliner by 2022, capable of reducing travel time and cost for trips under 1,600 km. The aircraft, Zunum Aero, will seat up to 12 passengers and be powered by electric motors with a range of 700 miles. A larger plane with up to 50 passengers will follow in the next decade. The planes aim to fly on battery power, with a potential future of remote piloting, and are designed to reduce flying costs by 8 US cents per seat-mile, compared to traditional small jets.

site_title: London mayor welcomes Uber boss' humility after licence loss
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan welcomed Uber's CEO Dara Khosrowshahi's humility after meeting with the city's transport regulator to overturn a decision stripping Uber of its operating licence. The licence was revoked due to Uber's approach to reporting serious crimes and background checks on drivers. Khan praised Khosrowshahi's apology, saying it shows the firm is willing to address issues. This humility has given Khan confidence that Uber will address the concerns raised by the regulator, potentially leading to a renewed licence.

site_title: ECB's Nowotny expects asset purchases to slow at start of next year
summary: European Central Bank policymaker Ewald Nowotny expects the asset purchases to slow down gently at the start of next year, likely transitioning to a cautious deceleration. The current 2.3 trillion euro bond purchase programme is set to end in December, and the ECB may decide to extend it with smaller monthly purchases or retain bigger purchases for a shorter period. Nowotny, who is in agreement with hawk Jens Weidmann, stated his expectation in remarks published weeks before the ECB's meeting on October 26.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.75 points to 1,759.09. The market saw a volume of 3.15 billion lots worth RM2.06 billion, with 487 gainers and 360 losers.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher as banks push STI up 25 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 25.19 points to 3,261.84 on October 5, 2017, driven by a rebound in the three banks. Despite a low turnover and mixed European markets, the index recovered from a two-day correction. The gains came despite US Dow futures falling and a closure in Hong Kong due to the Mid-Autumn Festival.

site_title: VX found on clothes of women accused of Kim Jong Nam murder: chemist
summary: Traces of the nerve agent VX, used to murder Kim Jong Nam, were found on the clothes of two women, Siti Aisyah and Doan Thi Huong, accused of assassinating the half-brother of North Korea's leader. Chemist Raja Subramaniam testified that he found VX on Aisyah's clothes and Huong's t-shirt, with a degraded form also found on a fingernail clipping. The women, who pleaded not guilty, claim they were duped into believing they were taking part in a prank. A post-mortem report confirmed Kim's death was caused by VX, which is listed as a weapon of mass destruction.

site_title: Germany's 'James Bond' found guilty of tax evasion
summary: Germany's former top spy, Werner Mauss, was convicted of tax evasion and sentenced to a two-year suspended term. Mauss, dubbed the "German James Bond," was found guilty of stashing undeclared assets in offshore accounts and shortchanging the state in millions of euros between 2002 and 2011. He was ordered to donate 200,000 euros to charity and claimed the accounts were used to channel funds for hostage operations, but was unable to mount a proper defense due to confidentiality agreements.

site_title: World food prices rise 0.8% in September: UN FAO
summary: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) reported that world food prices rose 0.8% in September, driven by higher valuations in vegetable oil and dairy sectors. The FAO's food price index averaged 178.4 points in September, up from August. Global cereals output is forecast to reach 2.612 billion tonnes, slightly above last year's record harvest, and global wheat production is forecast to reach 750.1 million tonnes.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics CEO gives S$435,000 of own shares to family charity
summary: Micro-Mechanics CEO Chris Borch donated approximately S$435,000 worth of his own shares, representing 0.18% of the company, to family charity The Borch Foundation. This donation increased Mr. Borch's interest in the company to 52.387%. The Borch Foundation was established in 2007 to support non-profit organizations focusing on education, community development, and conservation.

site_title: Nissan's premium brand Infiniti global sales up 8% in Sept
summary: Infiniti, Nissan's premium brand, reported a 8% increase in global sales for September, reaching 21,523 vehicles, up from the same period last year. This growth is attributed to strong sales of SUVs and the redesigned Q50 sedan, which was launched in July. The brand's worldwide sales for the first nine months of this year rose 11% to 182,884 vehicles. Two additional redesigned SUV models are planned for launch in the next three to four months.

site_title: Kingsford awarded Normanton Park for S$830.1m or S$969 psf ppr
summary: Kingsford Huray Development has been awarded the Normanton Park collective sale site for S$830.1 million, or S$969 per square foot per plot ratio. The 660,999 sq ft site, zoned for residential use, has a balance lease term of 59 years. Owners will receive a gross sale price of approximately S$1.68 million to S$1.86 million upon a successful sale, subject to conditions. The new high-rise development could potentially have 1,290 homes, averaging 100 sq m gross floor area.

site_title: Wall Street moves to Frankfurt as Brexit doubts grow
summary: Major US banks, including Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and JP Morgan, are moving to Frankfurt, Germany, as Brexit uncertainty grows in London. The banks are expanding their operations in Frankfurt, with Goldman Sachs leasing 10,000 square meters of office space and Morgan Stanley signing a lease for a tower. The moves aim to bolster activities such as trading, investment banking, and asset management, with some banks planning to double their staff in Frankfurt. The relocation is driven by concerns about London's future as a financial hub and the need for banks to establish a foothold in a stable EU market.

site_title: MAS, ABS-led consortium announces breakthrough in enhanced-privacy blockchain prototypes
summary: A consortium led by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has developed new blockchain software prototypes to decentralize payment netting while preserving transactional privacy. Codenamed Project Ubin, the prototypes are the world's first three models for "decentralised interbank payment and settlements with liquidity savings mechanisms." This innovation aims to protect payment details from unauthorized parties, promoting wider adoption of distributed ledger technology-based settlement systems. The consortium plans to share its findings with central banks and financial institutions to encourage experimentation and innovation.

site_title: Ezion calls meeting for holders of its Series 9 notes
summary: Ezion Holdings, a liftboat operator, is convening an informal meeting on October 19 for holders of its S$120 million Series 009 notes. The meeting, facilitated by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), aims to provide securityholders with an update on developments related to the company's 3.65% committed funding backed notes due 2020. This comes after a similar meeting held last month and amid Ezion's broader refinancing efforts amidst being a cash-poor company.

site_title: Qatar capable of supporting banks amid boycott
summary: Qatar's central bank governor, Abdullah bin Saoud Al Thani, stated that the country is capable of supporting its banks due to its vast sovereign wealth fund and foreign currency reserves. Stress tests show the strength of Qatari banks in the face of the boycott by Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt. Qatar has spent heavily to support its banks and defend its currency peg to the US dollar, with assets in the sovereign wealth fund and foreign currency reserves serving as a buffer.

site_title: UK car sales set for first annual decline since 2011 after September slump
summary: UK car sales are expected to decline for the first time since 2011 due to a 9.3% drop in September registrations, totaling 426,170 vehicles. Demand for diesel and petrol cars fell 21.7% and 1.2%, respectively, while fleet and consumer sales declined 10.1% and 8.8%, respectively. The decline is attributed to factors such as increased vehicle excise duty, possible new levies on diesel cars, and Brexit uncertainty, causing reduced buyer confidence.

site_title: US 'deeply disturbed' by arrest of Istanbul consulate staffer
summary: The US is "deeply disturbed" by the arrest of a local staffer at its Istanbul consulate, charged with espionage and seeking to overthrow the Turkish government. The staffer was remanded in custody by an Istanbul court, sparking strained ties between the two countries. The US claims the allegations are "wholly without merit" and presses Turkey to release the staffer. This arrest follows Turkey's push for the extradition of Pennsylvania-based Fethullah Gulen, who denies any link to last year's failed coup.

site_title: Siemens exits lighting with 1.2b euros sale of Osram stake
summary: Siemens sold its remaining 17% stake in lighting manufacturer Osram Licht AG for approximately $1.92 billion, exiting the lighting industry after a century. The sale, completed on October 4, 2017, follows Siemens' withdrawal from other businesses, including phones, hearing aids, and ovens. Osram's value more than doubled since its initial public offering in 2013, and the company is shifting its focus to high-technology energy-saving light-emitting diodes. Proceeds from the sale will be used for general corporate purposes, and Osram shares fell 3.5% in response.

site_title: Soilbuild gets S$50m contract for Kallang factory project
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has secured a S$50 million contract for a seven-storey factory development at No 171 Kallang Way. The project is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2019. The award does not significantly impact the group's financial performance for the current year, with its order book standing at S$574.2 million as of June 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index closed flat on Thursday, capping gains that pushed shares to two-year highs. The Nikkei 225 edged up 0.01% to finish at 20,628.56, while the Topix index fell 0.12% to 1,682.49. Profit-taking after several days of gains limited the advance.

site_title: Macron's sharp tongue throws French Twitter into a frenzy
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron sparked controversy when he commented on workers protesting his economic policies, saying they should "get a job" at a nearby aluminum factory. Critics, including far-left and far-right lawmakers, accused him of being out of touch with the common man and having "class contempt" for France's lower-income workers. Macron's spokesman defended his comments, saying they were taken out of context and meant to emphasize the need for collective solutions to joblessness. The incident is not the first time Macron has sparked controversy with his language, following previous comments that critics deemed arrogant and dismissive.

site_title: Emas to resume regular financial reporting from November as restructuring progresses
summary: EMAS Offshore plans to resume regular financial reporting in November, a key step in its restructuring efforts. The company, which is trying to resolve its financial difficulties, will report unaudited results for the fiscal fourth quarter on Nov 30 and its audited annual report for FY16 on Dec 8. This comes after an agreement with potential investors to inject US$50 million into the company. Emas expects to remain listed on the Oslo Stock Exchange and Singapore Exchange, which will publish its financial reports on a quarterly basis.

site_title: SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace launched to prepare Singaporeans for digital economy
summary: Singapore launched the SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace, a two-day training program to equip citizens with basic digital skills. Led by SkillsFuture Singapore, the initiative covers areas like cybersecurity, data interpretation, and digital applications. The program aims to benefit 100,000 Singaporeans over three years and has already trained over 330 participants. The initiative was developed with support from labor unions, employers, and technology partners, and plans to expand to community centers and public libraries.

site_title: Saudi Aramco not discussing taking stake in Novatek's Arctic LNG project
summary: Saudi Aramco's CEO Amin Nasser stated that the company is discussing investment opportunities with Russian firms, but there are no current plans to take a stake in Novatek's Arctic LNG project. Nasser also denied talks on participating in Aramco's planned initial public offer of shares next year.

site_title: Australia dollar falters as weak retail data mutes rate hike chatter
summary: The Australian dollar fell to US$0.7824 after retail sales data showed a 0.6% drop in August, its second straight monthly decline. The Reserve Bank of Australia expects a 3% economic growth rate over the next two years, citing weak wage growth and squeezed household finances. The Australian dollar's decline is attributed to the weak retail sales data, which supports the RBA's view that interest rates won't be raised next year. The New Zealand dollar also edged down to a one-month low.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singapore's Cairnhill Mansions, a freehold development in prime district 9, will be launched for collective sale with an asking price of S$362 million. SIA Engineering Company conducted its largest share buyback in a year, while HDB resale prices slipped 0.3% in September. The SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace was launched to prepare Singaporeans for the digital economy. Peter Lim filed police reports against scammers, and Pimco sees a chance that the Monetary Authority of Singapore may surprise by tightening its policy stance. The Straits Times Index rose 25 points due to a rebound in the three banks.

site_title: Bad boy of tennis Kyrgios pledges US$50 per ace for stricken Puerto Rico
summary: Nick Kyrgios pledged US$50 for each ace towards emergency relief in Puerto Rico, increasing his initial US$10 offer. The Australian tennis player, known for his sometimes troubled behavior, made the announcement on Twitter after beating Germany's Mischa Zverev at the China Open. Kyrgios' gesture is part of a larger effort, with US President Donald Trump requesting a US$29 billion emergency relief package for Puerto Rico. Former number one Maria Sharapova plans to travel to the stricken US territory with Puerto Rican player Monica Puig to support relief efforts.

site_title: Malaysia palm oil stocks seen rising to 19-month high
summary: Malaysia's palm oil end-stocks are expected to reach a 19-month high of 2 million tonnes in September, driven by a 3.2% increase from August and the strongest monthly production level in nearly two years. This surge in inventory could pressure benchmark palm oil prices, which rose 1.2% to RM2,715 a tonne. September output is forecast to be 1.84 million tonnes, with exports expected to rise 7.8% to 1.60 million tonnes, mainly driven by Chinese and Indian demand ahead of major holiday periods.

site_title: Amazon opening pop-up liquor bar in Tokyo's Ginza district
summary: Amazon is opening a 10-day pop-up liquor bar in Tokyo's Ginza district, starting October 20, to promote its alcoholic products sold on its website in Japan. The 78-seat bar will offer a variety of drinks, including beer, wine, and sake, at prices ranging from 500 to 1,500 yen. Amazon aims to boost its physical presence and branch into new markets through this initiative, which features an ordering system and sommeliers to provide wine advice.

site_title: Australia retailers suffer worst sales decline in August since early 2013
summary: Australian retailers experienced their worst sales decline in August since 2013, with a 0.6% drop in sales, confounding expectations for a 0.3% increase. This decline, combined with a 0.2% fall in July, marks the largest back-to-back fall since 2010. The drop in sales is attributed to debt-laden consumers tightening their purse strings, particularly in the food, furniture, and clothing sectors. The Australian dollar dropped 0.4% to US$0.7829 following the news, casting a shadow on the Reserve Bank of Australia's forecasts for a 3% economic growth over the next two years.

site_title: ECB lowers emergency funding cap for Greek banks to 32.6b euros
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lowered the emergency funding cap for Greek banks from 33 billion euros to 32.6 billion euros, effective up to October 26, due to improved liquidity conditions. This move follows a 3.7 billion euro drop in ELA funding to Greek lenders in August. The decision reflects the progress made since the ECB reinstated Greek banks' access to its cheap funding operations in June last year, reducing their reliance on the emergency liquidity lifeline.

site_title: HDB resale prices slip 0.3% m-o-m in September; volume down 14%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore slipped 0.3% in September from August, reversing a 0.2% gain in the previous month. Despite the price decline, resale transaction volumes decreased 14% in September compared to August. Resale prices of 3-room, 4-room, and executive flats dropped 0.5%, 0.6%, and 1.5% respectively, while 5-room flats increased 0.1%. Mature estates saw a 0.8% price uptick, while non-mature estates fell 1%. Resale prices are now 1.8% lower than last year, with prices 12.3% below the peak in April 2013.

site_title: Cairnhill Mansions to be launched for en bloc sale for S$362m
summary: Cairnhill Mansions, a 18-storey freehold development in prime district 9, is launching for en bloc sale with an asking price of S$362 million. Over 80% of owners have signed the collective sale agreement, with the property's sole marketing agent CBRE stating that the asking price works out to S$2,101 per square foot per plot ratio. The site is strategically located near Orchard Road shopping belt and Newton MRT Station, offering a balance of privacy and accessibility. The sale marks the fifth en bloc attempt for the property, with developers keen to replenish their land banks amid strong demand for prime residential projects.

site_title: Offshore rig firms see end to worst downturn in history
summary: Offshore rig firms are witnessing the end of their worst downturn in history, driven by oil companies' growing demand for harsh-environment exploration. This has led to multibillion-dollar tie-ups among drillers and increased rates for harsh-environment rigs, potentially rising to $300,000 by 2018. Analysts have "buy" or "strong buy" ratings for companies with exposure to harsh-environment rigs, and some executives are seeking mergers and acquisitions to capitalize on the market recovery.

images.alt_text: While the 2014-2016 oil price crash caused firms to cut exploration budgets, ending a boom in rig demand and bankrupting many owners, energy companies are now seeking to replenish their hydrocarbon reserves.

site_title: Uber's revenue climbed to £36.9m in London before ban
summary: Uber's London operation saw a 59% increase in revenue to £36.9m in 2016, with a 65% rise in profit before tax to £3m. The company had 199 average monthly employees, up 90%, before its license was revoked by Transport for London. Uber generated US$1.75 billion in adjusted net revenue in the second quarter, with over 40,000 drivers and 3.5 million riders in London. The company intends to appeal the decision and will operate during the appeal process. Uber faces criticism for its handling of crime reporting and driver background checks.

site_title: Australian shares mark time ahead of US job data; NZ hits record closing high
summary: Australian shares ended flat at 5,651.80 points, with materials and consumer staples companies gaining while financials fell. New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record high, closing at 7,974.7. Gains were led by Qantas Airways and A2 Milk, while Auckland Airport weighed on the index. The US non-farm payrolls data, set for release on Friday, kept traders cautious.

site_title: Las Vegas shooter's girlfriend denies knowledge of planned carnage
summary: Las Vegas shooter Stephen Paddock's girlfriend, Marilou Danley, denied knowing of his planned attack, describing him as a "quiet, caring man." Danley said she had hoped for a quiet future with Paddock and had no hint of what was to come. The shooting left 58 dead and over 500 injured, with authorities still searching for a motive. President Trump declared the US a nation in mourning and called for Americans to "struggle through" the horror together. The FBI is questioning Danley for clues, as investigators continue to hunt for the reason behind Paddock's actions.

site_title: Pimco sees chance that MAS surprises by tightening
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore may surprise financial markets by tightening its policy stance in October, according to Pacific Investment Management. Economic indicators suggest an improved growth outlook and core inflation approaching 2%, the top of the MAS's forecast range. This could make Singapore one of the first Asian central banks to tighten its policy. A 30% probability of a hike is considered possible, with a slight positive slope implying a tightening move.

site_title: KS Energy gets extra time for new bond, warrant issuances
summary: KS Energy has secured an extension of its bond and warrant issuance, pushing the closing date to Dec 21, 2017, three months after the initial Sept 21, 2017, deadline. The lenders involved, including OCBC Bank and Kris Wiluan, have agreed to this revised timeline. The contingent deferred amount under the back-end payment will be equivalent to accrued coupon payments and redemption premium owed to OCBC. This agreement allows KS Energy to access more funds, with the lenders having a combined stake of $52.5 million in convertible bonds due 2017.

site_title: Japan election a branding battle as party pledges converge
summary: Japan's general election is expected to be a branding battle between Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Liberal Democratic Party and Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike's Party of Hope, with the two parties' policy platforms converging on key issues such as nuclear power and sales tax. Koike's party trails the LDP in surveys, but her marketing campaigns may damage Abe's image, potentially leading to his ouster as leader. The election's outcome may hinge on voter perception rather than policy differences, with Koike's party unlikely to win a majority, and her party's chances of damaging Abe's image seen as uncertain.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul, closed on October 5, 2017, for public holidays. In contrast, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day on July 11, 2025, ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4%. US stocks also reached fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher. Meanwhile, Airalo raised $220 million in funding, valuing the eSIM platform over $1 billion.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian maintains 'hold' on SembMarine
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintains a 'hold' rating on SembCorp Marine, citing that the termination of Oro Negro rig contracts should not impact the company's bottom line. The brokerage notes that SembMarine has already reversed out profits and halted further revenue recognition. With estimated uncovered cash costs of US$136 million, SembMarine could resell its rigs without taking further losses, and recent resale of newbuild rigs were transacted at discounts to original contract prices. The target price remains S$1.77 for SembMarine.

site_title: Sultan of bling: Brunei monarch marks golden jubilee in style
summary: Brunei's Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah marked 50 years on the throne with a grand ceremony, travelling in a gilded chariot through the streets and holding a traditional ceremony at his palace. The celebrations, which began two weeks ago, highlight the country's wealth and Islamic laws, but also controversy over the introduction of strict Islamic laws and a family feud. The sultan's long reign has seen Brunei gain independence and high living standards, but also criticism for its absolute monarchy and lack of nightlife.

site_title: Nuke strike on North Korea's neighbours could kill estimated 2.1m: report
summary: US President Donald Trump's threat to destroy North Korea has raised concerns about a potential nuclear conflict. A report by 38 North estimates that a nuclear strike on Seoul and Tokyo could kill 2.1 million people and injure 7.7 million, citing North Korea's current estimated warhead technology. The report, based on a database and computer modeling, assumes a baseline arsenal of 20-25 warheads and the capacity to put them on ballistic missiles. The threat of a nuclear conflict has increased as North Korea accelerates its program and Mr. Trump threatens preemptive military action.

site_title: Bond bulls relish India as best story after September selloff
summary: India's bond market is experiencing a pullback, with the benchmark 10-year yield rising 14 basis points in September, its largest increase since April. Despite this, bulls see the market as undervalued and are adding to their positions. Aberdeen Standard Investments and Pacific Investment Management Co are particularly optimistic, citing a strong reform agenda under Prime Minister Narendra Modi and low foreign ownership of Indian securities. The Reserve Bank of India's decision to review foreign investment rules in bonds may also boost investor confidence.

site_title: Malaysian pension giants are said to seek insurer deal talks
summary: Malaysia's two largest pension funds, Employees Provident Fund (EPF) and Kumpulan Wang Persaraan (Diperbadankan) (KWAP), plan to pursue talks to buy stakes in foreign-owned insurers in the country. The funds, which manage a combined $203 billion, are considering acquiring minority stakes in locally incorporated life insurance companies owned by overseas firms. This comes as the government enforces caps on overseas ownership, with foreign insurers having until June 2018 to trim their holdings in local firms to 70% at most. Any deal would add to the $11.2 billion of acquisitions in Malaysia this year.

site_title: New chief of India's biggest bank faces mounting bad debts
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has appointed Rajnish Kumar, 59, as the new chairman of State Bank of India (SBI), India's largest lender, to tackle a surge in bad debts. Kumar, who will serve a three-year term, faces a soured-loan ratio that has swelled to its highest since 2005, and a slowing economy that may erode debtors' capacity to repay loans. SBI shares have dropped 19% since July, and the bank's valuation is 0.91 times its book value, lower than the Nifty PSU Bank Index.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up tracking Wall Street; NZ hits record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to a 5,664.2 index point, driven by gains in material and consumer stocks, particularly iron ore and gold. The country's trade surplus grew to $989 million, surpassing expectations. Mining stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, added 0.9% and 1.8% respectively. Meanwhile, New Zealand shares hit a record high, with the S&P/NZX 50 index up 0.4% to 7,980.95.

site_title: Gold pares gains as dollar comes off lows on US data
summary: Gold prices pared gains on Wednesday as the US dollar rebounded from its lows on strong US service sector data, with spot gold up 0.2% at $1,274.41 per ounce. The dollar's strength makes dollar-priced gold cheaper for non-US investors, while a weaker dollar could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The Fed Chair Janet Yellen's comments on possible rate hikes through 2018 will be closely watched, and a more dovish Fed candidate could slow the retreat from loose monetary policy, denting gold's appeal as a safe haven.

site_title: World markets leave Australia behind with shrinking equity
summary: Australia's stock market has shrunk in value since the global financial crisis in 2007, despite the country's economy growing faster than its peers. The market is dominated by oligopolies in retailing and finance, and foreign firms have been buying Australian businesses, removing their listings. The lack of innovation and productivity has led to a stagnant market, with the S&P/ASX 200 Index having returned 58% over the past 10 years, less than its global peers. Investors are turning to offshore markets, and experts blame a "cosy culture" and lack of government foresight for the decline.

site_title: SIAEC conduct largest 1-day share buyback in a year as stock slumps
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) conducted its largest one-day share buyback in a year, purchasing 419,300 shares at a price range of S$3.15 to S$3.35 apiece. The company's shares slumped to a six-year low after news that 38.9 million shares, representing a 3.5% stake, were offered by JP Morgan. SIAEC's shares closed at S$3.21, down 25 cents or 7.23%, after recovering slightly on Thursday.

site_title: Thai Sept consumer mood rises for second straight month-survey
summary: Thailand's consumer confidence rose for the second straight month in September, driven by expanding exports and tourism, according to a private survey. The University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce's index increased to 75.0 from 74.5 in August. Consumers also expressed optimism about government spending and future stability. However, low commodity prices remained a concern, and the country's economic growth forecast was revised upward to 3.8% by the Bank of Thailand. This follows a 3.2% growth in 2016.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall St up as US jobs come into view
summary: Asian markets edged up in muted trade on Thursday, following Wall Street's third-straight record close and positive US data, including a healthy private jobs report. The dollar held gains against major peers as traders await the release of US jobs figures and Donald Trump's pick for the next Federal Reserve boss. The euro remains in the mid-US$1.17 range, while the European Union urges dialogue to ease the Spain Catalonia crisis.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Addvalue, Alliance Mineral, Keppel Corp
summary: Addvalue Technologies has signed an agreement with a partner to offer maritime product and data solutions to deep-sea fishing vessels, expected to generate US$200,000 in monthly recurring revenue. Alliance Mineral Assets is placing A$19.575 million of shares to Burwill CommoditY after Ernst & Young flagged uncertainty about its ability to continue operations. Keppel Corporation secured a FPSO vessel conversion contract from SBM Offshore NV, with Keppel's shares closing at S$6.52.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets diverge at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets diverged on Thursday, with London rising and eurozone indices down. London's FTSE 100 index edged up 0.1% to 7,473.73, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.2% to 12,950.18 points. Madrid's IBEX index rose 0.8% to 10,043.10 points, reversing a 3% drop on Wednesday amid the Catalan independence crisis. The divergence was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks propelling shares, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: Hurricane Harvey sends US oil exports to new heights, but not for long
summary: Hurricane Harvey led to record US crude exports of 1.98 million barrels per day, the highest level since 1993. The surge is due to lower demand from Gulf Coast refiners still recovering from the storm and seeking international markets. However, the bonanza is expected to be short-lived as refineries recover and the price of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude becomes less attractive compared to international benchmark Brent. US crude exports are expected to return to normal levels once the Gulf Coast demand recovers.

site_title: Oman to create 25,000 state jobs by year-end amid downturn
summary: Oman aims to create 25,000 public sector jobs by year-end to combat high unemployment, which stood at 17.5% in 2016. The move is part of a broader effort to address economic concerns, including a budget deficit of 21% and a high gross debt ratio. The government's decision risks adding to a budget gap, echoing a similar pledge made in 2011. Moody's Investors Services has cut Oman's rating to its second-lowest investment grade, citing limited progress in addressing structural vulnerabilities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 1.28 points to 1,760.56. Trading volume reached 82.75 million lots worth RM29.6 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 108 to 55.

site_title: Alliance Mineral places A$19.6 million of shares as auditor flags going concern doubt
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets placed A$19.575 million of shares with Burwill Commodity as its auditor, Ernst & Young flagged significant uncertainty about the company's ability to operate as a going concern due to pre-tax losses and limited cash reserves. The company cited the capital raised through the placement to meet committed and planned capital expenditure. The shares will resume trading on Thursday.

site_title: Broker's take: CIMB maintains 'add' on CDL following Amber Park sale
summary: CIMB maintains its 'add' rating on City Developments Limited (CDL) shares following the successful bid for Amber Park, a record-breaking S$906.7 million sale. The developer will redevelop the site into 800 condo units, benefiting from its prime location and upcoming MRT station. CIMB expects the project to be value-accretive, with a target price of S$12.54, representing a 9.6% upside. This transaction will enable CDL to replenish its Singapore land inventory and reaffirms optimism over the private housing market recovery in Singapore.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OUE Commercial Reit to redeem 75 million convertible perpetual preferred units (CPPUs) at S$1 each, reducing distributions but increasing finance costs. Venture Corporation's earnings expected to remain strong, with a possible DPS increase to S$0.60 for FY2017. Analysts also expect improved office sector outlook, with Venture Corporation's acquisition of a 60-year leasehold land positioning the company for further growth.

site_title: Addvalue, partner to trial app for fishing vessels, eye market size of 500
summary: ADDVALUE Technologies has partnered with a company to offer its maritime product and data solutions bundle for deep-sea fishing vessels, targeting a market size of at least 500 vessels. The partnership aims to generate $200,000 in monthly recurring revenue through a two-month market trial starting in November 2017. The trial will test a new application that prevents bill shock and offers affordable voice and text messaging services. The successful trial will lead to a commercial rollout covering vessels returning to ports for maintenance and upgrades.

site_title: Excelsior sale flop a 'reality check' for hot Hong Kong property
summary: The scrapped sale of The Excelsior hotel in Hong Kong's Causeway Bay may have been a "reality check" for the city's overheated property market, according to Hysan Development's Irene Lee. The sale was scrapped after bids failed to meet expectations, with some speculating the bidding level could have reached HK$30 billion. Lee attributes the failed sale to a cycle of increasing expectations fueled by recent record-breaking property sales, and warns that developers must be sensible and not get "carried away." She expects an "adjustment" in the market, rather than a crash.

images.alt_text: The scrapped sale of The Excelsior hotel in Causeway Bay may have been a "reality check" in a heated Hong Kong property market, according to Irene Lee, chairman of Hysan Development.

site_title: Nerve agent found on clothes of women accused of Kim Jong-nam murder: chemist
summary: A chemist testified that traces of the nerve agent VX, used to kill North Korean leader Kim Jong-nam, were found on the clothes of two women on trial for his murder. Siti Aisyah and Doan Thi Huong, accused of smearing the poison on Kim's face in February, have pleaded not guilty. The chemist's testimony is the first direct link to the poison, which is listed as a weapon of mass destruction. The women claim they were duped into participating in a prank for a reality TV show, while their lawyers blame North Korean agents.

site_title: Europe: Rattled investors dump Spanish shares amid Catalan tension
summary: Madrid's main index, the Ibex, fell nearly 3% amid worries about the Catalan independence crisis, with investors dumping Spanish shares. Despite this, the euro gained against the dollar as investors bet on the European Central Bank's upcoming monetary policy decision. US stocks finished at fresh records, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all reaching new highs. Analysts say investors are looking beyond the crisis to the ECB meeting, expecting a tapering of monetary stimulus.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wall Street advance
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, following Wall Street's all-time peak for the third day, driven by strong economic data. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.14% to 20,655.53, while the Topix index increased 0.12% to 1,686.56. This uptrend is attributed to investors' optimism despite US trade uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Singapore shares open up on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.1% to 3,240.32. The gains follow record closing highs for US equities and data showing economic strength. About 54 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 70 to 56. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid uncertainty over US tariffs.

site_title: New Zealand's operating surplus higher than expected for this fiscal year
summary: New Zealand's government reported a fiscal year operating surplus of NZ$4.069 billion, slightly higher than expected due to higher tax revenues and reduced spending. The economy was fueled by a surge in migration, resulting in a 7.4% rise in tax revenues. Net debt fell to 22.2% of GDP, its first decline since 2008. The better-than-forecast surplus is seen as a positive indicator for the country's economic growth and fiscal consolidation.

site_title: Google unveils US$49 Home Mini digital assistant
summary: Google has unveiled the US$49 Home Mini digital assistant, a slimmed down version of its connected speaker. The device responds to voice commands using artificial intelligence and is available for pre-order in seven countries, with a release date of October 19. The new speaker aims to make Google's hardware offerings more accessible, with Google CEO Sundar Pichai stating that the company is working on software and hardware together to drive computing forward. This move steps up Google's challenge to market leader Amazon.

site_title: US dollar weakens before payrolls, pares losses on strong non-manufacturing index
summary: The US dollar weakened 0.7% on Wednesday ahead of the jobs report, but recovered after a strong non-manufacturing index. The dollar index fell to 93.479, but pared losses after the ISM non-manufacturing index rose to its highest level since August 2005. Investors expect a possible interest rate hike in December, with 83% likelihood, and a less hawkish head of the Federal Reserve. The jobs report, expected to be released Friday, remains a concern due to the impact of hurricanes on hiring.

site_title: Philippine inflation accelerates faster than expected in Sept
summary: The Philippine central bank reported that the country's annual inflation accelerated to 3.4% in September, exceeding economists' forecasts, but still within the central bank's target range of 2.8-3.6%. Core inflation, excluding volatile food and fuel items, rose to 3.3%, indicating manageable inflation that has allowed the central bank to maintain its monetary policy unchanged since 2014. The central bank expects inflation to average 3.2% this year and next year.

site_title: Yellen says Fed is working on tailoring regulations to bank size
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the central bank is working to tailor regulations to the size, complexity, and roles of the lenders it oversees. She emphasized that regulations for community banks, which avoided risky business practices during the financial crisis, should be improved without being unduly burdensome. This comes as President Trump pushes to reduce business regulations, with his nominee for Fed vice-chair, Randal Quarles, set to be confirmed.

site_title: Handful of wary Republicans imperil Trump's tax reform bid
summary: US congressional Republicans are working towards passing tax reform by December, but face opposition from a handful of wary Republicans who could derail the bid. The proposal, which includes deep cuts to corporate and individual tax rates, aims to spur economic growth and neutralize lost tax revenue. However, critics argue it would blow a $1.5 trillion hole in the deficit and disproportionately benefit the wealthy. With the Senate's narrow margin, a few defectors could jeopardize the party's long-held goal of tax reform.

site_title: External auditor expresses doubt about Perisai's viability
summary: An external auditor, Baker Tilly AC, has expressed doubts about Perisai Petroleum Teknologi Bhd's viability as a going concern due to significant net losses and current liabilities exceeding current assets. The company incurred losses of RM607 million and RM309 million for the fiscal year and has current liabilities of RM1.34 billion and RM730 million, respectively. Despite this, Perisai's board of directors maintains it can be salvaged and is addressing key issues, including a restructuring plan.

site_title: Zika vaccine shows promise in early human trial
summary: A DNA-based Zika vaccine from Inovio Pharmaceuticals Inc and GeneOne Life Science Inc induced anti-Zika immune responses in a human trial, with all 40 healthy volunteers developing Zika-specific antibodies after three doses. The vaccine, GLS-5700, was shown to be protective against the virus in mice, with those receiving immunized serum showing no signs of Zika infection. The study's rapid development, from design to trial in just seven months, demonstrates the potential of synthetic DNA vaccines. Further testing is needed to confirm the vaccine's effectiveness in humans.

site_title: Striving to better energy performance
summary: Petrochemical Corporation of Singapore (PCS) has been awarded the Excellence in Energy Management category and received an Honourable Mention in the Best Practices award category for its proactive energy-conservation efforts. Since the 1980s, PCS has been monitoring its energy efficiency through established key performance indicators and implementing projects to maintain and improve its energy performance. The company's initiatives include regular assessment, predictive maintenance, and the installation of energy-efficient systems, resulting in reduced unit costs and greenhouse gas emissions. PCS plans to continue promoting energy efficiency through its ongoing efforts.

site_title: Actsys's strong commitment pays off
summary: Actsys Process Management Consultants Pte Ltd has been awarded Outstanding Energy Services Provider of the Year at the EENP Awards. The company, founded by Norman Lee in 2001, has built long-term relationships with clients and contributed to energy-efficiency market development through services such as energy auditing, performance monitoring, and training. Actsys' commitment to energy efficiency has led to outstanding success in improving energy performance, with Mr. Lee citing energy-efficiency improvement as a cost-effective way to address energy cost, energy security, and global climate change.

site_title: US services growth hits 12-year record in September
summary: US services sector growth reached a 12-year high in September, surpassing analyst expectations with a 4.5 percentage point increase to 59.8%, according to the Institute for Supply Management. This marked 93 consecutive months of expansion, with 15 of 17 service industries reporting growth, including retail, construction, and financial services. The business activity index rose 3.8 points, and supplier deliveries jumped 7.5%. Despite hurricanes Harvey and Irma, most industries reported minimal disruption, with some exceptions in hospitality and food services.

site_title: DBS, OCBC launch products to help busy executives
summary: DBS and OCBC, two Singaporean banks, have launched products to help busy executives, particularly CFOs and corporate treasurers. DBS's Treasury Prism platform allows users to simulate various bank and corporate solutions, review potential opportunities, and analyze the relative benefits and costs. The platform provides contextual insights and real-time updates on regulatory and tax changes. Meanwhile, OCBC will allow SME customers to transfer funds and make account balance enquiries using Apple's Siri from October 9, with no limit on the amount and fingerprint authentication for security.

site_title: India homebuyers petition top court over bankruptcy law
summary: Hundreds of Indian homebuyers have petitioned the country's top court to challenge the insolvency law, citing concerns that the law prioritizes banks over homebuyers and fails to safeguard their investments. The petitioners, who invested in a collapsed housing project, claim the law gives banks unfair priority and leaves buyers with no chance of getting their homes or investments back. The petitioners argue that the law should treat homebuyers equally to secured creditors, but currently, they are only recognized as unsecured creditors.

site_title: Singapore, Thailand discuss e-payment alliance for digital push
summary: Singapore and Thailand are discussing a regional digital payment alliance to connect their national platforms, PayNow and PromptPay, respectively. The move aims to curb cash use and modernize the payment process. The alliance, if successful, would bring together Southeast Asia's first national digital-payment platforms. The Bank of Thailand has 24 million registrations for PromptPay, while PayNow has over 500,000 registrations. The tie-up is part of efforts to compete with foreign digital payment firms and promote more efficient and traceable transactions.

site_title: US: Wall St extends run of record highs; services data upbeat
summary: US stocks extended their record-high run, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite reaching new highs. The services sector expanded at its fastest pace in 12 years, despite hurricane-related disruptions. Oil prices declined, weighing on energy shares. Analysts expect third-quarter earnings to rise 5.5% from the same period last year, boosting market optimism. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.09% to 22,661.64, while the S&P 500 gained 0.12% to 2,537.74.

site_title: Oil slips after surprising increase in US crude exports
summary: Oil prices fell after a surprise increase in US crude exports to a record 2 million barrels per day, sparking concerns about global oversupply. US crude stockpiles dropped sharply, but exports rose to 1.98 million bpd, pushing WTI down 44 cents to $49.98 a barrel and Brent down 20 cents to $55.80 a barrel. The US oil-production profile is forcing Opec to re-evaluate its strategy, and analysts worry that the heavy increase in US exports will undermine the Opec-led efforts to reduce supply.

site_title: Brunei sultan to mark golden jubilee with lavish celebrations
summary: Brunei's Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah is marking his 50-year reign with lavish celebrations, including a 21-gun salute and a procession through the capital, Bandar Seri Begawan. The festivities, which began on October 4, 2017, are a chance for citizens to celebrate the life and times of the monarch, who has ruled one of the world's few absolute monarchies. The celebrations come as the country continues to face controversies, including the introduction of Islamic laws and a family feud involving the sultan's brother. The event has also drawn international attention, with Southeast Asian leaders and Middle Eastern royalty attending a banquet.

site_title: BAT's Lankan unit set to lose dominant position amid levies
summary: British American Tobacco's Sri Lankan unit, Ceylon Tobacco Co, is expected to lose its dominant position in the market due to increased levies on cigarettes, prompting smokers to switch to cheaper beedi alternatives. The company's profit margin narrowed to 64% in 2016, with the beedi industry capturing at least half of the tobacco market, posing a threat to the legal cigarette industry. The government is considering tighter regulations on the beedi segment, and Ceylon Tobacco is taking measures to contain the impact, including reducing factory shifts and widening its portfolio.

site_title: Japan's transport ministry inspects 2 more Nissan plants
summary: Japan's transport ministry conducted spot inspections at two Nissan plants, following the discovery of unauthorised final vehicle checks for most domestic models. The inspections were part of a probe into final checks after Nissan recalled 1.2 million cars sold in Japan. The initial inspections at four factories last week prompted Nissan to suspend new vehicle registrations with the government.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Electronics signed a memorandum of understanding with Sky Seven to promote Oman's Virtual Aerodrome Laboratory for airport training and simulation. Saizen Reit will delist from the Singapore Exchange on October 6 due to a termination notice. Unusual, a concert producer, is exploring a corporate exercise without providing details. SinoPipe Holdings gave an executive director a 29,000 yuan raise to compensate for increased workload.

site_title: Puerto Rico will run out of cash on Oct 31, treasurer says
summary: Puerto Rico faces a government shutdown on October 31 due to a lack of emergency funds, according to Treasury Secretary Raul Maldonado. The US commonwealth's government is burning through its $1.6 billion in reserves after Hurricane Maria, and is running short on funds for fuel, salaries, and food aid. Maldonado has requested $6-8 billion in aid from Congress to keep the government running for a few months, but warned that a shutdown would curtail essential services and aid distribution. The island's debt is estimated to be $74 billion, but immediate crisis is more pressing.

site_title: How Asean can unlock promise of artificial intelligence
summary: Southeast Asian nations, particularly Singapore, are lagging in AI adoption, but have the potential to unlock its benefits. The region's digitally savvy industries, such as finance and telecom, have already begun to adopt AI, but face challenges in scaling up and integrating it into their organizations. To fully harness AI's potential, Southeast Asian banks and manufacturers must develop new skills and collaborate with fintech startups and governments. Despite the potential for significant value creation, common use of AI in patient care and healthcare data sharing remain years away due to data consolidation and privacy concerns.

site_title: US business groups say WTO unable to curb many Chinese trade practices
summary: US business groups express frustration over China's efforts to create an uneven economic playing field, citing rules and policies that favor domestic companies and inhibit foreign investment. These practices include subsidies to state-owned enterprises, excess manufacturing capacity, and forced technology transfers. The groups claim that World Trade Organization (WTO) rules are insufficient to address these issues, which could lead to trade sanctions by President Trump. The concerns were highlighted in a public hearing by the US Trade Representative's office, which will influence an annual report on China's WTO compliance and a USTR investigation into intellectual property practices.

site_title: Las Vegas shooter's girlfriend back in US; FBI to question her
summary: Stephen Paddock's girlfriend, Marilou Danley, 62, has returned to the US after arriving in Los Angeles. She is classified as a "person of interest" to FBI investigators and is not in custody, allowing her to move freely. The FBI wants to question her about the motive behind the Las Vegas shooting, which left 58 dead and over 500 wounded.

site_title: Storms spur US$22.3b investment in battery-backed grids
summary: US$22.3 billion will be invested in battery-backed local energy systems over the next decade, driven by growing demand for resilient power supplies. Microgrids, small-scale solar systems with batteries, are expected to reach 14.9 gigawatts in operation by 2026, up from 238 megawatts this year. North America and Asia-Pacific will receive most of the investment, with Puerto Rico becoming a target for developers to showcase microgrid designs after Hurricane Maria. Declining battery costs and new financing methods will boost deployment in areas prone to natural disasters.

site_title: Legoland owner Merlin is said to approach SeaWorld over deal
summary: UK theme-park operator Merlin Entertainments Plc has approached SeaWorld Entertainment Inc over a potential deal, with an eye on acquiring part of the company. SeaWorld, currently valued at $1.3 billion, has received interest from other suitors and prefers an outright sale. The deal would target SeaWorld's Busch Gardens theme-park assets, which Merlin values due to its policy of not keeping cetaceans in captivity. This move comes as SeaWorld struggles to turn around its business, with revenue and stock price declines amid shrinking attendance and missed earnings forecasts.

site_title: Addvalue, Delong remain in play after unusually active sessions draw queries
summary: Shares of Addvalue Technologies and Delong Holdings remained active on Wednesday after the companies said they could not explain the unusual trading activity. Addvalue slipped 2.2% to close at 4.4 cents, while Delong advanced 8.1% to end at S$1.945. Both companies stated they were unaware of any new information that could explain the trading activity, which prompted the Singapore Exchange to issue a trading query on Tuesday.

site_title: In the world's most liveable cities, few can afford to buy a home
summary: Home ownership among young Australians has reached its lowest level on record, with only 45% of 25-34 year-olds owning their own home, down 16 percentage points from the 1980s. The explosive property boom, driven by record low interest rates and a lack of supply, has pushed home prices to over 140% increase in the past 15 years, making Sydney the world's second-most expensive housing market. The issue is further exacerbated by hefty mortgages, household debt, and a tax system that favors property investors, leading to mounting voter angst and pressure on the government to address the issue.

site_title: Keppel secures Liza FPSO conversion from SBM Offshore
summary: Keppel Shipyard secured a contract to convert a Very Large Crude Carrier (VLCC) into an FPSO for ExxonMobil's Liza field in Guyana. The FPSO will have a storage capacity of 1.6 million barrels and produce up to 120,000 barrels of oil per day. The shipyard's work scope includes refurbishment, life extension, and installation of topside modules. This is Keppel's 25th major project from SBM Offshore, demonstrating the company's expertise in FPSO conversions and its strong partnership with SBM Offshore.

site_title: Singapore real-estate investors shining on global stage
summary: Singaporean real estate investors have amassed the largest pool of foreign assets among Asian buyers, with 3,290 properties worldwide as of October 2017. They hold the largest share of industrial assets in the US, followed by offices and shopping malls in Australia and China. Capital outflows have doubled each year since 2009, with US$106.5 billion shifted to offshore real estate. Singaporean investors have explored opportunities in central and eastern Europe, Ireland, and Spain, and have also invested in student housing, manufactured homes, and residential properties in the US and UK.

site_title: Buyout firm to take Swissco OSV business private
summary: A buyout firm has raised US$40 million to acquire Swissco's offshore support vessel (OSV) business, which will continue to operate out of Singapore as a privately-owned entity. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move by Asian Strategic Turnaround Ventures, with observers noting that JM has other plans for the listed entity. The OSV business will remain separate from the listed holding company, Swissco Holdings.

site_title: Toyota's Sept car sales in US get boost from Hurricane Harvey
summary: Toyota's US vehicle sales surged 15% in September, driven by post-Hurricane Harvey recovery efforts. The company's light truck sales jumped 29% as buyers rushed to replace waterlogged vehicles. Toyota's September gains trailed only General Motors in sales volume, with Honda and Nissan also beating expectations. The storm may have been a boost to the car market, which has been shrinking since record sales last year, with sales expected to continue into October and November.

site_title: Yahoo says all 3 billion accounts hacked in 2013 data theft
summary: Yahoo revealed that all 3 billion of its accounts were hacked in a 2013 data theft, tripling its earlier estimate, in a disclosure that increases Verizon Communications' legal exposure. The breach, one of the largest in history, expands the number of consumer class-action lawsuits against Yahoo, with at least 41 filed in US courts. This news raises concerns about the legal liability of Verizon, which acquired Yahoo in 2017.

site_title: Corporate-startup programmes should focus on the startups, not the corporates
summary: ST Engineering launched Innosparks, a healthcare, workplace safety, and security startup incubator, with a commitment of up to S$500,000 per startup. This is part of a growing trend of large corporates launching accelerators and incubators to nurture in-house innovation. Other corporates, such as Shell and GIC, have also launched similar initiatives, indicating a shift towards corporate-startup collaboration.

site_title: Unsustainable to increasingly buy land at higher prices, warns Redas chief
summary: Singapore's Redas chief Augustine Tan warns that the trend of developers buying private residential sites at higher prices is unsustainable due to cooling measures, slow population growth, and buyers' price sensitivity. He expects no runaway demand in sales transaction volume and property prices in the next few years. Despite recent price increases, private home rents are still falling, and vacancies remain high. Tan advises developers to value stability in the property market, citing ongoing concerns of geopolitical uncertainty, global economic activity, and monetary policy tightening.

images.alt_text: Mr Augustine Tan (left) arriving at the Redas Mid-Autumn Festival Lunch with guest of honour, Minister for the Environment and Water Resources, Mr Masagos Zulkifli.

site_title: Airbus says it has capacity to raise A350 production
summary: Airbus announced it has the capacity to increase A350 production beyond its targeted 10 aircraft per month by the end of 2018, with some reports suggesting a possible increase to 13 aircraft per month by 2019. The company has delivered 50 A350 aircraft so far this year and is sticking to its production target. This move comes as its main rival Boeing prepares to step up some of its own production output.

site_title: Ministry of Finance leading the way in energy-efficiency practices
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) received a commendation for Best Energy Efficiency Practices in the public sector for its efforts in adopting and implementing energy-efficient practices in its buildings. MOF was the first ministry to adopt the Guaranteed Energy Savings Performance (GESP) contracting model and has since implemented two GESP projects. The award recognizes the ministry's commitment to reducing energy consumption and promoting sustainability.

site_title: SIAEC sinks to six-year low on talk of bulk sale
summary: SIA Engineering Company's (SIAEC) share price plummeted 9% to a six-year low, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange, due to talk of a bulk sale. JP Morgan allegedly offered 38.9 million shares at a 4.6-10.1% discount to the share price, representing a 3.5% stake in the company. The shares were sold at a price range of S$3.11 to S$3.30 each.

site_title: Biopharma firm AbbVie opens S$400m biologics plant in Tuas
summary: AbbVie, a biopharma firm, has opened a new S$400m biologics manufacturing plant in Tuas, Singapore, marking its first facility in Asia. The 120,000-sq metre plant will create 250 jobs and expand its biologics manufacturing capabilities. This move is part of the company's global expansion efforts.

images.alt_text: (From far left): Site director Marc O'Donoghue, chairman of the Singapore Economic Development Board Beh Swan Gin, Trade and Industry Minister S Iswaran, chairman and chief executive of AbbVie Richard Gonzalez, senior vice-president of operations at AbbVie Azita Saleki-Gerhardt and vice-president of manufacturing operations Biologic at AbbVie Daniela Ottini.

site_title: Dollar retreats on talk of less hawkish Fed chief
summary: The US dollar retreated against a basket of major currencies on Wednesday, falling 0.3% to 112.46 yen, after a Politico report suggested that Fed Governor Jerome Powell may be favored to replace Janet Yellen as chairman, potentially leading to a more dovish monetary policy. The dollar had reached its highest since mid-August on Tuesday, driven by stronger economic data and expectations of another rate hike. The euro rose 0.25% to US$1.1770.

site_title: Fans fired up by Springsteen on Broadway
summary: Bruce Springsteen began a four-month run of solo shows on Broadway, with tickets initially selling for $75-$800. However, resale sites like StubHub were selling tickets for up to $6,000, with buyers coming from nearly every US state and 30 countries. Springsteen's team implemented a "verified fan" program to curb exorbitant resale prices, but tickets still went to secondary markets. The singer has since extended his run and offered a last-minute lottery for $75 tickets to reach more fans.

images.alt_text: Springsteen decided to go to Broadway after performing at the White House in a concert that then-president Barack Obama arranged as a gift to his departing staff.

site_title: Jardine group, banks drag STI lower
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 9.43 points to 3,236.65 on Wednesday, dragged down by weakness in the Jardine group and three banks. Despite a mixed session, the index was supported by a weak trading volume of 1.9 billion units worth S$999 million. The overall session was mixed, with 236 rises versus 184 falls, contrasting with the Wall Street's all-time closing high on Tuesday.

site_title: UK economic growth remains subdued; BOE set to raise rates
summary: The UK economy is expected to expand 0.3% in Q3, according to a survey, but price pressures are rising. The Bank of England is likely to raise interest rates due to the subdued growth. The IHS Markit/CIPS PMI showed services growth up unexpectedly in September, while businesses are increasingly worried about the impact of Brexit on their trading relationships. This news may keep the Bank of England on track to raise interest rates soon, despite the subdued economic growth.

site_title: Head of new China M&A firm riffs on history and oil's future
summary: Chinese energy firm CEFC China Energy's head Ye Jianming says despite oil prices sliding below US$30, it will still be needed for petrochemicals. Ye justifies purchasing a US$9 billion stake in Rosneft Oil Co, citing long-term supply security for China, the world's biggest energy user. CEFC plans to produce petrochemicals for the Chinese market, and is eyeing natural gas, which will be used most in future electricity generation.

site_title: Siberian subprime exposes Putin's divided Russia as credit booms
summary: A credit boom is unfolding in Tuva, Russia's second-highest unemployment area, with consumer loans increasing by over 50% in the first seven months. This phenomenon reflects the country's vast economic inequality, with some of Russia's poorest taking on high-cost debt to make ends meet. The surge in lending is emblematic of Russia's unequal economy, where some regions experience rapid growth while others struggle with high unemployment. This trend highlights the challenges facing President Putin's administration in addressing Russia's deep-seated economic disparities.

site_title: On a crusade to build a greener future for the next generation
summary: Avtar Singh, energy manager at MSD International GmbH (Singapore branch), has been recognized as the Outstanding Energy Manager of the Year for driving energy efficiency in the company. Since 2011, Singh has led the organization in reducing energy consumption by 62.6 GWh, equivalent to a 33% reduction and a 43,000 metric ton reduction in carbon dioxide emissions. His efforts have inspired a culture of sustainability, with initiatives such as energy treasure hunts and employee awareness programs, resulting in cost savings of millions of dollars per year. Singh's leadership has promoted energy efficiency and reduced the company's environmental impact.

site_title: Committed to a low-carbon future
summary: Shell Chemicals Seraya (Pte) Ltd has won the EENP award for Best Practices for its "Energy savings from two stage flashing" project, resulting in a 15% reduction in steam consumption. The project, which achieved energy savings through heat integration and an expansion project, showcases the company's commitment to a low-carbon future. Shell Chemicals credits its energy management system and various projects, including the deployment of a two-stage flasher, for enabling efficient operations and reducing its energy footprint.

site_title: Xi to consolidate power at Party Congress
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to consolidate his power during the 19th Party Congress, set to take place on October 18, by appointing key posts and shaping the party's direction. While no major policy changes are anticipated, analysts will be watching for the size and power balance of the Politburo and Standing Committee, as well as the wording of Xi's work report, which could outline his policies for the next five years. This will provide insight into his legacy and ability to entrench his mark on the party and the country.

site_title: Placing emphasis on saving energy
summary: ExxonMobil Asia Pacific has won three EENP awards for Excellence in Energy Management, Best Practices at its Singapore Refinery, and Best Practices (Honourable Mention) at the Singapore Chemical Plant, bringing its total awards to six since 2013. The company aims to be more disciplined in its operations to address its energy-intensive nature. This emphasis on energy management reflects ExxonMobil's commitment to efficiency and sustainability.

site_title: Japan's economy sees output exceed capacity the most in 9 years
summary: Japan's economy saw output exceed full capacity by 1.22% in the April-June quarter, the largest gap in 9 years, according to a Bank of Japan estimate. This positive output gap justifies the central bank's decision to keep policy steady, as inflation is expected to accelerate towards its 2% target. The economy expanded at an annualized 2.5% in the second quarter, driven by strong consumer and company spending. A sustained positive output gap may take time to translate into actual business responses, such as increased investment and inflation.

site_title: Ford to slash US$14b in costs, drop some car models
summary: Ford Motor Co plans to slash US$14 billion in costs over the next five years by reducing materials and engineering costs by US$10 billion and US$4 billion, respectively. The company will focus on SUVs, trucks, and electrification, dropping passenger cars from its lineup. Ford aims to shift spending towards products like the resurrected Bronco SUV, with no specific models mentioned. The move is aimed at reversing the company's three-year stock slide under new CEO Jim Hackett.

site_title: World Bank sees more currency risk in S-E Asia
summary: The World Bank warns that Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines are more vulnerable to currency risk due to their large external debt, despite having adequate foreign exchange reserves. This is amid tightening global financial conditions.

site_title: Exposing students to clean energy technologies and practices
summary: Bukit View Secondary School in Singapore has received the EENP award for best energy-efficiency practices in the public sector. The school's comprehensive learning and outreach programme exposes students to clean energy technologies and practices, including the Applied Learning Programme in Clean Energy and Environmental Technology and the JOULES programme. The school aims to reduce energy consumption by 3% and has already implemented various energy-saving measures, such as a STEM centre and ecotrails. The award recognition is seen as an honour and a spur to continue the school's environmental efforts.

site_title: New S$100m fund should spur athletes to excel
summary: Singapore has launched the One Team Singapore Fund, a S$100m initiative to support elite athletes and national sports associations, aiming to increase competition opportunities and improve athlete development. The fund will match donations of up to S$50m from Singaporeans and corporates, with the goal of winning more medals at international games. National sports associations must demonstrate progress to justify the financial commitment, and athletes are expected to deliver results to secure monetary support.

site_title: Uber board declares truce; Softbank to join
summary: Uber's board has declared a truce, passing measures to strengthen corporate governance and bring in major investor SoftBank. The agreement aims to diminish the power of former CEO Travis Kalanick and set a deadline for an initial public offering (IPO) in autumn 2019. Governance policies adopted by the board would make it difficult for Kalanick to return as CEO. Early investors Shervin Pishevar and Steve Russell have vowed to sue to block the change, which cuts their super-voting rights. SoftBank's $10 billion investment is contingent on the deal being finalized, with the company set to acquire 2 seats on the board.

site_title: Give HK political reform and independence idea will die
summary: Hong Kong's pro-independence movement is facing increased scrutiny and hostility from Beijing. Zhang Xiaoming, director of the State Council's Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office, has denounced the idea, calling it "a calamity for Hong Kong" and a "serious erosion" of academic freedoms. The move comes after pro-independence banners and posters were displayed at universities, prompting campus authorities to remove them. Student unions have condemned the removal as a restriction on academic freedoms, but Zhang's statement suggests that Beijing views the movement as a threat to the region's stability and the Chinese constitution.

site_title: Why yuan's internationalisation has slowed
summary: China's yuan has seen a slowdown in internationalisation since its introduction to the International Monetary Fund's special drawing right in October 2016. The country's growth model limits further capital account opening and domestic financial reform, prioritising stability and reform. The yuan's upward trajectory stalled around August 2015, marking a shift from a one-way trend to a slower pace of liberalisation. China's cautious approach to currency liberalisation is attributed to its preoccupation with domestic financial stability and growth.

site_title: Smarter transport to ease traffic woes
summary: Big Data analysis can transform Southeast Asia's megacities, easing traffic woes and improving quality of life. The Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) celebrates its 50th anniversary, marking significant economic growth from $37.6 billion to $2.6 trillion. However, this progress has come at a cost, including traffic congestion.
