The proposal was made after talks with Myanmar's de facto civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi's representative, who agreed to set up a working group to coordinate repatriation. The refugees will be verified by the joint group, with the United Nations not involved, and the process has no specified timeframe. This comes after Suu Kyi stated that Myanmar would take back "verified" refugees.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singtel's stock offers 17% upside potential as its core plus digital business trades at a 5.6 times FY18 EV/EBITDA ratio, compared to peers at 7-9 times. Analysts expect the valuation discount to disappear due to narrower digital losses in FY18. Delfi Ltd, an Indonesian consumer goods company, is expected to see improved consumer spending in FY18, driven by government subsidies and the completion of product rationalization. Delfi's share price has corrected by 31% due to soft Q2 results, but analysts see value emerging at its current 24 times FY18 PE ratio.

site_title: Capitalism is the only way, UK finance minister says in challenge to Labour
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond defended capitalism as the only route to prosperity, countering Labour's vision for a more centrally-controlled economy. Hammond stated that every country with a market economy system has achieved success, citing examples of rising living standards and job creation. His comments echo those of Prime Minister Theresa May, who also defended capitalism. The remarks come as Labour proposes nationalizing Britain's infrastructure, increasing government spending, and taxation. Hammond's defense of capitalism comes amid concerns about the threat Labour poses to the pro-business orthodoxy underpinning British economic policy.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific acquires freehold residential sites in Guillemard Lane for S$34m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired two freehold residential sites in Guillemard Lane, Singapore, for S$33.5 million. The combined site has an estimated land area of 25,601 sq ft and will be amalgamated with existing freehold land parcels for residential development. The acquisition is expected to be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, with minimal impact on the company's earnings and net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Abe support falls as Koike steals spotlight before election
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's support has fallen below his disapproval rate in two polls, three weeks before a general election, as Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike's Party of Hope threatens to eat into his majority. Koike's party plans to field candidates in only half of the 465 seats, but her rise has shaken up the election. Abe's ruling Liberal Democratic Party unveiled its election manifesto, focusing on his economic record and plans to change the pacifist constitution. Koike's party opposes Abe on key issues, including nuclear power and the sales-tax hike, and may potentially deprive Abe's party of its single-handed majority.

site_title: Eurozone Sept factory PMI hits highest since Feb 2011 as new orders accelerate
summary: Factories across the eurozone experienced their most productive month since February 2011 in September, with the manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reaching 58.1. New orders accelerated, and firms raised prices at the fastest rate in five months, a welcome sign for policymakers at the European Central Bank. This momentum is expected to continue into October, supporting the ECB's case for gradual removal of stimulus. The acceleration in demand and activity could lead to the central bank announcing a reduction of its asset-buying program soon.

site_title: AI for traditional industries
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming traditional industries, including industrials, agriculture, and finance, by driving new solutions at lower costs. AI can optimize tasks, beat human reasoning, and address complex problems. Companies need to rethink their mindset and approach to adopt AI, which requires new datasets, simulations, and human guidance. Traditional companies can leverage AI to reinvent business models, but must also change their role from command-and-control to teaching AI systems. AI can mitigate disruptions, optimize functions, and help companies stay ahead of the curve, but requires a fundamental shift in how they work and interact with the world.

site_title: Facebook pulls page, limits posting for exiled Chinese tycoon Guo
summary: Facebook has taken down a page affiliated with exiled Chinese billionaire Guo Wengui and temporarily restricted his ability to post on his profile due to violations of its community standards. The page and profile contained personal identifier information without consent. Guo, who is living in New York, has been using social media to claim corruption in the Chinese government ahead of the ruling Communist Party's congress. The move comes as Chinese authorities try to repatriate Guo, who has been living in US political asylum since September.

site_title: Halcyon Agri sells stake in SIAT
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation Limited sold its 35% stake in SIAT SA to Fimave SA/NV for 192.56 million euros (S$308.23 million). The disposal was completed on September 29, 2017, with an aggregate call option price of 5.5 million euros. This move follows Halcyon Agri's decision to delist GMG Global, a natural rubber supply chain manager, from the Singapore Exchange in December 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end slightly higher despite upbeat business report
summary: Tokyo stocks ended slightly higher on Monday despite a business confidence report showing a decade-high level of optimism. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.22%, while the Topix index fell 0.07%. Nissan's decline was attributed to news that thousands of its vehicles for the Japan market had been inspected by uncertified staff. The slight increase in Tokyo stocks contrasted with the upbeat business report, which was seen as a positive sign for the Japanese economy.

site_title: UK factory growth slows, price pressures rocket again
summary: The UK manufacturing sector experienced slower growth in September, with the IHS Markit/CIPS UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers'Index falling to 55.9 from 56.7 in August. This marks a further sign of momentum loss across the UK economy. Cost pressures surged, with factory costs for goods increasing at the fastest pace since March, driven by commodity price hikes and supply chain constraints. The slowdown may prompt interest rate hikes by the Bank of England, which are expected by most economists to occur in November.

site_title: IE Singapore inks MOUs to help tech firms break into China
summary: IE Singapore signed two memoranda of understanding with Chinese tech partners AIRMaker and NTUitive to help Singapore tech firms break into China's market. The partnerships aim to provide customized accelerator programs, co-working spaces, and market access to support growth and expansion. AIRMaker will connect Singapore deeptech and medtech companies to China's ecosystem, while NTUitive will bring its research innovations on board. 36Kr will provide curated accelerator programs and networks for Singapore startups. The partnerships will benefit around 10-20 companies, including those working on artificial intelligence solutions.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars lose altitude as Treasury yields climb
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined against the US dollar, with the Aussie falling to US$0.7825 and the kiwi at US$0.7196. Rising US Treasury yields, driven by speculation of a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike, contributed to the losses. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates steady at 1.5%, while New Zealand's central bank remains cautious, citing a slowing housing market and high household debt.

site_title: Britain's Monarch Airlines ceases operations, flights cancelled: CAA
summary: Britain's Monarch Airlines ceased operations with immediate effect, leaving 110,000 customers stranded overseas and 300,000 future bookings cancelled. The UK's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has chartered 30 aircraft to repatriate affected passengers. This marks the UK's largest ever airline to enter administration, amid tough competition in the airlines sector. Monarch had been struggling financially and was previously talking to potential partners to sell parts of its short-haul network.

site_title: TSMC's founder to retire and hand reins to co-CEOs in June
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) chairman and founder Morris Chang will retire in June 2018, handing over the reins to co-CEOs Mark Liu and CC Wei. Chang, who founded the company in 1987, will step down after the annual shareholders meeting, marking a formal succession plan. The company's shares have surged 21.5% this year, thanks to projected demand for Apple's new iPhones and other products. Chang, 86, will not participate in any TSMC management activities after his retirement, leaving Liu and Wei to lead the company, which is the world's largest producer of made-to-order microchips.

site_title: Upbeat China data lifts Australia shares; NZ edges down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Monday, driven by upbeat Chinese factory data, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 5,729.30. China's manufacturing activity grew at its fastest pace since 2012, easing concerns of a slowdown. Financial and material stocks led the gains, with Commonwealth Bank and Westpac Banking Corp among the top performers. Meanwhile, New Zealand shares fell 0.019% due to uncertainty over coalition talks, which may delay a government's direction.

site_title: At least 50 dead, more than 200 wounded in Las Vegas shooting
summary: A gunman killed at least 50 people and wounded over 200 at a country music festival on the Las Vegas Strip, making it the deadliest mass shooting in US history. Stephen Paddock, 64, was identified as the gunman and was shot dead by police. Authorities found multiple firearms and a possible accomplice, Marilou Danley, but no motive was confirmed. The attack occurred on the last night of the Route 91 Harvest festival, which was attended by thousands. One off-duty police officer was killed and another critically injured.

site_title: Euro-area economy shines through in year of political strain
summary: The euro area economy is experiencing its strongest expansion in a decade, driven by consumer and business confidence at its highest since the financial crisis. Despite political risks, such as the Catalan independence referendum, the economy is on track to grow 2.2% this year, according to the European Central Bank. This has led to increased investor confidence, with the Stoxx Europe 600 rising over 7% this year and European takeovers reaching $526 billion. However, some economists warn that the expansion may slow in the third quarter and decelerate further in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Japan ruling party pledge omits timing of primary surplus target
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) has omitted the deadline for returning to a primary budget surplus in its campaign platform. The platform also includes plans to raise the national sales tax as scheduled in October 2019, use revenue for childcare and welfare programs, revise the constitution to clarify the Self Defense Force's role, and offer free education and care to pre-schoolers. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has called a snap election for October 22.

site_title: Smartphones made in India? Manufacturing ambition hits hurdles
summary: India's ambitions to become a smartphone-making powerhouse are facing hurdles due to a lack of skilled labor and part suppliers, as well as a complex tax regime. Despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Make in India" drive, only a small percentage of high-end components are made domestically, with most phones assembled from imported components. The government has a phased programme to manufacture phones, aiming to step up value added locally every year, but industry executives warn that more needs to be done to attract investors and create a skilled workforce.

site_title: China's Geely group to take majority stake in Denmark's Saxo Bank
summary: China's Geely group will acquire a 51.5% stake in Denmark's Saxo Bank, with Finland's Sampo Oyj taking a 19.9% stake. Geely, owner of Volvo, will pay 265 million euros for its stake, matching Sampo's offer. Current shareholders TPG Capital and SinarMas have accepted the offers and will sell their shares. Saxo Bank's CEO Kim Fournais' 25.71% stake remains unchanged. The deal aims to expand Saxo Bank's technologies across Asia.

site_title: German factory growth surges in September: Markit
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector experienced its fastest growth in almost 6-1/2 years in September, with a 60.6 Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), surpassing the 50 line separating growth from contraction. The sector's expansion is expected to contribute to a growth in the third quarter. Strong demand from Asia fueled growth in orders, leading to new staff hires, but also resulted in increased delivery times, backlogs, and input prices, driving up cost inflation. Confidence among German manufacturers rebounded to a three-month high, with economists raising their forecast for the economy to grow by 1.9% this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Monday, down 0.37 point to 1755.22, with a trading volume of 157.95 million lots worth RM52.85 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 120 to 81.

site_title: Indonesia's Sept annual inflation rate eases, hits 6-month low
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate decreased to 3.72% in September, its lowest since March, due to a decline in food prices. On a monthly basis, consumer prices rose 0.13%. The core inflation rate, excluding food prices, stood at 3% from 2.98% in August. Bank Indonesia has cut its benchmark interest rate twice since August, signaling a pause in policy easing. This easing comes as the country aims to boost economic growth, which the governor deemed sufficient.

site_title: US retail mall vacancies up 8.3% in Q3: Reis
summary: US retail mall vacancies rose 8.3% in Q3 to 8.3% due to store closures of J C Penney and Sears Holdings Corp. Construction activity fell 49.2% with 1.63 million square feet of new construction completed. The trend is expected to continue with more store closures, including Toys R Us and The Gap. 10 retailers have filed for bankruptcy in 2017, surpassing the 2008 financial crisis. Asking rent and effective rent increased 0.4% and 0.5% respectively, while net absorption fell to 578,000 square feet.

site_title: Automakers plan electric car blitz even as Tesla burns billions
summary: Automakers plan to release almost 50 new electric car models globally between 2018 and 2022, despite Tesla's significant losses. Companies like Daimler AG, Volkswagen AG, and BMW are investing billions in electric vehicle development, driven by regulatory requirements and consumer demand. China's mandate for electric vehicle production is expected to boost sales, with the global market projected to surpass fossil fuel sales by 2040. However, concerns remain about consumer demand and the high cost of battery technology, which still makes electric cars a financial drain for many manufacturers.

site_title: 880,000 Singaporean households to receive GST voucher of up to $95 in October
summary: Singaporean households will receive a GST voucher of up to $95 to offset utilities bills starting in October. Households in 1- and 2-room flats will receive $95, while those in 3-room and 4-room flats will receive $85 and $75 respectively. The move aims to help low- to middle-income households with their utility costs.

site_title: How to respond to the challenge of AI
summary: The GIC Insights event, held on September 15, 2017, brought together 110 global business leaders to discuss Asia's role in an uncertain world. The theme included topics such as Asia's challenges and prospects, artificial intelligence for traditional industries, and a long-term future in an uncertain world. The event highlighted the need for businesses to adapt to the challenges posed by artificial intelligence, which was expected to transform traditional industries. The leaders emphasized the importance of developing AI solutions that benefit both businesses and society, and navigating the uncertainty of the future.

site_title: Australia home prices slow as Sydney suffers rare fall
summary: Australia's major cities saw a marginal rise in home prices for the second month in September, with a rare 0.1% decline in Sydney. The combined capital cities' annual growth slowed to 8.5%, from 9.7% in August. Tighter lending rules and higher interest rates are believed to be contributing to the slowdown. Melbourne's housing market, however, continued to outperform, with prices rising 0.9% in September. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to keep interest rates steady at its October policy meeting.

site_title: Emerging Towns & Cities taps Yoma Bank to offer home loans in Yangon project
summary: Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore (ETC Singapore) has partnered with Yoma Bank to offer home loans for its Golden City project in Yangon, Myanmar. The 15-year loan will cover up to 70% of the purchase price. The partnership comes as Myanmar's Condominium Law allows foreigners to buy property, expected to be passed soon. The Golden City project has generated returns of US$2,500 to US$3,000 per month for its luxury apartments, aiming to make high-end living more accessible to locals.

site_title: FLASH: Private home prices up for the first time after 15 quarters of decline: URA
summary: Singapore's private home prices have risen for the first time in 15 quarters, with a 0.5% increase in the third quarter of 2017. This follows a 0.1% drop in the previous quarter. The increase is attributed to a decrease in property prices.

site_title: Asian markets closed for holiday
summary: Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Mumbai, closed on October 2, 2017, for a public holiday. No relevant market data or news is provided in the given article.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly higher on Monday, tracking gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.16% to 20,388.93, while the Topix index increased 0.13% to 1,676.96. The Bank of Japan's quarterly Tankan survey showed business confidence hitting its highest level in a decade. This modest gain follows a broader Asian market rally, with Singapore stocks extending a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Fed eyes rates as asset-price tool in break with hands-off past
summary: The Federal Reserve is shifting its strategy to use interest rates as a tool to contain asset-price-driven financial instability, rather than maintaining a hands-off approach. Fed officials, including Chair Janet Yellen, are hinting at the need for more interest-rate hikes to address elevated asset prices and potential economic imbalances. The shift is a departure from the past, when the Fed focused on letting asset bubbles burst and cleaning up the mess afterwards. The Fed has penciled in one more rate hike for 2017 and three more for 2018, citing the need to keep the economy in balance and prevent financial instability.

site_title: Over 60% of Singapore-listed companies score well on cyber security: study
summary: A private study by cyber intelligence company Kinkayo found that 60% of Singapore-listed companies have little or no cyber exposure, exceeding the global average of 40%. This suggests that Singapore-listed firms are better prepared for cyber threats. The study's findings indicate that Singapore's companies have lower exposure to sensitive disclosure, exposed credentials, and hacker group activity compared to other markets. The results are a positive indicator for Singapore's cybersecurity efforts.

site_title: Singapore's STI open up on Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened at 3,234.49 points, up 14.58 points or 0.45% on Monday, following a Wall Street rally over the weekend. This is the first uptick in the private residential property market since 15 consecutive quarters of decline. DBS Bank, ST Engineering, and OCBC Bank were among top gainers. The Urban Redevelopment Authority reported a 0.5% increase in Singapore's private residential property index in Q3, marking the first quarterly rise.

site_title: Google unveils new moves to boost struggling news organisations
summary: Google has announced new measures to support struggling news organizations, replacing its decade-old "first click free" policy with a "flexible sampling" model that allows publishers to require subscriptions for some or all content. The new policy, effective worldwide, will allow publishers to decide whether to show articles at no cost or implement a paywall. Google will also work with publishers to simplify the subscription process, using data and machine learning to help recognize potential subscribers. The goal is to generate fresh revenues for publishers and provide high-quality journalism to users, with no intention to take a slice of subscription revenues.

site_title: Hong Kong shareholder buys remaining Golden Village Singapore stake after blocking mm2's bid
summary: Hong Kong's Orange Sky Golden Harvest Entertainment (Holdings) acquired the remaining 50% stake in Singapore's Golden Village cinema business, previously blocked by mm2 Asia's bid. Village Roadshow sold the stake for A$165 million, which will be used to reduce debt. The deal follows a failed attempt by mm2 Asia to purchase the stake in July, after failing to obtain Orange Sky's support. Completion is expected by year-end.

site_title: Australia shares up on positive China data, Beach Energy; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to 5,747, driven by positive factory data from China and Wall Street's previous session. The S&P/ASX 200 index saw its biggest intraday gain since July 13. Beach Energy surged 19.4% after acquiring assets from Origin Energy, while material stocks and financials also gained. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.03%. The gains were attributed to global growth recovery and low inflation supporting equity markets.

site_title: Disney, Altice reach deal that avoids ESPN blackout
summary: Disney and Altice USA reached a tentative deal to avoid an ESPN blackout, keeping the networks in millions of New York-area pay TV customers' homes. The deal secures fee increases for ESPN, ABC, and other major networks, averting a potential blackout that could have affected Tuesday's baseball playoff game and "Monday Night Football." The agreement came as Disney was preparing to pull its networks from Optimum, and Altice had offered higher fees but was met with Disney's proposal as "outrageous." The deal is part of Disney's efforts to negotiate with cable operators over the next two years.

site_title: US dollar stands tall against euro as investors watch Catalan vote aftermath
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro on Monday, gaining 0.1% to 93.192 on the US dollar index, as investors monitored the aftermath of a disputed independence vote in Spain's Catalonia. The euro edged down 0.1% to $1.1796. Meanwhile, Japan's manufacturers expressed confidence in their business outlook, boosting the yen. The US dollar is expected to be influenced by upcoming US data and the Federal Reserve's rate hike plans, with speculators holding a record net short position of $17.36 billion.

site_title: New ETF first to link to Singapore Reits
summary: The Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF, launched on October 2, 2017, is Singapore's first ETF dedicated to Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits). It offers low-cost access to high-quality S-Reits, providing a sustainable income stream and potential capital growth. The fund invests in 23 S-Reits, offering portfolio diversification and a lower correlation to other asset classes. It replicates the Morningstar Singapore Reit Yield Focus Index and declares dividends semi-annually, with a unit price of S$1 during the initial offer period.

site_title: Uber board is said to consider votes to cut ex-CEO's power
summary: Uber's board of directors is set to vote on reforms aimed at limiting the power of ousted CEO Travis Kalanick, who appointed two new board members despite the board's consideration of changes. The proposed reforms include equal voting power among shareholders, moving towards an initial public offering, and limiting Kalanick's influence. The moves come as Uber faces multiple challenges, including lawsuits, investigations, and sexual harassment allegations. The board's decision could drastically reshape the company's governance and potentially pave the way for a $10 billion stock sale to SoftBank.

site_title: Oil prices edge lower after strong third-quarter
summary: Oil prices edged lower on Monday after a strong third-quarter, with US crude down 2 cents at $51.65 a barrel and Brent crude down 6 cents at $56.73 a barrel. The third-quarter gain was the largest in five quarters, driven by anticipated demand from US refiners resuming operations after Hurricane Harvey. However, oil output from Opec rose by 50,000 barrels per day, led by increased Iraqi and Libyan exports, which may lead to lower prices.

site_title: Japan business confidence hits decade high: Bank of Japan
summary: Japan's business confidence has reached its highest level in a decade, according to the Bank of Japan's Tankan report, with major manufacturers showing a reading of 22. This marks the fourth consecutive quarter of improvement, driven by strong exports and investments linked to the Tokyo 2020 Olympics. The positive economic data comes ahead of Japan's national election on October 22, offering a boost to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS Group Research flags upside potential for Singtel
summary: DBS Group Research has flagged potential upside for Singtel's share price, citing a valuation discount compared to regional peers. Despite a 38% rise in regional telco stocks over the past three years, Singtel's shares have been flat due to mounting losses in digital businesses. The research notes a narrower digital loss forecast for FY18 and an earlier-than-expected earnings break-even for Singtel's digital advertising arm. DBS projects a target price of S$4.30, with a 17% upside, and special dividends of S$600 million to S$1.5 billion.

site_title: Women plead not guilty to murdering N Korea leader's half-brother
summary: Two women, Siti Aisyah of Indonesia and Doan Thi Huong of Vietnam, pleaded not guilty to murdering North Korea's half-brother Kim Jong Nam, who was poisoned with VX nerve agent at Kuala Lumpur airport in February. The trial is ongoing, with prosecutors claiming the women deliberately applied the poison, while defense lawyers argue the real culprits have left Malaysia. The case has sparked an international row between North Korea and Malaysia, with both countries expelling each other's ambassadors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GLP, Rotary, Noble, FSL Trust
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) announced a €2.4 billion (S$3.8 billion) acquisition of Gazeley, a leading European logistics platform. Rotary Engineering was proposed to be taken private by an investment arm of the Oman government, while Noble Group sold a unit to Mercuria Energy America Inc for US$102 million. FSL Trust's deal with Navios Maritime Holdings Inc to inject equity and debt financing is no longer on the table.

site_title: New Zealand's "kingmaker" to start talks with both major parties this week
summary: New Zealand First Party leader Winston Peters will begin talks with both the National Party and Labour Party this week, following the election where neither party won enough seats to govern alone. Peters' party won 9 seats, holding the balance of power. National Party leader Bill English has called Peters, and Labour leader Jacinda Ardern has also spoken with him, with plans to meet this week. The outcome is uncertain, with Peters' policies aligning more with Labour's, but also potentially opting for a simpler two-party coalition with National.

site_title: Digital disruption is not a zero-sum game
summary: GIC's annual thought leadership event, GIC Insights, discussed Asia's evolving role in an uncertain world. The event featured 110 global business leaders on topics such as Asia's challenges and prospects over the next decade, artificial intelligence, and a long-term future. A key takeaway from the event was that digital disruption is not a zero-sum game, implying that technological advancements can create opportunities for growth and innovation rather than solely replacing existing industries. This perspective highlights the potential for businesses to thrive in a rapidly changing world.

site_title: Catalan government says 90% voted to leave Spain
summary: In a banned referendum, 2.26 million Catalans voted 90% in favor of leaving Spain, with a 42.3% turnout. Police disrupted the vote, injuring over 800, and sparking a constitutional crisis. Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont said the region's citizens have "earned the right" to an independent state. Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy ruled out independence and called for talks, while critics, including the UK's Boris Johnson, condemned the police violence. The outcome sets the stage for a possible unilateral declaration of independence by the Catalan Parliament.

site_title: Facebook to give Russia-linked ads to US Congress on Monday
summary: Facebook plans to turn over to the US Congress on Monday copies of 3,000 ads bought on the social network by people in Russia likely in the months before and after the 2016 US election. The ads, which cost $100,000, amplified divisive US social and political messages, including support for Muslim voters and Black Lives Matter protests. The materials will be delivered to congressional investigators and may provide valuable clues for US investigators looking into alleged Russian election meddling. Facebook has already provided similar information to special counsel Robert Mueller.

site_title: Blow for India's RCom as wireless unit merger with Aircel collapses
summary: India's Reliance Communications Ltd faces another setback as a deal to merge its wireless business with Aircel collapses due to regulatory delays and legal uncertainties. The company, controlled by billionaire Anil Ambani, aims to reduce debt by 250 billion rupees by selling stakes in its mobile masts arm and merging its wireless business. The collapse raises doubts about its ability to repay debt, with investors concerned about potential haircuts to lenders. RCom has already earned a temporary reprieve from its lenders, but the collapse of the deal further complicates its debt repayment plans.

site_title: Euro jolted briefly by Spanish vote, Asia data augur well
summary: The euro briefly fell 1/3 of a US cent after the violence-marred independence vote in Spain's Catalonia, but steadied at $1.18. Strong economic data from China and Japan, including China's manufacturing activity growing at its fastest pace since 2012, supported equities and commodities. Asian shares rose, with Australia's main index jumping 1.1% and Japan's Nikkei inching up 0.1%. Copper prices rose for the fifth consecutive quarter, and Brent oil prices boasted their strongest third-quarter performance since 2004.

site_title: ARA's CEO named chairman of APREA
summary: John Lim, CEO of ARA Asset Management, has been elected chairman of the Asia Pacific Real Estate Association (APREA). Lim, who co-founded APREA and has over 30 years of real estate experience, aims to promote a more informed and connected marketplace in Asia. He plans to encourage greater access to information on modern real estate business models and practices, and build a bridge between established Western markets and Asia's emerging real estate opportunities.

site_title: HDB flash estimate for resale price index slips 0.6% q-o-q in Q3
summary: The Housing & Development Board's (HDB) resale price index for the third quarter slipped 0.6% compared to the second quarter, following a 0.1% decline in Q2 2017. Year-over-year, the index is down 1.3%. The decline is attributed to a decrease in resale price inquiries for older HDB flats, with sellers needing to lower prices to sell units quickly. Newer flats, with long lease remaining, continue to be supported by buyers. The HDB will release more detailed data on October 27, including the resale price index for the full third quarter.

site_title: Verstappen wins Malaysian F1 race after turning 20
summary: Max Verstappen won the Malaysian F1 race on his 20th birthday, finishing 12.7 seconds ahead of Lewis Hamilton, who secured second place and stretched his championship lead to 34 points. Sebastian Vettel, who started from last place, finished fourth after a collision with Lance Stroll. The victory marked Verstappen's second Grand Prix win, and he credited his car's performance for the success.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB upgrades Delfi to 'buy' following share price correction
summary: RHB has upgraded confectionery maker Delfi to "buy" from "neutral" despite weak Q2 results, citing a 31% correction in its share price. RHB expects a recovery in FY18 due to improved consumer spending and cost-cutting measures. The broker raised its target price to S$1.86, driven by Indonesia's planned increase in non-cash subsidies and Delfi's expanded distribution to convenience stores. Risks include a slow consumer sentiment recovery and increased competition.

site_title: Flash: HDB flash estimate of resale price index down 0.6 % q-on-q in Q3
summary: The HDB flash estimate of the resale price index fell 0.6% quarter-on-quarter in Q3, indicating a slowdown in Singapore's resale market. Meanwhile, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. This comes as US mortgage rates rose after five weeks of declines, affecting the global property market.

site_title: Gold drops to lowest in nearly 7 weeks; stronger US dollar, equities drag
summary: Gold prices dropped to nearly 7-week lows, falling 0.3% to $1,274.90 an ounce, as the US dollar strengthened and equities rose, amid growing expectations of a December interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The metal's biggest monthly decline this year occurred in September, despite a quarterly rise of 3%. The US dollar's rise and higher interest rates are weighing on gold, with some analysts predicting a range of $1,261-$1,267 per ounce.

site_title: Thai Sept headline consumer price index up 0.86% y-o-y, above forecast
summary: Thailand's annual headline consumer price index rose 0.86% in September, beating forecasts, for a third straight month. This is below the Bank of Thailand's target range of 0.6-4%. The central bank left its policy interest rate unchanged at 1.5% despite calls for a cut to address the baht's strength. The core CPI index rose 0.53%, and inflation has been contained by state price controls and soft domestic demand. The Bank of Thailand reviews monetary policy on November 8, with most analysts expecting no change for the rest of 2017.

site_title: Global Logistic to buy Gazeley for 2.4b euros
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) agreed to acquire European logistics platform Gazeley for approximately 2.4 billion euros (S$3.8 billion). Gazeley's portfolio consists of 32 million square feet of total gross leasable area, primarily in the UK, Germany, France, and the Netherlands. The deal, valued at 2.4 billion euros, is expected to increase GLP's earnings per share and add a premier operational and development platform in Europe.

site_title: Zuckerberg seeks forgiveness for division caused by his work
summary: Mark Zuckerberg asked for forgiveness on the Jewish holiday of atonement for ways his work at Facebook was used to divide people rather than bring them together. This comes amid increased scrutiny over Facebook's handling of paid political ads and its role in the 2016 US Presidential election campaign. An investigation by the US Department of Justice and several congressional committees has clouded President Trump's agenda. Facebook has launched an overhaul of its paid political ad policies and Zuckerberg expressed a commitment to doing better.

site_title: Private home prices end almost 4 years of decline: URA flash estimates
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) flash estimates show a 0.5% increase in private residential property prices in the third quarter, ending a 15-quarter decline. This marks the first uptick in the market since 2013. The increase is attributed to a 0.2% rise in Core Central Region, 0.7% in Outside Central Region, and 0.5% in the Rest of Central Region. The statistics are based on transaction prices and unit sales data up to mid-September, with full Q3 data to be released on October 27. This uptrend may signal a recovery in the private residential property market.

site_title: Cromwell's shelved IPO reflects market's preference for simpler fare
summary: Singapore's scrapped IPO of Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) suggests investors prefer simpler portfolios over complex ones. The Reit's portfolio, spanning six European countries with mixed ownership structures and varying fees, may have deterred potential investors. Despite Cromwell's Reit having a strong forward yield, investors were wary of the complexity, citing higher costs and lower occupancy rates. This may indicate Singapore's Reit market still needs to develop sophistication in evaluating non-straightforward securities.

site_title: Alliance Mineral halts shares pending announcement
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets has halted its shares pending an announcement, following a trading suspension in August to update on its reserves. The company's stock last traded at 30 Singapore cents on Friday. The halt does not provide further details on the nature of the announcement.

site_title: Drones - the terrorist threat that is being ignored
summary: The US government is increasingly concerned about the threat posed by drones to national security. Islamic State fighters in Iraq and Syria have used drones to menace US Special Operations forces, and experts warn that the technology is becoming increasingly accessible to terrorists. Commercial drones can be purchased online for the price of a flat-screen TV, and some are being modified to carry small bombs or toxic materials. The Trump administration has drafted legislation to enhance police powers in tracking civilian drones, but critics argue it may not be enough to address the growing threat.

site_title: Scotland leader Sturgeon 'concerned' at Catalonia scenes
summary: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon expressed concern over the violence in Catalonia, where dozens were injured in a banned independence referendum. Sturgeon backed the right to hold a vote on separation, calling for Spain to change course. The referendum is unconstitutional according to Spain's central government and courts. Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson also condemned the violence, urging authorities to exercise restraint. Demonstrations in Scotland, including a 500-person march in Edinburgh, showed support for Catalan independence.

site_title: Trump tells Tillerson North Korea outreach a waste of time
summary: President Donald Trump criticized Secretary of State Rex Tillerson for wasting time in seeking negotiations with North Korea, calling the approach "wasting his time" and referencing his predecessors' failed diplomatic efforts. Trump's comments came after Tillerson acknowledged direct US-North Korea talks and Tillerson's trip to Beijing to press China to bring Kim Jong Un to the negotiating table. The US remains open to diplomatic channels, with some officials suggesting that Trump's public criticism may have been a signal to China to continue pressure on North Korea.

site_title: Noble Group subsidiary completes sale of unit to Mercuria Energy America
summary: NOBLE Group's subsidiary, Noble Americas Corp, has completed the sale of Noble Americas Gas & Power Corp to Mercuria Energy America, Inc for US$102 million. The sale was initially announced on July 26, 2017. Additionally, Noble Group expects to complete the sale of its global oil liquids business by December 31, 2017.

site_title: Navios Maritime debt financing deal for FSL Trust called off
summary: Navios Maritime Holdings Inc has canceled a debt financing deal for FSL Trust, a shipping trust, after failing to sign definitive agreements by the agreed deadline of September 30, 2017. The deal, which included a $20 million second priority mortgage convertible loan, has been automatically terminated. FSL Trust stated that its trustee-manager will continue to pursue refinancing to ensure long-term stability. The company's share price fell 0.1 cents to 8.9 Singapore cents following the news.

site_title: Scores hurt as riot police crack down on banned Catalan vote
summary: Spanish riot police used batons and rubber bullets to crack down on a banned Catalan independence referendum, injuring at least 92 people and sparking clashes. The referendum, which asked if Catalonia should become an independent state, was organized in secret and was banned by Madrid. Despite the violence, thousands of Catalans defied the central government and voted, with many reporting peaceful voting in some areas. Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy called the referendum a "farce" and suggested he would negotiate with Catalonia to try to satisfy the region's demands for greater autonomy.

site_title: Chinese border trading hub struggles amid North's troubles
summary: China's border city of Dandong struggles with a housing glut due to international sanctions on North Korea. The city's properties, including unsold apartments in the New Zone, have remained in high inventory, with 28.8 months needed to work through the current surplus. The sanctions have prevented trade and tourism with North Korea, affecting Dandong's planned developments, including a sports centre, concert hall, and hospital. The city's housing prices have remained stagnant, unlike other major Chinese cities, where prices have increased by double-digit percentages.

site_title: Shining a spotlight on the secret life of entrepreneurs
summary: Singaporean entrepreneurs and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face hardship, but support from loved ones, staff, and family can help them get through difficult times. Three companies, Secretlab, Greenology, and Ace Water, won top honours at the 2017 Emerging Enterprise Awards, with prizes worth at least S$340,000 each. The awards celebrate promising young businesses that have achieved success despite challenges, and their winners have demonstrated entrepreneurial spirit, ingenuity, and perseverance.

site_title: 20% of serious food safety violations in US are ignored
summary: US government inspectors failed to take action on nearly one in five serious food safety risks identified in manufacturing facilities, according to a report by federal auditors. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) asked food manufacturers to correct violations voluntarily in the remaining cases. The agency's inspection data from 2011 to 2015 showed that only 78% of major food safety violations were addressed, with over 300 cases ignored. The FDA has acknowledged the issues and committed to improving its inspection process, but concerns remain about funding and resources to fulfill the agency's expanded mission.

site_title: A look at valuations and reasons to buy - or sell
summary: Singapore stocks face a challenging market environment, with valuations at a high level and a lack of clarity on investment decisions. The local market has enjoyed a stellar first half, but it's becoming difficult to justify continued buying. Valuations are high, with the Straits Times Index trading at a price-earnings ratio of 11, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average are trading at 22 and 19, respectively. Despite improving economic numbers, investors have not responded significantly, and a re-rating of stocks could lead to a buying frenzy.

site_title: Build homes for the homeless? Sure, just not in my backyard
summary: A proposed 49-unit homeless shelter in Los Angeles' Boyle Heights neighborhood has been blocked by a City Council committee amid opposition from local residents citing environmental and safety concerns. The project, backed by a nonprofit organization, aims to raise $1.2 billion to build 10,000 units of housing for the homeless over the next decade. Despite a 2017 vote supporting a $1.2 billion housing bond, the project faces significant hurdles, highlighting the challenges of developing housing for the homeless in Los Angeles. The standoff may impact the city's efforts to address its growing homelessness crisis.

site_title: Hot stock: Rotary gains 9.8% as major shareholders bid S$0.46/share to delist
summary: The controlling family of Rotary Engineering, led by the Chia Family, has teamed up with the Oman government's investment arm to take the company private through a S$0.46 per share cash offer. The offer, made through Orochem Pte Ltd, represents a 25% premium over the company's net tangible asset value and a 62% premium over its net asset value. The offer will close at least 14 days after the offer documents are despatched, with DBS Bank serving as sole adviser for the delisting. Rotary's shares gained 9.8% to close at 45 Singapore cents.

site_title: Becoming a regional hub for digital and smart factories
summary: Singapore should position itself as a hub for digital and smart factories by leveraging its strengths in R&D capabilities, connectivity, and innovation. The city-state should focus on growing talent and equipping them with necessary skills to fully leverage advanced manufacturing technologies. By embracing predictive capabilities and building a local talent pipeline, Singapore can remain competitive in the electronics manufacturing sector. Experts emphasize the need for collaboration among multinational corporations, local SMEs, and startups, as well as the government's role in driving policy action on competitiveness, capabilities, and connectedness.

site_title: China unveils plan for targeted lending to aid growth
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), plans to reduce the amount of cash lenders must hold as reserves from next year, with cuts ranging from 0.5 to 1.5 percentage points depending on the amount of business with small enterprises, agricultural borrowers, and startups. The move aims to encourage lending to these sectors ahead of the 19th Party Congress and is seen as a structural adjustment, not a shift in monetary policy. The targeted reduction is expected to free up about 600-700 billion yuan of funding.

site_title: Chinese investors bemoan Beijing's bitcoin crackdown
summary: China's central bank has shut down bitcoin trading platforms, leaving investors to cut their losses. The decision, made in mid-September, has shaken global bitcoin prices and disrupted the local market. The ban affects platforms like Okcoin and BTC China, which accounted for 22% of global bitcoin volume. Investors are now seeking alternative ways to acquire virtual currencies, including private transactions on messaging apps. The ban is seen as a response to concerns over speculation and capital flight, which the government aims to curb.

site_title: Viking warrants deserve a new review
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine's warrants rose to S$0.004, up from S$0.001, on a volume of 2.1 million, following a renounceable and non-underwritten two-for-five rights issue in May. The warrants have a five-year life span and can be exercised at any time. Despite being out-of-the-money, they offer a 81.25% conversion premium and 4x gearing. The company raised funds for partial loan repayment and working capital. The warrants' rise may indicate market interest, but it's unclear if it will lead to concrete developments.

site_title: Social media and democracy: optimism fades as fears rise
summary: Social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter are facing growing concerns that authoritarian governments are using them to suppress dissent and manipulate public opinion. The latest revelations from Facebook and Twitter have highlighted the use of Russian-backed entities to spread disinformation and sow discord. Researchers warn that social networks have become tools for social control, with governments using bots and paid employees to create an artificial sense of popularity and muddy the online waters with misinformation. The impact on democracy is being felt, with the US election being a prime example of how social media can be manipulated to influence public opinion and polarize the electorate.

site_title: Uber may be under CPIB probe over car buys: industry talk
summary: Uber's majority-owned car rental company, Lion City Rental (LCR), may be under investigation by Singapore's Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) over car purchases made from parallel importers. LCR, which has a fleet of 15,000 private-hire cars, has acquired some models from unauthorized distributors. The CPIB has reportedly contacted former and/or current Uber staff over the issue, but Uber has declined to comment on rumors or speculation. This comes as Uber faces a US federal probe into suspicious activity in several Asian countries.

site_title: Healthcare sector upside to come from regional earnings
summary: The healthcare sector in Singapore is expected to experience an upside in earnings, driven by regional expansion and the perception of being "recession-proof" due to the growing demand for healthcare services among Asia's rapidly ageing populations. Despite underperforming the rest of the market this year, healthcare stocks trade at premium valuations, with smaller-cap companies such as Singapore Medical Group and Singapore O&G trading at higher price-to-earnings (P/E) ratios. Analysts predict that re-rating catalysts, including a better economic outlook and new expansions, could lead to a potential recovery in earnings growth.

site_title: Pay close attention to the US Fed
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced a balance sheet reduction, starting with a $10 billion monthly reduction from October, despite not raising the Federal Funds Rate as expected. This move signals a hawkish tone, but a prolonged rate hike cycle often ends in crisis and market downturn. A similar pattern occurred during the dotcom bubble and housing boom, with the Fed's rate hikes preceding significant sell-offs in the S&P 500. As the current rate hike cycle continues, the market is advised to remain cautious and consider the "buy the dip" strategy until a dovish shift in sentiment occurs.

site_title: Rethinking the future of work - now
summary: Industry leaders emphasize the need for strong leadership, employee ownership of professional development, and embracing change to adapt to the future of work. Disruptive technologies like AI and the gig economy are expected to significantly impact both employees and employers. While some predict job elimination, others note that new jobs are being created, augmented, and partially replaced. To succeed, employees must leverage their value to organizations, and leaders must develop new competencies to manage and communicate in a global, digital economy. Organizations must also rethink processes and create lifelong learning opportunities.

site_title: Lehman, Citigroup settle US$2 billion financial crisis-era dispute
summary: Citigroup and the estate of Lehman Brothers have settled a long-standing dispute over $2.1 billion, with Citigroup agreeing to return $1.74 billion to Lehman's estate. The settlement resolves a 10-year-old bankruptcy case and sheds light on the frenzied weekend before Lehman's bankruptcy filing in 2008. Lehman accused Citigroup of concocting the claim and using "phantom transaction costs" to justify its claim, while Citigroup maintained it followed accepted standards on closing out trades. The deal is a boon for Lehman's unsecured creditors and avoids a potential public ruling on derivatives trading practices.

site_title: IBM's second home, half a world away
summary: IBM has shifted its global operations to India, employing 130,000 people, about one-third of its total workforce, with work spanning various fields including artificial intelligence, computer vision, and research. The company has expanded its presence in India since 2007, nearly doubling its workforce, while its US workforce has shrunk due to layoffs and buyouts. IBM's Indian operations are a microcosm of the company, and its expansion has been vital in keeping costs down. However, this trend has raised concerns about the impact of globalization and offshoring on US jobs, with US President Donald Trump criticizing the company for laying off Americans and moving jobs to India.

site_title: Australia's housing boom over
summary: Australia's housing market has officially ended its boom, with national house prices remaining unchanged in October from September and annual growth slowing to 7% from over 10% in July. The slowdown suggests tightening financial conditions, weighing on consumption growth. This news is welcomed by first-time buyers, but may negatively impact property investors already squeezed by regulatory lending curbs. The Reserve Bank may keep interest rates at a record low to avoid further downward pressure on dwelling prices.

site_title: Helping financial institutions become future-ready
summary: UBS Wealth Management Asia-Pacific head Edmund Koh praises the Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) for helping UBS Singapore prepare for future challenges, citing the IBF's accreditation of UBS's internal certification programs and the Wealth Management Institute's Anti-Money Laundering Risk Management program. This collaboration reinforces Singapore's position as a top financial center, Koh notes.

site_title: NTUC Income rolls out insurance sector's first self-service digital platform for startups
summary: NTUC Income has launched Start.Sure, the insurance sector's first self-service digital platform for startups. The platform is designed for new startups with 2-15 full-time staff to purchase and manage employee benefit insurance. Start.Sure offers three plans catering to different life stages and scales, aiming to provide a reliable and accessible insurance solution for Singapore's young entrepreneurs. The platform is a result of NTUC Income's commitment to supporting the startup community, in partnership with NTUC U Startup.

site_title: Five injured, Somalian suspect arrested as Canada probes 'act of terrorism'
summary: A 30-year-old Somalian man, Abdulahi Hasan Sharif, was arrested in Canada after a high-speed chase in a rented truck that injured four people, including a police officer. The incident, which occurred in Edmonton, was described as a "terrorist attack" by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. Authorities found an Islamic State flag in one of the vehicles, leading them to investigate the incident as a potential act of terrorism. Sharif had applied for asylum and was known to the security services, but authorities did not pursue terrorism charges due to insufficient evidence.

site_title: Oil market stars risk being dimmed by giant version 2.0 in China
summary: China's independent refiners, known as "teapots," are facing a new generation of firms building massive petrochemical plants, threatening to eclipse them. The new plants, supported by regional governments, will focus on producing petrochemicals, not fuels, and are expected to increase global supply. The first of these plants, Rongsheng Petrochemical Co's $24 billion refinery in Zhejiang province, is set to come online in 2018, rivaling major energy companies like Royal Dutch Shell. This shift could disrupt oil markets worldwide, as the new plants gain access to deep-water ports, reducing freight costs and increasing their ability to import long-haul crudes.

site_title: APAC Realty debuts; Yanlord leads buyback tally
summary: APAC Realty debuted on the Mainboard with an offer price of S$0.660 per share, ending its first session up 15% at S$0.760 per share. Yanlord Land Group led the buyback tally with 1,684,900 shares purchased at S$1.662 and S$1.815 per share over the five sessions. The Straits Times Index (STI) added 0.4% in the same period, bringing its dividend-inclusive return for 2017 to 15.3%. Other notable transactions include CapitaLand Commercial Trust's director acquiring 30,000 units of CapitaLand CCT and Mapletree Logistics Trust's independent director purchasing 100,000 units of MLT.

site_title: May insists UK government united on her Brexit policy
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is battling to assert her authority over a divided Conservative Party amid calls to quit as leader. Despite Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson's public demands for a different Brexit policy, May insists her cabinet is united on her Brexit plan. Johnson reportedly believes May will be gone within a year, but she remains committed to fighting the next general election. The party's instability raises concerns about the Brexit negotiations and potential leadership changes.

site_title: Ex-Uber chief reignites board battle by appointing two new directors
summary: Uber co-founder Travis Kalanick has appointed two new directors, Ursula Burns and John Thain, in a surprise move that reignites a board battle over his role. The move comes after new CEO Dara Khosrowshahi's plan to restructure the board and gain greater control, which could dilute Kalanick's power. Kalanick, a largest shareholder, claims he acted to ensure the full board could deliberate on the proposal, which would give Khosrowshahi control of four board seats. The move could lead to a new legal challenge, with Benchmark Capital potentially blocking the appointments.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore's MAS and PBOC to enhance green and transition finance collaboration. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long as her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a Mumbai launch event. Citigroup set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Moya Holdings Asia thirsty for more Indonesia acquisitions
summary: Moya Holdings Asia, a water company, has acquired fellow Indonesian water company Acuatico for $92.87 million, becoming the largest water company in Indonesia. The acquisition has helped Moya reverse its losses to record a net profit of $2.5 million in the first half of the year, with revenue quadrupling year-on-year. CEO Simon Melhem expects further growth through greater efficiencies and savings, and the company is not done with acquisitions, targeting operating assets to expand its bottom line. Moya's share price has more than doubled since the beginning of the year, and the company is well-positioned to compete in the Indonesian water market, which is 15 years behind China's in terms of development.

site_title: China's growth slower than expected in October
summary: China's manufacturing sector experienced slower-than-expected growth in October, with the PMI falling to 51.6, its weakest reading in three months. The decline was attributed to tighter pollution rules forcing factories to curtail production, as well as weaker export orders. China's economy has recorded better-than-expected growth of nearly 6.9% this year, but the slowdown raises concerns about the government's ability to sustain high-quality growth without stimulus measures.

site_title: US energy secretary seeks incentives for coal, nuclear plants
summary: US Energy Secretary Rick Perry has asked federal regulators to offer incentives to keep coal and nuclear power plants open, citing grid resilience and reliability. The proposal aims to reward plants with at least 90 days of fuel supply on site, allowing them to recover costs through regulated pricing. The move has drawn praise from the coal and nuclear industries, but raised concerns from renewable energy groups and environmentalists about increased emissions and waste.

site_title: Macau casino scion rolls dice on Japan venture
summary: Lawrence Ho, son of Macau gaming legend Stanley Ho, is planning to invest in Japan's untapped gambling market, seeking to expand his family's reach beyond Macau. His father transformed Macau into a gaming boom town, and Lawrence aims to replicate this success in Japan.

site_title: Puerto Rico's hurricane destruction lights the way for new energy
summary: Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico's power grid, leaving millions without electricity. Federal funds may be used to modernize the grid, shifting away from imported coal and oil and towards local wind, solar, and batteries. US Senator Ron Wyden's bills aim to make the grid more resilient to natural disasters, offering grants for small-scale renewable projects. Government support is crucial, as Puerto Rico's utility, Prepa, is $9 billion in debt and relies heavily on imported fuel. Renewable energy companies see an opportunity to take over market share, and Tesla is sending batteries to provide emergency help.

site_title: Services to replace electronics in growth limelight
summary: Singapore's services sector has shown a significant leap in business optimism, with a 9% net weighted balance of businesses expecting improved conditions, according to a survey by the Economic Development Board and Singstat. The sector's optimism is higher than the 5% seen a quarter ago, while the manufacturing sector showed a modest improvement with a 5% net weighted balance. However, the electronics cluster, a key driver of growth, showed the greatest pessimism, with 11% of businesses expecting a less favorable operating environment.

site_title: South Korea's exports surge on strong demand for steel, semiconductors
summary: South Korea's exports surged 35% in September to a record high, driven by strong demand for steel, semiconductors, and petrochemical products. Shipments jumped across 13 major categories, with semiconductors experiencing a 70% increase. The trade surplus reached $13.8 billion, and month-on-month growth in exports was the most since January 2011. However, economists predict export growth will slow from October due to the US Federal Reserve's balance sheet reduction and other central banks' monetary stimulus reduction.

site_title: New Zealand's ban on foreign home-buyers to start early 2018
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced a ban on foreign buyers of existing homes starting early 2018, but not for Australians. The move aims to reduce demand and address the country's housing crisis, where prices have risen over 50% in the last decade. The ban will be introduced as legislation by December 25 and will not affect the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal. Ardern hopes to preserve rights for New Zealanders and make it easier for locals to buy their first homes.

site_title: Growing and succeeding in the cognitive era
summary: IBM's PartnerWorld program is helping businesses in Singapore and elsewhere develop innovative solutions in the "cognitive era" of artificial intelligence and thinking technology. Partners are leveraging IBM's cloud capabilities to create new revenue streams, such as smarter hotel recommendations and a locker ledger network for delivery. Solutions like RetailSmart and Talview are also being developed, with IBM providing scalable cloud and SaaS-driven solutions. These innovations have wide-reaching positive spin-offs, including improved customer experiences and enhanced security, with IBM Business Partners seeing success and growth in the region.

site_title: HK Land eyes mainland China, Singapore to drive growth
summary: Hong Kong Land, a property investment and development group, is seeking growth in South-east Asia and mainland China due to limited prime office space in Hong Kong. The company has seen significant growth in its markets in Singapore and mainland China over the past 10 years, with underlying profit increasing 32% year-on-year to $517 million in the first half of 2017. Hongkong Land aims to develop premium residential and commercial properties, and benefits from a strong retail sector in mainland China and stable office and residential markets in Singapore.

site_title: Preparing for a changing landscape
summary: The financial services industry is undergoing significant changes, driven by technological advancements, regulatory shifts, and shifting client demands. Key changes include the rise of non-traditional players, increased focus on consumer protection, and the need for banks to adapt to digital offerings. To succeed, professionals require a range of skills, including digital literacy, creativity, and critical thinking. Talent acquisition and development are also critical, with a focus on grooming and nurturing talent to drive competitive advantage. The industry must balance the need for innovation with the need for caution, as seen in the increasing focus on risk management and prudent decision-making.

site_title: Helping the elderly - in life and death
summary: A Singaporean company, Direct Life Foundation (DLF), was established in 2015 after an elderly man expressed his fear of dying alone without anyone discovering his decomposing body. The organization, under Direct Funeral Services (DFS), connects the elderly with volunteers through activities like free haircuts and outings, aiming to build a "kampong community" where residents can support each other. DLF advocates filial piety and aims to minimize cases of abandonment, while DFS provides pro bono funeral services to the underprivileged. The company's mission is to serve the elderly and volunteers, not just as a business, but as a way of life.

site_title: Qatar Airways will groom Meridiana to be Italy's top national carrier
summary: Qatar Airways has acquired a 49% stake in Meridiana's parent company, AQA Holding, to back the Italian airline's expansion. Meridiana will receive widebody and narrowbody jets to grow its network, with deliveries starting in six months. The airline will relaunch with new branding and aircraft, and Qatar Airways' CEO, Akbar al-Baker, aims to "massively grow" Meridiana to become Italy's top national carrier.

site_title: Washington finds it easier to lure millennials than to keep them
summary: Washington D.C. struggles to retain millennials, with a new analysis finding that more people are leaving the region than arriving since the Great Recession. The city's tech scene, once a draw for young workers, is no longer enough to keep them. Many are moving to lower-priced cities with better job prospects, and some are even moving back home. The trend is expected to have long-term consequences, complicating efforts to diversify the region's economy. The city's inability to retain talent is attributed to rising rents outpacing salary growth, making it difficult for young professionals to afford a decent quality of life.

site_title: Climate change lands at the airport
summary: Climate change is forcing airport planners to rethink their infrastructure, as rising sea levels and heat waves pose significant challenges. Dozens of airports worldwide are at risk, with low-lying airports vulnerable to storm surges and hot temperatures causing tarmac damage and weight restrictions. Investments of over $1.1 trillion are planned or underway to address these issues, with some airports already taking proactive measures, such as building sea walls and drainage systems. Experts warn that climate change could push airport infrastructure to its limits, posing a long-term economic challenge for airports.

site_title: China, S Korea agree to mend fences after Thaad standoff
summary: China and South Korea agreed to mend fences after a year-long standoff over the US Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) system, a dispute that hurt South Korean businesses relying on Chinese consumers. The deal comes ahead of US President Donald Trump's Asia trip, where the North Korean nuclear crisis will be a focus. China had expressed concerns over the Thaad system's radar capabilities, but the two sides agreed to strengthen exchange and cooperation, boosting South Korean stocks to a record high. The thaw is expected to benefit South Korean tourism, retail, and entertainment industries.

site_title: Migrant Filipina mothers in HK sing for their distant children
summary: A choir of Filipina domestic workers in Hong Kong, known as the "Unsung Heroes," performs on Sundays, singing songs that remind them of their children left behind. The choir, formed by Jane Engelmann three years ago, aims to overcome daily struggles and show pride in their work. The theme of maternal sacrifice runs through their performances, with songs written specifically for them. The choir's success story is featured in a new documentary, "The Helper," which also portrays the emotional toll of leaving children behind, highlighting the struggles faced by Hong Kong's domestic workers, many of whom are from the Philippines and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Filipina domestic workers who are members of the "Unsung Heroes" choir taking part in a practice session inside a kindergarten school's classroom in Hong Kong.

site_title: Carmakers rush to put Saudi women behind wheels of their models
summary: Saudi Arabia has lifted its ban on women drivers, with carmakers racing to capitalize on the move. Companies such as Ford, Tata Motors, Volkswagen, and BMW have released social media campaigns and advertisements to woo potential female drivers. The change is part of a larger effort to modernize and diversify the kingdom's economy, potentially adding $90 billion to economic output by 2030. Carmakers are now looking to offer smaller models for single working women and female students, while ride-hailing services like Uber may see a decline.

site_title: IMO taking steps to cut greenhouse gas emissions by shipping sector
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is considering bringing forward measures to cut greenhouse gas emissions from shipping by 30% by 2022, three years ahead of the original target. This comes as the IMO aims to halve emissions by 2050 to align with the COP21 Climate Change pact. The organization has already implemented energy efficiency standards since 2013 and is also considering a global sulphur cap to curb emissions of sulphur dioxide. The move is seen as a step towards reducing emissions from the shipping sector, which is a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Energy-rich Gulf states say goodbye to their tax-free reputation
summary: The six Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) states, including the UAE and Saudi Arabia, will introduce value-added tax (VAT) in 2018, marking a significant change to their tax-free reputation. The VAT, set at 5%, aims to revitalize the region's economies, which have been hit by a global supply glut and a drop in oil prices. However, the move is expected to increase prices across the board, affecting citizens and low-income workers, who will see their budgets affected. The introduction of VAT is seen as a step towards ending the region's decades-long reputation as tax havens.

site_title: P&G faces uphill fight with Peltz after proxy firms back him
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) faces a tougher fight in its proxy battle against Nelson Peltz, a billionaire investor seeking a board seat, after prominent firms Institutional Shareholder Services and Glass Lewis endorsed him. ISS and Glass Lewis cited P&G's "suffocating bureaucracy" and past missteps, such as failed CEO succession and divested brands. P&G has scheduled a webcast to convince investors to reject Peltz's bid, arguing that his presence would derail progress. The outcome may be uncertain, with many institutional investors relying on ISS and Glass Lewis' advice when voting in proxy fights.

site_title: SBI Offshore gets legal adviser's final report on past deals involving associate firm
summary: SBI Offshore's board should weigh the costs and benefits of taking legal proceedings over conflicting agreements on the acquisition and disposal of a 35% stake in Jiangyin Neptune Marine Appliance Co. A final report by UniLegal LLC suggests there may not be direct financial losses from the discrepancies. The report does not recommend Interrogatories Before Action against key shareholders and former CEOs, and instead advises against pursuing the matter further "for now".

site_title: Asia: Markets rise after Wall Street gains
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday following overnight gains on Wall Street, driven by solid US economic data, rising oil prices, and strong earnings reports. Tokyo led the rally, with tech shares surging as exporters benefited from a weak yen. Other markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and South Korea, also rose, with key players like Sony, Honda, and Samsung Electronics announcing positive results. The US Federal Reserve meeting result, expected to be published after Asian markets close, will be closely watched for indications of a potential December interest rate hike.

site_title: Loyz Energy to issue 77m new shares to Arctos Investments for joint venture
summary: Loyz Energy will issue 76.6 million new shares to Arctos Investments Pte Ltd at 1.305 Singapore cents apiece as part of a joint venture to diversify into fund management, investment, and trading. Arctos will own 5.02% and 4.78% of Loyz Energy's existing and enlarged share capital, respectively, with no consideration paid. This move will not raise any proceeds for the company.

site_title: Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF debuts with initial AUM of S$100m
summary: The Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF, launched on the Singapore Exchange, has garnered an initial assets under management (AUM) of over S$100 million, exceeding its initial target of S$40-50 million. The ETF, jointly issued by Lion Global Investors and Phillip Capital Management, was well-received by investors, with Lion Global CEO Gerard Lee expressing encouragement over the investor response.

site_title: Q&M Dental acquires HK's CJ Group with seven clinics to expand business in region
summary: Q&M Dental Group has acquired 60% of CJ Group (Holding) for HK$4 million (S$698,000) to expand its business in the Hong Kong region. The acquisition includes seven fully operational dental clinics, six in Hong Kong and one in Shenzhen, China. The deal is subject to conditions, including a restructuring and due diligence exercise. The acquisition aims to enhance Q&M's presence in the region and provide additional dental services to patients.

site_title: Ghana wakes up and smells the coffee
summary: Ghana has seen a resurgence in its coffee production, with the country's coffee farmers hopeful of growing a major cash crop. Introduced in the 18th century, coffee production in Ghana has rebounded in recent years due to growing demand and a domestic market. A government scheme launched in 2011 to revive the sector has led to the establishment of new and revitalized coffee plantations, with farmers attracted by fair prices. Ghanaian coffee is a matter of heritage and personal pride for farmers, and efforts are being made to connect local cafes with local sellers, aiming to establish Ghanaian beans in the home market.

site_title: Populist Britain goes gaga over unabashed elitist
summary: British populist Jacob Rees-Mogg, known for his elitist views and eccentric behavior, is being considered as a potential leader of the Conservative Party. Despite his conservative views on abortion and gay marriage, voters have been drawn to his "authentic" and "straight-talking" nature. Rees-Mogg's rise to prominence began with his strong stance on Brexit and has been fueled by his popularity among young voters. However, some party members have expressed concerns about his views, with one columnist calling him an "unfailing, unbending, unrelenting reactionary." Rees-Mogg has denied any ambition for the leadership, but his popularity shows no signs of waning.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on oil talks boost; NZ gains most since Sept 26
summary: Australian shares rose 13.743 points to 5,916.90, driven by a rise in oil prices to their highest in over two years. The market recovered from a 0.2% drop on Friday, following a court ruling that made Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce ineligible for his parliamentary seat. Financials led the gains, with banking stocks benefiting from a regulatory investigation into the rigging of the bank bill swap reference rate.

site_title: Tennis: Swiss great Hingis quits for third and 'final' time
summary: Swiss tennis great Martina Hingis announced her "definite" retirement at 37, marking her third and final career exit. She cited perfect timing, ending on a high note with a potential semi-final win at the WTA Finals in Singapore. Hingis, a former world number one and 20-time major title winner, will remain involved in the sport, possibly as a coach, and expressed gratitude for her career, saying "I couldn't ask for a better finish."

site_title: Hot stock: OCBC slips in early-morning trade
summary: OCBC's shares slipped 2 cents to $11.53 in early morning trade after reporting a 12% increase in net profit for the third quarter, driven by a 12% growth in net interest income. The bank also saw a 40% increase in specific allowances for loans, primarily due to weakness in the oil-and-gas segment. Despite this, OCBC reported "sustained momentum" across its key markets.

site_title: Big changes to Pacific trade deal may not be possible before Apec meeting: NZ minister
summary: New Zealand's trade minister, David Parker, says significant changes to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) may not be possible before the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) meeting in Vietnam. The Labour-led government plans to renegotiate the agreement due to its opposition to foreign ownership of existing houses, a key campaign promise. Trade officials warn that late changes may not be feasible, and Parker suggests focusing on domestic law to achieve the goal, potentially overriding the TPP rules.

site_title: Industry digital plan lends Singapore logistics SMEs a hand
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has unveiled the Industry Digital Plan (IDP) to support small and medium-sized logistics businesses. The plan aims to guide SMEs in participating in projects and national initiatives that can benefit the entire industry. It provides step-by-step advice on digital solutions and a self-assessment checklist to help SMEs identify their digital readiness and opportunities. The plan includes initiatives such as in-mall distribution, federated lockers, and the National Trade Platform, aiming to uplift the logistics sector as a whole.

site_title: Heineken beer sales rise on strength outside Europe, US
summary: Heineken reported a 2.5% increase in third-quarter beer sales, excluding acquisitions, to 60.0 million hectolitres. Growth was seen in all regions except Europe, where poor summer weather reduced demand, and the US.
